Now Prada is expanding: in 2012 it opened new stores in Abu Dhabi and Kuwait. Now, the company is reportedly seeking a partner to enter India. In May 2012, the normally publicity-shy Prada received recognition on the artistic side of business, with an exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art entitled 'Schiaparelli and Prada: Impossible Conversations.'
title: Owner, Fashion Designer

name: Billionaires
bio: The legendary buyout titan, who is known as much for his multiple marriages as his deals, has an assortment of investments, including stakes in cosmetic giant Revlon, production house Deluxe Entertainment, lottery outfit Scientific Games and Humvee maker AM General, over which he is currently locked in a legal dispute with fellow billionaire Ira Rennert. Perelman bought into AM General in 2004 for $110 million, and has since received distributions totaling $1.7 billion. In December 2011, Perelman successfully took liquorice and check producer M&F Worldwide private, buying out the shares he didn't already own at $25 apiece. Perelman, who was once married to actress Ellen Barkin, married for the fifth time in 2010 and recently welcomed his eighth child, the second with current wife Dr. Anna Chapman. Wharton graduate began learning the buyout business from his father, attending board meetings when he was in elementary school. His first solo deal came in 1978 when he bought a stake in jewelry distributor Cohen-Hatfield, selling the company 7 years later to Sam Walton. In July 2012, Perelman, who supported Hilary Clinton in 2008, hosted a fundraiser for Mitt Romney at his Georgica Pond estate in East Hampton. In 2008 a $50 million gift from Perelman to New York Presbyterian Hospital and Weill Cornell Medical Center established the Ronald O. Perelman Heart Institute. In February, he gave $25 million to the University of Pennsylvania, his alma mater, for the construction of a new home for the university's economics and political science departments.

name: Billionaires
bio: Anne Cox Chambers is the surviving daughter of Cox Enterprises founder James M. Cox (d. 1957). James Cox started the company in 1898 when he purchased the Dayton Evening News for $26,000. Today the company includes Cox Communications (broadband and cable), Cox Media Group (newspapers, TV and ration stations), Manheim (car auctions), and AutoTrader.com. In January the company cancelled plans to take AutoTrader.com public, citing current market conditions. At age 93 Chambers continues to sit on the board. Her nephew, Jim Kennedy, is chairman. She was ambassador to Belgium under President Jimmy Carter and holds the French Legion of Honor title. Atlanta's High Museum of Art named a wing after her.

name: Billionaires
bio: Stefan Quandt, son of the late Herbert Quandt, inherited a 17.4% stake in German automaker BMW. He sits on the company's supervisory board along with sister Susanne Klatten, who is also a billionaire. Their mother Johanna Quandt also owns a slice of BMW and sports a multi-bilion dollar fortune. Stefan Quandt, a trained engineer, also owns and manages Delton AG, a pharmaceutical company with about $2 billion in sales, plus a stake in Data Card, a smart card maker. In 2012 he bought 94% of bankrupt solar module maker Solarwatt and invested alongside financial services group RHJ International, private equity firm BlackRock and Chinese conglomerate Fosun to buy Deutsche Bank subsidiary BHF Bank for about $500 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Malaysian tycoon Ananda Krishnan's shrewd dealmaking boosted his fortune by $1.7 billion, helping him retain status as country's second richest person after Robert Kuok. He sold a small stake in listed telecom firm Maxis, his biggest asset. Reportedly a deal with Russia's Sistema to sell his holding in Indian telecom outfit Aircel fell through.  Last October, he relisted the domestic business of pay -TV  operator Astro which he'd taken private in 2010, raising $1.5 billion. In separate deals, he sold the power and gaming businesses of privately-held unit Tanjong, for over $3 billion. Shares of his offshore services provider Bumi Armada are up by nearly one-fifth since its 2011 listing. His only son is a Buddhist monk in Thailand.

name: Billionaires
bio: When 87-year-old Julio Mario Santo Domingo Pumarejo died in October 2011, his son Alejandro Santo Domingo Davila, 36, became the face of his father's Santo Domingo Group. A Harvard history grad, Alejandro is the eldest son from the jet-setting beer magnate's second marriage. In 2005, Julio Mario swapped control of his Bavaria brewery for 15% of SABMiller, which makes more than 150 brands, including Blue Moon beer. The Santo Domingo Group has since reduced its holdings to 14.1%, a stake now worth nearly $11.2 billion. Other assets, owned via publicly traded Valorem S.A., include a controlling interest in Colombia's biggest TV broadcaster, Caracol and in forestry outfit Refocosta, and shares in packaging maker Biofilm. Born into a rich family with interests in breweries, Julio Mario Santo Domingo took over management of its holdings in 1972 after his father retired. Now Alejandro, a managing director at Quadrant Capital Advisors, a New York-based investment advisory firm, is filling the role he has been groomed for over many years. In 2012, Quadrant led a $32 million investment in online clothing store Dafiti; Santo Domingo also purchased, through Grupo Santo Domingo, a 3% stake in Chile's Corpbanca for $100 million; and bought a majority stake in Integral de Servicios Tecnicos, a supplier for the oil industry. Alejandro sits on the board of Valorem, and, since 2009, the board of the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York. The family owns a private island, Baru, off the Caribbean coast of Colombia. Alejandro's younger brother Andres appears in U.S. gossip columns with socialite wife, Vogue magazine editor Lauren Davis. Julio Mario Jr., half-brother to Alejandro and Andres from their father's first marriage, died in 2009 in New York, reportedly from cancer. Julio Mario's widow, Beatrice Davila Rocha, is also understood to share in the inheritance.

name: Billionaires
bio: The "Quant King" retired from his $20 billion hedge fund firm, Renaissance Technologies, in 2010, but he continues to play a role at the firm and benefit from its funds, particularly the secretive and consistently profitable Medallion. Not all of the firm's funds, however, had a good year in 2012 and two of its funds actually lost money. The MIT grad started his career as a theoretical mathematician and was a code breaker for the U.S. Department of Defense during the Vietnam War. He later was head of the math department at SUNY-Stony Brook. In 1982 he founded Renaissance, which is based in East Setauket, N.Y. The fund uses computer modeling to find inefficiencies in highly liquid securities. Simons has shown a preference for hiring PhDs over MBAs. He chairs Math for America and supports autism research.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Charoen Sirivadhanabhakdi's fortune more than doubled as shares of his Thai Bev, Thailand's largest brewer and maker of Chang Beer, doubled in past year. He beat out Indonesia's Riady family for control of Singapore-based beverage and property company Fraser & Neave in a $11 billion deal. Through publicly listed bottling company Serm Suk, he introduced Est Cola to Thailand with aim to grab market share from Pepsi and Coke. Owns Bangkok's famous tech-mall Pantip Plaza, Hotel Plaza Athenee in Manhattan, plus hotels in Asia, the United States and Australia, residential, commercial and retail buildings in Singapore and Thailand. TCC Land, his private property arm, opened outdoor mega mall and entertainment complex in Bangkok, in April of last year.  Son of Bangkok street vendor, he made fortune selling inexpensive beer and whiskey. Took his Thai Bev public in Singapore in 2006.

name: Billionaires
bio: Zong Qinghou is the richest man in mainland China and one of the biggest gainers on the world's billionaires, with a net worth up 75% from a year ago. Zong chairs the privately held Wahaha, the country's top homegrown beverage company. The fast-growing producer of a mix of bottled water, teas and other ready-to-drink concoctions reported pretax profit of $1.6 billion last year, up 18%, amid lower costs for ingredients. In a move to enhance its image among sports fans in China, Wahaha in January said it would become the official beverage partner of the Manchester United soccer team in the country. Yet tough competition in its core business at home is leading Wahaha to look into new businesses. The company in November opened a boutique shopping mall for imported goods, Waow Plaza, in Hangzhou and aims to open another 100 or so in as little as three years. Wahaha in August signed a research cooperation agreement with the University of Nottingham in the UK in areas ranging from bioenergy technology to animal feed, robotics, electrical motors and food technologies. Wahaha's name evokes a young child's laugh. Daughter Kelly is Zong's heir apparent.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Brazil's richest woman Dirce Navarro De Camargo died on April 20  at the age of 100. She and her family were ranked number 87 among the world's billionaires in March, with a net worth of $11.5 billion. The bulk of Dirce Navarro de Camargo's wealth came from her stake in Camargo Correa, a conglomerate founded by her late husband, Sebastiao Camargo, in  1939. The firm has operations in cement, energy and construction. In 2012 it bought 95% of Cimpor, a publicly traded cement maker based in Lisbon, for $3.7 billion. Dirce became chairman of Camargo Correa upon her husband's death in 1994 and served until 1996.  Camargo?s three daughters - Renata de Camargo Nascimento, Rosana Camargo de Arruda Botelho and Regina de Camargo Pires Oliveira Dias - will inherit the family fortune since they hold equal share of the Participacoes Morro Vermelho SA holding company, which controls Camargo Correa.

name: Billionaires
bio: The son of a welder, John Fredriksen started trading oil in the 1960s in Beirut, bought his first tankers in the 1970s, ran crude oil for Iran in the 1980s, and in the 1990s, with Frontline Ltd. , established himself as the king of the tanker trade. In 2005 he got into the deepwater drilling business with Seadrill; that company now puts $400 million a year in dividends in his pocket. Last year, with tanker business in the toilet and ship prices depressed, Fredriksen made the biggest bet of his career and started putting in orders for a new fleet of tankers. He has given up Norwegian citizenship for tax-haven Cyprus, runs empire from London mansion, relaxes in Marbella.
title: Investor

name: Billionaires
bio: The continued success of London's booming prime property market meant a good year for Gerald Cavendish Grosvenor. The U.K.'s wealthiest landowner, also known as the 6th Duke of Westminster, saw his fortune rise $400 million this past year along with the value of real estate in Belgravia, London's most expensive neighborhood, where his family trust owns 190 acres (and where homes can sell for $150 million). His private Grosvenor Group separately owns real estate on five continents and reports just under $20 billion in assets under management. His family also has 96,000 acres in Scotland, 32,000 acres in Spain and thousands elsewhere in England.

name: Billionaires
bio: A pioneer in drilling the Bakken shale of North Dakota, Harold Hamm now thinks the play is the biggest in the United States, with the potential to yield 24 billion barrels of oil in the decades to come, and be producing more than 1 million barrels per day within 5 years. No company has more acreage there than Oklahoma City-based, publicly traded Continental Resources, of which Hamm owns more than 70%. Blistering growth: oil and gas production has surpassed 100,000 barrels per day. No wonder Mitt Romney picked Hamm as one of his energy advisers. Down-to-earth guy prefers burgers at Sonic and drives his own pick-up truck. With his wife Sue Ann, Hamm has donated $30 million to create a diabetes center at the University of Oklahoma. The couple has signed on to the Bill Gates-Warren Buffett Giving Pledge.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Continental Resources', 'uri': 'companies/continental-resources', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Rupert Murdoch is busy. The Australian-born media baron is in the midst of splitting News Corp. into two publicly traded companies: one for its fast-growing entertainment assets, the other for its publishing businesses. It's a move that lets him keep Wall Street happy while at the same time indulging his unfashionable taste for newsprint; he is rumored to be eyeballing new assets including the Los Angeles Times. At the same time, he's picking the biggest fight imaginable, launching a national sports network to compete with Disney's ESPN. Through it all, News Corp. shares, the reservoir of nearly all his wealth, continue to rebound from their lows of 2011. The phone hacking and bribery scandal of that year still hovers over the company, but Murdoch appears ever more confident that his son James will emerge from it in shape to take over the empire someday.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'News Corp', 'uri': 'companies/news-corp', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False, 'revenue': 34300.0, 'revenueYear': 2012}

name: Billionaires
bio: Hedge fund titan John Paulson, who pulled off the greatest trade ever six years ago, is now having to sooth jittery investors after his Paulson Advantage ended 2012 down more than 14%, its second straight year in the red. In December, Morgan Stanley Smith Barney recommended that its advisors pull client money from the fund. However, Paulson's Enhanced fund returned nearly 20% net of fees last year, while the firm's Credit Opportunities fund netted 8.4%. Assets under management at Paulson & Co. stand at $18 billion, down from $36 billion in early 2011. Long bullish on gold, Paulson now seems to have faith in real estate. One of his funds picked up 875 acres in Las Vegas in 2012. For himself, he bought a 90-acre home and ranch called Hala Ranch in Aspen, Colorado, and a nearby 38-acre parcel known as Bear Cabin from a Saudi prince for $49 million. A former managing director of M&A at Bear Stearns, he founded his hedge fund firm in 1994 and became a billionaire in 2007 by shorting subprime mortgage securities, earning a $3.5 billion payout. In 2010, his take was $4.9 billion, a record for the hedge fund industry. An NYU alum and trustee, he donated $20 million to the school in 2009; he gave $5 million to Southampton Hospital, near his summer home, and is donating $15 million to a new maternity hospital in Guayaquil, Ecuador, where his father, after whom it is being named, was born. Paulson made headlines in October 2012 when he pledged $100 million to the Central Park Conservancy.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Asia's most generous person, Azim Premji gave away $2.3 billion worth of shares in his outsourcing firm Wipro to his education-focused foundation in February, just days after agreeing to sign Bill Gates' and Warren Buffett's Giving Pledge. Premji, who co-hosted a philanthropy meeting in June 2012 in Bangalore with Gates and Ratan Tata, had already given away $2 billion to his foundation in 2010. By Forbes' count, only four people in the world are more generous than him. Meanwhile Wipro's stock has dipped in what is seen as a difficult market for outsourcers as they scramble for new contracts. The company has reportedly been poaching executives from rivals like Infosys to beef up its ranks. In November, it spun off consumer products arm into Wipro Enterprises which bought Singapore skincare firm L.D.Waxsons for $144 million in December. His private investment arm invested in the local franchisee of Hard Rock Cafe. In a surprising turn, Premji recently supported the government's new tax on the rich.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Ernesto Bertarelli inherited biotech firm Serono when his father died in 1998; he ran it with his sister for many years, expanding revenue to $2.4 billion by 2006. The company's blockbuster drug was the billion dollar multiple sceloris therapy Rebif. Bertarelli sold Serono to Germany's Merck in 2007 and took home $9 billion with his sister and mother. Bertarelli's Team Alinghi, two-time winner of the America's Cup, lost to rival racing billionaire Larry Ellison in February 2010. Bertarelli is still racing competitively in the Extreme Sailing Series. He owns the $100 million plus yacht, Vava II. The family's Waypoint Group has been buying property in London via its Crosstree Capital Partners arm, expanding life sciences investments, and is on the hunt for acquisitions. Family is building on the marine conservation started in 2011 in the Indian Ocean; they recently announcing a $5 million donation to turn Belize's Turneffe Atoll, the second-largest coral reef in the world, into a nature reserve. Bertarelli is also hoping to launch a biotech campus on the former Merck Serono site in Geneva, along with Swiss billionaire Dr. Hansjorg Wyss, to create a regional research hub. Bertarelli's sister, Dona, is a successful entrepreneur in her own right, with substantial private investments in the hotel and leisure sector, including the Grand Hotel Park in Gstaad, and is expanding herand her own sailing team Spindrift Racing to compete this year in the Rolex Fastnet Race for the first time. Ernesto's wife Kirsty, former British beauty queen, continues to build her music career, working on an album with Sony/ATV.

name: Billionaires
bio: Beer heiress Charlene de Carvalho-Heineken is one of the richest women in the world. A decade ago she inherited a 25% controlling stake in Dutch brewer Heineken from her late father, Freddy Heineken. The company has more than 170 premium brands in more than 65 countries. A mother of five, Carvalho-Heineken studied law at the University of Leiden. She is a member of St. Moritz's elite Corviglia Ski Club and enjoys photography, music and architecture. Her husband, investment banker Michel de Carvalho, sits on Heineken's supervisory board. He's a former child actor who appeared in the 1962 epic Lawrence of Arabia.

name: Billionaires
bio: Tragedy struck Hans Rausing's family in 2012 when his daughter-in-law died as a result of a drug overdose. His son Hans-Kristian, also a drug addict, hid her body in a bedroom for eight weeks. "He had been prescribed enough morphine, we were later told, to kill a small horse," Hans-Kristian's sister reportedly told a reporter at the Guardian.  Hans' father founded packaging giant Tetra Laval in 1944. Hans and his brother Gad inherited the business. Hans sold his share to Gad for estimated $7 billion in 1995. He moved to the U.K. in the early 1980s to avoid punitive Swedish taxes, and now resides on a 900-acre estate in village of Wadhurst in East Sussex. He is an investor in Ecolean, maker of environmentally friendly packaging material; he previously invested in Chumak, a maker of condiments.  Rausing was awarded an honorary knighthood for his services to charity in 2006. His Hans Rausing Endangered Languages Project at the University of London supports research, training, and archiving of endangered languages. He has also historically made numerous contributions to the British conservative party, while his daughter, Sigrid Rausing, gives money to more liberal causes, such as ones promoting human rights. Rausing stands 6'8" tall, speaks fluent Russian, and collects vintage cars.

name: Billionaires
bio: Jack Taylor's Enterprise Holdings, the parent of Enterprise Rent-A-Car, National and Alamo, has the largest fleet in the country and is the biggest car rental company in term of sales, which exceeded $14 billion in 2012. The company spun off its fleet management business in 2011. Taylor, who passed the CEO job to his son Andy in 1994, is retired; as an advisory director he continues to play a part in strategic decisions. His daughter Jo Ann Taylor Kindle runs the company's Enterprise Foundation. Taylor left Washington University in St. Louis (without a degree) to join the Navy, and served as a fighter pilot during World War II. He became a sales manager for a St. Louis Cadillac distributor, then took a 50% pay cut to start Enterprise, named after the aircraft carrier he served on. The Crawford Taylor Foundation, a family fund, supports animal welfare, community development, the environment and services for women and youths, mainly focusing on organizations in the St. Louis metropolitan area
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Lui Che Woo's fortune shot up by $5 billion in the past year as gambling revenue continued to grow at a double-digit pace in the world's largest casino market, Macau, driving shares in his Galaxy Entertainment to an all-time high. He opened his biggest casino project, the Galaxy Macau, on the Cotai Strip in May 2011, with the second phase slated for completion in 2015. His vice-chairman and eldest son, Francis Lui, 56, manages the gambling side of the family business. He established his first company in the 1950s, buying construction equipment from Japan and reselling it in Southeast Asia. He made his original fortune through property developer K. Wah International and San Francisco's Stanford Hotels, before winning one of six coveted Macau gaming licenses.

name: Billionaires
bio: Silicon Valley's wealthiest woman, Laurene Powell Jobs, is focusing her attention on spreading awareness for the DREAM Act, a congressional push that would give undocumented youth raised in the U.S. the chance to earn citizenship by going to college or serving in the armed forces. In January 2013, Powell Jobs teamed up with filmmaker Davis Guggenheim to launch TheDreamIsNow.org to share some of the stories of the more than 1 million undocumented young people that could be affected by this legislation. As the namesake of the Laurene Powell Jobs Trust, Jobs is the largest single shareholder of Walt Disney Co., with a 7.3% stake. That stake in Disney is worth twice that of her Apple shares, left to her by late husband and company cofounder, Steve Jobs. He met Laurene Powell in 1989 after giving a talk at Stanford University, where Powell was a student in the Graduate School of Business. Less than two years later, they were married in Yosemite. The couple had three children together. Powell Jobs, a strong advocate of education and immigration reform, sits on the boards of several nonprofits, including the NewSchools Venture Fund, Conservation International and College Track, an organization she founded that is designed to ensure admittance to and graduation from college for underserved students.  She  is also the founder and chair of the Emerson Collective, which works with entrepreneurs to advance education, immigration reform, social justice and conservation. In September 2012, she was appointed to Stanford University's board of trustees.
title: Investor, Philanthropist
employment: {'name': 'Emerson Collective', 'title': 'Founder and Chair', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: It's been a humbling year for Eike Batista, who lost the title of Brazil's richest man as prices plummeted on five of his six publicly-traded holdings. The biggest crash occurred at oil and gas driller OGX Petroleo e Gas: The value of his 61% stake was worth $3.7 billion in mid February, down from nearly $19.9 billion a year earlier. Altogether, over the past 12 months Batista's assets shed nearly two-thirds of their value, or $19.4 billion, making him the billionaire with the biggest drop in net worth. In March 2012, before his stocks began falling, Batista sold a 5.6% stake in his umbrella EBX Group to Abu Dhabi government investment fund Mubadala for $2 billion. In May 2012 he sold a 0.8% stake in EBX to U.S. conglomerate GE for $300 million. Needless to say, Batista is no longer boasting loudly about overtaking Carlos Slim of Mexico as the world's richest man.

name: Billionaires
bio: Charles Ergen is fighting hard to transform his satellite TV provider, Dish Network, into the wireless data business. In January 2013 Dish bid for 25% of wireless broadband provider Clearwire's spectrum, a deal that must be approved by the FCC. Sprint, which owns the majority of Clearwire but does not control the board, is opposed to the deal. Ergen started his business with his wife, Cantey. They sold satellite dishes door-to-door in Colorado in the 1980s, building a satellite company called EchoStar. After competitor DirecTV launched a new, small satellite, Ergen followed suit. He undercut rivals' rates and gave away free dishes to push his new company, Dish Network.  By 2004, EchoStar had $6 billion in sales. In April 2011 Dish bought bankrupt retailer Blockbuster for $320 million. It then bought $3 billion in broadband spectrum. Ergen gave up his CEO title in 2011 after 30 years but remains chairman of both Dish and EchoStar, which owns and operates Dish's satellite fleet.
title: Founder and Chairman
employment: {'name': 'DISH Network', 'uri': 'companies/dish-network', 'title': 'Founder and Chairman', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Johanna Quandt, one of the richest women in Germany, is the former secretary and third wife of the late Herbert Quandt, the German executive who rescued automaker BMW from bankruptcy. BMW sold a record 1.85 million vehicles in 2012, including its RollsRoyce and Mini brand cars; revenues in 2011 were $92 billion. An uptick in BMW's stock price lifted her net worth from $10 billion last year. Johanna Quandt retired from BMW's supervisory board in 1997 but still owns more than 16% of the automaker. Her children, Susanne Klatten and Stefan Quandt, have significant stakes in BMW and are also billionaires. Quandt lives quietly in Bad Homburg, a town near Frankfurt known for its spas. In 2010, the German government recognized her for the cultural and social contributions she has made in support of journalism and education.

name: Billionaires
bio: German Khan's Alfa Group, which he shares with fellow billionaires and college buddies Mikhail Fridman and Alexei Kuzmichev, is the biggest financial and industrial group in Russia. Khan worked as executive director of TNK-BP, the group's oil business, a joint venture with ВР, since it was founded in 2003. He will have to leave the company soon: In 2012 Alfa Group together with billionaires Viktor Vekselberg and Leonard Blavatnik agreed to sell a 50% stake in TNK-BP to state-owned Rosneft for $28 billion. From this deal Khan will get almost $3.3 billion in cash. A Kiev native, Khan came to Moscow to study. With his friends Fridman and Kuzmichev, he started commodities trading outfit Alfa-Eco in 1989. Two years later the trio launched Alfa-Bank, now the biggest private bank in Russia. The group bought Tyumen Oil from the state in the late 1990s and merged it with BP's Russian assets to form TNK-BP. Alfa Group also has stakes in Vimpelcom cellular company and owns the biggest retailer, X5.

name: Billionaires
bio: Irish citizen and patriarch of Indian construction giant Shapoorji Pallonji Group, Pallonji Mistry handed over the chairman's mantle of group to older son Shapoor last June. Younger son Cyrus replaced  Indian business legend Ratan Tata as chairman of Tata Sons after Tata retired in December. Mistry's family has long been the biggest shareholder in Tata Sons, the holding outfit of the $100 billion (revenues) conglomerate, with an 18.4% stake, but this is the first time a family member is in charge. Cyrus is recruiting younger executives as part of his core team. Son Shapoor, a horse racing enthusiast, owns a stud farm in Pune that his dad gave him as a birthday gift many years ago.

name: Billionaires
bio: Brothers were raised in the U.K. Simon started out importing carpets and buying real estate; David in metals trading. They later joined together in Transworld, a metals trader that invested in Russia and Kazakhstan in the 1990s. A recent lawsuit filed by Michael Cherney, a former associate of the brothers, against Russian billionaire Oleg Deripaska mentions their former relationship; the Reuben brothers successfully sued Cherny for damages as a result of their dealing. Since selling their metals business, the pair have invested in UK real estate. They plan to turn the Mayfair estate of famed In and Out Club into a 48 bedroom residence and 35,000 bottle winecellar, valued as the most expensive private residence in the UK. The Reuben brothers now control 48% of all horseracing in the UK following the acquisition of Arena Leisure last March. They are expanding their data center business, GlobalSwitch, in Hong Kong, Sydney and Singapore. Their Reuben Foundation which funds health care and educational causes, recently announced funding for university scholarships for inner-city children. David resides in Monaco and Florida; Simon resides in Monaco.

name: Billionaires
bio: Petr Kellner got his start in the early 90's selling office supplies, then borrowed $1 million against that business and started an investment fund which he used it to buy a controlling stake in the biggest Czech insurer during its privatization; Kellner recently announced he was selling out of this insurance stake to partner, Italian insurer Generali, for $3.6 billion. Last year, Kellner also sold his stakes in Czech lottery leader Sazka and Russian Nomos Bank for over $1 billion using the funds to pay down a significant portion of his debt. Kellner is now focused on growing his asset lender, Home Credit, which more than doubled its business in 2012. He is expanding into new areas like Russian real estate, energy, and anti-cancer drug research. A dedicated philanthropist, Kellner, with his wife, endows scholarships at his Open Gate School and became the leading sponsor of a new library- think-tank for outgoing Czech ex-president Vaclav Klaus.

name: Billionaires
bio: In August 2012 Roman Abramovich won a suit in the High Court in London brought by billionaire Boris Berezovsky. his former partner. Berezovsky had been seeking $5.6 billion he claimed Abramovich failed to pay for stakes in oil giant Sibneft and aluminum producer Rusal. Abramovich has stakes in steel giant Evraz and mining firm Highland Gold. Together with his Evraz partner, billionaire Alexander Abramov, he plans to buy a large stake (about 10%) in Norilsk Nickel. Abramovich was orphaned as a child and dropped out of college, then made his fortune in a series of controversial oil export deals in the early 1990s. He teamed up with Berezovsky to take over Sibneft at a fraction of its market value. He sold his stake in Russian Aluminum to another billionaire, Oleg Deripaska, and a 73% stake in Sibneft to gas titan Gazprom for $13 billion in 2005. He owns the U.K.'s Chelsea soccer team. He owns the world's largest yacht, the 533-foot Eclipse, which cost him more than $250 million in 2010. He also has a 377-foot ice boat, the Luna, a Boeing 767 and homes in London, France, St. Barts, Colorado and Los Angeles. He owns a large art collection. In January 2013 he bought a collection of 40 paintings by Ilya Kabakov, the most expensive living Russian artist, from U.S. collector John L. Stewart.

name: Billionaires
bio: Brothers Robert and Philip Ng's debut on list as coexecutors of the family estate inherited from their late father Ng Teng Fong who developed more than 700 hotels, malls and condos in Singapore and Hong Kong. Family's Far East Organization built one in six of the private homes in Singapore. In 2012, they listed the Far East Hospitality Trust, the largest hospitality and serviced residence portfolio by asset value on the Singapore stock exchange. Biggest part of their fortune is in public Tsim Sha Tsui Properties, chaired by elder brother Robert, in Hong Kong. Younger sibling Philip manages family's Singapore interests.

name: Billionaires
bio: Phil Anschutz has made fortunes in oil, railroads and telecom, but his biggest bets are in entertainment. In late 2012 he put his Anschutz Entertainment Group up for sale, hoping to get more than $8 billion. Through AEG, he operates dozens of the world's greatest concert venues like the Staples Center and Nokia Theater in L.A., London's O2, and Shanghai's Mercedes-Benz Arena. He fills his halls with his own in-house entertainment, including the L.A. Lakers and NHL's L.A. Kings. His music division manages rock stars like Justin Bieber, Enrique Iglesias and Jennifer Lopez. His film division has produced the Chronicles of Narnia series. New deal: AEG partnered with Ryan Seacrest and Mark Cuban to rebrand HDNet as a new TV network called AXS. It will feature lots of live entertainment from AEG's venues. AXS is also the name of AEG's new no-fee ticketing venture to compete with Ticketmaster. Anschutz hopes to bring NFL football back to L.A., with plans to build a $1 billion stadium adjacent to the Staples Center. If only he can find a team to buy. He's got plenty of cash to make the deal, having sold oil and gas fields for $1 billion in 2010. Other passions: the art of the American West; his collection of Bierstadts, Remingtons and Russells (now on display in a new Denver museum) could be the world's best. Enjoys the western vistas too; his company Xanterra manages lodges in many national parks, and this year he bought the famed Broadmoor resort in Colorado Springs. On his own land in Wyoming, Anschutz is developing a wind farm that could boast 1,000 turbines.

name: Billionaires
bio: Despite a lifetime spent building one of the great energy fortunes in America, thanks to politics George Kaiser's investment in failed solar company Solyndra has gotten more attention than anything else he's ever done. Kaiser insists the company's well-chronicled downfall was simply the result of market forces, namely low-cost solar gear from Chinese companies that get even more handouts from their government. Kaiser's family fled Nazi Germany and settled in Tulsa, Oklahoma, where his uncle founded Kaiser-Francis Oil Company. George inherited control in the late 1960s, and made the most of it. He's now pursuing oil plays in North Dakota, Wyoming and Canada. In the 1990s he bought the Bank of Oklahoma out of federal receivership for $60 million; his stake is now worth $2.4 billion. Kaiser also founded Excelerate Energy, which ships liquefied natural gas around the world. Other assets: a large number of private equity investments, especially in India, where owns a stake in the Bombay Stock Exchange. He is devoted to the cause of early childhood education and has endowed his George Kaiser Family Foundation with $4 billion.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Last year's biggest gainer, Mexico's Ricardo Salinas Pliego saw his net worth plunge $7.5 billion, as shares of his retailer Grupo Elektra fell 48%. Last year share prices for the home electronics retailer, which has a small float, jumped due to an equity swap with UBS and a new place on the benchmark IPC Mexican stock index, which pushed demand--and prices--sky-high. Now that Elektra shares are back to normal, Salinas's net worth is as well. Salinas is president and CEO of Salinas Group, with assets in media, specialized retail, financial services and telecommunications, and annual revenues of $6 billion. He took over his family's discount retailer, Grupo Elektra, in 1987 and turned it into one of Mexico's largest electronics retailers. In 1994 he launched TV Azteca, now Mexico's second biggest network broadcaster and one of the world's top producers of Spanish-language television. In mid 2010, Salinas took his financially troubled Mexican wireless carrier Iusacell private. He struck a deal in 2011 to sell a 50% stake of Iusacell to competing Mexican TV broadcaster Televisa for $1.6 billion. Regulators initially vetoed the deal, but Salinas won approval in 2012. He also purchased America's largest cash-advance company, Advance America, for $780 million in April 2012. His Azteca Foundation promotes youth orchestras across Mexico. Salinas has six children (three with his first wife and three with his second), including twins born in 2009.

name: Billionaires
bio: Richard Kinder's energy company, Kinder Morgan, owns 75,000 miles of pipeline and 180 storage terminals capable of handling 2.5 million barrels of oil and 55 billion cubic feet of gas a day. A former Army captain, he founded Kinder Morgan in 1997 with his friend William Morgan, after quitting as president of Enron the year before. He holds both bachelor and law degrees from the University of Missouri. His $78 million (assets) Kinder Foundation is devoted to enhancing the quality of life in Houston. With his wife, Nancy, Kinder donated $15 million to Rice University in 2010, endowing the school's Institute for Urban Research.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Kinder Morgan', 'uri': 'companies/kinder-morgan', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Tsai Eng-Meng, Taiwan's richest man, is the chairman of Want Want China, one of Asia's largest makers of Chinese-style snacks such as rice crackers. Its popularity in those niches keeps its profit margins, and Tsai's wealth, high. A rise in Want Want's stock price has boosted Tsai's fortune from a year ago. Tsai also invests in Taiwanese media, but has faced heavy criticism for what are perceived to be his pro-China views. His unlisted San Want invests in hotels and real estate. Tsai invests in financial services through Union Insurance and Waterland Financial Holding.

name: Billionaires
bio: Horst Paulmann is expanding his massive retail presence across Latin America.He and his family own 61% of $15.6 billion (2011 revenues) Cencosud, which is based in Chile and includes malls, supermarkets, department stores and home centers, an insurance brokerage, family entertainment centers, banks, and a travel agency. In late 2012 Cencosud elbowed out Wal-Mart to purchase Carrefour's Colombian operations for $2.6 billion. Cencosud also bought, for $484 million, the nearly 39% stake of Jumbo Retail Argentina that it did not already own. Paulmann took the company public in Chile in 2001. He opened the first Jumbo hypermarket in 1976, and now has 645 supermarkets in Chile, Argentina, Brazil, Peru; all told, his retail portfolio includes some 917 stores and 29 shopping centers. To cover the cost of rapid growth, Cencosud listed its ADR shares on the New York Stock Exchange in June, raising $5.8 (CK) billion and becoming Chile's largest company on the NYSE in terms of market cap. In 2012 Paulmann also opened Latin America's tallest building, the Costanera Center, a 960 foot-tall shopping center in Santiago; reportedly 7 million people visited the 250-store mall in its first three months. His three children all sit on firm's board of directors. Paulmann moved from Germany to Chile as a teenager after WW II. He still holds dual citizenship.

name: Billionaires
bio: Shares in Michael Kadoorie's power firm CLP were flat because of limited growth prospects and a dilutive stock sale. But Hongkong & Shanghai Hotels performed well, riding the travel boom. Its Peninsula Hotel in Kowloon underwent a $60 million refurbishment to prepare for its 85th anniversary in April. Figure for wealth includes shares held by brother-in-law Ronald McAulay and other relatives. Kadoorie is the scion of a family of Iraqi Jews who settled in Asia decades ago.

name: Billionaires
bio: Pharma entrepreneur Dilip Shanghvi saw fortune swell as shares of his Sun Pharmaceutical Industries, which he founded in 1982, gained 40% in 12 months, hitting a record high in October. It is the country's most valuable drug maker (recent market cap:$15 billion). In August, Sun said it would spin off its domestic formulations business, sparking rumor that it may be mulling a stake sale to big pharma; company denied it. In December, its American arm concluded $230 million acquisition of Nasdaq-listed skincare firm DUSA Pharmaceuticals and inked deal to to buy a US generics business of Japan's Takeda Pharmaceuticals for undisclosed sum. Sun recently dropped plan to take its NYSE-listed subsidiary Taro Pharmaceutical Industries, in which it has nearly a two thirds stake, private. His brother-in-law acquired a 26% stake in an Indian telecom joint venture with Norway's Telenor, amid speculation that Shanghvi was backing him.

name: Billionaires
bio: The federal government is breathing down Steve Cohen's neck with an insider-trading investigation that has spooked some of his investors, but that has not stopped Cohen from making money in financial markets. In 2012, his Stamford, Conn., SAC Capital Advisors, which manages $14 billion, posted gross returns in the 25% range. That was not enough for Cohen to deliver a U.S. stock market beating performance for his investors after he charged them his customary steep fees, but a net return of 13% was still better than the vast majority of hedge fund managers. A minority owner of the New York Mets and a prolific art collector, Cohen is also on the board of the Museum of Contemporary Art, Los Angeles. The father of a Marine, Cohen serves as Co-Chairman of the Veterans Advisory Board at the Robin Hood Foundation. The NYU Langone Medical Center recently announced that Cohen's foundation was making a $17 million grant to establish a new veterans' mental health research center.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: One of Sweden's richest women, Antonia Johnson succeeded her father as head of the Axel Johnson Group, a diversified trading company, in 1982. The privately held company, founded by her great-grandfather in 1873, has interests in food, security, energy, telecom, real estate and industrial products. Axfood AB, in which it holds a 46% share, is one of Scandinavia's largest food operations. She attended Radcliffe College as an exchange student in the early 1960s and is an avid horsewoman and involved with numerous Swedish charities, including the World Childhood Foundation, which was founded by the queen of Sweden.

name: Billionaires
bio: Dmitry Rybolovlev is best known in the U.S. for his real estate moves. He bought Donald Trump's Palm Beach mansion, Maison de L'Amitie, for $95 million in 2008. Though a trust set up for his 23-year-old daughter Ekaterina Rybolovleva, in 2011 he paid $88 million for a Manhattan apartment owned by former Citi chairman Sandy Weill. He also reportedly paid more than $300 million for a Monaco penthouse called La Belle Epoque, where he lives. Also in 2011 he bought a villa in Hawaii from movie star Will Smith. The bulk of Rybolovlev's fortune comes from Uralkali, Russia's largest producer of potassium fertilizer. In 2010 he sold his stake in the company for $6.5 billion. He started his business with his scientist father in 1990 after studying at the Perm Medical Institute. In 1992 he opened an investment fund and, like other Russian tycoons, began buying shares of industrial enterprises. He consolidated his holdings and in 1995, became chairman of the board of Uralkali. The company, founded in the 1930s, listed in London in 2007, raising $1 billion. His wife Elena filed for divorce in Palm Beach in 2009. She is seeking ownership of the former Trump mansion and half of her husband's wealth. In 2011 he bought the Monaco football club.

name: Billionaires
bio: Marcel Herrmann Telles share controls of Anheuser-Busch Inbev, the world's largest beer company, with longtime billionaire partners Jorge Paulo Lemann and Carlos Alberto Sicupira. The trio came together in the 1970s to form a Rio de Janeiro brokerage that ultimately became one of Brazil's biggest investment banks. The three billionaires and other partners sold it to Credit Suisse for $675 million in 1998. In February 2013 their investment firm, 3G Capital, with offices in Rio de Janeiro and New York City, partnered with Warren Buffett to buy Heinz. In 2010 3G partnered with Brazilian billionaire Eike Batista to acquire Burger King for $3.3 billion. They took the hamburger chain private and listed it again two years later. The trio also controls listed Brazilian retailer Lojas Americanas and real estate investment firm São Carlos Empreendimentos e Participações S.A. Telles reportedly enjoys spearfishing and spending time in Monaco.

name: Billionaires
bio:
Klaus Michael Kuehne has run transportation & logistics company Kuehne & Nagel for over four decades; grandfather August Kuehne was group's founder. Via the Kuhne & Nagel Holding AG he holds 53.3 % of the stake in the public company Kuhne und Nagel International AG. He stepped back as Chairman of the Executive Committee and now acts as Honorary Chairman. In 2008, in an effort to keep the company anchored in Germany, Kuehne and a group of investors that included the city of Hamburg formed the Albert Ballin KG consortium to bid for 160-year old Hapag Lloyd, one of the world's leading container ship operators. 77.96 % of the shares in Hapag-Lloyd Holding AG are held by Hamburgische Seefahrtsbeteiligung "Albert Ballin" GmbH & Co. KG ("Albert Ballin consortium") and 22 % by the TUI Group. Michael Kuehne now holds 28.2 % out of the 77.96 %. 
At the end of 2012 it was announced that the shipping companies Hapag Lloyd and Hamburg Sud are planning a merger. Hamburg Sud is owned by the famous German Oetker family. Together they would become the fourth largest Container shipping company in the world, with sales of Eu 10 bil. and 11.500 employees. Hamburg Sud is by now the twelth largest company with 107 Container Ships. Hapag Lloyd is the sixth largest company with 150 Container Ships. Lives in Switzerland but still has ties to his birthplace, Hamburg.  Although he lives in landlocked Switzerland, has built an extravagant house said to look like the main command deck of an ocean liner.

name: Billionaires
bio: Hasso Plattner's fortune has climbed by $1.7 billion since March 2012 thanks to a rise in the stock price of German software company SAP. Plattner cofounded SAP with four former IBM colleagues in 1972. (Three of those colleagues -- Dietmar Hopp, Klaus Tschira and Hans-Werner Hector -- are also billionaires.) Plattner stepped down as CEO in 2003 and since then has chaired the company's supervisory board and served as Chief Software Advisor. In 1998 he founded the Hasso Plattner Institute for IT Systems Engineering at the University of Potsdam; he serves as a professor of enterprise software systems there. A sports enthusiast, Plattner sails competitively on his yacht, Morning Glory, as well as skis, snowboards and plays tennis. He is also an avid golfer, and owns Fancourt Estate, a luxury golf course and hotel in South Africa's Western Cape province. His Hasso Plattner Ventures, based in Potsdam, invests in promising technology companies. In 2008 Hasso Plattner Ventures Africa began operating in Cape Town, South Africa with a $50 million (40 million Euro) fund.

name: Billionaires
bio: Iskander Makhmudov is the main owner of copper producer UGMK-Holding. He is also a shareholder in Transmashholding, Russia's largest maker of locomotives and rail equipment (he partnered with state-owned Russian Railways and Alstom, the French machine-building giant). Born in Bukhara, Uzbekistan, Makhmudov lived in Tashkent; he graduated from a local university with a degree in oriental studies. He put his Arabic-language skills to use in various Soviet military organizations in Libya and Iraq. His first moves as a businessman were with the industrialist Chernoy brothers, the billionaire Reuben brothers and their Trans-World Group, once the largest metals-trading operation in Russia. Spanish authorities named him in a money laundering case, which they handed over to the Russian Attorney General's Office for further investigation. In March 2012 the money laundering case, which also implicates billionaire Oleg Deripaska, was sent to the investigative department of the Ministry of Internal Affairs. A Deripaska spokesman has reportedly said that the Spanish court's decision to send the case to Russia means that there is not enough evidence to prove the charges.

name: Billionaires
bio: João Roberto Marinho and his two billionaire brothers, Roberto Irineu Marinho and José Roberto Marinho, control privately-held Rede Globo, Latin America's largest media group, which has about half of Brazil's television market. Rede Globo was founded by their father, Roberto Marinho, who died in 2003 at the age of 98 after a seven-decade career. João Roberto started as a journalist for the O Globo newspaper, where he held a number of positions before becoming chief editor. Today, as chairman of the Editorial Board, he determines the editorial direction of the Globo Organizations. João Roberto enjoys horseback riding.

name: Billionaires
bio: Roberto Irineu Marinho and his two billionaire brothers, Joao Roberto Marinho and Jose Roberto Marinho, control privately held Rede Globo, Latin America's largest media group, which has about half of Brazil's television market. The brothers also own O Globo newspaper of Rio de Janeiro. Rede Globo was founded by their father Roberto Marinho, who died in 2003 at age 98, after a seven-decade career. Roberto Irineu Marinho, the oldest son, heads the media empire as Globo's chief executive officer. He also owns Sertaozinho Farm, which produces Orfeu gourmet coffee. The family supports educational and cultural causes through Roberto Marinho Foundation.

name: Billionaires
bio: EBay founder Pierre Omidyar is $500 million richer thanks to the stock performance of his auction site. The Tufts grad was 31 years old when he became a billionaire in one afternoon with eBay's 1998 IPO. Since then his focus has been on giving most of his money away in his lifetime; he reiterated his intention by signing the Gates and Buffett Giving Pledge in 2010. He continues to gift eBay shares to the Omidyar Network, his philanthropic investment firm. In the past four years Pierre and his wife Pam Omidyar have become the single biggest private donors to the fight against the human trafficking industry. They've invested $115 million to date in their Humanity United foundation, which funds 85 antislavery nonprofits as well as on-the-ground projects in five countries, including their first in Nepal. They've pledged to spend another $50 million by 2016. Born in France of Iranian parents, Omidyar moved to the U.S. with his family at age six. He wrote code for his site, Auction Web, at age 28 and renamed it eBay after his first choice, Echo Bay, was already taken. Omidyar ceded executive control to new hire Meg Whitman in 1998; she in turn was replaced by John Donahoe 10 years later. Omidyar remains chairman of eBay.
title: Founder and Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: In June 2012, Hansjoerg Wyss, completed the sale of Synthes, a manufacturer of medical devices for orthopedic and trauma surgery, to Johnson & Johnson for $20.2 billion in cash and stock. He is now spending more time on his philanthropic pursuits. Along with fellow Swiss billionaire, Ernesto Bertarelli, he is planning to launch Wyss Institute in the former Merck Serno offices in Geneva. The campus will focus on healthcare, biotech and life sciences. His foundation will endow the project with over $100 million over six years. Wyss, a committed conservationist, is Chairman of The Wyss Foundation and The HJW Foundation, charitable organizations that work on environmental issues, as well as social issues in immigration reform, healthcare for all Americans, fairness in the loan industry and in women's health and reproductive rights, among many other projects. His Foundation recently donated $4.5 million to The Trust for Public Land to purchase oil and gas leases on 58,000 acres of sensitive land in Wyoming's Hoback Basin. Wyss also serves as President of Foundation Beyeler and is a founder of Stiftung GegenwART in Basel, Switzerland, which funds art programs and scholarships with The Bern Art Museum.

name: Billionaires
bio: José Roberto Marinho and his two billionaire brothers, Roberto Irineu Marinho and João Roberto Marinho, control privately-held Rede Globo, Latin America's largest media group, which has about half of Brazil's television market. Rede Globo was founded by their father, Roberto Marinho, who died in 2003 at the age of 98,after a seven-decade career. José Roberto Marinho leads the family philanthropy, Roberto Marinho Foundation, which supports educational and cultural causes and enjoys free publicity from the largest television network in Brazil.

name: Billionaires
bio: The second-richest man in Japan, Masayoshi Son, runs global telecom giant SoftBank. In October the company announced it would acquire 70% of Sprint Nextel for $20.1 billion. Since then the U.S. Department of Justice has asked the FCC to defer the proposed deal. Nevertheless, Softbank's share price has climbed by more than 40% during past 12 months. The company is also investing in wind and solar power generation projects in Japan. Son reportedly bought a $117 million estate in Woodside, California in November, the highest purchase price ever recorded for a U.S. home.
title: CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: Wang Jianlin chairs Dalian Wanda Group, one of China's largest commercial real estate developers. The company made waves in the U.S. in May by announcing it would purchase AMC Entertainment Holdings for $2.6 billion. The transaction was completed in September, turning Dalian Wanda into the world's largest operator of movie theaters. Last year Wanda opened 17 shopping plazas and 12 five-star hotels, according to the company's website. AMC in November kept expanding with the purchase of four movie theaters in Alabama, Louisiana and Florida.

name: Billionaires
bio: Giorgio Armani's private Armani Group got a nearly 14% boost in revenues in 2011 - to $2.35 billion (1.8 billion euros) -- thanks to Chinese luxury-goods shoppers, who spent 45% more than a year earlier on Armani clothing, perfume, home decor and high-end watches.That helped push up the 78-year-old designer's net worth by $1.3 billion from a year ago. Armani is also designing prescription eyeglasses and sunglasses for the Luxottica Group, owned by fellow Italian billionaire Leonardo del Vecchio, as part of a 10-year agreement; Giorgio Armani owns just under 5% of Luxottica shares. Armani has partnered with Dubai developer Emaar Properties on two luxury hotels: The Armani Hotel at the Burj Khalifa in Dubai, in the world's tallest building, opened in 2010; and the 96-room Armani Hotel Milan opened in late 2011.

name: Billionaires
bio: A shrewd banker, Beal started hoarding cash in 2004 as consumers and companies bathed themselves in debt. He waited until the economy began to crumble in 2007 and then set about snapping up loans jettisoned by struggling banks and desperate investors. The combined net income at his two main banks surged. By 2010 he stopped buying because asset prices had become too rich again, but he continues to literally reap dividends for how he handled the credit crisis. Since the start of 2011 his bank has paid him massive dividends. He is also working to to enhance his winnings by trying to get big banks to repurchase loans that were sold during the credit boom, but that he purchased at a big discount. Still, there have been setbacks. A federal appeals court in 2011 upheld a ruling that Beal improperly used a sham tax shelter to deduct $200 million in federal taxes. Son of a mechanical engineer, Beal scraped together his early kitty fixing  used televisions, and sold them to low-income families. He bought a Lansing, Mich. rental home at age 19, and opened the first branch of Beal Bank in Texas 1988. He added a Nevada bank years later. Beal mostly buys loans on the secondary market instead of originating them. A gifted poker player, he took on renowned card sharks Doyle Brunson and Phil Ivey at the Bellagio in Las Vegas in some of the highest-stakes games ever played.

name: Billionaires
bio: Oleg Deripaska reconciled with billionaire Vladimir Potanin in the war for control of Norilsk Nickel, thanks to a peaceful three-way agreement with Potanin and billionaire Roman Abramovich, who will become a Norilsk Nickel shareholder. He also settled a long-running London court fight with a former business partner, Mikhail Chernoy. Though details of the settlement are undisclosed, some sources say that Deripaska agreed to pay Chernoy, who wanted a stake in aluminum giant UC Rusal, up to $300 million. A former metals trader, Deripaska came back from the brink of collapse during the financial crisis. Facing margin calls and billions of dollars in debt, he personally negotiated with the Russian government, banks and other creditors to restructure his loan obligations. He managed to defend the majority of his assets from creditors, including car maker Gaz and power producer EuroSibEnergo. In 2010 Rusal, raised $2.2 billion in a Hong Kong IPO. The debt in his holding company, Basic Element, is still huge, about $20 billion.

name: Billionaires
bio: Budi Hartono and his brother Michael are known for their control of Bank Central Asia, Indonesia's biggest private bank that caters to the upper middle-class in the country. Budi's youngest son, Armand Wahyudi Hartono, has been operations and networking development director since 2009 and could take control of the banking group from his father. The family has also shown interest in the information technology scene in Indonesia. Budi's son, Martin Hartono, snapped up Kaskus, Indonesia's most popular website, through his venture capital firm Global Digital Prima Ventures. The younger Hartono has also bought an internet shopping site, Blibli.com and MerahPutih.com, Indonesia's first tech and digital business incubator.

name: Billionaires
bio: Brothers Shashi and Ravi Ruia's wealth got a boost as shares of their London-listed Essar Energy which had tumbled last year on a Supreme Court order that it was liable to prepay more than $1 billion in state taxes, recovered after latest ruling that the taxes could be paid over two years with no interest. Their Essar Group, a $27 billion (revenues) conglomerate with operations in 25 countries, has spent $18 billion since 2008 in expanding capacities, notably in steel and oil refining.  In May, Antwerp Port Authority bought minority stake in their Essar Ports. Brothers delisted India Securities. They are looking to sell their stakes in outsourcing firm Aegis, US steel operations and their telecom interests in Kenya, to bring down the group's $12 billion in debt.  They are reportedly seeking to settle with federal investigators in a case relating to their investment in Loop Telecom. In August, the group moved into new corporate headquarters in the Bandra-Kurla Complex, an upcoming financial district in suburban Mumbai; the brothers continue to operate from old downtown offices.

name: Billionaires
bio: Brothers Srichand and Gopichand Hinduja return to ranks after new information on the private holdings of their Hinduja Group, a multinational conglomerate with interests in automobiles, defense, energy, petroleum, media and technology. Their Indian flagship Ashok Leyland has a 25% share of the commercial vehicles market and country's cricket team captain M.S. Dhoni as a brand ambassador. Brothers were in news recently for the $1 billion acquisition of US-based lubricant maker Houghton International by their Gulf Oil. Other Indian assets include listed Indusind Bank, with a recent market cap of $4 billion.They have also been consolidating their land parcels under Hinduja Realty Ventures which has a land bank of 2500 acres. The brothers who live in London, along with younger sibling Prakash who is in Geneva, and youngest Ashok in Mumbai, are descendants of Parmanand Hinduja who founded a trading business between India and Iran. Together they own Carlton Terrace House, a 70,000 square foot mansion in which they all have apartments; it was originally commissioned by King George IV and is close to Buckingham Palace. Vegetarians and teetotalers, they are known to donate liberally to social, cultural and charitable causes.

name: Billionaires
bio: Buyout investor Harold Simmons saw his fortune jump more than $1 billion since September thanks to rising shares of his publicly traded holding company Valhi, through which he has controlling interests in Kronos Worldwide, Titanium Metals Corporation, CompX International, and Keystone Consolidated Inc. In January 2013, Precision Castparts Group acquired Simmon's Titanium Metals Corp. for $16.5 per share in cash, valuing the company at roughly $2.9 billion. Simmons is a lavish supporter of conservative causes. He gave more than $25 million to Republican super PACs during the presidential election, and the $600,000 he gave to back Republican candidate Kevin James made him by far the biggest spender in the race for mayor of Los Angeles. The University of Texas graduate began his career as a bank examiner before buying a drug store near the Southern Methodist University campus with $5,000 cash and a $95,000 loan. He expanded quickly and sold his business to Eckerd Corporation a decade later for $50 million in 1973. He has given $177 million to date to UT Southwestern to establish the The Harold C. Simmons Comprehensive Cancer Center. He's given money to organizations looking to find cures for arthritis, kidney disease, and diseases of the brain and nervous system.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Magnit, Russia's biggest supermarket chain and cosmetics retailer, had a great year, with net profits up 92%. The retailer's success has helped boost the net worth of its founder and CEO, Sergei Galitsky, by more than $3 billion. The entrepreneur started out in 1994 as a perfume and beauty supplies wholesaler. Four years later, the Wal-Mart admirer opened his own grocery store with the the slogan "Always Low Prices." (Wal-Mart's slogan has long been "Everyday Low Prices."). He took the company public in April 2006.  He sold off an 8% stake in the company in a secondary offering in December 2011; he still has a 38% stake plus investments in agriculture, development, tourism and advertising. He recently bought a business jet and has a yacht under construction.

name: Billionaires
bio: Michael Hartono and his brother R. Budi have built their fortunes on a range of business interests. A significant portion of their wealth comes from Bank Central Asia, Indonesia's largest private bank. The brothers inherited clove cigarette maker Djarum from their father. In 2009 Djarum was banned in the U.S. along with other clove cigarettes. Djarum launched Dos Hermanos, maker of a premium cigar that blends Brazilian and Indonesian tobaccos. The siblings also have palm oil interests, and they own Grand Indonesia, a luxury shopping mall, office building and hotel complex in the center of Jakarta.

name: Billionaires
bio: Alexei Kuzmichev's Alfa Group, which he shares with fellow billionaires and college pals German Khan and Mikhail Fridman, is the biggest financial and industrial group in Russia. Kuzmichev met his partners in college. In 1991 they started Alfa Bank, which is now the biggest private bank in Russia. The trio bought Tyumen Oil from the state in the late 1990s and merged it with BP's Russian assets, forming TNK-BP. Last year Alfa Group, together with AAR partners, billionaires Viktor Vekselberg and Leonard Blavatnik, agreed to sell a 50% stake in TNK-BP to state-owned Rosneft for $28 billion. From this deal Kuzmichev will get more than $2.5 billion in cash.The group also has stakes in cellular company Vympelcom  and owns Russia's biggest retailer, X5. Kuzmichev heads a company called A1, which manages a portfolio of assets including the largest car sale company in Russia, Nezavisimost; two large cinema networks, Kronwerk Cinema and Formula Kino; and the largest supermarket chain in Belorussia, BelMarket.

name: Billionaires
bio: Google's executive chairman is looking to looking to become a little more financially independent of the Mountain View, Calif.-based company. In February, Schmidt filed a form with the Securities and Exchange Commision stating that he is looking to sell  42% of his shares in Google (or up to 3.2 million shares) in the upcoming year to diversify his assets. Continuing his role as Google's international ambassador, Schmidt visited North Korea in January with his daughter Sophie and former New Mexico Governor Bill Richardson in an attempt to convince the country's leaders to open internet channels.  His philanthropic interests include ocean exploration via his Schmidt Ocean Institute, which is working to preserve reef habitats and study pollution. He's also one of a handful of billionaires backing a high-profile asteroid mining project through a company called Planetary Resources. With an electrical engineering degree from Princeton and a Ph.D. from UC Berkeley, Schmidt began in software at Bell Labs, Xerox PARC, then started pre-IPO at Sun Microsystems in 1983. He rose to chief technology officer and led the development of Java. Before taking the helm at Google in 2001, he was CEO of Novell.
title: Executive Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: August von Finck Jr. is the grandson of banker Wilhelm von Finck, founder of insurance giant Allianz and private bank Merck, Finck & Co. August von Finck Jr. oversaw the sale of both entities to Barclays Bank in 1990. From his tax-free home in Switzerland he oversees an investment portfolio that includes real estate and industrial companies.

name: Billionaires
bio: In December 2012 Leonard Lauder enlisted Sotheby's to sell jewelry formerly owned by his late mother, Estee Lauder (d. 2004), and wife, Evelyn (d. 2011). The pieces went for a total of $22 million. Chairman emeritus of the cosmetics company Estee Lauder, he joined the family business in 1958 after attending the University of Pennsylvania and Columbia Business School. He stepped down as CEO in 1999 and remains on the board. He has majority voting power in Estee Lauder through a trust set up for the benefit of him, his wife and his descendents, as well as through shares he holds directly. His wife, whom he met on a blind date, died in November 2011 of ovarian cancer. She had survived breast cancer and in 1992 co-founded the pink ribbon campaign for breast cancer awareness. Lauder, a passionate art collector, is chairman emeritus of the Whitney Museum of American Art. His 2008 donation to it of $131 million is the largest in the museum's history. He owns one of the world's finest private collections of Cubist works, including Picasso's 1909 "Nude Woman in an Armchair." His art collection is altogether worth an estimated $1 billion. The New York Post's Page 6 has reported that he has been dating Linda E. Johnson, the president and CEO of the Brooklyn Public Library. She is a quarter century his junior.
title: Chairman Emeritus
employment: {'name': 'Estée Lauder Cos', 'uri': 'companies/estee-lauder-cos', 'title': 'Chairman Emeritus ', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Samuel Irving Newhouse, known as "S.I." or "Si," co-owns publishing giant Advance Publications with brother Donald. Father Sam Newhouse (d. 1979) was a first-generation American who turned the Bayone Times into the country's largest privately held newspaper chain. The brothers expanded the company and today Advance includes Bright House Cable and a stake in Discovery Communications, operator of cable and satellite TV networks like Discovery Channels and TLC. Donald oversees the newspaper business and Si heads Condé Nast, the magazine division. Titles include Vogue, The New Yorker and Wired. After a few tough years, the magazine industry is starting to see ad sales pick up, especially among fashion magazines. British Vogue is launching Miss Vogue for teenaged readers in May. Si owns an extensive modern art collection.

name: Billionaires
bio: Widow of J. Pierce Marshall, who inherited nearly all of a 14.6% stake in Koch Industries from his father, J. Howard Marshall II. (Namesake son J. Howard III was cut out entirely.) According to J. Pierce's will, Elaine is the income beneficiary of a trust that holds the Koch stock for her sons, Preston and E. Pierce Jr. Through representatives, she has denied owning any shares. Still, there's the income: More than $80 million in 2007, according to tax records associated with E. Pierce's estate.
title: Investor

name: Billionaires
bio: South African-born surgeon Patrick Soon-Shiong built and then sold two successful drug companies. In 2011 he founded NantWorks, a company that is attempting to revolutionize three industries--health care, digital entertainment and commerce--using science, supercomputing, voice recognition and low-power semiconductors. The company is working on new cancer therapies. It is also working on an app that gives doctors access to scientific research and information on a patient's DNA. In 2012 Blackstone Group invested $125 million for a stake in NantWorks' NantPharma unit. Soon-Shiong's father was a village doctor in China. His family moved to South Africa during World War II. He finished high school at 16 and became a doctor by 23. He took American Pharmaceutical Partners public in 2001 and spun off a new company, Abraxis, in 2007. He sold APP in 2008 for $5.6 billion to Germany's Fresenius and Abraxis in 2010 to Celgene for $2.9 billion. A member of the Giving Pledge, his donations include $5 million to the University of Chicago to develop technology to improve patient care and $136 million to St. John's Health Center in Santa Monica, California.

name: Billionaires
bio: Brothers Alain and Gerard Wertheimer own the French luxury brand Chanel. The company was founded in 1909 by their grandfather Pierre Wertheimer, who eventually bought out his early partner Gabrielle (Coco) Chanel, the company's namesake. In addition to clothing, the company sells perfume, make-up, jewelry and watches. Alain, a U.S. resident, is the chairman of the company and Gerard, who lives in Switzerland, heads up the watch division. The brothers are very private and don't give interviews to the press. In addition to Chanel, they own French vineyards Rauzan-Ségla in Margaux and Chateau Canon in Saint-Emilion. They also have thoroughbreds, including horses that have won such races as the French Derby and the Breeders' Cup Turf in the U.S.

name: Billionaires
bio: Patriarch Galen Weston is executive chairman of George Weston, the Canadian food and retail giant founded by his grandfather in 1882. Its stock has gained more than 12% over the past year.  In December, shares of its food retailer Loblaw, where his son Galen, Jr. is executive chairman, jumped when it announced that it would spin off its considerable real estate holdings into one of Canada's biggest real estate investment trusts. Weston also controls Selfridges Group whose department store holdings include Ogilvy's and Holt Renfrew in Canada; Brown Thomas in Ireland; Selfridges in the U.K.; and de Bijenkorf in the Netherlands.
title: Owner

name: Billionaires
bio: Woo is chairman of Wharf Holdings, which contains his main real estate, investment, logistics and media businesses. His wealth has soared at a time of busy rentals at Woo's landmark Hong Kong properties. Wharf shares are up 40% from a year ago. Woo controls the company through his 59.8% stake in Wheelock & Co. Among Wharf's property portfolio's prizes: Times Square, where New Year's Eve revelers gather; and Kowloon's Harbour City. Also owns a minority stake in Salvatore Ferragamo and 73% of fashion retailer Joyce Boutique.

name: Billionaires
bio: Kumar Birla's $40 billion (revenues) Aditya Birla Group, a commodities conglomerate that is India's largest cement maker, among much else, is aiming for $65 billion in revenues by 2015. It snatched a 50% stake in Pantaloon Retail, flagship of troubled retail king Kishore Biyani, for $150 million. It also acquired Canadian pulp mill Terrace Bay for $110 million and is reportedly negotiating to acquire additional cement capacity. But it backed out of bid for Australian miner Northern Iron.  He's keen to start a bank and is likely to be among bidders for a new banking licence. In his first foray into media, he picked up 27.5%  in Living Media, which publishes magazines India Today and Business Today. The postal department recently issued a stamp, released by the president of India, commemorating his late father Aditya Birla. His mother Rajashree, who has built a hospital in her late husband's name and is known to support India's widows, has featured in Forbes Asia's Heroes of Philanthropy list.

name: Billionaires
bio: Carlos Alberto Sicupira shares control of Anheuser-Busch InBev, the world's largest beer company, with longtime billionaire partners Jorge Paulo Lemann and Marcel Telles. Their investment firm 3G Capital, with offices in Rio de Janeiro and New York City, partnered with Warren Buffett to buy Heinz in February 2013. In 2010 the trio partnered with billionaire Eike Batista, then the richest man in the Southern hemisphere, to buy Burger King. They took the hamburger chain private and listed it again two years later. The trio also control listed Brazilian retailer Lojas Americanas and real estate investment firm São Carlos Empreendimentos e Participações S.A. Sicupira holds multiple world records for underwater spearfishing.

name: Billionaires
bio: Like former business partner and fellow billionaire Lev Kvetnoi, Andrei Skoch was born in a small settlement near Moscow and studied at the same school of athletics, the Institute of Physical Culture. He later worked for Moscow's MontazhSpetsBank. With Kvetnoi, Skoch joined billionaire Alisher Usmanov's metallurgical business. Kvetnoi was sent to Oskol Metal Works, while Skoch went to Lebedinsky Mining. Later Usmanov joined the two firms with a third to create the Metalloinvest conglomerate. Kvetnoi sold out, but Skoch remains a partner. He became a member of the Russian parliament's lower house in 1999 and sponsors a literary competition for young authors called Debut. He is erecting a memorial to fallen Russian soldiers in Port Arthur (Lyushun, China), the site of the bloodiest battles of the Russo-Japanese war of 1904-1905.

name: Billionaires
bio: Tsai Wan-tsai and his sons Daniel and Richard are back on the upswing though solid growth at their Fubon Financial Holding, while his billionaire nephews run the other family business Cathay Financial Holdings. Fubon shares are up more than 30% from a year ago, as the bank continues to cement its reputation as one of the most aggressive Taiwanese banks to move into China. In December it announced the acquisition of an 80% stake in China's Firstsino Bank for $1.03 billion. Success in real estate, broadcasting and telecommunications businesses have also boosted the family fortune. His billionaire nephews run  Cathay Financial Holdings

name: Billionaires
bio: James ("Jim") Goodnight co-founded business analytics software giant SAS with John Sall in 1976. Now the world's largest private software company, SAS traces its roots back to a research project that analyzed agricultural data at North Carolina State University, where both men were faculty members. SAS's revenues increased to $2.87 billion in 2012. The firm is known for worker-friendly policies, wellness programs, on-site daycare centers and free snacks. With Sall, Goodnight also owns the tony Prestonwood Country Club and The Umstead Hotel & Spa. The two co-founded a private school, Cary Academy, near Raleigh-Durham, North Carolina. An outspoken proponent of education reform, Goodnight has made education the focus of SAS company philanthropy. He also developed educational software that helps schools extend the use of technology as a tool for learning.
title: CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: Savitri Jindal's fortune fell $3.3 billion over the past year and is down $5.6 billion in two years as the OP Jindal Group, steel and power conglomerate founded by her late husband, which she chairs, faced another tough year. Youngest son Naveen who runs Jindal Steel & Power, family's biggest asset, faced flak when a government auditor charged that the company had unfairly secured coal mines from the government. He denied any wrongdoing saying the mines were allocated on merit but its shares have fallen 35% nonetheless. After conducting a sting operation against reporters from fellow billionaire Subhash Chandra's broadcaster Zee, he accused them of blackmailing him by demanding advertisements in exchange for favorable coverage. Shares of JSW Steel, run by son Sajjan, fell when it announced plans to merge with JSW Ispat, a company it had acquired from Lakshmi Mittal's younger brother in 2010.

name: Billionaires
bio: Klaus Tschira's fortune more than doubled from a year ago based in part on a rise in the value of software firm SAP's shares, but mostly due to new information about the status of Tschira's charitable foundation, which owns about 4% of SAP stock. For many years, Forbes has excluded the value of those shares, believing them to be irrevocably owned and controlled by a charity. It turns out that the foundation is a limited liability company with a charitable purpose, over which Tschira has full control. As a result, Forbes is including the shares owned by the foundation as part of Tschira's net worth. Tschira co-founded SAP in 1972 with five former IBM colleagues --three of whom are also billionaires (Hasso Plattner, Dietmar Hopp and Hans Werner Hector). It has grown to be one of the world's largest software firms, with $18.5 billion revenue in 2011. He retired from the company in 1998 and stepped down from its supervisory board in 2007. His Klaus Tschira Foundation is one of Germany's largest philanthropic organizations, with assets of $2.7 billion. It supports scientific research and cultural projects such as a youth software prize given to students who explain math or science matters through the clever use of software. In 2010, the foundation spent $37 million on various projects. Tschira has taken up astronomy as a hobby, and has an asteroid between Mars and Jupiter named after him.

name: Billionaires
bio: Charles Butt is chairman and CEO of the San Antonio-based H-E-B grocery store chain, which has 305 stores in Texas, plus 42 stores in Mexico. Butt's grandmother founded the company in 1905. He is the majority shareholder; his two siblings and two nephews also own some of the company. H-E-B donates 5% of pretax profits to charity. Butt collects modern art.

name: Billionaires
bio: Kjeld Kirk Kristiansen is the grandson of the founder of LEGO. It is now the second biggest toy company in the world, having moved ahead of Hasbro. Kristiansen served as LEGO's chief executive for 25 years before stepping down in 2004. He remains deputy chairman of the board and the company's majority owner through his holding company KIRKBI A/S. During his tenure he introduced new ideas including Star Wars and Lord of the Rings-themed LEGOs and popular mini-figures. The company has been profitable since 2006 after selling off numerous assets. In 2012 LEGO shut down the LEGO Universe multiplayer online game because it couldn't recruit enough paying members. Kristiansen founded the Next Generation Foundation, which encourages child development through creativity and play.
