He also started the First Lego League (FLL), a program designed for children ages 9-14 who demonstrate a passion for science, technology and innovation. FLL has 20,000 teams in more than 70 countries and hosted its first worldwide robotics tournament in 2012.

name: Billionaires
bio: Liang Wengen owns 58% of Sany Group, one of China's largest non-governent-controlled makers of construction equipment. Liang topped the 2011 Forbes China Rich List with wealth of $9.3 billion, but his fortune has slipped in the past year on rough competition and eased demand for its excavators and backhoes. Shares in its Shanghai-listed flagship Sany Heavy Industry and its Hong Kong-listed coal mining equipment arm are only now recovering from their winter lows. Sany in December moved its headquarters to Beijing in a shift to help speed its overseas expansion; most of its operations will remain in its original home in Changsha. Sany Group suffered a setback in September when the U.S. rejected a Sany-backed application to build a wind farm next to a U.S. military base in Oregon. Sany had better luck a year ago in another cross-border deal: the successful teaming up with CITIC Private Equity Advisors of China to purchase Putzmeister of Germany, one of the world's largest concrete pump manufacturers, in a transaction worth $475 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Donald Newhouse co-owns Advance Publications with his brother "S.I." or "Si." He heads the newspaper division which publishes local papers in more than 25 American cities and towns. In the face of continued pressures on the newspaper industry Advance began to reduce the number of print editions published each week for a number of their papers. In October 2012 the Times-Picayune reduced its schedule to three printed issues a week, making New Orleans the largest American city without a daily paper. Brother Si oversees the magazine portion of the business under the Condé Nast banner. The company was founded by their father, Sam Newhouse, who turned the Bayone Times into the country's largest privately held newspaper chain. The brothers took over after their father's death in 1979 and expanded into cable television through ownership of Bright House Cable and a stake in Discovery Communications, operator of cable and satellite TV networks like Discovery Channel and Animal Planet. Despite dropping out of Syracuse University, Donald donates to the school and established the Wellesley Center for the Humanities at his wife Susan's alma mater.

name: Billionaires
bio: Dieter Schnabel owns chemical company Helm AG, whose sales grew 20% to $12.7 billion in 2011. That growth resulted in a $2.5 billion increase in Schnabel's estimated net worth since last year. He inherited Helm AG when his father Hermann, the company's founder, died in 2010. It is one of the world's leading independent chemical marketing firms, active in pharmaceutical ingredients, fertilizer and crop protection, organic and inorganic chemicals and human and animal nutrition, with offices in 30 countries. Schnabel was chairman of the executive board from 1984 until early 2012, when he resigned and became head of the supervisory board. He reportedly enjoys golf and kayaking.

name: Billionaires
bio: Leonid Fedun is a former military man turned financial whiz. While teaching in the Siberian city of Kogalym in the late 1980s, he met Vagit Alekperov, who was the head of the local oil and gas company. In the 1990s Fedun helped privatize Lukoil, which was formed from the best Russian oil properties. Alekperov now heads Lukoil, and Fedun works as his right hand man and has a more than 9% stake in the company. He also oversees the investing activities of IFD Capital. He owns the famous Moscow soccer team Spartak and is building a new $500 million stadium for it. The stadium is 80% finished. It was given the name Otkrytiye Arena in a formal ceremony in February 2013.

name: Billionaires
bio: Polymetal International CEO Suleiman Kerimov finally put an end to rumors that he was trying to buy out a 37.8% share of rival Polyus Gold International, held by Mikhail Prokhorov, his fellow metals billionaire. So much for a giant merger. Kerimov has made no secret of pouring resources into his local soccer club, Anzhi Mahachkala, and promoting the career of striker, Samuel Eto'o , a Cameroonian. An investor in distressed companies, Kerimov had a tough 2008. Selling nearly all his Russian assets-including shares in Gazprom, government-owned Sberbank and a massive housing development in suburban Moscow-just before Russia's financial meltdown, Kerimov borrowed heavily to buy stakes in Morgan Stanley, Goldman Sachs, Deutsche Bank, Credit Suisse and others. He lost billions soon after. But he recovered and, with the help of still more loans from Russia's VTB, began investing again in the Russian market, buying a stake in the nation's largest gold mining outfit, Polyus Gold, real estate company PIK and leading long-distance telephony provider Rostelecom. In the summer of 2010 he bought Dmitry Rybolovlev's controlling stake in Uralkali, the biggest producer of potassium fertilizers in Russia. In exchange he gave Rybolovlev a portion of his stake in Polyus Gold'setting up the rivalry. Kerimov is a native of Dagestan, a republic in Russia's North Caucasus.

name: Billionaires
bio: Master marketer Dietrich Mateschitz --the brains behind the Red Bull energy drink -- has coaxed year upon year of growth out of the Red Bull business. Sales grew an impressive 12% in 2011 to $5.6 billion (4.25 billion Euros). Mateschitz and his team continue to pull off eye-catching marketing stunts. In October 2012 he financed a team supporting the Austrian skydiver Felix Baumgartner, who broke a record with a supersonic freefall jump from 39 kilometers above the earth. Mateschitz formed Red Bull in 1984 with Thai business partner Chaleo Yoovidhya, who died in March 2012. A Taurus (the zodiac sign of the bull), Mateschitz owns 49% of the company, which still plans to expand to China. Red Bull is now also present in France, Denmark and Norway, where it had been banned because of its contents; it is still banned in Iceland and Uruguay. Thanks to higher sales figures, Mateschitz's estimated net worth rose $1.8 billion since last year. The company has stakes in two soccer teams: Red Bull Salzburg and New York Red Bulls, and a Formula One team, Red Bull Racing. Mateschitz's other interests include Seitenblicke magazine; Servus TV; a luxury resort on the island of Laucala in Fiji; and Hangar-7, the event center on the grounds of the Salzburg airport that houses his historical aircraft collection, the Flying Bulls.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ludwig Merckle inherited a debt-plagued fortune from his father, billionaire Adolf Merckle, and has executed an impressive turnaround. His most valuable holding is pharmaceutical distributor Phoenix, one of Europe's largest. Profits grew 50% in 2011 to $320 million on sales of nearly $29 billion and contributed to the $2 billion rise in FORBES' estimate of Merckle's net worth. His father Adolf committed suicide in early 2009 at age 74 after a bad investing bet on Volkswagen shares led to a spiraling debt load for the secretive German investor. Adolf Merckle was once one of Germany's wealthiest men; in 2007 FORBES pegged his fortune at $12.8 billion. Ludwig took over his father's VEM Holding in mid 2009 and began selling assets to pay off debt. In the fall of 2009 he unloaded shares of HeidelbergCement, cutting his stake from 74% to a current 25%. The following year he sold generic drug maker Ratiopharm to Teva Pharmacueticals for $5 billion. Ludwig still owns snowcat maker Kaessbohrer and drug wholesaler Phoenix, which had to borrow heavily to stay in business but is now paying down its debt.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mohamed Bin Issa Al Jaber owns a string of luxury and budget hotels in Europe and Egypt through JJW Hotels & Resorts. He settled a battle with Standard Bank in London in December 2011. The bank had accused him of failing to repay a $150 million loan, and Al Jaber claimed the bank made an unauthorized loan deal with his assistant to cover trading losses. A UNESCO special envoy, through his foundation Al Jaber has organized support for restoring Mali's cultural heritage including mosques and old Muslim manuscripts destroyed by militant Islamists over the past year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Edward Johnson III , CEO and chairman of Fidelity Investments, promoted his daughter, Abigail, to head up the biggest business units at Fidelity Investments in August 2012. She's now positioned to take over the money management firm. With $1.6 trillion under management, Fidelity is the second largest mutual fund company in the U.S. "Ned" joined Fidelity, his father's company, as an analyst in 1957 and took over the company's flagship Magellan Fund eight years later. He became president of the company in 1972 and chairman and CEO in 1977. The family owns 49% of the company, though he reduced his personal stake in 1995 for estate planning purposes. In addition to mutual funds, the firm runs a brokerage business, an insurance arm and a private equity group.

name: Billionaires
bio: Hong Kong property tycoon Joseph Lau faces bribery charges for allegedly paying off a former Macau official for an investment in a luxury residential development. Lau, who will also face money laundering charges, failed to attend a subsequent hearing on the case due to a "chronic disease". He has denied the allegations. Lau controls Chinese Estates, best known for a shopping complex in Tsim Sha Tsui, Kowloon, called The One. Together with his family, he also holds a large stake in Lifestyle International, whose tenants include the giant Sogo department store in Causeway Bay.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ralph Lauren's vision of upper-crust American prep continues to sell, both here and abroad, though the company discontinued its youth-oriented Rugby brand in February. Revenue hit $1.85 billion for the third fiscal quarter of 2013, up more than 2% over the same period last year. A Bronx native, Lauren left school in 1976 to design ties for Beau Brummel, then launched Polo with $50,000 later that year. The company now sells clothing, shoes, jewelry, home goods and fragrances, with Lauren's gear outfitting American athletes in the 2012 London Summer Olympic games. His car collection (Bugatti, Bentley, Alfa Romeo, Ferrari) is so well regarded that Boston's Museum of Fine Arts exhibited it in 2005. In the wake of Hurricane Sandy, Lauren donated $1 million to the Mayor's Fund to Advance New York City.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Ralph Lauren', 'uri': 'companies/ralph-lauren', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Home improvement tycoon John Menard has expanded his D-I-Y empire, now the third-largest retailer in its category in the U.S., with an estimated $8.8 billion in annual revenue, and 273 stores in 14 states. In 2013 Menards is slated to enter the St. Louis and Detroit markets. The University of Wisconsin-Eau Claire grad financed his education working construction. In the 1960s he began selling tools from a single store, which grew into his giant Midwestern chain. After fielding race cars in the IndyCar series for years, he finally broke through in 2011 when his son Paul won his first NASCAR race at the Brickyard 500. Menard serves on the board of Polaris Industries, a maker of ATVs and snowmobiles. He gave $15 million to the Mayo Clinic, which was used in part to build the Menard Center for Emergency Care at Luther Midelfort in Eau Claire, Wisconsin.
title: president and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Menard, Inc.', 'title': 'president and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: David Tepper continues to make a good case that he is one of the greatest hedge fund investors ever. While most hedge funds underperformed the U.S. stock market in 2012, Tepper trounced it. His flagship fund posted net returns of about 30%. His $15 billion Appaloosa Management has generated average annualized returns of approximately 30% net since inception in 1993. He returned some cash to his investors at the end of 2012. Tepper continues to focus his philanthropic efforts on education-- from the elementary school level to university--and feeding the hungry in his home state of New Jersey. Tepper has donated significantly to food banks and food pantries across N.J. for the past five years and funded numerous educational causes and institutions, like Teach for America. He gave $55 million to Carnegie Mellon's business school in 2004; it was renamed the Tepper School of Business. Tepper is a minority owner of the Pittsburgh Steelers.
title: President and Founder
employment: {'name': 'Appaloosa Management', 'title': 'President and Founder', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Robin Li is CEO of China's biggest search engine Baidu. You might think its 2012 profit growth of 57% would be enough to please investors, but Baidu shares have tanked on worries of intensifying competition and crimped revenue and profit as the world shifts from PCs to mobile devices. Li lost his top spot among mainland China's billionaires this year--his fortune has shrunk by a third. A one-day fall of 10% in January alone wiped $785 million from his fortune. Before founding Baidu, Li worked in Silicon Valley for Infoseek, a search pioneer. Li holds degrees from Peking University, where he majored in library science, and the State University of New York at Buffalo, where he earned a master's degree in computer science. He sits on the board of New York-listed New Oriental Education & Technology, which provides educational services in China. His wealth includes shares held by his wife, Melissa Ma.
title: Founder and CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: Ma Huateng, also known as Pony Ma, is the chairman and CEO of Tencent Holdings, one of China's "big three" Internet companies along with Baidu and Alibaba, led by fellow billionaires Robin Li and Jack Ma, respectively. Tencent 's QQ instant messaging service had a staggering 784 million active users at the end of September, 10% more than a year earlier. The company's WeChat mobile community reached 200 million users as of September. Those gains and the successes of its online games such as Legend of Yulong and Legend of Xuanyuan boosted revenue by more than half in the first nine months of last year to $5.1 billion;  profit increased by 21% to $1.5 billion. Tencent's chief technology officer Zhang Zhidong is also a member of this year's billionaires list.

name: Billionaires
bio: Telecom tycoon Sunil Mittal is poorer by more than $1 billion as shares of his Bharti Airtel, which has 262 million customers in 20 countries, tumbled.  It reported a 72% fall in net profits to $53 million, amid rising costs in its African operations.  Debt-laden company raised $600 million from December listing of telecom tower arm Bharti Infratel which brother Rakesh chairs. Shares are off 12% since. His joint venture with Wal-Mart which was to benefit from new rule allowing foreign investment in big-box retailing, is facing uncertainty amid a government investigation into whether it had allegedly violated foreign investment rules. Family's newest venture is a franchise for PizzaExpress managed by nephew Ramit. His Bharti Foundation operates 254 schools that have 38,000 students mostly from poor communities

name: Billionaires
bio: While his wife, fashion royalty Miuccia Prada, runs the design side of luxury goods and clothing giant Prada, Bertelli handles the business side as CEO. Both saw their net worth almost double year-on-year, from a combined $10.5 billion to $19.1 billion between them thanks to Prada's 75% stock boost (the Milan-based design house went public in Hong Kong in 2011). Now Prada is expanding: in 2012 it opened new stores in Abu Dhabi and Kuwait. Now, the company is reportedly seeking a partner to enter India. Bertelli ran a leather accessories company before meeting Miuccia in 1977 at a trade fair in Milan; the two were married the following year. He pushed Prada to open its first store in New York in 1986 and urged the brand to acquire smaller labels during the 1990s.

name: Billionaires
bio: Filaret Galchev's Eurocement Group is Russia's largest producer of cement. In the 1990s he built the country's largest coal-trading company, Rosuglesbyt. When he got into cement, he bought Stern Cement's plants and the cement arm of Inteko, owned by fellow billionaire Elena Baturina. Then he bought out partner Georgy Kransyansky to become Inteko's sole owner. In 2011 he bought his first stake in Holcim, a Swiss cement business, and now he owns 10.8% of that company, making him its biggest shareholder after Thomas Schmidheiny, who represents its founders' family. He also has invested in the construction of several modernized cement factories across Russia, and his company controls more than 35% of the Russian market for cement.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ivan Glasenberg, the chief executive of mining and trading giant Glencore International, landed the deal of a lifetime in 2012 by orchestrating the takeover of mining company Xstrata. The deal still faces hurdles but once it's final--the closing is expected by March 15--Glasenberg will emerge as the new company's CEO and second-biggest shareholder after the emirate of Qatar. Glasenberg earned his MBA from the University of Southern California in 1983 and joined commodity trader Marc Rich & Co. in 1984, working as a marketer in the coal and coke department in his native South Africa. By the time management bought out the company and re-branded it as Glencore in 1994, Glasenberg had risen to the post of worldwide director. He is a former South African race-walking champion and also represented Israel in the sport.

name: Billionaires
bio: In July 2012 Vladimir Yevtushenkov tussled with Uzbekistan authorities, who banned his mobile outfit MTS, the largest cellular operator in Russia, from operating in their country. They also confiscated the property of MTS' Uzbek subsidiary. Russian authorities responded by seizing a luxury apartment in Moscow that belongs to the Uzbek president's daughter, Gulnara Karimova. It now looks as if MTS may be able to resume operations in the neighboring nation in 2013. It is just one of some 200 companies that are part of Yevtushenkov's London-listed AFK Sistema.Other interests include toy stores and stakes in the oil companies Bashneft and Russneft. A former plastics engineer, Yevtushenkov co-founded Sistema in 1993 and took it public on the London Stock Exchange in 2005.

name: Billionaires
bio: Eva Gonda Rivera is new to the Forbes Billionaires list. She is the widow of Eugenio Garza Laguera, the former chair of Femsa, Latin America's largest beverage company and the biggest independent Coca-Cola distributor in the region. Eugenio died in 2008 and passed his stake to his wife and four daughters. Together they control 50% of Femsa's B shares, which are traded both in Mexico and on the New York Stock Exchange. One of the daughters, Eva Maria Garza Laguera Gonda, is married to Jose Antonio Fernandez Carbajal, the CEO of Femsa.

name: Billionaires
bio: France's internet king Xavier Niel has gotten $2.1 billion richer in the past year, thanks to a jump in the stock of Iliad, parent company of his telecom outfit Free. In 2012 Niel launched Free Mobile, which aims to do for mobile phones what Niel has already done for broadband in France: ruffle the feathers of the establishment by offering cut-rate prices without commitment. A year in, Free Mobile already claims a 5.4% market share. Niel has also made waves by taking on Google on his home turf, blocking the web giant's online ads for users of his Free ISP. The 45-year-old had his first entrepreneurial success as a teenager when he built an erotic chat service for French internet forerunner Minitel. After foregoing college, he launched his country's first ISP in 1993, making his first fortune when it sold for $50 million at the height of the internet boom. He was a shareholder in sex shops and peep shows until a prostitution scandal landed him in jail for a month. He was cleared of pimping charges but convicted of failing to disclose income.

name: Billionaires
bio: Johann Rupert's fortune has grown an astounding 30% over the course of the past year, due largely to the thriving fortunes of his Swiss-based luxury goods outfit, Compagnie Financiere Richemont. The stock has jumped more than 50% year-on-year. In November 2012, the company announced that Rupert will step down as CEO by March. Co-CEOs Richard Lepeu (currently deputy CEO) and Bernard Fornas (currently head of Cartier) will replace him. His fortune is further buoyed by stakes in investment holding companies Remgro and Reinet. He is an avid golfer.

name: Billionaires
bio: Dietmar Hopp co-founded and helped build German software company SAP into the giant that it is today, serving as co-CEO from 1988 to 1998 and then chairman of the supervisory board until 2003. He retired from the SAP board in 2005. The following year, he transferred nearly three-quarters of his 10% stake in SAP into a limited liability company with a charitable purpose; his Dietmar Hopp Stiftung supports sports, medicine, education and social programs. FORBES counts the SAP shares in the Dietmar Hopp Stiftung towards Hopp's net worth because he controls them and can sell them at any time (though the dividends must be used for a charitable purpose). Hopp's net worth has climbed $1 billion over the past year due to a jump in the value of SAP shares. He also owns Domaine de Terre Blanche, a luxury golf resort and gated community in Provence, and has invested in a number of biotech and life science companies.

name: Billionaires
bio: Tech tycoon Shiv Nadar's wealth got a boost as shares of HCL Technologies, flagship of his $6.2 billion (revenues) HCL Group, gained on a better than expected performance in the last quarter when net profits rose by 68% to $180 million. In  January, its chief executive Vineet Nayyar handed charge to another company long-timer, though he remains vice-charman. Earlier, in June Nayyar had sold all his shares sparking speculation about his exit which the company had denied.  Hardware arm HCL Infosystems announced plan to spin off its hardware, learning and services businesses into three subsidiaries.  Daughter Roshni overseas two schools established by family's philanthropic arm. Wife Kiran has an art museum in a popular mall in Delhi.

name: Billionaires
bio: Idan Ofer and his older brother Eyal inherited a fortune from their father, shipping magnate Sammy Ofer, who was once Israel's richest man and died in June 2011. Idan is the principal of Quantum Pacific Group, which holds the Ofer stake in Israel Corporation, the largest public holding company on the Tel Aviv Stock Exchange; and also of Pacific Drilling SA, which went public on the NYSE last year. He is also chairman of Better Place, a Silicon Valley electric car fueling station startup, which has yet to turn a profit. In November, he launched a 50-meter yacht named after that company. He shares his father's shipping empire and vast art collection, said to be one of the world's most magnificent, with Eyal.

name: Billionaires
bio: Diamond magnate Nicky Oppenheimer made a pivotal decision in November 2011 to sell his family's 40% stake in De Beers, the world's largest diamond producer, to mining behemoth Anglo American for $5.1 billion. Anglo already owned 45% of DeBeers. The deal was slowed by the government of Botswana, which owns the remaining 15% of the company, and had preemptive rights to one fourth of Oppenheimer's stake.Botswana passed on the opportunity to buy that stake in July 2012, and the deal got final regulatory approval that month. The all-cash deal marks the end of Oppenheimer's control of De Beers, a relationship that began when Nicky's grandfather, Ernest Oppenheimer, took over the firm in 1927. (Ernest also founded Anglo American in 1917.) Some say the Anglo American deal undervalued De Beers, but there were no other interested buyers. Nicky Oppenheimer's passions include flying helicopters, cricket and conservation. He owns the Tswalu Kalahari Reserve, the largest private game reserve in South Africa.

name: Billionaires
bio: Investor Ira Rennert is a former credit analyst who made his first fortune in junk bonds in the 1980s. The Brooklyn native built his Renco Group into one of the nation's largest holding companies. In 2011 he bought steel assets from Russia's OAO Severstal through a new company, RG Steel. Fourteen months later RG filed for bankruptcy and laid off 4,000 workers. In January 2013 RG's creditors sued, accusing Rennert of delaying bankruptcy proceedings for personal gain, but the creditors withdrew the suit the next month. In 1992 Rennert paid $133 million for military contractor AM General, which started selling consumer Hummers. In 2004 he sold a majority stake to billionaire Ronald Perelman's MacAndrews & Forbes for $930 million. Renco's holdings include US Magnesium and the Doe Run Company, a mining outfit in Peru that is the subject of a long-running pollution suit. Rennert's 43,000-square-foot home in Sagaponack, N.Y., has 29 bedrooms and 39 baths. His neighbors have reportedly complained about his noisy helicopter. He gives to Jewish causes and gave $2 million to the Albert Einstein College of Medicine and $1 million to the pro-Romney Restore Our Future political action committee.

name: Billionaires
bio: Nassef Sawiris runs Orascom Construction Industries, Egypt's most valuable publicly-traded company. He announced in January 2013 that the company was exchanging all global depository receipts of the company for newly issued shares of OCI NV on NYSE Euronext in Amsterdam. The transaction was backed by $1 billion from U.S. investors, including Bill Gates, and will help cover payments to shareholders who opt instead to tender their OCI shares for cash. With Egypt still in turmoil, it is the largest foreign investment in the country since the revolution, but a primary listing on an international exchange gives it more credibility with investors.

name: Billionaires
bio: Shares in private equity powerhouse Blackstone Group have risen in the past year, driving up chairman and CEO Stephen Shwarzman's fortune by $1.3 billion. The firm went public in 2007 and as of the end of 2012, had $210 billion in assets under management. In the past year it upped its investments in the property market, spending more than $2.5 billion on 16,000 homes to manage as rentals. Schwarzman co-founded the firm with Peter Peterson in 1985 with only $400,000 on the balance sheet. Peterson left the firm in 2008. That same year Schwarzman announced a $100 million donation to the New York Public Library; the main Fifth Avenue branch was soon named after him. He and his wife also send hundreds of children to parochial schools in New York each year, receive all their report cards and write them all notes. He went to Yale with George W. Bush.
title: Chairman and CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: Stefano Pessina's net worth has more than doubled since last year due a whopping purchase by Walgreen of a chunk of international drugstore chain Alliance Boots in mid 2012. Walgreen paid $6.7 billion in cash and shares for a 45% stake in Alliance Boots, which has some 3,300 retail outlets in 25 countries and revenues of $35.7 billion. Pessina took his payment in Walgreen's equity, and now owns about 8% of Walgreen stock. He held on to about half of his Alliance Boots stake--roughly 18%-- now worth $3.3 billion. Pessina, a former nuclear engineer, turned his family's ailing Naples pharmaceutical wholesaler into Alliance UniChem Group, which merged with the U.K. pharmacy chain Boots Group in 2006 to form Alliance Boots. The following year Alliance Boots went private in a $22 billion deal with financing from private equity firm KKR, still Europe's largest leveraged buyout. In an effort to expand globally the company formed a strategic partnership with China's fifth largest pharmaceutical wholesaler, Nanjing Pharmaceutical, in September 2012. Pessina is Alliance Boots' executive chairman and sits on Walgreen's Board.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heinz Hermann Thiele and his family acquired brakemaker Knorr-Bremse AG in the late 1980s and transformed it into world's leading manufacturer of braking systems for rail and commercial vehicles. His fortune has risen by $2 billion over the past year, buoyed by a nearly 15% rise in revenues, to $5.6 billion, in 2011. Thiele sits on the company's advisory board; he withdrew from his position on the operational side of the business in 2011. He has also given a portion of the company to his two children, Henrik and Julia. Thiele is said to enjoy hiking, skiing and animal photography. He has received various awards for his philanthropic contributions, including his support of children's cancer research and aid to developing countries. In 2012 Thiele increased his ownership of quoted German railroad equipment maker Vossloh to 25% of the company.

name: Billionaires
bio: In November 2012 Eli Broad returned to his alma mater, Michigan State University, to inaugurate the Eli and Edythe Broad Art Museum, a project to which he had donated $28 million. The son of Lithuanian immigrants, he was born in the Bronx and raised in Detroit. He bought his first real estate at age 20 and co-founded the home builder Kaufman & Broad in 1957 with $25,000 borrowed from his in-laws. It became one of the nation's biggest home builders by supplying parents of baby boomers with affordable housing. In 1971 he bought Sun Life Insurance (later renamed SunAmerica), and he sold it to AIG in 1998 for $18 billion in cash and stock. Now he largely devotes himself to philanthropy, and he has already given an estimated $3.5 billion (more than 50% of his current net worth) to charity, including $600 million to found the Broad Institute for biomedical research at Harvard and MIT. He and wife, Edythe, created the Broad Art Foundation in 1984; it now owns more than $2.4 billion in art, which it lends to contemporary art to institutions around the world. The couple is building The Broad, a new contemporary art museum and worldwide headquarters for their foundation, to open in Los Angeles in early 2014. "My wife, Edye, and I have been blessed with extraordinary success," Broad told Forbes. "We consider it a privilege to invest our resources in making life better for people by improving public education, advancing scientific and medical research and fostering public appreciation of the arts." He is also the largest donor to, and sits on the board of, the Museum of Contemporary Art, Los Angeles. He was one of that museum's earliest donors and made its construction possible. MOCA has been embroiled in infighting and leadership changes, with charges of mismanagement and difficulty generating donations. Following the financial crisis, Broad promised $30 million in additional gifts to it to be distributed as matching gifts. He also gave his blessing to the museum's naming of a businessman as its director, and some have charged that the museum's artistic integrity has suffered as a result. Broad is a member of the Giving Pledge and, like Warren Buffett, supports higher taxes for the rich. "Those of us who have gained great success have an obligation to pay more taxes," he told Forbes in 2011. "We've been coddled long enough and have tax breaks that 99.9% of the public don't have, and it's not fair."

name: Billionaires
bio: Chung Mong-Koo is chairman of Hyundai Motors, the fifth largest automaker in the world. The company sold more than 7 million cars in 2012. Hyundai had a 10% market share in the U.S. in 2011, up from 3.3% in 2001, though recalls hurt U.S. sales in 2012. It is the only car company that has an in-house steel mill that produces steel plates used in its vehicles. Chung is the second son of the Hyundai conglomerate's late founder, Chung Ju-Yung. Chung Mong-Koo's son Chung Eui-Sun is Hyundai's vice chairman. His brother, billionaire Chung Mong-Joon, has a big stake in the nation's largest shipbuilder, Hyundai Heavy Industries.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Shares of Indian land baron Kushal Pal Singh's listed developer DLF fell in October over a scandal for allegedly selling prime properties at below market rates and giving loans to Robert Vadra, son-in-law of Congress Party's Sonia Gandhi. DLF denied any wrongdoing stating that all transactions were above board. The federal corporate affairs ministry had earlier probed DLF for alleged accounting irregularities. Meanwhile, it has been selling assets in bid to reduce its $3.9 billion debt. In August, it sold a prime plot of land in Mumbai, on which it had planned a luxury residential project to fellow billionaire Mangal Prabhat Lodha. In December, it sold its stake in Amanresorts chain to its original founder Adrian Zecha for close to $300 million. It's also reportedly negotiating with South Korea's Samsung Life to sell its stake in an insurance venture.

name: Billionaires
bio: Silvio Berlusconi sure acts like the Teflon politician. Despite an October 2012 conviction by a Milan court for tax fraud and still pending charges against him for having sex with a minor (he denies the allegations), the billionaire announced in December that he plans to run for prime minister of Italy again -- a post from which he resigned in November 2011 amid plunging approval ratings and one he has held three times. Berlusconi started his career as a singer on cruise ships and built a fortune through holding company Fininvest that includes stakes in Mediaset, Italy's largest media company; financial services company Mediolanum (founded by Italian billionaire Ennio Doris); Mondadori, one of the country's largest publishing houses; movie maker Medusa and popular soccer team A.C. Milan. Berlusconi's eldest daughter Marina chairs Fininvest. A rise in the price of Mediolanum stock lifted Berlusconi's net worth by $300 million over the past year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Eduardo Belmont  is new to the Forbes Billionaires list. One of Peru's richest men, he owns Belcorp, a $2 billion (estimated sales) door-to-door cosmetics company that operates in 15 Latin American countries and the U.S. He and his brother Fernando used to run a jointly-owned cosmetics firm called Yanbal, but in 1988 the two parted ways and each now runs his own beauty enterprise. Fernando's company kept the Yanbal name. Eduardo has degrees from both Harvard Business School and Wharton.

name: Billionaires
bio: Rosalia Mera, co-founder of Inditex with ex-husband Amancio Ortega, remains Spain's richest woman. Mera dropped out of school at age 11 to work as a seamstress, then helped her then-husband make dressing gowns and lingerie in their home. Today the company Ortega and Mera founded is one of the globe's most successful retailers: Inditex, parent company of the Zara retail stores. Mera and Ortega are long-divorced, but she still holds a 5.1% stake in the $18.1 billion (2011 sales) Inditex, and has diversified after the retailer's 2001 IPO, which netted her $600 million at the time. Mera has invested money in causes dear to her heart: a marine fish farming group, a company that looks for cancer treatments in products from the ocean, and a maker of a fingerprinting system for newborns. She's also a major investor in London's exclusive Bulgari Hotel, and runs a contest for young jazz musicians in Spain. Her Paideia Foundation works to integrate people with physical and mental disabilities, like her son Marcos, into larger society.
title: Investor, Philanthropist

name: Billionaires
bio: Brothers Paolo & Gianfelice Rocca, both Italian citizens, inherited stakes in Italian conglomerate Techint from their late father, Roberto Rocca, who had three children. Their older brother, Agostino, died in a plane crash in 2001. Thanks to their stake in Techint, they control Argentine firms Ternium and Tenaris, the world's leading producers of seamless steel pipes for the oil industry.  Paolo, the youngest brother, is the president of both companies. He studied political science at the University of Milan but lives in Argentina. His brother, Gianfelice, is president of Humanitas, a health care company based in Italy, where he lives.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sulaiman Al Rajhi announced plans in May 2011 to donate the bulk of his fortune to charity, and in a recent interview with a Saudi publication said, "Now I own only my dresses." But he is still listed on the Saudi stock exchange as the owner of nearly 20% of Al Rajhi Bank, worth more than $5 billion. He founded the bank with his brothers Abdullah, Mohammed and the late Saleh, turning it into one of the world's largest Islamic banks. Al Rajhi said he is mostly focused on his SAAR Foundation, which has funded antihunger efforts and education in Saudi Arabia. In 2000 it dissolved its U.S. branch, which had reportedly been linked to the funding of alleged terrorists.

name: Billionaires
bio: David Geffen, who faked a UCLA degree to land one of his first jobs, is adding to his reputation as the school's largest donor. In December 2012 he gave $100 million to UCLA to create the David Geffen Medical Scholarship Fund, which covers the entire cost of a medical education for the school's top-performing students. A decade earlier he gave $200 million to its medical school, which was renamed in his honor. A multimillionaire by age 25, Geffen, a University of Texas dropout, got his start sorting mail at the William Morris talent agency. He founded Asylum Records and Geffen Records, launching the careers of the Eagles, Aerosmith and Guns N' Roses. In 1990 he sold out to MCA for $550 million. Four years later, with Steven Spielberg and Jeffrey Katzenberg, he raised $2 billion in one week to start DreamWorks. He left the studio in 2008. An inductee into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame, in 2012 he reportedly paid a record $54 million for a 12,000-square-foot Manhattan penthouse overlooking Central Park, sold by heiress and songwriter Denise Rich.

name: Billionaires
bio: Jim Kennedy, the grandson of Cox Enterprises founder James M. Cox (d. 1957), is chairman of the privately held company. He served as CEO from 1988 to 2008. Under his leadership, Cox revenues rose from $1.8 billion to nearly $15 billion. Cox Enterprises includes cable company Cox Communications, Cox Media Group (newspapers, TV and radio stations), Manheim (car auctions) and AutoTrader.com. In January the company cancelled plans to take AutoTrader.com public, citing current market conditions. Kennedy inherited a 25% stake in Cox Enterprises after his mother, Barbara Cox Anthony, passed away in 2007. He is interested in wildlife habitat conservation and sits on the board of the PATH Foundation, a Georgia trail-building non-profit.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Liu Yongxing's East Hope Group is one of China's largest privately held industrial materials manufacturers. Liu started out dabbling in electrical product repair and then joined his three brothers (Liu Yongyan, Chen Yuxin and Liu Yonghao) in selling quail and later feed in rural Sichuan Province in the early 1980s, turning their Hope Group in the one of the country's best private-sector success stories at the start of economic reforms under Deng Xiaoping. The four cordially went their separate ways in business in the mid-1990s. East Hope Group is investing more than $1 billion in an aluminum and power complex in Xinjiang, and is putting money into commercial real estate in Sichuan's capital. His brother Liu Yonghao is also a multibillionaire.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Margarita Louis-Dreyfus, who is new to the Forbes Billionaires list, has held her own as chairman of the French commodities giant formerly run by her late husband, Robert. Margarita took over when Robert died of leukemia in 2009. In October 2012 she sold the company's energy trading business. She has also raised capital on the public markets for the first time in the firm's 160-year history, issuing $350 million in bonds on the Singapore market.  A Russian who is known as "the tsarina" by the French press, she reportedly plans to spend $7 billion on acquisitions over the next five years. She appears to be preparing her three children to join the firm. She reportedly put her twins, Kyril and Mauric, in boarding school in Singapore for a year to expose them to new schools of thought. Her eldest son, Eric, had an internship at Glencore, a competing firm. She married Robert in 1992 after meeting him on a plane in 1988. It was the second marriage for both.
title: Chairman of Louis Dreyfus
