name: Billionaires
bio: In February 2013 John Malone's Liberty Global agreed to buy British cable company Virgin Media for $16 billion. A month earlier Liberty Media completed the spin-off of its Starz Entertainment group into a separate company. Also in January Malone won his fight to take control of satellite radio company Sirius XM Radio when the FCC approved the takeover. Malone, who U.S. Vice President Al Gore once called "Darth Vader," has squared off against other formidable opponents including Viacom's Sumner Redstone over the years. In 2010 he unwound his 17-year partnership at InterActiveCorp with Barry Diller. A former partner of TCI Cable founder Bob Magness (d. 1996), he sold what was then the nation's largest cable company to AT&T in 1999 for $54 billion. Today his Liberty Media owns stakes in Sprint Nextel, Live Nation, Barnes & Noble and pro baseball's Atlanta Braves. It also owns a stake in Discovery Communications, which was spun off from Liberty Media in 2005. Malone is also the country's largest individual landowner with nearly 2.2 million acres in Maine, Maryland, New Mexico, Colorado and Wyoming.

name: Billionaires
bio: Eyal Ofer and his younger brother Idan inherited a fortune from their father, shipping magnate Sammy Ofer, who was once Israel's richest man and died in June 2011. Eyal is chairman of Zodiac Maritime Agencies, a privately-held London-based corporation with a diversified fleet of more than 150 shipping vessels. He also controls stakes in Royal Caribbean Cruise Lines and Mizrahi Tefahot bank. Through Global Holdings he owns an impressive array of real estate including the Altria Building and 15 Central Park West in New York. Global Holdings is currently redeveloping the historic St. Vincent's Hospital, in Greenwich Village, 18 Gramercy Park (with architect Robert A. M. Stern), and  50 United Nations Plaza (with architect Norman Foster). He is controlling shareholder of Miller Global, which owns the 1,002-room JW Marriott San Antonio Hill Country Resort and Spa and the Nickelodeon Suites Resort in Orlando. He shares his father's shipping empire and vast art collection, said to be one of the world's most magnificent, with Idan.

name: Billionaires
bio: James Packer severed his family's deep ties to the media sector in 2012 when he sold pay-TV company Consolidated Media Holdings to Newscorp., pocketing $1 billion. That leaves him to focus on his gaming empire Crown Ltd., which owns casinos in Australia and has a joint venture in Macau. Packer inherited a $5 billion business when his father Kerry Packer died in late 2005. The family fortune was built on media assets. James operates a charitable foundation named for his father. He seeded it with $10 million in 2006. He has been a strong supporter of a program to help indigenous Australians move into corporate jobs. In December 2012 he took delivery of a $20 million super-yacht called Seahorse. His second wife, Erica Baxter, is an Australian pop singer and model.

name: Billionaires
bio: Blair Parry-Okeden is the granddaughter of Cox Enterprises founder James M. Cox (d. 1957). Parry-Okeden inherited a 25% stake after her mother, Barbara Cox Anthony, passed away in 2007. Her brother Jim Kennedy is chairman of the nearly $15 billion (sales) company. Cox Enterprises consists of Cox Communications (cable), Cox Media Group (newspapers, TV and radio stations), Manheim (car auctions), and AutoTrader.com. Earlier this year the company shelved plans to take AutoTrader public, citing current market conditions. Not active in the family business, Parry-Okeden lives in near-anonymity in Australia, making her one of that country's richest residents.

name: Billionaires
bio: Norwegian real estate magnate Olav Thon bought his first building in 1951 and opened his first restaurant in 1966. Now his Olav Thon Group is Norway's largest private real estate company, with 450 properties, including 60 hotels. Thon grew up as a farm boy who only went to the city to sell fox pelts. Today he is still an avid outdoorsman and honorary member of the Norwegian Trekking Association.He's proud of his success, and his large tax bill, which he says he is glad to pay. Having no heirs, Thon has announced his intention to give away all his properties and assets to society, particularly to medical science, through the establishment of an independent foundation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Reinhold Wurth made a fortune from fasteners but has turned his attention primarily to art. Wurth, 77, took over his father's tiny screw business at 19. The privately held Wurth Group had $13 billion in 2012 revenues and employs 65,000 people in 84 countries. His net worth rose by $800 million over the past year as values for the tool and fasteners sector increased. The company also has interests in a bank and a solar energy firm. Wurth retired in 1993 and these days he rides a Harley-Davidson and has a professional pilot's license. His daughter Bettina heads the advisory board. He maintains a vast art collection -- an estimated 15,000 pieces -- including works by Edvard Munch, Max Beckmann and Pablo Picasso, which he displays in a two principal museums near Stuttgart and in small museums near Wurth Group offices in across nearly a dozen European countries. In 2012 he acquired the Virgin of Mercy ("Schutzmantelmadonna" in German), a famous painting by Hans Holbein the Younger.

name: Billionaires
bio: Hui Ka Yan's net worth is back where it was a year ago after his Evergrande Real Estate Group successfully rode out a period of tight controls on real estate lending with a double-digit increase in its Hong Kong shares. This year, it has greater ambitions: Contracted sales of $16.4 billion an increase of 25% from 2012. In January Evergrande announced plans to issue a billion new shares to outside investors and Hui will buy another billion shares so that he and his wife's stake will only dip slightly to 63.5%. Hui topped the latest list of China's top philanthropists published by Forbes China with donations of $62 million in 2011. Evergrande is one of the biggest developers to come out of Guangdong province. Hui also owns a soccer team and movie studio.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Most of Sergey Popov's fortune stems from his former partnership with fellow billionaire Andrey  Melnichenko. Together they formed industrial group MDM in the 1990s and began to buy assets, creating TMK, Russia's largest pipe exporter, and Eurochem, the country's biggest mineral fertilizer producer. They also founded SUEK, Russia's largest independent coal producer. In 2006 the partners started splitting their assets, a process they finished in 2012. In 2008 Popov merged his MDM Bank with Russian banking magnate Igor Kim's Siberian Ursa Bank. Popov is a 1993 graduate of the Ural Polytechnic Institute.

name: Billionaires
bio: Carnival Cruises, the company founded by the father of current boss Micky Arison, had a shipwreck of year, at least in terms of public relations. In February 2012 32 passengers were killed when a ship on its Costa line, the Concordia, ran aground in Tuscany. A year later, 4,000 passengers were stranded for days in the Gulf of Mexico with little food and few working bathrooms after an engine fire crippled its ship, Triumph. The stock was immediately slammed but had run up nicely (20%) in the prior 12 months on optimism about renewed consumer spending on vacations. Another positive development on dry land: Arison's NBA team, the Miami Heat, won the 2012 NBA championship, helping boost the franchise's value by 37% to $625 million.
title: Chairman and CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: Andrew Forrest was cleared by Australia's High Court in October 2012 after regulators pursued him for six years, alleging he misled investors. A sharp drop in iron ore prices have hurt his Fortescue Metals, forcing 1,000 layoffs and erasing $500 million from his fortune. The onetime stockbroker and keen amateur boxer started his first mining company, Anaconda Nickel (now called Minara Resources) in 1994. In 2003 he founded Fortescue Metals Group, which brought him much greater success in the simple business of digging up and delivering iron ore to China. Once Australia's richest man, his net worth peaked at $12.7 billion in June 2008 when Fortescue shares hit an all-time high. Known by his schoolboy nickname "Twiggy," Forrest is a descendant of the first premier of the state of West Australia, Lord Forrest of Bunbury. He has been a strong advocate of job creation for Australia's Aboriginal people.

name: Billionaires
bio: Charles Johnson serves as chairman of Franklin Resources, parent of mutual fund purveyor Franklin Templeton, with more than $781 billion in assets under management as of December, 2012. His half-brother, Rupert, Jr. serves as vice chairman. Their father, Rupert Sr., founded a mutual fund shop in 1947, then called Franklin Distributors. Charles took over as chief executive in 1957 and the two brother expanded into Franklin Resources in 1969. Charles' son Gregory is the company's chief executive, while his daughter Jennifer serves as chief operating officer.  A Yale alum, he worked as a waiter at a dining hall as an undergrad. Charles is chairman of the San Francisco Giants baseball team, and recently made a rare public appearance at the team's World Series celebration parade in October. He and his wife own the Hillsborough, Calif. Carolands mansion, which has 98 rooms and was the site for a Mitt Romney presidential fundraiser in May 2012. Johnson and his wife also oversee the Charles and Ann Johnson Foundation, which gives regularly to local schools and causes such as Stanford University and the California Academy of Sciences.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Huiyan Yang, the daughter of the cofounder of real estate developer Country Garden Holdings, is once again China's richest woman with shares of her company up 46% since September. Yang Huiyan's father Yeung Kwok Keung transferred his stake to her before the company's IPO in 2007. Revenue in the first nine months of 2012 was up 22% to $3.7 billion. Profit rose 34% to $617 million. The company in January sold $750 million of 10-year bonds to help fund its vibrant portfolio of some 110 projects underway as of mid-2012, many in its home base of Guangdong province. Country Garden is also adding 17 hotels to the 29 it already owns or operates, mostly under the Phoenix brand, and is buying up land in Malaysia. The previous holder of the title of China's richest woman, Wu Yajun, had her fortune splintered in a divorce last year. Yang has a degree from Ohio State University.

name: Billionaires
bio: The son of legendary wildcatter H.L. Hunt, has been building on his inheritance for nearly 40 years. Hunt Consolidated owns hotels and office parks around Dallas, 400,000 acres of ranches across the West and oil and gas fields worldwide. This year Hunt Oil made a huge discovery in Iraqi Kurdistan. Other bold moves include liquefied natural gas projects in Peru and Yemen. In 2011 he sold a one-third stake in Hunt Oil's Eagle Ford shale fields to Japan's Marubeni for $1.3 billion. Hunt also raised $600 million from banks in 2011 to build a high-voltage power line in Texas. Torch passing is underway: son Hunter Hunt, the second of his five children, is now chief executive of Hunt Consolidated Energy; Ray remains chairman and CEO of parent company Hunt Consolidated.

name: Billionaires
bio: As vice-chairman, Rupert Johnson, Jr. runs investment firm Franklin Resources, parent of the Franklin Templeton mutual fund company, with half-brother Charles (chairman), nephew Gregory (CEO) and niece Jennifer (COO). The publicly traded firm had $781 billion in assets under management as of December 2012. Charles and Rupert Jr.'s father, Rupert Sr., founded mutual fund shop Franklin Distributors in 1947. Charles took over as chief executive in 1957 and Rupert Jr. joined him eight years later. In 1969, the pair expanded into Franklin Resources. Rupert Jr. has served as vice chairman since 1999. His Rupert H. Johnson Foundation is a big giver to his alma mater, Washington and Lee University. He made a $100 million pledge to the university in 2007, of which $85 million has been designated to scholarships. According to the latest available public documents, as of 2010 Johnson's foundation has given about $38 million of the pledged gift to Washington and Lee.
title: Vice Chairman and Director
employment: {'name': 'Franklin Resources', 'uri': 'companies/franklin-resources', 'title': 'Vice Chairman and Director', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman and CEO of Japan's biggest e-retailer, Rakuten, Hiroshi Mikitani continues acquiring companies to grow his global offerings and challenge behemoths eBay and Amazon. He has spent more than $1 billion over the past several years acquiring Buy.com in the U.S., Play.com in the U.K., Canada's tablet-maker Kobo and others. This past May, Mikitani took a $100 million stake in photo-sharing site Pinterest. Rakuten was ranked 7th on Forbes 2012 list of the world's most innovative companies. Mikitani is an avid tennis player with an MBA degree from Harvard. He is the grandson of the Minolta camera company's founder.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of Public Bank, Malaysia's third largest bank by assets, and its chairman for 46 years, Teh Hong Piow saw his fortune rise as shares of the bank touched a record high in December. A banker for over six decades, he started his career as a clerk with Oversea-Chinese Banking Corp. before founding Public in 1965. With 400 branches and 17500 employees, it has expanded into Hong Kong, Vietnam, China and Cambodia. Other interests include a holding in insurance firm LPI Capital.

name: Billionaires
bio: Brothers Alejandro Pedro Bulgheroni and Carlos Alberto Bulgheroni get the bulk of their wealth from their stake in Pan American Energy, Argentina's second largest energy company, with annual revenues of more than $3 billion. Pan American Energy is the result of a merger in 1997 between Bridas Corporation, the company owned by the Bulgheroni family, and Amoco, a U.S. company that merged with British Petroleum in 1998. Alejandro is the vice president of Bridas, founded by his father in 1948. Carlos was responsible for closing the sale of 50% of Bridas to Chinese oil company CNOOC in 2010. He reportedly spends a lot of time in Italy, where his current wife lives.

name: Billionaires
bio: Charles Cadogan, head of one of London's richest and best-known real estate dynasties, passed the reigns onto the next generation in 2012. The 8th Earl Cadogan -- or Charles, to his friends -- stepped down as chair of Cadogan Estates, his family's 300-year-old property portfolio, 38 years after taking over its management. His son Edward, Viscount Chelsea, is now running the business. Edward is overseeing the redevelopment of Sloane Street, a popular shopping destination named after an ancestor, with a new piazza of high-end shops. In 2011 Cadogan Estates got permission to go ahead with the project. The Cadogan clan's 90-acre estate stretches across the capital's most desirable postcodes in the posh neighborhoods of Chelsea and Knightsbridge. Charles began his career at merchant banker Schroder Wagg.

name: Billionaires
bio: In 2011 Hildebrand turned a $100 million investment in the Eagle Ford shale of Texas into a $1.4 billion payday with a sale to Marathon Oil. He has already reinvested in Cook Inlet, Alaska, buying fields from Chevron and Marathon. He's also in big in the Utica shale of Ohio. Hildebrand left a safe career at Exxon and founded Hilcorp Energy in 1989. He started small, just three guys and a telephone, but was able to buy out partner Thomas Hook for $500 million in 2003. He began buying proven fields that were too small for the supermajors, then started using advanced technology to boost efficiency. His Hilcorp did well enough that in 2010 every employee got $50,000 to buy a new car. If they double the size of Hilcorp again by 2015, the bonus will be $100,000 each. Hildebrand is ultra private, but a fixture of the Houston social scene. He donates to Texas Childrens' Hospital, Star of Hope Missions, Boys & Girls Clubs and the Houston Livestock Show & Rodeo.

name: Billionaires
bio: Jim Pattison and his Pattison Group show no signs of slowing. He still goes to work every day and sometimes on weekends, and has expanded his company to employ 43,000 people in more than 465 locations worldwide. The third-largest private company in Canada, with sales of more than $7.5 billion in 2012, the group has operations in the automotive, media, packaging, food, entertainment and financial industries. In February 2012 the company bought CoMag a U.S. magazine distributor that was co-owned by Conde Nast and Hearst. His fortune ballooned by $1.1 billion this year after FORBES learned about the company's massive retail and industrial real estate portfolio largely located in Western Canada.
title: Founder, Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Jim Pattison Group', 'title': 'Founder, Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Juan Roig's $23.1 billion (revenues) Mercadona grocery store chain, the largest in Spain, continues to beat the prevailing economic doldrums, sending Roig's fortune up by $800 million in the past year. President of the supervisory board, Roig holds a 55% stake in the 1,356-store food empire his parents founded. To respond to Spain's financial crisis, Mercadona cut prices in stores by 14%, in part to help Spanish families get through the squeeze. Mercadona's low-price marketing strategy has helped it capture a 22% market share, the largest of any grocer. The company prides itself on the long tenure of its 63,500 employees, who have regular schedules, enjoy company profit-sharing, and are 66% female. Daughters Hortensia, Amparo, Juana and Carolina all sit on the supervisory board with their dad. Roig has recently launched a seed capital fund for entrepreneurs. His charitable foundation sponsors a half marathon event in Valencia. He is a big basketball fan, who reportedly attends Valencia's professional games twice a week.

name: Billionaires
bio: Thomas Schmidheiny's great-grandfather owned a brick factory, his grandfather worked in cement. When Thomas' father Max carved up his estate in 1984, Thomas' brother Stephen, also a billionaire, got construction company Eternit, and Thomas got Holcim, the world's second-largest supplier of cement and concrete. Thomas ran Holcim for 2 decades and stepped down as chairman in 2003. He still holds 20% of the growing company and works with its foundation. He also owns wineries in Napa Valley, Australia, Argentina and Switzerland, and a hotel in Switzerland.

name: Billionaires
bio: Soda pop tycoon Carlos Ardila Lulle returns to the Billionaires list for the first time since 1997, thanks to his growing empire of soft drinks and media. After graduating from college he worked for soda maker Gaseosas Lux developing new flavors including a popular apple-flavored drink. He began buying up shares of competing soda-maker Postobon, until he became the majority shareholder and appointed himself president of the company. In 1973 he bought a local radio station. He acquired various stations across Colombia, building Radio Cadena Nacional. He also created a programming arm that produced telenovelas and news for Colombia's government-owned television channel. In 1998 the government privatized broadcasting, and he started RCN TV, the prominent Colombia television station that produced the hit telenovela "Betty La Fea" (Ugly Betty). In 2012 Ardila Lulle struck a deal with Rupert Murdoch to create a Spanish-language channel for Hispanics in the U.S. to compete with Telemundo and Univision. He also owns Colombia's largest sugar refinery and has interests in bottling and packaging.

name: Billionaires
bio: Pyotr Aven heads Alfa Bank Group, which owns Russia's largest private bank, Alfa Bank, and is part of the Alfa Group conglomerate controlled by fellow billionaires Mikhail Fridman, German Khan and Alexei Kuzmichev. Last year Alfa Group together with AAR partners Viktor Vekselberg and Leonard Blavatnik agreed to sell a 50% stake in TNK-BP to state-owned Rosneft for $28 billion. That deal will bring Aven almost $2 billion in cash. He grew up in Moscow, graduated from Moscow State University, and worked at the Institute for Systems Studies at the Soviet Academy of Sciences. In 1989 he went to work at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs; two years later he was tapped to be minister of foreign economic relations. In 1994 he met Alfa Group's Mikhail Fridman, and he soon became an Alfa Bank shareholder. He owns the largest private collection of Russian art in Russia but keeps his most valuable pieces in the U.K. In November 2012 he bought Wassily Kandinsky's painting "Study for Improvisation 8" for $23 million, a record for thie artist.

name: Billionaires
bio: Johann Graf founded the Novomatic Group of companies, one of the largest manufacturers of electronic betting machines, with businesses in more than 32 countries. The group also owns casinos in Europe and in Chile. It produces high-tech gaming devices and exports to more than 70 countries. In 2011 turnover was $4.3 billion (3.2 billion Euros) and had 18,000 employees. Graf owns 100% of Novomatic AG, the biggest group in the company. His eldest son Thomas heads the technology business on the management board of the company. In June 2012 Graf bought a 9% stake in Austrian private bank Alizee, a struggling bank undergoing a crisis. A car buff, Johann owns some 120 vintage Jaguar models.

name: Billionaires
bio: Real estate mogul Richard LeFrak's family has been investing in property for more than a century. His grandfather, Harry, started investing in 1901. His father, Sam, expanded the company's operations in New York City and New Jersey. Richard joined the firm in the 1970s and became chairman after Sam died in 2003. The company owns the 5,000-unit apartment complex LeFrak City in Queens and more than 16 million square feet of commercial, residential, and retail properties in Newport, N.J. Over the past year, LeFrak has been diversifying outside of the tri-state area, buying stakes in properties in Oregon, Washington and California. The firm also owns a piece of the former Gansevoort hotel in Miami's South Beach. After a $100 million renovation to create what has been dubbed a "lifestyle eco-brand," the hotel is slated to reopen in 2014 under the 1 Hotel & Residences South Beach brand.  The LeFrak Organization has interests in 860 on-shore-producing oil and gas wells through its LeFrak Energy subsidiary.  The firm also has a branch that handles merchant banking and equity and fixed income investing.

name: Billionaires
bio: New Zealand's richest person, Graeme Hart, is showing signs that he is having trouble keeping his packaging empire together. In October 2012 Moody's cut the credit rating on his Reynolds Group, a subsidiary of his larger Rank Group, by one notch, citing concerns with the company's massive debt of more than $18 billion. Reynolds Group has used the debt to finance acquisitions. It bought Graham Packaging in 2011 for $4.5 billion. Other acquisitions include America's Pactiv, makers of Hefty garbage bags, Swiss packager SIG and Alcoa's former packaging unit. Hart drew up the idea for Rank as an MBA. student at the University of Otago in New Zealand. A boating enthusiast, he owns a 190-foot yacht, Ulysses, which is reportedly for sale, and is working on his new prize, a superyacht called Weta.

name: Billionaires
bio: Bidzina Ivanishvili became the prime minister of Georgia in October 2012, after his Georgian Dream coalition won the election. Georgia's richest person by far, he decided to enter politics just a year earlier and within months had sold off all of his business interests in Russia for a net gain of nearly $1.3 billion. Son of a miner and homemaker, he is the youngest of five. In 1984 he left for Moscow where he earned a Ph.D. in labor economics. During Russia's privatization era, he and a partner, Vitaly Malkin, began accumulating mining and metals assets. Together they also set up Rossiysky Kredit Bank and invested in real estate projects. Ivanishvili moved back to Georgia in 2003 and built a 108,000-square-foot compound in the mountains overlooking Tbilisi. Over the years, he sold off his businesses and reinvesting proceeds in gold, Russian and American equities, and art. He has a collection worth $1 billion that includes Dora Maar with Cat by Pablo Picasso, which he bought at Sotheby's in 2006 for $95 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Frank Lowy is founder of one of the world's biggest listed retail property groups, Westfield, which owns 104 shopping malls in Australia, New Zealand, the U.K., the U.S. and Brazil. He enjoyed a $1 billion jump in wealth as his Westfield Stratford City--opened in September 2011 near the London Olympics site--proved a huge success. He also made some canny joint-venture deals. In 2011 he relinquished the company reins after 50 years, but remains chairman. His sons Steven and Peter are joint CEOs. Eldest son David runs the family's investment arm. Czech-born Lowy fled post-war Europe and set up a Sydney delicatessen in 1952, then expanded first into property development in the city's western suburbs and later into malls. A passionate soccer supporter, he is chairman of the Football Federation of Australia. He is also a donor to many causes including the Lowy Institute think tank, the Lowy Medical Research Institute and an aviation museum.

name: Billionaires
bio: Wei Jianjun's fortune more than doubled in the last year thanks to a soaring share price at his Great Wall Motor, one of China's largest non-government owned automakers. Its net profit was up 66% to $934 million in 2012 on a sales increase of 43% to $7.1 billion. Great Wall, founded in 1984, now has 10 plants outside of China and ships its vehicles to more than 100 countries. It has 48,000 employees. Particularly successful in the SUV market, the company last year was also a member of Forbes Asia's Fab 50 list of the region's best large companies. Wei graduated from the Committee College of Hebei Province branch of the Communist Party, specializing in corporate management. He worked in carpet and a water-pump factories before joining Great Wall.

name: Billionaires
bio: Younger Ambani brother was poorer by $2.6 billion, continuing  a three-year decline in his fortune. He's reportedly negotiating to lease his telecom towers with brother Mukesh's Reliance Industries, a deal that is likely to help Reliance Communications, his debt-laden telecom unit. He's partnering China's Dalian Wanda Group in a property venture. He recently sold shares in Reliance Power to bring down holding as per a regulatory requirement. Reliance Capital concluded the sale of a 26% stake in its asset management arm to Japan's Nippon Life for $275 million in August. Group's entertainment arm Reliance MediaWorks bought 30% stake in Digital Domain, a Hollywood special effects firm owned by film maker James Cameron, at a bankruptcy auction in September. His Reliance-DreamWorks Studios' Jv with Steven Spielberg got 2 Academy Awards for their film Lincoln. In January, he co-hosted a party at Mukesh's sky palace in Mumbai for their niece's wedding.

name: Billionaires
bio: Jean-Claude Decaux founded JCDecaux, an outdoor advertising company, in 1964. Its first contract was to install ads on bus shelters in Lyon. Since 2010 it has been the world's largest outdoor advertising company with over 10,300 employees worldwide in more than 55 countries. In 2012 it closed a deal with the city of Sao Paulo: It won a 25-year contract to design, manufacture, install and  maintain the advertising faces on 1,000 digital clocks. Decaux is chairman of the company's supervisory board. In 2000 he handed over the CEO post to his sons Jean-Francois and Jean-Charles who serve as co-CEOs.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cell phone tycoon Denis O'Brien is profiting handsomely from Digicel, his mobile phone network provider, which operates in Central America, the Caribbean, and the Pacific Islands. Despite substantial debt, the company boosted subscribers and revenue in the last fiscal year. Now O'Brien is looking toward Myanmar, as easing sanctions on that former dictatorship open up millions of potential customers. He is also focused on philanthropy, especially in earthquake-ravaged Haiti, where Digicel has built nearly 100 schools and says it plans to build 50 more in the next year. The son of a human rights activist, O'Brien says, "We're not robber barons." He tries to operate his companies on an 80%-business, 20%-philanthropy ethic.

name: Billionaires
bio: Jorn Rausing joins the list in 2013 after his mother, Birgit Rausing, passed on her family fortune to her three children, as confirmed by the family company, Tetra Laval. Jorn sits on Tetra Laval's board with his siblings Kirsten and Finn. Jorn's grandfather founded Tetra Pak, which invented aseptic ­packaging technology that makes it possible to store beverages like milk and orange juice without refrigeration; some criticize the ­innovation for being difficult to recycle. Tetra Pak is now the central subsidiary of Tetra Laval Jorn also owns a stake in Ocado, an internet retail grocer. A plan by pro-Palestinian terrorists to kidnap him was broken up in 1989. The family maintains a low profile.

name: Billionaires
bio: Tang Yiu founded and chairs China's biggest footwear retailer, Belle International, which counts 16,675 outlets. His fortune jumped more than $1 billion as rising sales and profits boosted shares by more than a fifth. Chain sells its Belle and Staccato footwear brands, as well as Nike and Adidas, among many others. Expects early this year to complete $145 million purchase of Big Step Ltd., which operates 600 shoe stores in China.

name: Billionaires
bio: Dennis Washington gravitates to fixer-uppers, whether that it be homes, yachts or businesses. With help from a crew of 224, he toiled for approximately 40 months, ripping apart and rebuilding his latest yacht, the 332-foot Attessa IV. In business too he likes diamonds in the rough.  He bought an abandoned copper mine in Butte and restarted it twice, first with nonunion labor in the 1980s and again after the shutdown from the energy crisis; today the business is worth well over a billion. His Washington Co. also controls Montana Rail Link, which transports freight over 900 miles of track; a tugboat and barge business in Vancouver; a container shipping company; and a heavy equipment distributor in the U.S. and Russia. He spent $60 million on Washington Family Ranch, an Oregon camp he donated to Christian youth organization Young Life in 1998. The child of divorced parents, he went to seven grade schools and suffered a bout of childhood polio. He eventually settled in Montana where he worked for his uncle's construction firm before striking out on his own.

name: Billionaires
bio: Dannine Avara, one of four heirs to the Enterprise Products energy-pipeline empire, is $900 million dollars richer than a year ago thanks to rising Enterprise shares and the partnership's generous payouts. Her father Dan Duncan, formerly the richest man in Houston, died in 2010 at age 77. Dan Duncan lost his mother and brother at age 7 and was raised by his grandmother. He cofounded Enterprise Products in 1968, meeting customers' delivery needs with 2 trucks. Today the company owns more than 50,000 miles of natural gas, oil, and petrochemical pipelines.

name: Billionaires
bio: Amway co-founder Richard DeVos bought the NBA's Orlando Magic back in 1991 for just $85 million. After the 2012 collective bargaining agreement was signed, the franchise value jumped to its highest ever: $470 million. DeVos met fellow Amway founder and lifelong friend Jay Van Andel in high school after DeVos offered to pay him 25 cents a week for a ride to school. After a two-year stretch in the U.S. Air Force, DeVos returned home to open a drive-in diner with Van Andel in what was the duo's first business together. In 1959 the friends founded Amway (short for "American Way") and began selling multi-purpose cleaner to friends, family and door-to-door. DeVos stepped down in 1993 and his son, Doug, took over as president of the company. As of 2011, the company had revenues of $10.9 billion.

name: Billionaires
bio: Scott Duncan is the youngest of the four children who inherited the massive fortune of late energy-pipeline entrepreneur Dan Duncan, founder of Enterprise Products Partners. Thanks to Enterprise's impressive rise on the New York Stock Exchange, Scott and his siblings each find themselves $900 million dollars richer than a year ago thanks to the rising value of Enterprise shares and the partnership's large payout plan. Dan Duncan, formerly the richest man in Houston, died in 2010 at age 77. He grew up poor and formed Enterprise Products with two trucks in 1968, selling door to door. Today Enterprise owns more than 50,000 miles of natural gas, oil, and petrochemical pipelines.

name: Billionaires
bio: Milane Frantz is one of four children who inherited billions from their late father Dan Duncan, founder of pipeline company Enterprise Products Partners. Frantz saw her wealth rise $900 million since last winter thanks to an 8% jump in Enterprise Products shares and the partnership's rich payouts. Her father, formerly the richest man in Houston, died in 2010 at age 77. Dan Duncan grew up poor and formed Enterprise Products with two trucks in 1968, selling door to door. Today Enterprise owns more than 50,000 miles of natural gas, oil, and petrochemical pipelines. Frantz's sister Randa Duncan Williams sits on the board of the company.

name: Billionaires
bio: Terry Gou runs Hon Hai--better known as Foxconn, which manufactures the world's favorite gadgets, including the iPad, iPhone, Kindle, Xbox, PlayStation and the Wii. Gou's factories assemble around 40% of the world's consumer electronic products, but at a cost. There have been extensive allegations of unfair and unsafe labor practices. Gou owns about 13% of the company's shares.
title: CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: Karl-Heinz Kipp made his first fortune in retailing and his second one in real estate. After selling clothes for more than a decade, he opened the first Massa department store in 1965. He sold the chain in 1986, but smartly held on to the underlying real estate, which he rents to retailer Metro. Kipp has divested his real estate in the U.S., notably 950 Third Avenue and several other high-end properties in Manhattan. He owns four Swiss luxury hotels and resorts including the Hotel Eden Roc in Ascona; the Carlton Hotel in St. Moritz and the Tschuggen Grand Hotel in Arosa, where he lives with his wife, Hannelore.

name: Billionaires
bio: Finn Rausing joins the list in 2013 after his mother, Birgit Rausing, passed on her family fortune to her three children, as confirmed by the family company, Tetra Laval. Finn sits on Tetra Laval's board with his siblings Kirsten and Jorn. Finn's grandfather founded Tetra Pak, which invented aseptic ­packaging technology that makes it possible to store beverages like milk and orange juice without refrigeration; some criticize the ­innovation for being difficult to recycle. Tetra Pak is now the central subsidiary of Tetra Laval. An attempted kidnapping of brother Jorn near his home in Sweden was foiled in 1989. The family maintains a low profile.

name: Billionaires
bio: Kirsten Rausing joins the list in 2013 after her mother, Birgit Rausing, passed on her family fortune to her three children, as confirmed by the family company, Tetra Laval. Kirsten sits on Tetra Laval's board with her siblings Finn and Jorn. Their grandfather founded Tetra Pak, (precursor to Tetra Laval) which invented aseptic ­packaging technology that makes it possible to store beverages like milk and orange juice without refrigeration; some criticize the ­innovation for being difficult to recycle. Tetra Pak is now the central subsidiary of Tetra Laval. An attempted kidnapping of brother Jorn near his home in Sweden was foiled in 1989. The family maintains a low profile. Kirsten breeds horses in the U.K.

name: Billionaires
bio: Randa Duncan Williams is the eldest of the four billionaire children of the late energy-pipeline entrepreneur Dan Duncan, founder of Enterprise Products Partners. Formerly the richest man in Houston, he died in 2010 at age 77. Williams' net worth climbed $900 million since our last Billionaires issue thanks to an 8% jump in shares of  Enterprise and its generous cash payouts. Enterprise owns more than 50,000 miles of natural gas, oil, and petrochemical pipelines. Williams, who previously practiced law, is the most publicly involved of her siblings in the family fortune and serves on the board of Enterprise Products Partners, Encore Bancshares and Encore Bank. She's active in a number of Houston charities including the Ballet Foundation, Manned Spaceflight Education Foundation, the Museum of Natural Science and the Girl Scouts.
title: Director

name: Billionaires
bio: Isak Andic opened his first apparel store in Barcelona in 1984. Today his $2.3 billion (sales) retailer Mango banks 82% of sales outside Spain and oversees about 2600 stores (65% of which are franchises) in 109 countries, from the Dutch Antilles to China. The group, known for producing reasonably priced, trendy women's apparel, opened 800 "corner" stores within other retailers in the past few years, including 500 in JC Penneys, but sales have been disappointing. In 2011 profits dropped. Mango introduced changes including a 20% reduction in prices, a return to basic designs and shifting clothing production in-house. Jonathan Andic, Isak's 31-year-old son and heir apparent, who oversees He by Mango, the retailer's line for men, was named deputy president in 2012, just below his father on the org chart. But some things stay the same: specifically, Kate Moss as the face of the brand. Andic also has shares in Banco Sabadell, one of Spain's largest banking groups. The media-shy entrepreneur's family came to Spain from Turkey in the 1960s. He is an enthusiastic sailor and owns a yacht called the Nirvana. Andic was a vocal advocate for bringing billionaire Sheldon Adelson's EuroVegas to Barcelona, but in 2012 Adelson decided to build the project in Madrid.

name: Billionaires
bio: María Asunción Aramburuzabala Larregui, known as Mariasun, became Mexico's beer queen thanks to her inherited stake in the maker of much-quaffed brews like Corona and Negra Modelo. After the unexpected death of her father, Paul Aramburuzabala Ocaranza, in 1995, Mariasun partnered with her mother and sister, Lucrecia, to fight against groups that were trying to gain control of the family's shares in Modelo, the Mexican brewery founded by Mariasun's grandfather in 1925. That is how the trio founded Tresalia ("tres aliadas" or three allies) and started investing in sectors with high growth potential such as technology infrastructure, telecommunications, real estate development and land reserves. Mariasun also makes direct investments in major Mexican companies through private equity and venture capital firms. She was the first woman to sit on the board of directors of the Mexican Stock Exchange (2003-2006). Both Mariasun and her sister Lucrecia benefited from the largest Mexican corporation sale ever, the $20.1 billion sale of Grupo Modelo to Anheuser-Busch InBev, a company controlled by Brazilian billionaires Jorge Paulo Lemann, Marcel Herrmann Telles and Carlos Alberto Sicupira. Mariasun is president of the Councils of Tresalia Capital, KIO Networks and Network Abilia Universalia, and a member of the boards of Grupo Financiero Banamex and Tory Burch. She has been on the Forbes World's 100 Most Powerful Women list.

name: Billionaires
bio: Philip Green sold 25% of Topshop to J. Crew's investor Leonard Green & Partners for $763 million in 2012, valuing his fashion chain at $3 billion and wiping out the bank debt for his retail powerhouse Arcadia. Some wonder if he'll attempt another takeover of UK retailer Marks & Spencer after failing in 2005. Arcadia has bucked the economic gloom in Britain with additional help from its department store BHS and fashion chain Dorothy Perkins, which introduced the Kardashian Kollection to Brits in August. Green is a high school drop-out who bought his first store in London at age 27 and sold discounted designer brands. He bought retail group Arcadia in 2002 for $1.2 billion; sales now top $4.2 billion. Rigorous cost-cutter warned Conservative British government of "staggering waste" in 2010, but keeps his own money offshore through investment vehicle Taveta Investments, shared with wife Cristina. Lavish party-giver lives in Monaco, counting Simon Cowell and Kate Moss as friends.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sports and real estate mogul Stanley Kroenke added to his expansive property portfolio with the purchase of the Broken O Ranch, a 124,000 acre Montana farm, in November 2012. Kroenke is the owner of the NBA's Denver Nuggets, the NHL's Colorado Avalanche, the NFL's St. Louis Rams, and the Premier League soccer club Arsenal. He made his first fortune developing commercial and retail properties. He now owns Canada's largest cattle ranch and two wineries. The Kroenke Group has several hundred storage facilities, apartment buildings, and shopping centers -- many anchored by Wal-Mart, cofounded by his wife Ann's father, Bud Walton. Ann is a billionaire in her own right thanks to her Wal-Mart holdings.

name: Billionaires
bio: Brothers Hank and Doug Meijer are co-chairmen of the Michigan-based Meijer grocery chain. Hank is also CEO. Founded in 1934, the company pioneered the superstore in 1962 when its combined grocery and department stores started operating under the Thrifty Acres banner. The bulk of Meijer's revenues, estimated at nearly $15 billion in 2012, comes from its big-box stores across five states. Lately the company has been investing in smaller, more upscale grocery stores under the name Meijer Marketplace. The brothers took over from their father Frederik in 1990, though he remained active in the business until his death in November 2011. A third Meijer son, Mark, owns an ambulance company. Frederik Meijer's widow, Lena, is still living. The family's Meijer Foundation supports local institutions such as the Fred and Lena Meijer Heart Center and the Frederick Meijer Gardens and Sculpture Park.

name: Billionaires
bio: The recovery in Japan's real estate sector has boosted the fortune of real estate magnate Akira Mori. The chief of Mori Trust, the $1 billion (operating revenue), which operates 67 rental buildings and 29 hotels, plans to use his growing coffers to start aquiring properties abroad, targeting New York and London. Akira, with his late brother Minoru, who died last March, inherited his initial fortune from his father. The brothers parted ways in 1999, with Akira focusing on office buildings, apartment blocks and hotels in high-rent districts of Tokyo. Akira is now expanding beyond buildings, investing in China via his newly created MA Platform Group, which recently invested in closely held Tsingda eEdu Corp., which offers English lessons over the Internet in China.

name: Billionaires
bio: Brothers Augusto and Giorgio Perfetti together own Italian candy and gum manufacturer Perfetti Van Melle. Founded by their father Ambrogio and Uncle Egidio Perfetti in 1946 in a small town near Milan, the company was the first to introduce chewing gum to Italians. Their Brooklyn brand is still one of the most popular in Italy. (The gum was named after American soldiers who chewed gum in Italy during World War II.) In 2001 Perfetti paid more than $900 million for Van Melle, the Dutch owner of Mentos, Fruittella and Airheads. In 2006 the company acquired Spanish company Chupa Chupas, best known for its lollipops. The press-shy brothers, who live in Switzerland, are no longer involved in business operations.

name: Billionaires
bio: Interactive Brokers founder Thomas Peterffy made a splash in October 2012 when he ran a self-funded political advertisement on several major television networks. Issuing a stern warning of the dangers of socialism, Peterffy encouraged viewers to vote Republican. His firm was in talks to acquire the majority of MF Global's operating assets in October 2011, but Interactive's due diligence uncovered information that immediately killed the deal: hundreds of millions of missing MF customer dollars.  Born in Budapest in 1944 during a Russian bombing raid, Peterffy immigrated to the United States in 1965. When he arrived in New York he spoke no English. In 1977 Peterffy left his job designing commodities trading software and purchased his own seat on the American Stock Exchange where he began trading options. In 1993 he launched the electronic brokerage firm Interactive Brokers. An avid equestrian, Peterffy keeps horses at his Greenwich estate. His favored charitable organization is Teach for America.

name: Billionaires
bio: Tobacco king Lucio Tan consolidated many of his private holdings, including Asia Brewery, which makes popular Beer na Beer, and his stake in Philip Morris-Fortune Tobacco, which has an estimated 80% market share of the country's cigarette market into publicly listed LT Group in which he owns close to 90%. Fortune includes Hong Kong based Eton Properties, stake in Philippines Airlines. Tan got his start as a chemical engineer and mopped floors to pay for school. He enjoys flying helicopters.

name: Billionaires
bio: Wee Cho Yaw, chairman of United Overseas Bank, Singapore's most valuable bank, will be stepping down in April after close to 40 years at the helm though he will remain on the board. It was founded by his father and run by him for 33 years until 2007, when son Wee Ee Cheong became chief executive. Family's property developer and private equity company Kheng Leong, opened an office in Shanghai last year; Topiary, a condo project they co-developed in Singapore, sold out its 255 units in four hours in December. Singapore listed Haw Par, which family owns nearly one quarter of, makes iconic Chinese ointment Tiger Balm.

name: Billionaires
bio: Kunio Busujima is the founder and honorary chairman of pachinko gaming-machine maker Sankyo, now run by his son Hideyuki. The company's sales during the first half of its fiscal year shrank by nearly 25%, reflecting a declining customer base.

name: Billionaires
bio: Roberto Civita, who inherited a media group started by his father and turned it into one of Brazil's largest magazine publishers, died on May 27, 2013 due to complications from an aneurysm, according to his media company, Grupo Abril. Civita's father Victor founded Abril in 1950; Roberto took over when his father died in 1990. The group employs some 7,000 people. Its Editora Abril arm publishes some of Brazil's most read magazines, including the newsweekly Veja, which Roberto Civita founded in 1968. His family also owns a majority of publicly traded education firm Abrill Educacao. Civita was born in Italy, moved with his family to the U.S. and then to Brazil. He got a bachelor's degree from the University of Pennsylvania and a masters degree in sociology from Columbia University. Civita is survived by his second wife, Maria Antonia; three children from his first marriage, Giancarlo (who will take his place as the head of Abril), Roberta and Victor; and six grandchildren.
title: President of the Management Board and Editorial Director
employment: {'name': 'Abril Group', 'title': 'President of the Management Board and Editorial Director', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Port operator Enrique Razon who controls Manila-listed International Container Terminal Services saw his wealth climb by $3 billion, following last May's listing of Bloomberry Resorts, his new hotel and casino venture in which he retains a 71% stake. His Solaire Resort & Casino, one of four new casinos in the Manila Bay complex. In December, he sold nearly 9% stake in Bloomberry to Global Gaming, the casino manager at much below market value as per a pre-arranged deal. Avid golfer, he backs the Philippines Golf Tour.

name: Billionaires
bio: Robert Rowling took over TRT Holdings from father Reese (d. 2001), an oil and gas wildcatter. He owns the Omni hotel chain, which he's built up to 15,000 rooms in nearly 50 locations including the  Amelia Island resort in Florida. He's investing $75 million rehabbing the hotel on Amelia and another $250 million on a new hotel in Nashville. Rowling is also rebuilding oil company Tana Exploration with the $220 million acquisition last year of offshore explorer Meritech. He also owns the Golds Gym chain. Big donor to Karl Rove's American Crossroads superPAC.

name: Billionaires
bio: David Duffield's net worth more than doubled year over year as of March thanks to the October IPO of Workday, his enterprise software firm. Duffield didn't wait to enjoy the fruits of his labor, purchasing a new estate in Lake Tahoe in December for a reported $25.5 million. Through an investment company, the Workday cofounder also bought a new office complex in Pleasanton, Calif. in February as the company ramps up expansion plans. Duffield started his first big success, PeopleSoft, at age 47, mortgaging his house to fund what was his fourth startup. PeopleSoft eventually became one of the largest application software companies and, after a bitter battle with nemesis Larry Ellison, was acquired by Oracle for $10 billion in 2005. After a momentary retirement, Duffield was at it again, founding Workday in March 2005. Through his Duffield Family Foundation, he has given more than $290 million to Maddie's Fund, an animal welfare foundation named after his beloved schnauzer. Duffield says he plans to leave his fortune to his animal charity, not his 10 children. He is also the namesake of Cornell's Duffield Hall, a leading nanotechnology center completed in 2004 that was endowed by a donation of more than $40 million.
title: Chairman and co-CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: Dr. Thomas Frist's net worth grew $1.6 billion in the past year, thanks in part to a total of $4.50-per-share dividends his HCA Holdings paid out in late 2012 to avoid new tax rules. Shares of the for-profit hospital conglomerate Frist founded are up 69.7% year-over-year on 2012 revenues of $33 billion. He is the biggest shareholder. The former Air Force flight surgeon started HCA with his father in 1968; it went public a year later. He led a management buyout of the firm in 1989, only to take the company public again three years later. In 2006 he took the company private again in a $33 billion buyout with help from KKR, Bain and Bank of America. The company restructured the board to include Frist's two sons. When HCA issued $2.2 billion in cash dividends during 2010 and 2011, he and family members pocketed $800 million. HCA went public for the third time in 2011. The Frist family, operating apart from HCA as a new company called CHC, is building a hospital with the Chinese government in Cixi, 100 miles south of Shanghai, slated to open in August 2013. In August 2012 HCA disclosed that the Justice Department was investigating whether some 10 HCA hospitals in Florida and other states conducted unnecessary heart procedures; Frist and HCA said HCA had already taken appropriate steps to address the issues, and nothing came of the probe. Frist was honored in 2012 for founding the Alexis de Tocqueville Society, which has donated $7 billion to the United Way.

name: Billionaires
bio: Hui Wing Mau is the chairman of Hong Kong-listed Shimao Property Holdings, one of China's largest real estate developers with more than 70 projects currently under way, according to the company's latest financial report. They include colorful spots such as "Ningbo Shimao Sea Dawn" and "Kunshan Shimao Butterfly Bay." Sales rose by 12.4% to $485 million in the first half of 2012.  Hui's wealth has increased on a big rise in Shimao Property's stock price, which in turn has been fueled by expectations of a pick-up in property prices and sales in China this year. A mainland native who resides in Hong Kong, Hui is a vice chairman of the China National Federation of Industry and Commerce, vice president of China Overseas Chinese Entrepreneurs Association, and chairman of Shanghai Overseas Chinese Chamber of Commerce. He holds a MBA from the University of South Australia and is chairman of Shanghai Shimao, a 64% owned real estate subsidiary of Shimao Property. Son Jason is vice chairman and heir apparent to leadership of the family's main business. Daughter Carol is president of smaller Shanghai Shimao.

name: Billionaires
bio: Quek Leng Chan heads Hong Leong Group Malaysia and gets biggest part of fortune from its stake in Hong Kong listed investment company, Guoco Group, which he's trying to take private in a $1.1 billion deal. His attempt to take investment banking arm Hong Leong capital privately wasn't successful as shareholders chose to hold out for a better price. Gaming group Rank, listed on the LSE but controlled by Quek through Guoco, is planning to merge with former rival Gala to become UK's biggest gaming company. His other interests include financial services, property development and hotels across Southeast Asia. Shares control of massive Hong Leong Group with Singaporean cousin, Kwek Leng Beng, and Kwek's family.  Inherited fortune from his father, one of 3 brothers who started a small banking group in the 1920s.

name: Billionaires
bio: Karl Wlaschek founded Austrian retail chain Billa and sold it in 1996 for roughly $1 billion. Since then, he's been investing in real estate and is one of the largest private real estate owners in Austria, via his KWPS Immobilien GmbH, with about 250 properties, including 10 hotels and 8 palaces and historic buildings in the center of Vienna. He is known as a canny investor. Wlaschek, still fit at age 95, married for the fifth time in April 2012, to a woman age 65.  After World War I, Wlaschek was a pianist and lead singer of the band "Charly Walker."

name: Billionaires
bio: Reclusive Nigerian billionaire Mike Adenuga built a fortune in mobile telecom and oil production. He founded Globacom, Nigeria's second largest mobile phone network, in 2006. It has 24 million customers in Nigeria, operates in the Republic of Benin and recently acquired licenses to start businesses in Ghana and the Ivory Coast. His Conoil Producing is one of Nigeria's largest independent exploration companies, with a production capacity of 100,000 barrels of oil per day. Adenuga made his first fortune at age 26 in the 1970s by distributing lace and other materials, but he hit it big during the military regime of former President Ibrahim Babangida. Adenuga is widely believed to be a proxy investor for former President Babangida.

name: Billionaires
bio: Michael Herz, his brother Wolfgang and his mother Ingeburg (all billionaires), own German coffee retailer Tchibo GmbH and 50% of listed skin care company Beiersdorf AG, which sells the Nivea brand. Herz helped push out his brother Gunter and his sister Daniela from the company in 2003 in a drawn-out family feud. His brother Joachim died in a motorboat accident in 2008.

name: Billionaires
bio: Wolfgang Herz, his brother Michael and his mother Ingeburg (all billionaires) own Tchibo GmbH, makers of Germany's best-known coffee brand, and 50% of the outstanding shares of skincare company Beiersdorf AG, which makes the Nivea brand. Herz helped push out his brother Gunter and his sister Daniela from the company in 2003 in a drawn-out family feud. His brother Joachim died in 2008 in a motorboat accident.

name: Billionaires
bio: Patrick McGovern is the founder and chairman of International Data Group, a publishing, events, media and research company. He studied neurobiology at MIT while working for Computers & Automation, the first computer magazine in the U.S. He founded IDG in 1964 with $5,000 he made from selling his car and launched Computerworld magazine three years later. Today the company publishes 200 magazines (PC World, CIO), 460 websites (CFOworld.com) and produced 700 events worldwide (Macworld/iWorld). McGovern owns an 84% stake in the $3.4 billion (revenue) company. He donated $350 million to fund the McGovern Institute for Brain Research at MIT in 2000.
title: Founder and Chairman
employment: {'name': 'International Data Group', 'title': 'Founder and Chairman', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: In February, Sumner Redstone, the executive chairman of Viacom and CBS, was accompanied by George Lucas and Steven Spielberg as he attended the opening of the Sumner M. Redstone Production Building at USC's School of Cinematic Arts. He is currently writing an autobiography, "How to Live Forever." He has recently hinted that his daughter Shari may succeed him as the overseer of his stakes in Viacom and CBS, thwarting the conventional wisdom that CEO Phillipe Dauman, who took home $84.5 million in compensation in 2010, would be his successor. In September 2012 he announced an $18 million donation to the law school at Boston University, where was on the faculty in the 1980s, teaching entertainment law. In the past year he has made donations to the Global Poverty Project and a Los Angeles-based initiative that aims to eliminate bullying from schools. The World War II vet and Harvard Law grad took over his family's Northeast Theater Corp. (later named National Amusements), acquired control of Viacom in 1987 and spun off CBS in 2006.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Alexander Abramov is partner with billionaire Roman Abramovich in the steel company Evraz, and it is rumored that in 2013 the two will buy a 5.8% stake in Norilsk Nickel. Abramov has about $3 billion in cash to invest, by Forbes' estimate, including money from the sale of the energy infrastructure firm Energostroyinvest in December 2012. Abramov got his start as the head of a research lab before the collapse of the Soviet Union. In 1992, he established a precursor to Evraz Holding, and he made a fortune exporting metals and coal from the Urals and Siberia. After the 1998 Russian financial crisis, he bought up hobbled steel companies and coal mines on the cheap, including two U.S. firms, Claymont Steel and Oregon Steel. He was elected chairman of Evraz in December 2008, replacing fellow billionaire Alexander Frolov, with whom he co-founded it.

name: Billionaires
bio: Britain's headline-grabbing billionaire Richard Branson is $400 million richer this year, thanks mostly to the sale of his Virgin Media to fellow billionaire John Malone's Liberty Global. In 2012 Delta Airlines bought a 49% stake in Branson's Virgin Atlantic airline, expanding both companies' flight networks. After years of planning, his Virgin Galactic commercial space program is expected to make its inaugural flight this year. In true Branson style, when he opened his (and the world's) first commercial spaceport in New Mexico in 2011, he rappelled down the side of the huge glass building while popping champagne. That same year, his Virgin Money teamed with U.S. billionaire investor Wilbur Ross in a deal worth $1.2 billion to bail out the U.K.'s nationalized Northern Rock, which collapsed in 2007 after a run on the bank.

name: Billionaires
bio: Media-shy Walter Faria is new to the Forbes Billionaires list. He bought Grupo Petropolis in 1998 and transformed it into one of Brazil's largest brewery and beverage companies. He learned the ins and outs of the industry working as a distributor for Schincariol, a Brazilian brewery and beverage company that Japan's Kirin Holdings bought from the billionaire Schincariol family. Petropolis' Itaipava beer is fighting to be the country's second biggest seller after No. 1 seller, Skol, made by Anheuser-Busch InBev. Faria wants Petropolis to expand internationally. It is sponsoring the Scuderia Ferrari Formula One Team through its TNT brand of energy drinks, which will soon be sold in Germany.  A self-made mogul, Faria came from rough beginnings. One of his brothers was assassinated and another was sent to jail, accused of drug dealing.
title: Entrepreneur

name: Billionaires
bio: Among Singapore's wealthiest clans and biggest landlords, the four Kwee brothers debut on list on the rising value of their jointly owned privately-held property developer and hotel operator Pontiac Land. Its collection of prime properties includes  the Ritz-Carlton, the Regent, Conrad Centennial and the Capella in Singapore. Recent projects include Capitol Center, a $600 million luxury property development in which they have a 50% stake. Kwee Liong Keng, the eldest, is managing director; Kwee Liong Tek, an avid art collector, is chairman. Brothers Kwee Liong Seen and Kwee Liong Phing sit on board. The business was founded in 1959 by their father, Henry Kwee as a small company developing architecturally distinctive homes.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founders of fast fashion retailer Forever 21, Do Won (Don) Chang and his wife Jin Sook immigrated to America from Korea in 1981. Chang initially held three jobs at once, doing janitorial work, pumping gas and working in a coffee shop. He and his wife opened their first clothing store in 1984. Today Forever 21 operates more than 480 stores including its first store in France, which opened in January 2012. Annual sales are estimated at over $3 billion. The firm has been criticized for copying designer clothes and sued more than 50 times by other retailers such as Anthropologie for copyright infringement. Born-again Christians, the two reportedly attend church at 5:20 a.m. on weekdays, keep bibles in the office, and print John 3:16 on the bottom of each bag. Running the company is a family affair. Don is chief executive, Jin Sook is the head buyer, daughter Linda runs marketing, and daughter Esther heads the visual display team.

name: Billionaires
bio: Paul Desmarais, Sr. died on October 8, 2013. He was 86. One of Canada's richest people, he built up Power Corp. from his family's one-route Ontario bus line over the last half century. Montreal-based Power Corp. and its subsidiaries own financial services firms including mutual fund company Putnam Investments, insurance firm Great-Life Westco and a stake in Chinese conglomerate CITIC Pacific. Together with Belgian billionaire investor Albert Frere, Power Corp. also maintains investments in some of Europe's biggest companies, including cement giant Lafarge, oil company Total and wine and spirits maker Pernod Ricard. Desmarais' sons, Andre and Paul, Jr., serve as co-CEOs.

name: Billionaires
bio: Hobby Lobby founder David Green has taken the Obama Administration to court over new regulations that force companies to pay for employee health insurance that covers emergency contraceptives. A preacher's son from a poor background, Green started his business with a $600 loan in 1970 and has turned it into one of the biggest Christian companies in the U.S. The arts and crafts chain now has 520 locations across the country, all of which are closed on Sunday. Green is a big contributor to evangelical education, with a $10.5 million gift to Jerry Falwell's Liberty University in 2004 and $70 million to bail out Oral Roberts University in 2007. He has also put nearly 1.4 billion copies of gospel literature in homes in more than 100 countries, mostly in Africa and Asia. He joined the Giving Pledge in 2010.
title: CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: Brothers James and Arthur Irving head the family's diversified New Brunswick business conglomerate. Dominating the local economy, Irving Group of Companies interests include oil, natural gas, gas stations, timber, paper products, shipbuilding, construction, agriculture, building supplies, newspapers, radio stations and a Canadian Hockey League team. In October 2011 Irving Shipbuilding's Halifax Yard won a monstrous federal contract to build $25 billion worth of frigates, destroyers and patrol ships for the Canadian military. The Irving empire was founded in 1881 by the brothers' grandfather, J.D. Irving. James and Arthur's brother and business partner, John, died at age 78 in 2010. His heirs' share of the Irving fortune is not attributed to James and Arthur.

name: Billionaires
bio: Henry Kravis is suing St. Louis entrepreneur Donald Bryant over three paintings that depict a human skull and male genitalia. The pair teamed up in 2008 to purchase the Jasper Johns triptych, "Tantric," and they have traded it off between their homes every year since, until Bryant allegedly refused to transfer it to Kravis in January 2013. Meanwhile, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, the private equity firm that Kravis founded in 1976 with his cousin George Roberts and his Bear Stearns mentor Jerome Kohlberg, is expanding into asset management and retail servicing. In 1989 KKR orchestrated the $25 billion buyout of RJR Nabisco that became the basis of the bestselling book "Barbarians at the Gate." In July 2010 KKR went public. Kravis is a big enough patron of the Metropolitan Museum of Art to have had a wing named after him. His economist wife, Marie-Josée, is president of the Museum of Modern Art's board. A new building at Columbia's business school will be named after Kravis, thanks to a $100 million pledge he made  in 2010. It is scheduled to open around 2014.
title: Co-Chair and Co-CEO
employment: {'name': 'KKR and Co ', 'title': 'Co-Chair and Co-CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Wal-Mart heiress Ann Walton Kroenke, the daughter of James "Bud" Walton and niece of the massive retailer's founder Sam, is one half of a billionaire power-couple. Her husband Stan, who made his own fortune building shopping centers in the U.S. (many anchored by Wal-Mart), is the owner of the NBA's Denver Nuggets, the NHL's Colorado Avalanche, the NFL's St. Louis Rams, and Premier League soccer club Arsenal. They met while skiing in Colorado in 1971. With her father's death in 1995, Ann and her sister Nancy inherited a large chunk of Wal-Mart shares. She received more than $70 million in dividends in 2012.

name: Billionaires
bio: Palm oil producer and property developer, Lee Shin Cheng saw his wealth decline as shares of his listed IOI Group fell after it reported a 28% drop in first quarter earnings, due to weaker palm oil prices. He stepped up investment in China real estate buying land in Xiamen for $190 million last year. He recently bought out his Taiwanese partner in an ongoing 7.7acre residential and commercial project in the same area. Lee grew up on a rubber plantation where his father ran a Chinese food shop

name: Billionaires
bio: Trevor Rees-Jones first worked as a bankruptcy lawyer, and then switched to oil and gas exploration. His Chief Oil & Gas Co. has shown impeccable timing. Rees-Jones was an early investor and early seller (2008) in the Barnett shale gas play in Texas, netting more than $1.5 billion. He plowed cash into the Marcellus shale gas play and made another $2 billion selling acreage there to the likes of Chevron and Enerplus, and another $1 billion dealing his Marcellus pipeline network to Penn-Virginia this year. He reinvested big in the Mississippian Lime play in Kansas, with additional holdings from sea to shining sea. He's been a generous donor to Dallas charities: he's given $25 million each to the Perot Museum of Nature & Science, the Boy Scouts and the Parkland Foundation, which provides medical care to the poor. Big backer of Karl Rove's American Crossroads SuperPAC. Hired the Eagles to play his 60th birthday party in 2011.

name: Billionaires
bio: Harry Triguboff was one of the first Australian developers to see the potential of apartment living at a time when most of his countrymen aspired to a suburban block. In 50 years he has put up more than 55,000 apartments, earning him the nickname "High Rise Harry." His company, Meriton, has made the best of a sales downturn by ramping up serviced-apartment offerings in Sydney and in Australia's Gold Coast and buying inexpensive development sites. Born in China to Russian parents, he moved to Australia as a teenager. He began his working life in the textile business, making his move into property in the 1960s. These days Chinese are among the most enthusiastic buyers of his developments in Sydney and Brisbane. In 2011 he won the Gold Harold Humanitarian Award for supporting work to educate youth about drugs and well-being. He established a center in Israel that focuses on immigrants and Judaism.

name: Billionaires
bio: Leslie Wexner's lingerie giant Victoria's Secret has started its long-awaited international expansion in earnest. Its first two London stores and a Montreal shop  opened in the summer of 2012. The company is also set to launch the third UK store in Yorkshire in March 2013. The other mall staple of Wexner's Limited Group, lotion emporium Bath & Body Works, is looking to the Middle East for growth: six stores opened in Saudi Arabia, Bahrain, Jordan and the Emirates in the fall of 2011. Wexner himself keeps a low profile, although he made clear his support of Mitt Romney for president by hosting a fundraiser for the GOP candidate in Ohio in June. He stepped down from the board of his beloved Ohio State University the same month, but continues to support the school generously. In 2011, he pledged $100 million to OSU, much of which will go to the school's Wexner Medical Center -- itself named after a 1989 gift of $75 million from the retail billionaire. An OSU science grad (and law school dropout), Wexner founded The Limited with a $5,000 loan from his aunt in 1963, and took it public six years later. He sold off his majority stake in The Limited clothing chain in 2007 and sold off the remaining stake in 2010. He's a passionate contemporary art collector, with numerous pieces by Picasso, Matisse, Degas and DeKooning in his collection. He also owns a 315-foot yacht called Limitless.
title: Chairman and CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: Despite a difficult business climate in his native Venezuela, Gustavo Cisneros remains one of South America's most successful businessmen, overseeing a diversified empire with interests in Venezuelan television stations, telecom, a regional brewery and a baseball team. With U.S. billionaire Jerry Perenchio and Mexican billionaire Emilio Azcarraga Jean, Cisneros sold U.S. Spanish-language TV network Univision to a private equity consortium led by U.S. billionaire Haim Saban for $13.7 billion in 2007. Although Venevision has tangled in the past with President Hugo Chavez, the company now avoids politics, focusing instead on entertainment content, including hugely popular Latin American soap operas. Venevision reportedly has a 67% audience share in Venezuela and reaches 500 million people around the world. Cisneros also owns the Miss Venezuela contest, interests in Colombia's Caracol TV and in DirecTV, and has reportedly been looking to purchase a television channel in Brazil. In October 2011, Carlos Slim's America Movil bought Cisneros' digital content business, DLA Inc., for $50 million; Cisneros has since been adding digital advertising businesses to his portfolio. He and wife Patricia are familiar figures in high society, hobnobbing with former presidents like George H. W. Bush, designers and fellow billionaires. The couple boasts an extensive collection of Latin American art; Madrid's Reina Sofia Museum is displaying some of the collection in 2013. Cisneros' daughter, Adriana, directs company strategy and is overseeing the development of Tropicalia, a luxury eco-resort in the Dominican Republic, from her home in New York. The family foundation promotes education and protection of indigenous people in the Amazon basin.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heinz-Horst Deichmann and his children own Deichmann-Schuhe SE, Europe's largest shoe retailer and owner of Rack Room Shoes and the Off Broadway chain in the U.S. Sales increased 5% in 2011 to nearly $5.5 billion (4.1 billion Euros) Heinz-Horst Diechmann gave up his orthopedic practice in 1956 to take over the family's shoe business, now in its 100th year. Heinz-Horst's son Heinrich runs the daily operations. A committed philanthropist Heinz-Horst regularly donates milions of dollars to missionary and humanitarian organizations, including a program to help leprosy victims in India, which he visits annually. He holds the Martin-Luther Foundation's "Luther Rose" award for his social and charitable work.

name: Billionaires
bio: Francisco Ivens de Sa Dias Branco is the Chairman of the Board of Directors and CEO of M. Dias Branco S.A., Brazil's  leading company in the cracker, cookie and pasta market. Since 1953 Francisco has been the controlling shareholder of the company, which was founded as a bakery by his father Manuel in the 1940s. Reaping the benefits of Brazil's booming middle class, the company's stock rose in the past year, boosting Francisco's fortune by $600 million. He also owns more than $1 billion worth of real estate in the northeastern Brazilian state of Ceara, where he lives.

personName: Francisco Ivens de Sa Dias Branco
title: Entrepreneur

name: Billionaires
bio: Lately Sir James Dyson has been on a mission to convince the world that engineering is cool and sexy, and that studying it can ensure high pay and job security. In January 2013 he took U.K. government ministers to task for what he saw as their wrong engineering focus:  "I am concerned that we are sometimes distracted by the glamor of web fads and video gaming rather than the development of tangible technology that we can export. There seems to be an obsession with Shoreditch's so-called 'Silicon roundabout'" (England's Silicon Valley). An engineer inventor himself, Dyson ran through 5,127 prototypes before he perfected his G-Force upright vacuum cleaner, which spins air to use the power of centrifugal force. He introduced it in England in 1993, and the bagless machine was an immediate hit. He debuted his latest invention, a futuristic bladeless fan called the "Air Multiplier," in 2010, and has since been battling to take down Chinese ripoffs of it. The company is hush-hush about new products to come, but digital motors are in the mix. Also, Dyson has invested in Ingenious Media, the investment company behind "Avatar" and "Live Free or Die Hard."

name: Billionaires
bio: Sports mogul Malcolm Glazer's soccer club Manchester United became the first sports team to be valued at more than $3 billion in January 2013. Glazer took the team public the previous August, retaining 98% of voting shares and netting $100 million in cash. The stock surged more than 33% in the following 6 months. Glazer's other sports franchise is the NFL's Tampa Bay Buccaneers, who finished 7-9 in 2012. He inherited his father's watch business at age 15 and later formed real estate company First Allied, which today owns more than 6.7 million square feet of retail space in the United States. His Glazer Children's Museum opened in Tampa in September 2010 after he donated $5 million. His six children manage the family's assets.

name: Billionaires
bio: Erivan Haub and his family own the Tengelmann Group, one of Germany's largest food retailers. The group, established as a family business more than 140 years ago, is run by Erivan's sons: Karl-Erivan Haub is CEO and managing partner and Christian W. E. Haub is co-CEO of Tengelmann as well as chairman of Greenwich, Connecticut-based investment firm Emil Capital Partners. Revenues and earnings at Tengelmann Group each fell about 5% in 2011but the value of the group rose as listed competitors fared better. The Haubs owned 41% of U.S. grocery chain A&P, which filed for bankruptcy in 2010, but have exited that investment. A big fan of the U.S., Haub owns land in Washington state, a buffalo ranch in Wyoming and a ski resort in the Cascades called Sun Mountain Lodge. He is a small celebrity in Tacoma, Washington thanks to his contribution to the town's revitalization.

name: Billionaires
bio: Pansy Ho, Hong Kong's richest woman, won government approval in October 2012 for her joint venture with MGM Resorts International, MGM China, to build a $2.5 billion casino resort on Macau's Cotai Strip. The daughter of Stanley Ho, she is also managing director of Shun Tak Holdings, the property and transportation company controlled by the 91-year-old casino tycoon's extended family. Pansy is the eldest of five children from Ho's second wife. Her brother Lawrence Ho is co-chairman of Melco Crown Entertainment, a joint venture with Australian billionaire James Packer

name: Billionaires
bio: Among India's most respected bankers, Uday Kotak founded and runs Kotak Mahindra Bank. It has featured among Forbes Asia's Fab 50 list of companies 3 years in a row. Japan's Sumitomo Mitsui Bank which is a minority investor in the bank has partnered Kotak's investment banking arm for M&A deals between India and Japan. It also has ties with Scotiabank to offer financial services to immigrants in Canada. India's central bank has asked him to reduce his 45% stake in the bank to 20% by 2018. His annual Diwali party, hosted at Mumbai's iconic Taj Mahal Palace & Towers Hotel, draws over 500 guests.

name: Billionaires
bio: For real estate developer Stephen Ross, 2012 was a big year: He stepped aside as chief executive of his Related Companies (he'll keep role of chairman) and the company broke ground on New York City's Hudson Yards in December, a $15 billion mega-project to create a new neighborhood on the West side of Manhattan that will include Coach's headquarters and Danny Meyer restaurants. Meanwhile other projects are planned or underway in New York, Chicago, Los Angeles, Santa Monica, Calif., Florida, Brazil, Saudi Arabia and Abu Dhabi's Sowwah Island, with Gulf Capital. In Hunter's Point South in the Bronx, Ross is developing the largest affordable housing complex in New York since the 1970s, which will break ground this year. In 2009 Ross completed a $1 billion purchase of pro football's Miami Dolphins; he owns 95% of the team. Last year he started RSE Ventures, investing in eight sports industry companies like Relevant Sports, FanVision and LeapSeats. Now planning a possible $400 million renovation of the team's home, Sun Trust Stadium, alongside city of Miami. After Ross gave $100 million to the business school at alma mater University of Michigan in 2004, the school was renamed after him.

name: Billionaires
bio: Stef Wertheimer has devoted more than $100 million to his own method of creating a lasting peace between Israel and the Palestinian territories. His "capitalist kibbutzes" are industrial parks that provide rent-free working space for industrial start-ups in Israel's economically disadvantaged and predominantly Arab regions. He was honored with Oslo Business for Peace Award in 2010 for these efforts. More recently, he grabbed headlines for speaking candidly about South Korea's successes. "You have done a marvelous job in the past 60 years to make yourselves competitive today," Wertheimer said of South Korea. "You made industry and exports your new religions, which unfortunately our country has not done enough. We (Israel) are in love with problems, and you are in love with solutions."
