He first garnered international attention in 2006, when the carbide industrial cutting tool manufacturer company he founded out of a garage in his backyard became the first big international target of Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway. Wertheimer sold 80% of Iscar to Buffett that year; he still has a 20% stake in the company, which his son Eitan currently runs. After a stellar 2011, one that Buffett described as one of Berkshire's "fabulous five," Iscar struggled in 2012, hit by tough economic conditions in certain markets.

name: Billionaires
bio: Daniel Ziff is the youngest son of publishing magnate William Ziff Jr. (d. 2006), the man behind the Ziff-Davis empire that included PC Magazine and Car and Driver. Daniel and his billionaire brothers Dirk and Robert inherited the family fortune in 1994 after their father sold 95% of the business to Forstmann Little for $1.4 billion and retired. Through their New York City-based Ziff Brothers Investments, the brothers reinvested the proceeds across equities, debt, real estate, commodities, private equity and hedge funds, providing seed money to fund manager and fellow billionaire Daniel Och in exchange for a 10% stake in Och-Ziff Capital Management, which went public in 2007. ZBI reportedly cashed out its investment in Edward Lampert's ESL investments in January 2012, which led to Lampert buying $130 million of Sears stock from the fund. Daniel was married in 2009 at New York City's legendary Metropolitan Club.

name: Billionaires
bio: Dirk Ziff is the eldest son of publishing magnate William Ziff Jr. (d. 2006), the man behind the Ziff-Davis empire that included PC Magazine and Car and Driver. Dirk and his billionaire brothers Daniel and Robert inherited the family fortune in 1994 after their father sold 95% of the business to Forstmann Little for $1.4 billion and retired. Through their New York City-based Ziff Brothers Investments the brothers reinvested the proceeds across equities, debt, real estate, commodities, private equity and hedge funds, providing seed money to fund manager and fellow billionaire Daniel Och in exchange for a 10% stake in Och-Ziff Capital Management, which went public in 2007. ZBI reportedly cashed out its investment in Edward Lampert's ESL investments in January 2012, which led to Lampert buying $130 million of Sears stock from the fund. Dirk is married to a former Forbes Reporter.

name: Billionaires
bio: Robert Ziff is the middle son of publishing magnate William Ziff Jr. (d. 2006), the man behind the Ziff-Davis empire that included PC Magazine and Car and Driver. Robert and his brothers Dirk and Daniel inherited the family fortune in 1994 after their father sold 95% of the business to Forstmann Little for $1.4 billion and retired. Through their New York City-based Ziff Brothers Investments the brothers reinvested the proceeds across equities, debt, real estate, commodities, private equity and hedge funds, providing seed money to fund manager and fellow billionaire Daniel Och in exchange for a 10% stake in Och-Ziff Capital Management, which went public in 2007. ZBI reportedly cashed out its investment in Edward Lampert's ESL investments in January 2012, which led to Lampert buying $130 million of Sears stock from the fund. Robert made headlines in 2011 for his financial contributions to Republican legislators supportive of gay marriage.

name: Billionaires
bio: Emmanuel Besnier has been called the "French Howard Hughes,"  "the Emperor of Cheese," and, thanks to his disdain for the press, "the invisible billionaire": he's said to shun the media so much that only a handful of photos of him exist. The oldest of three siblings, Emmanuel is CEO of Lactalis, his family's dairy company, based in his ancestral hometown of Laval in western France. The makers of well-known brie brand President and Milkmaid yogurts brought in over $20 billion in revenues last year; he and his brother Jean-Michel and sister Marie own 100% between them, having inherited Lactalis from their father Michel. In 2011, the Besnier clan helped buy Italian milk and cheese giant Parmalat out of bankruptcy. Now, through a holding company, they own 82.4% of the publicly traded firm.

name: Billionaires
bio: Leon Black's Apollo Global Management and fellow billionaire Dean Metropoulus were approved as 'stalking horse' or lead bidders for the auction of most of Hostess's snack and bread business, set for mid-March. Among the firm's most notable 2012 deals were its investments in oil and gas producer EP Energy and in Great Wolf Resorts, North America's largest family of indoor water park resorts. A former M&A boss at Drexel Burnham Lambert, Black formed Apollo with two younger colleagues, Marc Rowan and Joshua Harris, now also billionaires, in 1990 after Drexel collapsed.  A renowned art collector, he spent a record $120 million, buying Edvard Munch's The Scream at auction in 2012. He lent it to the Museum of Modern Art, where he is a vice chairman of the board, for six months ending late April 2013. Black, whose mother was an artist and whose aunt owned a gallery, donated $48 million to his alma mater, Dartmouth College, for the construction of the Black Family Visual Arts Center; it opened in September 2012. He and his wife Debra, a Broadway producer and Melanoma survivor, have also given $40 million to the Melanoma Research Alliance.

name: Billionaires
bio: Jewelry business insiders call British diamond merchant Laurence Graff the new Harry Winston. Specializing in the highest end of jewelry retailing, Graff has more than 20 stores worldwide, including new outposts in Hong Kong, Hanghzhou, Macau, Gstaad and Dubai. Clients include the Sultan and Queen of Brunei, Oprah Winfrey and Donald Trump. In May 2012, Graff was set to offer shares to the public on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange, but he cancelled the offering as Europe's debt problems drove down first-time stock sales. A self-made tycoon, Graff spent his childhood in London's gritty East End, dropping out of school at age 14 to become a jeweler's apprentice. In 2008 he achieved full vertical integration when he bought a stake in publicly traded diamond miner Gem Diamonds. His assets include a polished diamond trading venture in Antwerp, real estate in London's tony Mayfair district, and a stake in a South African diamond wholesaler. Graff splits his time between homes in Gstaad, London, Cap Ferrat, New York City and his 150-foot Feadship yacht. He also owns Delaire Graff Estate, a vineyard and winery with a boutique hotel and restaurant in Stellenbosch, the Napa Valley of South Africa, and an extensive modern and contemporary art collection. On a personal note, Graff, 74, has acknowledged that he fathered a baby girl out of wedlock four years ago. He and French wife Anne-Marie have been married 50 years, and remain together. The value of Graff's fortune has increased in the past year due to a strengthening market for high-end diamonds and expansion in Asia.

name: Billionaires
bio: Hedge fund legend Kovner, who had generated more than $12 billion in net gains for investors since he founded Caxton Associates in 1983, called it a career in September 2011. The reins to his then-$10 billion firm were officially handed to former chief investment officer Andrew Law on January 1, 2012. Kovner addressed the transition in a letter to investors saying he will miss the adrenalin rush of confronting markets every day. The son of a trade unionist, Kovner abandoned his Harvard Ph.D. in economics after a fit of writer's block. He moved on to driving taxis, writing and studying harpsichord at Julliard. At 31, he turned $3,000 he borrowed on his credit card into $45,000 trading soybeans and soon watched as that value halved. It was a seminal lesson in risk management. The chairman of Julliard, Kovner has donated 140 scores and sketches by Bach, Beethoven and Brahms to the school; he also gave $20 million to Julliard in January 2012 to endow a graduate-level program in historical performance. Since Kovner's departure from Caxton, performance, AUM and fees have all fallen at the $6.5 billion firm.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Elisabeth (Liz) Mohn is the widow of Reinhard Mohn (d. 2009) and the owner of private German media conglomerate Bertelsmann. Its assets include European broadcaster RTL Group; Random House, the world's largest book-publishing group; and Gruner + Jahr, Europe's biggest magazine publisher. Mohn serves on the supervisory board of Bertelsmann and on the board of the Bertelsmann Foundation. She and her children own 23% of Bertelsmann, while the remaining shares are controlled by the charitable Bertelsmann Foundation. Their net worth has increased by $700 million over the past year primarily due to an increase in values among listed media companies; profits at Bertelsmann fell slighty to $620 million (465 million Euros) in 2011, while revenue edged up to $20 billion (15.25 billion Euros). Liz and Reinhard Mohn had three children together, two of whom --Brigitte and Christof -- are on the company's supervisory board. In the early 1990s, Liz founded the German Stroke Foundation and still serves as its president.

name: Billionaires
bio: A former mozzarella delivery boy, Emaneule "Lino" Saputo is Canada's cheese king. His net worth has risen some $500 million over the past 12 months primarily due to an increase in the price of Saputo Inc. shares; he owns 35% of the company. Saputo Inc. began as a cheese store with his father Giueseppe in 1954 and rose in prominence with the boom in pizza consumption. Saputo, an immigrant to Canada from Sicily, expanded his empire in the 1980s by acquiring U.S. and Canadian dairies. He took the company public on the Toronto stock exchange in 1997. Saputo remains chairman of the board but has handed most day-to-day operational control of the company to his son, Lino, Jr.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Charles Schwab left the CEO post of his eponymous brokerage firm 2008, but still remains chairman and the largest individual shareholder, with about a 15% stake. He founded the company in a two-room office in 1971. Since then, the firm has benefited from the deregulation of brokerage commissions and the trend toward online investing, now managing more than $1 trillion in client assets and 7 million individual investor accounts. A dyslexic, Schwab flunked English courses twice in his early education and has used his story to spread awareness of the disorder. In 2007, his Charles and Helen Schwab foundation shifted its focus away from its established education programs to concentrate on grants and giving. The foundation still donates to education causes and gave $1 million to the KIPP Foundation in 2010.
title: Chairman and Founder
employment: {'name': 'Charles Schwab', 'uri': 'companies/charles-schwab', 'title': 'Chairman and Founder', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Takemitsu Takizaki chairs Keyence, a global supplier of sensors and other electronic components for factory automation systems, which he founded in 1974. The company's stock price is up more than 40% over the past year, driven by rising sales to the auto industry and strong profits. The company has built up a substantial pool of technology patents from its large investments in R&D.

name: Billionaires
bio: Wu Yajun leads major real estate developer Longfor Properties and was once China's richest woman, but her divorce last year knocked her from the top spot. Her ex-spouse Cai Kui is now also a billionaire in his own right. Wu, a former journalist, started Longfor in Chongqing in 1994. She and her team turned it into a national brand and it's now headquartered in Beijing. In the face of government policies aimed at breaking real estate prices, Longfor turned up the sales volume in the first half of this year: Sales soared 85% to $2.3 billion; profit rose 72% to $532 million. That growth, and hopes for government policy easing, helped to boost Wu's stake in Longfor in the past year. Wu is looking to second-tier cities such as Yantai, Wuxi and Changzhou for growth as first-tier cities such as Beijing mature. She holds a degree in navigation engineering from Northwestern Polytechnical University. China's richest woman on the 2013 Forbes Billionaires List is Yang Huiyan of property developer Country Garden Holdings, who is worth $5.7 billion.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: In February, Carnival Cruises' Triumph lost power in the Gulf of Mexico, forcing its 4,200 passengers to survive on board for nearly a week while it got towed to land. Shari's father Ted founded the company, which she still maintains a stake in. She also has stakes in Israel's Bank Hapoalim, and infrastructure behemoth Shikun & Binui Holdings Ltd. Israel's richest woman, she controls her investments and philanthropy through the Arison Group and Ted Arison Family Foundation, which each year contributes to hundreds of nonprofits involved in health, education, disabilities and research. The Tel-Aviv resident has tried to position herself as a force for good in business by investing in a number of green projects, including a massive desalination plant and a green shopping mall in Israel, and also starting  Miya in 2008, a $100 million venture dedicated to maximizing the efficiency of large urban water systems. She also launched International Good Deeds Day to advocate community service, and in 2009 published the book Birth: When the Spiritual and the Material Come Together.
title: Investor, Philanthropist

name: Billionaires
bio: Sir Anthony Bamford's family-owned farm equipment brand is so ingrained in British culture that its name is generic: a "JCB" is a backhoe, just as a Kleenex is a tissue in the U.S. Thanks to a post-recession construction boom, J.C. Bamford Excavators posted revenues of more than $4.3 billion in 2012, up almost 40% year on year. The Bamford family fortune has climbed $2 billion in the past year. Now their firm is looking to Brazil and India for growth. Former U.K. Prime Minister David Cameron, a Bamford friend and recipient of Bamford political donations, cut the ribbon at a new factory in 2012. Founded by Sir Anthony's father in 1945, JCB is wholly owned by the family, who also lay claim to some of Britain's most desirable real estate, like 1,700-acre Daylesford House in Gloucestershire. Sir Anthony's wife Carole started Daylesford Organics to sell organic food from the estate's farm. It's turned into a small, upmarket cafe chain.

name: Billionaires
bio: In 2012, S. Truett Cathy's Chick-fil-A fried chicken chain became an unexpected totem for the religious right with its vocal position against gay marriage. The controversy began years ago when the Cathy family's WinShape Foundation started donating millions to groups lobbying against equal marriage rights. His oldest son, Dan, the company president, set off the most recent wave of protests  when he reaffirmed Chick-fil-A's stance in a July 2012 interview with the Baptist Press. Outrage on social networks soon sparked an LGBT "kiss-in" at some of the chain's 1,600-plus stores in 40 states. Cathy opened his first Chick-fil-A outlet in Atlanta's Greenbriar Mall in 1967. Forty-five years later, the 91-year-old devout Baptist remains CEO of the second largest fried chicken chain in the country -- only KFC is bigger. Cathy's net worth got a recent boost due to new information Forbes uncovered on system-wide sales; his fortune includes shares held by Dan and younger son Don, who oversees Chick-fil-A's other dining brands and goes by the nickname Bubba. Several grandchildren are now franchise owners. All Chick-fil-A stores are shut on Sundays so employees can attend church.

name: Billionaires
bio: Bruce Halle opened his first tire store more than 50 years ago in Ann Arbor, Michigan. Today his Discount Tire is the world's largest independent tire and wheel retailer with more than 840 locations in 24 states. The company's "Thank You" commercial holds the Guinness World Record for the longest-running TV commercial; the ten-second spot has been on the air since 1975. The No. 22 Discount Tire car, driven by Brad Keselowski, won the 2010 NASCAR Nationwide Series championship. Halle maintains what is most likely the world's largest collection of vintage tire advertisements; his collection contains about 400 unique lithographs from the earliest days of the industry. His Bruce T. Halle Family Foundation supports many causes, from the Diane Halle Center for Family Justice at Arizona State University to Children First Academy, the nation's largest school for homeless children.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Joe Lewis' medical city in Lake Nona, near Orlando, is now one of the fastest-growing communities in the USA. Anchored by four large medical institutions, two of which opened in 2012, the 7,000-acre development is selling 40 houses per month. It was recently recognized by Cisco CEO John Chambers as one of eight "Smart+Connected" Cities for the 21st century. Lewis made his initial fortune trading currencies and is still an active FX trader. He also has interests in more than 150 companies through his Tavistock Group. Among the more notable holdings: London Premiership soccer team Tottenham Hotspur (Spurs), a stake in UK's largest pub operator, Mitchell's & Butlers plc, and approximately 135 restaurants in the U.S. operating under such brands as Abe & Louie's and Freebirds. His vast art collection, said to be worth $1 billion, includes works by Picasso, Matisse, Lucian Freud and Francis Bacon. While he has homes in Florida, the Bahamas and Argentina, he spends most of the year working from his yacht.

name: Billionaires
bio: Hollywood producer Arnon Milchan's New Regency films, the company he founded, produced no movies in 2012 as he worked to rebuild his management team, but four movies are slated for release in 2013, including "Noah," a Darron Aronofsky-directed setting of the Biblical flood story starring Russell Crowe, Emma Watson and Anthony Hopkins. The company recently reopened its television division, which earlier produced "Malcolm in the Middle" and "The Bernie Mac Show." Once a business student and professional soccer player, Milchan transformed his family's bankrupt fertilizer company into a $125 million business with interests in agriculture, aerospace, animal health products, plastic, fiber optics and pharmaceuticals. An avid art collector, he has lately been doing paintings of his own. He has seven homes around the world.

name: Billionaires
bio: In 2011 Viktor Rashnikov stepped down from his post as chief executive of Magnitogorsk Iron & Steel Works (MMK) after 14 years. He remains chairman of the company's board. He began his career there in 1967 as a mechanic and rose to eventually become its general director. He built his ownership to nearly 100% by buying shares on the market, and he fought off takeover attempts by companies associated with fellow billionaire Iskander Makhmudov. When he faced shortages of iron ore, he and partners bought one of the biggest iron ore deposits in Russia. In 2007 he took MMK public on the London Stock Exchange and pocketed around $1 billion, but the vast majority of his wealth remains tied up in the stock. Outside of MMK, he invests in real estate, including the construction of the Rossiya Hotel and a wedding palace in Moscow.

name: Billionaires
bio: Real estate mogul Leonard Stern started buying land in the 1960s and today owns more than 38 million square feet of commercial, residential, and retail property in New York, New Jersey and Chicago. Stern joined the family business, Hartz Mountain Pet Products, in 1959 and sold it for $350 million in 2000 to private equity firm J.W. Childs. Older son Emanuel oversees the real estate holdings. Son Edward, started Hartz Energy Holdings in 2010, to focus on the oil and gas business. Leonard gave $30 million to alma mater New York University in 1988; the NYU Stern business school is named after him.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Hartz Mountain Industries, Inc.', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Portuguese businessman Americo Amorim started out in his family's cork production company, Corticeira Amorim, but has grown the Amorim Group into a diversified group with activities in real estate, tourism and private equity. His most valuable asset --worth some $2.3 billion -- is an 18% stake in Galp Energia, Portugal's former state-owned oil company. Amorim became chairman of the board of Galp Energia in April 2012. He also owns bank stakes in Spain, Angola and Mozambique and in 2012 bought 33% of a small bank in Brazil. His net worth has fallen by $300 million from a year ago in part due to a drop in the Galp Energia share price.

name: Billionaires
bio: Pierre Bellon turned a small Marseilles catering outfit into Sodexo, one of the world's largest catering companies, with 413,000 employees in 80 countries. Sodexo supplies food to the U.S. Marine Corps. It also does catering in prisons and it organizes catering for major events including the Ryder Cup, the Dakar Road Rally, and the World Scout Jamboree. Bellon put together a joint venture with Magic Johnson to provide dinning and catering to schools and corporate cafeterias. He stepped down as chief executive of Sodexo in 2005 and wrote his autobiography, "I've Had a Lot of Fun."

name: Billionaires
bio: Chan Laiwa is one of only a handful of self-made billionaire women in China, thanks to the success of her Fu Wah International Group, one of Beijing's largest real estate developers. Fu Wah has developed nearly 1.5 million square meters of property since its inception in 1988. Much of the profits from older projects were reinvested in Fu Wah's best-known development Jinbao Street, located in one of Beijing's main business districts. Chan's net worth increased $570 million in the past year due an increase in commercial property values in the city. Fu Wah has aspirations beyond Beijing: this year it agreed to develop a helicopter landing facility in Ninguo in Anhui Province. Chan was born a poor descendant of Chinese royalty but now has a place on the 2012 Forbes Asia list of Asia's most powerful women. Her son reportedly paid $1.1 million for a race horse at an auction in Hong Kong in March 2012. She is now focused on preserving Chinese art and culture, investing $16 million to open the China Red Sandalwood Museum in Beijing in 1999 and donating sandalwood pieces to museums worldwide.
title: Philanthropist

name: Billionaires
bio: Barbara Carlson Gage jointly owns Carlson Inc. with her sister, Marilyn. It operates more than 1,300 hotels (Radisson, Country Inns & Suites), 900 T.G.I. Friday's restaurants and holds a majority stake in Carlson Wagonlit Travel. Revenues in 2011 grew 8% to $4.5 billion. Her father, Curt (d. 1999), founded the company to sell Gold Bond trading stamps in the 1930s and later expanded into dining and hospitality. Barbara runs the Curtis L. Carlson Family Foundation, which makes $5 million in grants annually with a focus on youth education and at-risk children. With Queen Silvia of Sweden, she cofounded the World Childhood Foundation, which supports 120 programs in 14 countries to raise awareness and provide aide to sexually abused or trafficked women and children around the world. In 2012 she stepped down from Carlson's board, and her son, Geoffrey Gage, replaced her.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ken Griffin, the founder of Chicago-based hedge fund firm Citadel, is on a winning streak. After battling back from a catastrophic year in 2008, Citadel's flagship Kensington and Wellington funds blew past their high water marks at the end of 2011, a year in which the funds returned more than 20% net of fees. The trend continued in 2012, as the pair finished up an impressive 25%. Though the firm is best known for its hedge funds, Citadel also houses a growing securities business, which currently accounts for 14% of U.S. consolidated equity volume. Griffin began investing as a Harvard undergrad when he read a Forbes article about the Home Shopping Network. By the time he finished school, Griffin was running $1 million. After graduation, he was introduced to Chicago hedge fund manager Frank C. Meyer, who seeded the young trader when he launched Citadel in 1990. A noted art collector, Griffin paid $80 million for Jasper Johns' "False Start" in 2006 and sits on the boards of the Museum of Contemporary Art and the Art Institute of Chicago.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: The Hult International Business School, named after Bertil Hult, has teamed up with President Bill Clinton to challenge business schools the world over to create, efficient sustainable nonprofit business models. It's par for the course for the Swedish billionaire who got rich helping others learn. He dropped out of college after a year to start a business in his dormitory's basement, helping set up students with host families as they prepared to study abroad. The company, EF Education First, focuses on cultural exchanges, educational travel, language training and degree programs. Its programs are now available in over 50 countries. It was the official supplier of language training for the 2008 Beijing Olympic Games. Hult, who has passed the reins of EF to his sons, donates money to a Swedish school annually, based on innovative support for dyslexia education. He made headlines when he lent his yacht, the Erica XII, and his private jet to Swedish royals Crown Princess Victoria and Prince Daniel for their 2010 honeymoon. He is a trustee and former chairman of the Mentor Foundation. He is an avid sailor.

name: Billionaires
bio: The only son of Samsung Group Chairman Lee Kun Hee, Jay Y. Lee has been groomed for years to take over Korea's biggest conglomerate. He became president of Samsung Electronics in 2009 and was named as Samsung's vice chairman last year. He has been credited for the strong growth in Samsung's smartphone and TV business. The company's popular Galaxy S III overtook the iPhone 4S as the world's most popular smartphone in 2012. Though he usually keeps a low profile, Lee went to Steve Jobs' memorial service in 2011.

name: Billionaires
bio: The namesake of Moore's Law, which posits that computing power will double every 18 months (later updated to 2 years), Gordon Moore is a Silicon Valley legend. After co-founding Fairchild Semiconductor, he started chipmaker Intel in 1968, serving as chief executive until 1987 and chairman until 1997. The Gordon and Betty Moore Foundation was created in 2001 with a donation of his 175 million Intel shares; the foundation now has several billion dollars of assets. It awards approximately $200 million annually to support environmental conservation, fundamental science, patient care, conservation and science and technology museums in the San Francisco Bay Area. The foundation is the largest backer of the Thirty Meter Telescope, world's largest, under construction in Hawaii; it has contributed $50 million for the design and in 2007 pledged $200 million over nine years for the telescope's construction. Moore studied chemistry at U.C. Berkeley and earned a Ph.D. in chemistry and physics from the California Institute of Technology, where he is a life trustee.
title: Cofounder and Chairman Emeritus
employment: {'name': 'Intel', 'uri': 'companies/intel', 'title': 'Cofounder and Chairman Emeritus', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Marilyn Carlson Nelson jointly owns Carlson Inc. with her sister, Barbara. The company operates more than 1,300 hotels (Radisson, Country Inns & Suites), 900 T.G.I. Friday's restaurants and holds a majority stake in Carlson Wagonlit Travel. Revenues in 2011 grew 8% to $4.5 billion. Her father Curt (d. 1999) founded the company to sell Gold Bond trading stamps in the 1930s and later expanded into dining and hospitality. Marilyn stepped down as CEO in 2008 and passed the chairmanship to her daughter Diana Nelson in 2012. She continues to serve on the boards of the United Nations Global Compact, The Committee Encouraging Corporate Philanthropy, the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts and the Harvard Kennedy School Advisory Board.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: In December 2012 Claremont McKenna College announced that it had received a $50 million unrestricted gift from its trustee and alumnus George Roberts. In thanks, a new athletic facility will be built in his name. Roberts made partner at Bear Stearns when he was 29, and a few years later, in 1976, he founded KKR, with his cousin Henry Kravis and his Bear Stearns mentor Jerome Kohlberg. The firm was one of the first to use leverage in its acquisitions. In 1989 KKR orchestrated the $25 billion buyout of RJR Nabisco; the deal became the basis of the bestselling book "Barbarians at the Gate." KKR, which Roberts and Kravis still run, went public in July 2010. In June 2012 it bought $8 billion (assets under management) Prisma Capital Partners for an undisclosed sum. Roberts is also the founder of REDF, a San Francisco nonprofit that uses venture philanthropy to create job opportunities. REDF has assisted 50 social enterprises that employ 6,500 people, generating revenues of more than $100 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Melker Schorling is the chairman and owner of investment firm Melker Schorling AB. He founded it in 1999 and took it public in 2006, attracting such investors as fellow billionaire Stefan Persson of H&M, who sits on MSAB's board. Schorling has also partnered with fellow Swedish billionaire Gustav Douglas.

name: Billionaires
bio: Bruno Schroder is the fourth generation in his banking family to operate their eponymous financial-services company, Schroders. He is a non-executive director and a member of the nominations committee. As of late 2012, the firm had $327.4 billion in assets under management (globally). Shares of the company are at all-time highs, up 24% from one year ago, bolstering the fortune he shares with his sister Charmaine by $800 million. His nephew, Philip Mallinckrodt, sits on the company board. In his spare time, Schroder flies his private plane and breeds Middle White pigs at his estate in Islay, Scotland.

name: Billionaires
bio: Guinea's first democratically elected president is threatening to take back the world's largest untapped iron reserve from Beny Steinmetz who acquired rights to the project from dictator Lansana Conte for free, after he had stripped it from Australian giant Rio Tinto. Steinmetz then flipped 51% to Vale SA for $2.5 billion, but he's only received $500 million so far. Born and raised in Israel, Steinmetz served in the army after the Yom Kippur War and moved to Belgium in 1978 to run his father's diamond business. He eventually became chairman of the Geneva-headquartered Steinmetz Diamond Group.

name: Billionaires
bio: Brothers Jeronimo, Manuel, and Placido Arango made their fortune when they sold their stake in retailer Cifra to Wal-Mart's Mexican arm in 1997. Jeronimo is said to live a quiet life in Los Angeles. Manuel, a real estate developer, founded the Mexican Center for Philanthropy and in 2011, called on businesses to donate at least 1% of their profits to charity. Placido collects art and has owned a chain of restaurants.

name: Billionaires
bio: Vincent Bollore heads Bollore Group, founded in 1822. In 1981 he became chairman and chief executive officer of the company's paper business. Under his leadership the diversified empire became one of the world's 500 largest companies.Its portfolio includes African shipping, Asian palm-oil plantations, plastics, media, construction, logistics and more. His group is responsible for Autolib, the electrical car-sharing service in Paris. Following Autolib's success, Bollore has started to sell its electric car, Bluecar, to the general public. Vincent Bollore started as a bank trainee at Edmond de Rothschild. He hosted close friend, former French President Sarkozy, on his yacht for a post-election holiday off Malta in 2007. He has a collection of 1,000 comic books.

name: Billionaires
bio: Gayle Cook, wife of the late William Cook, inherited her husband's stake in the medical device company Cook Group after he died in April 2011. She sits on the board. In June 2012 Cook Medical got approval from the FDA to work as a contractor to drug makers at its Bloomington, Indiana plant, dubbed Cook Pharmica. Cook Medical also got FDA approval in 2012 for a stent that releases drugs into arteries in the legs, to treat peripheral artery disease. The Cooks started the company in their Bloomington apartment in 1963. The company now has offices in the U.S., Europe and Asia. It specializes in stents and catheters that contain antibiotics. Cook Group has an arm focusing on cell and tissue processing and cryopreservation technologies. From 1996 to 2007, the couple spent $500 million to restore the luxury French Lick Resort and West Baden Springs Hotel in Indiana, adding a casino and a Pete Dye-designed PGA golf course. Thanks to their philanthropy in Bloomington, the mayor proclaimed June 20th Bill and Gayle Cook Day. The Cooks donated an estimated $10 million to Northwestern University, where the couple endowed the Bill and Gayle Cook Professor in Biochemistry, Molecular Biology and Cell Biology.
title: co-founder

name: Billionaires
bio: John Paul DeJoria went from living in his car along L.A.'s Sun Set Strip to lording over a haircare and alcohol empire. In 1980, the Navy vet  teamed up with Paul Mitchell to launch a shampoo company with a $700 investment. DeJoria sold product door-to-door. Current sales: nearly $1 billion. He struck gold again launching premium tequila maker Patron Spirits with Martin Crowley in 1989. DeJoria's philanthropic efforts include Grow Appalachia (in partnership with Berea College), which helps families fight obesity and poverty by creating gardens. Other charities: Blazer House, Mineseekers and Food4Africa.

name: Billionaires
bio: For 36 years, Carl Engelhorn headed pharmaceutical companies Boehringer Manheim and DePuy. In 1997, he engineered the sale of both firms to Roche for $11 billion. Engelhorn made $4.4 billion on the deal. FORBES has reduced his estimated net worth by $2.6 billion since last year to account for large sums of money that Engelhorn has said he has transferred to his children; he is a father of five. Engelhorn, whose mother was American, sponsors the Heidelberg Center for American Studies at the University of Heidelberg, funding it with an annual donation of more than $400,000. He also supports the Reiss-Engelhorn Museum in Mannheim. He is the great-grandson of Friedrich Engelhorn, the founder of German chemical company BASF. Engelhorn and his wife own a chalet in Gstaad, Switzerland; a ranch on the Costa Brava in Spain and a villa on the Cote D'Azur in France.

name: Billionaires
bio: Andre Santos Esteves is the chief executive and controlling shareholder of Brazilian investment bank BTG Pactual, which has more than $60 billion in assets under management. While studying mathematics at the Federal University of Rio de Janeiro, Esteves joined the IT department of investment bank Pactual as an intern in 1989. He worked his way up as an ace trader while Brazil was experiencing hyperinflation. Esteves sold BANK Pactual to UBS in 2006,forming the Brazilian subsidiary UBS Pactual. In 2009 he engineered the sale of UBS Pactual to BTG. In April 2012 Italy's market regulator hit him with a $458,000 fine for alleged insider trading weeks before BTG Pactual's successful IPO. Promoting an aggressive and meritocratic management structure, BTG Pactual employs more than 1,500 professionals and has offices in Brazil, Chile, Peru, Colombia, United States, United Kingdom and China.

name: Billionaires
bio: Andrei Guriev, a senator from Murmansk Oblast, controls Fosagro, one of the world's four biggest phosphor fertilizer producers, which continues to benefit from a fertilizer boom. In September 2012 Fosagro bought from the state a 20% interest in Apatit, its most important source of raw materials; it now owns 77.6% of the company. Guriev, a former Moscow communist committee leader, became an avid capitalist in the 1990s working with Mikhail Khodorkovsky's Menatep Group and eventually rose to be chairman of its subsidiary Apatit. During the prosecution of former billionaire Mikhail Khodorkovsky, who has been in jail for years, Guriev led a management buyout to acquire control of Apatit.

name: Billionaires
bio: Retail entrepreneur Stein Erik Hagen founded discount supermarket Rimi with his father in the late 1970s, before eventually merging with giant international supermarket Ahold for a big payday. Hagen sold his remaining 20 percent stake in the company in 2004, and has since invested in a variety of Scandinavian enterprises. He took department store chain Steen & Strom private in 2007, then flipped it the next year for NOK 22 billion. Hagen is the chairman of consumer goods manufacturer Orkla and also owns hardware store chain Jernia, which he acquired in 2005.

name: Billionaires
bio: Micky Jagtiani controls $4.7 billion (sales) Landmark Group, a Middle East retailing empire with 1,300 stores in 18 countries. It's partnered with French retailer Auchan for a hypermarket venture in India where it also operates the franchise for doughnut chain Krispy Kreme in India; it plans to open 80 stores in the next five years. He's expanded into healthcare, opening iCARE, a primary healthcare clinic in Dubai. Landmark sponsored Madonna's concert in Abu Dhabi last June as "fashion partner." The Indian born retail mogul drove a cab in London before starting a kids' store in Bahrain in 1973 with $6,000 inherited after the untimely deaths of his parents and brother.

name: Billionaires
bio: The younger brother of Charles (and David's twin) missed out on the huge increase in value at Koch Industries by selling out early, but has built a multibillion-dollar fortune himself based on coal and petroleum coke. Lately he's been defending against charges he illegally imprisoned a disgruntled former employee on his Colorado ranch. "A frivolous, desperate attempt" to divert attention from allegations of wrongdoing against the ex-employee, Koch's lawyer says.

name: Billionaires
bio: Real estate tycoon Ted Lerner and his family are the majority owners of the Washington Nationals baseball team. In 2012 the team became the first D.C. franchise in 79 years to make it to the playoffs. Lerner amassed his fortune building shopping malls in the D.C. suburbs. A former lawyer, in 1952 he borrowed $300 from his wife to start his company, Lerner Enterprises. Today he owns 20 million square feet of commercial and retail space as well as 7,000 apartments and 750 private home lots. He's currently developing hotels, apartments and offices in the Virginia and Maryland suburbs. The Lerners own a stake in regional broadcast network Mid-Atlantic Sports Network. Their team's Washington Nationals Dream Foundation committed $2 million toward a pediatric diabetes wing at Children's National Hospital in D.C.  The Lerners? family foundation gave $5 million to the Lerner Family Health and Wellness Center at George Washington University,and $10 million to the Lerner Family Sports Center at Hebrew University in Jerusalem.

name: Billionaires
bio: Lin Rong San is one of Taiwan's largest real estate moguls. He owns commercial buildings in Taiwan's capital of Taipei and tracts of land in suburban areas where  middle-income Taiwanese have been looking for affordable real estate following a run-up in central prices in recent years. Lin's newspaper, the Liberty Times, has been a voice for a cautious approach in relations between the island and the mainland, and may benefit from the recent sale of the independent-minded Apple Daily's Taiwan operations to a China-friendly group of Taiwan businessman. Lin's brother Lin Yu-lin is also a member of this year's Forbes Billionaires List. The family also controls the Union Bank in Taiwan.

name: Billionaires
bio: Lu Zhiqiang chairs China Oceanwide Group of Beijing, one of China's largest non-government-controlled conglomerates, with interests in real estate (Oceanwide Real Estate), financial services (China Minsheng Banking) and computers (Lenovo). Along with other big real estate developers, his flagship Oceanwide Real Estate Group's stock price is up sharply from its lows in late 2012 on expectations of recovery in 2013. Lu was a pioneer in China's private sector, and is a vice chairman of the All-China Federation of Industry & Commerce.

name: Billionaires
bio: Lorenzo Mendoza runs Empresas Polar, one of Venezuela's largest private companies. Polar makes beer and basic food items including flour, condiments, tuna fish and wine; the privately held company reported revenues of $6.5 billion in 2011. Last year, Empresas Polar joined forces with Spanish firm Leche Pascual to launch a $146 million yogurt factory in Venezuela; its "MiGurt" yogurt product will have a shelf life of six months, with no refrigeration needed. Leftist President Hugo Chavez regularly attacks Mendoza in the press, and Mendoza continues to critique the country's strict price controls. Polar's company-backed Empresas Polar Foundation is one of Venezuela's biggest charities, with a focus on children's nutrition, health and education.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sun Guangxin is the chairman of Xinjiang Guanghui Industry Investment Group, a conglomerate with large energy, real estate and auto distribution businesses. Sun started his real estate business in 1993 and today he is one of the biggest developers in northwest China. Sun's Grand Auto chain has almost 400 locations in 18 provinces. His Shanghai-listed Guanghui Energy invests in China and Kazakhstan and is active in coal mining; shares have risen more than 50% in the last year, pushing up Sun's net worth by more than $1 billion compared to a year ago. Sun-related companies have raised more than $700 million through debt sales in recent months.

name: Billionaires
bio: In the largest real estate transaction since 2007, Zell's Equity Residential REIT is acquiring 60% of apartment giant Archstone's holdings in a $16 billion deal. His private investment firm, Equity International, has $2 billion invested overseas, including $1 billion in Brazil and investments in Mexico, Colombia, Peru, Chile, China and Egypt. His net worth is down markedly compared to a year ago primarily because Forbes is using a lower estimate of Zell's stake in Equity International. Big charitable donations: $5 million to Northwestern University's business school for the Zell Center for Risk Research and $4 million to the University of Michigan's Ross School of Business in 2004 for the Zell-Lurie Institute for Entrepreneurial Studies.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of a factory worker, Andrew Tan did odd jobs to put himself through college. Saved money he earned as a kitchen appliance salesman to buy a distillery and made his first fortune in brandy. His holding company, Alliance Global, which has interests in food and beverage, real estate, gaming, saw its shares climb 70% since last year on higher profits, revenues from gaming. With Malaysian tycoon Lim Kok Thay's Genting Hong Kong he plans to start building a new $1.1 billion casino, Resorts World Bayshore, in a new entertainment hub in the Philippines, due to be completed in 2016.

name: Billionaires
bio: Wal-Mart heiress Nancy Walton Laurie and her sister Ann became billionaires when their father James "Bud" Walton died in 1995, leaving them each a large chunk of shares. Wal-Mart now has sales of $444 billion and employs 2.2 million people worldwide. Nancy received more than $60 million in dividends in 2012. In 1999, she and her husband Bill bought hockey's St. Louis Blues, only to sell it six years later. Nancy also founded Cedar Lake Contemporary Ballet in New York in 2003, and owns Providence Bank, commercial real estate, and shopping centers.

name: Billionaires
bio: In October, The Walt Disney Company stunned Hollywood by ponying up $4.05 billion for George Lucas' LucasFilm, which includes his Industrial Light and Magic special effects house and more importantly, the Star Wars franchise. Disney is already busy producing a sequel (to be helmed by J.J. Abrams) and planning spin-off movies. In the meantime, Lucas has said he will give most of the money to charity. The director recently got engaged to Ariel Investments partner Mellody Hobson.
title: Director/Producer

name: Billionaires
bio: Luo Jye is chairman of Cheng Shin Rubber of Taiwan. Founded in 1967, the company has advanced from early success as a supplier of tires to Taiwan's then-booming bicycle export industry to become one the world's largest manufacturers of tires for passenger cars, trucks and motorcycles.  A key to its success: worldwide sales of its Maxxis brand, particularly in China's world-leading auto market. Other brands include Cheng Shin and Sakura. Luo's fortune has risen by $900 million from a year ago due to a significant increase in the price of its Taiwan-traded shares.

name: Billionaires
bio: Daughter of Hennes & Mauritz founder Erling Persson, Lotti, as she is known to her friends, is the second largest shareholder of trendy apparel retailer. The biggest shareholder is her brother Stefan, who has run the company since 1982. He is chairman. Her nephew , Karl-Johan Persson,has been CEO since 2009. H&M has more than 104,000 employees and around 2,800 stores in 48 markets. It plans to open its first stores in Chile, Estonia, Lithuania, Serbia and Indonesia in 2013.

name: Billionaires
bio: India's vaccines man Cyrus Poonawalla  saw his wealth jump on rising sales of a five-in-one vaccine made by his Serum Institute of India, which he founded and runs. One of the world's largest producer of vaccines, Serum makes one billion doses annually for such diseases as measles, meningitis and flu, and sells them in 140 countries at prices well below its multinational competitors. In a bid to expand its portfolio, he bought Bilthoven Biologicals, a producer of injectible polio vaccines owned by the Dutch government, for $90 million last July. Poonawalla and son Adar hosted Bill Gates last May when he visited Serum's factory in Pune; Gates had previously called him one of the world's seven vaccine heroes. He bought several pieces of art in July at a Christie's auction, including works by Renoir, Dali and Chagall

name: Billionaires
bio: Mitchell Rales and his brother, Steven, cofounded manufacturing and technology company Danaher, naming it after the Montana stream where they fished for trout. In February 2013 the company's blood-analysis division agreed to pay a reported $300 million for Quest Diagnostics' HemoCue, which makes blood-testing equipment for doctors' offices. Also in early 2013, Danaher acquired Navman Wireless, a company that makes a tracking system for monitoring fleets of vehicles. Mitchell and his brother left their father's real estate firm in 1979 and started buying small manufacturing companies during the junk bond frenzy of the 1980s. The result was Equity Group Holdings. The brothers acquired a crippled REIT and fused it with other industrial companies to form Danaher. Both brothers sit on the Danaher board. They took industrial pump maker Colfax public in 2008. In January 2012 Colfax finalized a $2.4 billion deal to buy British welding, cutting and automation company Charter International. A trustee of the National Gallery of Art, Mitchell has amassed a valuable collection of post-WWII art that includes works by Jeff Koons, Alexander Calder and Jackson Pollock, housed at Glenstone, a private museum in Potomac, Maryland. He is in the process of turning Glenstone into a public museum.

name: Billionaires
bio: The Sobrato Organization, founded by John A. Sobrato, manages about 7.5 million square feet of commercial office space and 30 apartment communities with 6,700 units. Commercial tenants include Apple, Yahoo and Netflix. He began his real estate career in 1957, selling homes in Palo Alto while going to school at Santa Clara University. From there, he built up a commercial real estate empire in the 1960 and 1970s with fellow Silicon Valley building pioneer, Carl Berg. He founded his own company in 1978, which he still oversees today with son John M. Sobrato as CEO. The elder Sobrato still serves as chairman. A Giving Pledge signatory, Sobrato, through his Sobrato Family Foundation, has donated more than $230 million in real estate and cash to local communities since 1996. In January, Sobrato and his wife made a $5 million donation to the Santa Clara Valley Medical Center.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Former car salesman raced into billionaire ranks after selling stakes in Formula One Group of companies for $2.5 billion to CVC Capital. Racing company was valued at $9.1 billion in 2012 after CVC sold stakes to funds managed by Waddell & Reed Investment Management Company and Ivy Investment Management Company. Ecclestone's grip on F1 could loosen later this year after German bribery investigation moves to London's High Court. The 82-year-old still owns 5.3% of F1, with 8.5% under control of Bambino Trust for socialite daughters Tamara and Petra. Ecclestone left school at 16 and built a large car dealership. After failing to qualify as a Formula One racing driver, he bought a team and brokered a complex series of contracts and TV deals for others before taking over most rights in 1997. His daughters are in the midst of selling their London mansions for as much as $47 million each, while frugal dad stays put in penthouse above office. He reportedly brokered $30 million to license F1 Grand Prix rights to Australian state of Victoria till 2015. Ecclestone had to pay ex-wife Slavica a reported $1.2 billion in landmark divorce settlement in 2009.

name: Billionaires
bio: Aloysio de Andrade Faria sold most of his Banco Real to Dutch bank ABN Amro in 1998 for $2.1 billion. With the remaining assets he built Conglomerado Alfa, a holding company that controls financial firms like Banco Alfa and eleven other companies including Agropalma, Latin America's biggest palm oil producer, hotel chain Transamérica, which operates one of Brazil's most exclusive resorts in Comandatuba Island in the northeast region of the country, Labasque, a premium  ice cream maker, C&C, a chain of home improvement stores and others ranging from radio stations to cultural centers. Today he is mostly retired and spend sa lot of time on his farm reading and admiring his 150 pure-bred horses. He trained as a doctor and practiced medicine for two years. When his father died suddenly, Faria took his place running Banco Real.

name: Billionaires
bio: Diane Hendricks took over ABC Supply, the nation's largest roofing, window and siding wholesale distributor, after her husband and business partner, Kenneth Hendricks, died in 2007. Sales hit $4.65 billion in 2012, up from $4.56 billion the previous year. In addition to ABC, Hendricks presides over 25 million square feet of commercial property and 25 smaller companies via Hendricks Holding Co., including manufacturing plants, recycling businesses and pharmaceutical research. She is a major supporter of economic development and education in Wisconsin. She underwrites the Wisconsin Eye Public Affairs Network and sits on the boards of the Beloit Foundation, Beloit College and the Hendricks Family Foundation, which she and Ken founded to direct their local philanthropic giving.
title: Cofounder and Chairman
employment: {'name': 'ABC Supply', 'title': 'Cofounder and Chairman', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Samvel Karapetyan heads the real estate firm Tashir Group, which owns 24 shopping centers, seven office centers, and seven hotels. He made big acquisitions during the financial crisis and has been buying again more recently. Born in Armenia, he moved to Kaluga, near Moscow, in the 1990s. His companies operate in 25 regions of Russia, but recently he has focused on launching new projects in the Moscow area. He is believed to have construction and tourism contracts with officials in Yerevan, the capital of Armenia, as well. His older brother Karen Karapetyan is a well-known Armenian politician and a former high official in the Armenian president's administration.

name: Billionaires
bio: Liu Yonghao is the chairman of the New Hope Group, one of the country's largest agribusiness concerns and producers of meat, eggs and dairy products. His wealth is little changed from a year ago in part because shares of New Hope were hit in December after reports that chickens processed by one of its subsidiaries weren't checked for antibiotics. China Minsheng Banking, where he is vice chairman, posted a 35% rise in profits in the first nine months of last year to $4.6 billion. New Hope Group has reportedly been in talks with Blackstone Group to acquire Australian poultry producer Inghams Enterprises for about $1.5 billion. Liu Yonghao was named man of the year for 2012 by Chinese government broadcaster CCTV. Liu Yonghao is the younger brother of Liu Yongxing, who is also a member of this year's Billionaires List. Daughter Liu Chang is heir apparent.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mark Zuckerberg's former roommate and Facebook co-founder, Dustin Moskovitz may no longer be with the Menlo Park, Calif.-based social networking giant, but he still holds a significant financial stake in the company. That stake got a little smaller over the summer as he proceeded to sell 7.5 million Facebook shares. Still, as of February, he still owns more than 5% of the company's outstanding stock. Facebook's third employee, he dropped out Harvard with Zuckerberg and moved to California to work for the social-networking firm full-time. He left in 2008 to start Asana, a software company that aims to improve how people work with project collaboration tools. Engaged to former journalist Cari Tuna, Moskovitz and his fiancee founded Good Ventures and plan to publish their grants and conversations with charities with the goal of rewarding results over crafty fundraising techniques. He is also a signee of Bill Gates' and Warren Buffett's Giving Pledge. Moskovitz bikes to work, flies commercial, and pitches his own tent at Burning Man.
title: CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: Ukrainian mogul Victor Pinchuk was back at the annual World Economic Forum in Davos this year, hosting a panel on online education with panelists including fellow billionaires Bill Gates and Peter Thiel. Pinchuk is himself getting more involved with online ventures: he launched internet business incubator EastLabs in Kiev which hopes to encourage start-ups. "My goal in my social activities is to empower the next generation to change their country and the world," Pinchuk told Forbes. But the majority of his wealth comes from traditional pipe manufacturing; this past year, his Interpipe launched a $700 million steel plant, the first such plant build from scratch in Ukraine since 1991. Other parts of his diversified empire have not fared as well with co-investments with the Privat Group faltering: Aerosvit, one of the largest Ukrainian airlines, declared bankrupcy and the ferroalloy business struggled with its debt load. He also sold a 40% stake of his oil exploration firm Geo Alliance to Arawak Energy Ukraine for $150 million. Son-in-law of ex-president Leonid Kuchma, Pinchuk made his first fortune with Interpipe, supplying pipes for huge energy customers including Gazprom and Rosneft.

name: Billionaires
bio: Steven Rales and his brother, Mitchell, cofounded manufacturing and technology company Danaher, naming it after the Montana stream where they fished for trout. In February 2013 the company's blood-analysis division agreed to pay a reported $300 million for Quest Diagnostics' HemoCue, which makes blood-testing equipment for doctors' offices. Also in early 2013, Danaher acquired Navman Wireless, a company that makes a tracking system for monitoring fleets of vehicles. Steven and his brother left their father's real estate firm in 1979 and started buying small manufacturing companies during the junk bond frenzy of the 1980s. The result was Equity Group Holdings. The brothers acquired a crippled REIT and fused it with other industrial companies to form Danaher. Steven chairs the board of the publicly traded company. The brothers took the industrial pump maker Colfax public in 2008. In January 2013 Colfax finalized a $2.4 billion deal to buy British welding, cutting and automation company Charter International. Steven is reportedly a supporter of the Washington Ballet and DePauw University. He also founded a film production company in Santa Monica, California, called Indian Paintbrush, which produced Wes Anderson's "The Darjeeling Limited," "Fantastic Mr. Fox," "Moonrise Kingdom" and "Seeking a Friend for the End of the World." In January 2013 "Breathe In," which Rales produced, premiered at the Sundance Film Festival.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Statistics wizard John Sall met partner James Goodnight at North Carolina State University. They co-founded SAS, the world's largest private software company, in 1976. Sall runs the dynamic data visualization division. The company reported 2012 revenues of $2.87 billion, as clients looked to business intelligence to solve problems and identify opportunities. The Cary, North Carolina-based firm is known for worker-friendly policies, including wellness programs, on-site child care centers and free snacks. With Goodnight, Sall owns the tony Prestonwood Country Club and the Umstead Hotel & Spa near Raleigh, North Carolina. The two co-founded local private school Cary Academy. Sall is a trustee at North Carolina State.
title: Co-Founder, Executive Vice President
employment: {'name': 'SAS Institute', 'title': 'Co-Founder, Executive Vice President', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Roger Wang chairs the Golden Eagle International Group, which in turn is the majority owner of Hong Kong-listed retailer Golden Eagle Retail Group. The company operates middle- to high-end malls in China, concentrated in the prosperous Jiangsu Province. Sales will increase to $3.1 billion this year from $2.6 billion last year helped by store expansion, according to a projection by Citibank. Wang was born in China, grew up in Taiwan and went to college at Chinese Culture University there before heading to graduate school in the United States. He got an MBA from Southern Louisiana University. After success in real estate, he chose Nanjing to set up Golden Eagle and pursue the career move that has turned him into a billionaire. Wang has his own real estate assets in addition to shares in his publicly traded retailer.

name: Billionaires
bio: It has been a hectic year for Abilio Diniz. In 2012 Casino Guichard-Perrachon SA, France's No.2 retailer, took control of Grupo Pão de Açúcar, which was founded in 1948 by Diniz's father, a Portuguese immigrant. The company began as a bakery and Abilio transformed it into Brazil's largest retailer. He remains Pao de Acucar's chairman but his relationship with Casino could not be worse. The new management slashed his personal security and travel expenses, which were reported to come to $15 million a year. He still wants to run a huge company and is negotiating to become chairman of the administrative board of Brasil Foods (BRF), a company with more than 120,000 employees that handles 20% of the global poultry trade. If Diniz gets a formal position at BRF, one of Pao de Acúçar largest suppliers, Casino has already made it clear that it will try to force him off Pao de Acucar's board. In 1989 he was kidnapped by Canadian terrorists who held him underground for seven days until the federal police set him free. He sticks to a regimen of multiple daily workouts, balanced meals and prayer. He is a fan of Sao Paulo Futebol Clube and is known for making harsh comments on Twitter when his club does performs poorly.

name: Billionaires
bio: Albert Frere built the family's scrap-metal business into a media, utilities and oil empire, Compagnie Nationale a Portefeuille (CNP). In May 2011 he and French bank BNP Paribas took CNP private. They paid more than $1.9 billion for the 28% of the company they didn't own. Frere now owns 70% of CNP. In July 2008 he helped push through the stalled mega-merger of CNP subsidiary Suez with French utility Gaz de France. The merged company, European energy giant GDF Suez, is one of the largest independent electricity suppliers in the world.

name: Billionaires
bio: Barry Lam chairs Quanta Computer, one of the world's largest manufacturers of notebook computers. His customers include HP, Apple and Amazon. Quanta's shares and Lam's wealth are unchaged from a year ago. Quanta is hoping for a pick-up in orders this year, especially from Apple and for shipments of datacenter products. According to a forecast by J.P. Morgan, notebooks will account for only 52% of Quanta's sales in 2013, down from an estimated 62% of the total last year, as the iPad and tablet computers cut into the one-time computing workhorse of business travelers on the go.

name: Billionaires
bio: Known as "Duvet Larsen" in Denmark, Lars Larsen is the founder and owner of JYSK, a home furnishing chain that sold more than $3.5 billion worth of furniture, bedding, mattresses and home décor in 2012. A competitor of IKEA, the cut-price furnishings chain is in the middle of a big international push, targeting China among other markets. JYSK averages two to three store openings each week and has stores in 34 countries. The company opened its 2,000th store in September 2012 in the Norwegian city of Leknes. Larsen grew up on a potato farm and apprenticed in a bedding store. He opened his first bedding warehouse in 1979. A consummate self-promoter, Larsen sent 2.4 million copies of his autobiography to every household in Denmark in 2004, making him the country's most widely-read author. Today he stars in his own TV commercials,

name: Billionaires
bio: Bernardo is one of three siblings who share a fortune that comes from forestry and paper products as well as stakes in telecom, banking and shipping firms. Each of the three--Bernardo, Patricia, and Eliodoro--has a different role. In January 2012 their family's CMPC, Chile's largest paper and pulp producer, announced plans to invest $2.5 billion in Brazil. Most of the investment is in the Guaiba celulose plant. Until May 2011, Eliodoro was president of five of Grupo CMPC's holdings; he stepped down that month but maintains leadership over Empresas CMPC, the primary holding company. Bernardo oversees the family's other assets including their stake in Banco Bice, of which he is president, and electric utility Colbun. Patricia, a sociologist, is on the board of Instituto Libertad y Desarrollo, a private think tank that analyzes public policy and economic and social issues. Following Eliodoro's leadership change, Bernardo Larrain Matte, Patricia's son; Jorge Matte Capdevila, Eliodoro's son; Juan Carlos Eyzaguirre, Patricia's son-in-law; and Andres Echeverria, another son-in-law of Patricia, took on new roles at various of the family's companies.

name: Billionaires
bio: Eliodoro Matte is one of three siblings who share a fortune that comes from forestry and paper products as well as stakes in telecom, banking and shipping firms. Each of the three--Bernardo, Patricia, and Eliodoro--has a different role. In January 2012 their family's CMPC, Chile's largest paper and pulp producer, announced it plans to invest $2.5 billion in Brazil. Most of the investment is in the Guaiba celulose plant. Until May 2011 Eliodoro was president of five of Grupo CMPC's holdings; he stepped down that month but maintains leadership over Empresas CMPC, the primary holding company. Bernardo oversees the family's other assets including their stake in Banco Bice, where he is president, and electric utility Colbun. Patricia, a sociologist, is on the board of Instituto Libertad y Desarrollo, a private think tank that analyzes public policy and economic and social issues. Following Eliodoro's leadership change, Bernardo Larrain Matte, Patricia's son; Jorge Matte Capdevila, Eliodoro's son; Juan Carlos Eyzaguirre, Patricia's son-in-law; and Andres Echeverria, another son-in-law of Patricia, took on new roles at various of the family's companies.

name: Billionaires
bio: Patricia is one of three siblings who share a fortune that comes from forestry and paper products as well as stakes in telecom, banking and shipping firms. Each of the three--Bernardo, Patricia, and Eliodoro--has a different role. In January 2012 their family's CMPC, Chile's largest paper and pulp producer, announced plans to invest $2.5 billion in Brazil. Most of the investment is in the Guaiba celulose plant. Until May 2011, Eliodoro was president of five of Grupo CMPC's holdings; he stepped down that month but maintains leadership over Empresas CMPC, the primary holding company. Bernardo oversees the family's other assets including their stake in Banco Bice, of which he is president, and electric utility Colbun. Patricia, a sociologist, is on the board of Instituto Libertad y Desarrollo, a private think tank that analyzes public policy and economic and social issues. Following Eliodoro's leadership change, Bernardo Larrain Matte, Patricia's son; Jorge Matte Capdevila, Eliodoro's son; Juan Carlos Eyzaguirre, Patricia's son-in-law; and Andres Echeverria, another son-in-law of Patricia, took on new roles at various of the family's companies.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ed Roski Jr.'s presides over the commercial and industrial real estate empire that is Majestic Realty. One of the largest privately-owned real estate companies, Majestic was founded by Roski's late father in 1948 and today maintains over 70 million square feet of industrial and commercial real estate from Los Angeles to Atlanta. Roski's net worth shoots up this year after FORBES learned of new information about his ownership stake in Majestic, which is completely family-owned. Roski helped build Staples Center in Los Angeles with fellow billionaire Philip Anschutz, but is currently engaged in a tussle with his former business partner over where the city will build a new football stadium to lure an NFL team. A University of Southern California alumnus, he and his wife pledged $23 million to his alma mater's fine arts school in 2006 and currently serves as chairman of the USC board of trustees. Roski is an avid cyclist and mountain climber and has climbed to base camp at Mt. Everest, K2 and Mt. Kilimanjaro.
title: President and Chairman
employment: {'name': 'Majestic Realty, Co.', 'title': 'President and Chairman', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Barry Sherman owns and runs privately held drug company Apotex, Canada's largest generic drug maker. Sales in 2012 topped $1 billion, largely unchanged from the previous year. Sherman earned a doctorate in rocket science at MIT before taking his mother's life savings and buying his uncle's drug company, which became the basis of Apotex, in 1974. He started with two employees. Today its 5,000 employees produce some 300 different generic drugs, making it the largest Canadian-owned pharmaceutical company. Much of Apotex's work is done in North American courtrooms where the company engages in legal battles in an effort to market cheaper, generic versions of brand-name drugs. Sherman is also involved in some legal troubles of his own. In 2007, his cousins sued him for a partial stake in Apotex, asserting that Sherman's firm is a successor company to the one the billionaire purchased from his uncle more than 40 years ago. That lawsuit has yet to go to trial.
title: Chairman and CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: Jeff Skoll has spent the past decade as a full time philanthropist and film producer. He is among the youngest billionaires who have given away $1 billion or more; he built his fortune via eBay shares; he was the company's first employee and first president. His Skoll Foundation backs a rigorously selected group of social entrepreneurs who are working to improve education, health care and other issues in some of the poorest parts of the world. His Skoll Global Threats Fund is tackling issues such as climate change and aims to eliminate pandemics. He spends about half his time on Participant Media, which makes films intended to inspire social change, such as Al Gore's 2006 Oscar-winning documentary on climate change, "An Inconvenient Truth." Another masterpiece was "Lincoln," an Oscar contender that Skoll co-produced. Other films include "Food Inc.," "Syriana" and "Waiting for Superman." His Capricorn Investments manages his money and the assets of the Skoll Foundation, and has stakes in Tesla Motors and SpaceX. (Skoll drives a red Tesla roadster.) Skoll, who was born in Montreal and later moved to Toronto, pumped gas to pay his way through the University of Toronto. He was named an Officer of the Order of Canada in December 2011 and obtained U.S. citizenship in 2007. In mid-2012 he moved with his girlfriend from Beverly Hills back to Silicon Valley.

name: Billionaires
bio: Maria Luisa Solari Falabella and her daughter Maria Cecilia Karlezi Solari join the Forbes Billionaires list thanks to their stake in SACI Falabella, Chile's largest retail company by market capitalization. Falabella started in 1889 when Maria Luisa's great grandfather opened the first large tailor shop in Chile. In the 1930s Alberto Solari, who was married to a grandchild of the original founder, joined the business, expanded it into women's clothing and housewares, and brought in members of his family to help it grow and to enjoy the financial rewards. Falabella has become a Latin powerhouse, employing more than 80,000 people in Colombia, Peru, Chile and Argentina. It is mainly controlled by the Solari family but members of the del Rio Goudie family also hold significant stakes. Maria Luisa tries to keep a low profile but in 2008, Chilean authorities fined her for trading on privileged information during a failed 2007 merger.

name: Billionaires
bio: New York real estate tycoon Sheldon Solow reached a deal in January 2013 to sell land overlooking the East River for a reported $200 million. Formerly owned by Consolidated Edison Inc., the plot is zoned for two apartment towers. Solow originally bought the parcel, plus another larger one, in 2005 for $630 million, when he was planning a seven-building, $4 billion project along New York City's East River. The project stalled because of a lawsuit between Solow and his business partner, the Fisher & Company real estate firm. That suit suit settled in 2010, and Solow put the smaller parcel up for sale. In May 2012, Citigroup won dismissal of a Solow lawsuit alleging that the firm committed securities fraud during the 2008 financial crisis. In early February 2013, Solow sued Citbank, B of A, JP Morgan, alleging that the banks colluded to manipulate the libor rate, which had an impact on his bond portfolio. The Brooklyn-born son of a bricklayer, he was a small-time builder when he risked everything on one Manhattan high-rise in 1972. That building is now the prestigious 9 West 57th Street, with tenants like KKR and Apollo Global Management. A serious art collector, Solow owns Boticelli's "Young Man Holding a Medallion," and paintings by Balthus, Matisse, and Kline, and sculptures by Giacometti. In February 2012 he sold a Francis Bacon painting for $33.5 million, a Joan Miro painting for $26.6 million, and a Henry Moore sculpture for $30.1 million. In February 2013 he sold Amedeo Modigliani's portrait of his mistress Jeanne Hebuterne for approximately $42.1 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Samuel Yin heads Taiwan's Ruentex Group, whose business interests include real estate, textile, finance and retailing.  Yin's fortune has increased from a year ago on a rise in the stock price of his main China retail investment, Hong Kong Stock Exchange-listed Sun Art Retail Group, which operated a total of 240 RT-Mart and Auchan hypermarkets in the country as of mid-2012. Yin is a stellar philanthropist. His Guanghua Education Foundation has funded scholarships for more than 100,000 students at mainland universities.  In January, Yin said he would set aside $100 million to create the Tang Prize as an international scholarly award to promote human development. It's named after China's Tang dynasty, a golden age of cosmopolitan cultural and political power in the country.

name: Billionaires
bio: Majid Al Futtaim is the estranged brother of billionaire Abdulla Al Futtaim. Non-family members run his eponymous holding company, which operates malls and supermarkets across the Middle East, including 48 Carrefour hypermarkets.The group has rebounded from a depressed real estate market and losses, raising his net worth by $2.5 billion. In 2012 earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization were up 7% on revenues of nearly $6 billion. The group, which is heavily invested in Egypt through its City Centre malls and Carrefour, is not backing away from the country's turmoil. It expects to start construction in Cairo on a Mall of Egypt in the first quarter of 2013. It also recently offered the billionaire Mansour brothers between $250 and $300 million to buy their supermarket chain Metro. The group is conducting due diligence.

name: Billionaires
bio: MIT grad Adi Godrej, heads the 116-year-old Godrej Group, a $3.8 billion (revenues) consumer goods conglomerate that makes everything from locks to refrigerators. Singapore's Temasek recently invested over $100 million for a 20% stake in Godrej Agrovet, an agri-business firm. Chocolate maker Hershey's bought out Godrej's 43% stake in their Indian joint venture. Son Pirojsha, a Columbia University grad, is chief executive of fast-expanding property arm Godrej Properties. His fortune is up due to rising value of family's biggest asset, a 3,500 acre estate in suburban Mumbai. Shares fortune with brother Nadir. His biography, published by Penguin, is being released this year. He's currently president of the Confederation of Indian Industry, an industry lobby group. Godrej got Ernst & Young's Entrepreneur Of The Year award for 2012.

name: Billionaires
bio: US-trained mechanical engineer Jamshyd Godrej, the third generation of the Godrej clan and a cousin of Adi Godrej, has a 40% share in the family fortune along with sister Smita Crishna. Fortune up on new information about his holding and rising value of family's estate in Mumbai. He has been running Godrej & Boyce, group's privately-held consumer durables arm, for over twenty years. Son Navroze, a graduate student at Chicago's Illinois Institute of Technology, sits on company's board.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former chambermaid and Johnson & Johnson heiress died in April 2013, following a "long and complicated illness," according to her family. After studying art history at Wroclaw University, "Basia" left Poland for the United States in 1968, landing a job as the chambermaid of Johnson & Johnson heir J. Seward Johnson and his wife Esther. By 1971 Johnson had divorced his wife and married Piasecka. Upon Johnson's death in 1983 Piasecka inherited the bulk of his fortune, including 18 million shares of Johnson & Johnson. She also got the couples' Princeton, New Jersey estate, Jasna Polana, which she later transformed into a country club with the manor house serving as club house and the grounds becoming a par-72 golf course designed by Gary Player. Piasecka was a noted art and antiques collector, with a particular interest in Baroque and Old Masters. In 2004 she sold the world's most expensive piece of furniture, the Badminton cabinet, to Prince Hans-Adam II of Liechtenstein for a record $36.7 million and in December 2009 sold a Rembrandt to Steve Wynn for $32.9 million. Wynn tried to sell the work for $47 million last year but found no takers. Piasecka was an active supporter of Art for Autism and funded philanthropic initiatives in her native Poland, where she resided at the time of her death.

name: Billionaires
bio: Paul Tudor Jones is founder of Tudor Investment Corporation, a $12 billion hedge fund firm. His flagship BVI Global fund, which runs the vast majority of the firm's assets, recorded a 6.3% net return in 2012. Tudor's relatively tiny Tensor fund, on the other hand, continued to struggle. After ending 2011 down 10.3%, the fund again failed to finish 2012 in the black, closing the year down 2.2%. Jones made his first fortune trading cotton on Wall Street before launching Tudor Investment Corporation in 1980. Having anticipated the 1987 market crash, he was able to triple his capital. An avid pheasant hunter and bass fisherman, the UVA grad owns property in the Florida Keys and in Tanzania. Jones founded New York City's iconic poverty-fighting Robin Hood Foundation in 1988. A favorite of many of Wall Street's elite, the organization has committed more than $1.25 billion to the cause.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Ronald Lauder, the younger son of Estee Lauder (d. 2004), serves as chairman of Clinique Laboratories, a unit of publicly traded cosmetics giant Estee Lauder. Ronald's daughter Jane was elected to the Estee Lauder board in 2010; his daughter Aerin is a senior vice president. He served as U.S. ambassador to Austria from 1986 to 1987 and deputy assistant secretary of defense for European & NATO affairs from 1983 to 1986. He has been president of the World Jewish Congress since June 2007. In 1987 he established the Ronald S. Lauder Foundation, dedicated to rebuilding Jewish communities in Central and Eastern Europe. Like his older brother, Leonard, he owns a vast art collection. In 2006 he bought a 1907 Klimt portrait for $135 million, at the time the largest sum ever spent on a single painting. On other occasions he has teamed up with New York financier Leon Black to buy art. His Neue Galerie, in New York, is a museum devoted to early twentieth-century German and Austrian art and design.

name: Billionaires
bio: Axel Oberwelland inherited German candy company Storck -- makers of Werther's Original, Riesen and Toffiffee brands -- when his father died in 2005. He is the fourth generation to run the family company, which also makes house-brand chocolates for German retailer Aldi (Aldi Sud is owned by billionaire Karl Albrecht). Storck does not disclose its revenues, but industry watchers estimate the company brought in $2.1 billion (1.6 billion Euros) in 2011, about the same as the previous year. Roughly half the company's sales are from outside Germany. Oberwelland's net worth has climbed $1.1 billion since last year due to an overall rise in the market value of the candy sector. The company established the Stork Foundation in 1992 to preserve Germany's endangered stork population.

name: Billionaires
bio: Zhang Xin, also known as Pan Marita, leads Soho China, Beijing's largest property developer, with her husband Pan Shiyi. The company reported a 65% drop in first-half net profit to $97 million as it completed fewer projects during the period. To reverse the profit drop, the company announced plans to move into a "build-and-hold" business model for its office and retail assets, meaning it will no longer sell prime commercial projects it develops in Beijing and Shanghai, citing the potential for asset appreciation and booming rents at key locations.
