Concerns over the transformation sent shares of Soho China down more than 8% in the two days after the announcement. Over the past year, shares have fallen about 15%, shaving $650 million from Zhang's net worth. Zhang and Pan founded Soho China in Beijing in 1995, and have continued to aggressively buy up real estate in Beijing and Shanghai, transforming the cities' skylines. Prior to founding Soho China, Zhang worked on Wall Street for Goldman Sachs and Travelers Group.
title: Cofounder, CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: Reclusive British tycoon Michael Ashely got a financial boost from the London Olympics. Britain's largest sporting retailer Sports Direct, in which he has a 71% stake, saw profit and shares jump in 2012 as a summer of sporting events inspired strong sales. Demise of arch rival JJB Sports probably helped too. The shrewd negotiator, who prefers casual dress, started his sports-clothing chain after leaving school in 1982 and was the sole owner until a 2007 IPO. At that time he sold a chunk of the company, personally pocketing $1.8 billion. Ashley bought Premier League soccer club Newcastle United right after becoming billionaire that year. He then tried unsuccessfully to sell it, twice, and upset fans by renaming its home stadium the Sports Direct Arena. He remains executive deputy chairman of the retailer.

name: Billionaires
bio: John Gandel's investments in listed property companies helped lift the Melbourne tycoon's net worth. He first got rich expanding his Polish immigrant parents' women's clothing chain, Sussan, but his real wealth came from the shopping malls he bought from Myer department stores for $37 million in the 1980s. He owns 50% of Chadstone, the largest shopping center in Australia, which has plans to add a $525 million hotel and office tower. He donates money to health care, the arts and Jewish education. He and wife Pauline collect Japanese art.

name: Billionaires
bio: The majority of Dan Gilbert's wealth comes from his privately held Quicken Loans, the nation's largest online lender, which saw explosive growth in 2012, closing $70 billion in loans, up from $30 billion in 2011. He also owns the Cleveland Cavaliers. His gaming business is taking off, with one new casino in Ohio, another in development and a recent deal to acquire Greektown Casino in Detroit. Meanwhile, he's behind many revitalization efforts in Detroit, where he has purchased more than a dozen office buildings and is trying to create a downtown tech hub. Gilbert has pledged $24 million to Children's National Medical Center in Washington, D.C. and $6 million to the Children's Tumor Foundation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Investor Jan Kulczyk's diversified portfolio continues to bring in generous returns. His 3.8% stake in beermaker SABMiller is up 25% over the past year; the largest piece of his fortune. He also has stakes in LSE-listed oil and gas exploration company Ophir Energy, with a predominantly African portfolio and Kulczyk Oil Ventures, with oil and gas assets with Brunei, Syria and Ukraine, and electricity producer, Polish Energy Partners. In 2011 he bought power plant Elektrocieplownia Nowa Sarzyna; now his Polenergia Holding is planning to construct two coal power units in Pelplin, the next step towards Poland's first private energy group. In November, Kulczyk also announced a mining venture with the Qatari government. He enjoys the high life, with a yacht, plane and homes in Florida, France and on a Mediterranean island.

name: Billionaires
bio: Tom Love and his wife Judy leased an abandoned filling station in Watonga, Oklahoma, in 1964 for $5,000, less than three years after they married, and named that first business Musket Corp. A few years later the company, eventually renamed Love's Travel Stops and Country Stores, opened its first convenience store. Today the company has more than 290 locations in 39 states and more than $22 billion in sales. Love's is still family-owned and operated: Tom Love is chairman and CEO; three of his four children work for the company.
organization: Love's Travel Stops and Country Stores
title: Chairman and CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: Najib Mikati, who became prime minister of Lebanon in January 2011, has been trying to steer the country on a neutral course, but the war in Syria threatens to engulf Lebanon. Billionaire Saad Hariri, a political opponent, called for Mikati's resignation in October 2012 after a car bomb killed the head of an intelligence unit. Mikati once entertained an open, friendly relationship with Syrian dictator Bashar al-Assad. He and his brother Taha established themselves as telecom operators in several African countries, as well as in Syria, through their company Investcom, before ultimately selling it to MTN Group of South Africa in 2006 for $3.6 billion in cash and stock. Najib's stake in MTN is still his most valuable asset, worth $1.9 billion, about $200 million more than a year ago.

name: Billionaires
bio: Taha Mikati founded Investcom with his brother, Lebanese Prime Minister Najib Mikati, during Lebanon's civil war in the 1980s, and later expanded into Africa. In 2006, they sold their stake to South African telecom powerhouse MTN Group, and remain the company's largest single shareholder through their holding company M1 Group. Taha Mikati is responsible for strategic decisions, while his son Azmi, a Columbia University engineering grad, runs the day-to-day business. M1 Group has investments in real estate, jet leasing, and apparel company Façonnable. Last year it bought a stake in U.K. supermarket chain J Sainsbury. The Mikatis have hired British architect Norman Foster to redesign their headquarters in Beirut.

name: Billionaires
bio: Two decades after he burst onto the political scene, Ross Perot is still best known as the billionaire who twice unsuccessfully campaigned to become president. But lately his focus is Hillwood, a massive nationwide real estate firm run by son H. Ross Perot, Jr. Hillwood's biggest project is the 18,000-acre AllianceTexas industrial park near Dallas, which includes homes, offices, a giant rail yard and its own airport. Hillwood also drills for oil and gas in Texas and Iraq. Perot fortune stems from Electronic Data Systems, which he founded a half century ago and sold to General Motors in 1984 for $2.5 billion. He then founded Perot Systems, and sold it to Dell in 2009 for $3.9 billion. A veterans' advocate, Perot Sr. was honored at the Army Heritage Center Foundation in July 2011 for donating to POWs' families, children of deceased soldiers and entertainment efforts for active troops through USO events.

name: Billionaires
bio: Lynn Schusterman is the widow of Oklahoma wildcatter Charles Schusterman (d. 2000) who built Samson Resources from nothing. In November 2011 the Schusterman family decided to sell most of Samson to a KKR-led group for $7.2 billion. Much of the windfall went to the Charles & Lynn Schusterman Foundation. The deal excluded deepwater Gulf of Mexico prospects like Buckskin and Moccasin that are in development now with Chevron. Lynn and daughter Stacy are dedicated givers to Jewish charities, including Birthright Israel as well as early-childhood education projects in Tulsa. Splits time between homes in Tulsa, New York and Jerusalem.

name: Billionaires
bio: Steven Udvar-Hazy's Air Lease Corp. is getting bigger and bigger by the day. In February, the firm, which leases planes to airlines, placed a $9 billion order for 39 new Airbus aircraft in a telling sign that's he is ready to compete head-on with Udvar-Hazy's former company, International Lease Finance Corp. (now owned by AIG). The godfather of the air leasing industry, Udvar-Hazy built up ILFC before selling it to AIG in 1990. He started Air Lease Corp. in 2010 and took it public in 2011, later facing a civil suit from AIG for stealing trade secrets. He moved to New York from Budapest, Hungary as a child. A certified jet pilot, he co-founded International Lease Finance Corp. after cobbling together deals with airlines while still a student at UCLA. After school, Udvar-Hazy started his own California commuter airline, but struggled to stay in the black. He said it was then that he realized that the money was to be made in leasing airplanes to airlines, not operating the airlines. He's given about $100 million to Stanford University, where his children went to college, and is also the namesake of the Smithsonian's National Air and Space Museum Steven F. Udvar-Hazy Center, to which he donated $66 million.
title: Director

name: Billionaires
bio: South Africa's third richest man, Christoeffel Wiese, is the chairman and the largest single shareholder of Africa's biggest retailer, low-priced supermarket chain Shoprite. He also owns a large stake in discount clothes, shoes and textiles chain Pepkor, where he is executive chairman. Wiese is significantly invested in seven publicly traded companies, and those stakes are worth approximately $500 million more than they were a year ago. In 2009 Wiese, known as Christo, found himself in an awkward situation when $1.1 million in cash was found in his luggage and confiscated at London City Airport. The cash was finally returned in July 2012, despite his insistence that the sum was "peanuts" to him. Wiese restored a South African farm estate and turned it into a five-star hotel, Lanzerac Manor & Winery. He replanted the vineyards around it, created a modern cellar and has been making wine. He also owns wine producer Lourensford Estate and a private game reserve in the Kalahari.

name: Billionaires
bio: Onetime metals trader Anil Agarwal controls London-listed, $14 billion (revenues), Vedanta Resources. Record production at oil explorer Cairn India, chaired by brother Navin, contributed to a 50% jump in Vedanta's net profits in the first half of 2012, offsetting setbacks elsewhere. A mining ban in Goa hit shares of its Indian unit, Sesa Goa, whose merger with group's Sterlite Industries is imminent. Agarwal is investing in Liberia. He's negotiating with the government to acquire the stakes in Hindustan Zinc and Bharat Aluminum that he doesn't already own.  In October, the company shut down its alumina refinery in eastern India due to a shortage of bauxite caused by the closure of its mine in 2011 after a storm of protests over the company's mining practices.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heinz-Georg Baus began as a carpenter, then founded German home-improvement chain Bauhaus AG with a single store in Manheim, Germany in 1960. He expanded into Austria in 1972 and today the private family-owned company has more than 190 stores in 16 European countries, with revenues estimated at $6.3 billion (4.75 billion Euros). More than half of the sales take place in Germany. Baus makes his debut on the Forbes World's Billionaires list this year. He is married and lives in Zug, Switzerland, where the head office of Bauhaus AG is located. He has one son, Bernd, who serves as a managing director at the company.

name: Billionaires
bio: Juan Coneo Solari joins the Forbes Billionaires list thanks to stakes he shares with his daughthers, Paola Cuneo Queirolo and Giorgianna Cuneo Queirolo, at SACI Falabella, Chile's largest retail company by market capitalization. Falabella started in 1889 as the first large tailor shop in Chile. In the 1930s Piero's uncle, Alberto Solari, joined Falabella, expanded it into women's clothing and housewares and brought in members of his family to help and to enjoy the financial rewards that came with stellar growth. Falabella has become a Latin powerhouse, employing more than 80,000 people in Colombia, Peru, Chile and Argentina.  Juan Coneo is the chairman of Falabella, which has announced plans for $3.92 billion in investments during the 2013-2017 period. He holds a degree in commerce and engineering sciences from Pontificia Universidad Catolica de Chile.

name: Billionaires
bio: Pauline Keinath is one of six secretive billionaire relatives who together still own a majority of Cargill, now the largest private company in the U.S., with $134 billion in revenues in fiscal year 2012 from all areas of food production, including crops, cattle, commodity trading, and risk management. She is great-granddaughter of founder W.W. Cargill, the son of a Scottish sea captain who started a small Iowa grain storage business after the Civil War. His son-in-law, John MacMillan, took control in 1909, and until 1995 the CEO was always a family member.

name: Billionaires
bio: Lin Yu-lin has thrived as one of Taipei's richest landlords. His Hung Tai Group owns Exchange Square I and II in the Taiwanese capital's prestigious Xinyi district. He also has space at the city's Hung Tai Financial Center and Hung Tai Center on offer. Lin is an investor in Hung Tai Construction and Hontai Life Insurance. His brother Lin Rong San is also a member of this year's Forbes Billionaires List.

name: Billionaires
bio: Richard Livingstone, a chartered surveyor, and his older brother Ian, a former optometrist, kicked off their business career together by opening optical stores and acquiring the David Clulow optical chain in 1992 (which they sold in 2011). Their main business these days is real estate, which they first entered in the late 1980s when they founded a property trading company. They now operate multiple property investment vehicles under the umbrella firm Loopsign Limited, with interests in the U.K., Germany, Russia, and Panama. In 2012 they got approval for a $930 million redevelopment of the Elizabeth House hotel near the Waterloo train station in Central London.  The firm's property in Panama, dubbed, Panama Pacifico, includes 250 acres of commercial development,  with hotels, shops, schools , parks and 20,000 homes located 15 minutes outside of Panama City.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sri Prakash Lohia made his fortune by producing a basic component used to make plastic bottles. Sri Prakash Lohia made his fortune producing a basic component used to make plastic bottles. His company, Indorama Ventures, is among the world's biggest suppliers of polyethylene terephthalate (PET) resin. Lohia chairs the company. In February 2012 Indorama bought  the U.S. chemical division of Old World Industries Inc. Indorama also has a highly profitable Nigerian unit. His son, Amit, runs the Indonesian and African businesses from Singapore, while his younger brother, Aloke, oversees the business from Thailand as its CEO. Lohia collects rare books and lithographs.

name: Billionaires
bio: In January China's e-commerce king Jack Ma made a surprise announcement to employees of his Alibaba empire, saying he will be retiring as CEO in May at age 48, declaring himself no longer young enough to run an Internet company. The timing was odd, with Alibaba widely anticipated to float its shares in a massive IPO later this year. Ma's fortune is up by $700 million since last year as the value of Alibaba Group jumped after the firm arranged to buy back the 40% stake of the company owned by Yahoo and delist shares of its B2B commerce site Alibaba.com from the Hong Kong stock exchange. The purchase valued Alibaba at $40 billion. An IPO is expected some time before 2015. The Alibaba Group's consumer shopping site, Taobao.com, is the 13th most popular website in the world. Ma's company, founded in 1999 with a score of business partners, employs 24,000 people in 70 cities.

name: Billionaires
bio: Whitney MacMillan is the great-grandson of founder W.W. Cargill, the son of a Scottish sea captain who started a small Iowa grain storage business after the Civil War. His son-in-law, John MacMillan, took control in 1909, and until 1995 the CEO was always a family member. The agro-giant is now the largest private company in the U.S., with $134 billion in revenues in fiscal year 2012 from all areas of food production, including crops, cattle, commodity trading, and risk management. Whitney is one of six secretive billionaire relatives who together still own a majority of Cargill. He was the last family member to run the company.

name: Billionaires
bio: Agro-giant Cargill is now the largest private company in the U.S., with $134 billion in revenues in fiscal year 2012 from all areas of food production, including crops, cattle, commodity trading, and risk management. Gwendolyn Meyer is the great-great-granddaughter of its founder, W.W. Cargill, the son of a Scottish sea captain who started a small Iowa grain storage business after the Civil War. His son-in-law, John MacMillan, took control in 1909, and until 1995 the CEO was always a family member. Gwendolyn is one of six secretive billionaire relatives who together still own a majority of Cargill. She is the only surviving child of Marion MacMillan Pictet, who died in 2009.

name: Billionaires
bio: Carlos Rodríguez-Pastor and his family fled Peru in 1968 after a political coup, because his father was an official of the Peruvian Central Bank. They settled in California where Carlos went to the University of California, Berkeley. He earned his MBA at Dartmouth and worked on Wall Street before his family returned to Peru. In 1994 his father bought Banco Internacional del Peru but died the following year. Carlos became head of the bank and invested bank profits in numerous other businesses. In 1998 he founded Nexus Group, a private equity firm based in Panama. In 2011 he started InRetail, a holding company that has supermarkets, malls and drugstore. In October 2012 InRetail went public and raised $400 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ferit Sahenk is chairman of his family-owned, Dogus Holding, which has interests in finance, media, tourism and construction companies. Last year, the group expanded into luxe restaurant chains including the purchase of a 74% stake in the Door's Group, which owns 18 brands such as Kitchenette, Gina and Da Mario, as well as a majority stake in restaurant chain Go Mongo. Under Sahenk's leadership the group is also building tourism in Croatia and Greece. But the family's main holding is Garanti Bank which is co-owend with GE Capital. In November 2010 the Spanish Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argenteria (BBVA) bought 6.3% of Garanti Bank from Dogus Holding for 2 billion dollars; the share transfer was made in May 2011. Ferit Sahenk's mother Deniz Sahenk and sister Filiz Sahenk are also billionaires. He is married to Diana Sahenk, an American.

name: Billionaires
bio: David Shaw's D.E. Shaw & Co. continued to beat the market and the competition in 2012. The firm's flagship Oculus fund closed the year up 18% net of fees, with the slightly smaller Composite International fund finishing just behind it at 15.6%. Shaw, a Stanford PhD, oversees higher-level decisions affecting the firm, but spends the bulk of his time leading D.E. Shaw Research, an independent laboratory he founded in 2002 to focus on computational biochemistry. Shaw was a Columbia University computer science professor until 1986, when he left to work at Morgan Stanley. Finding the environment too bureaucratic, he departed to launch D.E. Shaw & Co. in 1988. The firm, which made its mark employing mathematical computer-driven models, is known for being incredibly selective in its hires: only one in 500 applicants make the cut (Amazon founder and fellow billionaire Jeff Bezos is a former employee). Shaw was appointed to the President's Council of Advisers on Science and Technology by President Clinton in 1994, and again by President Obama in 2009. He has been a senior research fellow at Columbia since 2005 and is an Adjunct Professor of Biomedical Informatics at Columbia's medical school.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Teresa Matilde Solari Falabella joins the Forbes Billionaires list thanks to shares she owns in SACI Falabella, Chile's largest retail company by market capitalization. She owns the stake together with her two children, Juan Carlos Cortes Solari and Maria Francisca Cortes Solari, Falabella started in 1889 when Teresa Matilde's great grandfather opened the first large tailor shop in Chile. In the 193's Alberto Solari, married to a grandchild of the original founder, joined the business, expanded it into women's clothing and housewares, and brought in members of his family to both help it grow and to enjoy the financial rewards. Falabella has become a Latin powerhouse, employing more than 80,000 people in Colombia, Peru, Chile and Argentina. It is mainly controlled by the Solari family but members of the del Rio Goudie family also hold significant stakes.

name: Billionaires
bio: Andreas Strungmann and his twin brother, Thomas, created generic drug maker Hexal AG in the mid 1980s and two decades later sold it and their two-thirds stake in Eon Labs of the U.S. to Novartis for $7.5 billion. Since then the brothers have been investing primarily in the German biotech sector via their Santo Holding, with a focus on cancer research. In late 2005 Santo Holding acquired the majority of the anti-infectives division from Bayer, now called AiCuris; in October 2012 AiCuris struck a deal with Merck of the U.S., which acquired rights to develop and sell AiCuris' drug candidates. The twin brothers, who hail from South Africa, established a neuroscience research center in Frankfurt named after their father, Ernst Strungmann. Andreas is known to love sailing, golf and skiing.

name: Billionaires
bio: Thomas Strungmann and his twin, Andreas, are among Germany's most successful pharmaceutical entrepreneurs. The two founded generic drug maker Hexal AG in 1986, built it into Germany's second-largest generic drug maker and in 2005, they sold the business and their 68% stake in U.S.-based Eon Labs to Novartis for $7.5 billion. Since then they have invested more than $900 million (700 million Euros) in a swath of German biotech firms through their Santo Holding and Athos Service GmbH. The twins, who hail from South Africa, established a neuroscience research center in Frankfurt named after their father, Ernst Strungmann. Thomas is said to be the more extroverted of the two. He reportedly collects modern art and Swiss watches.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairul Tanjung's fortune comes from investments in the media industry through his conglomerate, CT Corporation. His Trans Corp Media owns news website Detik.com and two of Indonesia's top five TV stations. He also controls has investments in retail businesses, including Carrefour Indonesia and a number of luxury-brand franchises including Giorgio Armani, Jimmy Choo, and Valentino. A trained dentist who got his start selling study guides while in school, his first venture was a medical and dental equipment trading business he started in 1983. He chairs the Indonesia National Kidney Foundation and is a board member of the Indonesian Committee for Humanitarian Programs.

name: Billionaires
bio: After his lawyers produced documents in 2011 proving that Kamprad had irrevocably transferred the majority of his economic stake in global furniture retailer Ikea to entities beyond his economic control and benefit decades ago, later selling them the balance, his net worth took a drastic slide. But with the exception of his winery in Provence, Kamprad has historically shown little interest in the trappings of wealth anyway. He reportedly drives a Volvo 240 GL he has owned for over two decades. At age 86 his great love remains Ikea and the culture he built that made Ikea one of the world's most successful brands and retailers. Known for his relentless pursuit of efficiency, Kamprad introduced the flat-pack in 1953, moved production to Soviet Poland in 1961 to minimize labor costs and publishes the Furniture Dealer's Testament or the "Ikea Bible," which includes maxims such as "wasting resources is a mortal sin at Ikea." In October, Ernst & Young, hired by Ikea to investigate allegations made in a recent Swedish documentary, concluded that some Ikea products made in the communist German Democratic Republic we produced by political prisoners, eliciting an apology from Ikea. Kamprad currently has interests in banking, real estate, asset management and insurance; Ikea is one of the firm's biggest customers.

name: Billionaires
bio: Casino magnate Kirk Kerkorian is reportedly a bachelor again. He was engaged for a time last year to Joan Dangerfield, the widow of comedian Rodney Dangerfield, who set up a flash mob for him in celebration of his 95th birthday in June. Then three months later, he apparently got engaged to Lu Beard, a longtime friend and widow of an Oklahoma oil baron who died the previous year, but that relationship too has ended. The eighth grade dropout, ex- boxer and World War II fighter pilot trainer started his career in Las Vegas with a land purchase in 1962. He opened the original MGM hotel and casino after picking up the movie studio in 1969. Kerkorian stepped down as its chairman in 2011 to become the first director emeritus, and has since sold at least three-quarters of a billion worth of stock. These days Kerkorian heads Tracinda, his privately owned investment firm, and the Lincy Foundation, originally founded to aid victims of the 1989 Armenian earthquake; both organizations are named after his two daughters, Tracy and Linda.

name: Billionaires
bio: Shipping tycoon Spiro Latsis rebounded after taking a huge hit amid Greece's economic woes. Stocks of his EFG International, Lamda Development, and Hellenic Petroleum all jumped in 2012. He transferred approximately $300 million in stock in Eurobank, where he was the largest shareholder, to nine younger members of the Latsis family and to the John S. Latsis Public Benefit Foundation. He is a three-time graduate of the London School of Economics, having received a bachelor's degree in Economics in 1968, a master's degree in Logic and Scientific Method in 1970, and a doctorate in Philosophy in 1974. He sits on the board of Institute of Advanced Studies in Princeton.

name: Billionaires
bio: Media baron Kalanithi Maran's wealth got a boost as shares of Sun TV Network, a regional broadcasting powerhouse he founded in 1993, are up by more than a third since last year after falling in July amid reports that the Central Bureau of Investigation would be charging him and his politician brother Dayanidhi for their alleged involvement in a telecom deal linked to Malaysian billionaire Ananda Krishnan. They deny the allegations. He's pumping money into his budget airline SpiceJet which is benefiting from the closure of rival Kingfisher Airlines. It reported a $20 million profit in the latest quarter and is rumoured to be mulling stake sale to a foreign airline.  He snatched bid for a cricket team of the Indian Premier League, paying $80 million for five years.

name: Billionaires
bio: In 2012 Alexander Nesis  agreed to sell his stake in Nomos Bank to Otkrytiye, a financial firm, in exchange for cash and a stake in the combined company. In the 1990s Nesis got his start reinvesting profits from Central Asian uranium mining into other metals and shipbuilding. He created miner Polymetal, then in 1995 sold the company to Suleiman Kerimov, who is now a fellow billionaire. Three years later, in the midst of the financial crisis, Nesis bought back a stake at a rock-bottom price. He owns 19% of the company. His ICT Group controls a railroad car repair factory, a chemicals factory and land for housing developments.

name: Billionaires
bio: Christopher Reyes runs global food and beer distributor Reyes Holdings with his brother Jude. The company consists of Reyes Beverage Group (beer distributor), Martin-Brower (McDonald's distributor) and Reinhart Foodservice (food distributor). System-wide sales were $22 billion in 2012. Reyes Holdings got its start when the family purchased a small South Carolina beer distributor for $740,000 in 1976. They bought Chicago Beverage Systems three years later. The company is now the largest beer distributor in the U.S., delivering 95 million-plus cases a year. The company expanded into food distribution in 1998 with its purchase of Martin-Brower, McDonald's largest distributor of food and supplies. In 2004, Reyes added Reinhart Foodservice, one of the largest food distributors in the U.S. In 2012 the company bought Keystone Foods' distribution and logistics business from Brazilian food giant Marfrig. Chris is on the board of the Ronald McDonald House Charities, chairman of the board of the Ann & Robert H. Lurie Children's Hospital of Chicago and a trustee of the University of Notre Dame
title: Co-Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: With his brother Christopher Reyes, M. Jude Reyes co-chairs Reyes Holdings, the largest beer distributor in the U.S. It also owns the largest U.S. distributor to McDonald's, Martin-Brower, acquired in 1998; the outfit delivers burgers and fries to McDonald's outlets in the United States, Canada, Europe, Central America, South America, Asia Pacific, Latin America and Ireland. Another unit, Reinhart Foodservice, is one of the largest food service distributors in the U.S. In April 2012 Reyes Holdings purchased Keystone Foods' distribution and logistics business from Brazilian food giant Marfrig. The family-owned company --which had revenues about about $22 billion in 2012- has acquired more than 130 other firms since it was created in 1976. He is  a trustee at Northwestern University.
title: Co-Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Arkady Rotenberg is among the most influential businessmen in Russia. in part due to his relationship with president Vladimir Putin. He and his brother Boris (also a billionaire) were judo sparring partners with Putin and remained close ever since. Starting in 2008 the Rotenbergs began acquiring subsidiaries of Russia's national energy champion Gazprom and built them into Stroygazmontazh Corporation (or SGM Group), one of the biggest suppliers of steel pipe to Gazprom and a mjor construction contractors in the energy field. SGM recently acquired Gazprom-Bureniye, one of the biggest drilling companies in Russia. Rotenberg owns 51% of SGM, and holds a 26% stake in Mostotrest, a big road construction corporation that in January paid $258 million for the concession to a toll road from Moscow to Saint Petersburg. The brothers also controls SMP Bank. Arkady and Putin are longtime benefactors and leaders of Moscow's elite judo club Yawara-Neva. The both share a love for hockey, too. Rotenberg recently became the president of multi-championship-winning hockey club Dynamo Moscow, which in its early days decades ago was sponsored by the KGB.

name: Billionaires
bio: Keichiro Takahara is the chairman and founder of Unicharm, maker of diapers, sanitary napkins and other personal-care goods. His son, Takahisa, is its CEO, a position he's held since 2001. Because of Japan's aging population, the sale of adult diapers exceed that for babies for the first time in 2012. The company's stock price is up over the past year, thanks in part to robust sales particularly in China and India. It also has a successful joint venture with Sumitomo's US based pet business, Hartz. The company has pledged to bring affordable diapers and sanitary products to 36 million low-income women in the Middle East/North Africa and Asian regions as part of the Business Call to Action (BCTA), a global initiative to reduce poverty.

name: Billionaires
bio: Zhang Jindong founded and chairs Suning Appliance, China's largest retailer of electrical appliances. His wealth has declined from a year ago amid heated online competition from the likes of Amazon, 360buy and Yihaodian. Zhang told Forbes in an interview last September that he looks to make Suning more of a broadline merchandiser like Wal-Mart and Amazon by selling more everyday items. Toward that end, the company last year acquired Redbaby.com, a site that caters to the needs of toddlers. Net profit of Suning Appliance in 2012's first nine months dropped by 31.3% to $379 million, though sales increased 7% to $11.7 billion. Suning's overseas partners include Microsoft and Whirlpool. Zhang was 27 when he opened his first appliance store in late 1990 in historic Nanjing.

name: Billionaires
bio: Tamara Hughes Gustavson, the daughter of self-storage tycoon B. Wayne Hughes, is the largest single shareholder in Public Storage, owning nearly 11%, more than the rest of her family combined. She sits on the company's board, along with brother B. Wayne Hughes Jr. In 2010 her father told Forbes that he would be transferring his assets to his kids and grandchildren. In the past year as Public Storage shares climbed, the fortune of the Malibu mother of two grew by $500 million. A graduate of the University of Southern California graduate, she sits on the school's board of trustees and gives to causes including the HollyRod Foundation, which supports care for people who have autism and Parkinson's disease.

name: Billionaires
bio: Semahat Arsel is a member of the Board of Directors of Koc Holding, the family conglomerate and runs the group's investments in the tourism sector, including Setur Tourism and Divan Hotels. Because of a disease she suffered from when she was young, she made it her mission to support the nursing profession. She is still president of SANERC (Semahat Arsel Nursing Education & Research Center) which she founded in 1992. Arsel is also vice president of the Florence Nightingale Fund and founder of the Koc University Nursing Academy. Her brother Rahmi Koc and sister Suna Kýrac as well as her nephews Mustafa, Omer and Ali Koc are also billionaires.

name: Billionaires
bio: Two of Britain's richest and most private brothers, David and Frederick Barclay, emerged victorious in 2012 after waging battle over ownership of London hotel group Maybourne, owner of luxury landmarks Claridges, the Berkeley and the Connaught. The UK's High Court threw out a case brought by Irish developer Paddy McKillen, who claimed the two had acted unlawfully in buying up both equity in the group and debt in its parent company, sold cheap in the aftermath of the Celtic Tiger bust. The duo can now add the Maybourne hotels to their empire, which already includes the capital's exclusive Ritz and Cavendish hotels. The Barclays started together in the accounts department at General Electric and then flipped houses before buying their first hotel in 1975. Their business umbrella now includes the Telegraph Newspaper Group and U.K.'s largest online retailer, Shop Direct Group. The media-shy duo live together in a mansion on the isle of Brecqhou in the English Channel and have significant investments on neighboring Sark.

name: Billionaires
bio: Vladimir Bogdanov is often called the "Siberian hermit," because he rarely leaves the remote town of Surgut; he avoids public attention and the trappings of wealth entirely. A professional oil driller, he was appointed chief executive of Surgutneftegas when he was 33. In the early 1990s he and fellow managers privatized the company, which is famous for its thrift and avoiding expensive purchases. Only once in its history has the company tried to buy a serious asset abroad: In 2009 it acquired a 21.2% stake in Hungary's MOL, but it couldn't gain full control and sold the stake two years later. Thanks to its thrift Surgutneftegas sat on an amazing $30 billion in cash in 2012.

name: Billionaires
bio: Gustaf Douglas is a Swedish count who made his fortune in the security business. In 2011, he merged his personal holdings in Sakl AB with the largest source of his wealth, AB Latour, which has stakes in Assa Abloy, the world's largest producer of locks; Securitas AB, one of largest publicly traded security companies; and Fagerhult AB, a Swedish maker of light fixtures. Formerly on the board of Sweden's Moderate party, Douglas has now taken an interest in education policy. He is a member of the Royal Swedish Academy of Engineering Sciences. His wife Elisabeth née von Essen is also of noble descent.

name: Billionaires
bio: Temp agency entrepreneur Frits Goldschmeding founded Uitzendbureau Amstelveen in 1960 and changed the company's name to Randstad Holding four years later. He expanded his employment enterprise outside of the Netherlands, building 32 branches in four countries, including Belgium, Germany, and the UK by 1970. Golschmeding took Randstad public in 1990, then merged with Dutch group Vedior in 2008 to form the world's second-largest temp agency. Now truly retired, he still owns 35 percent of the company. Goldschmeding is also a professor at the Centre for Entrepreneurship of the Nyenrode Business University, and enjoys sailing in his free time.

name: Billionaires
bio: One of America's most successful entrepreneurs, Wyoming billionaire Robert Earl Holding, died on April 13 at age 86, apparently from age and complications related to a 2002 stroke. The son of mormons who lost everything in the 1929 Crash, Holding grew up very poor. He served in the Army Air Corps and later attended the University of Utah. After a time as a civil engineer for the Bureau of Reclamation, he moved his family to southwest Wyoming in 1952 to manage money losing motel-gas station in isolated Little America, Wyo.  He eventually bought out the other owners and started adding pumps. He later borrowed to buy the Mobil refinery in Casper Wyoming in 1968, and went on to purchase Sinclair Oil in 1976.  A year later he bought Sun Valley ski resort in Idaho, paying $12 million. At the time of his death, he was considered to be among the largest landowners in America with some 400,000 acres across the west. He owned the Grand America hotel in Salt Lake City, and the ski resorts  Snowbasin, Utah and Sun Valley.  Holding most recently ranked 139 among America's richest, with a net worth of $3.2 billion. He is survived by his wife of 64 years, Carol, and his three children including son Stephen who is considered to be his father's heir apparent.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heidi Horten inherited a fortune estimated at $1 billion in 1987 following the death of her husband, Helmut Horten, founder of German department store chain Horten AG. Helmut had sold his shares in the chain before he died. In the mid 1990s competitor Kaufhof took over and changed the names of the Horten stores. Heidi Horten divides her time between a penthouse in Vienna, a residence in Tessin, Switzerland, and a home in Lyford Cay in the Bahamas. She owns one of world's largest yachts, the 315-foot Carinthia VII. In 2008 she sold a 35.5 carat diamond, once part of the crown jewels of Bavaria, for $24 million, at Christie's. Horten is said to enjoy hunting and collecting art. She met Helmut in a hotel bar in 1959 when she was 19; he was 30 years older.

name: Billionaires
bio: In 1981, Fredrik Lundberg took over L.E. Lundbergforetagen AB, founded by his father Lars in 1944 as a construction company. It is now a diversified holding company with interests in property management and investments totaling nearly $6.6 billion (assets). New billionaire Carl Bennet, a Swedish Industrialist, has sat on his company's board since 2009. Daughters Louise and Katarina sit on the board as well, each with more than $350 million in stock to their names. Lundberg enjoys hunting and was once a junior curling world champion.

name: Billionaires
bio:
Dmitry Mazepin, an owner of the mineral fertilizer company Uralchem, has gotten involved in politics and now represents Vladimir Putin's United Russia party in the Kirov region's legislative assembly. A native of Minsk, he attended Minsk Suvorov Military School and in the late 1980s served as an interpreter in Afghanistan. He graduated from the Moscow State Institute of International Relations and until 2000 worked with the petrochemical companies TNK and Sibur. He also was a deputy chairman of the Russian Federal Property Fund.
In 2004 he founded his own company, which bought stock in chemical plants; he later merged these assets into Uralchem. Together with billionaire Oleg Derispaska he is a member of the supervisory board of the All-Russian Swimming Federation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Karen Pritzker inherited her billions from her Chicago-based Pritzker family, which counts 11 billionaires among its ranks. She is the granddaughter of A.N. Pritzker (d. 1986), who built industrial conglomerate Marmon and hotel chain Hyatt with his sons Jay (d. 1999), Donald (d. 1972) and Robert (d. 2011), Karen's father. With husband Michael Vlock, an investor, Karen has held onto her shares. She and Vlock invest in buy-and-hold stocks; their biggest holding other than Hyatt is in Apple. The couple also has a venture fund, LaunchCapital LLC, and stakes in a chain of grilled cheese restaurants and in a battery-operated surfboard/paddleboard-maker. They have made major donations to Yale, including a pledged $20 million to the School of Medicine. They've also pledged $5 million to Teach for America and donated $1.5 million to the Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research, in honor of Karen's father, who had Parkinson's. Karen also funds a new website, tina.org, that debunks misleading advertising.

name: Billionaires
bio: In 1969 Antonio Luiz Seabra founded Natura, a Brazilian version of Avon.The company sells products door-to-door in seven Latin American countries and France. Shares have risen in the past year, lifting Seabra's fortune by $300 million. Media-shy Seabra is reported to live in London. He communicates directly to Natura's employees through  motivational videos. He also cofounded Bresco, a Brazilian property-rental operation, with fellow Natura billionaire Guilherme Leal.
title: Entrepreneur

name: Billionaires
bio: Real estate mogul Jerry Speyer is the ultimate New York City power player, but much of the firm's recent activity is in China, Brazil and Europe. His Tishman Speyer is building its second condo tower in downtown San Francisco with Chinese partner Vanke. Speyer is also a seller in the hot Bay area, unloading three office complexes for $430 million that he bought for a reported $295 million in 2005. In mid-2012 the firm closed on a $188 million renminbi-denominated China real estate fund, the first foreign developer to do so in the country's currency. Speyer's net worth is up a bit since the 2012 Forbes 400 list thanks to the rise in value of his firm's most prized property, Rockefeller Center, co-owned with the family of Lester Crown. Tishman Speyer is very much a family business. Speyer started the firm with his late father-in-law Robert Tishman in 1978. Speyer's second wife Katherine Farley runs things in Brazil and China. Eldest son Rob is co-CEO and the clear heir apparent. Speyer is a major collector of contemporary art and a champion of new artists. He's been chairman of the board of the Museum of Modern Art since 2007 and his wife is chairman of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, to which they have given $21 million over the past decade. Speyer, who grew up in New York City, got his B.A. and M.B.A. from Columbia University, where he roomed with singer Art Garfunkel. A former yo-yo champion, Speyer wears a Mickey Mouse watch to work every day.

name: Billionaires
bio: Spielberg's latest, Lincoln, was nominated for 12 Academy Awards including Best Director marking the 7th time the director earned a nod. He didn't win, but no matter. Lincoln is a financial hit, earning $225 million and counting at the global box office on a budget of $65 million. His DreamWorks studio's TV work hasn't been doing as well. While Falling Skies is returning for a third season on FX, Smash on NBC has become one of the most vilified shows on network television while The River and Terra Nova were both canceled.
title: Director/Producer

name: Billionaires
bio: Another year, another 52 weeks of Donald Trump headlines. In 2012 he continued a long-running "will he, won't he?" game with the press, claiming to have seriously entertained the idea of running for president. He didn't, but loudly disputed President Obama's birth certificate while stumping for Mitt Romney. In 2013 he started some new celebrity feuds to add to his laundry list from the past, threatening to sue comedian Bill Maher following a joke about the mogul's own birth certificate, attacking young rapper Mac Miller for using his name in a song and sparring on Twitter with fellow billionaire Mark Cuban over everything from TV ratings to philanthropy. The Donald continues to collect prime real estate, most recently Miami's Doral golf and spa resort and Washington, D.C.'s Old Post Office building, which he's redeveloping as a luxury hotel. He's also still raking it in as a one-man brand: he was number 17 on Forbes' Celebrity 100 list in 2012, mostly thanks to the success of his Apprentice franchise. The Trump name can also be found on alcohol, neckties, high-end mattresses and, as of March, a fragrance collection for men called Success by Trump. His controversial $150 million golf course in Scotland opened for business in July 2012.
title: Entrepreneur, Personality

name: Billionaires
bio: Gautam Adani, owner of the largest port in India's private sector, saw his wealth fall by $2.3 billion as shares of his Adani Enterprises tumbled by 40% in the past year. His $7 billion (revenues) Adani Group, which is among the country's top power producers, also owns coal mines in Australia, Indonesia. To prune debt, it is selling its stake in an Australian coal terminal to Adani's family though price is yet to be determined. Losses also mounted at Adani Power, listed power unit, largely due to soaring coal costs. Group's port arm, where son Karan works, was reportedly among those denied security clearance to bid for certain ports. It has appealed to the government to review its case. In another setback, the government cancelled Adani's 4500-acre special economic zone citing alleged violations of certain rules.

name: Billionaires
bio: Abdulla Al Ghurair and his billionaire brother, Saif, are scions of a prominent UAE business family. Al Ghurair founded Mashreq in 1967, now a leading bank in the country. He remains chairman. His son Abdul Aziz is CEO. Another son, Sultan, is a board member. The bank was hurt by its exposure to bad real estate loans during the recession. Now it is cleaning up its balance sheet by cutting lending. In the first nine months of 2012 it reported a 28% increase in net profits. The family owns a conglomerate that has interests in food, construction and retail and in November 2012 hired a non-family member to run it. The new CEO has an MBA from Stanford University and ran Hewlett-Packard's business in the Middle East.
person: {'name': 'Abdulla bin Ahmad Al Ghurair & family', 'uri': 'abdulla-bin-ahmad-al-ghurair', 'imageExists': True, 'squareImage': '//specials-images.forbesimg.com/imageserve/5a988f2e4bbe6f0fa8271657/416x416.jpg?background=000000&cropX1=648&cropX2=1589&cropY1=256&cropY2=1197'}
personName: Abdulla bin Ahmad Al Ghurair & family
title: Athlete

name: Billionaires
bio: David Azrieli survived the Holocaust and has built a real estate empire that spans North America and Israel. He heads two companies: the Azrieli Group, which went public on the Tel Aviv Stock Exchange in 2010 and sported a recent $3 billion market capitalization, and Montreal-based Canpro Investments, which is privately held. In March 2012, the Azrieli Group began construction on the Sarona Tower, which, when completed, will be Israel's largest office building. Azrieli, an avid art collector, maintains a large Jewish art collection. His Azrieli Foundation supports initiatives ranging from education and medical research to Jewish appreciation and Holocaust commemoration. Azrieli's parents, brother and sister were killed during the Holocaust. He fled Poland in 1939 at age 17, traveled through Russia, Palestine, South Africa and England and eventually settled in Canada.
title: Chairman & Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Othman Benjelloun's father was a large shareholder in a small Moroccan insurance company. Othman took over in 1988 and built privately-held RMA Watanya into a leading insurer. He then expanded into banking. In 2010 his publicly-traded BMCE Bank bought a majority stake in Bank of Africa and now operates in more than a dozen African countries. BMCE shares tumbled in May 2012 as Benjelloun denied rumors that he was ill. In October 2012 Moodys downgraded shares in BMCA because of the increased credit risk that came with expansion into sub-Saharan Africa. His holding company, FinanceCom,also  has interests in telecom, airlines and information technology.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grocery store magnate Ron Burkle, head of Yucaipa Companies, took a significant hit when Yucaipa-backed ground beef processor, AFA--the company stuck in the "pink slime" controversy--filed for bankruptcy in April 2012. He primarily invests in private companies that support the food trade in areas like logistics, cold storage and food safety, but he's also backed technology ventures including Airbnb and Foursquare, as well as Relativity Media. Burkle also owns a stake in the NHL's Pittsburgh Penguins and was involved in negotiations to end the league's lockout in January. The son of a grocer, Burkle started working as a box boy at age 13. In 1986 he formed investment firm Yucaipa, and bought and sold supermarket chains Fred Meyer, Jurgensen's, Ralphs and others. He is the namesake behind the Burkle Center of International Relations at UCLA and gave the school $10 million in 2005.
title: Founder
employment: {'name': 'The Yucaipa Companies, LLC', 'title': 'Founder', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: The eldest son of Hyundai Motors chairman Chung Mong-Koo, Chung Eui-Sun is the vice president of the company. After getting a masters in business administration at the University of San Francisco, Chung worked at Japanese trading house Itochu's New York office before joining Hyundai Motors in 1994. He moved up the ranks and in 2005 became president of Kia Motors, which is also controlled by the Chung family. He is credited with the successful launch of small family car Kia Cee'd in Europe, as well as the Soul and the Forte. In 2009 he was promoted to his current position as vice president of Hyundai Motors. The bulk of his fortune comes from Hyundai Glovis, the conglomerate's fast-growing logistics arm, where he is the largest individual shareholder.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cable television mogul Charles Dolan's family didn't please a lot of sports fans in 2012. Madison Square Garden, run by his son James, let New York Knicks sensation Jeremy Lin slip away. Before that, MSG had a 48-day standoff with its rival Time Warner Cable that kept 2 million customers from watching Lin. However, MSG reported strong earnings of $46.9 million for the quarter that ended Dec. 31, 2012, up 83% from a year earlier, through higher ad revenues and lower expenses. Dolan got his start editing sports reels and sending them out to TV stations. He started the network that would become HBO in 1965 and traded it to Time Inc. in 1973 for the Long Island cable company that became Cablevision. He is now chairman of both Cablevision and AMC. In 1998 he and his son founded the Lustgarten Foundation, in memory of a Cablevision executive who died of pancreatic cancer. It has donated more than $65 million to fund pancreatic cancer research. In 2000 he donated $25 million to Fairfield University, home to the Charles F. Dolan School of Business.
title: Chairman and Founder
employment: {'name': 'Cablevision Systems Corp.', 'title': 'Chairman and Founder', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Guenther Fielmann is Germany's optician billionaire. He opened his first optometry shop in Cuxhaven, Germany in 1972. Today, Fielmann AG sells nearly half the prescription eyeglasses in Germany, and also has outlets in Austria and Switzerland. Fielmann took the company public in 1994 and still serves as chief executive officer. He and his children together own 71% of the company's shares, which have risen in value, pushing up Fielmann's net worth by $500 million dollars over the past year. Fielmann reportedly wants his son, Marc, 23, to take over the company someday. He is a committed environmentalist and grows a tree for every employee each year, and also owns an organic farm.

name: Billionaires
bio: He Xiangjian is co-founder of Midea Group, one of China's biggest appliance manufacturers. Shares in its main business, GD Midea, have been suspended since Aug. 27, in connection with the merger of unlisted businesses with Shenzhen-listed GD Midea. The listed operation has struggled to increase its profits. Net income for first nine months of 2012 rose 4.2% to $484 million, though revenue dropped by 34% to $8.7 billion. GD Midea said on Jan. 28 its shares will resume trading by the end of March. Midea Group also controls Hong Kong-listed Welling Holding. Its Midea Real Estate has development projects in seven domestic cities, according to the company's website. Midea's foreign business partners include Carrier, a unit of United Technologies.
title: Founder
employment: {'name': 'Midea Group Co. Ltd.', 'title': 'Founder', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Antti Herlin, Finland's only billionaire, amassed his fortune via the $8.4 billion (sales) KONE Corporation, a Finnish elevator and escalator manufacturer and installation and maintenance firm. His net worth jumped by $1.1 billion in the past year after KONE's record 2012 earnings, 50% of which came from new equipment orders, primarily in the Asia-Pacific region. Herlin's grandfather founded the company in 1924. After being appointed deputy chairman and CEO in 1996, Antti expanded operations through a series of acquisitions, alliances and technological advancements. He stepped down as CEO in 2006. He has been chairman since 2003, the year his father Pekka died. He is also the chairman of Security Trading Oy, and sits on the board of Finnish construction firm YIT. He received the Nordic 2012 Chair of the Year award,an honor given to the best chairman of a publicly listed company in the region.

name: Billionaires
bio: Reid Hoffman, arguably the most connected man in Silicon Valley, is cofounder and chairman of Silicon Valley's best-performing social networking company, LinkedIn. In February, the LinkedIn's shares were up more than 80% year-over-year after the Mountain View, Calif.-based company  beat analysts' estimates for the seventh quarter in a row. A influential angel investor and partner at venture capital firm Greylock Partners, Hoffman doubles as a savvy investor. He made a $40,000 investment in Facebook in 2004 and was an early investor in Zynga. At Greylock, he has led the firm's investments in Groupon and Airbnb. He sits on the boards of several nonprofits including Kiva, which seeks to combat poverty through microfinance. Hoffman belongs to the so-called "PayPal" mafia and was one of the first employees at the payment business that was later sold to eBay.  Prior to joining PayPal in 1998, Hoffman was the founder of (failed) online dating site Socialnet, which some regard as the first online social network.
title: Partner

name: Billionaires
bio: Nathan Kirsh debuts on the Forbes list of billionaires this year after decades of quietly investing in a diverse set of businesses. He made his first fortune in his native Swaziland, founding a corn milling business in the country in 1958. He expanded into wholesale food distribution in apartheid South Africa, and then into a variety of other categories, including supermarkets and commercial property development. But South African insurance company Sanlam bought up 49% of the company, and entered into agreements on the company's behalf to build a slew of financially unviable shopping malls -- backed by company assets. Suddenly, Kirsh was broke. The bulk of his current fortune comes from Jetro Holdings, which operates Jetro Cash and Carry stores and Restaurant Depots in the New York City area -- supplying wholesale goods to bodegas, small stores and restaurants. Kirsh told FORBES that Jetro has a near monopoly on the business of providing small stores in the New York City area -- other wholesalers don't deem them worth the time. Kirsh's charitable endeavors are focused on Swaziland, where he has supplied more than 10,000 people with starter capital for small businesses. He says 70% of those individuals are women and the program has a 70% success rate. He is also working to make Swazi high schools the first in Africa to guarantee graduates are computer literate.

name: Billionaires
bio: Lampert purchased a Miami Beach home in March 2012 for a reported $38.4 million and moved his hedge fund, ESL Investments, to Florida. ESL's former CFO, Adrian Maizey, remained in Connecticut, where he now runs Rand Group, which provides investment research, operational and technical services to ESL and is staffed largely with former ESL employees. Lampert is a lawyer's son who read corporate reports and financial textbooks in high school before heading to Yale, where he was a member of Skull & Bones. After graduating, he learned alongside billionaire investor Daniel Och in the risk arbitrage department at Goldman Sachs. In 1988, Lampert went solo and later acquired Kmart in bankruptcy by buying its bonds. He then merged Kmart with Sears Roebuck and Co. and has served as chairman of the combined company since 2005. Lampert added CEO to his title in early 2013 after Louis D'Ambrosio announced his resignation in January.

name: Billionaires
bio: Lu Guanqiu chairs the Hangzhou-based Wanxiang Group, a conglomerate with interests in real estate, finance and auto parts manufacturing. Wanxiang survived U.S. political sniping and a bidding war in its successful $256 million acquisition of the bankrupt lithium-ion car-battery maker A123 Systems in Michigan, perhaps because Wanxiang is already an established U.S. manufacturer with more than 3,000 employees stateside. Its other auto businesses include China-listed parts maker Wanxiang Qianchao and Jiangsu Senwei, whose customers incude Bosch. The Wanxiang-backed real estate developer Shunfa Hengye had a good year, with net profit in the first nine months of 2012 up 97% to $60.6 million. Lu was born into a peasant family, apprenticed as an ironsmith and made it through the Cultural Revolution by acquiring scrap steel from villages to fabricate farming tools. He started Wanxiang in 1969 with $500 in capital. The company now employs 40,000 and grossed $16 billion in the first 11 months of 2012.

name: Billionaires
bio: In the fall of 2012 Home Depot co-founder Bernard Marcus and fellow Atlanta conservative Herman Cain hit the road for a 30-day, 30-city "Truth Tour 2012," where the two businessmen shared their vision on job creation and the American dream. In October 2012, Marcus appeared in an anti-Obama television ad released by the Republican Jewish Coalitio. Back in 1978 he started the world's largest home improvement retailer with fellow billionaire Arthur Blank, then took it public in 1981. Home Depot's stock has surged in the past year, driving up Marcus' fortune by $800 million. He retired in 2001 to focus on philanthropy through his Marcus Foundation and has signed on to the Giving Pledge, promising to give away at least half his wealth to charity. In 2003 Marcus pledged $250 million to open the Georgia Aquarium, the world's largest. He also started the Marcus Autism Center in Atlanta in 2008.
title: Co-founder, ex chairman of the board
employment: {'name': 'Home Depot', 'uri': 'companies/home-depot', 'title': 'Co-founder, ex chairman of the board', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Alain Merieux is the chairman of Institut Merieux. The institute's numerous public health and medicine subsidiaries specialize in diagnostics, immunotherapy and nutrition. Alain's father Marcel Merieux was a laboratory aide to Louis Pasteur. He founded the Institut Merieux, now a $2.2 billion (sales) medicine and public health conglomerate, in 1897. In 1963, Alain founded BioMerieux, a $2 billion (sales) subsidiary which specializes in diagnostics that test for infectious diseases such as HIV and tuberculosis. In 1967 Marcel established Fondation Merieux to combat infectious diseases in developing countries. After becoming an industry leader in human and veterinary vaccines, Institut Merieux made a series of acquisitions and has since formed Merieux Nutrisciences to address food supply issues. The firm also launched Merieux Developpement as a healthcare investment vehicle. Rodolphe Merieux, Alain's oldest son, was killed in 1996 at age 27 when TWA Flight 800 crashed on Long Island. In 2001, Fondation Rodolphe Merieux was established to conduct research and training in developing countries in collaboration with Fondation Merieux. Alain's second son, Christophe, who was expected to take over the family business, died of cardiac failure in 2006 at age 39. In 2007, Fondation Rodolphe Merieux was renamed Fondation Christophe et Rodolphe Merieux. Alain's third son Alexandre is on the board of Institut Merieux. Over the last three years, the firm has dedicated $820 million to R&D in an effort to develop vaccines for future diseases prevention.

name: Billionaires
bio: Husnu Ozyegin is the owner of Fiba and Fina Holdings which invest in finance, retail, real estate, energy, ship construction and port services. The financial investments are gathered within Fiba, the non-financial investments within Fina Holding. Last year, he opened his first foray in China, the $200 million Star Mall Shenyang Plaza, and plans to continue to build there with ten shopping malls on the drawing board. Ozyegin expects to invest over a billion dollars in the energy sector by 2015. Last year, the first graduating class of his Ozyegin University got their diplomas.

name: Billionaires
bio: Clayton Riddell started with near-barren natural gas wells when he founded Paramount Resources in 1974. Since then, he's built a natural resources empire, spinning off several successful energy companies in the process. He currently owns stakes in at least 10 publicly traded energy companies, with Paramount remaining one of his largest holdings. He is also a minority owner of the National Hockey League's Calgary Flames. In 2012, Riddell was embroiled in an academic scandal after it was revealed that he had a donor agreement with Carleton University in Ottawa, Canada, that allowed him to have final say over hiring for certain positions in the school of political management. In August, Carleton revealed that it had rewritten this agreement, removing Riddell, who had pledged $15 million to the school, from the decision-making process.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Paramount Resources Ltd.', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Haim Saban made his mark by transforming a Japanese TV program, Mighty Morphin Power Rangers, into a global brand that has kept the cash tills ringing. He continues to build his fortune in media. His Saban Capital Group bought a 7.5% stake in Indonesia's largest TV and radio media group, Media Nusantara Citra, in October 2011 for about $110 million; the stake has more than doubled in value since then. Saban's largest holding -worth about $500 million-- is his slice of Spanish language broadcaster Univision, which he and a group of private equity firms bought for $13.7 billion in 2007; he serves as the chairman. His Saban Brands owns and manages the Power Rangers brand as well as that of Paul Frank, known for its monkey, Julius. Saban sold Fox Family Channel, a joint venture with News Corp. to Disney in 2001 for $5 billion; Saban's take was $1.7 billion. A longtime Democratic donor and friend of Bill Clinton, he and his wife, Cheryl, have donated nearly $47 million to Children's Hospital Los Angeles, $11 million to the Saban Free Clinic (formerly the Los Angeles Free Clinic) and just over $15 million to the Soroka Medical Center in Israel.

name: Billionaires
bio: Piero Solari Donaggio joins the Forbes Billionaires list thanks to his stake in SACI Falabella, Chile's largest retail company by market capitalization. Falabella started in 1889 as the first large tailor shop in Chile. In the 1930s Piero's uncle, Alberto Solari,  joined Falabella, expanded it into women's clothing and housewares and brought in members of his family to help and to enjoy the financial rewards that came with stellar growth. Falabella has become a Latin powerhouse, employing more than 80,000 people in Colombia, Peru, Chile and Argentina. It has announced plans to make $3.92 billion in investments during the 2013-2017 period. Piero's shares his stake with his two brothers Carlo Solari Donnagio, vice chairman of the company, and Sandro Solari Donnagio, Falabella's chief executive officer.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ulker Murat is the chairman of Turkey's largest food producer, Yildiz Holding, which makes everything from biscuits, chocolate, milk to baby food and packaging. The group also has interests in finance, packaging, real estate, whole sale commerce and personal grooming. Ulker Biscuit which is the Group's largest publicly traded company streamlined operations this year, leading to a 100% increase in the companies stock price. Murat's sister Ahsen Ozokur is also a billionaire. Murat Ulker's father and the founder of the company, Sabri Ulker, died June 2012.

name: Billionaires
bio: Riley Bechtel is the fourth-generation CEO and chairman of San Francisco-based engineering and construction giant Bechtel Corp. He worked his way up through the company, beginning as a contract coordinator and later piping superintendent at its Belle River Power Plant in Michigan. He worked in Indonesia, New Zealand and London before becoming CEO in 1990. He and his father Stephen Bechtel, Jr., are each believed to own 20% of the company, which builds roads and rail systems, airport and ports, liquefied natural gas processing plants and copper smelters. Notable projects include the Hoover Dam, the Channel Tunnel and, more recently, reconstruction work in Iraq. He is reportedly a member of San Francisco's exclusive all-male Bohemian Club, whose fellows are thought to include every Republican President since Herbert Hoover. He sits on the governing board of the Indian School of Business and is a member of the Chancellor's Board of Advisors at the University of California at Davis, his alma mater.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Bechtel Corp.', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Stephen Bechtel, Jr. ran his family's giant engineering and construction firm, Bechtel Corp., until his retirement as chairman in 1990. Signature projects include the Hoover Dam, the Tacoma Narrows Bridge and the Bay Area Rapid Transit (BART) system. Stephen became Bechtel president at age 35 in1960 and chairman 13 years later. His son Riley, also a billionaire, now runs the company. Stephen is believed to own 20% of the privately held company. He is reportedly a member of San Francisco's exclusive all-male Bohemian Club, whose fellows are thought to include every Republican President since Herbert Hoover. His foundation donated $50 million to the Boy Scouts of America in 2009 to help create a 10,600-acre reserve in West Virginia.
title: Former Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: John Catsimatidis is out to follow in the footsteps of Mike Bloomberg and become the next billionaire mayor of New York. In January the grocery and oil billionaire announced his candidacy on the city's Republican ticket, running on a pro-business agenda which includes bringing the World's Fair back to New York City. The son of Greek immigrants turned a single grocery store into the Red Apple Group empire that controls New York's Gristedes supermarkets and most of the valuable real estate the shops sit on. His energy investments include hundreds of gas stations and the Pennsylvania-based United Refining Company.

name: Billionaires
bio: As a cofounder and co-CEO of private equity firm the Carlyle Group, William Conway appeared in Carlyle's first-ever Podcast, released in February 2013. He discussed the firm's investment outlook for the year, noting a near-bottom in the European market and looming interest rate increases domestically. His opinion has changed dramatically from 2012, when he cited historically low interest rates and the willingness of institutions to lend money to explain why Carlyle was so active. In 2012 the firm realized $18.7 billion in proceeds from 197 investments across 32 fund vehicles. Conway went to Dartmouth College and the U. of Chicago graduate school before beginning a near-decade-long stint at the First National Bank of Chicago. He cofounded Carlyle in 1987 with fellow billionaires David Rubenstein and Daniel D'Aniello. The firm leveraged ties to politically connected advisers, including former President George H.W. Bush and former British Prime Minister John Major, to buy defense businesses, fix them up and sell at a profit. Today Carlyle has $157 billion in assets under management across 101 funds and 64 funds of funds. The firm went public in May of 2012 and was up more than 50% as of mid-February 2013. Like his partners, Conway donates to many charities in the D.C. area where Carlyle is headquartered, including a recent $5 million pledge to the Capital Area Food Bank.
title: Co-Chief Executive Officer and Co-founder
employment: {'name': 'Carlyle Group', 'title': 'Co-Chief Executive Officer and Co-founder', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Daniel D'Aniello amassed his fortune at the helm of the Carlyle Group, where he holds the titles of chairman and cofounder while also running the day-to-day operations. He grew up in Butler, Pennsylvania, where he bagged groceries and lived with his mother, who was an insurance claims agent. After graduating from Syracuse University and getting his M.B.A. at Harvard Business School, he worked at TWA and PepsiCo before becoming the vice president for finance and development at Mariott. In 1987 he cofounded Carlyle with fellow billionaires William Conway and David Rubenstein. The firm leveraged ties to politically connected advisers, including former President George H.W. Bush and former British Prime Minister John Major, to buy defense businesses, fix them up and sell at a profit. In May 2012 Carlyle went public and was up more than 50% by mid-February 2013. The firm has $157 billion in assets under management across 165 investment vehicles. In August 2012, it bought Getty Images for $3.3 billion. D'Aniello is also an active donor, giving mainly to educational institutions including his alma mater, Syracuse.

name: Billionaires
bio: William Ding, also known as Ding Lei, is the master of online games in China as the 45% owner and cofounder of Netease. Its Nasdaq-listed shares have roared back from their lows in 2012, even as its growth slowed from prior years. In 2012, Netease revenue was up 12.1%  to $1.3 billion. Profits were $137 million, well ahead of investor expectations. It saw growth in both online games, with the much-awaited launch in China of Blizzard Entertainment's smash hit World of Warcraft, as well as new games Kung Fu Master, Soul of the Fighter and Heroes of Tang Dynasty II. Using games as its hook, NetEase also hosts news, e-mail, search, microblogging and other services on its portal, 163.com, which ranks among China's top ten most visited websites. Not content with being a videogame billionaire, Ding has begun to explore organic farming. His wants to lure back some of the hundreds of millions of rural peasants who have fled their inefficient fields for China's factory towns, setting up financial incentives for them to produce quality food for decent wages so that capital flows into the countryside.

name: Billionaires
bio: Archie Aldis "Red" Emmerson's Sierra Pacific Industries owns more than 2 million acres of forest in California and Washington. He began the lumber producer with is father in 1949, took it public in 1969, and went private again four years later. In 1988 he bought 522,000 acres from Santa Fe Southern Pacific Railroad with a $460 million loan.

name: Billionaires
bio: His Millennium Partners hedge fund finished 2012 up 6.4% net of fees. Englander founded Millennium in 1990 with $35 million in capital. Today the firm runs $17.8 billion. A hedge fund purist, "Izzy" doesn't charge a fixed management fee. Rather he simply passes expenses through to his investors, earning fees only in years that he makes them money. A Brooklyn native, Englander earned a B.S. in finance at NYU before dropping out of the university's MBA program to work full-time on Wall Street as a trader and floor broker at the American Stock Exchange. Englander serves on the board of Weill Cornell Medical College and the Metropolitan Council on Jewish Poverty. His sister was married to famed investor Jack Nash (d. 2008).
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Mikhail Gutseriev, through his BIN Group, has been buying up real estate. In 2012 he purchased two five-star hotels in the center of Moscow, the Summit and the Lux, from Bidzina Ivanishvili, the billionaire prime minister of Georgia. Before that he purchased Moscow's famous National Hotel from Elena Baturina, Russia's richest woman. In 2011 he established the fertilizer producer Slavkaly, in Belarus. He heads the oil company Russneft and owns 49% of its shares; another 49% are controlled by billionaire Vladimir Yevtushenkov's AFK Sistema. At the end of 2006 Gutseriev was accused of violating terms of his oil license and failing to pay taxes. He denied the charges, sold Russneft to billionaire Oleg Deripaska for $2.8 billion, and moved to London. Then in 2010 all the charges were dropped; Gutseriev returned to Russia and reclaimed his company. Born in Kazakhstan, into a family deported from Ingushetia after World War II, he became the president of the state oil company Slavneft but was dismissed in 2002, before privatization. Over a four-year period he bought a number of small Russian oil companies, with the help of the Swiss firm Glencore, and he combined them to form Russneft. Yevtushenkov negotiated the deal, and his AFK Sistema got a 49% stake. Gutseriev writes lyrics for songs that are performed by famous Russian singers. In 2012 and 2013 he bought several Russian radio stations.

name: Billionaires
bio: Otto Happel turned his father's dust removal business into thermal engineering firm GEA. In 1999, he sold GEA to Germany's MG Technologies for $1 billion in cash and kept a 21% interest in the combined group. In 2005 the company renamed itself the GEA Group. Happel cashed out in 2006, selling his remaining stake to institutional investors for approximately $630 million. An enthusiastic sailor, he has a yacht named Hetairos and lives in Switzerland with his wife and six children. He also owns a luxury resort, Fregate Island, in the Seychelles. A foundation in his name supports development projects in the developing world.

name: Billionaires
bio: Before he teamed up with fellow Azerbaijani God Nisanov, Zarakh Iliev moved  to Moscow and started selling alcohol. Once he threw in with Nisanov, they built shopping markets near metro stations, and these grew into larger retail complexes. Today they own the Radisson Royal Ukraine Hotel, European Shopping Center and Radisson SAS Slavyanskaya Hotel in Moscow, as well as several big shopping centers in Moscow's outskirts, where wholesalers from all over Russia come to buy goods. Lots of other hotel projects are in the works. Also on the drawing board: two oceanariums in Russia, one of which, the biggest in Eastern Europe, will be located in historical part of Moscow at VDNKh, the giant exhibition center.AM I RIGHT??

name: Billionaires
bio: Herbert Kohler, Jr., is the third-generation head of Kohler Co. a company founded by his grandfather in 1873. Herb has been chairman and CEO of Kohler since 1972. He and his sister Ruth own a majority stake. Best known for sinks, showers, toilets and faucets, the company also sells furniture, tile, engines, and generators. The company owns two golf resorts in Kohler, Wis., and the Old Course Hotel in St. Andrews, Scotland. One of its golf resorts, Whistling Straights, located on Lake Michigan, will host the 2015 PGA Championship. Herb breeds Morgan show horses.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Kohler Co.', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Lev Kvetnoi is the largest shareholder in Moscow's Vnukovo Airport. He also holds shares in a number of airport services companies, including an airplane repair factory, and he owns cement businesses which in 2011 he expanded by acquiring one of billionaire Elena Baturina's factories in southern Russia. For a time he served as chief executive of a company in billionaire Alisher Usmanov's metals group, but he sold out his interests to Usmanov in 2006, and the next year he bought both National Standard Bank and NovorossCement, Russia's third-largest cement producer. In 2012 he sold a piece of a fuel-supply business at Vnukovo Airport to state-owned Rosneft for $525 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: James Leprino is the chairman and owner of privately-held  Leprino Foods, the world's largest mozzarella cheese producer. Headquartered in Denver, Colorado, Leprino supplies cheese to brands such as Domino's, Papa John's, Pizza Hut and Hot Pockets. Founded by Leprino's father, Mike Sr., in the 1950s, when he began making homemade mozzarella and ricotta for local stores. Today the company has estimated sales of $2.7 billion. In addition to cheese, the company sells its by-products such as whey-protein, lactose and sweet whey powder used in infant formula and yogurt. Its newest plant opened in Greeley, Colorado, in 2011 and will eventually process 7 million pounds of milk per day into 700,000 pounds of cheese.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Sergio Mantegazza's father Antonio founded tour outfit Globus in 1928 with a single boat that ferried tourists around Lake Lugano. Today Mantegazza controls the family's tour and travel empire. Half of his wealth is tied up in low-risk bonds. His Monarch Airlines has been expanding routes; for the fiscal year ending October 2012, passenger traffic was up 15.7% and revenue per seat was up 9%. Tina Turner holidayed on his "Lady Marina" yacht last summer.

name: Billionaires
bio:
God Nisanov and his partner Zarakh Iliev ran into a hitch last year over a $2 billion rehab of the All Russia Exhibition Center after Moscow officials decided to rethink the plan. Nisanov still has a lot on his plate: He and Iliev own the Radisson Royal Ukraine Hotel, European Shopping Center and Radisson SAS Slavyanskaya Hotel in Moscow. The partners also own several big shopping centers in Moscow's outskirts, where wholesalers from all over Russia come to buy goods.

This real estate empire started modestly, after Nisanov, born in Azerbaijan, moved to Moscow. With Iliev he began creating shopping markets near metro stations, turning them into shopping complexes. Their real estate projects total nearly 10.8 million square feet.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fracking billionaire Terry Pegula sold East Resources, his oil and gas company, to Royal Dutch Shell for $4.7 billion in May 2010. After the sale, Pegula shifted his attention and money to the game of hockey. He bought his hometown team, the NHL's Buffalo Sabres, for $189 million in February 2011.
