He also donated $102 million to his alma mater Penn State to build a hockey arena and field a division one team. A former math major, Pegula switched to petroleum engineering for a scholarship and joined Getty Oil after graduation. In 1983 with a $7,500 loan from friends and family, he founded East Resources to drill sand wells.
title: Owner

name: Billionaires
bio: Anthony Pritzker and his brother Jay, known as JB, run The Pritzker Group, a private equity and venture capital firm with offices in Los Angeles and Chicago. The brothers are heirs to the Hyatt hotel fortune. Anthony's net worth has increased by several hundred million dollars over the past year due to profits from a recent sale of shares he and JB retained in industrial conglomerate Marmon, the majority of which was sold to Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway in 2007. Through their Chicago-based venture capital arm New World Ventures, the Pritzkers has invested $50 million into an Arizona-based data center technology company. Anthony Pritzker spent twenty years running middle market manufacturing and distribution companies, including firms within the Pritzker family's Marmon conglomerate. His new 49,300-square-foot home in the Bel-Air hills neighborhood of Los Angeles features 72 kilowatts of solar power, geothermal cooling, and energy efficient lighting. An ironman triathlete, he sits on the board of the Los Angeles County Museum of Art and chairs the board of the UCLA Institute of the Environment and Sustainability.

name: Billionaires
bio: Jay Pritzker, known as JB, and his brother Tony run The Pritzker Group, a private equity and venture capital firm with offices in Chicago and Los Angeles. Both of them are heirs to the Hyatt hotel fortune; his net worth is up several hundred million dollars compared to a year ago due to profits from the sale of shares he retained in industrial group Marmon, the majority of which was sold to Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway in 2007. JB started venture capital firm New World Ventures in 1995. The city of Chicago is also tapping his expertise to create local jobs in digital, clean technology and life sciences. Pritizker will lead a new council of technology business leaders, called ChicagoNEXT, to spur growth in this space. He is a trustee at Northwestern University, a longtime Democratic donor and a supporter of early childhood education.

name: Billionaires
bio: Nevaldo Rocha runs Brazil's version of fast-fashion king Zara. He founded his first clothing store, ?The Capital,? in 1947. In 1956 he co-founded apparel maker Guararapes Confeccoes with his brother. In 1979 the company acquired the Riachuelo department stores, expanding its business into retail. Guararapes Confecções now supplies goods to its retail subsidiary, Lojas Riachuelo, which has 169 stores nationwide and absorbs more than 80% of its production. The remaining production goes to more than 10,000 merchants in Brazil through sales representatives. Guararapes Confeccoes went public in 1970. Together with his three children Rocha owns 83% of the company. The company's chairman and chief executive officer, Rocha never went to high school. His son Flavio is vice president of the company and his two other children, daughter Lisiane and son Elsio, are board members.
title: Entrepreneur

name: Billionaires
bio: Maritime magnate Kjell Inge Rokke, who is dyslexic, was reportedly told by a schoolteacher that he'd never amount to anything. He sold fish off a single boat in Seattle before eventually returning to Norway and building up a fleet while earning a reputation as a ruthless corporate raider. After nearly sinking his empire in 2003, Rokke had to sell off his yacht to pay his debts. Back in the black, Rokke now owns a majority of Aker ASA, a conglomerate that operates ships, shipyards, offshore drilling, and more. He also has a new 230-foot super-yacht that can accommodate 24 guests and 28 crew on board.

name: Billionaires
bio: Jeans guru Renzo Rosso co-founded Diesel 35 years ago, at the ripe old age of 23. Since then, Diesel has evolved into to a lifestyle brand with revenues of $2 billion in 2012. Through a holding company called Only The Brave, Rosso has spent the last decade snapping up majority stakes in small, upmarket fashion houses all across Europe: Paris-based Maison Martin Margiela, Amsterdam's Viktor & Rolf, and this past December, Milanese label Marni. The avid snowboarder and guitar player owns South Beach design hotel The Pelican as well as a winery near his northern Italian home and invests in tech startups including Nonabox, a Birchbox for pregnant women.
title: Entrepreneur

name: Billionaires
bio: Cofounder and Co-CEO of the Carlyle Group, David Rubenstein is a leading figure in private equity.  His firm reaped proceeds of $5.1 billion from 117 deals executed in the third quarter of 2012 alone. After growing up in working class Baltimore he went to Duke University and U. of Chicago Law School on scholarships. He practiced law in New York until he became deputy domestic policy assistant to President Jimmy Carter. He cofounded Carlyle in 1987 with fellow billionaires William Conway and Daniel D'Aniello. The firm leveraged ties to politically connected advisers, including former President George H.W. Bush and former British Prime Minister John Major, to buy defense businesses, fix them up and sell at a profit. He collects historical artifacts including original copies of the Emancipation Proclamation, the Declaration of Independence, and the Magna Carter. In 2011 he donated $13.5 million to the Foundation for the National Archives. In January 2012 he said he would give $7.5 million to help fix the earthquake-damaged Washington Monument. Also in 2012 he gave $15 million to Duke to fund the university's Innovation and Entrepreneurship Initiative. In February 2013, alongside Bloomberg CEO Dan Doctoroff and Bloomberg Philanthropies he pledged a combined $25 million towards finding a cure for ALS (Lou Gehrig's disease).
title: Co-Chief Executive Officer and Co-founder
employment: {'name': 'Carlyle Group', 'title': 'Co-Chief Executive Officer and Co-founder', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Filiz Sahenk heads the luxury brand clothing and tourism businesses in her family's Dogus Holding conglomerate. Dogus Holding has interests in finance, media, tourism and construction companies, but their main investment is in Garanti Bank. Sahenk represents global brands Tod's, Emporio Armani, Gucci, Loro Piana and In-Formal in Turkey. She is also the president of the Ayhan Sahenk Foundation established in her father's name. Sahenk is joined by her brother Ferit Sahenk and mother Deniz Sahenk on the billionaires list.

name: Billionaires
bio: Alvaro Saieh Bendeck is new to the Forbes Billionaires list. He owns 53% of the highly acquisitive Chilean bank Corpbanca, and as of February 15, 2013, that stake was worth $260 million. According to Corpbanca's investor relations director, Claudia Labbe Montevecchi, he has amassed a fortune worth $2.6 billion, with holdings in retail, media, real estate and insurance companies. His retail unit, SMU, owns Chile's leading supermarket chain, Unimark, along with seven shopping malls, 32 shopping centers, Santiago's Hyatt hotel and several other hotels. In media he owns Chile's second biggest daily paper, La Tercera, and several radio stations and magazines. His insurance holdings include a majority interest in Corpseguros and Corpvida. He built Corpbanca after buying Chile's Banco Concepcion in 1995, and he added Banco Santander's Colombian unit to it in 2012.

name: Billionaires
bio: Stephan Schmidheiny is an industrialist turned philanthropist and environmentalist. Since February 2012, he has been appealing a guilty verdict in a lengthy criminal trial related to alleged asbestos-related illnesses in a company associated with Schmidheiny's Swiss Eternit group (Eternit Italia was a public company and Schmidheiny's Swiss Group was the biggest single shareholder for a couple of years within the 80 years' history of Eternit Italia). Schmidheiny and another shareholder were sentenced to 16 years each in prison and were provisionally ordered to pay compensation to former workers and residents who lived near the plants. In 1976 Schmidheiny became president of the board of his father's Swiss Eternit Group, a construction materials manufacturer, diversifying the company away from asbestos long before it was a banned substance. In 2003, Schmidheiny donated all shares of his forestry firm Grupo Nueva, worth $1 billion, to his Viva Trust, whose profits are used to promote causes like sustainability and education. Schmidheiny is an art collector who favors contemporary painters Richter and Warhol.

name: Billionaires
bio: E.A. Soares dos Santos chairs food retailer Jeronimo Martins, which has more than 2,500 stores in Portugal and Poland and had 2011 revenue of $13 billion (9.8 billion Euros). He and his family own about 22% of the listed retailer. An uptick in the share price lifted his net worth by $300 million in the past year. Despite economic stagnation in Portugal, Jeronimo Martins is growing thanks to its Polish stores, which contribute some 60% of the revenue. The company, which traces its beginnings to a tiny store opened in Lisbon in 1792, operates the Pingo Doce and Recheiro chains in Portugal and the Biedronka chain in Poland. It is expanding to Colombia, where it aims to initially open as many as 40 stores by the end of 2013. Soares dos Santos' son Pedro serves as the CEO of Jeronimo Martins; another son, Jose, is a board member.

name: Billionaires
bio: Friede Springer, the fifth wife and widow of Axel Springer, inherited 52% of the eponymous media company founded by her late husband, Axel Springer. The company, Axel Springer Verlag, is one of Germany's leading publishing groups and publishes 230 newspapers in 34 countries, including leading German conservative daily Die Welt and Germany's largest tabloid, Bild Zeitung. Axel Springer publishes the foreign language editions of Forbes magazine in Poland and Russia. Revenues in 2011 hit $4.2 billion, and climbed 3.9% in the first nine months of 2012. Her fortune is unchanged from a year ago. Friede Springer is active in various philanthropic organizations and has received numerous awards for her efforts to rebuild German-Jewish relations. Springer also holds the Federal Cross of Merit for her efforts to promote social, cultural and scientific dialogue worldwide. She is a member of the German's conservative party, the Christian Democratic Union, and is a personal friend of chancellor Angela Merkel.

name: Billionaires
bio: Wang Yung-tsai is a younger brother and business collaborator of deceased Y.C. Wang, the Taiwan postwar management icon. Starting in the 1950s, the duo built the Formosa Plastics Group into one of Asia's largest business petrochemical manufacturers. Wang's wealth has slipped in the past year amid a limited industry rebound from the global downturn. Now retired, Wang has no management oversight any of the group's biggest companies such as Nan Ya Plastics, Formosa Plastics and Formosa Fibre. The group also has investments in electronics, hospitals and education, among other fields. His niece Cher Wang is chairman of mobile phonemaker HTC and also a member of this year's Billionaires List.

name: Billionaires
bio: Germany's "Mr. Wind". Aloys Wobben founded wind turbine manufacturer Enercon in 1984 and has built it into the fifth largest company in the sector, behind Vestas of Denmark, Goldwind of China, GE and Spain's Gamesa. The company has managed to avoid the cash-flow and board room problems that have plagued some of its competitors, and has captured nearly 60% of the market in Germany. It does not sell its turbines in the U.S. Enercon is private and does not disclose its financial figures; analysts estimate 2012 revenues grew to around $5.34 billion (4 billion Euros). In October 2012, Wobben transferred his 100% stake in Enercon into a family trust and announced he was retiring from business for health reasons. Wobben's nephew, Simon-Hermann Wobben, is on the company's board.

name: Billionaires
bio: Property barons Zakay brothers have been on a buying spree in the past two years, apparently amassing at least 1 million sq. feet of industrial, retail and office space and over 700 hotel rooms. They have also been busy in the property lending business. Plus they continue to look for opportunities abroad. Sol, who originally founded the group in the late 1980s and ran it for years, left the UK after a 50% tax rate on high earners was enacted. Now living in Gibraltar, he is chairman of Topland Group Holdings, the international part of the business. The group has significant interests in natural resources throughout the world through its JV with Barclays, it has ventured into residential development in India, and into new sectors such as solar energy and mezzanine finance. Eddie meanwhile is chairman of the Topland Group of Companies, which encompasses the UK property business.

name: Billionaires
bio: Zhang Shiping's net worth is off 15% from a year ago due to declines in the stock prices of his two principal holdings: China Hongqiao Group, a supplier of aluminum products, and Weiqiao Textile, a textile maker whose first-half 2012 profit tanked 90%. His son, Zhang Bo, is China Hongqiao's CEO. His son-in-law Yang Congsen also holds a top job in Zhang's empire. Zhang attracted notice early on from the government: He was selected by the State Council as a "National Model Worker" in 1995.

name: Billionaires
bio: His net worth down again, 15% from March 2012, Vasily Anisimov has had a rough couple of years. Coalco, his development company, has sucked up a lot of resources, forcing him two years ago to liquidate his shares of Metalloinvest in order to pay down a loan. At least one headache is gone: Last October, his longtime antagonist, exiled Russian oligarch Boris Berezovsky, withdrew a $2 billion suit against Anisimov, based on a claim for a stake in Metalloinvest. That freed up $600 million in Anisimov's accounts. Anisimov has darted in and out of the spotlight since the 1990s, when he owned banks and aluminum plants. He liquidated everything in 2000, and kept a very low profile. Four years later, he emerged from the shadows as an investor in Metalloinvest, along with rising fellow billionaires Alisher Usmanov and Andrei Skoch.

name: Billionaires
bio: Martha Ingram is the former chairman of Ingram Industries. She took over in 1995 after her husband's death. In 2008 she stepped down when son John replaced her as chairman and son Orrin became president and CEO. The company consists of two parts, Ingram Content and Ingram Marine. The content group distributes books, offers print-on-demand services and provides published content to Apple's iBookstore for the iPad. The marine division operates nearly 4,000 barges and more than 100 towboats on America's inland waterways. Son David runs Ingram Entertainment, a DVD and videogame distributor. (Its value is excluded from Martha's net worth.) Ingram is prominent in Nashville society; she sits on boards of cultural institutions that support theater, opera and the symphony in Tennessee.
title: Former Chairman
employment: {'name': 'Ingram Industries, Inc.', 'title': 'Former Chairman', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Shahid Khan may have endured a rough 2-14 season as rookie owner of the NFL's Jacksonville Jaguars, but his main business, auto parts manufacturer Flex-N-Gate, is thriving with 2012 sales of $3.9 billion, up from $3.4 billion. The Pakistan-born Khan came to the U.S. for the first time at age 16 for college. After getting an engineering degree from the University of Illinois, Khan eventually designed a revolutionary one-piece truck bumper design that saved weight while adding structural support, which he parleyed into an auto parts empire.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mustafa Rahmi Koc is the honorary president of the family company, Koc Holding, but is slowly stepping down from other responsibilities. Last year, he handed over the position of Chairman of the Board at Ford Otosan to his younger son Yildirim Ali Koc. He continues to take interest in the Rahmi Koc Museum, Turkey's first museum dedicated to the history of transportation, industry and communication; it houses thousands of objects ranging from gramophone needles to real size ships and planes. Koc is known for his love of the sea and luxury yachts. His sisters Semahat Arsel and Suna Kýrac as well as his sons Mustafa, Omer and Ali Koc are also billionaires.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mining magnate Patrice Motsepe is South Africa's first and only black billionaire. His publicly traded mining conglomerate, African Rainbow Minerals (ARM) has interests in platinum, nickel, chrome, iron, manganese, coal, copper and gold. Like most of South Africa's mining industry, ARM has suffered a rough year filled with labor disputes, violence and subsequent production losses. That has kept ARM from growing year-on-year, leaving Motsepe's fortune flat, although shares of Harmony Gold, which Motsepe owns through ARM, began to recover at the end of 2012. Born in the sprawling black township of Soweto and then trained as a lawyer, he became the first black partner at the Bowman Gilfillan law firm in Johannesburg and then started a contracting business doing mine scut work. He bought low-producing gold mine shafts in 1994 and turned them profitable using a lean management style. Motsepe benefited from South Africa's Black Economic Empowerment (BEE) laws, which mandate that companies be at least 26% black-owned in order to get a government mining license. He also holds a stake in Sanlam, a publicly traded financial services company outside Cape Town, and is the president and owner of the Mamelodi Sundowns Football Club which has had an incredibly rough season.

name: Billionaires
bio: Daniel Och is CEO of Och-Ziff Capital Management, one of the world's only publicly-traded hedge fund firms. His $21.5 billion Master fund led the way for the firm in 2012, netting an 11.2% return. Och's Europe fund and Global Special Investments fund also recorded gains, rising 8.6% and 9.4%, respectively. Assets under management at the firm are up to $33.1 billion, thanks in part to commitments from large institutional investors like the Florida State Board of Administration's pension fund, which kicked in $150 million in July. Och got his start at Goldman Sachs with other big time investors such as Eddie Lampert and Thomas Steyer; he struck out on his own in 1994 with a reported $100 million in seed money from the billionaire Ziff brothers. On December 6, 2010 Solomon Schechter Day School of Essex and Union in West Orange, N.J., became Golda Och Academy after receiving a $15 million donation from The Jane and Daniel Och Family Foundation. The school was renamed for Och's mother, a former history teacher and administrator at the school.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Och-Ziff Capital Management Group', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Candy maker Hans Riegel is the Gummi Bear billionaire -- and business has been growing, despite economic malaise in Europe. Riegel's estimated fortune has climbed an impressive $600 million in the past year as a result of increased sales. He is credited with inventing more than 200 sweets, including Gummi Bears, Vademecum sugar-free gum and Maoam fruit chewies, and has said he gets his inspiration from reading comic books and watching movies for children. The candies are produced by Riegel's ultra tight-lipped, family-owned Haribo candy company, which does not even disclose its revenues -- estimated at $2.9 billion (2.2 billion Euros) in 2011. He and his brother Paul rebuilt the company after World War II and ran it together until Paul's death in 2009, avoiding use of any debt. Hans, who is single and has no children, owns 50% of the company, still runs it and is in charge of marketing. The remaining 50% is owned by Paul's heirs. Paul's son Hans Guido Riegel heads production and technical questions. Two other sons of Paul, Hans Juergen Riegel and Hans Arndt Riegel, also sit on the supervisory board.

name: Billionaires
bio: Shi Yuzhu's wealth is up by half this year, one of China's biggest movers on the list. The Shanghai-based investor has a twenty-year track record of making golden bets on widely different industries. Most of his net worth is in investments in banks and beverages, but he's seen his shares of online game company Giant Interactive double since issuing a fat $3 dividend per share in 2011. Shi also profited handily from a timely investment in China Minsheng Bank, in which he holds a 4% stake with his daughter. Minsheng's other billionaire investors include Lu Zhiqiang, Liu Yonghao and Guo Guangchang.

name: Billionaires
bio: Zygmunt Solorz-Zak founded TV network Polsat in 1992; today the Polsat Group is listed on the Warsaw Stock Exchange and includes a digital platform as well as sports, news and film channels. He also listed his utility, ZE PAK, in Poland's largest public offering in a year. Solorz-Zak also has shares in Poland's InvestBank, pension fund PTE Polsat, pharmaceutical company Bioton and TV producer ATM Group. He is planning to transfer a portion of the shares in his empire to his son Tobias in the first quarter of 2013; he may be doing so as a hedge against his upcoming divorce. In February, court proceedings will determine how much of his fortune he will have to hand over. In a recent interview, Sorlorz-Zak stated his dream is to create an intelligent house that could be controlled entirely by smartphone.

name: Billionaires
bio: In November 2012 a former flight attendant for Taubman Air Terminals filed a sexual harassment suit against Alfred Taubman asking for $29 million in damages, which would be 1% of his fortune. Three weeks later she dropped all charges. Taubman dropped out of the University of Michigan, and he started his mall empire, Taubman Centers, in 1950. He took the auction house Sotheby's private in 1983 and then public again in 1988. He sold his controlling interest in 2005 and the remainder of his shares within the past year. He has written a memoir, "Threshold Resistance," that tells about his career and a 9-month prison sentence he served in 2004 on an art auction price-fixing conviction. He pledged $56 million to the University of Michigan in 2012 and has given the school $142 million in all, making him its largest donor ever. Its college of Architecture and Urban Planning bears his name, as does a research institute at the medical school. In all, Taubman has given more than $250 million to charity, including $26 million to Detroit-area schools. He is a strong supporter of stem cell research and hopes to make his home state, Michigan, a stem cell mecca.

name: Billionaires
bio: With her sister-in-law Wilma Tisch, Joan Tisch controls a family fortune built by their late husbands, investors Laurence and Preston Tisch. The brothers started with a small New Jersey hotel in 1946. They acquired Loews Theatres in 1959. Today publicly traded Loews Corp. holding company includes oil drilling (Diamond Offshore), natural gas pipelines (Boardwalk) and insurance (CNA). Joan owns 6.6% of Loews. Joan's son Jonathan heads Loews Hotels and serves as co-chairman. Wilma's son James is CEO of Loews. Wilma's other son Andrew is co-chairman with Jonathan. Joan inherited 50% ownership of the Super Bowl champion New York Giants football team, which her late husband, Preston, bought in 1991. She has committed herself to working toward a world without AIDS and funded the Tisch building at Gay Men's Health Crisis in Manhattan. Her passion for the project is personal: "I have known several people afflicted with AIDS, some of whom have died, and I would like to be of service."

name: Billionaires
bio: Dennis "Chip" Wilson stepped down as Chief Innovation and Brand Officer of Lululemon Athletica, the yoga-inspired athletic apparel company he founded, in 2012. He remains its chairman of the board and largest individual shareholder though he recently put in a plan to sell around a chunk of shares, approximately 13.4% of his shares or a 4% stake. In December, Wilson announced that he would help fund a new design school focusing on high-tech clothing at Kwantlen Polytechnic University. He and his wife are donating $8 million.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: New Zealand native Richard Chandler, now a resident in Singapore, runs Richard Chandler Corp., a fund aimed at emerging markets that he founded after splitting with his billionaire brother Christopher. In October, he invested $112 million for 13.4% of Union Bank of Nigeria; in December he agreed to pay $74 million to acquire 15% of WesternZagros, an oil and gas company operating in the Kurdistan region of Iraq. Holdings include a stake in Sino-Forest, a controversial Canadian-listed Chinese timber firm, which filed for bankruptcy protection last year after trading was suspended in August 2011 on allegations of fraud.

name: Billionaires
bio: Arnold shocked the hedge fund world in May 2012 when he announced he was calling it a career at age 38. "After seventeen years as an energy trader, I feel that it's time to pursue other interests," wrote the former Enron star, who is said to have made $750 million for the defunct energy giant in 2001. Arnold and his wife Laura, who are signatories of the Giving Pledge, plan to devote much of their time to philanthropy, specifically their $1.3 billion Laura and John Arnold Foundation. In August, the couple, who have already given away more than $1.2 billion, launched the Giving Library, a collection of videos featuring 250 charities, to help philanthropists learn about the nonprofits. Centaurus was up 4% net of fees through May, when Arnold began returning capital to his investors.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Choi is one of the world's richest toymakers owing to his early success in the industry, yet most of his fortune today comes from well-timed real estate investments, such in as Kowloon City Plaza and Auto Plaza in Hong Kong. In mainland China, Choi is looking to transform land under a toy-making facility just over the border from Hong Kong into a mini-city; toy production will be moved further inland. Son Karson is a push into watch retailing by the family's new Halewinner chain.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former concrete inspector David Consunji debuts on list on better understanding of his holdings. He founded construction company DMCI in 1954 and later expanded into infrastructure, real estate, mining and power. Stock price of the Philippines Stock Exchange-listed company, which is up more than 20-fold since its 2009 low, took hit recently when an accident at its coal mine in Antique province claimed three lives. Son Isidro is DMCI Holding's president.

name: Billionaires
bio: Stanley Druckenmiller closed down his $12 billion hedge fund, Duquesne Capital Management, in August 2010 and returned investors' money, citing frustration with his inability to deliver high returns. Druckenmiller had started Duquesne Capital Management 30 years earlier with $1 million. In 1988 the Bowdoin College graduate was hired by George Soros and the duo was reported to have made $1 billion in a day with a timely short position on the British Pound in 1992. Druckenmiller returned to running his own fund in 2000 and reportedly succeeded in making money in 2008 when most other firms tanked. He now manages his fortune via a New York-based family office, running his own book and investing in funds managed by former Duquesne portfolio managers. In December 2009 he announced a $705 million commitment to "medical research, education and the fight against poverty," including $100 million for a new neuroscience institute at NYU Langone Medical Center. He chairs Harlem Children's Zone, which helps 17,000-plus children and adults in its mission to break the "cycle of generational poverty."

name: Billionaires
bio: Doris Fisher's art collection is only slightly less valuable than her stake in Gap, but that doesn't make it any less impressive. With more than 1,100 works by 185 artists, the collection focuses on 1960s contemporary art and includes a number of works from Andy Warhol, Roy Lichtenstein, Chuck Close and Gerhard Richter. An expansion project at the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art, to be completed in 2016, will permanently display the collection. She started the Gap with her late husband Donald in 1969 as a San Francisco jeans and music store. Doris' sons Robert and William both serve on the board. A third son, John, owns a significant stake in the company as well and manages the family's investment group, Pisces Inc. Gap co-founder is also a noted philanthropist, with an interest in education; she is a co-founder and board member of the KIPP Foundation, which supports the Knowledge Is Power Program (KIPP) public charter schools. Since 2000, Fisher has donated $120 million the KIPP charter school network and Teach For America.
title: Cofounder

name: Billionaires
bio: Gong Hongjia's wealth has increased by more than $1 billion in the past year as the share price soared at listed video surveillance equipment maker Hangzhou Hikvision Digital Technology. Sales in the first nine months of 2012 rose by 39% to $772 million, while profits were up 43% to $193 million. Last year Gong donated $1.6 million to his alma mater, Huazhong University of Science and Technology.

name: Billionaires
bio: Oakley founder Jim Jannard now spends the majority of his time building his second world-class brand, RED, which produces better-than-film-quality digital cameras for making movies and shooting magazine covers. In February 2013 RED sued Sony for patent infringement. Jannard started Oakley in 1975. At first he sold rubber grips for motorcycles and BMX bikes out of the trunk of his car. He began making high-tech lenses for sunglasses in 1984 and transformed Oakley into a premium brand by persuading cyclists, skateboarders and motocross riders to wear his shades. Oakley went public in 1995 and later diversified into goggles, apparel, bags and footwear. An avid photographer, Jannard founded RED in 2005. Two years later he sold Oakley to Italian billionaire Leonardo Del Vecchio's optics giant Luxottica for $2.1 billion. RED cameras have been used to shoot "The Social Network," "The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo," and "The Hobbit," among other films. Jannard says he plans to give away much of his money, but won't provide details.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman and CEO of SC Johnson, H. Fisk Johnson oversees the $9 billion (estimated sales) cleaning products giant. Fisk, as he is know, is the second youngest of founder SC Johnson's great-great grandchildren. His mother, Imogene, is the widow of Samuel Curtis Johnson, who passed the company on to the fifth generation in 2000. Fisk and his family have faced scrutiny in their hometown of Racine, Wisc. since older brother Curt was charged with sex crimes against a child in 2011. Curt entered a plea of not guilty. The trial is on hold. In 2011 the Johnson family sold one of their companies for the first time: Bubble wrap maker Sealed Air bought industrial cleaning firm Diversey (Curt had been at its helm, but stepped down following charges against him). Fisk's sister Helen runs Johnson Outdoors and Johnson Financial.

name: Billionaires
bio: Imogene Powers Johnson is the widow of Samuel Curtis Johnson (d. 2004), who ran household products company SC Johnson. The company is known for brands such as Windex and Pledge. Sam joined the SC Johnson company in 1954, expanding it into industrial cleaning, banking and camping supplies. He passed the company on to the fifth generation in 2000. Her son Curt stands accused of sex crimes against a child. He entered a not-guilty plea and his trial is on hold. In 2011 the Johnson family sold one of its companies for the first time: Bubble wrap maker SealedAir bought industrial cleaning firm Diversey (Curt had been at its helm, but stepped down following charges against him). Her other son, Fisk, is the chairman of SC Johnson and daughter Helen runs Johnson Outdoors and Johnson Financial. Imogene is the founding director and chairman of the Prairie School, a college prep day school originally built for the children of SC Johnson factory workers. The Johnsons have left an indelible stamp on their hometown of Racine, commissioning Frank Lloyd Wright to design the corporate headquarters in the late 1930s.

name: Billionaires
bio: S. Curtis Johnson is still awaiting trial after being charged in March 2011 with the sexual assault of a minor. The child was later revealed to be his stepdaughter. He pleaded not guilty and the case is on hold. Until February 2011 Curt chaired family-owned industrial cleaning outfit Diversey Inc., formerly JohnsonDiversey. He stood down, citing personal reasons, before his arrest last year. Diversey was sold to Sealed Air, the maker of Bubble Wrap, for $4.3 billion in October 2011. Curt is one of four children of Samuel Curtis Johnson (d. 2004), great-grandson of the former salesman who started a flooring company in 1886, then moved into the wax business. Curt's brother Fisk heads up SC Johnson, while sister Helen Johnson-Leipold runs the businesses under the Johnson Financial Group umbrella.

name: Billionaires
bio: Helen Johnson-Leipold runs financial services company Johnson Financial as well as Johnson Outdoors, a publicly traded camping and military supplier. She also chairs the Johnson Foundation at Wingspread, one of many Frank Lloyd Wright-designed buildings maintained by the Johnson family. Helen is the eldest daughter of Imogen and the late Samuel Curtis Johnson (d. 2004). Her brother Fisk is chairman of cleaning products giant SC Johnson with over $9 billion in estimated sales. The Johnsons have faced scrutiny in their hometown of Racine, Wisc. since Helen's older brother Curt was charged with sex crimes against a child in 2011. He has entered a not-guilty plea and his trial is on hold.

name: Billionaires
bio: Winifred Johnson-Marquart is the president of the Johnson Family Foundation and the only Johnson sibling to live outside of hometown Racine, Wisc. She lives in Virginian Beach. The youngest daughter of Imogen and the late Samuel Curtis Johnson (d. 2004), who ran household products company SC Johnson. Sam passed the company to his children in 2000. The Johnsons have faced scrutiny since older brother Curt was charged with sex crimes against a child in 2011. He entered a not guilty plea; his case is currently on hold.

name: Billionaires
bio: Shares of Patrick Lee's paper maker Lee & Man Paper Manufacturing, gained 50% in the past year, despite weaker paper prices amid soft demand. Sales in the six months through September fell 1.9%, and net profit only a 4.3% gain. The company in which Lee holds 60% with his family, produces close to 4 million tons of containerboard annually, which is used for shipping and packaging cartons. It also owns a pulp mill in California. Lee, who is chairman, runs the firm with his sons, Raymond (chief executive) and Man Bun (managing director).

name: Billionaires
bio: Farhad Moshiri has shares in numerous companies in the U.K. and Russia, including Metalloinvest, Megafon and the Arsenal Football Club. He is a chartered certified accountant and from 1979-1992 he worked for Ernst & Young, Pannell Kerr Forster and Deloitte Touche. After meeting with fellow billionaire Alisher Usmanov in the early '90s he became Usmanov's partner in several projects. He was Usmanov's representative in Britain and head of Usmanov's Cypriot Investment Company, Gallagher. He was a board member of MMK Norilsk Nickel, Mail.Ru Group, and is a board member of Metalloinvest. In November 2012, Moshiri became co-owner of USM Holdings with Usmanov and billionaire Vladimir Skoch.

name: Billionaires
bio: After originally closing his legendary hedge fund, Tiger Management, in 2000, Julian Robertson became a pioneer in seeding and mentoring handpicked hedge funds, known as Tiger Cubs. He has seeded over 40 funds, the majority of which operate out of 101 Park Avenue, where Robertson himself runs his family office. In September 2012 Robertson's 80th birthday party at Lincoln Center drew many of those Cubs, including John Griffin, Chase Coleman, Lee Ainslee, Andreas Halvorsen and Chris Shumway. Robertson's $850 million (assets) Tiger Accelerator Fund, a fund of funds open to outside investors, invests exclusively in a group of six Tiger-seeded hedge funds. A fan of New Zealand, Robertson owns a winery and three golf resorts there. His Robertson Foundation has nearly $850 million in assets and focuses its work in four areas: education, the environment, medical research and religion and spirituality.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ronda Stryker is the only member of the founding family still active in Stryker Corp., the medical device company founded by her grandfather, Homer Stryker (d.1980). As a director and the largest shareholder, she has considerable influence. In 2012, she reportedly had a hand in pushing out CEO Stephen MacMillan amid controversy over his relationship with a former employee. Kevin Lobo is now CEO of Stryker, which had $8.7 billion in sales in 2012. Stryker is looking to expand its presence in China with the $764 billion acquisition of Trauson Holdings. An advocate for diversity in education, Ronda Stryker has donated more than $20 million to Spelman College, where she is a trustee.

name: Billionaires
bio:
Alexander Svetakov simplified his business interests last year, selling off the industrial assets of his holding company, Absolut Group, to concentrate mostly on real estate, trading and insurance.
Trading has coursed through is veins a long time. As a student at Moscow Institute of Electronics Technology in the early 1990s, he and his cohorts ran a wholesale business, importing home appliances and electronics from Singapore. (A wholesale appliance division of Absolut pulled in sales of $2 billion last year.) Like many Russian billionaires, his dealings took him into banking. Luck of timing led to a lucrative sale of Absolut-bank for nearly $1 billion to a Belgian group, a full year before the financial panic of 2008. Svetakov put the proceeds into land acquisition, and began building commercial space and affordable housing.

name: Billionaires
bio: At age 17 Sukanto Tanoto started working in the family business, selling spare parts to oil and gas companies. As the eldest son in his family he took over the business and expanded into building gas pipelines for multinationals, an especially profitable business during the 1972 oil crisis. Today his conglomerate, Royal Golden Eagle (RGE), owns palm oil firm Asian Agri, papermaker Asia Pacific Resources International Ltd., and a stake in cellulose producer Sateri Holdings, his biggest publicly held investment. He set up the Tanato Foundation more than ten years ago to offer scholarships, honoraria to teachers and healthcare in remote areas. He received the Dean's Medal from Wharton, the school's highest honor, in October 2012. Three of his children graduated from Wharton and Tanoto sits on its board of Overseers.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sarik Tara is the founder of Turkey's largest construction company ENKA, now run by his son, Sinan, also a billionaire. The company made a big play in Russia as both a contractor and real estate investor; it owns offices, a hotel, and shopping malls in Moscow as well as 63 additional supermarkets, hypermarkets and shopping malls across Russia. Enka is also known for constructing U.S. embassy buildings like those in the Dominican Republic, Equatorial Guinea and Afghanistan. The conglomerate is one Turkey's largest electricity producers, and is expanding in the energy sector.

name: Billionaires
bio: Silicon Valley legend Andreas (Andy) von Bechtolsheim has hit gold several times. The brains behind the SUN Workstation, the German-born computer whiz went from being a Stanford Ph.D. student to a cofounder of Sun Microsystems in the early 1980s. A renowned angel investor, Bechtolsheim wrote one of the first checks to Larry Page and Sergey Brin to start a fledgling dorm project known as Google. His initial $100,000 investment in 1998 is now worth more than $2 billion in company stock. Along with fellow Google investor and billionaire David Cheriton, he has started three different tech companies with a focus on IT networking. Their latest, Arista Networks, was funded almost entirely with money from the pair and is now challenging the likes of Cisco in the network switching market. The speed-talking Bechtolsheim serves as Arista's chairman and chief development officer.
title: Entrepreneur

name: Billionaires
bio: Oprah Winfrey may not be on the nation's TV screens daily since her long-running talk show ended in 2011, but she's stayed in the headlines. America's only African-American billionaire appears to be reviving the fortunes of her once-faltering cable channel, OWN (Oprah Winfrey Network), which grabbed ratings with an exclusive Lance Armstrong mea culpa interview after the cyclist's fall from grace. She also sat down with big-name stars Beyonce and Rihanna and announced an upcoming Tyler Perry-helmed sitcom. Fellow investors the Discovery Channel report that the network could be out of the red by the end of 2013. Despite low ratings early on, a deal with Comcast means that OWN can now be seen in 83 million homes. The talk show queen spent much of 2012 splitting her time between Montecito, California, her new home base since she left Chicago, and New Orleans, where she shot a film called "The Butler" opposite Forest Whitaker, due out this year. The majority of Oprah's net worth stems from 25 years of her profitable daytime TV show, plus earnings from her Harpo production company, which has a hand in the Dr. Phil, Rachael Ray and Dr. Oz shows. She continues to support educational causes and has spent $100 million on the Oprah Winfrey Leadership Academy for Girls in South Africa. Her lifetime giving totals $400 million.
title: Entrepreneur, Personality

name: Billionaires
bio: Casino magnate Steve Wynn watched fourth-quarter 2012 profits at his Wynn Resorts fall 40% thanks in part to lower revenue at the gambling empire's properties in Macau, which competes for business with properties owned by fellow billionaire Sheldon Adelson. Wynn operates two casinos in Macau and is building a third on the Cotai Strip. He also has plans to build a $1 billion casino in Everett, Mass. and another in Fishtown, a neighborhood in Philadelphia. In November 2012, Wynn shareholders enjoyed an $7.50-per-share special dividend. Also throughout 2012, the gambling tycoon continued to spar with former business partner and fellow billionaire Kazuo Okada. In the latest scrimmage in an ongoing war, Okada stepped down from the board of Wynn Resorts and vowed to fight Steve Wynn's seizure of Okada's nearly 20 percent stake in the resort empire, which Wynn wrested away from Okada in 2012 at a 30 percent discount. Okada, who made his fortune in pachinko--Japanese slot machines--was once the largest shareholder and a director of Wynn Resorts Ltd. In February 2012, Wynn forcibly bought out Okada's 20% stake and filed suit against the Japanese billionaire in Nevada. Wynn Resorts hired former FBI director Louis Freeh (author of the Freeh Report on the Jerry Sandusky sex abuse scandal at Penn State) to investigate Okada. Freeh's report claims that Okada violated the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act when he gave gifts and payments worth more than $100,000 to gaming officials in the Philippines, where Okada is building a casino. Although Okada disputes the charges and has countered with a suit attempting to take back his stake, he is now facing an FBI probe in relation to his activities in the Philippines. Meanwhile, Steve Wynn's ex-wife Elaine Wynn has claimed the Okada brouhaha nullifies an agreement that requires Steve Wynn's approval to sell her shares. Steve Wynn owns a 14-room penthouse apartment above the Ritz-Carlton on Central Park South, and paid $70 million for it, one of the highest prices ever paid for an apartment in New York City. In January 2010 Wynn divorced his wife, Elaine, for the second time. She is a billionaire by virtue of her stake in Wynn Resorts. Steve Wynn wed British girlfriend Andrea Hissom in April 2011.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Wynn Resorts', 'uri': 'companies/wynn-resorts', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Yeoh Tiong Lay who founded YTL Corp as a construction firm in 1955, got a boost from rising shares of his conglomerate,  partly due to a better performance by its cement unit. Company is run by eldest son, Francis. Its YTL Power owns PowerSeraya, Singapore's second-largest power plant, Wessex Water in the U.K. YTL's Malaysian-listed Starhill REIT closed a $415 million deal for three Marriott Hotels in Australia. Hotel arm reopened Kuala Lumpur's Hotel Majestic in December, closed for 28 years, after an $82 million facelift of the heritage property.

name: Billionaires
bio: Shares fell at his MMC Corp. and DRB-Hicom as they racked up debt for acquisitions and other purposes; Syed Mokhtar AlBukhary is the country's biggest private borrower. Companies own ports, an airport and interests in power, automobiles, construction, engineering and postal services. In December his fledgling telecom, Puncak Semangat, beat out big players such as Maxis, owned by fellow billionaire Ananda Krishnan, to snatch biggest slice of spectrum for 4G services. MMC's power subsidiary may go public in $1 billion deal.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ali Ibrahim Agaoglu is one of Turkey's largest developers, opening a 2,700 unit project in Maslak, one of Istanbul's most valuable areas, last year; plans for more units are under way. Agaoglu is also active in tourism. In 2012, he sold his investments in the energy sector to Dogan Holding, owned by fellow billionare Aydin Dogan, for over $300 million. Agaoglu is famous for his passion for luxury cars.

name: Billionaires
bio: With his brothers, Robert Bass controls one of the country's largest privately held oil outfits, Bass Enterprises Production. His great uncle, oil baron Sid Richardson, left a piece of his fortune to the Basses in 1959. They made the most of it, in part by putting capital in the hands of legendary investor Richard Rainwater. Robert co-founded private equity firm Oak Hill Capital Partners, which has $8 billion under management. Other investments include Aerion, a firm developing supersonic business jets. The sizable drop in our estimate of his wealth is due to our more conservative valuation of Aerion, as production of the company's jets may not begin until the end of the decade. Last year, he put up for sale a $34 million apartment at 834 5th Avenue in Manhattan, two floors below Rupert Murdoch's pad.

name: Billionaires
bio: After divorcing China's then-richest woman, Cai Kui became a billionaire himself in 2012. As a result of his divorce from real estate developer Wu Yajun, Cai received a 30% stake in Longfor Properties, a company he co-founded with Wu in 1994. Longfor has turned itself into a national brand from its initial base in Southwest China's Chongqing. In 2009, Longfor made its debut on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange and pushed Wu and Cai's net worth to $4 billion. Today it is headquartered in Beijing, with a recent market cap of $7.64 billion. In January the company announced 2012 sales of 4.18 million square meters of property nationwide for $6.4 billion (40.1 billion yuan), up 4.9 %and 27.2% year-over-year respectively. After Wu and Cai's August 2012 divorce, the couple split their 70% stake in the company but they remain its two biggest shareholders.

name: Billionaires
bio: Shopping mall magnate Edward DeBartolo Jr., better known as "Mr. D," took over his father's real estate business in 1994 and orchestrated a merger with Simon Property Group in 1996 that created the largest public REIT in North America. Known for his 23-year ownership of the San Francisco 49ers, he holds the best record of any team owner in NFL history, with five championship wins. He made history in 1977 when he took over the 49ers at the age of 30, making him the youngest owner in the NFL. In 1998 he pled guilty to a felony related to the corruption case of Louisiana Governor Edwin Edwards. The NFL fined him $1 million, suspended him from running the 49ers for one year and put him on probation for two years. Six years after their father's death, DeBartolo and his sister Denise York finalized the separation of their father's assets. He got full ownership of the real estate holdings while York became the owner of the 49ers. Shares in Simon Property have increased nearly six-fold since 2000. He also owns stakes in the Famous Famiglia pizza chain, DeBartolo Sports & Entertainment, and DeBartolo Development. He co-founded a charter school in Tampa Bay with former Buccaneers linebacker Derrick Brooks.

name: Billionaires
bio: John Doerr's Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers remains one of the top-tier firms along Menlo Park, Calif.'s Sand Hill Road with stakes in the likes of Twitter, Google, Spotify and Square. Despite this, the firm is still embroiled in an ongoing legal tussle with former junior partner Ellen Pao. Pao alleges that she was sexually harassed and discriminated against because of her gender. Doerr and Kleiner Perkins have denied wrongdoing, portraying Pao as a disgruntled employee in court documents. Legal issues aside, Kleiner Perkins closed a $525 million early stage fund--its 15th early stage fund--in May 2012. Doerr has been involved with most of those funds after joining the firm in 1980 and earned the bulk of his wealth from timely investments in companies like Amazon, Netscape and Sun Microsystem. After missing out on an early investment in Facebook, Kleiner Perkins' venture into Web 2.0 has had mixed results. While the firm's stake in Zynga has fallen dramatically with the social gaming company's falling stock price, Kleiner Perkins still holds a significant stake in Twitter. Doerr is a signatory of the Giving Pledge and sits on the board of the NewSchools Venture Fund.
title: Partner

name: Billionaires
bio: Guo Guangchang co-founded and chairs Hong Kong-listed Fosun International, one of China's largest conglomerates, with interests in pharmaceuticals, real estate, steel, mining, retail and publishing. In October 2012 Fosun Pharmaceutical, a unit of  Fosun International and a generic drug maker, was also listed in Hong Kong. The drug company's stock has remained flat but Fosun International's stock price advanced, boosting Guo's total net worth by $300 million in the past year. Meanwhile a public fight between Guo and another Chinese property tycoon, SOHO China president Pan Shiyi, has heated up in 2012 over the control of a prime waterfront location on the Bund in Shanghai. Fosun filed a lawsuit in May 2012 against SOHO China and two other firms for breaching Fosun's rights to acquire a major stake in the Bund plot.

name: Billionaires
bio: Gunter Herz and his siblings inherited a fortune from their father, coffee magnate Max Herz. He headed the family's Tchibo Holding, now called Maxingvest AG, for almost 35 years. A nasty family feud led Herz and his sister Daniela to sell their combined 40% stake in the German consumer goods group to their mother and three brothers (two of whom are billionaires) for an estimated $5 billion in 2003. Gunter and Daniela put a chunk of the money they received into private equity firm Mayfair SE, which in 2011 acquired 40% of the Vapiano Group, a restaurant chain with operations in more than 70 locations in Europe, the US and the Middle East.  Gunter's two children, Michaela and Christian, are on the management board of Mayfair SE. Gunter acquired shipping classification company Germanischer Lloyd in 2006; in December 2012 the company agreed to merge with Det Norske Veritas of Norway and will be called DNV GL Group. Gunter raises horses at his stud farm and races his yacht, All Smoke.

name: Billionaires
bio: Amos Hostetter graduated from Harvard Business School in 1961 and convinced his employer, Boston-based Cambridge Capital, to finance a small cable television system in rural New Jersey. Alongside his Amherst College roommate, Hostetter spread the business to the rest of the country under the name Continental Cablevision. The company eventually became the largest privately held cable company in the country and was sold to US West for $11 billion in 1996. Later, Hostetter bought the company back, renamed it MediaOne, and sold it for $44 billion in cash and stock to AT&T. The deal closed in 2000; it was the biggest U.S. cable TV provider at the time. Today, he owns Boston's Lewis Wharf, which serves as the base for his privately held Pilot House entities. He is an investor in cable companies, broadband startups and the odd piece of Nantucket real estate. His billion-dollar-endowed Barr Foundation has donated millions to Boston-area museums as well as nonprofits focusing on education and energy efficiency.
title: Chair

name: Billionaires
bio: Huang Rulun is the chairman of the unlisted Century Golden Resources Group, one of China's largest real estate developers, with 14 five-star hotels and six shopping malls as part of a total of 75 million square feet of property built over the years. Huang also has minority stakes in New China Life Insurance and the Bank of Beijing. In October, Century Golden agreed to pay $32 million for a 10% stake in newly established Fuzhou Airlines. Long one of China's most generous philanthropists, New Century said in January it would support the construction of an art museum at Tsinghua University in Beijing.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mike and Marian Ilitch built a single pizza shop into the Little Caesar's Pizza chain, which had over $3 billion in revenues last year. But the price of cheese and other commodities pressured profit margins. A shortened NHL season hurt their Detroit Red Wings hockey team, but he's hoping his Detroit Tigers can make a return trip to the World Series. Meanwhile, her Motor City Casino and hotel saw slightly lower revenues in the face of increased competition.

name: Billionaires
bio: Masatoshi Ito is honorary chair of Japan's largest retail group, Seven & I, with some 50,000 stores worldwide, including 7-Eleven convenience shops as well as superstores and department stores. The company plans to open 1,500 7-Elevens at home during the 2013 fiscal year; abroad the US and China are key expansion targets. It is also focusing on consolidating product development in new categories for its own private-label products and expanding services like home delivery, insurance; the group is also looking into beefing up internet sales.

name: Billionaires
bio: Although Boston Bruins owner Jeremy Jacobs helped deliver the Stanley Cup to the team in 2011 after a 39-year drought, he spent the second half of 2012 under fire thanks to his significant role in the most recent NHL lockout. He is chairman of the NHL's Board of Governors and represented the interests of the NHL team owners in negotiating the terms of the league's new collective bargaining agreement. He also owns 20% of the New England Sports Network. The bulk of his fortune comes from Delaware North, one of the largest concession companies in the world serving up food, drinks, and entertainment at 200 venues across four countries. Some of the better-known settings include Boston's TD Garden, Oriole Park at Camden Yards in Baltimore, and London's Wembley and Emirates Stadiums. While the NHL lockout had a dampening effect on Jacobs' revenue stream, it was offset by a surge in other areas of his firm's operations, namely travel and hospitality. Jacobs' father founded the business in 1915 selling popcorn and peanuts. Jacobs took over as CEO after his father's death in 1968. He runs the $2 billion (sales) business with his three sons. He and his family recently donated $10 million to his alma mater, SUNY Buffalo, to fund clinical research on heart and vascular diseases.

name: Billionaires
bio: Dallas Cowboys owner Jerry Jones' new 111,000-seat stadium helps Jones bring in league-leading revenue. The franchise remains America's most valuable sports team, worth $2.1 billion, despite a sometimes lackluster performance on the field. He made his first fortune in the 1970s drilling natural gas wells, then bought the Cowboys in 1989 for just $150 million. The team won three Super Bowls in the 1990s. Jones also owns a real estate development operation. A big Salvation Army supporter, he has used the Cowboys' well-known Thanksgiving halftime show to raise $1.6 billion for the charity over the past 15 years.
title: President and General Manager

name: Billionaires
bio: Manuel Jove, a carpenter by trade, opened his own business in 1980 and developed it into one of Spain's leading property companies, Fadesa Inmobiliaria. In 2004 he took the company public; he sold his 55% stake to real estate group Martinsa for $3 billion in September 2006, just before the collapse of the Spanish real estate bubble. Martinsa filed for bankruptcy two years later then, in March 2011, sued Jove for $2 billion, claiming that the purchase price of Fadesa had been inflated. Jove prevailed in the court matter in September 2012, even winning his legal costs. Meanwhile, his Inveravante investment group remains active in private equity, renewable energy, residential and commercial development, and hospitality. In 2012 the company also signed a deal with Hilton Worldwide to open two new Hiltons in Tangier. Jove reduced his stake in Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria, one of Spain's largest banks, from 5.1% to 2.99%. He collects art from the Spanish province of Galicia and enjoys woodworking.

name: Billionaires
bio: Peter Kellogg's father, James Kellogg, was a founder of brokerage house Spear, Leeds & Kellogg, which Peter took over in 1973.  After becoming CEO, he turned the firm into a market maker during the '80s and '90s.  The firm was the first specialist brokerage to control more than 10% of the stocks trading on the Big Board. In 2000 he orchestrated the sale of the company to Goldman Sachs for $6.5 billion. He invested the proceeds in reinsurance house IAT.  He has donated more than $4 million to the U.S. Ski and Snowboarding teams as well as some $40 million to his alma mater, The Berkshire School, a prep school in Sheffield, Massachusetts.  He is a member of the New York and American stock exchanges and sits on the board of numerous organizations including the U.S. Olympic Ski team, Goldman Sachs Advisory, and Nam Tai Electronics.

name: Billionaires
bio: Real estate developer Vincent Lo is the power behind Shui On Land, the developer of the iconic Xintiandi nightlife and shopping area in Shanghai. Its spinoff "Tiandi" sites can be found in Chongqing, Dalian, Foshan, Hangzhou, and Wuhan; other cities have approached Lo to expand further. Shui On's Hong Kong-traded shares have risen 7% over the past 12 months on rising expectations for Chinese economic growth in 2013. Lo said last May it would considering separately listing its Xintiandi-related business, but there hasn't been any follow-up. Lo is also chairman of SOCAM Development, a real estate, cement and construction business.

name: Billionaires
bio: Granddaughter of Campbell Soup founder and condensed soup inventor John T. Dorrance, Mary Alice Dorrance Malone is the company's largest shareholder and has sat on the board with her billionaire brother Bennett Dorrance for over 20 years. Campbell, the world's largest soup company with 2012 revenues of $7.7 billion, owns other familiar brands such as Pace (salsa), V8 (vegetable juice), Pepperidge Farm (cookies, Goldfish) and Swanson (broth). In July 2012 the company announced it would acquire Bolthouse Farms for $1.6 billion. Bolthouse, which sells juices and baby carrots, will help Campbell expand in the packaged fresh-food market. Malone breeds horses on her Iron Spring Farm, which encompasses a thousand acre property an hour west of Philadelphia and a location in Ocala, Florida. A former employee pled guilty to extortion charges in Philadelphia federal court in 2011 after demanding $250,000 a year to keep quiet about the heiress' life.

name: Billionaires
bio: A Glencore lifer, Mate broke into the ranks of the world's billionaires when the commodities giant went public in May 2011. Despite its shares losing more than 25% of their value since their debut, the future seems bright for Glencore. The firm announced plans to merge with mining outfit Xstrata in February 2012. The proposed all-stock "merger of equals" is currently awaiting regulatory approval in China. Daniel Mate joined Marc Rich & Co. in 1988 in Switzerland, six years before the firm was bought out by management and rebranded. Mate joined the zinc, copper and lead commodity department in 1991, rising to co-director of the division in 2000.

name: Billionaires
bio: A citizen of both the United Kingdom and his native Greece, Mistakidis attained billionaire status in May 2011 with the IPO of commodities giant Glencore. In February 2012 the firm announced plans to merge with mining outfit Xstrata. The proposed all-stock "merger of equals" is currently awaiting regulatory approval in China. After graduating from the London School of Economics, Mistakidis got his start at private commodities giant Cargill where he worked in non-ferrous metals for six years. Mistakidis then joined Marc Rich & Co. in 1993 just before the firm was bought out by management and renamed Glencore. Mistakidis worked in what would become the zinc, copper, and lead department, rising to the rank of co-director in 2000.

name: Billionaires
bio:
In 1971 Theo Mueller took over the company Theo Muller Group from his father, which was founded in 1896 by his grandfather in Aretsried, Bavaria. He started with four employees, but today is one of the largest company in the dairy business. In 2012 Robert Wiseman Diaries, supplier of one third of Britain's fresh milk, had agreed to sell the company to Theo Muller for GBP 279.5 mil. (about $ 450 mil). In July 2012 Pepsi and Theo Muller Group announced their U.S. joint venture, Muller Quaker Dairy, to enter the growing U.S. dairy market in mid-July 2013 with premium yogurt products. 
Under the leadership of Heiner Kamps, Stefan Muller (oldest son of Theo Muller) and Dr. Henrik Bauwens, the companies of the Group employ about 21.000 people.
title: Entrepreneur

name: Billionaires
bio: In February 2013 Elon Musk went head-to-head with a New York Times reporter who panned Musk's newly-released Tesla Model S electric car for performing poorly in frigid East Coast winter conditions. The resulting shootout created an Internet sensation--and scads of mixed PR for Tesla. While some CEOs would cringe at the controversy, it was vintage behavior for Musk, a South African-born serial entrepreneur fiercely focused on bringing his shoot-the moon business projects to life. Musk made his first fortune selling PayPal to eBay in 2002. Now NASA is using his SpaceX to resupply the International Space Station while shares of his Tesla electric car company gained 10% last year. Next up: SolarCity, run by Musk's cousin Lyndon Rive, wants to put solar panels on your home.
title: Founder, CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: Kerr Neilson is often compared to Warren Buffett because of his contrarian, value-based approach to investing. A native of Johannesburg, he bought his first stock at 13. He moved to Sydney in 1983 and started international equities specialist Platinum Asset Management in 1993 with George Soros as a founding stakeholder. He owns 57% after partially cashing out in a well-timed 2007 public offering. He still manages its flagship fund. He earned guru investor status at BT Australia during the 1980s. His great calls included short selling just before the 1987 crash and picking the top of the late 1980s Japanese bull market. His White Rabbit Gallery in Sydney, open to the public, displays his wife Judith's extensive collection of post-2000 Chinese art.

name: Billionaires
bio: David Rockefeller Sr.'s grandfather, John D. Rockefeller, built Standard Oil, the energy company that fueled America's industrial revolution. After the company was broken up in 1911, David Sr.'s father, John D. Rockefeller Jr., began buying real estate, including a 19-building complex in midtown Manhattan dubbed Rockefeller Center. David Sr. joined Chase Bank in 1946. He worked his way up to CEO and Chairman before leaving to focus on real estate, philanthropy and the arts. His parents helped establish the Museum of Modern Art in New York City. David has a huge collection of modern and contemporary art, including a "Water Lillies" painting by Claude Monet. He also has one of the biggest beetle collections in the world. In 2005 he gave $100 million to Rockefeller University and $100 million to MoMA. In 2008 he gave $100 million to his alma mater, Harvard. Since 2010 his son, David Jr., has been chairman of the Rockefeller Foundation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Warren Stephens is a renaissance man of investing. He owns Little Rock, Ark. investment bank Stephens, Inc., founded by his uncle W.R. (Witt) in 1933. Witt and Warren's father, Jackson, paid $5.4 million for Arkansas-Oklahoma Gas in 1954, which has since evolved into natural gas driller Stephens Production. They plowed the earnings into private equity and underwrote Wal-Mart's public offering in 1970. Warren grew up in the business, becoming chief executive in 1986. Witt died in 1991. Warren bought out his cousins' stake in 2006. Since then he's expanded the company's asset management and insurance arms and added to private equity stakes like Stephens Media, which owns 30 newspapers, including the Las Vegas Review-Journal. He recently bought 16 regional papers from the New York Times. When market maker Knight Capital Group imploded in August 2012 after buggy software sent out bad trades, Stephens stepped in with a $30 million investment to help recapitalize. A golf nut, he built the ultra-private Alotian Club on 1,000 acres outside of Little Rock. Stephens is also a wine aficionado; he sold 5,000 bottles in a 2007 Sotheby's auction. His favorite quaff: 1959 Chateau Latour.

name: Billionaires
bio: Oil pipeline magnate Kelcy Warren's company, Energy Transfer Equity, bought Sunoco, with its 4,900 retail outlets in 23 states, for $5.3 million in April 2012. That followed the purchase of fellow billionaire George Lindemann's Southern Union pipeline company for more than $5 billion the month before. Now he's streamlining the company. In December 2012 he sold off two of ETE's new assets, Missouri Gas Energy and New England Gas Co., to Laclede Group, for $1 billion. When he's not building his natural gas empire, the music fan prints albums for singer-songwriters at his Austin-based studio, Music Road Records. He amassed his pipeline network in the wake of Enron's collapse.

name: Billionaires
bio: Michael Ying surprised many when he raised his stake in struggling clothing retailer Esprit from 4.5% to 10.3% in late 2012, sparking widespread speculation that he may take an active role in the company's management. He had stepped down as chairman in 2006 and sold most of his stock by 2010. In February the chain said it will close all its U.S. and Canadian stores.

name: Billionaires
bio: Zhang Li is the co-chairman and CEO of Guangzhou R&F, one of China's largest real estate developers. Zhang's wealth, like that of many other Chinese property developers in the past year, has increased on signs of an industry rebound. Zhang started the company in 1994 with fellow billionaire Li Sze Lim. Zhang divides the work with Li by overseeing land acquisition, engineering, construction, cost control and management of the daily operations. Zhang also chairs Kinetic Mines and Energy, a mining company that listed on the Hong Kong exchange in March. Zhang is the vice chairman of China Real Estate Chamber of Commerce and a part-time professor at Jinan University. His sister Zhang Lin is a non-executive director at Guangzhou R&F.

name: Billionaires
bio: Prince Sultan Al Kabeer is new to Forbes' billionaire ranks this year. A member of the Saudi royal family, he founded dairy company Almarai in 1977 and took it public in 2005. He owns nearly 29% of it. In 2012 the company reported net income of $384 million on revenues of $2.6 billion. It trucks products, including milk from Holstein cows, throughout the Arab Gulf countries. To feed its herd, in 2011 Almarai bought an Argentine farm operator that produces barley, maize and wheat. According to the Breeders' Cup horse racing organization, Al Kabeer keeps a stud farm outside of Riyadh where he trains some 100 horses.

personName: Prince Sultan bin Mohammed bin Saud Al Kabeer
firstName: Prince Sultan bin Mohammed bin Saud

name: Billionaires
bio: Marc Benioff, the tech entrepreneur who built software company Salesforce.com, has long said that companies and products should be as social as vacation updates on Facebook. In 2012 he acquired several companies, including social media advertising company Buddy Media for $689 million in June and months later, Canadiam startup Golnstant, which designed a technology that allows people at different locations to browse websites together, reportedly for $70 million. Salesforce shares have made a strong showing in the past year, driving up Benioff's fortune by $600 million. At age 15 he founded his first company, which wrote Atari videogames. He started Salesforce in 1999 after stints at Apple and Oracle, where he was a protege of Larry Ellison. Though he has been a big Democratic donor, hosting a $35,800-a-plate dinner for President Obama at his home in April 2011, he also gave to Rep. Paul Ryan before Mitt Romney picked Ryan as his running mate. In November 2012, in a partnership with the city of San Francisco, he and his wife Lynn and the Salesforce.com Foundation donated more than $500,000 to the homeless.
title: Chairman and CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: Co-founder of TPG Group built a $55 billion private-equity empire from a lucky early break reorganizing Continental Airlines. He's had his challenges lately with flameouts like Texas utility TXU, but that didn't stop him from reportedly throwing a 70th birthday party for himself and 700 friends at the Wynn resort in Las Vegas -- with fellow septuagenarian Paul McCartney as the featured performer.

name: Billionaires
bio: Brothers Martin and Olivier Bouygues hold just over 21% of the Bouygues Group, a diversified industrial conglomerate founded by their father in 1952. In addition to construction the company has interests in telecom and media. Martin started as a supervisor and is now chairman and CEO, a post he has held for 23 years, while Olivier is the deputy chief executive and the CEO of their holding company, SCDM. Construction projects include the Hassan II Mosque in Casablanca, the University of Riyadh in Saudi Arabia, the English Channel Tunnel, the Kwun Tong viaduct in Hong Kong, numerous motorways in Hungary, and the Sydney CityRail airport link. Bouygues Telecom got a boost in early 2013 when its parent company injected $900 million into the firm in an effort to improve and expand amid increased competition. The brothers bought a famous vineyard, the Chateau Montrose, in 2006, and sell wine. Martin is a close friend of ex-French President Nicolas Sarkozy and the godfather of Sarkozy's son. Martin was also awarded the ultra-prestigious Legion d'honneur in July 2010.

name: Billionaires
bio: Thomas Bruch runs German food retailer Globus & Co., where revenues rose 5% in the first seven months of 2012, despite economic malaise. Sales in 2011 grew 4.5% to $8.6 billion (Euro 6.46 billion). That helped push up Bruch's net worth by $200 million over the past year. Bruch is the fifth generation of his family to run the  Globus & Co., which has supermarkets in the Czech Republic and Russia and also operates 83 hardware stores and nine electrical appliance stores. His great-great-grandfather Franz Bruch opened the first store in 1828. Thomas Bruch took over from his father in 1979. Three of his three sons work at the family company.

name: Billionaires
bio: Nuclear physicist Peter Buck loaned his friend's son, Fred DeLuca, $1,000 in 1965 to open a sandwich shop in Bridgeport, CT. From that first location sprang the Subway restaurants empire,  generating revenue of $18.1 billion in 2012. Buck, who lives in Danbury, CT, still owns half the business, though his role has diminished significantly over the years. With more than 38,200 locations from Afghanistan to Zambia, Subway overtook McDonalds in the spring of 2011 to become the largest restaurant chain in the world. Subway doesn't actually own a single location, but collects 8% of revenue from each franchisee. In 2004, Buck donated a massive 23.1-carat ruby to the Smithsonian, naming the stone for his late wife, Carmen Lucia.
title: Co-Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: John Caudwell keeps busy investing in small to medium-sized businesses and prime London real estate and chairing Caudwell Children, the charity he promotes through Twitter and is the largest benefactor of. He spent $233 million on a Mayfair parking lot in 2011, intending to turn it into high-end apartments. The billionaire and avid sportsman claims he is Britain's biggest income tax payer yet refuses to use offshore tax havens like Jersey or Monaco. Born into a working-class family in Stoke-on-Trent, he made an early bet on the world's mobile future by starting a mobile phone wholesaler in 1987 with his brother, Brian. He bought 26 devices from the United States and sold them for thousands each to British plumbers and businessmen. Then in 1993 the brothers founded the mobile service provider Singlepoint, taking on 1.9 million contract customers before selling it to Vodafone in 2003 for $650 million. Caudwell used the proceeds of that sale to grow his mobile handset wholesaler, by then called Phones4U, into a retail and distribution giant. He  sold a majority stake in Phones4U to Providence Equity Partners in 2006 for $2.8 billion, and a remaining 25% in 2011 for $272 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Jack Dangermond founded the Environmental Systems Research Institute in 1969 with $1,100 of family savings. The mapping software company is now the largest in the world and provides software to 350,000 customers including federal agencies, health departments and schools in half the states across the nation. In October 2012 ESRI acquired Geoloqi, a six-person start-up based in Portland, Oregon, that maps consumer trips. Dangermond studied environmental science at Cal Poly Pomona, urban planning at the University of Minnesota, and landscape architecture at the Harvard Laboratory for Computer Graphics and Spatial Analysis. In February 2011 the Secretary of the Interior appointed him to the National Geospatial Advisory Committee, which provides recommendations on federal geospatial policy. He and his wife recently endowed a geography chair at the University of California at Santa Barbara, donating $2 million to the department.

name: Billionaires
bio: Edson de Godoy Bueno made his fortune from health-plan operator Amil, a company he founded in 1972 and built together with his then-wife Dulce, who is also a billionaire. Edson decided to become a doctor at age 14 and studied for a medical degree at Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro while working at a struggling clinic, which he bought before graduating in 1971. In the past five years Amil bought more than 15 companies, becoming Brazil's largest health care company. At the end of 2012 giant U.S. health insurer United Health Group, looking to expand into Latin America, paid $4.9 billion for a 90% stake in Amil, which had done an IPO in 2007. UHG bought 30% of Amil from public shareholders and 60% from the Buenos. As part of the deal, labeled the "samba project," the Buenos retained 10% of Amil and Edson remained Amil's CEO. Edson became the first foreigner to join the board of United Health and one of the largest individual shareholders of the group, with 0.8%. The Buenos also own shares in Dasa, the largest chain of laboratories in Latin America and in Totalcare, a private holding company that manages direct investments in hospitals in Rio de Janeiro and Sao Paulo

name: Billionaires
bio: In 1965 a young Fred DeLuca borrowed $1,000 from family friend Peter Buck to start a "submarine" sandwich shop in Bridgeport, CT. DeLuca's plan was to offset the cost of his college education with the profits. The result was Subway, the world's largest restaurant chain, with 38,200 worldwide locations (in spring 2011 it overtook McDonalds) and 2012 revenues of $18.1 billion. Subway doesn't own a single location, but collects 8% of revenue from each franchisee. While Buck's role has become less active over the years, DeLuca continues to oversee the company's day-to-day operations. Despite his wealth, DeLuca drives a 11-year-old Lexus convertible. His favorite Subway sandwiches? Vege Delight and Turkey.
title: President and Co-Founder
employment: {'name': "Doctor's Associates (Subway)", 'title': 'President and Co-Founder', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Philippe Foriel-Destezet merged his French staffing firm Ecco with Klaus Jacobs's Swiss firm Adia to create Adecco in 1996. Foriel-Destezet stepped down as co-chairman of Adecco in 2005 and was made an honorary president in 2006. He founded his staffing company in 1964; by the 1980s the firm was France's largest supplier of temporary personnel. Adecco has more than 5,500 branches and more than 33,000 employees in over 60 countries. He serves as the chairman of Akila Finance, a holding company based in Luxembourg. Though a native of France (he was awarded the French Legion of Honor) and a graduate of the prestigious Hautes Études Commerciales (HEC) school of management in Paris, he resides in London where taxes are lower. His business partner, Klaus Jacobs, passed away in 2008.

name: Billionaires
bio: Dr. Phillip Frost made his fortune selling drug manufacturer Ivax to Israel's Teva Pharmaceuticals for $7.6 billion in 2005. A former dermatalogy professor, he got his start in pharma in the early 1970s when he took over Key Pharmaceuticals with partner Michael Jaharis to develop generic drugs and veterinary products. They sold out to Schering-Plough in 1986. Frost went on to found Ivax. Today he is chairman of Teva, which moved from Nasdaq to the NYSE earlier this year. He also has stakes in more than a half-dozen firms, including medical device company SafeStitch, and most recently athlete-focused Musclepharm. In May, Frost hosted a $50,000-a-plate dinner for Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney in his Miami Beach Home. Frost is an active trader, and hold stakes in several public companies. In June, he bought a 45% stake in Israeli vaccine-maker Opko Health.

name: Billionaires
bio: William Fung took over as the chairman of trading firm Li & Fung in May of 2012 as his elder brother, Victor, became honorary chairman after 23 years at the helm.
