A supplier of toys and clothing to retailers such as Wal-Mart and Target, the company's profits tumbled in the past year on sluggish demand in the U.S. and Europe and rising manufacturing costs in China, driving William's fortune down by $1.2 billion. In 2012 the brothers' investment firm bought apparel maker Hang Ten Group Holdings for $340 million. The Fung Group also includes high-end menswear retailer Trinity and Convenience Retail Asia, which operates Circle K convenience stores. The brothers launched the Fung Global Institute in August 2011, funding a $15 million endowment for the Hong Kong nonprofit research group.

name: Billionaires
bio: Tom Gores' Beverly Hills private equity shop Platinum Equity made numerous purchases in 2012, including medical equipment company DMS Health Technologies, car parts supplier SMW Automotive, digital publishing firm Mobile IQ and a majority interest in Caterpillar Logistic Services. In late 2011 Platinum also bought Truesense Imaging, the company responsible for the high-definition photo sensors that captured images of Mars on NASA's rover, Curiosity. Gores also owns Palace Sports & Entertainment, which includes the NBA's Detroit Pistons and related entertainment businesses, including the Palace at Auburn Hills arena. The Michigan native and Michigan State alum started his career in private equity with his billionaire brother Alec.

name: Billionaires
bio: Huang Wei is the chairman of Xinhu Zhongbao, a real estate and investment company based in the eastern Chinese city of Hangzhou. His wealth up more than $600 million from a year ago based on an improved real estate market and better overall economic conditions going into 2013. Huang capitalized on the bullishness in Xinhu Zhongbao in recent months by cutting his holding company's stake from 68% to 64%; he sold $161 million worth of shares between September and December of last year. Xinhu Zhongbao annouced a plan to buy 34% of the Northwest Mineral Group for $121 million, part of a push into the mining industry.

name: Billionaires
bio: After a drawn-out battle and plenty of haggling, Daryl Katz finally got what he wanted: a new stadium in downtown Edmonton for the National Hockey League's Oilers. In January, city officials approved a stadium project to be funded jointly by the city, taxpayers and the Katz-owned Oilers at an estimated cost of $600 million. Katz will own surrounding properties and land around the new stadium. The son of a pharmacist, Katz bought up distressed pharmacies in the late 1990s, amassing an empire of 1,800 drug stores across Canada. In 2012, the Katz Group shed a large number of these pharmacies by selling its Medicine Shoppe pharmacy business and its Drug Trading unit to McKesson Corp. for around $1 billion. The Katz Group now oversees about 450 Rexall pharmacies in central and western Canada.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Suna Kirac is the youngest daughter of Koc Holding founder Vehbi Koc. Since contracting ALS (Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis) also known as Lou Gehrig's disease in 2000, she can communicate only with her eyes. Her husband Inan Kirac is the owner of Karsan, one of the three companies that made it to the final round in the New York Cab Tender, with Ford and Nissan. With her husband, she cofounded the Pera Museum which exhibits anatolian weights and measures, Kutayha glazed tiles and ceramics as well as Orientalist paintings. Her sister Semahat Arsel and brother Rahmi Koc as well as nephews Mustafa, Omer and Ali Koc are also billionaires.

name: Billionaires
bio: Shares of Wilmar International, the world's largest palm oil company, in which he has minority stake and runs as chief executive, fell close to 30% in the past year due to declining profits and depressed palm oil prices. Wilmar is expanding into speciality chemicals in a joint venture with Swiss firm Clariant and processed foods with Archer Daniels. His other investments include a small stake in Zhong Sheng Jian's Yanlord Land and London's Aviva Tower, which he co-owns with Indonesian billionaire and Wilmar shareholder Martua Sitorus. He and Sitorus are investing in property developments located around China's high-speed railways.

name: Billionaires
bio: Kar Po Law owns Lobo Investment, which invests in real estate and hotels such as Singapore's Grand Park Orchard. Strategy for success: buy very low, sell very high and pay close attention to feng shui. His wealth jumped more than $1 billion from a year ago as real estate and hotel values keep soaring. Current project: luxury De Yucca villas set in northern Hong Kong mountain location that was a romantic hot spot for couples in the 1950s and 1960s. Son Allen oversees hotel business; daughter Wendy is executive director of Park Retail Group, which includes 3 Knightsbridge department stores.

name: Billionaires
bio: San Antonio-based Rodney Lewis has been drilling for gas in south Texas for three decades, operating 500,000 acres around the Eagle Ford shale. Experience in the region helped him win a contract to drill just over the border for Mexico's Pemex. Lewis Energy is also producing oil in Colombia. He battled and beat esophageal cancer a few years ago. His passion is World War II-era planes. He now owns 24, perhaps the best collection in the world, topped off by Glacier Girl, a P-38 Lightning dug out of Greenland ice and restored to mint condition. Last year Lewis flew his B-25 bomber at an event memorializing the 70th anniversary of Jimmy Doolittle's famous raid on Tokyo.

name: Billionaires
bio: Friedhelm Loh chairs and owns the private Loh Group, which encompasses a number of companies focused on technology and steel. Rittal, the largest company in the group, supplies enclosures, power distribution gear, climate control and IT infrastructure. Group revenues rose 20% to $2.9 billion (2.2 billion Euros) in 2011. Loh inherited the company when his father, Rudolf, died in 1974. Loh Group is openly committed to social and environmental issues; Friedhelm Loh and company employees regularly donate funds for disaster relief and hunger alleviation. He established the charitable Rittal Foundation in late 2011 on the company's 50th anniversary. Loh is known for his religious beliefs and has established the Christian Media Foundation, which publishes Christian literature. He is also an avid collector of antique cars.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ana Maria Marcondes Penido Sant'Anna and her sister Rosa Evangelina Marcondes Penido Dalla Vecchia join the Forbes Billionaires list thanks to their father, Pelerson Soares Penido, who died in 2012 at the age of 93 and left them shares in CCR Group, Brazil's largest toll-road company by market value. In the 1950s Pelerson played an importnat role in the construction of the country's capital, Brasilia. Later he exchanged his toll-road operation for a stake in CCR, which has been listed since 2002 and holds 38% of STP, which operates the Brazilian versions of electronic payment systems similar to E-Z Pass. Ana Maria is chairman of the board of directors of CCR and has never held office in the administration of other publicly-held companies. She has a degree in business administration from Mackenzie University, in Sao Paulo.
title: Investor

name: Billionaires
bio: Greek shipping heir Philip Niarchos is intensely private. His massive art collection, which includes such masterpieces as Vincent van Gogh's "Self-Portrait with a Bandaged Ear" and Pablo Picasso's self-portrait "Yo, Picasso," is one of the most valuable in the world. A board member of the Museum of Modern Art in New York City, he inherited his father's collection and has added such contemporary works as Jean-Michel Basquiat's "Self-Portrait" and Andy Warhol's "Shot Red Marilyn." Commissioned to do Niarchos' portrait, Warhol created a series based on CAT-scans of his skull. Before fellow billionaire Leon Black bought Edvard Munch's "The Scream" at auction for a record-setting $120 million in May 2012, rumor had it that Niarchos was one of a few serious buyers who were given their own personal viewing.

name: Billionaires
bio: Rubens Ometto Silveira Mello, the world's first ethanol billionaire, is also known as "the tractor." The name comes in part from the fact that his companies harvest sugarcane. It also stems from his ten-year court fight with family members for control of his company, Cosan, which was listed in 2005. Through 10 takeovers in five years he turned Cosan into one of the world's largest growers and processors of sugarcane and one of the largest producers of ethanol. In 2007 he strengthened his grip on the company by setting up Cosan Limited, a firm with a dual share structure that gives some of his shares ten times the voting weight of ordinary shares. At age 24, after graduating from the Polytechnic School of the University of São Paulo, one of Brazil's top engineering universities, he became the youngest financial director of industrial conglomerate Votorantim Group, thanks to his mentor Antônio Ermírio de Moraes.

name: Billionaires
bio: Value investor Wilbur Ross's 9% stake in Bank of Ireland gained in value in early 2013 as the Irish economy started to recover. He has also been buying companies in the distressed assets market. In December 2012 he announced plans to acquire a third of U.K. buyout firm NBNK. Ross is also offloading assets. In October 2012 he sold Homeward Residential, which collects mortgage payments, to mortgage-service lender Ocwen Financial Corp. for $750 million. He has said he wants to bid with a Chinese partner in China's first shale gas tender open to foreign investors by teaming up with Exco Resources, a U.S. natural gas firm in which he holds a stake. He graduated from Yale and Harvard Business School, joined Rothschild in 1976 and became head of it bankruptcy advisory practice. He left in 2000 to start his own company. He has a collection of 20 works by Belgian surrealist Rene Magritte.

name: Billionaires
bio: Brothers Malvinder and Shivinder Singh have continued to transform their fortune, since selling their pharma inheritance in 2008 for $2 billion. They hived off some assets of Fortis Healthcare, among Asia's largest hospital chains, into Religare Health Trust, which listed in Singapore, raising $417 million. In September, they inked a deal to sell 49% stake in asset management arm of Religare Financial to Invesco for $87 million. Their new venture is Air Mantra, a regional airline connecting cities in North India. Malvinder, a Singapore permanent resident, is executive chairman of Fortis; Shivinder is vice chairman.

name: Billionaires
bio: David Sun and his business partner John Tu have been in the computer memory industry for more than 30 years. They founded Kingston Technology, their second company, in 1987, and sold it to venture capital firm Softbank for $1.5 billion in 1996. They eventually bought that stake back three years later for $450 million. Today, Kingston is world's largest independent manufacturer of memory products and employs more than 4,000 people worldwide. The Fountain Valley, Calif.-based company is private and beats competitors on price by using pared-down packaging and closely monitoring supply shipments to avoid holding onto excess inventory. Sun and Tu continue to work in cubicles at the center of the sales floor. Originally from Taiwan, Sun is the president of the David and Diana Sun Foundation, which in the last few years has given millions of dollars to vocational schools and high schools in his birth country.
title: COO

name: Billionaires
bio: Nikolai Tsvetkov chairs Financial Corporation Ursalib, which is involved in banking, insurance, investment, leasing companies, and asset management. At the end of 2012 he attended every Ursalib company's New Year's party, congratulated employees, and sang his own songs from the stage. In 2010 he sold his Kopeyka supermarket chain to X5 Group for $1.1 billion in cash, and he has created a network of companies that produce organic food. He was once a lieutenant colonel in the Russian Air Force, and after he founded Nikoil, later renamed Uralsib, he helped fellow former military officer Leonid Fedun and his boss Vagit Alekperov gain a controlling stake in the company. For his services he was rewarded with a sizable stake in Lukoil. He also owns the legendary  Lomonosov Porcelain, which he restored to its original name, Imperial Porcelain Manufacture, and he is passionate about Eastern philosophy and yoga.

name: Billionaires
bio: John Tu and his business partner David have been in the computer memory industry for more than 30 years. They founded Kingston Technology, their second company, in 1987, and sold it to venture capital firm Softbank for $1.5 billion in 1996. They eventually bought that stake back three years later for $450 million. Today, Kingston is world's largest independent manufacturer of memory products and employs more than 4,000 people worldwide. The Fountain Valley, Calif.-based company is private and beats competitors on price by using pared-down packaging and closely monitoring supply shipments to avoid holding onto excess inventory. Sun and Tu continue to work in cubicles at the center of the sales floor. An active philanthropist, Tu donated $1.2 million to the University of California, Irvine to give an iPad to every first-year medical student at the school in 2011. He was also the main benefactor of the Freedom Writers program, which was started in Long Beach in 1997 as an initiative to improve the academic outlook of students in poor communities. The program spawned a 2007 motion picture starring Hilary Swank. Tu plays drums with his band, JT and California Dreamin'.
title: President

name: Billionaires
bio: Chee Chen (C.C.) Tung has been CEO of Orient Overseas (International) Limited, more commonly known as OOIL, since 1996. The $6 billion (sales) firm, which has 270 offices in 60 countries, is involved in three business areas: container transport, ports and terminals, and property investing. A well regarded Hong Kong businessman, he sits on the board of Cathay Pacific Airways, Wing Hang Bank,  Sing Tao News Corporation Limited and U-Ming Marine Transport . His brother Tung Chee Hwa is a former Hong Kong chief executive.

name: Billionaires
bio: Banking tycoon George Ty, major shareholder of Metrobank, the  Philippines' second largest lender, took his family holding company, GT Capital public last year, raising $330 million; shares are up 40% since. The company increased its holding in Toyota Motor Philippines to 51% after buying shares from Metrobank. Also has stakes in Philippine AXA Life Insurance, Federal Land, Global Business Power Corporation. He reportedly plans to invest close to $1 billion this year in power and property projects. Self-starter founded bank in his twenties; stepped down as chairman in 2006 in favor of son Arthur. Hobbies include swimming and collecting art.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ye Chenghai chairs and owns 74% of Shenzhen Salubris Pharmaceuticals with his family, one of several pharmaceutical industry entrepreneurs to make this year's billionaires list thanks to increased spending in China on pharmaceutical products. Salubris supplies cardiovascular, anti-cancer and anti-infection drugs. Sales in the first nine months of 2012 rose by a quarter from a year earlier to $217 million, boosting net profit by 52% to $70 million. Salubris in November helped to set up the Tsinghua University-Salubris Joint Center For Small Molecule Drug Discovery and Development, and will provide financial support for its operations. Ye's son Kevin is the company's chief executive officer, holds an MBA from Yale and is a U.S. citizen. Ye's daughter, Ye Yujun, is the chief financial officer. Ye is a former vice mayor of Shenzhen, but dropped out of politics in the 1980s.

name: Billionaires
bio: Zhang Zhidong is a cofounder of Internet giant Tencent with fellow billionaire Ma Huateng and serves as the company's chief technology officer. He holds a stake of roughly 3% in Tencent, compared with Ma's 10% stake; his net worth is up by $800 million from a year ago thanks to a 40% jump in price of Tencent shares. Tencent's Twitter-like microblog service QQ has 100 million daily active users. Zhang holds a degree in computers from Shenzhen University, the city where Tencent is headquartered; he also holds a master's degree from South China University of Technology.

name: Billionaires
bio: Anita Zucker inherited her fortune from her late husband, billionaire Jerry Zucker, who died in 2008. Her InterTech Group is a diversified manufacturer that makes specialty chemicals, high-tech fibers and precision aircraft parts like sealing devices and gaskets. She serves as chairman and CEO alongside her son Jonathan, who is president. The company moved up 15 spots to No. 95 on Forbes' list of America's biggest private companies in 2012, pulling in estimated revenues of $4 billion. Zucker owns the Carolina Ice Palace and 50% of the South Carolina Stingrays, a minor league hockey team. She's committed to higher education: This year she pledged $1 million to Trident Technical College, a Charleston trade school, she gave $5 million to the University of South Carolina for aerospace education and she is leading the charge at the University of Charleston to create a vegan/kosher dining hall for students.

name: Billionaires
bio: New Huadu Group Chairman Chen Fashu's fortunes wavered in the past twelve months as lower mineral prices and rising costs pushed net profit at his Zijin Mining down by 17% to $583 million. In January, a once-lauded hire, former China Microsoft boss Tang Jun, left New Huadu Group following years of controversy over the accuracy of his professional background. Chen's once briskly growing Shenzhen-listed New Huadu Supercenter said net profit in first nine months of 2012 increased by only 3.4% to $19 million, leading to drop in its shares. In January, New Huadu Supercenter said Chen's younger brother Chen Zhiyong and elder brother Chen Yunlan would sell all of their personal holdings in the listed company; they owned 6.55% and 0.33% of its shares. His Tsingtao Brewery issued a statement to allay insider trading rumors in June after Chen sold a 2.4% stake in the company for $194 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Emilio Azcarraga Jean is the president and CEO of powerhouse Mexican TV broadcaster Televisa. Grupo Televisa is a leader in content generation in Mexico, producing thousands of hours of original programming, exported to dozens of countries, including the U.S. Azcarraga has declared war on Carlos Slim, the world's richest man, by entering the telecommunication business after Mexican authorities finally allowed him to buy 50% of the shares of mobile phone company Iusacell. He became the CEO of Grupo Televisa after the death of his father in 1997. He is on the boards of Grupo Financiero Banamex and Univision. He is also a global board member of Endeavor, an international non-profit development organization that finds and supports high-impact entrepreneurs in emerging markets.

name: Billionaires
bio: Leon Cooperman outperformed the vast majority of money managers in 2012, guiding his $6.6 billion Omega Advisors hedge fund to net returns of more than 25%. Cooperman grew up in the South Bronx and started his career as a Xerox quality control engineer in 1965. After earning his MBA at Columbia University, Cooperman joined Goldman Sachs, where he rose to the head of the bank's asset management business. He departed in 1991 to found Omega, his own fund management company. His Leon and Toby Cooperman Family Foundation currently has more than $160 million in assets. Cooperman gifted a $20 million life insurance policy to the Jewish Community Foundation in February 2012, the largest gift ever given to that organization; he also gave $25 million to Columbia Business School in April 2012. In his words, "I try to give back to those organizations that have affected me over my lifetime." His other major philanthropic involvements include the United Jewish Appeal, the NJ Performing Arts Center, the Crohn's & Colitis Foundation of America and Paul Tudor Jones' Robin Hood Foundation. Cooperman also serves as Treasurer of the Damon Runyon Cancer Research Foundation, where he oversees the foundation's $60 million endowment.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Henry Fong Yun Wah's wealth is up sharply this year thanks to rising values of the high-rent real estate portfolio built over decades by his unlisted Hip Shing Hong Group in Hong Kong. Son and managing director David Fong has taken the lead on five projects in the past four years, including the boutique Madera hotel in the city's Jordan district and a luxury residential project with New World Development, the flagship firm of fellow billionaire Cheng Yu-tung.

name: Billionaires
bio: In May of 2012 Victor Fung handed the chairman's role in trading firm Li & Fung to his brother William after 23 years at the helm. Founded by their grandfather, the brothers built the company into the leading supplier of clothes and accessories to retailers like Wal-Mart. But a recent profit warning and concerns over the long-term future of the company's business model drove the stock down in the past year, shaving $1.2 billion off Victor's fortune. He hails from Hong Kong but earned an engineering degree from MIT and a Ph.D. in economics from Harvard, becoming a U.S. citizen along the way. He taught at Harvard Business School for four years in the early 1970s.

name: Billionaires
bio: Korean-Japanese businessman, Han Chang-Woo, is chairman and CEO of Maruhan, which owns pachinko parlors, bowling alleys, golf driving ranges and movie theaters. The company's subsidiary, Maruhan Japan Bank, has been expanding in Cambodia, Myanmar and Laos. This past January, Maruhan said it would be an official bid partner for Tokyo 2020 Olympic bid. Chang-Woo is a classical music afficianado who sits on the board of Tokyo Philharmonic. After years of donating to Korean causes, Chang-Woo announced in November 2011 that he would give away almost all of his wealth to solidify relations between Korea and Japan.

name: Billionaires
bio: Inspired by his geologist father, Tim Headington founded Headington Oil in 1978. He stayed under the radar until 2008 when he sold acreage in North Dakota's Bakken oil play to XTO Energy for $1.85 billion. Though still growing the oil business, Headington is funding another passion, moviemaking. Through GK Films, a production company he owns with Graham King, he has bankrolled more than a dozen films including "Hugo," which won five Oscars this year and "Rango," which won for best animated film. It will be years, however, until "Hugo" can make back its $160 million budget. The returns look better for the lower-budget flicks produced by the Film District division, such as "Drive" and "Insidious." Headington has also built two ultra-chic hotels in Dallas, the Lumen and Joule.

name: Billionaires
bio: Daniela Herz-Schnoeckel inherited a stake in Tchibo Holding GmbH (now called Maxingvest) from her father, coffee magnate Max Herz. In 2003 she and her brother, Gunter (also a billionaire), sold their combined 40% stake in the German consumer goods group to their mother and three brothers for an estimated $5 billion. They plowed a chunk of those funds into private equity firm Mayfair SE, which in 2011 acquired 40% of the Vapiano Group, a restaurant chain with 120 locations in Europe, the US and the Middle East. Gunter and his sister bought shipping certification company Germanischer Lloyd in 2006; in December 2012 the company agreed to merge with Det Norske Veritas of Norway. It will be called DNV GL Group and will be one of the largest ship classification companies in the world.

name: Billionaires
bio: Hui Lin Chit is the cofounder of Hengan International, one of China's largest makers of tissue paper, sanitary napkins and disposable diapers. The company's Hong Kong-traded shares have surged 18% since late in 2012, coming after a sales bump of 10% to $1.4 billion in the first half of 2012; profits increased 38% to $206 million due to an emphasis on sales of more profitable items. Sales of tissue paper, the company's top seller, are poised to rise in the second half of 2012 due to expansion of a production plant in Chongqing. He started the company with fellow billionaire Sze Man Bok in 1985. Sze, Hengan's deputy chairman and CEO, owns about 18% of the company.

name: Billionaires
bio: Erman Ilicak founded construction company Ronesans in 1994 in St Petersburg, Russia, growing it to encompass infrastructure projects throughout Central Asia and the Middle East. He also owns shopping malls, office and hotels in Russia. In 2012, Ilicak partnered with Turkish billionaire Aydin Dogan, to invest in Turkish real estate; separately he owns 12 shopping malls in Turkey. Ilicak is also active in the energy sector.

name: Billionaires
bio: Alicia Koplowitz and older sister, fellow billionaire Esther, inherited construction firm Fomento de Construcciones y Contratas from their late father. In 1989 the sisters took over and jointly ran the business until 1997, when Alicia sold her share to Esther for $800 million. While the company is facing severe challenges today in the midst of Spain's financial crisis, Alicia's fortune has done quite well. Over the years she's invested in steelmaker Acerinox, electric utility Iberdrola and Banco Sabadell. She also has a stake in Hospes, a chain of luxury hotels in Spain, and owns hotels in Italy and Miami. Her assets in Spain and England total more than $1 billion. Through her charitable foundation she sends Spanish fellows to study child psychiatry in England and the U.S. at places like Columbia University's Medical Center. In 2009 she was named an honorary member of the Spanish Society of Psychiatrists for her efforts to promote the study and development of child and adolescent psychiatry.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ziyad Manasir's construction firm Stroygazconsulting has close ties with Russia's state-owned gas producer, Gazprom. In 2012 it put into operation the Portovaya pumping station, which sends gas through the Nord Stream pipeline system. The company had sales of more than $11 billion during the year but there's no news of any new projects as big as the Portovaya one. Manasir was born in Jordan, went to Russia as an exchange student and attended the Azerbaijan Oil and Chemistry Institute. While a student, he began buying and selling computers and cars, and he later moved on to trading yellow phosphorus, timber and oil products. In the mid-1990s he bought a construction factory in Tyumen and started building residences for Gazprom workers there. Other big clients of Stroygazconsulting, besides the gas monopoly, include Rosavtodor, a federal agency behind road construction in Russia.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sigfried Meister makes ovens for the professional set. His Rational AG has a 54 percent share of the global market for thermal food preparation appliances - ovens, steamers, and grills - in professional kitchens. Customers include chefs Gordon Ramsey and Paul Bocuse as well corporations like KFC and Hilton Hotels. Meister, an electrical engineer, founded Rational in 1973, owns 63% of the publicly traded company and chairs the supervisory board. Shares have risen over the last year, pushing Meister's net worth up by several hundred million dollars.

name: Billionaires
bio: A. Jerrold "Jerry" Perenchio made the bulk of his fortune selling Spanish-language broadcaster Univision for $13.7 billion in 2007 to a consortium led by fellow Los Angeles billionaire Haim Saban. That deal was the capstone of Perenchio's long career in the entertainment business, which began in 1964 when he founded his own talent agency, representing the likes of Marlon Brando and Elizabeth Taylor. The grandson of Italian immigrants, Perenchio co-promoted the 1971 World Heavyweight bout between Muhammad Ali and Joe Frazier at Madison Square Garden and was a producer of such shows as "The Jeffersons" and "Diff'rent Strokes." Perenchio formed Embassy Communications with "All in the Family" producer Norman Lear, then sold it to Coca-Cola for $485 million in 1985. He reinvested those proceeds in television, buying Univision, with two Latin American media partners, from Hallmark for $550 million in 1992. He is a longtime Republican donor giving several million to super PACs during the recent election cycle to support Mitt Romney and Repbulican causes. Recent charitable gifts include $1 million to the Los Angeles Opera in 2011 and $4.8 million to the UCLA Foundation in 2010 for a surgery endowment and other medicine-related causes.
title: Founder & Owner

name: Billionaires
bio: Sebastian Pinera, a businessman-turned-politician, is in his last full year as his country's first conservative president in decades. He has a PhD in economics from Harvard, founded credit card company Bancard and owned other businesses. After he was elected president in January 2010, Pinera kept his campaign promise to sell his holdings, a popular move. He unloaded his 26% stake in Chilean airline LAN for $1.5 billion, sold the TV channel Chilevision to Time Warner for a reported $150 million, and sold his share of popular soccer team Blanco & Negro. Under his leadership Chile's economy has grown roughly 5% for the past three years, thanks in part to the country's prodigious copper exports. A wave of student protests, worker strikes, and raging wildfires in Torres del Paine National Forest pushed Pinera's approval rating down to 30% as of November 2012. His public blunders, such as using one term when he means another, are known as "pinericosas" and followed in their own Wikipedia page. He is not immediately eligible for a second term.
title: President

name: Billionaires
bio: Anders Holch Povlsen of Denmark took over his family's fashion retail business, Bestseller, at age 28. He is now the CEO and sole owner of the $3.2 billion (sales) fashion player, which sells apparel and accessories to women, men, teenagers and children in 46 markets in Europe, the Middle East, Asia and Canada. The company markets the items under 10 brand names, including Mamalicious, Name It and Vera Moda, and it employs 12,100, a quarter of them in Denmark. Anders' parents, Troels Holch Povlsen and Merete Bech Povlsen, opened the family's first store in 1975 in the small Danish town of Ringkobing. They are still involved in the business, Merete is its chairman and Troels sits on the board, but Anders is now its owner. The family also has an interest, along with two Danish partners in China, in Bestseller Fashion Group China, an independent company that designs collections sold in approximately 5,000 stores in China. Through his organization Wildland, Anders Povlsen is involved in land preservation projects in Scotland and Romania. He has bought land in the area of Leota in the Romanian Carpathian Mountains, to protect it against development and exploitation, and has also been buying up land in the Scottish Highlands, where he now owns a reported 120,000 acres.

name: Billionaires
bio: Paul Ramsay's net worth jumped 40% as shares of his Ramsay Health Care climbed in value. He is the firm's biggest shareholder and chairman. The company has 116 hospitals and other facilities across Australia, Indonesia, the U.K. and France, and treats 1 million patients a year with a staff of 30,000. His decision to start a private hospital in 1964 has proved visionary as he has capitalized on the world's aging populations. He is also a major shareholder of regional television company Prime Media. He sold his stake in soccer team Sydney FC. In late 2011 he donated $300,000 to actor Kevin Spacey's foundation, which supports young actors, writers, directors and producers,

name: Billionaires
bio: Hotel and casino magnate Phillip Ruffin introduced self-serve gasoline at stations in Kansas, one of the first states to allow customers to pump gas without help. He used the cash from his chain of convenience stories to build his first hotel. He earned $2.2 million from an agreement with Total to lease out his convenience store locations to the French oil company. In 2007 he sold the New Frontier Hotel & Casino to Israeli billionaire Yitzhak Tshuva's Elad Group for $1.2 billion after buying the hotel in 1998 for only $165 million. In March 2009 he bought the Treasure Island Resort & Casino from MGM Mirage for $755 million. It is now worth an estimated $1.6 billion. In July 2012 he played in a high-stakes poker tournament for charity put on by fellow billionaire Guy Laliberte, founder of Cirque du Soleil.

name: Billionaires
bio: It's been a busy past year for Naguib Sawiris.The eldest son of Egyptian billionaire Onsi Sawiris sold nearly all his shares in Russian telecom giant VimpelCom, which had acquired the Sawiris' Orascom Telecom in a cash and stock transaction in 2011. Naguib set up Orascom Telecom Media and Technology, which has a 75% stake in Koryolink, North Korea's only cell network. Sawiris sold his stake in Telekom Austria to Mexican billionaire Carlos Slim's America Movil in June 2012. A month later, his Weather Investments entity bought Canadian mining company La Mancha from French nuclear giant Areva for $317 million. Sawiris founded the Free Egyptians Party in the aftermath of Egypt's revolution and has been a vocal opponent of the Muslim Brotherhood; his party did not back the election of President Mohamed Morsi.

name: Billionaires
bio: Peter Sondakh runs Rajawali Group, a conglomerate with interests in mining, plantations, hotels and transportation services. In November 2012 the group paid $50 million to raise its stake in Indo Mines, a firm that trades in Australia and supplies iron concentrates to Asian buyers. The group also owns a stake in railway consortium Bukit Asam Transpacific Railway. In addition the group runs Express, a taxi company traded in Indonesia. Sondakh owns St. Regis Bali,  the Surfers Paradise resort hotel in Queensland, Australia and a home in Beverly Hills. He funded the Rajawali Foundation for Asia at Harvard University, devoted to scholarship about Asia.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sze Man Bok cofounded Hengan International, one of China's largest makers of tissue paper, sanitary napkins and disposable diapers, with fellow billionaire Hui Lin Chit in 1985. The company's Hong Kong-trade shares are up 14% in the past year, pushing Sze's net worth up by $400 million. Sales grew 10% to $1.4 billion in the first half of 2012; profits surged 38% to $206 million on lower prices for raw materials and an emphasis on sales of relatively profitable items. Sales of tissue paper, the company's top seller, are poised to rise in the second half of 2012 due to expansion of a production plant in Chongqing. Sze, Hengan's chairman, owns nearly 19% of the company.

name: Billionaires
bio: Tong Jinquan keeps a very low profile as chairman of Summit Property Development in Shanghai. At a time when many of China's largest real estate developers have listed on a stock exchange, his company remains privately held. Summit's projects include apartments, hotels, offices and shopping malls around the country. Last year Tong sold 80% of a shopping mall in Chengdu to Singapore-listed Perennial China Retail Trust; last year, the same fund reportedly bought a stake in Tong's basket of properties in Shenyang.

name: Billionaires
bio: The man who invented Beanie Babies, Ty Warner, was all over the news in August 2012 for cutting a $20,000 check to a Santa Barbara woman who provided him with driving directions. She was raising money to cover the cost of a vital stem cell procedure unavailable in the United States because she suffers from kidney failure and does not qualify for a transplant. While the Beanie Babies fad has faded, Ty Inc continues to produce the stuffed creatures and pen the whimsical quatrains that accompany each toy. These days a major portion of Warner's wealth is held in his Ty Warner Hotels and Resorts, a portfolio that includes the New York and Santa Barbara Four Seasons hotels. In November 2012 Warner received an offer of $900 million for the NYC property. At roughly $2.4 million per room the transaction would have been one of the richest in the city's history. Warner ultimately walked away from the deal.

name: Billionaires
bio: Unassuming real estate baron John Whittaker is $800 million richer this year thanks in part to new information Forbes discovered about his many real estate and port holdings. In 2011 the press-shy mogul sold one of Britain's best-known buildings, Manchester's massive Trafford Centre mall, to Capital Shopping Centres in return for a nearly one-fourth stake in the group. He is now deputy chairman of the company, which renamed itself Intu as of February 2013 in hopes of creating a stronger brand identity across all of its properties including Essex mall Lakeside, a longtime favorite for Londoners. Whittaker's Peel Group also owns a stake in Pinewood Shepperton, the famous U.K. film studio where the James Bond and Harry Potter films were shot. His Peel Group is also behind MediacityUK, a massive development in the northern English city of Salford that serves as the BBC's official headquarters. Whittaker lives quietly on a private estate called Billown Mansion on the Isle of Man, a self-governing British dependency in the Irish Sea.

name: Billionaires
bio: H. Wayne Huizenga's latest business venture has run into trouble. After the Florida-based serial entrepreneur took industrial cleaning firm Swisher Hygiene public in 2010, the Nasdaq and the Toronto Stock Exchange threatened to delist the stock if the company didn't file revised financial statements. In February 2013 Swisher met the filing deadline but it still faces a shareholder suit over its numbers. Huizenga's fortune started with Waste Management, the trash hauling giant he founded with one trash truck after dropping out of college. He left the company in 1984 and bought Blockbuster video, then sold it to Viacom for $8.4 billion in 1994. He owned the Miami Dolphins for 15 years before selling the team to real estate billionaire Stephen Ross for $1.1 billion in 2009. He still owns a 5% stake and has a Dolphins helmet painted on the tail of his Boeing 737 jet. He also owns a golf course and vineyard property in Tennessee. He has donated to his alma mater, a prep school in Florida called the Pine Crest School, and he gave $4 million to Nova Southeastern University, where the Wayne Huizenga School of Business and Entrepreneurship is named after him.

name: Billionaires
bio: Yvonne Bauer, chief executive of Bauer Media Group, is expanding her international publishing empire. The group, which publishes 570 magazines in 16 countries, acquired Australian magazine publisher ACP Magazines in October 2012, its largest investment since 2008. Bauer's U.S. titles include First for Women, Woman's World and In Touch. Sales were projected to grow 8% in 2012 to $2.9 billion (2.175 billion Euros). That helped raise Bauer's net worth by several hundred million dollars since last year. In December 2010, Yvonne's father, Heinz Bauer, transferred 85% of the family-run business to her. Her sisters Mirja, Nicola and Saskia each hold a 5% share in the company, and Heinz Bauer remains a general partner. Yvonne Bauer is the fifth generation of the family to run the group, which was founded in 1875.

name: Billionaires
bio: Clive Calder, whose wealth comes from selling his Zomba Group for $2.7 billion, started out playing in a band at age 18 to support his mother and sister after his father's death. He moved to London in 1975 and founded Zomba, whose crown jewel was Jive Records. Calder's firm ventured stateside in 1978, signing acts like Billy Ocean and the Cars, Backstreet Boys, Britney Spears, and 'N Sync. In November of 2002 Calder sold Zomba to BMG. Since the sale he has maintained a low profile, living in the Cayman Islands and spending part of his time on charitable foundation Elma Philanthropies, which works in twelve African countries to improve children's education and health.

name: Billionaires
bio: Media mogul Subhash Chandra's biggest asset is Indian TV broadcaster Zee Entertainment, which he started two decades ago and is now run by son Punit. It claims to reach 650 million viewers in 168 countries through 32 channels. Chandra is aiming to reach one billion viewers. The conversion of cable television to digital last year, boosted Zee's shares. Dish TV, group's direct-to-home arm launched a price war against rivals by offering 70 channels free to its subscribers in four cities. Fellow billionaire Savitri Jindal's son Naveen accused Zee of extortion by demanding advertising for favorable coverage. That led to the arrest of two Zee editors and Chandra himself being questioned. Zee denied the allegation. He bought slightly over 10% in IVRCL, a listed infrastructure firm last year sparking speculation about a hostile takeover but later backed out, selling most of stake in October. Chandra, who practices Vipassana, a Buddhist meditation technique, believes the key to happiness is to take success in your stride and not be depressed when you fail.

name: Billionaires
bio: Serial entrepreneur Mark Cuban, a critic of the U.S. patent system, donated $250,000 in December 2012 to the Electronic Freedom Foundation to aide its efforts to reform patent laws. The outspoken Mavericks owner continues to throw barbs at everyone from basketball referees to Donald Trump. Cuban's net worth rose slightly in the past year as a result of a new NBA collective bargaining agreement that added value to NBA franchises. Cuban won the original dot-com lottery, along with fellow billionaire Todd Wagner, when he sold audio and video portal Broadcast.com to Yahoo for $5.7 billion in 1999. His other entertainment vehicles include cable channel AXS, Landmark Theatres and filmmaker Magnolia Pictures.
title: Owner

name: Billionaires
bio: Dulce Pugliese de Godoy Bueno met her ex-husband, Amil founder Edson de Godoy Bueno, in medical school and helped him build the Brazilian health plan operator, starting with the acquisition of a few medical clinics. Amil's IPO was in 2007 and in the past five years it bought more than 15 firms, becoming Latin America's largest health care company. It provides health care, dental care, and discount pharmacy coverage to more than 5 million people. In late 2012, U.S. health insurance giant United Health Group, looking to expand into Latin America, paid $4.9 billion for a 90% stake in Amil, which had done an IPO in 2007. UHG bought 30% of Amil from public shareholders and 60% from Dulce and Edson Bueno. As part of the deal, which was labeled the "samba project," the Buenos retained 10% of Amil. Dulce also own shares in Dasa, the largest chain of laboratories in Latin America and Totalcare, a private holding company that manages direct investments in hospitals in Rio de Janeiro and Sao Paulo. She was an assistant professor in the pediatrics department at Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro, where she also served as academic dean of the undergraduate program and founded the Pediatric Rheumatology Service of the Martagão Gesteira Pediatric Institute. She earned a PhD in management from McCombs School of Business at the University of Texas at Austin.

name: Billionaires
bio: Rafael del Pino y Calvo-Sotelo, new to the Forbes Billionaires list this year, is the second oldest of five siblings - Maria, Joaquin, Leopoldo  and Fernando. In 2008, when their father, billionaire Rafael del Pino y Moreno, passed away, they inherited  Ferrovial, S.A., Spain's biggest infrastructure construction and management company. Founded in 1952 as a railroad construction company, Ferrovial, S.A is a multinational company involved in the design, construction, financing, and operation of transport infrastructure. In 2000, Del Pino y Moreno transferred control of the company to his son Rafael. Today Ferrovial generates close to $10 billion in annual revenues and manages major airports and highways around the world, including London's Heathrow Airport, the Chicago Skyway, the Indiana East-West Toll Road and the Trans-Texas Corridor. It provides municipal services to more than 800 cities and towns in Spain and to the millions who use the Madrid metro system. He is a member of the MIT Corporation and the International Advisory Group of American financial services company Blackstone. Through holding companies he owns about 20% of Ferrovial. He enjoys outdoor sports, from skiing to sailing.

name: Billionaires
bio: Campbell's soup heir John Dorrance III renounced his U.S. citizenship and moved to Ireland in 1994, presumably to avoid paying capital gains taxes, prior to selling his 10.5% stake in the company in 1995-1996. Grandson of the firm's founder, Dorrance cashed out at the perfect time, right before the stock plunged. Since then he's lived quietly in South Dublin, while frequenting the Bahamas with his Finnish wife. In the past Dorrance joined movements to legalize game ranching in Wyoming and fox hunting in Great Britain.

name: Billionaires
bio: Colombian Jaime Gilinski Bacal turned his father's fortune into a multi-billion dollar financial group and debuts on the Forbes World's Billionaires List this year. His father, Isaac, started two ventures, snack foods maker Yupi and plastics firm Rimax. Jaime studied in the U.S. and worked for Morgan Stanley's M&A unit. He moved back to Colombia and bought the Colombian asset of bankrupt bank BCCI, restructured it and flipped it. He did the same thing with Banco Colombia, bringing in George Soros as an investor. In the early 2000s he fused two banks to form Banco GNB Sudameris, which bought HSBC's operations across Latin America in 2012 for $400 million. In Panama with the billionaire Livingstone brothers of the UK, Gilinski won a bid to develop 2,750 acres on the outskirts of Panama City for about $700 million, a project dubbed Panama Pacifico.
title: Investor

name: Billionaires
bio: Former professor Desh Bandhu Gupta founded generics-maker Lupin, 45 years ago and built it into one of the world's largest producers of tuberculosis drugs. With revenues of $1.5 billion, it has 12 factories and 6 research centers in India and Japan. Its biggest market is the U.S. where it claims to be among the top 5 generic firms in terms of prescriptions, selling pediatric and anti-cholesterol drugs, among others. It has forged an alliance with Novartis to sell its asthma drug in India. Daughter Vinita, who sits on Lupin's board and heads its US and Europe operations, got Ernst & Young's Entrepreneur of the Year Award 2012 for Maryland.

name: Billionaires
bio: In 2008 Bahaa Hariri, the eldest son of slain Lebanese Prime Minister Rafik Hariri, split from the family business, now run by his brother Saad, to focus on his own interests. He has invested heavily in Jordan. In partnership with the Jordanian government, his real estate holding company Horizon Group is building a new development in downtown Amman. The project began in 2004 but has been delayed because of the downturn in the real estate market. In 2011 he inaugurated the Rafik Hariri Center for the Middle East at the Atlantic Council, which he hopes will focus on governance in Egypt.

name: Billionaires
bio: Vyacheslav Kantor heads Acron, one of Russia's biggest fertilizer producers. In 2012 Acron planned to spend $800 million for a stake in Apatit, another fertilizer maker, but pulled out and let the holding go to Fosagro, owned by Andrei Guriev, helping to settle differences with that company. The son of a Moscow department store director, Kantor graduated from the Moscow Aviation Institute and set up a computer trading company in late 1980s. Later he became friendly with the governor of Novgorod, Mikhail Prusak, and during privatization bought a local fertilizer producer there, Azot. He renamed Azot Acron and with it began his chemicals empire, which is now publicly traded. He is a passionate collector of paintings by Jewish Russian artists, and he chairs the European Jewish Congress. He spends most of his time at his mansion in Geneva.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mehmet Emin Karamehmet is the owner of Cukurova Holding, which has interests in packaging, chemicals, finance, construction, defense, telecom and media. The bulk of his fortune is tied to Turkcell, Turkey's largest GSM mobile phone operator and the only Turkish company publicly traded on the NYSE. His Russian partner in the company, Alfa, laid a claim to 13.8% shares of Turkcell by alleging that Karamehmet failed to pay his $1.35 billion dollar debt. The UK's Privy Council ruled in January that Karamehmet's company could keep its shares but should pay Alfa the debt owed on the pledged shares. A new court will rule on the amount to be paid and the conditions of payment, but it is expected to be around $2 billion. His shares in Genel Energy. which produces oil in Northern Iraq, have lifted his fortune.

name: Billionaires
bio: Danil Khachaturov is reportedly considering either a private placement or a public offering for his insurance giant Rosgosstrakh, one of Russia's highest-volume insurers. Standard&Poor's has given Rosgosstrakh a long-term credit rating of only BB-. Khachaturov studied construction and finance at Moscow schools and went to work at privately-held BIN Bank and then at Slavneft, an oil company led at the time by billionaire Mikhail Gutseriev. Between 2001 and 2003 Khachaturov and his partners spent $60 million buying 75% of then-insolvent Rosgosstrakh from the government; they purchased the remaining 25% in 2010. They managed to transform the Soviet-era company into an insurance powerhouse with $3.4 billion revenue and $600 million in debt. Selling shares would enable him to reduce the company's debt.

name: Billionaires
bio: Pharmaceutical entrepreneur R.J. Kirk resigned from the University of Virginia Board of Visitors in October 2012, citing a move to Florida. In his most controversial action during his three years on the board, he supported the forced resignation of University President Teresa Sullivan in 2012 (she was later re-instated after public pressure). On the business side, he is focused on biotech start-up Intrexon. He has had plenty of success in the industry. He sold his drug company Clinical Data to Forest Laboratories for $1.2 billion in 2011, and before that sold New River Pharmaceutical to Shire for $2.6 billion in 2007. Son of a drill sergeant, he graduated from Radford University in 1976 and the University of Virginia School of Law in 1979 before launching his first pharmaceutical firm in 1984. He is an avid falconer.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partner and fellow billionaire Henadiy Boholyubov, Ihor Kolomoyskyy controls Privat group, a banking and industrial conglomerate which has faltered this year. Two of the group's ferroalloy plants stopped production because of high energy costs and airlines it owns have declared bankruptcy; plans to IPO oil producer Ukrnafta have stalled. Outside of Private, Kolomoyskyy has a minority stake in Roman Abramovich's steel-maker, Evraz; the company's stock price is down 30% over the past year. With his partner Boholyubov, he opened the world's biggest multifunctional Jewish center, the Menorah Centre in Dnepropetrovsk last fall. Among the guests were Israeli Chief Rabi Shlomo Amar and US ambassador John Tefft.

name: Billionaires
bio: In 2012 George Lindemann Sr. sold his natural gas company, Southern Union, to Texas billionaire Kelcy Warren's Energy Transfer for more than $5 billion in cash and stock. The native New Yorker got his start when he sold his family's eye-care company, Permalens, in 1971. He founded Vision Cable in 1972, and the Newhouse brothers bought the cable TV company a decade later for $220 million. Next he started the cell phone firm Metro Mobile, flipping it to Bell Atlantic for $2.5 billion in 1991, before getting into the energy business. In June, his son Adam had a Salvador Dali painting stolen from his newly opened Manhattan gallery, only to have it anonymously returned a week later. Another son, George Jr., is chairman of the Bass Museum of Art, in Miami Beach. George Sr.'s wife, Frayda, is the chairman of the National Opera Center.

name: Billionaires
bio: NIels Peter Louis-Hansen is the deputy chairman of $2 billion (sales) Coloplast, a Danish health care company that provides medical devices and services in the fields of colostomy, continence and urology. Hansen owns a 21% stake in the public company, making him its largest shareholder. Shares did well in the past year, driving his fortune up $900 million. The firm's products include colostomy bags, catheters and medical implants. Coloplast also makes dressings for wounds. His late father, Aage Louis-Hansen, founded the business in 1957 and took it public in 1983.Louis-Hansen currently manages a foundation, named after his late parents, that funds cultural and scientific initiatives.

name: Billionaires
bio: Shares in David Murdock's Dole Foods have been dropping since fall 2012, driving his fortune down by $300 million. But Dole is in the midst of a promising deal, expected to close in April 2013, to sell its worldwide packaged foods and Asian fresh produce business to Japanese trading house Itochu for $1.7 billion. Murdock founded Dole and is its majority shareholder. He is a health nut who told the New York Times that he wants to live to be 125. He pins his longevity hopes on a strict diet, daily exercise and a lifestyle free of pills or supplements. He dropped out of high school in the ninth grade and worked at a gas station before being drafted into the Army in 1943. After the war he made a small profit buying and selling a dine, and later developed property in Arizona. In 1985 he bought out a failing Hawaiian real estate outfit that owned fruit company Dole. In 2012 he made headlines when he sold the company's most noted holding, 98% of the Hawaiian island of Lana'i, to fellow billionaire Larry Ellison, for a reported $500 million. In 2009 Murdock took Dole, now the world's largest fruit and vegetable producer, public. The same year he received his high school diploma. Murdock's other investments include chassis leasing firm Flexi-Van and cancer drug developer NovaRx, where his son Justin is CEO. Murdock has put $35 million into Duke University's MURDOCK Study; the research effort has enrolled 8,000 participants in an attempt to understand diseases, cures and treatments at the genetic level.

name: Billionaires
bio: Igor Olenicoff's $1.7 billion lawsuit against UBS AG was thrown out by a U.S. federal district court in April 2012. He had claimed that UBS had mismanaged his investments and misled him into evading his tax obligations. In 2007 he pleaded guilty to tax felony charges for stashing more than $350 million in Europe. He paid $52 million in back taxes and was sentenced to two years of probation and 120 hours of community service. He now cooperates with the U.S. government on investigations of foreign financial institutions. Through Olen Properties, he owns more than 6.4 million square feet of office space and nearly 12,000 residential units in Las Vegas, Arizona and Florida.

name: Billionaires
bio: Marvel Entertainment, run by reclusive billionaire CEO Isaac Perlmutter, has continued its string of superhero hits.  In 2012 the film "The Amazing Spider-Man" pushed the character's total franchise gross to $3 billion. "The Avengers" was an even bigger blockbuster in 2012, reaping $1.5 billion in worldwide box-office revenue, the third-highest worldwide gross ever. In the spring of 2013 Marvel and Sony Pictures Entertainment are due to release an anime movie, "Iron Man: Rise of Technovore." Perlmutter emigrated from Israel to the United States with just $250 to his name. His former company, Toy Biz, beat out Carl Icahn and Ron Perelman for control of then-bankrupt Marvel Entertainment Group in 1998. In 2009 Perlmutter sold Marvel, along with the rights to use its more than 9,000 characters, to Disney for $4 billion, with Perlmutter staying on as CEO. He and his wife Laura have endowed a cell biology professorship in their names at the Skirball Institute of Biomolecular Medicine, part of New York University's Langone Medical Center, where Laura is a trustee.
title: Chief Executive Officer
employment: {'name': 'Marvel Entertainment', 'title': 'Chief Executive Officer', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Robert Rich, the chief of his family's food company Rich Products, is also a sportsman, author, Broadway producer and sports team owner. Rich Products Corp., founded by his father, Robert Sr., began with soy-based whipped cream in 1945, and has since expanded to more than 2,000 products. The Buffalo-based food company is expanding abroad to Asia and Brazil as growing middle classes gain an appetite for American desserts. Rich runs three minor league baseball teams and produced the musical Chaplin, which debuted on Broadway in 2012.

name: Billionaires
bio: Moise Safra is the scion of a Middle Eastern billionaire banking family that moved to Brazil. He made news in 2012 when he reportedly bought an office building in London for $810 million. His name is also on a community center being built for Syrian Jews on Manhattan's Upper East Side, scheduled for completion in 2014. He sold his half of Brazilian bank Banco Safra plus stakes in Safra-owned banks in New York, Luxembourg and other locations, to his brother Joseph in 2006 for a sum estimated at $2 billion. Joseph and Moise's deceased brother Edmond had a separate multibillion-dollar banking fortune, part of which he left to his wife Lily, who is also a member of the Forbes Billionaires list. Moise occasionally appears in Brazil's society pages and has an auditorium named after him at the Albert Einstein Israelite Hospital in Sao Paulo.

name: Billionaires
bio: Alexandra Schorghuber (also spelled Schoerghuber) is the widow of Stefan Schorghuber, who inherited a fortune built by his father, Joseph, and died unexpectedly in 2008 at age 47. She has taken her husband's position at private family investment company Schoerghuber Unternehmensgruppe, which oversees stakes in a brewery co-owned with Heineken and Arabella Hospitality, a hotel joint venture with Starwood of the U.S. The group also owns one of Germany's largest real estate companies, Bayerische Bau und Immobilien GmbH. The family is known for its support of modern art and subsidized holidays for underprivileged children and their families.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mexican steel magnate Rufino Vigil Gonzalez is new to the Forbes Billionaires list. He is president of $3.4 billion (market cap) Industrias CH, a steel production and processing company with an annual capacity of more than 5 million tons. Vigil Gonzalez has a 64% stake. Industrias CH is a holding company. Its subsidiaries produce commercial steel, including steel seamed pipes. In 1991 the Vigil family formed Industrias CH and began making a series of acquisitions. In 1999 the holding group merged with Grupo Ruvi, another steel manufacturer. In 2001 it bought out 82.5% of Grupo Simec, a steel smelter with factories in Guadalajara and Mexicali. In 2010 the Simec assets represented 91% of ICH's net sales. The company has 24 steel production and processing units, 16 in Mexico, and eight in the United States and Canada.

name: Billionaires
bio: Wang Yusuo is the chairman of the ENN Group, one of China's largest non-government-controlled energy businesses. His flagship company is ENN Energy Holdings, a Hong Kong-listed distributor of natural gas. Net profit in the first six months of 2012 rose by 16% to $118 million, on sales that increased by 22% to $1.4 billion helped by China's 7% GDP growth last year. ENN Energy last year signed new distribution contracts for the Longyan Development Zone in Fujian Province and the Wenan Industry Park in Hebei Province. ENN in January sold $500 million of zero coupon bonds to raise money for refinancing and general purposes. Wang's wife Zhao Baoju is a non-executive director of the company.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cher Wang (pictured above) chairs HTC, Taiwan's largest mobile phone maker and one of the biggest in the world. Her fortune has gotten whacked as HTC shares have sunk 80% from their peaks in the spring of 2011. The brand has been facing especially tough competion from Apple and Samsung. Revenue in the fourth quarter dropped by 41% to $2.1 billion, and its operating profit margin fell to 1% from a year earlier. HTC projects its margins could slide even lower, to 0.5%, in the first quarter of this year. On the upside, HTC  last year settled all of its outstanding lawsuits with Apple and reached a 10-year licensing agreement. It is a major partner with Microsoft, offering a variety of Windows phones. Wang is the daughter of Taiwanese entrepreneurial icon Wang Yung-ching. Our wealth estimate includes assets held by her husband Wenchi.

name: Billionaires
bio: Kamil Yazici laid the foundation for the Anadolu Group, one of Turkey's largest industrial groups, in the 1950's together with his partner Izzet Ozilhan. The Anadolu Group has investments in beverages, cars, finance and retail as well as food, health, energy, electronics, IT and tourism. It is the world's fiftth largest Coca-Cola bottling company based on sales volume, with 20 bottling facilities in Turkey and across Central Asia and the Middle East. It's flagship company, Anadolu Efes, is the producer of Turkey's number one beer brand, Efes. Last year the company took over the beer operations of SAB Miller in Russia and Ukraine; in turn SAB Miller agreed to take a 24% stake in Anadolu Efes. He published a memoir, "Common Sense."

name: Billionaires
bio: Publishing and real estate tycoon Mort Zuckerman backed Barack Obama in the 2008 presidential race but in 2012 he threw his support behind Mitt Romney, penning op-eds that criticized Obama's economic policies. Zuckerman has reportedly considered getting into politics himself and was said to consider a challenge to New York Senator Kirsten Gillibrand in 2010. In April 2012 fellow media heavyweight James Dolan's Cablevision accused Zuckerman of "a campaign of intimidation and extortion" to facilitate the merger of his New York Daily News with Cablevision's Newsday after the Daily News published a story alleging the New York Knicks, owned by another Dolan company, misled fans about an injury suffered by star player Jeremy Lin. The son of a Montreal tobacco and candy seller, Zuckerman co-founded real estate investment trust Boston Properties and took it public in 1997. In 2006 he donated $100 million to fund a cancer research center in his name. In December 2012 in the wake of the Newtown school massacre, he pledged $200 million to Columbia University for mental health research.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Boston Properties', 'uri': 'companies/boston-properties', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Mohammed Al Issa is one of the largest individual investors in the Saudi stock market. His holdings include major stakes in Savola Group, one of the Kingdom's largest food processors, and Riyad Bank. In December 2012 his son Abdullah was appointed chairman of Saudi Hotels & Resorts Co., which owns and operates hotels in Saudi Arabia, including a Marriott in Riyadh.

name: Billionaires
bio: Hubert Burda is the chief executive officer of Hubert Burda Media, which publishes 300 magazines around the world, including Focus and Bunte in Germany. In late 2012 it lifted its stake in XING AG, Germany's equivalent of professional social network LInkedIn, to 59%. Hubert Burda aims to compete with Google, Amazon and Apple rather than German media groups Gruner + Jahr and Axel Springer AG. Group revenues grew to Eu 2.45 bil. He transferred 40% of the company to his two children, Jacob and Elisabeth, who are in their twenties, in 2011. He owns the remaining 60% (FORBES' estimate of his net worth does not include his children's stake.) An active philanthropist, Burda established the Felix Burda Foundation, which is committed to reducing the number of deaths from colon cancer in Germany, and named after Hubert's son Felix, who died of colon cancer in 2001 at age 33. He also formed the Burda Academy of the Third Millennium, an interdisciplinary forum for researchers and thinkers. Burda is married to well-known German actress Maria Furtwangler.

name: Billionaires
bio: Jose Calderon Rojas and his brother Francisco Jose Calderon Rojas are new to the Forbes Billionaires list. The bulk of their wealth comes from their stake in FEMSA, which was co-founded by their father. FEMSA is the largest distributor of carbonated beverages in Latin America. Jose Calderon has expanded Coca Cola FEMSA, which after a series of acquisitions, became the largest bottler of Coca-Cola products in the world, accounting for one out of every ten Coca-Cola products sold globally. In January 2013 Coca-Cola FEMSA bought 51% of Coca-Cola's bottling operation in the Philippines. The company plans to expand in Asia.
person: {'name': 'Jose and Francisco Jose Calderon Rojas', 'uri': 'jose-and-francisco-jose-calderon-rojas', 'imageExists': False}
personName: Jose and Francisco Jose Calderon Rojas

name: Billionaires
bio: Austen Cargill is one of six secretive billionaire relatives who together still own a majority of Cargill, now the largest private company in the U.S., with $134 billion in revenues in fiscal year 2012 from all areas of food production, including crops, cattle, commodity trading, and risk management. The great-grandson of founder W.W. Cargill, the son of a Scottish sea captain who started a small Iowa grain storage business after the Civil War. His son-in-law, John MacMillan, took control in 1909, and until 1995 the CEO was always a family member. He worked at the company as a marine biologist before retiring in 2001 to a ranch in Montana.

name: Billionaires
bio: James Cargill is one of six secretive billionaire relatives who together still own a majority of the agro-giant Cargill, now the largest private company in the U.S. Cargill's $134 billion in revenues in fiscal year 2012 came from all areas of food production, including crops, cattle, commodity trading, and risk management. James is the great-grandson of founder W.W. Cargill, the son of a Scottish sea captain who started a small Iowa grain storage business after the Civil War. His son-in-law, John MacMillan, took control in 1909, and until 1995 the CEO was always a family member. James has two adopted children.

name: Billionaires
bio: Jim Davis is chairman and owner of New Balance, a company he bought in 1972 on the day of the Boston Marathon. The company has expanded to include apparel and equipment for sports including soccer and lacrosse. In January the company signed a deal with Walt Disney Parks & Resorts, making New Balance the official athletic shoe in Disney resorts. The company has kept some of its manufacturing facilities in the U.S. and 25% of New Balance shoes sold in North America are made or assembled there. In 2011 Davis purchased two parcels of land in Boston near the current company headquarters. Plans for the site include a hotel, sports complex and office buildings. The Massachusetts Department of Transportation plans to build a new commuter rail station to serve the development. Davis also owns property in nearby Gloucester, Mass, including a summer home, the original Birds Eye plant and a stake in the cruise port.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Audio tech titan Ray Dolby died on Sept. 12, 2013 after suffering from Alzheimer's Disease and acute leukemia. He was 80.The founder of Dolby Laboratories, he played clarinet as a child and became fascinated with reed vibrations. Audio and video company Ampex hired him at age 16 to develop electrical components of its tape recording system. He earned a Ph.D. in physics at the University of Cambridge. In 1963, Dolby took up a two-year appointment as a United Nations adviser in India, and then returned to London to found Dolby Laboratories in 1965. He made his fortune with audio-processing systems that eliminate background noise. The first inception of the system was used on the soundtrack of the 1971 hit "A Clockwork Orange." He took Dolby public in 2005. He is survived by wife Dagmar, who assumed control of the family's Dolby shares after Ray's death, and two sons.
title: Founder and director emeritus
employment: {'name': 'Dolby Laboratories Inc.  (Cl A)', 'title': 'Founder and director emeritus', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Ralph Dommermuth built one of the leading Internet service providers in Germany and with it, a multi-billion-dollar fortune. He owns over 40% of publicly traded United Internet AG, which also provides email services and storage and is pushing the growth of mobile applications in Germany and internationally. Shares of the company have risen in the past year, adding several hundred million dollars to his net worth. Dommermuth started in 1988 by offering marketing services for small software suppliers and later developed marketing services for clients such as IBM, Compaq and Deutsche Telekom. An avid sailor, Dommermuth and his company sponsored the United Internet Team Germany in the 2007 America's Cup.

name: Billionaires
bio: Alexander Dzhaparidze was the major shareholder in Eurasia Drilling Company, an oilfield services concern, until in 2011 he sold his 22% stake in it, estimated at more than $1 billion, to buy a piece of Hadar Fund, a mysterious investment vehicle. He said he simply want to diversify, but there is as yet no data to indicate the success of Hadar. He is a geologist who predicted the pent-up demand in post-Soviet Russia's deteriorating oil sector, and in 1995 he set up PetroAlliance, an oil services firm. Eight years later he sold PetroAlliance to the oil-services giant Schlumberger, and a year after that, with Russian oil companies consolidating and shedding assets, he teamed up with partners including former Halliburton managers to buy Lukoil's well-drilling business. In 2007 he helped orchestrate Eurasia Drilling's public offering, in London.

name: Billionaires
bio: The onetime Democratic candidate in Florida for the U.S. Senate, Jeff Greene, is continuing to snap up real estate properties, particularly in Palm Beach. In November, he paid $34 million for 150 condos in City Palms in West Palm Beach, bringing his total number of units in South Florida to 1,150. He also has 3,500 Los Angeles apartments. Last year he bought a spot in the West Village he plans to eventually convert into residential condos. He also owns several luxury homes in Palm Beach, Beverly Hills and Palm Beach. Greene put himself through Johns Hopkins working as a busboy at the Breakers Hotel in Palm Beach, teaching Hebrew School part-time and checking IDs outside a gym. He also traveled the country selling circus tickets to pay his way through Harvard Business School. He made his fortune buying credit default swaps on subprime mortgage-backed bonds as housing crashed in 2007 (an idea he got from hedge fund tycoon and then good friend John Paulson).

name: Billionaires
bio: Bill Gross heads the world's largest mutual fund, PIMCO's Total Return, which ended 2012 with more than $285 billion in assets under management. "The Bond King" co-founded Pacific Investment Management Company, LLC, or PIMCO, in 1971 and sold a 70% stake to Allianz SE in 1999 for $3.3 billion. Today, PIMCO, still under parent company Allianz, manages more $2 trillion in assets as of December. After a year of net outflow in 2011, the first since its inception in 1987, PIMCO's Total Return, brought in about $18 million of net new cash in 2012. Gross got his start in Las Vegas where he spent four months playing blackjack after college and turned $200 into $10,000. He became an investment superstar after discovering that the key to profits was to trade bonds, not to buy and hold them. He and his wife are behind the William and Sue Gross Family Foundation, an annual contributor to Columbia University, Doctors Without Borders and the Smithsonian's National Postal Museum, which is building the 12,000-square foot William H. Gross Stamp Gallery. An active philatelist, Gross donated about $9.1 million from the proceeds of his stamp collection auction to Doctors Without Borders in 2007.
title: Cofounder and Co-Chief Investment Officer
employment: {'name': 'Pacific Investment Management Company LLC', 'title': 'Cofounder and Co-Chief Investment Officer', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: David Hains owns one of Australia's biggest and most private hedge funds, Portland House Group, based in his hometown of Melbourne. The firm, which mostly trades equities, bonds and currencies, and focuses on the U.S. markets, is mainly run by sons now. The former engineer stopped working for 7 years in late 1960s to improve his golf game with legendary Australian coach Norman von Nida. He later became well-known for restructuring companies like U.S. steelmaker Wheeling-Pittsburgh. He is also an active horse breeder and racer though his Kingston Park Stud.

name: Billionaires
bio: Peter Hargreaves co-founded Hargreaves Lansdown out of a spare bedroom in Bristol, England, in 1981. It's now one of the U.K.'s largest financial services firms with about $48 billion in assets under management, and Hargreaves is executive director. Before starting the firm Hargreaves, as a Chartered Accountant, held positions at KPMG, Unisys Group and Whitbread Plc. The company's online investment management system, named Vantage, contributed 78% or $290 million (GBP 186 million) to the company's top line last year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Henry Hillman is the son of industrialist J.H. Hillman, Jr., who owned Pittsburgh Coke & Chemical. He diversified the family fortune through his investment firm the Hillman Co., investing in real estate, private equity and venture capital. He was a founding investor in influential Silicon Valley venture capital firm Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, and LBO titan Kohlberg Kravis Roberts. Formerly the owner of downtown Pittsburgh's PPG Place, he has since sold it. In 1964, Hillman began expanding the Hillman Foundation, set up by his father in 1951. It now includes 18 regionally focused foundations run by different members of the Hillman family. His focus remains in Pittsburgh. The University of Pittsburgh Cancer Center bears his name, and he funded Traffic21, a Carnegie Mellon-based project devoted to improving transportation efficiency.

name: Billionaires
bio: Vladimir Kim is chairman of copper miner Kazakhmys and former member of Kazakh President Nazarbayev's political council. In May 2012, Kim announced he would step down as Kazakhmys chairman by mid 2013 in order to make way for an independent chairman to bring the company in line with the UK Corporate Governance Code. At the time, he indicated he would not reduce his shareholding. In October, however, Kim upped the portion of shares that are leveraged as collateral for loans; he has now leveraged two thirds of his stake, up from 8 percent last year. There is no indication as yet as to what the extra money is to be used for; speculation is rife he may be planning to sell-off. Kim is a descendent of Koreans forced by Stalin to move to Kazakhstan. He joined Kazakhmys during Khazakstan's early 1990s privatization wave.

name: Billionaires
bio: New England Patriots owner Robert Kraft saw his team reach the playoffs in 2013 for the tenth time in the past twelve seasons, but the Patriots didn't make it to what would have been their sixth Super Bowl appearance. Kraft has built one of the most successful NFL teams on the field and off since he bought it for $172 million in 1995. His observant Jewish father was a dressmaker in Boston's Chinatown who wanted his son to be a rabbi, but Kraft went to Harvard Business School instead. He joined, then bought packing firm Rand-Whitney. Today the Kraft Group owns real estate, paper companies, and the New England Revolution soccer team. Myra Kraft, his wife of 47 years, passed away in July 2011.
title: Chairman & CEO
employment: {'name': 'The Kraft Group', 'title': 'Chairman & CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: The fourth "wife" of Stanley Ho (they never officially married), Angela Leong emerged with control of Ho's core gambling business, SJM Holdings, fending off challenges from other factions in the tycoon's family. A former dance instructor from Guangzhou, she took over as managing director of the gaming empire in late 2010. The company lost its monopoly on Macau's casino industry in 2004, but SJM still controls the largest share of the enclave's gaming market. A two-term legislator in Macau, she plans to seek reelection this year

name: Billionaires
bio: Marianne Liebmann is the great-granddaughter of founder W.W. Cargill, the son of a Scottish sea captain who started a small Iowa grain storage business after the Civil War. His son-in-law, John MacMillan, took control in 1909, and until 1995 the CEO was always a family member. The agro-giant is now the largest private company in the U.S., with $134 billion in revenues in fiscal year 2012 from all areas of food production, including crops, cattle, commodity trading, and risk management. Marianne is one of six secretive billionaire relatives who together still own a majority of Cargill. She owns a flower shop in Montana.

name: Billionaires
bio: Alexander Mamut was trained as a lawyer but made his fortune as an investor. In December 2012 he sold his 50% stake in the mobile phone chain Evroset to Alisher Usmanov, and Usmanov's cellular operator Megafon, for more than $1 billion. The deal brings Mamut not only cash but also Usmanov's 50% of the Internet company SUP Media. Now Mamut owns SUP Media outright. SUP owns, among other things, LiveJournal.com, Russia's most popular blogging platform, which began in the U.S. and which Mamut bought in 2007. He holds substantial stakes in Polymetal and Uralkali, and in 2011 he purchased the British bookstore chain Waterstone's, founded by his friend Tim Waterstone. He graduated from Moscow State University and gained notoriety in the late 1990s during the Bank of New York money-laundering scandal, when he became known as "the Yeltsin family banker." No charges were filed against him in connection with the case. He was one of the founders of Imperial Bank, at one point ran MDM-Bank, and was a major investor in the Troika-Dialog investment bank and Ingosstrakh insurance company. In recent years he has preferred to be a portfolio investor, putting money into real estate, retail, telecom, construction, and oil fields. He is one of the founders of the Strelka Institute for Media, Architecture and Design, a cultural and educational center.

name: Billionaires
bio: Masahiro Miki founded ABC-Mart, a discount retailer of shoes in 1985. Last year ABC spent $138 million to acquire LaCrosse Footwear, a NASDAQ-listed maker of premium work and outdoor footwear. Miki plans to expand LaCrosse throughout Asia and Europe, while also growing his network of some 680 stores in Japan as well as 120 in Korea, Taiwan and Hong Kong. The company's stock price is up 18% over the past year. Miki is a former amateur boxer.

name: Billionaires
bio: Michael Miken made billions in leveraged buyouts in the 1980s.
