In 1990 the former Drexel Burnham Lambert partner pled guilty to securities fraud after the government agreed to drop charges against his younger brother, Lowell. After serving 22 months in prison, he has devoted himself to philanthropy and investing in education companies. A prostate cancer survivor, he has given millions to efforts to eradicate the disease. He also founded the Milken Institute, a non-profit economic think tank. He invested in education companies like interactive toy maker LeapFrog and educational software outfit K12. In December 2010 he signed the Giving Pledge, promising to donate at least half his wealth to charity.

name: Billionaires
bio: A reclusive Canadian billionaire, Robert Miller rarely gives interviews, doesn't attend public ceremonies and does not allow his picture to be taken. In 1968, Miller founded Future Electronics with partner Eli Manis to sell and distribute electronic components. Eight years later, he bought out his partner for $500,000. Today, the Quebec-based company is one of the world's largest electronics distributors and has operations in 169 locations in 42 countries in the Americas, Europe and Asia. Miller's estimated net worth is down about $200 million from a year ago due to lower values for publicly traded competitors. Miller believes in cryonics, the science of freezing bodies to restore life later on, and supports the cryonics-focused Alcor Life Extension Foundation. He is also a commercial real estate investor and was embroiled in a lawsuit with his former wife regarding a Florida housing development.
title: President and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Future Electronics', 'title': 'President and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Pan Zhengmin's fortunes have soared on the updraft of the smartphone boom. He is CEO of AAC Technologies, a maker of acoustics components that counts Apple among its customers. A profit surge of 58% in the first nine months of 2012 helped to fuel gains in AAC shares and Pan's wealth. Pan's wife, company co-founder Ingrid Wu, is a non-executive and shares his fortune.

name: Billionaires
bio: The lone American among the billionaires at Swiss commodities trading giant Glencore, Tor Peterson Peterson officially became a billionaire thanks to Glencore's May 2011 IPO. He joined the firm in 1992 following a six year stint at Phibro-Salomon in New York where he worked as a commodities marketer. In 2002 Peterson succeeded current Glencore CEO Ivan Glasenberg as director of the coal and coke department. The firm announced plans to merge with mining outfit Xstrata in February 2012. The proposed all-stock "merger of equals" is currently awaiting regulatory approval in China.

name: Billionaires
bio: Thomas Pritzker, the chairman of Hyatt Hotels, has one of the more public roles of the 10 billionaire members of the extended Pritzker family. He's expanding from high end hotels to emerging markets--the venture he cofounded to look for opportunities in Iraq has announced its first major project, an upgrade of a Persian Gulf port. In 2007, the family sold control of industrial conglomerate Marmon Holdings to Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway for $4.5 billion. Tom's grandfather A.N. Pritzker (d. 1986), with his sons Jay (d. 1999), Robert (d. 2011) and Donald (d. 1972), created Marmon and the Hyatt hotel chain. Tom remains chairman of Marmon Holdings and sits on the board of Royal Caribbean Cruises. He's a trustee at the University of Chicago and chairman of the Art Institute of Chicago; a Director and Vice President of The Pritzker Foundation; Chairman and President of The Hyatt Foundation and President of the Pritzker Family Philanthropic Fund.
title: Executive Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Richard Rainwater, the legendary Fort Worth dealmaker, a friend and mentor to tycoons like Eddie Lampert, David Bonderman, Ken Hersh and the Bass brothers, is now mentally incapacitated, struggling since 2009 with a rare neurodegenerative disease, progressive supranuclear palsy. Often mistaken for Parkinson's disease, it strikes just 6 people in 100,000. Seeking a cure, Rainwater's family has organized a genius-filled group of researchers dubbed the Tau Consortium. Any advance is unlikely to help Rainwater, but could lead to future breakthroughs in treating dementia. In happier news, Rainwater's wife, Darla Moore, a legendary investment banker in her own right, was one of the first two women admitted in August as members at Augusta National Golf Club. (Condoleezza Rice was the other.)

name: Billionaires
bio: Kerry Stokes eked out a gain in his net worth despite falling demand for heavy earth-moving equipment, the core of his Seven Group Holdings. He also suffered a decline in his second-string media assets. One shift that helped boost his fortune: at his three Caterpillar franchises--two in Australia and one in China--margins on spare parts and maintenance are now higher than on new equipment. He exited pay-TV outfit Consolidated Media Holdings along with fellow billionaire James Packer and collected a $500 million windfall. Stokes started with a franchise to sell Cat tractors and trucks in Australia and then expanded into China where demand is surging. Once regarded as a minor player in newspapers and television, his Seven Group has a bigger market share in Australia than the country's better-known media baron, fellow billionaire and U.S. citizen Rupert Murdoch. Stokes is a keen skier and swimmer and an avid collector of Australian art and military memorabilia.

name: Billionaires
bio: Wang Chuanfu is chairman of BYD, one of the country's largest non-government controlled automakers, and a company 10% owned by a unit of Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway. Like BYD vice chairman Lu Xiangyang, who also makes this year's billionaires list, Wang has seen the value of his BYD shares shrivel in the past couple of years after a botched overexpansion. BYD's net profit in the first nine months of 2012 dropped 94% amid slow sales, and the company suffered a public relations disaster when one of its "green" vehicles caught fire in Shenzhen after a collision. Wang was named China's richest man in 2009 with wealth of $5.8 billion.

name: Billionaires
bio: Zhu Zingliang is the biggest shareholder and a director at Suzhou Gold Mantis Construction Decoration, China's largest interior designer. The company has done interior and exterior decorating, landscaping, design and other work for some of China's best-known new structures, including the Bird's Nest National Stadium and the National Grand Theatre in Beijing. Gold Mantis has also worked with a who's who of billionaire-controlled real estate developers across China, including Soho China, Shimao Group and Wanda Group, and has designed and decorated five-star hotel interiors in China for brands such as InterContinental. The company, a debut member of the Forbes Asia Fab 50 list in 2012, acquired U.S. interior designer Hirsch Bedner Associates last December. Zhu's wealth is up from a year ago on a rise in domestically traded Gold Mantis shares, on expectations of easier real-estate lending conditions in China in 2013.
title: Entrepreneur

name: Billionaires
bio: Abdullah Al Rajhi, together with brothers Sulaiman, Mohammed, and the late Saleh, formed Al Rajhi Bank more than 50 years ago. One of the largest Islamic banks in the world, it has $71 billion in assets. Sulaiman is also a billionaire thanks to his stake in the bank. Abdullah holds a stake in Islamic bank powerhouse Al Baraka Banking Group, founded by fellow billionaire Saleh Kamel. He also owns stakes in cement and agriculture companies.

name: Billionaires
bio: Herbert "Herb" Allen controls reticent investment banking house Allen & Co. and is the largest known individual owner of Coke stock, holding more than 12 million shares after the company's August 2-for-1 stock split. Founded as an investment partnership in 1922 by Allen's uncle Charles, Allen was named president of the firm's nascent underwriting business in 1966 at the age of 26. In the summer of 1982 Allen & Co. sold Columbia Pictures to the Coca-Cola Company. The transaction landed Allen on Coke's board and secured Allen & Co. a lucrative spot on many of the  soda maker's subsequent deals. Since Allen's son Herbert A. Allen III took over as CEO of the family business in 2002, the firm has had a hand in high-profile tech IPOs including Google, Zynga, Zillow, Groupon, Facebook, LinkedIn, and Yelp. Allen & Co.'s annual Sun Valley conference brings out many of the biggest names in the media and technology industries each summer.

name: Billionaires
bio: Nadhmi Auchi was once a middle man for major oil companies and state-owned oil fields in the Gulf. He settled in Britain in 1980 after fleeing Saddam Hussein's Iraq. After an abysmal year in 2011, his company, General Mediterranean Holdings (GMH), made a strong showing in 2012, boosting his fortune by $700 million. GMH owns hotels and office buildings in France, the U.K., the Middle East and Chicago. GMH also invests in construction, pharmaceutical and finance companies. Auchi owns a stake in Egyptian billionaire Naguib Sawiri's Orascom Telecom. He owns Team Lebanon of the A1 Grand Prix Race series.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fernando Belmont, a Peruvian entrepreneur residing in Lima, is new to the Forbes Billionaires list. He owns Yanbal International, a fast-growing door-to-door cosmetics company with estimated sales of $720 million. He became head of the company in 1988 when he and his brother Eduardo decided to dissolve their partnership in then-jointly-owned Yanbal and each run his own beauty enterprise. He has since expanded the firm to Spain and to eight Latin American countries. His favorite hobby is golf.

name: Billionaires
bio: Casino magnate Neil Bluhm is currently expanding his gambling operations (already in the Southern U.S. and Canada) into Massachusetts. The former lawyer cofounded JMB Realty with his University of Illinois roommate in 1970. He later started the real-estate-focused private equity firm Walton Street Capital in 1994. He still has stakes in both Walton Street Capital and a piece of JMB Realty, which owns, manages and develops commercial property throughout North America. His Bluhm Family Charitable Foundation gives to a variety of causes, including the Art Institute of Chicago and The Jewish United Fund.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chu Mang Yee, the chairman of real estate developer Hopson Development returns to this year's billionaires list after the company's share price more than doubled last year amid optimism about a recovery in China's property market. Hopson shareholders also enthused about a plan to buy about $1 billion of assets from a company own by his Chu's son Chu Yat Hong. Chu's daughter Chu Kut Yung is a member of Hopson's board.  Hopson raised $300 million in a debt sale in January.

name: Billionaires
bio: In 1954, chiropractor Jacques Courtin set up his first spa in a Parisian suburb. His skin-firming, circulation-boosting massages were an immediate hit, as were the essential oils he used as part of his new skin line, Clarins. By the late 1970s, the company was such a success that Courtin affixed "Clarins" to his surname.Today Clarins is an international powerhouse, with 2011 revenues of $1.6 billion according to Women's Wear Daily's annual cosmetics report. The quintessential French beauty brand has also made Jacques' sons Olivier and Christian billionaires. The Courtin-Clarins brothers and their families own 100% of the company, having spent $3.6 billion taking it private in 2008. What started as one massage table is now a cosmetics empire: as well as their namesake skincare brand, the Clarins Group owns the fragrance divisions of top jewelers David Yurman and Swarovski and an 85% stake in French fashion house Thierry Mugler.

name: Billionaires
bio: Reality TV pioneer John de Mol's latest hit, singing competition "The Voice," is licensed in 50 countries.The Chinese version has taken off, racking up hundreds of millions of viewers. He has a new show coming out in the United States, called "The Winner Is..." He made his first fortune with the production company Endemol, which created international hits "Deal or No Deal," "Fear Factor," and "Big Brother." He sold Endemol to Spanish telecom giant Telefonica in 2000, but he's bought back into a small stake in the company since then. De Mol now works through his new production company, Talpa Media, which has an independent U.S. division.

name: Billionaires
bio: The youngest son of Gap founders Doris and Donald Fisher (d. 2009), John Fisher is the only one of the couple's three sons who is not on the company's board. A sports enthusiast, he owns the majority of Major League Baseball's Oakland A's, who had a resurgent 2012 season, and has stakes in Major League Soccer's San Jose Earthquakes and Scotland's Glasgow Celtic football club. Like his brothers William and Robert, he went to Princeton and Stanford University's Graduate School of Business. John is president of Pisces Inc., the Fisher family's investment management company, and chairs the board of the KIPP Foundation, which trains and funds teachers for the KIPP public charter school network.
title: President

name: Billionaires
bio: Fu Liquan vaults into the ranks of the world's billionaires this year thanks to soaring shares of his security and surveillance equipment firm Zhejiang Dahua Technology, of which he is chairman. The company's Shenzhen-listed shares have more than doubled in the past year as sales in the first nine months of the year increased by half to $353.7 million, helping to increase net profit by 85% to $60.8 million. In October Dahua announced plans to invest up to $57 million to build more production capacity in Hangzhou. Fu's hobbies include golf.

name: Billionaires
bio: An emerging face of irresponsible capitalism in Africa, Dan Gertler took his family's fortune in diamonds (his grandfather was the first president of the Israeli Diamond Exchange) and invested it in mining assets in the Democratic Republic of Congo. While in his 20s, he became a friend of Joseph Kabila, who then ran the military and is now the DRC's president. Since Kabila became president, Gertler has paid state-owned entities undisclosed amounts for mining rights; good governance and other nonprofit groups have accused him of using his ties to the president to pay below market levels, essentially robbing the government of the land's great resource wealth. Questions regarding the deals have led the IMF to halt loan payments to the DRC. Eurasian Natural Resources Corporation, which co-owned Camrose Resources, a copper-mining concern, with Gertler, agreed in late 2012 to buy up 49.5% of it from him for $550 million (it had purchased 50.5% of the company for $175 million in 2010), apparently to distance itself from him and the controversy around him. He owns his stakes in these concerns through a holding company in the tax haven of Gibraltar.

name: Billionaires
bio: Esther Grether is one of the biggest individual shareholders in watch maker Swatch Group, whose shares are up lately thanks in part to its January announcement that it would buy jeweler Harry Winston for $1 billion. Grether also chairs a beauty and health care products company she inherited from her late husband in 1975; she runs it with her daughter's involvement. Her collection of 20th century art is one of the most valuable in the world and reportedly includes more than 600 pieces by artists including Pablo Picasso, Paul Cezanne, Salvador Dali, Francis Bacon and Alberto Giacometti.

name: Billionaires
bio: Matriarch Indu Jain chairs Bennett, Coleman & Co., India's biggest media house, run by her sons, Samir and Vineet. It publishes 13 newspapers and 18 magazines including daily newspaper, The Times of India,  and business daily, The Economic Times. It also owns Times Now, country's leading English news channel, and FM radio network Radio Mirchi with 32 stations. It has a long-running trademark dispute with the  UK's Financial Times over a supplement called the Financial Times published by Bennett Coleman's Times Publishing House which is being fought in Indian courts. Her granddaughter Trishla is Bennett, Coleman's executive director and sits on board.
title: Artist

name: Billionaires
bio: Jiang Bin, the founder and chairman of electronics components maker GoerTek, has seen his net worth rise by several hundred million dollars in the past year as GoerTek shares climbed amid growing shipments of acoustic components to customers such as Samsung, Sony and Lenovo. GoerTek sales in the nine months through September 2012 rose to $723 million; net profit increased by nearly two-thirds to $93 million. In late December GoerTek announced a manufacturing joint venture with Travice of South Korea; GoerTek will invest $3.2 million for an 80% stake in a facility to be located in Vietnam. Back at home, GoerTek is gearing up to expand its research staff in Qingdao. Jiang's wife, Hu Shuangmei, is a deputy general manager at GoerTek. Jiang's brother, Jiang Long, is GoerTek's vice chairman.

name: Billionaires
bio: Li Shufu is chairman of Geely Auto, one of China's largest non-government controlled automakers. Geely's Hong Kong-listed shares more than doubled in the past year as shipments in 2012 climbed 15% from a year earlier to 483,483 vehicles. Geely, one of Forbes' Fab 50 top-performing big companies in Asia, is targeting 16% growth this year as it moves into the electric vehicle business through a planned joint venture with Nasdaq-listed Kandi Technologies Group which, like Geely, is headquartered in Zhejiang Province. Li holds a master's degree in engineering from Yan Shan University and is a member of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference, a central government consultative political body.

name: Billionaires
bio: Li Sze Lim chairs Guangzhou R&F Properties, which has 42 real estate projects under way in China. Profit was down 35% in the first half of 2012, but shares more than doubled last year on expectations for a recovery in property prices this year, boosting his wealth by nearly $600 million. Li started the firm with fellow Chinese billionaire Zhang Li.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mohamed Mansour and his two brothers are rapidly expanding outside of Egypt through their holding company Mansour Group. Some 60% of the company's revenues now come from other countries. Sales at the group's General Motors dealership took a hit following the uprising in Egypt, but are climbing back, and its Caterpillar dealerships in Russia, Africa, and Iraq continue to generate strong revenues. Last year the Mansour Group's private equity arm, Man Capital, bought U.S.-based OTS Logistics Group for $360 million. Interests in Egypt include Philip Morris and McDonald's franchises.The Mansours also own the largest supermarket chain, Metro, which recently received an offer from Emirati billionaire Majid Al Futtaim for up to $300 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: No longer involved in day-to-day operations at Sequoia Capital because of an incurable medical condition, venture capitalist Michael Moritz has turned his focus to philanthropy. A signatory of the Giving Pledge, the Welsh-born former journalist pledged $5 million to the Juilliard School in February, following a $115 million pledge to his alma mater, Oxford University, in July. As a partner at the Menlo Park, Calif.-based firm, he's invested in some of Silicon Valley's biggest companies, among them Google, LinkedIn, Yahoo and PayPal. He also flipped Zappos to Amazon for $1.2 billion in 2009. Sequoia portfolio companies Palo Alto Networks and Kayak.com both went public in July. Travel firm Priceline announced that it would acquire Kayak for $1.8 billion in cash and stock only three months later, in a deal that is yet to close as February. Though they missed out on Facebook--a young Mark Zuckerberg infamously showed up late to a funding pitch in pajamas--Sequoia was a backer of Instagram, investing $50 million at a $500 million valuation in April before it was bought by the social networking giant. Moritz maintains board a board seat at LinkedIn. A vocal supporter of Manchester United Football Club, Moritz wrote a series of opinion pieces that opposed the team's stock offering on the NYSE in August. He has also used his pen to back immigration reform that will allow more foreign-born entrepreneurs and engineers to obtain visas and come to the U.S.
title: Investor

name: Billionaires
bio: Two-wheeler tycoon Brijmohan Lall Munjal's Hero Group seems to be losing ground, two years after breaking off ties to its longtime partner Honda Motors. With rivals, including Honda, closing in, it has reported a drop in net earnings in the last two quarters. To compound its woes, workers at its factory near Delhi went on a hunger struck for higher wages. The company, which has technical alliances with Italian design firm Engines Engineering, Austrian engine maker AVL, is reportedly working on a new 250 cc bike with American performance bike maker Erik Buell Racing. It has appointed distributors in Sri Lanka, Nepal and Latin America and is apparently looking to expand to Africa. Despite moves, shares of flagship Hero MotoCorp, run by sons Pawan and Sunil, have lost 20% since last year amid slowdown in two-wheeler market due to rising fuel prices and interest rates. Hero has given up all cricket sponsorships and become the title sponsor of country's hockey league.

name: Billionaires
bio: Viktor Nusenkis gained the bulk of his fortune in his native Ukraine, where he owns two coal mines, a coke-chemical plant, and metallurgy works. He became the director of a Ukrainian coal mine during the Soviet era and was an early independent exporter of coal, despite communist rules. In 1993 he founded Energo Concern, to help state-owned factories organize trade deals. Energo quickly became one of Ukraine's biggest coal traders. He did business under the protection of Gennady Vasilyev, the former attorney general of Ukraine, who is currently trying to prove in a Cyprus court that he owns half of Energo. Nusenkis, now a Russian citizen, owns coal mines in Siberia. He has been very active in the Russian Orthodox Church since the 1990s and is one of its most influential patrons in both Ukraine and Russia.

name: Billionaires
bio:
Dmitry Pumpyansky has moved well beyond making pipes, the source of his wealth. Sinara Group, which he owns jointly with German industrial giant Siemens, created a joint venture that won a nearly $3 billion contract from Russian Railways to deliver locomotives by next year. Last year, Pumpyansky led the supervisory borad of Rosselkhozbank, an agricultural lender and the fourth-largest bank in Russia.  His companies are also giving a facelift to a stadium that will host the 2018 World Cup in Ekaterinburg.
Graduating from the Urals Polytechnic Institute with a concentration in metallurgy, Pumpyansky began as a trader, then oversaw several metals plants in the Urals during the 1990s before taking over the Sinarsky Pipe Factory. Joining hands with fellow billionaires Sergei Popov and Andrei Melnichenko, Pumpyansky became CEO of MDM Group, acquiring 35% of pipe conglomerate TMK. In full acquisition mode, MDM clashed with Mikhail Fridman's Alfa Group for control of a fourth major pipe factory?and won. Seeking further consolidation, Pumpyansky bought out Melnichenko and Popov in late 2006, and listed TMK on the London Stock Exchange, raising $1 billion. But, badly in need of capitalCK, he was forced to surrender his controlling stake to state-owned banks as security for a $1.85 billion loan. Two years later, after the terms were renegotiated, Pumpyansky was back in control of TMK.

name: Billionaires
bio: Since the 1970s master marketers Lynda and Stewart Resnick have built or bought companies including POM Wonderful, Fiji Water and flower delivery service Teleflora. In January 2013 federal regulators ruled that the health claims in POM's advertising (pomegranate juice can help treat prostate cancer, erectile dysfunction and heart disease) must be backed by clinical trials. The Resnicks own large pistachio, almond and citrus farms, as well as Justin Vineyards and Winery in Paso Robles, California. Lynda ran a marketing and advertising agency before she joined entrepreneurial forces with her husband. The Resnicks are art collectors as well as patrons. They've given $45 million to the Los Angeles County Museum of Art for an exhibit space that bears their names. They also provide scholarships to the children of workers on their farms and in the surrounding communities. They donated $20 million to the Resnick Institute at CalTech to support the development of renewable energy and $15 million for The Stewart & Lynda Resnick Neuropsychiatric Hospital at UCLA.

name: Billionaires
bio: Facebook co-founder Eduardo Saverin renounced his United States citizenship in 2011, news of which broke days before the company's IPO and drew accusations of tax evasion. His response: "My decision to expatriate was based solely on my interest in working and living in Singapore, where I have been since 2009." Saverin, immortalized in The Social Network as Mark Zuckerberg's onetime best friend, provided Facebook with early seed money, earning him a one-third stake. This fell to 30% when Zuckerberg's roommate, Dustin Moskovitz, joined. When the others dropped out of Harvard to relocate to California, Saverin stayed behind. Facebook later sued him for allegedly interfering with business and insisting on keeping a 30% stake; Saverin countersued. The parties settled, with Saverin apparently receiving a 5% stake and a co-founder bio on Facebook's site. He has since sold more than half his stake in Facebook and has started to invest in startups including Qwiki and Jumio, which created the online payment Netswipe.

name: Billionaires
bio: Maria-Elisabeth Schaeffler and her son Georg jointly own one of world's largest producers of roller bearings, Schaeffler Group. Maria has been at the helm of the business since 1996, when her husband died. Georg, who practiced international business law in Dallas, has been at his mother's side helping to run the company since 2009. In 2008, the company announced a $15 billion takeover of Continental AG, one of Europe's largest tire and auto parts maker. In 2009, Schaeffler Group restructured the $16 billion debt incurred due to the takeover and now holds a 36% stake in Continental.
title: Entrepreneur

name: Billionaires
bio: Press-shy brothers Michael and Rainer Schmidt-Ruthenbeck together own nearly 16% of retailer Metro, which is based in Dusseldorf, Germany but has stores throughout Europe, in Asia and parts of Africa. Neither brother is involved in management. Metro shares have dropped over the last 12 months due to economic weakness in Europe and a company-issued profit warning. As a result, the brothers' fortune is $100 million lower than in March 2012. Metro was co-founded in 1964 as a partnership between the Schmidt-Ruthenbeck family, the Haniel family and recently deceased billionaire Otto Beisheim and at one time was the world's third largest retailer. The Schmidt-Ruthenbeck brothers also own Travel Charm, a chain of 11 luxury hotels and spas in Germany, Austria and Italy. Together the brothers fund the Mercator Foundation, which supports projects in climate change and arts education. The foundation has a current endowment of $145 million. Since its formation in 1996, the foundation has financed nearly 600 projects with more than $200 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: A lifelong friend of Warren Buffett, Walter Scott Jr. made most of his money from MidAmerican Energy, an electrical utility acquired by Berkshire Hathaway in 2000. Before becoming good friends with Buffett, the two vied with each other for the hearts of girls in high school. Chairman of telecom provider Level 3 Communications, Scott also sits on the board of Berkshire Hathaway, as well as the boards of Valmont Industries, Peter Kiewit Sons' and MidAmerican Energy. He got a bachelor's degree in civil engineering from Colorado State before taking a job with his father's employer, Kiewit Construction (now Peter Kiewit Sons'). He became CEO in 1979 and expanded the company's operations into fiber optics, telecom and power plants before stepping down in 1998. Through the Suzanne and Walter Scott Foundation, he and his wife support education, the Boy Scouts and the Omaha zoo.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Shen Guojun is one of China's most successful retail and real estate investors. He chairs Intime Department Store, which has benefited over the years from increasing consumer spending. Its Hong Kong-listed shares enjoyed a double-digit rise in the past 12 months. Intime is also partly owned by Hong Kong billionaire Lee Shau Kee. Shen has stakes in domestically listed retailers Baida Group and Wuhan Department Store, China-traded real estate concern Metro Land, Shenzhen-listed Science City Development Public, and the Yintai Center along Beijing's prestigious Chang An Street, which houses the Park Hyatt Beijing Hotel. Shen is a member of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference, a government consultative body. He holds a master's degree in economics from Zhongnan University of Finance and Economics.

name: Billionaires
bio: Now chairman emeritus of the Simon Property Group, the largest publicly traded real estate investment trust in the United States, Herbert Simon founded the company's precursor, Melvin Simon & Associates, with his brother Melvin (d. 2009) in 1960. Today Simon Property Group, which is known for its interest in shopping malls, owns or has interests in 242 million square feet of leasable space and 333 retail real estate properties in North America and Asia. Simon also has ownership stakes in several sports teams: the Indiana Pacers basketball team, the Reno Aces minor league baseball franchise, and the WNBA's Indiana Fever. A father of eight and on his third marriage, Simon is married to a former Miss Universe from Thailand. Although he splits his time between Indiana and his home in California, he still supports many causes in Indianapolis. He made a $2 million gift to the local library foundation in 2009-2010 and gave $4.5 million to the Riley Children's Foundation. He has a bachelor's degree in business administration.
title: Chairman Emeritus of the Board of Simon Property Group, Inc.
