name: Billionaires
bio: As housing starts surged at the end of 2012 so too did demand for Spangler's building and construction materials supplier National Gypsum's products. Not that he was worried about a comeback. As he once told Forbes, "We think in ten year cycles". After studying business at UNC and Harvard Business School, Spangler took over his father's failing Bank of North Carolina, merged it with NCNB in 1982, and eventually with Bank of America. A lifelong proponent of education, Spangler served as chair of North Carolina's board of education from 1982 to 1986 and UNC's president from 1986 to 1997. Spangler also served as president of Harvard University's Board of Overseers from 2003 to 2004 and the Spangler Center at HBS is named for him. Through his C.D. Spangler Foundation he donates to his alma maters and to Charlotte's Teach for America. Spangler enjoys restoring antique grandfather clocks; he says the allure is working on something that someone else tinkered with 200 years ago.

name: Billionaires
bio: Suh Kyung-Bae chairs South Korea's leading cosmetics company, Amore Pacific. The firm does business  in China, Singapore, Hong Kong, Indonesia and the Philippines. Its brands include Laneige, which is endorsed by top Korean actress Song Hye Kyo, and Sulwhaso, a product that incorporates ginseng and other Asian herbs. Suh's father started the company in Gaesong, a Korean town that is nicknamed Ginseng City. In 2000 Amore Pacific set up a breast cancer foundation and has supported the nation's Pink Ribbon Love Marathon for the past decade to help breast cancer victims. In 2010 Suh received an award from Ernst & Young naming him Korea's best CEO.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Yitzhak Tshuva's net worth rebounded in the past year as Elad Group, his property company with buildings in New York City, Florida and LA, absorbed its publicly traded subsidiary Elad Canada. Tshuva's energy company, Delek Group, also did well. In July, Tshuva sold his 60% stake in Manhattan's Plaza Hotel and nearby retail space for $400 million. He had purchased it for $675 million eight years earlier and had apparently earned $500 million selling $1.5 billion worth of apartments. Meanwhile, another dream was deferred: Elad paid $1.24 billion for the New Frontier Casino in Las Vegas in 2007. With former billionaire Nochi Danker, it had grand plans to spend upward of $5 billion converting the property into another Plaza Hotel but the project never got off the ground. It is now a parking lot. Tshuva's family immigrated from Libya to Israel when he was six months old. After his service in the IDF, he worked as a contractor for the Israeli Defense Ministry. His start in real estate came in the 1970s, developing low-income housing in Israel.

name: Billionaires
bio: Kazakh investor Bulat Utemuratov continues to sell off assets. In October 2012 he renegotiated a previously announced deal with Glencore to buy out his firm's stake in Kazakhstan's largest zinc miner, Kazzinc; then in February he sold the remaining 29% stake to the Kazakhstan government for approximately $2.1 billion. He is moving to rebuild his banking assets and is reportedly in talks to repurchase Kazakstan's ATF Bank, having sold 91.8% of it to Italian bank UniCredit for $2.1 billion in 2007. He serves as a Kazakhstan special envoy to Kyrgyzstan and is a passionate tennis player who heads the Kazakh Tennis Federation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heir to gum maker Wrigley, Bill Wrigley oversaw the sale of his family's business to privately held giant Mars for $23 billion in 2008, a deal that led to the creation of the world's largest candy company. He stepped down as Wrigley's chairman 15 months later in January 2010. He now lives in Palm Beach, having reportedly sold more than $12 million worth of property in Chicago, including a Lake Forest mansion, in the spring of 2012.  After graduating from Duke University in economics, he headed to Seattle to help a friend launch a business selling stain remover. In 1985 he returned to Chicago and became his father's assistant. In 1999 his father's unexpected death thrust him into running the company at age 35. His great grandfather created the first spearmint chewables in 1893, and in 1915, sent four sticks of gum to every person in the U.S. with a listed phone number.
title: Director

name: Billionaires
bio: Xu Jingren's net worth is up $1 billion since the fall thanks to booming business in his privately held Yangtze River Pharmaceutical Group, one of China's largest drugmakers. Sales in 2012 rose by $1 billion from a year earlier to $5.4 billion. Yangtze River makes antibiotics, chemotherapy drugs and cardiovascular drugs. Xu's son Haoyu is the vice chairman. The company is headquartered in Taizhou, Hu's hometown, and has more than 7,000 employees. Xu is a member of the National People's Congress.

name: Billionaires
bio: Juan Abello, a onetime pharmacist, sold his family's pharmaceutical business in 1985 and invested the proceeds in multiple industries, from banking to textiles. He accumulated a 9.6% stake in construction giant Sacyr Vallehermoso, where he is a vice president. Lately he has been investing in Spain's abundant public debt. He often appears in tabloids alongside well-known politicians and members of Spanish artistic and cultural circles. Recently his nephew Gregorio was named in the Spanish press in connection with the Gao Ping money laundering scandal; Ping is accused of laundering money belonging to Spain's elite through China. Abello is also known for his valuable art collection, which includes works by Pablo Picasso, Francisco Goya, El Greco, Edgar Degas, Toulouse-Lautrec, Salvador Dali, Francis Bacon, and Van Gogh, among others. He's an enthusiastic hunter who enjoys bullfights and soccer.

name: Billionaires
bio: Consumer goods tycoon Joao Alvez de Queiroz Filho, known as Junior, controls Hypermarcas SA, which manufactures and sells the largest portfolio of consumer brands in Brazil, including food, drugs, cleaning supplies, and beauty and personal hygiene products. The company could be described as a Brazilian version of Unilever, which has grown thanks to acquisitions, product launches, intense brand renovation work, and publicity with Brazilian celebrities. Junior also has stakes in many other companies, including Burger King, which he bought in a 2010 transaction led by a trio of fellow Brazilian billionaires Jorge Paulo Lemann, Carlos Alberto Sicupira and Marcel Herrmann Tellles. Queiroz started building his fortune at Arisco, a cleaning product business he started with his father in 1969. Arisco became the biggest company in Brazil's food sector and was sold to Bestfoods for $760 million in 2000. Two years later Queiroz created Hypermarcas after buying steel wool companies throughout Brazil.

name: Billionaires
bio: Based in London, Alex Beard is the highest-ranking Glencore executive in the U.K., responsible for the company's worldwide oil operations. He joined the billionaires club when the commodities giant listed on the London exchange in May 2011. Despite its shares losing nearly 20% of their value since their public debut, the future is bright for Glencore. The firm announced plans to merge with mining outfit Xstrata in February 2012. The proposed all-stock "merger of equals" is currently awaiting regulatory approval in China. A graduate of Oxford University with a degree in Biochemistry, he had stints at BP and Trafigura, Beard joined Glencore in 1995. He was named director of the oil commodity department in 2007.

name: Billionaires
bio: Bernard Broermann founded his first hospital in 1984 and named it Asklepios, after the Greek God of medicine. The Asklepios Group is now one of the three largest operators of private hospitals in Germany, with 20 percent of the market.The group owns about 140 hospitals worldwide --including in Russia, China and California -- with 44,000 employees. It had 2011 revenues of $3.4 billion (2.56 billion Euros), up 12% from the prior year. Profits fell slightly to $115 million. Broermann practiced as an accountant and lawyer before founding the hospital chain and has an M.B.A. from Harvard University. He also owns the Kempinski Hotel Falkenstein in Koenigstein, a five-star luxury spa and hotel in the Taunus mountains near Frankfurt, Germany.

name: Billionaires
bio: Miloud Chaabi got his start in 1948 developing housing, then expanded through his privately owned Ynna Holding into hotels, supermarkets and renewable energy. His Ryad Mogador chain of low-priced hotels doesn't serve alcohol. Chaabi's net worth is down $800 million from a year ago as market values dropped for publicly traded competitors, which Forbes uses as proxies to value Ynna Holding. Chaabi was dubbed the "red capitalist" in the past when he allied himself with the socialist party. But in November 2011 he ran for parliament as a member of Morocco's environmentalist party from his hometown of Kenitra, and won. Chaabi has committed to building a university in Casablanca in partnership with Indiana State University.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partners and longtime friends Alexander Machkevich and Alijan Ibragimov (both billionaires), Patokh Chodiev built Eurasian Natural Resources Co., a metals and mining empire in Kazakhstan. Shares have lost more than half their value in the past 12 months, based on governance concerns. A new chairman is working to ease relations between the trio and the board. ENRC continues to expand and has been exploring the sale of of international assets. In December, ENRC bid $550 million for the remaining 49.5 percent of Camrose Resources that it does not already own, buying out Israeli billionaire Dan Gertler's stake. Uzbekistan native lived in Japan before teaming up with his pals in Kazakhstan.

name: Billionaires
bio: Silas Chou and his longtime partner Lawrence Stroll are the biggest beneficiaries of Michael Kors' hot run. Early investors in the fashion company, which they helped take public in late 2011, the former co-chairmen have sold more than two-thirds of their holding in it for more than $1 billion apiece. They still own a significant stake and sit on the board. Chou, who lives in Hong Kong, and Stroll, a Geneva resident, met through their fathers decades ago. Together they obtained the license to launch Polo Ralph Lauren apparel throughout Europe. After that they engineered the rise of the Tommy Hilfiger brand, in the 1990s. Other brands still in their portfolio include Tommy Hilfiger Asia, Karl Lagerfeld and Pepe Jeans. The friends have both reportedly signed $50 million contracts for apartments at the new One57 tower in Manhattan. Chou's daughter, Veronica, married in November in a celebrity-studded ceremony in Hong Kong attended by nearly 1,500 guests, including Duchess of York Sarah Ferguson and fashion designer Vivienne Tam.

name: Billionaires
bio: Financier Mark Coombs benefited from the march to emerging markets after founding fund manager Ashmore Group, which invests in equities, currencies and bonds in Asia, Latin America and other emerging economies. Cambridge law graduate started his career at Australia & New Zealand Banking Group and has been Ashmore's chief executive since 1998. He started Ashmore as new division of the company, then led a buyout in 1999 and took firm public in 2006, raising $2 billion. Coombs took advantage of cheaper equities in 2011 and bought money manager Emerging Market Management for $246 million more than doubling assets under management to $71 billion today, and re-balancing Ashmore's focus on equities and debt. Firm, in which he keeps a 42% stake, is now in London's FTSE index of 100 leading companies despite a lackluster stock and financial performance in 2012. Coombs is said to live a modest life, keeping to a 3-bedroom house in Wimbledon, within easy commuting distance of London.

name: Billionaires
bio: The younger half, with David Bonderman, of the team that founded $54 billion private-equity giant TPG Group also keeps a lower profile. Latest focus: Asia, where TPG is raising a $4 billion fund.

name: Billionaires
bio: Swiss tycoon got his start in oil trading. Later through control of the Addax & Oryx Group he parlayed contacts in Africa into oilfields in Nigeria and a vast network of fuel storage and distribution assets across Sub-Saharan Africa. Was among the very first movers into Iraq's Kurdistan region. Sold publicly traded Addax Petroleum to Sinopec for $7.3 billion in 2009. Now Gandur has gotten back into the oil game; his Oryx Petroleum has new positions in Kurdistan and Africa and plans an IPO this year. Despite European parents, Gandur grew up in Egypt and has one of the world's best private collections of Egyptian antiquities. Also a world-class collector of post-War European art and ancient European artifacts.

name: Billionaires
bio: Gao Dekang chairs Bosideng International Holdings, one of China's largest makers of down apparel. His wealth is up in the past year on a rise in the company's Hong Kong-listed shares amid hopes for a pick-up in China's economic growth in 2013. Net profit in the six months to September actually slipped by 3% to $51 million, though sales increased by 12% to $497 million. Bosideng took a big step in Europe last year by opening a flagship store in London's West End to coincide with the Summer Olympics. Bosideng's domestic brands include Bosideng, Snow Flying, Kangbo, Bengen and Jessie. Bosideng's foreign shareholders include International Data Group, the U.S. investment company. Gao holds an EMBA degree from Phoenix International University in New Zealand.

name: Billionaires
bio: Apollo Global Management managing director Josh Harris saw his fortune increase $600 million in the past year as shares of Apollo, which went public in 2011, rose to new highs. Harris co-founded the firm in 1990 with Leon Black and Mark Rowan in 1990, after their previous employer Drexel Burnham collapsed. He sits on the board of several companies including Apollo, LyondellBasell and oil and gas producer EP Energy, in which the firm co-invested last year. Harris is also the lead investor in the Philadelphia 76ers, which he and partners bought in 2011. A former wrestler, he competes in marathons and triathalons.

name: Billionaires
bio: Eduardo Hochschild's great uncle founded the Peruvian mining and cement-focused Hochschild Group in 1911. Today, Hochschild chairs both Hochschild Mining and Cementos Pacasmayo. Based in Lima, Hochschild Mining trades on the London Stock Exchange and operates gold and silver mines across North and South America. In May 2012, the company announced it would be investing $425 million into two mining projects in southern Peru over the next two years. Shares of the company have fallen slightly along with silver prices in the past 12 months, shaving $100 million from Hochschild's net worth. Cementos Pacasmayo, one of Peru's largest publicly traded cement companies, listed its shares on the New York Stock Exchange in February 2012. In 1998 during a period of political unrest in Peru, Hochschild survived an attack by gunman that claimed the life of his father. Hochschild was kidnapped by the attackers, but released six days later.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Satellite television mogul Stan Hubbard supported a wide range of Republican candidates in 2012, including donations of over $100,000 to those in his home state of Minnesota. Hubbard created the movie information and trivia channel ReelzChannel after selling his satellite TV outfit to DirecTV for $1.3 billion in 1999. The channel now reaches 65 million subscribers. Hubbard remains CEO and chairman of its parent company, Hubbard Broadcasting, though he has handed off daily operations to his five children, who all serve as operating officers of the various local television, radio and media subgroups. In January 2011, the company paid $505 million for 17 radio stations in Chicago, St. Louis, Cincinnati and Washington, D.C. Hubbard inherited a love of flying from his father, a pilot who started one of the first U.S. commercial airlines. His latest venture is Hubbard Aviation Technologies, the maker of hush kits that muffle engine noise in Gulfstream jets.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Hubbard Broadcasting, Inc.', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: With partners and longtime friends Alexander Machkevich and Patokh Chodiev (both billionaires), Alijan Ibragimov built Eurasian Natural Resources Co., a metals and mining empire in Kazakhstan. Shares have lost more than half their value in the past 12 months, based on governance concerns. A new chairman is working to ease relations between the trio and the board. ENRC continues to expand and has been exploring the sale of of international assets. In December, ENRC bid $550 million for the remaining 49.5 percent of Camrose Resources that it does not already own, buying out Israeli billionaire Dan Gertler's stake. Native of Kyrgyzstan moved to Kazakhstan when the group decided to pursue business interests there. Devout Muslim with 6 sons.

name: Billionaires
bio: Hailing from a family of shoemakers, Ajay Kalsi founded and runs London-listed Indus Gas. In December, Indus announced a dramatic increase in its hydrocarbon reserves in western India. He recently cashed in, selling a chunk of shares, reducing his stake to under two-thirds. Cambridge & LSE grad, he also holds a minority stake in Reebok's Indian arm, which got hit by a scandal over alleged financial fraud by its top executives.

name: Billionaires
bio: In December 2012 Min Kao stepped down as chief executive of GPS maker Garmin, becoming executive chairman. He and fellow billionaire Gary Burrell founded the company in 1989 to produce navigational tools for pilots and sailors. Coalition forces during the Gulf War were among the company's first customers. Garmin faces increasing competition from cell phone manufacturers offering built-in GPS technology. Garmin stock has slid in the past year. A native of Taiwan, Kao earned his master's and Ph.D. in electrical engineering from the University of Tennessee in Knoxville. He gave the school a $12.5 gift toward the Min H. Kao Electrical Engineering and Computer Science building, which opened in January 2012. He also donated $5 million to create the Min H. Kao Scholars and Fellows endowments and the Kao Professorship.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Garmin Corporation', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: With partners and longtime friends Patokh Chodiev and Alijan Ibragimov (both billionaires), Alexander Machkevich built Eurasian Natural Resources Co., a metals and mining empire in Kazakhstan. Shares have lost more than half their value in the past 12 months, based on governance concerns. A new chairman is working to ease relations between the trio and the board. ENRC continues to expand and has been exploring the sale of of international assets. In December, ENRC bid $550 million for the remaining 49.5 percent of Camrose Resources that it does not already own, buying out Israeli billionaire Dan Gertler's stake. Uzbekistan native lived in Japan before teaming up with his pals in Kazakhstan.

name: Billionaires
bio: Vadim Moshkovich started out in the early 1990s selling apartments, vodka, and oil. With the money he made, he invested in land and created Rusagro, an agro-industrial holding company that is today one of Russia's largest sugar producers. In 2005 he bought land near Moscow that had once been a cooperative farm that provided milk for intelligence officers. Where cows once roamed he now plans to build a massive residential and retail development. Some of his land appeared for a time to be a site for new government buildings in an expanded "New Moscow," but after Medvedev and Putin switched jobs at the top of Russia's government, that idea faded away. Moshkovich serves in Russia's Federation Council.

name: Billionaires
bio: Or Wai Sheun's wealth got a boost this year as shares in his Hong Kong-listed Kowloon Development surged on hopes for continued gains in real estate prices. Or is preparing to capitalize on the future growth of Kennedy Town, located at the western end of the island, as it evolves into a new expat cluster, with the Cadogan, a glitzy 49-story residential tower that should be completed by 2014. Other projects include the 35-story Gardenia in Kowloon. Its subsidiary Polytec develops property in Macau and owns an oil exploration and production company.

name: Billionaires
bio: Pharma tycoon runs generics maker Cadila Healthcare, cofounded by his late father, a pharmacy professor, in 1952. Its portfolio includes vaccines and SugarFree, India's top selling sugar substitute. It also has a marketing joint venture with Bayer Healthcare for India. A drug discovery deal with Eli Lilly is rumored to have unraveled. A Bombardier Challenger-604 plane he'd recently bought to visit Cadila's far-flung factories was impounded by the revenue authorities for an alleged evasion of customs duty

name: Billionaires
bio: Stanley Perron won a huge victory in 2012 against Australia's richest person, Georgina Rinehart, and the Bennett and Wright families, clawing back unpaid royalties on iron ore mining. He owns 15% of the royalties in Hamersley Iron, a subsidiary of Rio Tinto, and claimed he was being short-changed. A court settlement gave him $40 million immediately and more in the years ahead. He built his fortune on commercial property and on a Toyota distributorship he was awarded in the 1960s. His first job as a boy was carving boxes to hold handkerchiefs and selling them door-to-door in the gold mining town of Kalgoorlie. He tried his hand at everything from brick-making to running an ice rink before settling on cars and property. Once a keen fisherman, age is keeping him closer to home, though he still goes to the office to "read the paper," he says.

name: Billionaires
bio: Alexander Ponomarenko and his partner Alexander Skorobogatko made $1 billion apiece in January 2011 when they sold a stake in Novorossiysk Commercial Sea Port, Russia's biggest, to state-owned Transneft and its affiliate Summa Capital. Two months later, flush with cash, Ponomarenko spent $350 million buying a lavish holiday complex nearby on the Black Sea nicknamed "Putin's Palace." The 8,000-square-meter complex leased for $1 million a month that summer. Ponomarenko graduated from Simferopol State University and earned a doctorate in economics at the Russian State Academy of Management. He and Skorobogatko established a small perfume factory in Ukraine and then founded Russian General Bank in Moscow, which served the Novorossiysk port operation. After the 1998 Russian financial crisis the partners began buying up shares in stevedoring companies at the port, and they combined them to form Novorossiysk Commercial Sea Port. It went public in 2007, resulting in a windfall of $1 billion for the partners. In 2008 they sold 20% of their holdings to Arkady Rotenberg, a billionaire businessman who practices judo with Russian President Vladimir Putin. In the summer of 2012 Ponomarenko and Skorobogatko joined with Rotenberg to found TPS Real Estate Holding Ltd.It is capitalized at $1.5 billion.

name: Billionaires
bio: Nicolas Puech makes his debut on this year's Forbes Billionaires List. He is an eighth generation descendant of Thierry Hermes, founder of Hermes, one of the most recognized luxury brands in the world. Thierry started the Paris firm in 1837 as a harness workshop. It now boasts more than $3.8 billion in global sales of products ranging from leather clothing and silk scarves to jewelry and perfume.  Puech joined the Hermes supervisory board in 2012, which resulted in the company making public Puech's six-million-share holding in its annual report. The rest of the Hermes clan's shares are held under one entity, according to company documents.  Fellow luxury goods billionaire Bernard Arnault controls more than 22% of Hermes through his multinational LVMH Group. Hermes CEO Patrick Thomas is the first non-family member to captain Hermes.  He announced his intention to retire in 2013, paving the way for current COO and eighth generation Hermes family member Axel Dumas.

name: Billionaires
bio: Qiu Guanghe, chairman of apparel retailer Zhejiang Semir Garment, lost $1.2 billion in the past year   amid slowng growth in Chinese consumer spending. The company is working with government-controlled China Resources Land on MIXC, an $800 million commercial and residential real estate project in Wenzhou. Qiu's son-in-law, Zhou Pingfan, took over as president of Semir in June 2012, replacing Qiu's son Qiu Jianqiang, who is now vice chairman. The company also announced in June that it would set up a new firm, Shanghai Semir Investment, to buy stakes in apparel companies with growth potential.

name: Billionaires
bio: Apollo Global Management's cofounder Marc Rowan apparently paid $26 million for a co-op at 927 Fifth Avenue in Manhattan. He already reportedly has two in that building but put one of the others on the market. Rowan also sold his oceanfront mansion in Southampton for $28.5 million last year. Rowan's net worth jumped in the past year, along with Apollo's stock, which is trading at its all-time high since going public in 2011. He started the firm with former Drexel Burnham colleagues Leon Black and Joshua Harris in 1990. He sits on the board of Caesars Entertainment and Norwegian Cruise Lines.

name: Billionaires
bio: Alexander Skorobogatko and his partner Alexander Ponomarenko made $1 billion apiece in January 2011 when they sold a stake in Novorossiysk Commercial Sea Port, Russia's biggest, to state-owned Transneft and its affiliate Summa Capital. Skorobogatko graduated from Slavyansk State Pedagogical Institute and with Ponomoarenko founded Russian General Bank in Moscow, which served the Novorossiysk port operation. After the 1998 Russian financial crisis the partners began buying up shares in stevedoring companies at the port, and they combined them to form Novorossiysk Commercial Sea Port. It went public in 2007, resulting in a windfall of $1 billion for the partners. In 2008 they sold 20% of their holdings to Arkady Rotenberg, a billionaire businessman who practices judo with Russian President Vladimir Putin. Skorobogatko has served as an elected deputy in the State Duma since 2002, barring him from participating in the business. He was reelected to the Duma for a third term in December 2011. In the summer of 2012 Skorobogatko and Ponomarenko joined with Rotenberg to found TPS Real Estate Holding Ltd, and with it bought more than a half of the space in Ocean Plaza, the biggest shopping center in Kiev, for $280 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Frederick Smith's fortune comes from FedEx, the shipping company he launched in 1971. The company faces a challenge in 2013 when its contract with the U.S. Postal Service, worth more than $1 billion a year, expires in September. Competitor UPS will likely try to grab the business. In 2012 FedEx's profits dipped as some customers opted for slower delivery services. The idea for FedEx came from a term paper Smith wrote at Yale. When he started the company he invested every dollar he had. At one point he reportedly went to Las Vegas for the weekend and won $20,000 he injected into the cash-strapped company. Smith is also a founding member of the Electrification Coalition, which supports the development of electric vehicles. FedEx has been phasing in an electric fleet and switching to alternative energy like biofuel and natural gas. Smith is the majority shareholder of Alcon Entertainment, a production company that made the film "The Blind Side," which Smith's daughter Molly executive produced. A former marine, he co-chaired John McCain's 2008 presidential campaign and was mentioned as a potential vice presidential pick. At Yale he roomed with George W. Bush. Smith and his wife donated $10 million to fund the Memphis Zoo's three-acre exhibit featuring grizzly bears, the mascots of the city's NBA team.
title: Chairman and CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: Sylvia Stroher, a granddaughter of the founder of hair care group Wella AG, received $1 billion from the 2003 sale of Wella to Proctor & Gamble, which paid $4 billion for the group. Sylvia Stroher (also written "Stroeher") and her husband, a former nurse, have a well-known collection of contemporary German art  --approximately 1,500 pieces -- includes works by Baselitz, Immendorff and Kiefer, part of which is housed in the Museum Kuppersmuhle in Germany.

name: Billionaires
bio: Lawrence Stroll and his longtime partner Silas Chou are the biggest beneficiaries of Michael Kors' hot run. Early investors in the fashion company, which they helped take public in late 2011, the former co-chairmen have sold more than two-thirds of their holding in it for more than $1 billion apiece. They still own a significant stake and sit on the board. Stroll, who lives in Geneva, and Chou, a Hong Kong resident, met through their fathers decades ago. Together they obtained the license to launch Polo Ralph Lauren apparel throughout Europe. After that they engineered the rise of the Tommy Hilfiger brand, in the 1990s. Other brands still in their portfolio include Tommy Hilfiger Asia, Karl Lagerfeld and Pepe Jeans. The friends have both reportedly signed $50 million contracts for apartments at the new One57 tower in Manhattan. A driving and racing enthusiast, Stroll collects vintage Ferraris.

name: Billionaires
bio: T.Y. Tsai is a member of one of Taiwan's most influential business clans, particularly in the financial industry. His uncle Tsai Wan-tsai, also a member of this year's billionaires list, founded Fubon Financial Holding. T.Y.'s father Tsai Wan-lin built Cathay Life Insurance into a powerhouse and died as Taiwan's richest man when he passed away in 2004. T.Y. Tsai sold his stake in Cathay Financial Holding, Cathay Life's successor, in 2010 to his brothers, and has gone off on his own since with an eye to building up a real estate empire. T.Y. collects cars and art, including at least one Monet.

name: Billionaires
bio: Zhou Chengjian is the chairman of Shanghai Metersbonwe Fashion & Accessories, one of China's largest home-grown fashion chains. His wealth has declined from a year ago because of a drop in the price of the company's Shenzhen-listed shares amid a slowdown in the country's retail spending growth. Nine-month revenue at Metersbonwe rose by 6% to $1.2 billion; net profit was up by 1% to $121 million. Zhou invests in Chinese real estate through Shanghai Huafu Investment, which is wholly-owned by Zhou and his daughter Hu Jiajia.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ambassador to Spain and Andorra under President George W. Bush, George Argyros made his fortune in real estate. As the chairman and CEO of Arnel & Affiliates, he oversees a Southern California real estate company that manages 5,500 apartments and two million square feet of commercial space. He is a founding partner of private equity firm Westar Capital and a board member at software development company DST Systems. His Argyros Foundation gives to various causes and foundations in Southern California, including the South Coast Repertory, the Eisenhower Medical Center Foundation and Argyros' alma mater Chapman University. In 2011, he and his wife gave $5 million to University of California, Irvine's Gavin Herbert Eye Institute.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Arnel & Affiliates', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Andrej Babis continues to expand Agrofert, the chemical, agricultural and food product holding he founded, across Eastern Europe and now Germany with the purchase of bakery group Lieken in February. His group of over 200 firms leases most of the country's agriculture land, and is buying companies in wood processing, media and health-care to add to the stable. Until now, Babis has keep tight control of company management, using an old-fashioned paper calendar instead of a PC; but in January, he announced he would step back and delegate, even considering a possible IPO. Like fellow Czech billionaire, Zdenek Bakala, Babis is also active politically, he launched a new political party last year to tackle what he sees as the country's wide-spread corruption. During the summer Olympics in London, Babis converted a an inconic British double decker bus into a moving, performing robotic sculpture to amuse Olympic attendees. The son of a dilpomat, Babis was born in what is now the Slovak Republic; he began as a fertilizers trader for Petrimex, precursor to Agrofert.

name: Billionaires
bio: Rahul Bajaj is the patriarch of the 87 year-old Bajaj Group whose flagship Bajaj Auto is the country's second largest maker of two-wheelers. Run by son Rajiv, it is closing in on market leader and fellow billionaire Brijmohan Lall Munjal's Hero MotoCorp. In September, its Discover bike outsold Hero's Splendor model, the country's best selling bike and in January it launched a new 100 CC basic model. Eyeing expansion overseas, it's partnering with Kawasaki to jointly market their bikes globally. It reportedly plans to enter the US market with a bike developed with Austrian firm KTM. Its partnership with Nissan to make a small car to rival Tata's Nano has gone nowhere. Financial services arm, which son Sanjiv oversees, has an insurance joint venture with Germany's Allianz Group.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ed is the Renaissance man among the Bass brothers, once called "a Texas-bred cross between Prince Charles and Lorenzo de Medici," He shares investments in oil and gas, but loves architecture and urban planning. In the early 1990s he spent $200 million backing Biosphere 2, a self-contained living experiment in Arizona that he later donated to Columbia University. He owns ranches in Texas and Flint Hills of Kansas; and is devoted to seeding with native grasses. Spearheaded redevelopment of downtown Fort Worth and its central Sundance Square, which is home to the $65 million Bass Performance Hall, which opened in 1998 and boasts some of the best acoustics in the world. Enjoys waxing philosophical; at press conference for Sundance Square this year said, "Wealth is not, you know, a matter of money. It is a matter of being able to forwardly organize our lives in a positive way."

name: Billionaires
bio: Youngest of the Fort Worth Bass brothers, Lee is a dedicated conservationist. Served as chairman of the Texas Parks and Wildlife Commission in the 1990s. In Texas he operates El Coyote, Indio Faith and Rio Bravo ranches. Another in the Flint Hills of Kansas. Lee raises black rhinoceroses and longhorn cattle. He has long invested beside brother Sid; the two are now tied up in a legal fight Credit Suisse over hundreds of millions in cash they took out of the failed Lake Las Vegas real eastate development. Trial expected in 2013. He donated $20 million to Yale University in 1991 to support the study of western civilization, but had the grant returned in 1995 after the university decided it wasn't politically correct.

name: Billionaires
bio: Alberto Benavides de la Quintana joins the FORBES list of the World's Billionaires this year based on the 27% stake he and his family own in publicly traded Peruvian miner, Compania de Minas Buenaventura. The son of a former Lima mayor, Harvard-educated Benavides founded Buenaventura in 1953. The company is one of Peru's largest gold and silver producers, with a market capitalization that exceeds $7 billion. Its American Depositary Shares trade on the New York Stock Exchange. Alberto Benavides, who is 92 and no longer sits on the board, holds voting control over the family's shares, according to company financial documents. His son, Roque, serves as Buenaventura's CEO. Another son, Raul, sits on the board of directors.

name: Billionaires
bio: Carlo Benetton founded the Benetton Group in 1965 with his siblings Luciano, Giuliana and Gilberto. Carlo holds the title of Deputy Chairman with the group and deals with the company's production projects analysis and technological processes, as well as new industrial developments in the textile and clothing sectors. The company delisted from the Milan stock exchange in May 2012. Sales were $2.6 billion (2 billion euros) in 2011, slightly lower than in 2001. Profits fell 30% in 2011 to $95 million (73 million euros). In May 2012 the Benetton Group settled a lawsuit that had been filed against it by the Vatican after the company altered an image of Pope Benedict XVI kissing Mohammad Ahmed al-Tayeb, the grand imam of Cairo's Al Azhar mosque. Benetton has a history of unusual ad campaigns. Through Edizione S.r.l., a financial holding company, Carlo and his siblings own stakes several companies, including roadside restaurant company Autogrill, and its most valuable holding, motorway operator Atlantia S.p.A.

name: Billionaires
bio: Gilberto Benetton, with his siblings Luciano, Carlo and Giuliana, formed clothing retailer Benetton Group in 1965. The family delisted the company from the Milan stock exchange in May 2012 in the face of steeper competition and weaker results. Profits fell nearly 30% to $95 million (73 million euros) in 2011. Gilberto has chaired publicly traded Autogrill restaurants, which serves customers on highways and in airports, since 1995. He is also chairman of Benetton family investment company Edizione Holding and a director of Mediobanca, Atlantia and Pirelli, in which the family also owns stakes. Their most valuable holding is a stake in Atlantia, a multinational toll-road operator.

name: Billionaires
bio: Giuliana Benetton formed clothing retailer Benetton Group with her siblings Luciano, Carlo and Gilberto in 1965. In May 2012 the family took the company private in the wake of growing competition that eroded its profits. Sales in 2011 were $2.6 billion (2 billion euros), slightly lower in Euro-terms than in 2001. Profit fell nearly 30% in 2011 to $95 million. Giuliana originally knitted sweaters that her brother Luciano would peddle by bicycle; they were sold under a variety of labels before becoming United Colors of Benetton. Most of her fortune lies in the stakes she shares with her siblings in motorways operator Atlantia S.p.A and roadside restaurant chain Autogrill.

name: Billionaires
bio: Luciano Benetton, former chairman of Benetton Group, founded the fashion brand in 1965 with his siblings Giuliana, Gilberto and Carlo. He handed over control to his son, 48-year-old Alessandro, in April 2012 and de-listed the company from the Milan stock exchange in May. Sales had been flat for the past decade, dropping from 2.1 billion euros in 2001 to just over 2 billion euros ($2.6 billion) in 2011. Profits slumped 51% over the same period to $95 million(73 million euros). Most of his wealth lies in the stakes he shares with his siblings in motorways operator Atlantia S.p.A and roadside restaurant chain Autogrill.
title: Entrepreneur

name: Billionaires
bio: Dubbed the "homeless billionaire" for his penchant for living out of hotels, these days Nicolas Berggruen spends the bulk of his time working on his Nicolas Berggruen Institute, which aims to innovate and implement good governance practices around the world. After graduating from NYU in 1981 Berggruen worked for Bass Brothers Enterprises before launching Berggruen Holdings in 1985 to manage the family fortune amassed by his father, an international art dealer who assembled an unrivaled collection of works by artists such as Pablo Picasso and Paul Klee after World War Two. In 1988, Berggruen co-founded the Alpha Investment Management, a fund of hedge funds operation that was sold to Safra Bank in 2004. Today, his Berggruen Holdings is comprised of operating companies in the United States, India and Europe in retailing, for-profit education, hotels, publishing and car rental services, among other industries. The company is also invested in real estate around the globe, including more than 60 commercial and residential buildings in Berlin. Like his father before him, Berggruen is a passionate art collector, and owns pieces by Warhol, Basquiat and Koons. Berggruen has said he plans to give all his wealth away.

name: Billionaires
bio: Charles Bronfman and his brother, Edgar Bronfman Sr., inherited the Seagram spirits empire in 1971 after the death of their father, Sam. In 2000, Vivendi acquired Seagram in an all-stock deal worth about $34 billion. Charles and the Bronfman family eventually sold their shares in Vivendi and he has since focused on philanthropic giving.  He has authored two books on charity and signed Warren Buffett's and Bill Gates' Giving Pledge. Bronfman's spokesman says he has given away or pledged a total of $350 million to charities including the Andrea & Charles Bronfman Philanthropies, a foundation he started with his late wife. In July 2011, Bronfman announced that the foundation would close in 2016. His favorite causes include the promotion of Canadian culture and the development of Israeli pride. He is one of the main benefactors of Taglit-Birthright Israel, which sends Jewish youth from North America on educational tours of Israel.

name: Billionaires
bio: Daughter of Walter Haefner, the oldest billionaire at the time of his death at 101 this past June, Eva-Maria Bucher-Haefner inherited half of her father's stake in Computer Associates. Also inherited stake in AMAG, which sells Volkswagon, Seat, Skoda and Audi. She runs Moyglare, the 450-acre horse breeding farm in Ireland her father grew. She recently announced the sponsorship of a series of breeders' awards for winning fillies and mares in Ireland this year called the "Moyglare 50." Brother Martin Haefner is also a billionaire.

name: Billionaires
bio: Andrew and Peggy Cherng are co-CEOs of Panda Express, a chain of casual Chinese food restaurants. In 1966 Andrew came to the U.S. from China with little money. He and his father, trained as a master chef in Japan, opened a sit-down Chinese restaurant, Panda Inn, in 1973. Ten years later he launched the first Panda Express, a fast casual restaurant in the second-largest mall in Los Angeles County. Wife Peggy, a Ph.D. in computer science, left a software development career (3M and McDonnell Douglas) to help him. She served as CEO from 1998 to 2004; now the couple share the title. The $1.6 billion (2011 sales) business operates 1,500 restaurants, including 5 franchises in Mexico and 40 licensees. Up next: a Dry Cleaning partnership with Procter & Gamble; the first location, in a Las Vegas suburb, is dubbed Tide Dry Cleaners.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chey Tae-Won, former chairman of SK Group, one of the largest South Korean conglomerates and owner of the country's biggest mobile carrier and oil refiner, was convicted of embezzling $43 million in late January and sentenced to four years in prison. He is appealing the decision. In December he stepped down as SK's chairman. This is not his first conviction. In 2003 he spent seven months in prison for accounting fraud. He returned to SK after his release and was pardoned in 2008. He is married to the daughter of South Korea's former president, Roh Tae Woo, He has reportedly traveled to the World Economic Forum in Davos every year since 1998. A sports enthusiast, he is the owner of the SK Wyverns baseball team.

name: Billionaires
bio: Starting with one store in 1998, Lucio and Susan Co built their Puregold Price Club into the second largest retailer in the Philippines (after Henry Sy's SM Group) with more than 150 hypermarkets, supermarkets and discount stores. Puregold targets low and middle-income consumers and small store owners. Shares of Puregold have doubled since is its IPO in 2011, bouyed by the retailer's ongoing expansion, earning the Cos a spot on the list for the first time. They also have interests in gaming, hotels, wine distribution, real estate. Two of their children sit on board.

name: Billionaires
bio: Bharat Desai's fortune comes from Syntel, an information technology and outsourcing company in Troy, Michigan, that he founded with his wife in 1980. Born in Kenya, he spent his teenage years in India where he attended the Indian Institute of Technology in Mumbai. He moved to the U.S. in 1976 as a programmer for Tata Consultancy Services. Four years later he left to start Syntel while earning his M.B.A from the University of Michigan. Syntel went public in 1997 and now employs over 21,000 people in more than two dozen offices around the world. Desai stepped down as chief executive in 2009. He remains chairman.
title: Chairman and Co-founder

name: Billionaires
bio: The Sicilian-born elder half of the design duo, Domenico Dolce joins the Forbes Billionaires list thanks to surging revenues at Dolce & Gabbana (just under $1.5 billion in 2011). The fashion house's flamboyant looks (think animal prints and pink fur) have been a mainstay of both the catwalk and the party scene since the two men -- one-time romantic partners -- launched the company 28 years ago. Their brand continues to grow: In 2012 they debuted a couture line. The design duo has been in and out of court of late, charged by the Italian government with allegedly evading millions in corporate taxes by moving assets to Luxembourg. The trial is ongoing.

name: Billionaires
bio: Isabel dos Santos, the oldest daughter of Angola's longtime president, Jose Eduardo dos Santos, debuts on the Forbes list of the World's Billionaires with a fortune estimated at a minimum of $2 billion. She is Angola's first billionaire and the richest woman in Africa. Her first business, opened in 1997 when she was 24, was a restaurant called Miami Beach in Luanda, the Angolan capital. Though her representatives deny that her holdings have any connection with her father, research in Angola shows that President dos Santos has transferred stakes in several companies to his daughter. Her most valuable asset -- worth a conservative $1 billion -- is a 25% stake in Unitel, one of Angola's two mobile phone networks, where Isabel dos Santos is a board member. She also sits on the board of Angola's Banco BIC, where she also has a 25% stake. In Portugal, she owns nearly 15% of ZON Multimedia, a listed cable TV company, and just under 20% of Banco BPI, one of Portugal's largest publicly traded banks.

name: Billionaires
bio: Judy Faulkner founded fast-growing electronic health record software company Epic Systems in 1979. The company pulled in $1.5 billion revenues in 2012. She owns an estimated 33% stake of the private company and is one of just a handful of self-made women billionaires. Her net worth has increased several hundred million dollars compared to last year due to growing revenues and higher market values for its publicly-traded competition. More than 40% of the U.S. population will have its medical information stored in an Epic digital medical record by 2013. Clients include many of the country's top hospitals, including the Cleveland Clinic, Johns Hopkins, and Cedars-Sinai. Faulkner largely shuns the press and leads a modest lifestyle.

name: Billionaires
bio: Carlo Fidani's namesake grandfather founded Fidani and Sons, a Toronto area construction company, in 1948. After his father, Orey, died in 2000, Fidani assumed full ownership of the family business, now known as Orlando Corp. It has expanded into construction, development and management and owns, leases and manages more than 40 million square feet of industrial, office and commercial real estate in the Toronto area. The majority, 32 million square feet, is industrial distribution centers. Fidani has been a significant supporter of health services in the Toronto area, giving to the Carlo Fidani Peel Regional Cancer Centre in Mississauga, the Princess Margaret Hospital Foundation, and the University of Toronto Mississauga.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Alexander Frolov is chief executive of Evraz Group; Alexander Abramov, his partner and fellow billionaire, is chairman. Frolov has managed the steel company's debt burden since the beginning of the global economic crisis. Evraz's debt at its peak, in 2008, was $9.1 billion; by the end of 2011 it had been reduced to $7.2 billion, where it still stands, and that year the company was able to pay its first dividend in three years. Frolov and Abramov sold Energostroyinvest-Holding, a leading energy infrastructure company, in December 2012. Frolov still has an investment in Highlands Gold Mining. He got his start working as a research fellow at the I.V. Kurchatov Institute of Atomic Energy, and he holds a doctorate in physics and mathematics.

name: Billionaires
bio: The younger of the Italian design duo met his business partner and ex-boyfriend Domenico Dolce in 1980. They launched their flashy, flamboyant fashion house Dolce & Gabbana five years later. The line has since become a mainstay of both the catwalk and the party scene, banking revenues of just under $1.5 billion in 2011 and propelling the two to billionaire status this year. Their brand continues to grow: In 2012 the company debuted a couture line. The design duo has been in and out of court of late, charged by the Italian government with allegedly evading millions in corporate taxes by moving assets to Luxembourg. The trial is ongoing.

name: Billionaires
bio: The son of renowned oil baron J. Paul Getty Sr. (d. 1976), Gordon Getty sold  Getty Oil to Texaco in 1984 for about $10 billion, plowing his proceeds into investments and wine. He seeded mutual fund servicing outfit ReFlow Management in 2002 and bought a stake in investment firm Forward Management. Once an aspiring opera singer, Getty now composes operas and hosts numerous events in his native San Francisco for classical connoisseurs. He and his wife Ann preside over a stadium box of the World Series-winning San Francisco Giants. They regularly donate through the Ann & Gordon Getty Foundation to local music programs and foundations as well as Bay Area schools. In recent years Getty and his wife have given at least $1 million annually to the San Francisco Opera. In 2008, they donated $5 million to the University of California system. The pair also fund an invite-only preschool called Playgroup for children of high-profile people in San Francisco.
title: President and Chairman
employment: {'name': 'Ann & Gordon Getty Foundation', 'title': 'President and Chairman', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Walter Haefner, the oldest billionaire at the time of his death at 101 this past June, Martin Haefner inherited half of his father's stake in Computer Associates. Also inherited stake in AMAG, which sells Volkswagon, Seat, Skoda and Audi. Sister Eva-Maria Bucher-Haefner is also a billionaire; runs horse operations.

name: Billionaires
bio: He Qiaonv chairs Beijing Orient Landscape, one of China's largest landscape and interior design companies. She's one of just a handful of billionaire women in China, and her wealth is up a bit since last year thanks to rising shares of Beijing Orient on expectations of more construction spending this year. For the first nine months of 2012, Beijing Orient's revenue increased by 26% to $400 million, lifting net profit by a third to $67 million. Last May the company signed a three-year, $495 million construction contract with Xiangyang city government, the largest of its kind in company history. He added 500,000 shares in Beijing Orient between November and January, and holds almost 54% of its ownership. Husband Tang Kai, the company's vice chairman, holds 11%.

name: Billionaires
bio: In December 2012 retail magnate Igor Kesaev's Mercury Development sold five of the 75 floors of Moscow's pink mirrored Mercury City tower, the tallest building in Europe, to Japan Tobacco International (JTI).  He owns a controlling stake in supermarket chain Dixi, now the third biggest retailer in Russia. A graduate of the prestigious Moscow State Institute of International Relations, in 1991 he founded Mercury Company, which began as a food and alcohol importer and is now the biggest tobacco distributor in Russia. In 2005 he bought a stake in oil company Sibir Energy from former billionaire Shalva Chigirinsky. In the summer of 2009 Kesaev sold his stake in Sibir to state-controlled Gazpromneft.

name: Billionaires
bio: Wolfgang Leitner's is a classic tale of entrepreneurial success. The son of a machine fitter at Andritz AG, he went off to get a doctorate in chemistry and then started working as a research chemist at Vianova/Hoechst. He joined McKinsey as a consultant in 1981 and a few years later took on the challenge of working out a restructuring plan for Andritz. In 1987 he joined the firm as chief financial officer, and today he is its CEO and biggest individual shareholder, and it is one of Europe's largest engineering groups. He holds a nearly 30% stake in Andritz, after leading a 1999 management buyout. He also founded and still runs the pharmaceutical outfit Genericon Pharma.

name: Billionaires
bio: Edwin Leong, who made his fortune from dabbling in real estate, made a startling comment this year when he advised small investors to put their money in shares instead of the property market. Calling investment in his industry a gamble, he disclosed that he'd recently invested in shares of HSBC, China Construction Bank and an exchange-traded fund that invests in China's A-shares. Leong, known as as the "king of shops", founded real estate investor and developer Tai Hung Fai Enterprise, which owns several retail properties and hotels. It recently opened a four-star boutique hotel in Wan Chai that is managed by InterContinental Hotels

name: Billionaires
bio: Former stockbroker Peter Lim has been busy dealmaking since cashing out from palm oil producer Wilmar International in 2010. Stepped up investments in Malaysia recently by partnering state-owned property developer UEM Land Holdings to build Motorsport City, a $1.2 billion motor racing complex in Johor's Iskandar region. His Thomson Medical is partnering with Johor's royal family to build a medical hub there as part of a $ 3 billion integrated development called Vantage Bay being developed by Rowsley, a company that Lim also controls.  His other interests include stakes in Chinese property developer Yanlord Land, retailer FJ Benjamin and British automaker McLaren.

name: Billionaires
bio: In 2011 Yasseen Mansour, the youngest of Egypt's three Mansour brothers, was cleared of charges that he misappropriated state land for Palm Hills Developments, one of Egypt's biggest real estate developers. A major shareholder in Palm Hills along with his brothers, Yasseen stepped down as chief executive in 2011, but remains chairman. The company faces severe debt problems, prompting a Mansour investment company to lend it $100 million. The majority of his fortune is tied up in Mansour Group, which owns General Motors and Caterpillar dealerships. His brothers Mohamed and Youssef are also billionaires.

name: Billionaires
bio: Richard Marriott, the younger of the two billionaire Marriott brothers, has run Host Hotels since 1993, the year he and brother Bill spun the company off from Marriott International amid bondholder protests. Host now operates 121 hotels and properties, and is the largest lodging real estate investment trust in the world. He also has a stake in Marriott International, the board of which Mitt Romney rejoined after his defeat in the 2012 presidential election. The Marriott hotel empire began as a humble root beer stand that Richard's father, J. Willard, opened in Washington D.C. in 1927. He later expanded into catering, restaurants and hotels, and opened his first hotel, the Twin Bridges, in 1957.

name: Billionaires
bio: The father of natural gas shale drilling, George Mitchell was the first to use hydraulic fracking to crack open the Barnett shale field in Texas. He opened the door to development of shales worldwide. In 2002 Mitchell sold his company, Mitchell Energy & Development, for $3.5 billion to Devon Energy, where he remains the biggest shareholder. He spearheaded development of the Woodlands, a huge master-planned community north of Houston. He has completed $24 million in renovations of his three hotels in hometown of Galveston, damaged when Hurricane Ike slammed ashore in 2008. A big giver, he has directed $30 million to the construction of the Giant Magellan telescope, a ground-based replacement for the Hubble.

name: Billionaires
bio: Aeronautical engineer Martin Naughton founded Glen Electric in 1973, acquired Dimplex four years later, and built the combined company into the world's largest manufacturer of electrical heating appliances. Glen Dimplex builds and sells stoves, electrical fireplaces, space heaters, decorative fires and water heaters around the globe. Naughton became sole owner of the company in 2003 and has weathered the economic downturn with investments in new energy-efficient products. He has also avoided debt. He provides scholarships for 60 Irish college students every year and is a trustee emeritus at the University of Notre Dame. Naughton helped facilitate and fund the university's famed football team play a game in Dublin in 2012.

name: Billionaires
bio: Lirio Parisotto began as an entrepreneur but later built his fortune through investing. He created a video and audiotape production company, Videolar, and started investing the profits in the stock market in 1988. His Geracao Futuro L Par fund, of which he owns 92%, is worth $1 billion. His other assets include Brazilian bonds, the majority of Videolar (now a petrochemical company) and real estate in Sao Paulo state. He was born in southern Brazil but now makes his home in the city of Manaus in the Amazon. A firm believer in protecting the Amazon rain forest, he serves as vice president of the Foundation for a Sustainable Amazon.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sean Parker is turning his big vision and huge Rolodex to fighting cancer--in December he joined Stand Up To Cancer to help build an immunology dream team. Parker, 33, is also revamping his  much hyped start-up, Airtime, with the hopes that the video chat site will have the impact of his other Web companies--Napster and Facebook. Facebook's stock comeback helped add $700 million to his fortune since last August. At 19, Parker skipped college to disrupt the recording industry with music swapping site Napster and later advanced viral marketing with his Web address book Plaxo. He served as Facebook's first president at age 24, helping streamline the product and organizing the company to ensure his pal Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook's founder and CEO, maintained control. He's fixing the same music industry he helped dismantle a decade ago as director and cheerleader for hot--and legal--music platform Spotify.

name: Billionaires
bio: Together with his business partner John Arrillaga, Richard Peery built a significant real estate fortune by converting tracts of California farmland into office parks in the 1960s. The duo sold nearly 120 buildings in 2006 for $1.1 billion. Peery's son Dave runs the family foundation, which made grants of nearly $5 million in 2012, primarily to Bay Area charities and international social entrepreneurs. Peery is a 1961 graduate of Brigham Young University.

name: Billionaires
bio: Michael Pieper is new to the Forbes Billionaires list. He is the president and owner of the Artemis Group, which controls the Franke Group. Based in Aarburg, Switzerland, Franke makes sinks, cooker hoods and cooking appliances. It reported sales of $2.4 billion in 2011. In 1975 Michael's father, Will Pieper, acquired Franke, which was founded in 1911. Michael took control in 1988 and expanded into Eastern Europe, Asia, South and North America, and Africa. The Artemis Group also owns and manages a real estate portfolio in Switzerland and abroad, and has a majority stake in the Feintool Group, a company that specializes in precision cutting and automation technology. The Artemis Group had $2.7 billion in sales in 2011 and employs 10,500 people worldwide. Pieper is a board member of several Swiss companies including Forbo a flooring and manufacturing company, Rieter, a maker of textile machinery, and Berenberg Bank. Pieper enjoys sailing and skiing. His son, Alex, is the managing director of Franke's unit in Ras Al Khaimah, United Arab Emirates.
title: CEO of Artemis Group
employment: {'name': 'Artemis Real Estate Partners', 'title': 'CEO of Artemis Group', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False, 'assets': 2237.73, 'assetsYear': 2011, 'revenue': 2506.7, 'revenueYear': 2011, 'employees': 10437, 'employeesYear': 2011}

name: Billionaires
bio: Hailing from a prominent real estate clan in Mumbai, Rajan Raheja struck out on his own to build diversified conglomerate Rajan Raheja Group. Its biggest asset is a 46% stake in Exide Industries, maker of auto and industrial batteries, which has a technical collaboration with American battery maker East Penn Manufacturing. Rupert Murdoch's News Corp, his partner since 2000 in listed cable distribution arm Hathway Cable & Datacom, sold its 17% stake last year to Macquarie Bank and Providence Equity. He bought Dutch bank ING's stake in their life insurance joint venture in January. Sons Akshay, a Columbia Business School grad, and Viren, a London Business School grad, work with him.

name: Billionaires
bio: Onsi Sawiris is the patriarch of Egypt's wealthiest family. The Egyptian government nationalized his first construction business in 1971. Undeterred, he rebuilt what became Orascom Construction Industries. His son Nassef took over in 1995 and OCI is now Egypt's most valuable publicly-traded company. Amid continuing turmoil in Egypt, OCI announced in January 2013 that it was moving its primary listing to NYSE Euronext in Amsterdam with $1 billion in backing from U.S. investors, including Bill Gates.

name: Billionaires
bio: Shin Chang-Jae became chairman of Kyobo Life Insurance in 1997, taking over from his father, who founded the company. Kyobo is South Korea's third largest life insurer. Shin studied to be an obstetrician and worked as a medical school professor at Seoul National University. He runs the Daesan Foundation, which supports Korean arts and culture. His father set up the foundation and also founded the Kyobo Book Center chain, a subsidiary of the insurance group.

name: Billionaires
bio: Shin Dong-Bin is the chairman of Lotte Group. He took over from his 90-year-old father and founder, Shin Kyuk-ho, who still serves as chairman in chief. Shin is rapidly expanding the group, which is best known for its sweets and ice cream but is active in many businesses including golf courses and hotel management. Its Lotte department stores moved into several new overseas locations over the past year including Tianjin, China and Jakarta. It is set to open a store in Hanoi, Vietnam by the end of next year. Lotte operated in Hanoi  back in 2002 through the group's fastfood chain, Lotteria. Lotte Mart, one of South Korea's largest discount-store chains, opened its 200th global location in China in 2011.

name: Billionaires
bio: Martua Sitorus is cofounder and CEO of Singapore-listed Wilmar International, the world's biggest processor of palm oil and eighth-biggest sugar producer. The group gets nearly half of its revenue in cooking-oil sales from China through its Jin Long Yu, or Golden Dragon Fish, brand. China imposed a cap on price increases of edible oils in 2011 and 2012, which put a damper on Wilmar's share price, driving Sitorus's wealth down $1 billion. Sitorus traded shrimp as a teenager. He cofounded Wilmar with Kuok Khoon Hong, the nephew of Malaysia's richest man, Robert Kuok. Sitorus and Kuok Khoon Hong also own London skyscraper Aviva Tower.  Sitorus holds a degree in economics from HKBP Nomensen University in Medan, Indonesia.

name: Billionaires
bio: Michal Solowow started out in the late 1980s with construction company Mitex, which he sold in 2002 to French investor Eiffage. He continues to grow his stakes in four Polish public companies: chemicals firm Synthos, ceramics maker Rovese, real estate developer Echo Investment and flooring outfit Barlinek. He is also consolidating his private assets, selling several of his indirectly held companies to Rovese this year. The avid racecar driver is regularly on the scene at the European Rally Championships.

name: Billionaires
bio: Tahir, whose father had a business making pedicabs and whose mother owned a fabric shop, had to quit medical school in Taiwan because of his father's ill health. He later studied business in Singapore and returned to Indonesia, where he started Bank Mayapada, now one of nation's largest privately held banks. The bulk of his fortune comes from the bank and also from real estate holdings. He owns several buildings in Jakarta, hotels in Bali and Batam, and a new tower in Singapore. He is also a co-investor in the licensee that publishes Forbes Indonesia. Tahir has donated more than $50 million to universities in China, Indonesia, the U.S. and Singapore, where he is a permanent resident. His wife, Rosy, the daughter of another Indonesian tycoon, Mochtar Riady, recently started h2h Charity, which has a vintage shop in Jakarta, proceeds from which are donated to help provide schooling for underprivileged children in Indonesia.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ted Turner invented the 24-hour news channel in 1980 when he launched CNN. He got his start working for his father at Turner Advertising. In 1963, his father committed suicide. In 1970, he started buying television stations and turned those investments into Turner Broadcasting. In 1996 he sold Turner Broadcasting to Time Warner. When it merged with AOL in 2001, he became the largest individual shareholder, then lost $7 billion in two years after the shares collapsed. Since then he has devoted himself to philanthropy, with a focus on protecting endangered species, nuclear disarmament and environmental sustainability. In 1997 he pledged to give $1 billion to the United Nations; so far he has given $916 million. He is one of the nation's largest private landowners. His holdings include more than two million acres across 13 states.

name: Billionaires
bio: Martin Viessmann owns Viessmann Werke GmbH, one of Europe's largest producers of boilers and heating equipment. Sales at the private company rose 8% in 2011 to $2.5 billion (1.86 billion Euros) and were expected to climb another 5% in 2012. The company has 10 manufacturing plants around the world, including in Canada, Germany, Poland and China. Viesmann's grandfather founded the group more than 90 years ago. In 2008, Viesmann moved to the supervisory board to concentrate on company strategy. His company supports the Viessmann Academy to provide training for heating architects and engineers. In May 2012 Viessmann received an honorary doctorate from the University of Wisconsin. He also has a professional pilot's license.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former civil engineer Thongma Vijitpongpun founded Pruksa Real Estate, a builder and developer of townhouses, housing estates and condos, in 1993. He enters the billionaire ranks as Pruksa's stock price has rebounded after plunging in 2011 when floods hit more than 100 of its projects on the outskirts of Bangkok. Pruksa, which is expanding into India, Indonesia, the Maldives and Vietnam, plans to launch 216 projects in 2013. Thongma runs the company according to Buddhist philosophy.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chinese real estate and shipbuilding entrepreneur Zhang Zhirong returns to the ranks of the world's billionaires but has suffered a drop in his wealth from a year ago after a tumultuous year. Zhang paid $14 million to settle an insider trading case in the U.S. last year in connection with a Chinese government company's purchase of Canadian energy firm Nexen. That was followed by his resignation from the chairmanship of his two main businesses, shipbuilder China Rongsheng and real estate developer Glorious Property, to "devote more time to his personal endeavors." Finally, he cut his stake in Rongsheng in January through the transfer of a 11% stake to his father at no cost and the sale of a 7% stake to Rongsheng's CEO for $105 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Jean Coutu, a pharmacist by training, founded and chairs the Jean Coutu Group, which operates a network of 400 franchised drugstores in Canada and owns about 20% of U.S. drugstore operator Rite Aid. Revenues for the year through March 2012 were about $2.8 billion, up nearly 5% from the previous year. His net worth is up more than $300 million from a year ago due to an uptick in the company's share price. Coutu opened his first drug store in 1969 and gradually built up the group. He served as chief executive of the company until 2002, and then again from 2005 to 2007. He now sits as chairman of the board, while his son Francois oversees day-to-day operations as president and CEO. Coutu is also a founder of the Québec Association of pharmacists-owners and the Fondation Marcelle et Jean Coutu, a charitable foundation dedicated to fighting poverty and promoting wellness. The Jean Coutu Group is the largest shareholder in Rite Aid, which purchased Coutu Group's U.S. subsidiary in 2007, but has been whittling down its holding in the U.S. drugstore chain. It sold 56 million shares of Rite Aid, nearly a quarter of its stake, in April 2012.
title: Entrepreneur

name: Billionaires
bio: B. Wayne Hughes made his fortune from the Public Storage chain, which he built from one self-storage facility he opened back in 1972. He stepped down as CEO of the company in 2002 and now serves as chairman. Hughes is well known in the thoroughbred racing world, spending much of his time on his 700-acre Spendthrift Farm in Kentucky. He's also an avid supporter of conservative politics and causes. During the 2010 midterm election cycle he gave $3.5 million to Karl Rove's right-leaning super PAC, American Crossroads. He has shed assets to his family, including daughter Tamara Gustavson, who became a billionaire in 2010 and sits on the Public Storage board.

name: Billionaires
bio: Saleh Kamel is the founder and chairman of Dallah Albaraka, a conglomerate with interests in Islamic banking, real estate development and food production. Kamel took subsidiary Dallah Health public in December 2012, keeping a 52% stake. The company runs a hospital in Riyadh and distributes pharmaceuticals and dietary supplements. Dallah is also involved in developing a light rail system, an urban community and a mosque around Mecca.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ma Jianrong chairs Shenzhou International Group, a manufacturer of knitwear whose customers include Nike, Uniqlo and Adidas. His wealth has jumped from a year ago owing to a 75% increase in the company's Hong Kong-listed shares. Ma made it to the top job at Shenzhou as part of a career that included a stop as manager of the company's knitting and weaving department. Ma trimmed his holding in Shenzhou earlier this year, but remains the company's biggest shareholder. He is the vice chairman of the China Knitting Industrial Association, and a member of the People's Congress of Zhejiang Province. Ma's brother-in-law, Huang Guanlin, is an executive director at Shenzhou, as is his cousin Ma Renhe.

name: Billionaires
bio: Part owner in Egyptian conglomerate Mansour Group with his brothers Mohamed and Yasseen, Youssef Mansour keeps a low profile. He was responsible for building Egypt's largest supermarket chain, Metro, which recently received an offer from Emirati billionaire Majid Al Futtaim for up to $300 million. Mansour Group continues to generate strong sales from its Caterpillar dealerships in Russia, Africa and Iraq. Sales of its General Motors vehicles are back up thanks in part to Iraq, where the Mansours also have dealerships. Youssef now devotes his time to the family foundation, which targets illiteracy and education.

name: Billionaires
bio: Thailand's Channel 7, operated by Bangkok Broadcasting & TV, owned and run by media baron Krit Ratanarak, continues to dominate with a 33% market share. His fortune is up on higher ad revenues, up 12% in 2012. He also has big stakes in Bank of Ayudhaya and Siam City Cement, Thailand's second largest cement company, both founded by late father Chuan. In December, he bought back 9.3% stake in Siam City Cement from Swiss cement maker Holcim making family with 30% holding, the largest shareholder for the first time since the Asian economic crisis in 1997.

name: Billionaires
bio: Romesh Wadhwani, founder and chairman of Symphony Technologies Group, has turned his focus to investing. In 1969, he landed in the U.S. with only a few dollars in his pocket. He later developed business software firm Aspect Development with funding from Sequoia Capital and sold it in 2000 during the height of the tech bubble in to i2 Technologies for $9.3 billion. When the bubble burst, Wadhwani's fortune shriveled due to the all-stock deal. He then invested $250 million of his money to start, acquire or build 14 business software and IT companies. Wadhwani attended the Indian Institute of Technology in Mumbai and earned a Ph.D. in electrical engineering at Carnegie Mellon. His Wadhwani Foundation, with assets of more than $100 million, backs skills development colleges for young adults in India who decide that higher education is not the right path. Wadhwani signed Bill Gates' and Warren Buffett's Giving Pledge in September.
title: Founder and Chairman
employment: {'name': 'Symphony Technology Group', 'title': 'Founder and Chairman', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: John Arrillaga made his fortune developing commercial real estate in Silicon Valley. Working with Richard (Dick) Peery, the two men bought California farmland and built office buildings on it. The Peery-Arrillaga firm now oversees just under three million square feet of office buildings and 290 acres of land in and around San Jose and counts Google and Apple as tenants. Arrillaga has met a roadblock with his latest venture in Palo Alto. Residents fear that his proposed development, known as 27 University Ave - a 210,000 square foot project for office rental and a permanent home for TheatreWorks - would be too big to swallow. Arrillaga is a prominent backer of athletics at Stanford University. He reportedly lives in a lavish 210-acre estate in the foothills west of Stanford.

name: Billionaires
bio: Syrian-born Wharton MBA Ayman Asfari heads the oil services firm Petrofac. The company signed $5 billion in new contracts last year, including deals with Saudi Aramco, Pemex, and Apache Corp. Profits for 2012 were up 17% versus a year ago. He joined Petrofac in 1991, when it was one plant in Tyler, Texas, and then bought it out in 2001. A London resident, he took it public on the London Stock Exchange in 2005. His Asfari Foundation is creating a new institute with the American University of Beirut to focus on civil society and citizenship in the Arab world. When he isn't tending to his growing oil empire, he spends time on his yacht in the south of France.

name: Billionaires
bio: Hailing from a storied business clan in Kolkata, Benu Gopal Bangur controls North Indian cementmaker Shree Cement, whose shares have jumped by 82% in the past year on surging revenues and earnings. Company, which his son Hari Mohan has been running since 2002, is a star performer in its sector. Thanks to higher revenues from its power unit, its net profits more than tripled in the past quarter to $40 million. It has invested $400 million in the last 3 years in power plants and cement units in Rajasthan.  He plays volleyball once a week.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chao Teng-Hsiung is the chairman of Taipei real estate developer Farglory Land Development. Already one of the best-known real estate companies in Taiwan, Farglory is adding to that profile by building a 'Taipei Dome' stadium next to City Hall.  Chao also has a personal real estate empire in the mainland that includes several buildings in Shanghai. He grew up on a farm in central Taiwan and arrived in Taipei with a suitcase full of rice as a young man before finding entrepreneurial success.  He also operates an insurance company. Chao hikes for an hour each day before coming to work.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chu Lam Yiu, one of the world's youngest self-made female billionaires, chairs Huabao International Holdings, a giant producer of flavorings in China. Chu's wealth has declined following allegations of accounting problems at her company. Huabao has denied accusations of wrongdoing but its stock price hasn't fully rebounded. Huabao said in December that Chu will add the CEO title to her chairman post in April following the resignation of Lau Chi Tak.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chung Mong-Joon is South Korea's richest politician, thanks to his stake in Korean shipbuilder Hyundai Heavy Industries. The assemblyman, who is a former ruling party leader, is the biggest individual shareholder in the company, which he ran until 1988 when he entered politics. A representative of the Saenuri Party, Chung has recently showed his support for nuclear armament, saying, "Seoul can no longer deal with a neighboring rogue state armed with a machine gun, when it only has a piece of stone." He is said to have close ties to South Korea's former president, Lee Myung Bak, who used to work at Hyundai. The Hyundai conglomerate was founded by Chung Mong-Joon's father, Chung Ju Yung. Hyundai Motors is now run by his billionaire brother, Chung Mong-Koo. Chung Mong-Joon is the honorary vice president of FIFA, the world governing body for soccer.

name: Billionaires
bio: British media magnate Richard Desmond is stemming the fall in advertising revenue at his newspapers, the Daily Express and Daily Star, as well as his OK! magazine by cutting costs and capitalizing on synergies including his new printing plant. He is even considering buying more titles. Desmond is also redoubling efforts at his Channel 5 broadcaster after he received a 10-year extension on his license from the government. Channel 5 airs Dallas, American Idol and Celebrity Big Brother, and is planning more children's programming. Meanwhile his new venture, The Health Lottery, got a boost when Desmond won a high court case brought against him by Camelot, the operator of the multi-billion-dollar U.K. National Lottery, which sought to revoke Desmond's lottery license. He also brought suit against Credit Suisse Group for selling him a complex derivative product worth $80 million that left him with a large exposure. A high school dropout, Desmond started his first magazine, International Musician, in 1974 and built a stable of titles. At one point he owned more than 40 adult entertainment publications, which he sold in 2004. He bought British newspaper group Express in 2000. For fun and charity, he plays drums with his band RD Crusaders, whose other musicians include members of The Who and Led Zeppelin.

name: Billionaires
bio: Media mogul Barry Diller owns more than 150 web companies through his IAC conglomerate, including dating sites Match.com and OKCupid and online reference sites Dictionary.com and Reference.com. In January 2013 IAC bought online tutoring service Tutor.com. In late 2011 Diller spun off travel review aggregator TripAdvisor from his booking service outfit Expedia.
