In 2010 his Daily Beast site merged with Newsweek magazine. In July 2012 he told analysts he's debating taking the struggling print publication online-only. Fox and ABC are suing his IAC-backed Aereo, a broadcast startup that streams TV content to subscribers' smartphones and iPads.  A UCLA dropout, Diller started out in the mailroom at the William Morris agency. He worked at ABC, Paramount and Fox between 1964 and 1992 and oversaw the launch of hit TV shows including Cheers and The Simpsons. In 1995 he started IAC and bought the Home Shopping Network two years later. He is married to fashion designer Diane von Furstenberg. Their Diller-von Furstenberg Family Foundation donates to numerous causes including  Human Rights Watch, Jewish groups and Friends of the High Line.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Europe's largest mobile phone retailer, The Carphone Warehouse, Charles Dunstone received  £227 million pre-tax in 2012 when the company sold its 50% share of Best Buy Mobile back to the U.S. retailer. Carphone still has joint venture with Best Buy, with the two sharing ownership of Carphone Warehouse Europe. With about $12,000 in savings, Dunstone started the firm from his London apartment; now the company has more than 2,400 stores across Europe. Over the last few years the firm has undergone significant change, including the successful demerger of U.K. telecom firm Talktalk. Dunstone is an avid yachtsman and participates in sailing regattas across the globe.

name: Billionaires
bio: Gleb Gennadevich Fetisov maintains a large stake in Altimo, the company that inherited the assets of the food-and-commodity-trading business Alfa Eco. In April 2012, when Altimo sold its 25.1% stake in the mobile phone operator MegaFon to Alisher Usmanov for $5.2 billion, Fetisov made almost $740 million on the deal. He also owns My Bank, in Moscow, as well as My Decker Capital, an investment firm in Beijing that has a fund that in 2011 poured about $100 million into China's largest retail chain, New Cooperation Trade Chain. He studied economics at Moscow State University, earning a doctorate, and headed several investment firms before joining Alfa Group in 1995. There he first worked at Alfa Eco and later led the group's takeover of an aluminum plant in Siberia. He also became a lobbyist and a member of the Federation Council, the upper house of parliament, but stepped down in 2009. In the spring of 2012 he became the head of a new political party, Green Alliance?People's Party.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ken Fisher is a 28-year portfolio strategy columnist for Forbes and author of 8 finance-related books. He founded his money management outfit Fisher Investments in 1979. He also owns several commercial properties in Northern California and Washington State. He bought 2,000 acres of redwood timber in Mendocino last year. He and his wife gave $7.5 million to John Hopkins University in 2012 to fund a new infectious disease center. In 2006 he gave $3.5 million to fund the Kenneth L. Fisher Chair in Redwood Forest Ecology at northern California's Humboldt State University, his alma mater.

name: Billionaires
bio: Lindsay Fox, owner of Australia's biggest privately owned trucking company, Linfox, saw his business come roaring back after a tough year in 2011. His fortune is up by nearly 25%. He expanded into India and elsewhere in Asia and followed the mining boom in western Australia. In Melbourne, his hometown, he's planning to expand Avalon Airport, the small terminal he owns on the city's western fringe. Linfox is also building up its property portfolio. He sits on the board of directors of Premier Investments, the retail investment company owned by friend and fellow billionaire Simon Lew. Fox left his school for academically gifted boys at 16 to become a truck driver like his father and bought his first truck at 19. In April 2012 he held a three-day, $1-million-plus birthday party. He owns a 100-year-old Melbourne amusement part, Luna Park.

name: Billionaires
bio: In 2012 Alec Gores' Los Angeles private equity firm, Gores Group, bought four information technology companies. The firm also made headlines in May 2012 after a proposed $800 million buyout of auto parts shop Pep Boys fell apart. Gores Group paid $50 million in penalty fees. In March 2012 the firm announced plans to close a $300 million fund that targeted middle-market firms. In 2011 Gores reportedly looked into buying British music label EMI Group, which was eventually sold to Universal Music. He launched the firm in 1987 and has acquired 80 companies over 25 years. His younger brother, Tom, is also a billionaire.

name: Billionaires
bio: Carlos Hank Rhon's family holds 93% of Grupo Financiero Interacciones, the listed company that controls Banco Interacciones, a financial services firm and investment bank in Mexico that accounts for nearly $1.2 billion of Hank Rhon's fortune. Carlos and his family also control Grupo Hermes; its Hermes Infraestructura arm builds bridges, roads and hydroelectric plants. One Grupo Hermes marquee project: an $85 million contract to build six giant steam generators for a $20 billion petrochemical complex in Saudi Arabia, a joint venture of Saudi Aramco and Dow Chemical. Hermes also built and operates the Museo del Mundo Maya (Museum of the Mayan World) in Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula, which opened in 2012. A room in the new Rufino Tamayo museum in Mexico City also bears Hank Rhon's name. Hank's wife, Graciela, is a daughter of Gruma tortilla billionaire Roberto Gonzalez Barrera, who died in 2012.

name: Billionaires
bio: For security reasons Saad Hariri, son of slain Lebanese Prime Minister Rafik Hariri, has been living outside of Lebanon, splitting his time between his homes in Paris and Riyadh. In 2011 he lost his own post as prime minister to billionaire Najib Mikati. He has been calling on Islamist party Hezbollah to disarm. (The group was implicated in his father's assassination.) He is a vocal opponent of Syrian dictator Bashar al-Assad. Syria issued a warrant for Hariri's arrest for allegedly funding opponents to Assad. He remains chairman and CEO of Saudi Oger, one of the largest construction companies in Saudi Arabia and the source of the family's wealth.

name: Billionaires
bio: Low-profile real estate magnate Elie Horn founded Cyrela Brazil Realty in 1978 and built it into the largest publicly traded developer of high-end residential buildings in Sao Paulo and Rio de Janeiro. A workaholic, he was born in Syria, arrived in Brazil when he was 11, and started working when he was 19. He reportedly still works 16 hours a day but respects Shabbat; Cyrela does not close any deals from Friday afternoon through Saturday evening. Horn has announced he will leave Cyrela in 2015 and there are rumors that one of his sons will lead the company. In 2012 he resigned from the board of Brasilagro, an agricultural development company. He also owns shares in listed Cyrela Commercial Properties, which acquires, develops and rents shopping centers and corporate buildings in Sao Paulo and Rio. He told the Brazilian press years ago that he planned to give away most of his fortune at his death; he reportedly gives 20% of his earnings to charity every year, including to causes in Israel.

name: Billionaires
bio: Johnelle Hunt cofounded J.B. Hunt Transport Services with her late husband, Johnnie, in 1969. Johnnie died in 2006 at the age of 79. JBHT is one of the largest transport companies in U.S., with more than 12,000 trucks and trailers. Its share price has risen in the last year and the company has diversified through Hunt Ventures. Among its recent projects: a rock quarry in Honduras and Pinnacle Hills Memorial Gardens, a cemetery and 3,000-square foot-chapel in Johnelle's home state of Arkansas that opened in 2012. Hunt built the cemetery in Johnnie's honor. In November 2012 she moved her husband's remains there and held a memorial service attended by fellow billionaire Alice Walton and Congressman Steve Womack. The Women's Foundation of Arkansas recognized Hunt as 2012's Woman of the Year in Philanthropy for her commitment to the community.

name: Billionaires
bio: Michael Jaharis launched Kos Pharmaceuticals in 1988. Kos pioneered the cholesterol-fighting drug Niaspan and sold it to Abbott Labs in 2006 for $4.2 billion. Jaharis got his B.A. from Caroll College and went to law school at DePaul University. He began his career in pharmaceuticals in 1972 when he took over Key Pharmaceuticals with fellow billionaire Philip Frost. He served as CEO until 1986 when the company merged with Schering-Plough. In 2005 he founded Arisaph Pharmaceuticals, where he serves as a director. As a philanthropist he has made big donations to Tufts University. The school's Center for Nutritional and Biomedical Sciences carries his name. He is also a trustee emeritus and chairman of the board of overseers for the medical school. He has given $7 million to the Metropolitan Museum of Art to support the Greek, Roman and Byzantine art collection. He is Vice Chairman of the Archdiocesan Council of the Greek Orthodox Archdiocese of America.

name: Billionaires
bio: Brad Kelley made his fortune from discounted cigarette brands like USA Gold, Bull Durham and Malibu. He sold the business, Commonwealth Brands, for $1 billion in 2001 to conglomerate Houchens Industries. Now a rancher; he is one of the top five landowners in the U.S. with 1.7 million acres in Texas, Florida and New Mexico. He is breeds and races thoroughbred horses. He purchased the historic Calumet Farm in Lexington, Kentucky in May 2012 and his horse Optimizer ran in the 2012 Kentucky Derby.

name: Billionaires
bio: Andrei Klyamko owns Ukraine's Smart Holding Group, together with his partner and fellow billionaire Vadim Novinsky, and Smart Holding Group has a 24% stake in Metinvest, Ukrainian billionaire Rinat Akhmetov's iron ore producer. Klyamko also has stakes in Yuzhny GOK, a major independent iron ore mine in Ukraine, Regal Petroleum, an oil and gas company, and Amstor, a supermarket chain. He is president of the Sambo Federation of St. Petersburg, a martial arts organization.

name: Billionaires
bio: Kenneth Langone is the CEO of a small tech firm, Geeknet, with just $23 million in sales, but he's also a famed investment banker who made his first mark taking Ross Perot's Electronic Data Systems public, in 1968. He raised millions in capital to aid in the founding of The Home Depot in 1978, and he left that company's board after 30 years in 2010 and joined Geeknet the same year. He was the chair of the New York Stock Exchange's compensation committee from 1999 to 2002 and a board member until 2003; he was thrust into the limelight when he was forced to testify in a lawsuit over the $187 million pay package the Exchange had awarded to its former chief Richard Grasso. Langone is chairman of the Promise Academy, a charter school in New York City, and his Ken's Krew gives people with disabilities training and jobs at Home Depot and CVS stores. He gave an unrestricted $200 million gift to NYU Langone Medical Center in 2008. He is a graduate of the part-time MBA program at NYU, and it took his name after a 1999 donation of $10 million. He led a group of Republican donors to encourage New Jersey governor Chris Christie to run for president in 2012, then backed Mitt Romney after Christie declined.

name: Billionaires
bio: Richard Li Chairs Hong Kong's largest telecom company, PCCW. He revealed his ambitions for an Asian insurance business when he announced a $2.1 billion deal for ING's Hong Kong, Macau and Thai insurance units in October 2012. The purchase is to be funded by his father, Hong Kong's richest person, Li Ka-shing, who would own the assets for now. The deal follows the purchase of asset manager PineBridge Investments from AIG in 2010. In 1991 Richard borrowed $125 million from his father to launch satellite network StarTV. He sold it five years later to Rupert Murdoch for $950 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Igor Makarov is the founder of Itera, a gas company that through the second half of the 1990s was Russia's main exporter of gas from Turkmenistan. In 2012 Itera began a joint venture with Rosneft, the oil company; Rosneft estimated that Itera's business was worth about $3 billion. Makarov has made the most of gas-rich Turkmenistan, where he was born, as well as of his connections with high-ranking officials at the Russian natural gas monopoly Gazprom. His company acquired Gazprom assets for next to nothing and ended up owning big gas fields, but then in 2001, after Vladimir Putin shook up the leadership of Gazprom, Itera nearly lost its business; Makarov managed to save the company by turning over some assets to Gazprom. Itera holds a stake in the Dinamo Riga team in Russia's professional hockey league. Makarov is also the president of the Russian Cycling Federation and was once a member of the USSR cycling team.

name: Billionaires
bio: Joe Mansueto's Morningstar improved performance in 2012; net profits at the financial research firm climbed 9.9% year-over-year. Mansueto started the company in 1984 in his Chicago apartment, using $80,000 in savings. In 2005 he took the firm public. In December 2010 he joined the Giving Pledge, promising to donate more than half his fortune. A library in his name has been completed at his alma mater, the University of Chicago, thanks to his $25 million gift. Morningstar's assets include the Standard & Poor's fund data business and the U.K. media and data business arms of Hemscott, which have been integrated into Morningstar. Manseuto also owns the magazines Inc. and Fast Company. In January 2013 he signed his name to a pledge by corporate backers, including Groupon and Google, urging Illinois lawmakers to legalize gay marriage, calling it an economic imperative.
title: Entrepreneur, Investor
employment: {'name': 'Morningstar Inc.', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Former Iams chief Clayton Mathile has moved from pet food to high-tech communications with his investment in video chat company ooVoo. He also is helping small business owners take their companies to the next level with his $130 million entrepreneur campus, Aileron, in central Ohio. He started as a Campbell Soup accountant and joined Iams as general manager in 1970. He bought the firm in 1982. Mathile pushed premium pet food to high-end breeders and vets during the '80s and '90s. He sold Iams to Procter & Gamble for $2.3 billion in 1999 and gave employees $100 million of his personal cut. His wife, MaryAnn, runs the Mathile Family Foundation, promoting education.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partner and fellow billionaire, Andrei Klyamko owns Ukraine's Smart Holding Group, which has a 24% stake in billionaire Rinat Akhmetov's iron ore producer Metinvest. Novinsky also has stakes in oil and gas company Regal Petroleum and supermarket chain Amstor. The Russian native got his Ukrainian citizenship this year. He has worked in Ukraine since the mid-1990s starting with Lukoil North West, and then buying Ukrainian metallurgy companies, uniting them in 2006 into Smart Holding Group; in 2007, he exchanged them for the Metinvest stake.

name: Billionaires
bio: Jose Isaac Peres has had a good year. The stock price of Multiplan, the shopping mall developer he founded in 1975, has risen, boosting his net worth by $400 million. Multiplan manages 17 malls in Brazil. At age 22 while he was still an economics student, he founded his first company, real estate developer Vepan. The Rio de Janeiro native is passionate about his hometown and refuses to move Multiplan's headquarters to Sao Paulo, Brazil's main financial main center.
title: Entrepreneur

name: Billionaires
bio: Movie producer Jean "Gigi" Pritzker is one of 10 members of the extended Pritzker family on the Billionaires List. Gigi has been buying Hyatt shares from her cousins Linda and James. She owns the tiny (12 employees) film production company Odd Lot Entertainment, which backed the hit film "Drive" in 2011. The company is slated to release the film of Orson Scott Card's science fiction tale, "Ender's Game," starring Harrison Ford, in November 2013. Her grandfather, A.N. Pritzker (d. 1986), with sons Jay (d. 1999), Robert (d. 2011) and Donald (d. 1972), created industrial conglomerate Marmon and hotel chain Hyatt. In 2007, the family sold control of industrial conglomerate Marmon Holdings to Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway for $4.5 billion. Gigi is president and a trustee of the Pritzker Pucker Family Foundation, which has given to kidney research, the Chicago Children's Theatre and various schools.

name: Billionaires
bio: Dirk Rossmann debuts on FORBES list of the World's Billionaires this year. He founded and still runs privately held German drugstore chain Dirk Rossmann GmbH, which has 2,775 stores in six European countries. Revenues climbed 16% to $7.9 billion (5.95 billion Euros) in 2012. Rossmann owns 60% of the company; he sold a 40% stake in the 1980s that is now owned by Hong Kong billionaire Li Ka-Shing's Hutchison Whampoa. Rossmann opened Germany's first self-service drugstore in 1972, when he was 25, as deregulation of prices for pharmacy products was beginning. It's now the second largest drugstore chain in Germany. He also owns 25% of listed German private equity firm Deutsche Beteiligungs AG (DBAG). In 1991 he created a charitable foundation focused on family planning. His two sons, Daniel and Raoul, also work at Rossmann.

name: Billionaires
bio: Shin Dong-Joo is the eldest son of Lotte Group founder Shin Kyuk-ho, who founded the company as a confectionery manufacturer. Lotte Group is known for its sweets and ice cream but operates in several sectors, including golf course and hotel management. Shin is the vice chairman of Lotte Holdings and the vice-president of Lotte Group in Japan. He lives in Tokyo. Most of his fortune comes from his stake in publicly traded department store arm Lotte Shopping.

name: Billionaires
bio: Donald Sterling made a fortune acquiring apartment buildings in Los Angeles, Orange County, San Diego and Las Vegas. His net worth as risen by several hundred million dollars over the past year along with values of apartments, particularly in Los Angeles. He has owned the Los Angeles Clippers basketball team since 1981. The team had one of its best seasons in 2012. In December a Los Angeles jury ordered Sterling to pay $17.3 million in a lawsuit filed by an actress, Robyn Cohen, who lost most of her belongings in a fire at a West Hollywood apartment building Sterling owns. Sterling's son, Scott Ashley Sterling, 32, was found dead in his Malibu home in January, after an apparent accidental drug overdose.

name: Billionaires
bio: Georg von Opel is the great grandson of Adam Opel, the auto pioneer and namesake of the German car company, Opel. Georg von Opel graduated from the University of Rhode Islands in business administration. He inherited $150 million in 1989 after his father's death and carefully invested the money in investment group Hansa AG. In 2009, he sold his share of Swiss Jelmoli Holding to real estate company Swiss Prime Site for $230 million in cash and a 9% stake in the company. Von Opel Also controls 96% of private investment firm Athris through which he has stakes in a Swiss hotel chain, a restaurant chain, a sports store and shopping centers in Russia and Algeria. A long-time Swiss resident, his Georg and Emily von Opel foundation funds care and education of underprivileged children and teens in developing countries.

name: Billionaires
bio: Meg Whitman has had a challenging time as CEO of Hewlett-Packard, as shares in the struggling technology giant tumbled. Nevertheless, her net worth grew by $500 million in the pat year, thanks to a surge in the value of her shares in eBay, where she was CEO for 10 years, until early 2008. Though she agreed to take just $1 in annual base pay at H-P, she received compensation valued at $15.4 million for the fiscal year that ended in October 2012, including a $1.7 million bonus and stock awards and options. In 2010 she spent a chunk of her fortune on a failed run for the California governor's office. Also that year she turned down Warren Buffett's invitation to join the Giving Pledge, where donors agree to give away at least half their fortunes to charity. She serves on the boards of P&G and car sharing company ZipCar. Whitman took the top job at H-P in the fall of 2011.
title: CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: Liu Zhongtian is the founder and chairman of China Zhongwang, a maker of aluminum extrusion products used in the transportation industry. He has expanded Zhongwang's sales in China in the past few years after being hit with anti-dumping duties in the U.S. market. Liu's wealth is little changed from a year ago following a dip in Zhongwang's share price amid slack global economic conditions. Liu holds a degree in administrative management from Liaoning Radio and TV University. He is a member of the executive committee of the All-China Federation of Industry and Commerce and the vice chairman of the Liaoning Federation of Industry and Commerce.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former surgeon Prasert Prasarttong-Osoth becomes a billionaire as shares of Bangkok Dusit Medical Services, the hospital group he co-founded, rose 38% in 2012, amid Thailand's medical tourism boom. It has a network of 29 hospitals. He owns 22% of company after buying out co-founder for $320 million in October. He's planning a $250 million IPO of Bangkok Airways, the regional airline he founded, to fund its fleet expansion from 19 to 30 aircraft.

name: Billionaires
bio: John Pritzker grew up in a hotel-focused family and it has stayed in his blood. An heir to the Hyatt hotel fortune and a former Hyatt executive, Pritzker sold his Hyatt shares to his family in 2010 and has been busy building a boutique hotel business. In October 2011 he created Commune Hotels by merging the San Francisco-based Joie de Vivre chain with Thompson Hotels of New York. He co-chairs Commune with Thomson Hotels' owner Jason Pomeranc. The company had $380 million revenue in 2011 from 42 hotels and has ambitious plans to expand. Pritzker bought control of boutique hotel chain Joie de Vivre in 2010 via his San Francisco investment firm Geolo Capital. He is passionate about photography; his collection includes works by Richard Avedon and Man Ray. He and his wife, Lisa, have pledged $15 million to the University of California at San Francisco for new pediatric emergency room facilities at the UCSF Benioff Children's Hospital now under construction. The Lisa and John Pritzker Family Fund, run by Lisa Pritzker, supports organizations and programs focused on children's and adolescent health and education, civic activities, and Jewish affairs.

name: Billionaires
bio: Penny is the political Pritzker. An heir to the Hyatt Hotel and Pritzker family fortune, she was a key fundraiser for Barack Obama's presidential run in 2008, but was less visible in the 2012 election cycle. This winter she was considered to be the front-runner for Commerce Secretary. The decision is yet to be made. Chicago Mayor Rahm Emanuel counts her among his confidants, and she is a member of the Chicago Board of Education. In 2011 she donated $5 million to Chicago's Museum of Contemporary Art, an institution she has given to previously. Back in 2007, her family sold control of industrial conglomerate Marmon Holdings to Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway for $4.5 billion. Penny's grandfather A.N. Pritzker (d. 1986), with his sons Jay (d. 1999), Donald (d. 1972) and Robert (d. 2011), created Marmon and hotel chain Hyatt. Penny is a trustee at Stanford University, co-founder of investment firm Artemis Real Estate Partners and a board member at Hyatt Hotels.

name: Billionaires
bio: Luis Enrique Yarur Rey joins the billionaire ranks for the first time this year. His wealth comes almost entirely from his 42% stake in the holding company Empresas Juan Yarur S.A.C., which holds 54% of Banco de Crédito e Inversiones (BCI), a leading Chilean bank specializing in savings & deposits, asset management, securities brokerage, and insurance. He inherited his stake in the bank from his uncle Jorge Yarur Banna. In 2011 BCI had total assets amounting to $32.9 billion and until 2008 was the Latin American partner of Bear Stearns. Yarur Rey assumed the post of Chairman in October of 1991. Prior to that, he was CEO of BCI for 11 years. In Chile, Yarur Rey is a prominent member of the Catholic group, Opus Dei.

name: Billionaires
bio: Zhang Hongwei is chairman of United Energy Group, one of China's largest private-sector oil businesses. The company acquired the upstream operations of BP in Pakistan for $775 million in 2011, and has since increased production there. Zhang's Shanghai-listed Orient Group Incorporation owns 3.1% of China Minsheng Banking, one of China's largest non-government controlled banks. Zhang is the bank's  vice chairman. He also has interests in real estate and retailing. His daughter Zhang Meiying is a director at United Energy.

name: Billionaires
bio: Creator of the Slim-Fast brand, S. Daniel Abraham is also a generous donor to Jewish causes and the Democratic Party. He has funded Barack Obama's presidential campaign, a scholarship program for Jewish college students interested in studying the Torah after graduation and a Washington, D.C. center devoted to promoting Middle East peace. The conflict in the Middle East is a particular interest for Abraham, who penned a book chronicling his behind-the-scenes dealings with leaders in the region. The Long Island-born entrepreneur and World War II combat veteran joined his uncle's medical supply company after leaving the army. He founded Slim-Fast in 1977, after failed attempts to market itch cream and weight-loss gum. He took it public two years later and private again in 1987. He sold the company to Unilever for $2.3 billion in 2000.
organization: S. Daniel Abraham Center for Middle East Peace
title: Chairman
employment: {'name': 'S. Daniel Abraham Center for Middle East Peace', 'title': 'Chairman', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: In 2012 Aras Agalarov, one of the biggest developers in Russia and the owner of the country's largest convention center, began construction of his third Vegas brand shopping and entertainment complex, this time in southwestern Moscow. He got his start trading computers, but saw greater business potential in trade fairs. In 1988 he established Crocus, which became one of the country's largest trade-fair operators. He also started Crocus Inter, a company with retail malls including the luxurious Crocus City Mall, a "city of boutiques" in Moscow. He is considered the unofficial spokesman of Russia's Azerbaijani diaspora. In 2006 his son, Emin, married the daughter of Azerbaijan's president, Ilkham Aliyev, and he publishes Baku magazine, which his daughter-in-law, Leyla Aliyeva, edits.

name: Billionaires
bio:
CD-155 (a.k.a. SU-155), Mikhail Balakin's construction company, has roots going back to 1954, when it was known as "Stroymontazhtrest Number 3." It's still getting business from the state, but a growing slice of revenue comes from commercial and private construction (most notable: refurbishing the Bolshoi Theater). Having graduated from the Moscow Institute of Civil Engineering, Balakin got his start in the Glavmosstroi, the giant Soviet construction firm. The division he worked in went private in 1993 as Construction Department 155, over which he later took majority control. 
Some SU-155 projects have come in for criticism. One led to a prosecutor's investigation of various violations; another drew complaints about delays and title transfers from investors. Last year several small creditors filed suits to force SU-155 into bankruptcy. While that effort led nowhere, the company paid $70 million in settlements to creditors in January 2013.

name: Billionaires
bio: With his three brothers, Sid runs one of the biggest privately held oil and gas producers in the U.S., founded by uncle Sid Richardson (d. 1959) and father Perry (d. 2006). Over years they diversified fortune, and eventually became the biggest shareholder in Disney, but took a hit in 2001 when a string of losses and big margin call forced the sale of $2 billion in Disney shares. Sid divorced first wife Anne Hendricks in 1988 after falling for Mercedes Kellogg, who was then married to a U.S. diplomat. Anne is thought to have received a settlement of more than $200 million in Disney shares. In late 2011 Sid and Mercedes divorced amicably after 23 years. Mercedes, an urbane socialite, spearheaded their $25 million grant to the New York Metropolitan Opera in 2006. Sid said to prefer Texas, looking forward to never donning another tuxedo. New divorce settlement of several hundred million dollars for Mercedes just a guess; records are sealed.

name: Billionaires
bio: Baltimore Ravens owner Steve Bisciotti celebrated in February 2013 when his team beat the San Francisco 49ers to win Super Bowl XLVII. He was only a minority owner of the team when they last won a championship, in 2001. Bisciotti founded engineering staffing firm Aerotek in his basement with his cousin, Jim Davis. Now called Allegis Group, the company is the largest privately-held staffing firm in the U.S. by revenue ($8.3 billion in 2011). In 2004 Bisciotti bought a controlling interest in his hometown NFL team. A Salisbury University alumnus, he enjoys golfing and boating. He's also a rabid fan of the University of Maryland men's basketball team.
title: Owner

name: Billionaires
bio: Mario Brescia Cafferata, one of Peru's wealthiest men, died on May 16, 2013 at at 83. With his brother Pedro, Mario led of a group of companies known as Grupo Breca (it is also called Grupo Brescia), which included a stake in BBVA Continental, one of Peru's largest banks. The firm was founded by Fortunato Brescia Tassano, first as a real estate company that capitalized on Lima's growth. When Fortunato died in 1951, his sons Pedro and Mario took control. Since then, the company has expanded into a multitude of other businesses including agriculture, fish products, cement, paint products and mining. In 1969, the Peruvian government took control of the firm's agriculture companies and in 1973, it expropriated its fishery business. But later Grupo Breca regained a foothold in the fish products business with Tecnologica de Alimentos SA (TASA), now one of the largest producers of fish meal and fish oil in the world. Pedro gave his shares in the companies to his nephews and his sister, Ana María. Mario's sons own 40% of Grupo Breca. The firm also owns mining subsidiary Minsur, which has tin mines in Peru and Brazil. In 2012 Minsur bought 70% of Mina Justa, a copper project in Peru, for $505 million. In January 2012 Minsur started operating a gold mine, Pucamarca, along the border between Peru and Chile. That project has met opposition by groups that say the mine will contaminate the local water supply. Grupo Breca is still in real estate. It owns Intursa, Peru's largest hotel chain, which includes the Westin Lima Hotel, the tallest building in Lima.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chen Jianhua is chairman of Hengli Group, a privately held producer of plastics and fibers. Chen's wealth is down from a year ago due to slower economic growth and lower valuations in the industry. Hengli employs 40,000 people and is headquartered in Wujiang, China's "capital of silk." Its customers include Nike, Adidas and Toyota. Chen's wife Fan Hongwei co-founded Hengli with Chen and is a director and general manager of the Hengli Group. Chen is a vice chairman of the Federation of Industry & Commerce in Jiangsu Province, among other industry positions. He also owns the Tongli Lake Resort in Wujiang in Jiangsu Province, which has eight villas with 110 rooms. Chen and wife Fan Hongwei are graduates of Nanjing Normal University, along with fellow Chinese billionaire Zhang Jindong.

name: Billionaires
bio: Irish financier Dermot Desmond founded NCB Stockbrokers in 1981, which eventually became Ireland's largest independent brokerage. When Desmond sold NCB in 1994 for $39 million, he started his own private equity firm, International Investment & Underwriting. Current investments include biometrics company Daon, Mountain Province Diamonds, Barchester Healthcare, and Glasgow soccer club Celtic PLC. Desmond started his career at Citibank, before working briefly as a banking consultant for Pricewaterhouse Coopers in Afghanistan. An avid golfer, he's known as "The Kaiser" for his distinctive mustache.

name: Billionaires
bio: Commodities magnate Richard Elman's fortune was hit by a fall in shares of his Hong Kong-based Noble Group. The British-born Elman, who wears an amber bead bracelet on his wrist to keep a course of good energy going, has embarked on a new growth strategy by tapping into the natural gas market in the United States. The fall in US energy prices, given the shale gas boom, has prompted an opening for Noble to sell natural gas from America to Asia and Europe. Elman, a high school dropout who has often ruled out his retirement, is still very involved in Noble, despite appointing former Goldman Sachs banker Yusuf Alireza as chief executive last year. He enjoys hiking in the Swiss mountains, and owns a farm in New Zealand.

name: Billionaires
bio: Eduardo Eurnekian maintains his vitality leading America Corporation, Argentina's most diversified holding company. It operates more than 49 airports in Latin America and Europe, holds the concession of Argentina's official postal service, exploits 250,000 acres of land to produce wine, cereal and oilseeds, and invests in many other projects worldwide. The son of Armenian immigrants, Eurnekian has never married and has no children. His numerous nieces and nephews will inherit his companies. Among the family members who work with him are Martin and Hugo Eurnekian, sons of his deceased brother Alberto. Martin is the president of Puerta del Sol, the company that manages the group's airport business in Uruguay. Hugo leads the biggest challenge America Corporation faces in the next decade, the construction of a tunnel passing through the Andes. The company is investing more than $3 billion in the project.

name: Billionaires
bio: Gerald J. Ford made his fortune buying and selling banks. In 2012 he sold his private equity fund's 76% stake in Pacific Capital Bancorp to Mitsubishi UFJ, Japan's largest bank, for $1.15 billion, $650 million more than he paid for the stake in 2010 (Ford's take is $150 million). Son of a Texas farmer, he bought his first bank for $1.2 million in 1975 and later sold it for $80 million. With fellow billionaire Ron Perelman, he sold California's Golden State Bancorp to Citigroup in 2002 for $6 billion in stock. He survived the 2008 financial meltdown by hedging his Citi shares with options. He and his wife Kelli, an interior designer who owns a decorating firm with her sister, have homes in Dallas, Manhattan, and the Hamptons, a ranch in New Mexico, and a thoroughbred farm in Kentucky. In 1997 he donated $20 million to his alma mater, Southern Methodist University, to fund the construction of a new football stadium. He has also donated $10 million to the Weill Cornell Medical College.
title: Managing Member
employment: {'name': 'Ford Financial Fund', 'title': 'Managing Member', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: After losing control of his Ivanhoe Mines, founder and mining mogul Robert Friedland is showing international business mettle. In early 2012, mining group Rio Tinto took majority control of the company, forced Friedland to step down as CEO in April and change the firm's name to Turquoise Hill Resources in August. That didn't deter Friedland fromDB holding a public offering for his Africa-based mining operation Ivanplats on the Toronto Stock Exchange in February, raising more than $300 million.  Friedland is founder and chairman of Ivanplats. The Chicago native attended Reed College in Oregon and studied Sanskrit and Buddhism in India after graduating with a degree in political science. Friedland made his first fortune stumbling on a large nickel deposit at Voisey's Bay in Canada. He sold the nickel-rich property to Canadian miner Inco for $3.1 billion in 1996. He sold Ivanhoe Energy's U.S. oil and gas operations to Seneca Resources Corporation for $40 million in 2009. He currently resides in Singapore and maintains dual American and Canadian citizenship.
title: Founder and Executive Chairman
employment: {'name': 'Ivanhoe Mines', 'uri': 'companies/ivanhoe-mines', 'title': 'Founder and Executive Chairman', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: After training as a chartered accountant, Peter Gilgan founded Mattamy Homes in 1978, naming the home builder for the two oldest of his eight children, Matt and Amy. Inspired by the New Urbanism school of design, Gilgan set out to build suburban homes that broke with the bland and impersonal developments he saw popping up around Canada at the time. Since constructing his first two houses in Burlington, Ontario, Mattamy has built over 50,000 homes across the United States and Canada, and began designing and building entire planned communities from the ground up in 1986. Today, Mattamy is Canada's largest home builder. In March 2012 Gilgan donated CAD 40 million to Toronto's Hospital for Sick Children.
title: Founder, CEO and Chairman
employment: {'name': 'Mattamy Group Corp.', 'title': 'Founder, CEO and Chairman', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Jimmy Haslam came to the attention of the national media last August when he agreed to buy the Cleveland Browns from Randy Lerner for a reported $1 billion. The NFL approved the sale in October. Haslam owns a 70% stake in the team and will purchase the remaining 30% from Lerner in four years. He stepped down as CEO of truck stop chain Pilot Flying J in October 2012 after 18 years in that role, then resumed the top spot again in February, saying he missed his "first love." Pilot is one of the country's largest privately held companies, with $29 billion in sales. He gets most of his fortune from his 35% share of his family's 59% stake in Pilot. His father, who founded the retailer in 1958, has a much smaller stake, having given away most of his shares to other family members, including his younger son, Tennessee governor Bill Haslam.
title: CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: Hans-Werner Hector is one four cofounders of German software giant SAP who built a billion-dollar fortune. Hector built up the North American market for SAP and then left the firm in 1997 after a falling out with his partners. A trained mathematician, Hector holds an honorary professorship of mathematics for the University of Karlsruhe for his support of students in the math, natural sciences and technology fields. His charitable foundation gives money to cancer and AIDS research as well as for art and historic preservation. In 2011, Hector and his wife donated more than $60 million to the German city of Weinheim to renovate the city's museum.

name: Billionaires
bio: Roberto Hernandez Ramirez, the former chief executive of Banamex, reaped a windfall of some $2 billion in stock when Citigroup bought the Mexican bank in 2001. Hernandez remained on the Citigroup board until 2009, as the bank's shares fell precipitously. He is currently a board member of Mexican broadcaster Televisa. He has a small investment in Brazilian consumer goods company Hypermarcas (run by billionaire Joao Alves de Queiroz Filho). Hernandez has created two foundations intended to preserve the environment and Mayan cultural heritage and is on the board of the Nature Conservancy. He and his wife are reportedly renovating several properties in Merida, the understated city in Mexico's Yucatan that is attracting artists and designers as a vacation destination.

name: Billionaires
bio: After a spectacular run, Cirque du Soliel majority owner Guy Laliberte is falling back down to earth. The founder of the modern circus brand, who traveled to space as a tourist in 2009, shuttered four shows in 2012, among them Las Vegas' "Viva Elvis" because of poor ticket sales. Revenues have for the company dropped to roughly $900 million in 2012, down 10% from 2011. The company is looking to trim the fat, streamline its operations and focus on its key shows. In January, Cirque du Soleil announced it would lay off 400 employees (out of 5,000), mostly at its Montreal headquarters. Its moneymaker is still "Michael Jackson: The Immortal," which had $140 million in ticket sales in 2012, according to Pollstar data. Cirque du Soliel plans to open another Michael Jackson-themed show at Las Vegas' Mandalay Bay hotel in May. Laliberte founded the Montreal-based circus in 1984 with a gang of street performers, receiving early funding from the Canadian government. The outfit became a for-profit group in 1985; Laliberte bought out the majority partner in 2000. He sold 20% of the company in 2008 to two firms in Dubai for $600 million.
title: Cofounder and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Cirque du Soleil', 'title': 'Cofounder and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Guilherme Leal joined beauty products firm Natura in 1979 and played a key role in turning Brazil's version of Avon into a multibillion-dollar business. He serves as co-chairman of the company, sells its cosmetics door-to-door in seven countries in Latin America and in France. Increased demand in Brazil have driven up Natura's shares in the past year, boosting Leal's fortune by $200 million. After graduating from business school he worked for a public company where he was fired for fighting corruption before beginning his career at Natura. He promotes biodiversity and sustainable business practices and has cofounded the Ethos Institute and worked with the World Wildlife Fund of Brazil. He resigned from Natura to run as the Green Party candidate for vice president in the 2010 Brazilian presidential election but he did not win.

name: Billionaires
bio: In March 2012, Drayton McLane Jr. and his wife, Elizabeth, gave Baylor University its biggest capital gift ever, to build a new football stadium. The amount was not disclosed, but Forbes estimates it was north of $200 million. The gift comes with naming rights, but McLane has insisted that the arena be named Baylor Stadium. He began his career in 1959 as a truck loader on night shifts in the warehouse of his family's grocery distribution center and eventually grew the McLane Company into an international holding company with 18 divisions, including food service, software and novelty gifts, before selling it to friend and tennis partner Sam Walton for 10.4 million shares of Wal-Mart stock and $50 million in 1991. McLane is a graduate of Baylor, where he has been a trustee and regent and chairman of the endowment; he currently is "regent emeritus." In November 2011 he sold the Houston Astros baseball team to Houston investment manager James Crane for $610 million. He had bought the team in 1992 for $103 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Bob McNair celebrated the best year ever for his NFL team as the Houston Texans went 12-4 in the regular season. He and his partners paid $700 million for the expansion team a decade ago. Forbes ranks the Texans as the 5th most valuable football team, worth $1.3 billion; McNair owns the vast majority. He made his fortune selling power plant operator Cogen Technologies to Enron in 1999, and he still owns stakes in a couple power plants. The Robert and Janice McNair Foundation funds college scholarships for kids in his home state of North Carolina; in 2007 he donated $100 million to Baylor College of Medicine in Houston to attract top-notch doctors.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mario Moretti Polegato founded shoemaker Geox in 1995, with his patented "breathable shoe" technology. Impacted by the weak economy in Europe, Geox's net sales dropped 9% to $913 million (702 million euros) for the first nine months of 2012. It opened new stores in Moscow, Hong Kong, and three mainland Chinese cities in late 2012.The company makes footwear for men, women and children as well as apparel. It distributes to high-end retailers plus has company-owned stores in large markets. A former wine maker, he cut holes in his shoe soles during a hot walk in Nevada in 1989. He then developed a membrane that let shoes breathe, but blocked dirt and water. The idea was turned down by Nike. He took Geox public in 2004.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cousin of Adi Godrej, Rishad Naoroji has a 20% share of the Godrej family fortune inherited from his mother. His wealth is down on information that he has a smaller share than perviously estimated. Avid photographer and birdwatcher, he 's not involved in the business.

name: Billionaires
bio: Maja Oeri, a descendent of Fritz Hoffman-La Roche who founded drug giant Roche, joins the 2013 world billionaire ranks thanks to a 2011 decision to pull her 5% stake in bearer shares out of the family pool, which is collectively worth $16 billion. While she reportedly said at the time that she had no falling out with her family, her decision reduced the family's long majority control of Roche, maker of Tamiflu and Valium. The trustee of the Modern Museum of Art runs the contemporary art focused Emanuel Hoffman Foundation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Property magnate Chandru Raheja runs his privately-held K.Raheja Corp. with sons Ravi and Neel. It has opened a new mall in Bangalore and a 5-million-square-foot commercial complex, called Mindspace, in the satellite city of Navi Mumbai. It also completed Vivarea, a luxury residential high rise in South Mumbai, and is building another one in the same area. Its portfolio of 7 hotels includes a Westin in Hyderabad and a new Marriott in Bangalore. Other projects include IT parks, notably in the southern Indian city of Hyderabad

name: Billionaires
bio: Helena Revoredo is the widow of Herberto Gut, who founded Prosegur, a Spanish private security company known for its fleet of 3,800 yellow armored vans. Gut started the company in 1976. It debuted on the Spanish stock market in 1987. Gut died ten years later. Revoredo has been president since 2004. Her son, Christian Gut, is CEO and her daughter, Chantal Gut, sits on the board. Prosegur has a presence throughout Europe, Latin America, and Asia. Revoredo also supports the Prosegur Foundation, which works on education and social integration for people with disabilities and operates 30 schools in impoverished regions of seven Latin America countries.

name: Billionaires
bio: Leandro Rizzuto founded Conair in 1959 with his parents, using $100 he got from selling a Cadillac. The company first manufactured hot-air hair rollers invented by his father and then introduced the iconic pistol-shaped blow dryer in 1965. The company went public in 1972 and then private again in 1985 through a leveraged buyout. It later expanded to include home appliance brands Cuisinart and Waring, Interplak electric toothbrushyes  and the hair product lines Scunci, Babybliss and Rusk. Revenues at Conair exceed $2 billion. Rizzuto also owns the CuisinArt Resort in Anguilla.

name: Billionaires
bio: Teddy Sagi founded gaming site Playtech in 1999 and took it public on the London Stock Exchange in 2006. He has increased his ownership in the group from 40% to nearly 50% in the past two years -- and with good reason. The value of Playtech's stock has nearly doubled in the past year, adding hundreds of millions to Sagi's net worth. Talks in August 2012 to take his gas concern, Genesis Energy, public quieted after one well that he co-owns with fellow Israeli billionaire Beny Steinmetz was declared a likely bust -- not worth the cost of drilling. Sagi also owns several e-commerce services, an e-payment company, instant messenger service Messenger Plus and commercial real estate and hotels in Europe. He reportedly bought the most expensive home in Israel for about $35 million. Eligible bachelor, once tied in press to model Bar Refaeli, dates a former Miss Israel, Yael Nizri.

name: Billionaires
bio: Tom Siebel made his first fortune founding software company Siebel Systems in 1993. Today he is at the helm of his energy management firm, C3, and First Virtual Group, which deals in real estate and agribusiness. He worked as an executive at Oracle before starting Siebel Systems, which he sold to Oracle for $5.9 billion in 2005. After enduring 19 reconstructive surgeries over two and a half years, Siebel has fully recovered from elephant attack while on an African photo safari in 2009. His Siebel Foundation has given $250 million to promote alternative energy and education and fighting homeless and methamphetamine addiction. Management of his charity, Meth Project, has now been transferred to the Partnership at DrugFree.org.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder and CEO of social-network game site operator, Gree, Yoshikazu Tanaka has faced stiff competition this year from archrival DeNA and a game initiative by NTT DoCoMo, the giant cellphone carrier. Gree also took heat last year from a Japanese government crackdown on controversial tactics in marketing online games which has forced the company to resort to less aggressive sales methods. Coupled with new game delays and slow overseas sales, profits are down; the company's share price has slumped 50% over the past year. To get back on track, Tanaka moved to partner with Yahoo Japan and spent $210 million to buy US mobile game maker Funzio as well as $175 million to acquire Pokelabo, a Japanese social mobile game company.

name: Billionaires
bio: Malaysian timber tycoon Tiong Hiew King's Oregon Group is involved in forestry and property development in New Zealand and in designing and making plastic containers for kitchens. Now investing in a big way in oil-and-gas exploration in China, Malaysia and Myanmar through Singapore-listed RH Petrogas; he's increased his stake to 40%. Also owns 7 Chinese-language  newspapers and 30 magazines. Shares of his Chinese Media International rose 40% over the past year on lower newsprint costs and higher ad revenues.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sandro Veronesi, who is new to the Forbes Billionaires list, is the founder of the Calzedonia Group, an Italian company that sells lingerie, stockings and swimsuits through its Calzedonia, Intimissimi and Tezenis brands. It also has a majority position in Falconeri, an Italian clothing company known for its cashmere knitwear. Veronesi 's first job after graduating from Verona University was with Golden Lady, an Italian hosiery company. He started Calzedonia in 1987 while still working at Golden Lady. The company originally focused on tights and stockings and in the mid-1990s branched out to lingerie and underwear. Today there are more than 3,000 stores throughout Europe and the Middle East.

name: Billionaires
bio: Juan-Miguel Villar Mir is new to the Forbes Billionaires list. A former finance minister of Spain, he built a global engineering and construction empire. Together with his children, Villar controls $6.5 billion (2011 revenue) Obrascón Huarte Lain S.A., a construction firm traded on Madrid's stock exchange. OHL builds toll roads, railways, ports and airports, as well as residential developments, in 34 countries on seven continents. Among its projects: the Mecca-to-Medina high-speed railway in Saudi Arabia, the Marmaray railway linking the European and Asian sides of Istanbul in Turkey and the Ural Polar railway project in Russia. Separately from publicly traded OHL, his privately held Grupo Villar Mir is the largest independent producer of hydroelectric power in Spain, the world's leading producer of silicon metal, a major fertilizer producer, and a real estate developer with projects on the Mediterranean coast, in Florida and in Texas. Grupo Villar Mir also has smaller subsidiaries that make pre-stressed, reinforced concrete; trade, transport and distribute diesel oil; and retail clothing for children. In 2011 the King of Spain gave Villar Mir the title of "marquis."

name: Billionaires
bio: Dean White dropped out of U. of Nebraska to join the Merchant Marine Academy and serve in the South Pacific during World War II. He took over his father's billboard business in 1946 after graduating from the Academy and plowed the company's profits into building a hotel empire. In 1998 he sold the signage operations to Chancellor Media for $960 million. In 2006 he sold 100 hotels to BET founder Robert Johnson, for $1.7 billion. His latest project: building apartments in Austin, Texas. The 89-year-old is a workaholic who does not miss a day of work. He reportedly owns a private Falcon 7X jet.

name: Billionaires
bio: Wong Luen Hei chairs China Liansu Group, a supplier of plastic water and drainage pipes whose shares are up 85% since last summer amid expectations that orders will increase following Chinese government plans to boost infrastructure spending. Wong owns 70% of Liansu with his wife, Zuo Xiaoping, a vice president at the company. Zuo's brother Zuo Manlun is China Liansu's CEO.

name: Billionaires
bio: Hiroshi Yamauchi is the biggest individual shareholder of Nintendo, founded by his grandfather in 1889 as a maker of playing cards. Hiroshi ran the company for 55 years before retiring in 2005. His wealth slumped for a second straight year as Nintendo's share price is down another 24% due to the lackluster performance of the new Wii U video game console against rivals from Microsoft and Sony. The company's handheld player, a portable gadget called the 3DS that offers 3-D viewing without the use of special glasses, has also been upended by smartphone games since its launch in 2011. Yamauchi bought the Seattle Mariners baseball team in 1992, later transferring it to the company's U.S. unit.

name: Billionaires
bio: Zhu Gongshan stands out as China's richest man in the solar energy business, which has had a tumultuous year and faces crushing overcapacity problems. His GCL-Poly Energy Holdings is one of the world's largest suppliers of polysilicon and silicon wafers, but expects a full-year loss for 2012 with the imposition of U.S. anti-dumping duties and weak European demand. At home, meanwhile, GCL said its overseas rivals had been dumping "viciously low-priced polysilicon to China" last year. GCL's shares are only now beginning to bounce off their lows, and Zhu's wealth is off 20% from March 2012. He is currently a member of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference of Jiangsu Province and co-chairman of China Photovoltaic Industry Alliance. Zhu's wealth is held by a family trust.

name: Billionaires
bio: In 1995 Igor Zyuzin and partner Vladimir Iorich formed Uglemetkooperatsiya, a coal-trading company, which was among the first to buy up shares in coal mines and pits in Russia's Kuzbass region. In 2001 the partners bought a controlling stake in Chelyabinsk Metals Factory, which formed the basis of the Mechel Group, which now has more than 20 plants and coals mines around the world. Three years later its shares began trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Now Mechel is in the doldrums. In the first nine months of 2012 the company lost $550 million and racked up $9.1 billion in debt. In September 2012 Mechel announced it was selling assets including factories in Romania, a Lithuanian wire, nails and wire mesh maker called Mechel Namunas, and nicked producer Yuzhuralnickel.

name: Billionaires
bio: Jason Chang chairs Advanced Semiconductor Engineering of Taiwan, the world's largest independent packager of semiconductors.  Besides Taiwan, ASE has manufacturing or testing sites in South Korea, Japan, mainland China, Singapore, Malaysia, Mexico and Silicon Valley, and employs more than 50,000 people worldwide.  His wealth is little changed from a year ago. Chang is also an investor in Sino Horizon Holding, a real estate developer in mainland China. Chang holds a degree in electrical engineering from National Taiwan University, and a master's degree from the Illinois Institute of Technology.

name: Billionaires
bio: Canadian oil mogul N. Murray Edwards was heavily involved in the negotiations between National Hockey League owners and players during the league's lockout in 2012. The co-owner of the Calgary Flames (he bought his stake in the team in 1994), he was seen as a central deal maker in navigating the lockout, which finally ended in January 2013. That kind of negotiating prowess has characterized Murray's career, in which he has slowly built up positions at companies like oil sands miner Canada Natural Resources, where he was named chairman in April. A former partner at Calgary-based law firm Burnet, Duckworth and Palmer, he also serves as chairman at Ensign Energy Services and Magellan Aerospace Corporation and owns ski resorts in the Canadian Rockies.

name: Billionaires
bio: Jayme Garfinkel controls Porto Seguro, Brazil's second largest insurance company. The company was founded in 1945 and bought by the Garfinkel family in 1972. When his father died in 1978, Jayme was groomed to take over. Under his leadership, Porto Seguro has become the largest Brazilian auto insurer, with more than 4.2 million vehicles covered. Jayme stepped down as CEO in September 2011 but he participates in the daily activities of the company as board chairman. Through Porto Seguro he has supported the creation and maintenance of schools in favelas, or shantytowns, around Sao Paulo, which serve more than 50,000 children. He drives his Land Rover Discovery III around Sao Paulo without bodyguards and loves dancing.

name: Billionaires
bio: Rolf Gerling's grandfather founded Gerling Konzern in 1904 as a small insurance company. Gerling's father Hans expanded it into a global insurance group. In 1991, following the death of his father, Gerling took over the company. Though trained as an economist, he showed little interest in his legacy and in 2005, Gerling sold his 94% stake in the company to Talanx Group, Germany's third largest insurance company, for an estimated $1.6 billion. Gerling, a passionate environmentalist who lives in Switzeland, helped establish the Gerling Academy for Risk Research, a think tank set up to study the industrial world's impact on the environment.

name: Billionaires
bio: Valery Kogan, together with business partner Dmitry Kamenshchik, owns Moscow's Domodedovo Airport, the largest in Russia, used by 28 million passengers last year. In spring 2011 the airport's managing company, DME Limited, filed for an IPO in London, but later abandoned the plan. Rumors have been flying that the airport is up for sale. Kogan served in the Navy and owns an $18 million estate in Greenwich, Connecticut.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heralded as China's Steve Jobs, Lei Jun joins the Forbes Billionaires list this year. He became a billionaire in 2012 thanks to the soaring valuation of Xiaomi, one of China's fastest growing smartphone companies, of which Lei is co-founder, chairman and CEO. His net worth also got a boost in 2012 thanks to a Chinese social gaming company, YY Inc., going public on the Nasdaq in November 2012. He had invested $1 million in the company in 2005. He also owns minority stakes in a number of Chinese online enterprises, including Hong Kong-listed software firm Kingsoft, mobile browser provider UC Web and private e-commerce companies VANCL and Lakala. He graduated from China's Wuhan University in 1991 with a degree in computer science.

name: Billionaires
bio: Liang Long-shing is the son of one of the three founders of Taiwan's Chang Chun Group. The company was set up in 1949 by Suhon Lin, Liao Long-shing's late father M.K. Liao, and Tseng Shin-yi, with each holding a third of the business. The name "Chung Chun" in Chinese loosely means "long spring," and reflects the wish among the three that their bonds would endure. The group is one of Asia's most successful privately held businesses, as well as one of region's largest plastics and petrochemicals manufacturers, with operations in Taiwan, mainland China and most recently, Singapore. Overseas business partners include Bayer and Mitsubishi Gas Chemical. The three founders all attended what today is called National Taipei University of Technology.

name: Billionaires
bio: Suhon Lin is one of three founders of Taiwan's Chang Chun Group. The company was set up in 1949 by Lin, the late M.K. Liao, and Tseng Shin-yi, with each holding a third of the business. The name "Chung Chun" in Chinese loosely means "long spring," and reflects the wish among the three that their bonds would endure. The group is one of Asia's most successful privately held businesses, as well as one of region's largest plastics and petrochemicals manufacturers, with operations in Taiwan, mainland China and most recently, Singapore. Overseas business partners include Bayer and Mitsubishi Gas Chemical. The three founders all attended what today is called National Taipei University of Technology.

name: Billionaires
bio: This winter Bill Marriott transformed from hotelier to author, publishing "Without Reservations," the story of his family's business success. The advance praise for the book shows the Marriotts' powerful connections: Pepsico CEO Indra Nooyi, Mitt Romney, George H.W. Bush, Bill Clinton, Laura Bush and Roger J. Dow all lavish praise on the text. Bill stepped down from his position as Marriott CEO in 2012 after celebrating his 80th birthday. Along with brother Richard, Bill oversees a vast family fortune worth more than $5 billion. This winter, after losing the preisdential election, family friend Mitt Romney rejoined Marriott International's board, a position Romney maintained for 11 years prior to his ill-fated 2012 run for president.

name: Billionaires
bio: David Nahmad, together with his brother Ezra, is an influential megadealer of modern and impressionist art by the most well-known names, from Monet and Matisse to Renoir and Rothko. The brothers own a vast inventory of between 4,000 and 4,500 works, stored in a duty-free warehouse next to the airport in Geneva, Switzerland. Among those holdings: 300 Picassos, worth some $900 million. The brothers buy and sell most of their works at auction. The collection is worth some $3 billion and the brothers, who are listed separately for the first time this year, hold the assets jointly, split 50/50. David also trades millions of dollars in currencies, stocks and commodities. A skilled backgammon player who bets hundreds of thousands on the game in Monte Carlo, he holds the 1996 world title.

name: Billionaires
bio: Daniel Pritzker, a jazz buff, made a silent film, "Louis" about the life of Louis Armstrong, which was released to critical praise in 2010. A second jazz-infused film, "Bolden," which focuses on New Orleans rag-time innovator Buddy Bolden, was scheduled to be released in 2012, but has been delayed. One of the 10 billionaire Pritzkers, Daniel and family sold control of industrial conglomerate Marmon Holdings to Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway for $4.5 billion in 2007. Daniel's grandfather, A.N. Pritzker (d. 1986), with his sons Jay (d. 1999), Robert (d. 2011) and Donald (d. 1972), created Marmon and hotel chain Hyatt.

name: Billionaires
bio: Roustam Tariko, the creator of Russian Standard vodka, made a number of strategic investments in 2011, including buying a 9.9% stake in Polish CEDC, one of the world's largest vodka producers, and a 70% stake in Gancia, an Italian producer of sparkling wines and vermouths. In 2012 he increased he share in CEDC to 19.5%. Tariko earned his first money in the late 1980s helping foreign tourists find rooms in Moscow hotels. He later worked as a consultant for the Italian confectioner Ferrero Rocher and then started selling Italian vermouth, winning an exclusive contract with Martini & Rossi. In 1998 he created Russian Standard as Russia's first upscale vodka brand. The following year, with the help of McKinsey & Co., he set up Russian Standard Bank, pioneering in the consumer credit market and becoming the market leader in it three years later. Today the bank is one of Russia's 30 largest, and until the end of 2011 it had an exclusive Russian partnership with American Express. Tariko's Boeing 737 was most recently seen by plane spotters in St. Moritz, Switzerland, in January 2013.

name: Billionaires
bio: Tseng Shi-yi is one of the three founders of Taiwan's Chang Chun Group. The company was set up in 1949 by Suhon Lin, the late M.K. Liao, and Tseng, with each holding a third of the business. The name "Chung Chun" in Chinese loosely means "long spring," and reflects the wish among the three that their bonds would endure. The group is one of Asia's most successful privately held businesses, as well as one of region's largest plastics and petrochemicals manufacturers, with operations in Taiwan, mainland China and most recently, Singapore. Overseas business partners include Bayer and Mitsubishi Gas Chemical. The three founders all attended what today is called National Taipei University of Technology.

name: Billionaires
bio: Wei Ing-Chou is one of the four brothers from Taiwan, along with Ying-Chiao, Yin-Chun and Yin-Heng, that founded Hong Kong-listed beverage maker Tingyi (Cayman Islands) Holding. The company accounts for almost half of the ready-to-drink tea business in China, a quarter of bottled water sales, and 57% of instant noodle sales. Tingyi was criticized last year for its business ties to Japanese companies such as Sanyo Foods, Asahi Beverages and Itochu amid the heated nationalistic dispute between Beijing and Tokyo over a group of tiny islands located between the two sides. The Weis also partner with Pepsi, invest in real estate and control the Dicos fried-chicken chain.   Ing-Chou is Tingyi's chairman. Tingyi last year hosted the "8th World Instant Noodles Summit," whose theme was "Instant Noodles for Better Life."

name: Billionaires
bio: Alexei Ananyev began his career importing computers to Russia with his brother, fellow billionaire Dmitry Ananyev. The two then founded a bank, and they have also been active in real estate and media. Alexei heads up their IT business and general strategizing. Their company Technoserv is Russia's biggest in systems integration. Its 2012 revenue was more than $1.5 billion. In February 2013 Ananyev was named chief executive of Systemy Upravleniya, a state corporation set up to develop automated management systems for the military-industrial establishment. The brothers own Novospassky Dvor, a 21.5-acre business district along the Moscow River, and in 2011 they bought the Alfa Arbat Center, an office complex in central Moscow, for $230 million. In 2010 they sold their telecom company, Synterra, for $745 million to Megafon, which is owned by billionaire Alisher Usmanov. Despite their wealth, they felt a deficiency of education until they completed executive MBAs at the University of Chicago in 2005. Both brothers are very religious. Alexei owns the largest collection of Socialist realism-style art in Russia, and at the end of 2011 he opened a museum to display it.

name: Billionaires
bio: Dimitry Ananyev began his career importing computers to Russia with his brother, fellow billionaire Alexei Ananyev. The two then founded a bank, and they have also been active in real estate and media. They own Novospassky Dvor, a 21.5-acre business district along the Moscow River, and in 2011 they bought the Alfa Arbat Center, an office complex in central Moscow, for $230 million. In 2010 they sold their telecom company, Synterra, for $745 million to Megafon, which is owned by billionaire Alisher Usmanov. Despite their wealth, they felt a deficiency in education until they completed executive MBAs at the University of Chicago in 2005. Both brothers are very religious. Since 2006 Dmitry has represented the gas-rich polar region of Yamal in Russia's Federation Council, and because of that his brother has handled all of their business dealings.

name: Billionaires
bio: Perhaps one of the least known billionaire owners of publicly held corporations, 61-year-old Swedish industrialist Carl Bennet joins the ranks of the world's billionaires after hiding in plain sight for years. Through Carl Bennet AB, an investing vehicle that he owns outright, he holds stakes in seven companies that span a wide range of industries: medical products, biomedical research, printing, dental products, forestry and investing. The most lucrative of those investments is publicly traded medical products company Getinge Group, where he has served as chairman since 1997. He is beneficial owner of a fifth of that company, but through shrewd share divisions he claims nearly half of its voting rights. In total his stake in Getinge is worth $1.5 billion. A similar share structure has been employed at Elanders, a printing company where Bennet controls 59% of the equity and 73% of the voting rights. But the value of Elanders has plummeted since 2007; it is now worth a mere 15% of what it was then. Bennet is also the sole owner of LIFCO, a company that mainly makes dental products but also produces machinery and tools, environmental technology and sawmill equipment. Little is known about Bennet's personal life, but he began on his path to billionaire status when he and fellow investor Rune Andersson acquired Getinge, then a money-losing company, from Electrolux, in 1989. He served as CEO and president, Andersson as chairman. Getinge began producing a profit in 1991. When it debuted on the Stockholm Stock Exchange, in 1993, Bennet and Andersson sold off 57% of their equity for roughly $60 million, which they later invested in other companies. The duo owned Getinge through Andersson & Bennet, a company that was dissolved in 1997 when they parted ways. Bennet took over the holding company, which became Carl Bennet AB, and in turn Getinge. Andersson took on three other businesses they had owned together.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partner and fellow billionaire Ihor Kolomoyskyy, Henadiy Boholyubov controls Privat group, a banking and industrial conglomerate which has faltered this year. Two of the group's ferroalloy plants stopped production because of high energy costs and airlines it owns have declared bankruptcy; plans to IPO oil producer Ukrnafta have stalled. Outside of Privat, Boholyubov directs miner Consolidated Minerals which paid out a $50 million dividend in April 2011. His Boholyubov Foundation focuses on promoting Jewish education and religion. With his partner Kolomoyskyy, he opened the world's biggest multifunctional Jewish center, the Menorah Centre in Dnepropetrovsk last fall. Among the guests were Israeli Chief Rabi Shlomo Amar and US ambassador John Tefft.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ahmet Calik's Calik Holding focuses on renewable energy and energy distribution and has won contracts to build power plants in Iraq, Uzbekistan and Turkmenistan. Calik also owns Aktifbank in Turkey and BKT bank, and is developing billion-dollar real estate projects in Istanbul. Calik began building his holdings with Gap Guneydogu Tekstil, one of the world's top 10 denim producers, which sells products to Diesel, Levi's, Gap and other Western brands; today that business accounts for less than 5% of total company revenues. Calik attended Davos this year to elevate Turkey's presence in high-level European affairs.

name: Billionaires
bio: Without David Cheriton, Google may have never been created. In 1998, the Stanford professor invited two graduate students - Larry Page and Sergey Brin - to demo their project on his front porch. Following that presentation, Cheriton and Sun Microsystems cofounder Andy Bechtolsheim each wrote the pair a $100,000 check to fund the dorm room startup. That investment has paid off in spades for the billionaire computer science professor, though Cheriton doesn't flaunt his wealth. He still drives the same 1986 Volkswagen Vanagon and lives in the same Palo Alto home he's owned for 30 years. He also cuts his own hair, not necessarily to save money, he says, but because "it's just easy to do myself, and it takes less time." Cheriton is also an angel investor and has cofounded three successful startups with Bechtolsheim including Granite Systems (acquired by Cisco in 1996) and Kealia (bought by Sun Microsystems in 2004.)Their latest venture, Santa Clara-based Arista Networks, builds high-speed data switches and is competing with the likes of Cisco.
title: Entrepreneur

name: Billionaires
bio: Italian financier Ennio Doris, CEO and significant shareholder of financial services group Mediolanum SpA, has had good momentum. Net income at Mediolanum grew more than three-fold to $390 million for the first nine months of 2012, which drove up the share price by more than 25%. As a result, Doris' net worth has risen $400 million in the past year. Doris co-founded Mediolanum with former Italian Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi in 1982. The company provides investment advice, banking services, life insurance and real estate loans and currently has 1.1 million customers. Doris' son Massimo serves as executive deputy chairman.

name: Billionaires
bio: The grandson of Campbell Soup founder and condensed soup inventor John T. Dorrance, Bennett Dorrance has sat on the company's board since 1989. Today he owns 15% of outstanding shares, however, over 70% of these are pledged against bank loans. Campbell Soup is the world's largest soup maker with 2012 revenues of $7.7 billion and owns other familiar brands such as Pace (salsa), V8 (vegetable juice), Pepperidge Farm (cookies, Goldfish), and Swanson (broth). Dorrance is the co-founder and managing director of DMB Associates, an Arizona real estate development firm that specializes in planned communities. He also sits on the board of Insight Enterprise, an Arizona based IT consulting firms. Since 1999, his Dorrance Scholarship Programs helps send students, apparently 400 to date and most of whom are the first members of their families to go to college, to Arizona's three public universities or South Mountain Community College.

name: Billionaires
bio: The flagship hedge fund at Glenn Dubin's $28 billion Highbridge Capital Management finished 2012 up 11% net of fees. The firm's Long/Short equity fund and Statistical Opportunities funds were also up last year, returning 11% and 5.2% respectively. Named for the oldest bridge in New York City, Dubin founded Highbridge with childhood friend and fellow billionaire Henry Swieca in 1992. The pair sold a majority stake in Highbridge to JP Morgan Chase in 2004 for $1.3 billion. While Swieca departed in 2009, Dubin remains on board as Chairman and CEO. Dubin and his wife, Eva, an MD and breast cancer survivor, donated $16 million to found the Dubin Breast Center at Mount Sinai Medical Center, which opened in April of 2011.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Bulent Eczacibasi shares a stake in the Eczacibasi Group with his brother Faruk, also a billionaire. The conglomerate has interests in health, consumer goods, real estate and building materials companies, and plans to expand into mining. Shares of the group's publicly traded companies Eczacibasi Construction and Eczacibasi Investment Partnership have increased 62% and 36% respectively over the past year. They have also been buying: last year, they added the Ataman Group, an innovative company in the wet wipe market as well as Capintec, a well-known maker of radiation measuring and protective equipment used in nuclear medicine. Bulent Eczacibasi is one of Turkey's most important collectors. He co-founded The Istanbul Modern Art Museum with his wife Oya; their personal collection houses around 1,000 paintings and works of art. He is also the president of IKSV (Istanbul Culture and Art Foundation) which organizes international art festivals.

name: Billionaires
bio: Faruk Eczacibasi shares a stake in the Eczacibasi Group with his brother Bulent, also a billionaire. The conglomerate has interests in health, consumer goods, real estate and building materials companies, and plans to expand into mining. Shares of the group's publicly traded companies Eczacibasi Construction and Eczacibasi Investment Partnership have increased 62% and 36% respectively over the past year. They have also been buying: last year, they added the Ataman Group , an innovative company in the wet wipe market as well as Capintec, a well-known brand maker of radiation measuring and protective equipment used in nuclear medicine. Faruk Eczacibasi is president  of the Eczacibasi Sports Club; under his tenure last year, the Eczacibasi Vitra Women's Volleyball Team was league champion. He is also the president of the Turkey Informatics Foundation and has been working on the e-Conversion Executive Board. He is the founder and CEO of E-Guven which is Turkey's foremost secure electronic certificate provider.

name: Billionaires
bio: Galveston, Tex. native Tilman Fertitta grew up peeling shrimp at his father's restaurant and working as a lifeguard on the shore. Now his company, Landry's, is a sprawling restaurant and entertainment empire with 56 brands and 421 locations, many of which he acquired on the cheap in recent years. He was a partner in the first Landry's restaurant in 1980 and bought a controlling interest in the company in 1986. In 2010 he took the company private in a deal worth $1.4 billion. In addition to restaurants, Fertitta owns the Golden Nugget casinos, Houston's Kemah Boardwalk, the Tower of the Americas in San Antonio, and the San Luis Resort in Galveston. A college dropout, he serves on the board of regents for the University of Houston system.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': "Landry's Inc", 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: While fellow Yahoo co-founder and former CEO Jerry Yang has departed the company, David Filo is still around, directing technical operations behind the company's global Web network. As "Chief Yahoo" he reports to new CEO Marissa Mayer, who was brought aboard in July to refocus the company and get the stock price moving upward. If she succeeds, that will be good news for FIlo. Despite stock sales and gifting of shares, Filo remains the company's largest individual shareholder. He met Yang when they were both Stanford Ph.D. students and dropped out after creating Yahoo in 1994. The site was originally named "Jerry and David's Guide to the World Wide Web," later changed to an acronym for "Yet Another Hierarchical Officious Oracle." Filo received an undergraduate degree in computer engineering from Tulane University. He donated $30 million to Tulane's School of Engineering in 2005.
title: Chief Yahoo (director)

name: Billionaires
bio: Thomas Friedkin's fortune comes from Gulf States Toyota, a firm with the exclusive rights to import Toyotas in Texas, Arkansas, Louisiana, Mississippi, and Oklahoma. The firm has operated since 1968 and profits from car parts as well. He also owns two Lexus dealerships in Houston. A former Hollywood stunt pilot and actor, he is credited in 10 movies. He owns a big collection of World War II fighter planes. He and his family have donated more than $100 million to wildlife conservation efforts in Tanzania. He also supports environmental groups in Texas.

name: Billionaires
