bio: Former skiing champ Reinold Geiger's French cosmetics retailer L'Occitane is known for its all natural creams and perfumes made in Provence; one of its shea butter products is sold somewhere in the world every 10 seconds. His fortune is up $400 million in the past year, thanks to continuing demand for L'Occitane's products, particularly throughout Asia. Geiger started his career in packaging before investing in L'Occitane in 1994. Within two years he was the majority shareholder, having ousted a venture capital company. He took the company public on the Hong Kong stock exchange in 2010. He also owns Les Couvent des Minimes spa hotel in Provence, and has a beach house on the Ile de Re in the Atlantic and a ski chalet in Meribel.

name: Billionaires
bio: Singapore's 'Popiah king' Sam Goi is the world's largest maker of frozen rice wraps used to make spring rolls. He's expanded the portfolio of his privately-held Tee Yih Jia Food Manufacturing with acquisitions, such as a stake in dairy products firm Etika International Holdings. Goi has profited from China's economic boom and rural migration to second and third tier cities, by diversifying into property. His property arm GSH Corporation signed a deal recently to develop a marine eco-city in Zhangzhou. Son of a Fujian farmer, Goi dropped out of school to work in his father's grocery store. Started repair shop then took stake in struggling food unit which he eventually bought over.

name: Billionaires
bio: After working at Goldman Sachs for a decade, Noam Gottesman left in 1995 to set up hedge fund GLG Partners within Lehman Brothers. The fund became independent in 2000 and went public in 2007. The U.K.'s Man Group took over GLG for $1.6 billion in 2010. Gottesman stepped down as CEO and became non-executive chairman. Now he runs TOMS Capital, which handles personal investments, art and philanthropy. He is the financial backer of Manhattan restaurant Eleven Madison Park. In 2008 he paid $34 million for a former ice factory in downtown Manhattan, tore it down and built a 12,000-square-foot home. A trustee of the Tate Gallery Foundation, he owns works by Andy Warhol, Francis Bacon and Lucian Freud. Divorced, he reportedly dates the actress Lucy Liu.
title: Chief Executive Officer
employment: {'name': 'TOMS Capital', 'title': 'Chief Executive Officer', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Jim Justice II built a fortune in coal and farming. He sold his company's West Virginia coal resources to Russian mining and steel company Mechel OAO in 2009 for $436 million in cash and roughly $240 million of Mechel preferred shares -- much of which he has since sold. His Justice Family Companies retained coal interests in Virginia, Tennessee and Kentucky, and own active farmland in West Virginia, North Carolina, South Carolina, Virginia and Kentucky. After the sale to Mechel, Justice purchased the Greenbrier Resort n West Virginia from Marriott, paying $20 million. Justice has been hosting events at the Greenbrier ranging from poker and blackjack tournaments to an Evander Holyfield boxing match and a tennis match between legends Jon McEnroe and Pete Sampras in an effort to bring attention and revenue back to the estate.

name: Billionaires
bio: Kim Jung-Ju is the founder of Nexon, Korea's largest online game company. Nexon created such popular games as Kart Rider and Maple Story and distributes Dota 2 (Defense of the Ancients) in Japan and Korea. In 2010 Nexon took over competitors Ndoors and Gamehi. Nexon provides games for free while charging small amounts for virtual goods. It has 350 million users worldwide in more than 72 countries. The largest market for Nexon's games is China, followed by Japan and South Korea. Nexon Japan went public on the Tokyo Stock Exchange in December 2011 in the year's biggest IPO. Since 2008 Nexon has spent more than $1.8 billion on acquisitions. In 2012 that included buying shares in game developer NC Soft and purchasing a Japanese mobile game company called Gloops.

name: Billionaires
bio: TNK-BP board member Alex Knaster is part of a group of Russian investors, including Mikhail Fridman and Viktor Vekselberg, who agreed to sell a 50% stake in joint oil venture TNK-BP to state-owned Rosneft for $28 billion. The deal is expected to close in the spring of 2013. The Moscow-born banker emigrated to the U.S. with his parents in 1976 and became a U.S. citizen. He returned to Russia in the mid-1990s and headed Credit Suisse First Boston's Moscow operation. He later became chief of Alfa Bank, Russia's largest private commercial bank. Now he chairs Pamplona Capital Management, a British private equity firm he founded in 2005, whose clients include Alfa Group. In 2007 Knaster and other Russian Jewish billionaires formed the Genesis Philanthropy Group, a foundation that promotes Jewish identity among Russian-speaking Jews worldwide. He has also given significantly to his alma mater, Carnegie Mellon University, creating the Alexander M. Knaster Scholarship Fund to aid full-time undergraduate students in the department of Electrical and Computer Engineering; he also endowed the chair of the mathematics department at Carnegie Mellon.

name: Billionaires
bio: Low Tuck Kwong's net worth fell $1.9 billion in the past year as falling coal prices drove down shares in his coal mining company, Bayan Resources. At the same time East Kalimantan, where Bayan operates, is considering plans to cap annual coal output in an effort to promote alternative energy and cut back on the damage coal mining has done to the environment. In November 2012 a judge put to rest a $240 million defamation suit Low had filed against his former friend, Sukamto Sia. Low said he was defamed when Sia sent a letter to the stock exchange in Jakarta, claiming that he gave Low $3 million in 1995 to set up the coal-mining operations, and should have gotten half of the business in return. Sia countersued for a 50% share of Bayan. A judge wound up dismissing both claims. Born in Singapore, Low worked for his father's construction company in his 20s and moved to Indonesia in 1972. An animal lover, he has a zoo in Borneo with dozens of animals including gibbons, sun bears, and peacocks. He rehabilitates orangutans for reintroduction to the wild.

name: Billionaires
bio: Dutch businessman Hans Melchers founded chemical company Melchemie Holland BV, but now the majority of his wealth comes from his stake in HAL Trust, an international investment company based in the Netherlands Antilles. Melchers is a huge fan of the card game bridge. He founded his own professional team and provided major funding for the 2011 world bridge championship held in the Netherlands. In 2005, his 37-year-old daughter, Claudia, was kidnapped and ransomed for 660 pounds of cocaine, then released unharmed two days later. After the press insinuated Melchers was involved in the drug trade, he founded the Melchers Fund to provide financial aid to provide legal aid to victims of slanderous media reports. Melchers also owns a small castle in the eastern Dutch city of Vorden and reportedly bought 1000 works of art in 2012.

name: Billionaires
bio: The bulk of Rubens Menin Teixeira de Souza's wealth comes from his stake in low cost homebuilder MRV Engenharia. In 2011, U.S. investment firm Starwood Capital  bought 33% of MRV Log, the logistics arm of listed MRV Engenharia, which Menin co-founded in 1979. Menin is also founding partner of bank Intermedium and has been chairman of the board since it was established in 1994. Through MRV, Menin sponsors Sociedade dos Meninos São Vicente de Paulo, a group that provides shelter and schooling for children and teenagers in Belo Horizonte, north of Rio de Janeiro, where he currently lives.

name: Billionaires
bio: Theodore Rachmat is gearing up to list his palm oil business, Triputra Agro Persada, in three to five years' time. Co-owned by fellow billionaire Benny Subianto, the company is reportedly planning to increase its planted area by about two-thirds by 2015. Its expansion plan drew in a $200 million investment from Singapore's sovereign wealth fund, Government of Singapore Investment Corp., (GIC) and TPG Capital's Indonesian partner, Northstar. Rachmat's son Arif runs Triputra. Rachmat's links to GIC and Northstar run deeper than the investment in Triputra. In 2005 GIC  invested in coal producer Adaro Energy together with Rachmat and Subianto. Northstar was co-founded by Theodore's son- in-law, Patrick Walujo.

name: Billionaires
bio: Michael Rubin made $150 million when GSI Commerce, the ecommerce company he built from scratch in 1999, sold to eBay for $2.4 billion in 2011. But money wasn't the real prize. As part of the deal, Rubin paid $500 million in cash and loans for majority ownership of three GSI assets eBay didn't want to digest. Apparel retailer Fanatics, flash sales website Rue La La, and Amazon Prime competitor ShopRunner are now wrapped under Rubin's holding company Kynetic. Rubin's 90% stake in Fanatics alone is worth roughly $1.4 billion. A minority owner of the Philadelphia 76ers, he spends free time with his 6-year-old daughter. Rubin started his first company, a ski-tuning shop, in his parent's Lafayette, Pa. basement at the age of 12.
title: Entrepreneur

name: Billionaires
bio: Deniz Sahenk is the widow of Dogus Holding's founder Ayhan Sahenk, who died of a heart attack in 2001. She has no active duty in the Dogus Group companies which operate in the sectors of finance, media, tourism and construction. The majority of her wealth comes from the Garanti Bank; the company's stock price is up 25% over the past year. Her children Ferit and Filiz Sahenk are also billionaires.

name: Billionaires
bio: Broadcom cofounder Henry Samueli once again became chairman of the board in May 2012 after previously resigning from the position in 2008 in the wake of stock options backdating allegations from which he was later exonerated by a U.S. district court judge. Samueli is the winner of the 2012 Marconi Prize, considered one of the highest achievement awards in the information technology field. In the late 1980s he met Broadcom cofounder and fellow billionaire Henry Nicholas at aerospace and automotive company TRW. They designed high-speed telecom chips in Nicholas' spare bedroom, started Broadcom in 1991 and took it public seven years later. A UCLA grad, he has been an electrical engineering professor at the university since 1985. He and his wife Susan own the Anaheim Ducks hockey team.
title: Chief Technology Officer and Chairman
employment: {'name': 'Broadcom', 'uri': 'companies/broadcom', 'title': 'Chief Technology Officer and Chairman', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Anatoly Sedykh's United Metallurgical Company, Russia's second-largest pipe producer and biggest maker of train wheels, struck a deal last year with the state-owned monopoly Russian Railways to prolong its wheel contract for an unprecedented 12 years; by the time the contract is up the firm will have supplied more than 3 million wheels to the monopoly. UMC has been bolstered by two more massive deals, too: Its United Metals Company, or OMK, is supplying an oil pipeline to China and a gas pipeline to Germany. Sedykh graduated from the Moscow State Institute of Steel & Alloys, which several of Russia's other tycoons also attended, and worked as an economist in the Central Research Institute for Ferrous Metallurgy. In 1989 he started a joint venture in scrap-metal recycling with a $1.5 million loan from Sberbank, Russia's largest bank. He then began buying up shares in Vyksunsky Metallurgical Plant, a producer of pipes in the Urals region; by 1999 he and his partners were controlling shareholders. He subsequently established UMC.

name: Billionaires
bio: Thailand's former prime minister Thaksin Shinawatra, ousted in a 2006 coup, lives in self-imposed exile in Dubai and travels around the world while still being wanted at home on corruption charges. He returns to list after a decade following his disclosure to Forbes last October that he had received close to $1 billion back from the $2.3 billion of his assets frozen by the Thai authorities. He still owns a controlling stake of SC Asset Co, a real estate development firm that his younger sister Yingluck, Thailand's prime minister, used to run. Says he's been investing in gold and platinum mining in Africa. His visit to the U.S. last August incited protests.

name: Billionaires
bio: Anatoly Skurov owns 8% of the fertilizer producer Uralkali. His partners in the company are Suleiman Kerimov, Filaret Galchev, Alexander Nesis, and Zelimkhan Mutsoev, all also billionaires. He is a former designer of Soviet machine-building factories and worked for the state-owned coal producer Rosugol, where he took part in the reform of the Russian coal industry. In 1995, with Vladimir Melnichenko and Valentin Bukhtoyarov, both former billionaires, he founded the coal producer Sibuglemet. Lately the three have been battling over coal assets.

name: Billionaires
bio: Song Zuowen controls privately-held Nanshan Group, which has interests in aluminum, apparel, jets, education and tourism. His wealth is little changed as slower economic growth in China has squeezed his core aluminum business. Net profit at flagship Shandong Nanshan Aluminium dropped by 22% to $98.4 million. In January, Shandong Nanshan Aluminium said it invest 40 million yuan $6.5 million for a 80% stake in a joint venture with Zhongguancun Development Group to set up the Beijing Nanshan Aerial Material Research Institute. The move is seen as an effort by the aluminum company to expand into aviation-related materials. Song is also reportedly looking to set up an airline in Qingdao, Partners are said to include Air China and the Qingdao government.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ronald Southern founded power and utility company ATCO Group in 1947, investing $2,000 alongside his father, S.D. Southern. The two bought 15 utility trailers and rented them out in the Calgary area under the name Alberta Trailer Hire. They started importing and marketing mobile homes in the U.S. and then in the 1970s, moved into the oil and gas business. In the 1980s they expanded into electricity. Today the firm is engaged in the structures & logistics, energy, utilities and technology industries. Southern was president for 48 years and served as chairman of of ATCO Ltd and Canadian Utilities until December 2012. His daughter Nancy is ATCO's president, CEO and chairwoman. He owns Spruce Meadows, an equestrian complex outside Calgary known for producing Olympic riders including his daughter Linda. His net worth increased $500 million in the past year thanks to a surge in ATCO stock. Southern attended the University of Alberta where he earned a Bachelor of Science degree in medicine.

name: Billionaires
bio: Hary Tanoesoedibjo's MNC Group, Indonesia's biggest media company, is reportedly in talks with the politically influential Bakrie family to buy a 51% interest in Visi Media Asia. If MNC wins the bid, it may pay as much as $2 billion for Visi, which owns two national TV stations and a news website. In 2012 MNC set up a joint venture with Chinese internet company Tencent and with GS Home Shopping, adding to existing joint ventures with Japanese online retailer Rakuten and with Linktone, a Chinese media company. Tanoesoedibjo is becoming more politically active. After leaving one party, he quickly joined a second party, Hanura, which was founded by a former Indonesian military commander.

name: Billionaires
bio: While in college, Glen Taylor started working in a small print shop in North Mankato, Minn., that specialized in formal invitations. When his boss retired, he offered $2 million for the shop, to be paid off over 10 years. Now his Taylor Corp. does commercial printing, packaging and marketing; it publishes yearbooks, training manuals, clothing tags and gift cards. He owns farmland in Iowa and Minnesota and sells liquefied pasteurized eggs to food companies and restaurants. Also he is working to find a permanent solution to hearing loss and has invested in Envoy, a micro-device implanted deep within the ear that received FDA approval in 2010. He is the majority owner of pro basketball's Minnesota Timberwolves, serves on the board of directors of Imation Corp., a data storage and security company, and is a former Minnesota state senator. He has given around $25 million to local universities, colleges, churches, hospitals and other organizations.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mustafa Latif Topbas owes most of his fortune to BIM, Turkey's largest discount market, which he heads. BIM shares have increased 66.8% over the past year.  He also owns shares of the family textile business and partnerships with companies such as Ak Food and Link Food which belong to the Ulker Family, Turkey's largest food producer, with which he has family ties. Last year, he co-founded Bati Hatti Natural Gas to transport natural gas and obtained one of the four licenses to start importing.

name: Billionaires
bio: Wei Yin-Chun is one of the four brothers from Taiwan, along with Ing-Chou, Ying-Chiao, and Yin-Heng, who founded Hong Kong-listed beverage maker Tingyi (Cayman Islands). Tingyi accounts for almost half of the ready-to-drink tea business in China, a quarter of bottled water sales, and about 57% of instant noodle sales. Yet the company last year was criticized in China for its business ties to Japanese companies such as Sanyo Foods, Asahi Beverages and Itochu amid the dispute between Beijing and Tokyo over a group of tiny islands located between the two sides. The Weis also partner with Pepsi, invest in real estate and control the Dicos fried-chicken chain. Tingyi last year hosted the "8th World Instant Noodles Summit," whose theme was "Instant Noodles for Better Life."

name: Billionaires
bio: Wei Yin-Heng is one of the four brothers from Taiwan, along with Ing-Chou, Ying-Chiao and Yin-Chun, who founded Hong Kong-listed beverage maker Tingyi (Cayman Islands) Holdings. Tingyi accounts for almost half of the ready-to-drink tea business in China, a quarter of bottled water sales, and about 57% of instant noodle sales. Yet the company was criticized in China last year for its business ties to Japanese companies such as Sanyo Foods, Asahi Beverages and Itochu amid the dispute between Beijing and Tokyo over a group of tiny islands located between the two sides. The Weis also partner with Pepsi, invest in real estate and control the Dicos fried-chicken chain. Tingyi last year hosted the "8th World Instant Noodles Summit," which had as its theme "Instant Noodles for Better Life."

name: Billionaires
bio: Wei Ying-Chiao is one of the four brothers from Taiwan, along with Ing-Chou, Yin-Chun and Yin-Heng, who founded Hong Kong-listed beverage maker Tingyi (Cayman Islands) Holdings. Tingyi accounts for almost half of the ready-to-drink tea business in China, a quarter of bottled water sales, and about 57% of instant noodle sales. Yet the company was criticized in China last year for its business ties to Japanese companies such as Sanyo Foods, Asahi Beverages and Itochu amid the dispute between Beijing and Tokyo over a group of tiny islands located between the two sides. The Weis also partner with Pepsi, invest in real estate and control the Dicos fried-chicken chain. Ying-Chiao is an executive director at Tingyi. Last year the company hosted the "8th World Instant Noodles Summit," which had as its theme "Instant Noodles for Better Life."

name: Billionaires
bio: Elaine Wynn's fortune comes from her stake in Wynn Resorts. She married and divorced casino magnate Steve Wynn twice, but has remained on his company's board for three decades. In her 2010 divorce settlement she got 11 million shares, though she didn't have full control. An agreement between her ex-husband and his business partner, Kazuo Okada, requires that they sign off before she sells. She has been fighting in court to free her shares. A basketball fan, she sits on the board of the Basketball Hall of Fame. She also sits on the board of the Kennedy Center and chairs Communities in Schools, which works to keep kids in school. In December 2010 she gave $5 million to the Smith Center for the Performing Arts in Las Vegas for an arts education studio. Nevada Governor Brian Sandoval appointed her to the state Board of Education, effective in January 2013.
title: Board Member
employment: {'name': 'Wynn Las Vegas, LLC', 'title': 'Board Member', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Property tycoon Zhong Sheng Jian, chairman of Yanlord Land Group, saw his wealth climb after the company's strong financial showing there last year and on expectations of a recovery in real estate prices in China, where Yanlord's business is focused. For the first nine months of 2012, Yanlord's net profit nearly quadrupled to $199 million on sales up by a third to $919 million in the latest display of Zhong's success at targeting the country's middle-to-upper-income consumers. In recognition of Yanlord's good image, Zhong holds honorary citizenships in Nanjing, Zhuhai  Shanwei and Suzhou. He actively participates in China-Singapore business groups, and is also a member of the Tianjin People's Political Consultative Conference Standing Committee, a political consultation body in the eastern Chinese city.

name: Billionaires
bio: Abdulla Al Futtaim owns huge conglomerate Al Futtaim Group. It operates Ikea, Toys "R" Us and Marks & Spencer franchises, sells Toyota and Honda vehicles, and co-owns the Middle East's largest privately-funded urban community, Dubai Festival City. The group is building a residential and commercial complex, Cairo Festival City, but the opening has been delayed more than once because of the turmoil in Egypt. The property's mall is due to open in the summer of 2013. The group began construction of another big real estate project in Qatar called Doha Festival City; it is expected to be completed by 2014.

name: Billionaires
bio: David Gottesman has been a friend of Warren Buffett's since 1962. An early investor in Berkshire Hathaway, he serves on its board and owes the bulk of his fortune to the roughly 10,000 shares he owns. He founded investment advisor First Manhattan Co. in 1964; the firm now has nearly $13 billion in assets under management. He and his wife Ruth donated $25 million to Yeshiva University medical school in 2008 and they are funding the Jerusalem Biblical Zoo's planned aquarium, slated to be the largest in Israel and expected to open in 2015. He is a generous donor to New York City's American Museum of Natural History and serves as vice chairman of its board of trustees.  He has a degree from Harvard Business School.
title: Chief Executive Officer
employment: {'name': 'First Manhattan Co.', 'title': 'Chief Executive Officer', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Oaktree Capital Management's president Bruce Karsh was elected chairman of the Tribune, which recently emerged from bankruptcy after four years, in January. His firm is the largest equity owner in it, with a roughly 20% stake. Karsh and his longtime partner Howard Marks took Oaktree public in April 2012; they had previously sold 16% of Oaktree on a private Goldman Sachs exchange in 2007. In recent months, Karsh has personally paid $56 million to buy the Ritz-Carlton hotel in Clayton, Missouri, and $30 million for the world headquarters building of Fender Musical Instruments Corp . in north Scottsdale, Arizona. A Duke University trustee, he and his wife Martha are giving $50 million to his alma mater for undergraduate scholarships. They had previously given $35 million to Duke. They are also big supporters of Teach for America and public charter school group KIPP.  Karsh is a minority investor in the Golden State Warriors basketball team.
title: President
employment: {'name': 'Oaktree Capital Group LLC', 'title': 'President', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Lu Xiangyang is the vice chairman of BYD, one of China's largest privately controlled automakers and one of the world's biggest cell-phone battery makers. Warren Buffett is a shareholder. A division of Berkshire Hathaway bought 10% in 2008. Lu and his cofounder and cousin Wang Chuanfu, BYD's billionaire chairman, have had a bumpy year owing to slowing sales of its autos. Its big push these days is into electric-powered models, an effort that was not helped when one of its electric taxis caught fire in Shenzhen in a collision last year. BYD's profit in the nine months to September of last year fell by 94%. Lu also runs investment company Guangzhou Youngy Management & Investment Group.

name: Billionaires
bio: Oaktree Capital Management CEO Howard Marks sold his Malibu Mansion for $75 million in a record-breaking deal this January to an unidentified Russian billionaire couple. Marks has also listed a condo at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel in Manhattan for $50 million. He paid $52.5 million for an apartment in the storied Manhattan building 740 Park Ave., the subject of a book by the same name calling it the "story of the world's richest apartment building." He bought it in May, one month after he and his longtime partner Bruce Karsh took Oaktree public last year. They had previously sold 16% of Oaktree on a private Goldman Sachs exchange in 2007.A Wharton grad, he got his start in investments with First National Citibank (which later became Citicorp) in 1969, and joined TCW in 1985. He hired Karsh in 1987; the pair founded Oaktree eight years later. Oaktree's chairman, he has been penning highly regarded investment memos for clients for two decades. He is the author of The Most Important Thing; Uncommon Sense for the Thoughtful Investor.
title: Chairman
employment: {'name': 'Oaktree Capital Group LLC', 'title': 'Chairman', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Andrei Molchanov is the largest shareholder in the Russian property developer LSR Group, and he heads the committee for economic politics of Russia's Federation Council. In 1994, after he received his Ph.D. in economics from St. Petersburg State University, he and a classmate started a residential construction business. During Russia's privatization he bought LSR, or Lenstroireconstruktsiya, until then one of the largest city-owned construction firms, and he took it public in 2007. His stepfather was for many years the vice governor of St.Petersburg; later he went to work for VTB as vice-president in charge of infrastructure projects.

name: Billionaires
bio: Linda Pritzker's grandfather A.N. Pritzker (d. 1986), with his sons Jay (d. 1999), Robert (d. 2011) and Donald (d. 1972), created Chicago-based industrial conglomerate Marmon Holdings and hotel chain Hyatt. Back in 2007, the family sold control of Marmon to Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway for a reported $4.7 billion. Linda is a Tibetan Buddhist, a psychotherapist and sometime donor to liberal causes including Planned Parenthood and MoveOn.org.

name: Billionaires
bio: One of the first people to write a check to Google cofounders Sergey Brin and Larry Page, Kavitark "Ram" Shriram advised the pair weekly in their Menlo Park, Calif. garage. He is still a Google board member, but since March 2012 he has sold or given away more than 70% of his shares. Shriram's investment firm, Sherpalo Ventures, cashed in on Mint Software, which sold to Intuit for $171 million in 2009. Born in India, Shriram joined Netscape in 1994. His next company, Junglee, was bought by Amazon in 1998 for about $185 million worth of Amazon shares. He serves as a trustee at Stanford University, where he and his wife endowed the Shriram Family Professorship in Science Education.
title: Investor

name: Billionaires
bio: Gil Shwed's fortune is down $400 million in the past year as shares of Check Point, the cybersecurity outfit he founded in 1993 with Marius Nacht and Shlomo Kramer, tumbled. Shwed chalked up the poor performance due uncertainty in Europe and the strengthening of the dollar. Meanwhile the company is facing new pressures from recently listed Palo Alto Networks, another security outfit founded by one of Check Point's first engineers and backed by Check Point founder Kramer. Palo Alto's founder, Nir Zuk, has publicly criticized Check Point for what he claims is lack of innovation. Shwed is an avid photographer and cook, and says he perfected his cooking skills during parties -- hanging out with the chefs instead of the guests.

name: Billionaires
bio: When she was a baby in 1938, Lina Maria Aguiar was abandoned in front of a branch of Bradesco Bank, one of Brazil's largest banks. Amador Aguiar, the bank's founder, adopted her. Two years later he adopted Lina's biological sister, Emilia, and named her Lia Maria Aguiar. Both of them are now billionaires. Amador also adopted a third child, Maria Angela, who is not on the list because she received a smaller share of Bradesco Bank. In fact, the majority of Amador's fortune was left to the philanthropic Bradesco Foundation, founded by Amador in 1956 to benefit education in Brazil. Amador's death in 1991 sparked more than a decade of court fights over inheritance between his adopted daughters and his second wife, whom he married less than five months before his death Amador's widow, 40 years his junior, reportedly demanded her husband's body be exhumed for a DNA test to prove paternity and disqualify his three adopted daughters. Amador's daughters prevailed in court.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ron Baron runs Baron Capital, which manages $18.2 billion. Each year, his firm hosts a popular investors conference at the Metropolitan Opera House featuring surprise performances by musicians and other entertainers. Last year it was Celine Dion and Harry Connick Jr. Past performers have included Jerry Seinfeld, Jon Bon Jovi and Elton John. Baron grew up in Asbury, NJ, and spent summers doing odd jobs on the Jersey Shore, got his start as a biochemistry teaching fellow and then as a patent examiner in U.S. patent office, while attending George Washington law school. He became securities analyst in 1970 and started his own firm in 1982. Today, Baron owns one of the biggest estates in the Hamptons, 40-acres for which he paid $103 million in 2007. He also has homes in New York City and Vail.

name: Billionaires
bio: Home Depot co-founder Arthur Blank has already donated more than $250 million to charity through his own foundation and in 2012 he joined the Giving Pledge. Blank bought the Atlanta Falcons in 2002 after retiring from Home Depot, which he founded in 1978 with partner Bernie Marcus (who also became a billionaire). The pair handed out dollar bills in the parking lot to lure early customers. Home Depot went public three years later and is now the world's largest home improvement retailer with $70 billion in sales and more than 2,200 stores. Blank is also divorcing his wife of 17 years after separating in 2011.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Norman Braman, owner of car dealerships and art collector, is at war with fellow billionaire Stephen Ross, owner of the Miami Dolphins. Ross has plans for a $400 million renovation of the Dolphins' stadium and is looking for public financing, including a tax hike on area hotels, to help pay for it. Braman calls that "welfare for a multi-billionaire." Age seems to have made him feistier. In 2011 he bankrolled an effort to recall Mayor Carlos Alvarez, and 90% of voters chose to oust the mayor. In 2012 he funded a slate of four candidates to run against incumbent county commissioners; his slate was handily defeated. Braman started in business as a research analyst for a liquor company. He co-founded vitamin retailer Keystone Discount Stores, merged it with Philadelphia Pharmaceuticals in 1967, cashed out for $1 million a year later, and moved to Florida. He bought a Cadillac dealership in Tampa in 1972, and today he owns 17 car dealerships in Florida and Colorado. He owned the Philadelphia Eagles from 1985 to 1994. His major charitable gifts include $5 million to the University of Miami to establish the Braman Breast Cancer Institute and $5 million to Children's Hospital of Philadelphia to establish the Suzi and Scott Lustgarten Center for GI Motility. He plans to sell his 240-plus-piece art collection, including the largest collection of Alexander Calder's work, upon his death. The proceeds will go to a foundation that will be run by his children.

name: Billionaires
bio: Construction and real estate magnate Alfred James Clark is chairman of Clark Enterprises, a builder of popular sports venues including Baltimore's Camden Yards, FedEx Field outside Washington, D.C, and San Diego's Petco Park. The company also builds prisons, airports, military bases, university buildings and museums. The firm has interests in asset management, private equity and venture capital. Clark is a big proponent of engineering education. In 2011 he gave $8 million to George Washington University to fund scholarships. He also gave $15 million in 1994 to create the A. James Clark School of Engineering at the University of Maryland, his alma mater.

name: Billionaires
bio: Robert Coyiuto Jr joins the billionaire ranks for the first time on performance of Philippine power transmission company National Grid Corporation, which he owns 30% of and which is co-owned by the son of Philippines' richest man, Henry Sy.  Luxury car distributor, his PGA Automobile was appointed Bentley's sole distributor in the Philippines, in October. He was the publisher of the now-defunct Manila Chronicle.

name: Billionaires
bio: Reclusive Texas Rangers baseball team owner Ray Davis teamed with Kelcy Warren to form gas pipeline company Cornerstone in 1993. The pair bought small pipelines and consolidated the holdings into an efficient network. They flipped the pipelines to El Paso in 1999, using the proceeds to create natural gas retailer, distributor and pipeline company Energy Transfer Equity. Davis stepped down as co-chief executive in 2007.

name: Billionaires
bio: After a rare down year in 2011, fund manager James Dinan came roaring back in 2012. His York Capital Management's flagship Multi-Strategy fund posted a solid 13.5% net return on the year, while the firm's Credit Opportunities fund finished 2012 up 19%. A graduate of Wharton and Harvard Business School, he got his start working 100 hour weeks at investment bank Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. He lost his life savings on Black Monday in 1987; since then he says he rarely uses debt. Dinan launched York Capital in 1991 with $3.6 million from his DLJ colleagues. He sold 33% of York to Credit Suisse in September 2010. Dinan serves on the boards of the UPenn and Lincoln Center. He wears a hearing aid because he lost much of his hearing as an infant after being given the antibiotic streptomycin for a fever.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: One of three sons of Gap founders Donald and Doris Fisher, Robert "Bob" Fisher serves on the board of the apparel empire his parents started in 1969.  Fisher chaired the clothing retailer from 2004 to 2007. Like his two brothers, William and John, he attended Princeton, where he played tennis and majored in English, before heading to Stanford's Graduate School of Business. In between his undergraduate and graduate college stints, he gained retail experience working at Bloomingdale's department stores in New York and Washington. He is also a managing director at Pisces Inc., the Fisher family's investment fund.
title: Director

name: Billionaires
bio: Legend has it in his native Toronto that SmartCentres owner Mitchell Goldhar paid an unsolicited visit to Sam Walton in the early 1990s, seeking a partnership with the retailing icon to develop Wal-Mart stores in Canada. Though Walton initially declined, Goldhar's tenacity impressed Walton enough to eventually give him a shot. Goldhar soon became Wal-Mart's de facto developer in the country, paving the way for Wal-Mart as it moved into the market. Goldhar is still developing his Wal-Mart-anchored SmartCentres, many of which he then sells to Calloway, a real estate investment trust in which he holds a 21% stake. He manages the parallel operations out of SmartCentres headquarters, known as "the Igloo," in Vaughn, Ontario. In October 2012 Goldhar contributed CAD 1 million to the Brain Campaign for the Canadian Sports Concussion Project to "fund critical research into solving the unknowns of repetitive concussions that has affected so many players in Canadian sports."
title: Owner

name: Billionaires
bio: Tom Golisano founded Paychex, the payroll and human resources services provider that made him a billionaire, in 1971 with $3,000 and a credit card. Paychex generated $2.2 billion in revenue last year. In addition to serving as Chairman of Paychex, Golisano sits on the board of trustees of the Rochester Institute of Technology and is the national spokesman and major funder of the National Popular Vote Initiative, an organization dedicated to abolishing the Electoral College and instituting the direct election of the President of the United States by popular vote. Golisano sold the NHL's Buffalo Sabres to fellow billionaire Terry Pegula in March 2011 for $189 million. The longtime New Yorker reportedly rejected a rival bid that would have netted him an additional $70 million because it involved moving the team from Buffalo. In September 2012 Golisano gave $12 million to the Special Olympics; in October he pledged $20 million to the Children's Hospital of Southwest Florida.

name: Billionaires
bio: A former elite jet pilot, Achmad Hamami became the youngest colonel in the Indonesian military. He took early retirement after souring on corruption in the ranks. He started a tutoring business, giving private math lessons to students at home. A family friend helped him get a state investment-fund job dealing with Caterpillar. That was his break, and led to him becoming Caterpillar's Indonesia distributor. He now gets the bulk of his fortune from that business, Trakindo Utama, but turned over the reins to his son Muki after he lost his sight to glaucoma in 1999. In 2011 he took his energy services firm PT ABM Investama public.

name: Billionaires
bio: Richard Hayne returned to the helm of his trendy clothing chain Urban Outfitters after long-time CEO Glen Senk resigned in January 2012. A former hippie who protested the Vietnam War, Hayne opened his first store near the University of Pennsylvania in 1970, selling clothes to college kids and cash-strapped city dwellers. He has come a long way from his hippie past, donating to Republican politicians including Rick Santorum, who opposes gay marriage and abortion. Some of Urban Outfitters' merchandise has raised hackles. The Navajo Nation sued the company in 2012, alleging trademark infringement, after stores offered panties and flasks labeled "Navajo." In January 2013 the stores stirred controversy in the Latino community over whether a shirt emblazoned with the Wal-Mart company logo and the nametag "Juan" reinforced ethnic stereotypes. Today Urban Outfitters is a global empire that includes Anthropologie, Free People (run by second wife Margaret), Terrain Garden Center, and wedding-outfitter BHLDN. A surging stock price in the past year pushed Haynes' fortune up by $500 million. His net worth includes shares held by wife Margaret.
title: Chairman, President & Chief Executive Officer
employment: {'name': 'Urban Outfitters Inc.', 'title': 'Chairman, President & Chief Executive Officer', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'salary': 1.0, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Hintze's hedge fund firm, CQS, dominated the markets in 2012. The fund manager's flagship Directional Opportunities fund, which Hintze manages personally, returned nearly 36% net of fees last year. Assets under management at CQS now stand at nearly $12 billion. Hintze trained as an engineer and served in the Australian army before entering the world of financial services. He had stints at Goldman Sachs and Credit Suisse First Boston prior to launching CQS in 1999. The papal knight is well known in the U.K. for his consistent support of the Conservative Party and has given generously to the University of Sydney and to restoration projects at the Vatican. Hintze also owns thousands of acres of Australian farmland.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: The only daughter of Erie Indemnity founder Henry Orth (H.O.) Hirt (d.1982) and the first woman elected to its board of directors in 1980. H.O. Hirt established trusts in his name in 1967 for the benefit of his children and their respective families, which control Erie Indemnity's Class B voting stock. Susan is a co-trustee and also owns 35% of common shares through a family limited partnership. Hagen is a graduate of Ohio's Wittenberg University and an emerita member of its Board of Directors, receiving an honorary doctor of humane letters in 2011 in recognition of her distinguished career and community engagement. Also in 2011, Hagen took her commitment to service one step further by giving the largest cash gift ever received from a living individual to Wittenberg.  The $6 million gift endowed Wittenberg's Center for Civic & Urban Engagement, which now bears her name. Her husband Thomas B. Hagen is chairman of the board of Erie Indemnity and a former CEO.

name: Billionaires
bio: Launched Brevan Howard Asset Management in 2002 when he and four other Credit Suisse proprietary traders went solo.  Assets under management at the Geneva-based hedge fund firm now total $39 billion and the firm continues to hire talent away from banks and is again expanding its operations in the U.S. Howard's $28 billion Master Fund returned 3.8% net of fees in 2012, after an impressive 12.14% performance in 2011. His partnership group sold a 15% stake in the business to Swiss Re in 2007 for an undisclosed sum.
title: Founder
employment: {'name': 'Brevan Howard Asset Management', 'title': 'Founder', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: A year after telling Forbes he was almost "ancient," 87-year-old Stephen Jarislowsky announced that he was retiring as chief executive of Canadian money management firm Jarislowsky Fraser Ltd in November 2012. He will remain chairman of the firm he founded 57 years ago, which as of December 2012 had about $36 billion in assets under management. Jarislowsky remains as vocal as ever, and penned a series of opinion pieces in Canada's Globe And Mail on topics including the influence of money in politics and the problems of suppressing English in Quebec. Jarislowsky is also an art buff with a collection that spans Chinese jade to French impressionism. He owns Marina Island near Vancouver, a 2,000-acre islet with spectacular beaches and mountain views in the Strait of Georgia, British Columbia.
title: Cofounder and Chairman
employment: {'name': 'Jarislowsky & Fraser', 'title': 'Cofounder and Chairman', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Koo Bon-Moo is the chairman of LG Group, Korea's fourth largest conglomerate by assets. It operates more than 50 companies in electronics, home appliances, chemicals and telecom. He is the eldest grandson of LG Group founder Koo In-hoe, and has been chairman since 1995. The group's handset business has been strengthening and LG plans to invest heavily in marketing for its Optimus G II smartphone in the second half of 2013. The group also plans to produce organic light-emitting diode screens for televisions. The screens are thinner and brighter than the typical liquid liquid crystal display screens. Koo has said that LG's investments in green energy will reach $7 billion by 2015, and in 2013 the group plans to invest a record $20 billion to boost its various business lines. Koo's son died in an accident in the 1990s and Koo, who also has two daughters, later adopted his brother's son, Koo Gwang-mo, in 2004. The adopted son is the heir apparent to the LG group. Koo has a collection of more than 50,000 bottles of wine which he stores in a cave cellar.

name: Billionaires
bio: Yuriy Kosiuk heads Ukraine's largest agricultural holding, MHP, and continues it's growth with a planned $1.5 billion poultry plant. Further expansion set as sales to Europe were approved by the European Commission to start this summer. Kosiuk started as broker on commodities exchange; in the 1990s he imported furniture and Turkmenistan gas, exported grain and got into poultry production later on. He took MHP public in 2008; the company's stock price is up 34% over the past year

name: Billionaires
bio: Colorado cattle rancher Gary Magness inherited his fortune after his father died in 1996. Bob Magness founded cable television titan TCI, which merged with AT&T in 1999 in a $54 billion deal. He left hundreds of millions of dollars in stock to his son. Gary now owns ranches in Colorado including the water rights, and  invests in oil, gas, cattle and real estate. He also owns a 100,000-square-foot data center that provides rapid connectivity and security for its clients, many of them major corporations. He founded production company Smokewood Entertainment with his wife, Sarah Siegel-Magness. They produced the critically acclaimed movie "Precious," as well as "Crazy Kind of Love." Magness leads off-road truck racing team Mango Racing and collects vintage cars. The Magnesses gave $1.325 million to start Camp Precious, an outdoor camp for inner city girls run by The Fresh Air Fund. They also gave more than $1 million to the Food Bank of the Rockies distribution center, which now bears their name.

name: Billionaires
bio: Stephen Mandel returned to crushing the markets in 2012, with all of his Lone Pine Capital's funds ending the year up more than 22% net of fees. The firm scored big in 2012 with stakes in fashion retailers including Michael Kors and The Gap. This "Tiger Cub" worked at Mars & Co. and then Goldman Sachs before joining Julian Robertson's Tiger Management as a consumer analyst. Mandel departed in 1997 to launch his own firm, Lone Pine Capital, named for a mythical Dartmouth pine tree that survived an 1887 lightning strike at his alma mater. The firm currently manages approximately $23 billion across long-only equity funds, hedge funds and a fund of funds. Mandel contributed $134 million to his Zoom Foundation in tax year 2010, at which point the charitable vehicle had more than half a billion in assets. Past beneficiaries include the Children's Aid Society of New York, Phillips Exeter Academy, and the Fairfield County Foundation. Mandel also serves on the board of Dartmouth College and Teach for America.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Craig McCaw has cut his ties to Clearwire, the troubled high speed wireless network provider he helped try to build. He founded its predecessor, which later merged with part of Sprint Nextel in 2008, but stepped down as CEO in January 2012 and later sold his remaining stake to Sprint for $100 million pre-tax. These days he is chairman of Pendrell, formally known as ICO Global, a Seattle area intellectual property firm that acquired 1,300 U.S. and foreign patents for wireless handset and infrastructure technologies in 2012.  McCaw got his start selling cable services door-to-door for his father's company. He co-founded McCaw Cellular with his brothers, and sold it to AT&T in 1994 for $11.5 billion.  He reportedly bought the world's most expensive car last year, paying $35 million for an apple-green 1962 Ferrari 250 GTO made for race driver Stirling Moss. He is selling his 780-acre private island off the coast of Canada for $75 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Tuncay Ozilhan, with fellow billionaire, Kamil Yazici, controls the Anadolu Group. It's flagship company, Anadolu Efes, is the producer of Turkey's number one beer brand, Efes. Last year the company took over the beer operations of SAB Miller in Russia and Ukraine; in turn SAB Miller agreed to take a 24% stake in Anadolu Efes. Anadolu Efes and the Efes Marketing companies own a 50.2% stake in Coca Cola Beverages, whose shares have gone up 74.46% over the past year. The Anadolu Group also has a publicly traded company called Adel Pen in partnership with Faber-Castell which is an extension of Ozilhan's passion. He has collection of more than 3,000 pens and carries carries some of his pens with him in a suitcase.

name: Billionaires
bio: After selling a big chunk of his Piramal Healthcare's domestic formulations business to US-headquartered Abbott Labs for $3.7 billion in 2010, pharma tycoon Ajay Piramal has been busy remaking his fortune. In September, he changed his flagship's name to Piramal Enterprises to denote its broadening interests. It gets 70% of its $2 billion revenues from overseas. Last May, it acquired Illinois-based analytics firm Decision Resources Group for $635 million. Daughter Nandini oversees human resources and the group's over-the-counter business. Son Anand is executive director at privately-owned Piramal Realty which has 20 million square feet under development in Mumbai. He also has interests in financial services and glass manufacturing.

name: Billionaires
bio: Murdaya Poo started out selling newspapers and has since expanded into information technology and timber through his firm, Central Cipta Murdaya. He is also the majority owner of property developer Metropolitan Kentjana, and of Jakarta's convention center. In February 2013 his wife, Siti Hartati Murdaya, was sentenced to 32 months in prison and fined $15,000 after a court found her guilty of bribery. She was accused of paying $309,000 in bribes to Amran Batalipu, the former regent of Buol in Central Sulawesi, to speed up the application process of a business permit for her oil palm plantation company, PT Hartati Inti Plantation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ukraine's "chocolate king" Petro Poroshenko got his start selling cocoa beans, then purchased several confectionery plants, uniting them in Roshen in 1995. Poroshenko is now expanding his sweets company into Europe, buying a confectionery in Hungary last year. A former Minister of Foreign Affairs as well as Minister of Economy for Ukraine, Poroshenko returned to politics in 2012 as a member of the Ukrainian Parliament; he has stated his intention to run for mayor of Ukraine's capital Kiev.

name: Billionaires
bio: Stewart Rahr, who refers to himself as "Stewie Rah Rah, the No. 1 King of All Fun" sold his pharmaceutical distributor, Kinray, to Cardinal Health for $1.3 billion in November 2010. Following the sale, Rahr put aside $100 million to establish the Rahr Foundation, which will focus on supporting medical research and education. He is a regular in the New York gossip pages and, in December, news broke that Rahr would be divorcing his wife of 43 years, a process that he told Forbes is amicable. Rahr lines the wall of his Trump Tower office with framed photos of himself posing with celebrities and politicos. He calls himself a close friend of Donald Trump, and helped back Trump's short-lived campaign for the 2012 Republican presidential nomination. Rahr bought his massive Burnt Point estate in the Hamptons in 2005 for $44 million. At the time it was the most expensive single-family-home purchase in the history of New York State. Rahr is a large donor to the Make a Wish Foundation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Vito Rodriguez Rodriguez is new to the Forbes Billionaires list. Along with his brother Jorge, in 1967 he founded Jose Rodriguez Banda SA, a transport company that provided services for mining companies.  In 1986 the brothers bought Gloria SA, Peru's largest producer of canned evaporated milk. Nestlé owned 60% of Gloria and the Berckemeyer family of Peru owned 40%. Nestlé sold its shares because Alan García, then-president of Peru, said the company should be transferred to Peruvians. Gloria became a highly profitable company. Since 1991, it has bought a number of other companies. Today the Rodriguez family has stakes in food companies in Argentina, Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador, Puerto Rico and Uruguay. They also have investments in sugar mills in Peru, Ecuador and Argentina. In 1996 terrorists held Vito Rodriguez hostage for six days at the Japanese embassy.

name: Billionaires
bio: Howard Schultz, the man who made drinking lattes the American way, is stretching his company's vast reach into tea. Starbucks announced in November 2012 that it would acquire Teavana Holdings Inc. for $620 million in cash, Starbucks' biggest acquisition ever. In June 2012 it bought San Francisco' La Boulange Bakery for $100 million. In 2011 it bought Evolution Fresh, a small maker of premium juices, for $30 million. The chain continues to open retail shops in the U.S. In December 2012 it said it plans to add 1,500 in the next five years. Meanwhile it is pushing into India through its 50-50 joint venture with Tata Global Beverages; the partners opened a New Delhi flagship store in February 2013. Through venture capital firm Maveron, Schultz has had investments in consumer businesses including Pinkberry frozen yogurt, Lululemon activewear, eBay and Groupon. He was raised in housing projects in Brooklyn and played football at Northern Michigan U. After moving back to New York to sell kitchen equipment and housewares for a Swedish company, he landed a marketing gig at a small coffee bean store called Starbucks. He traveled to Italy and was inspired to open an espresso bar in the U.S. His Starbucks bosses said no, so he started a rival store in 1985, making his java with Starbucks beans. He bought Starbucks from his bosses two years later for $3.8 million and took it public in 1992. The longtime chairman returned as CEO to turn around the struggling retailer after an eight-year break.
title: Chairman and CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: Pat Stryker and her siblings are heirs to medical device and software company Stryker Corp., which was founded by her surgeon grandfather, Homer Stryker (d. 1980). The Kalamazoo, Mich.-based company sold $8.7 billion worth of replacement hips, operating tables and other equipment last year. Her Stryker Sonoma Winery in Geyserville, California, produces about 7,000 cases of wine a year. She is influential in political circles, donating to Democratic candidates in Colorado, where she lives, as well as to President Obama. In 2012, her White House connection came under scrutiny when Abound Solar, a Colorado start-up in which she invested, went bankrupt after receiving a $400 million loan from the U.S. Department of Energy.

name: Billionaires
bio: Djoko Susanto is best known for his chain of 6,000 Alfamart minimarts in Indonesia. The sixth of 10 siblings, he dropped out after one year of high school. At age 17 he began managing his parents' 170-square-foot food stall, then started peddling cigarettes and opening more stalls. His success attracted the attention of fellow billionaire Putera Sampoerna, who worked with Susanto to open more stalls and later, a discount supermarket chain. When Sampoerna sold his cigarette business to Philip Morris (now Altria), Djoko bought out the retail business and developed the minimart chain, which has a bee as its mascot.

name: Billionaires
bio: Peter Thiel, Facebook's first institutional investor, sold most of his position in the company last August following the expiration of lock-up agreements for early investors and employees. Thiel invested $500,000 in Facebook and sold half of his personal stake in the company's public offering in May 2012. Still, he kept enough shares to enjoy Facebook's recent 30% price surge. As an investor, Thiel has had mixed results. His Founders Fund was boosted significantly by the Facebook IPO, while the performance of his hedge fund, Clarium Capital, remained relatively flat after a dismal 2010 took assets under management well under $500 million (assets were as high as $6 billion in 2008.) According to public filings, there is more than $430 million under management as of October. He opened Mithril Capital Management, another venture fund, in June, with more than $400 million under management. His Thiel Foundation gives young entrepreneurs $100,000 over two years to skip college and pursue their business ideas. In April 2012, Thiel returned to the classroom at alma mater Stanford to lecture for 10 weeks about developing companies like PayPal and Facebook.
title: Partner

name: Billionaires
bio: Entertainment mogul Joop van den Ende started his career as a party-supply salesman before later partnering with John de Mol, now also a billionaire, to create reality TV production company Endemol. After scoring big with the worldwide hit Big Brother, the duo sold Endemol to Spanish telecom giant Telefonica in 2000 for $5.3 billion. Since then, Van den Ende has turned his attention toward theater. He is the founder and owner of Stage Entertainment, a theater production company that was spun off from Endemol, which now puts on between 40 and 50 plays, ice shows, dance events and concerts annually. Its U.S. division has won 46 Tony Awards on blockbuster musicals like The Lion King and Mamma Mia. Van den Ende stepped down as chairman in 2008, but remains president of the supervisory board. He received an honorary doctorate as a cultural entrepreneur from Nyenrode Business University in the Netherlands.

name: Billionaires
bio: Arne Wilhemsen is one of the co-founders of Royal Caribbean, now one of the world's largest cruise companies with 22 vessels visiting 270 destinations in 72 countries. The Harvard grad and longtime shipping broker retired long ago, with his son Alex taking his place on the Royal Caribbean board of directors in 2003. He still has a large stake in the cruise company. He also pocketed at least $500 million in 2008 when China Oilfield Services acquired Awilco Offshore, in which he had 40% stake, for $2.5 billion. Wilhelmsen owns private real estate company Linstow, one of Norway's largest property developers.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chen Jinxia is the widow of Wei Dong, an entrepreneur and financier who committed suicide in 2008. Chen inherited a controlling interest the Hunan Yongjin Group he founded, which includes shares in drug makers Jiuzhitang and Zhuzhou Qianjin Pharmaceutical, and brokerage Sinolink Securities. Her wealth is up on a big rise in the share price of Sinolink, in which Chen has a 22% stake. Yongjin's Shanghai Yonghua Investment Management has invested $806 million in more than 60 companies.

name: Billionaires
bio: Michael Chiang has grown rich as a supplier of touchscreens for Apple's iPhones and iPads via TPK Holdings, which went public in 2010. Its shares have been volatile in the past couple of years, along with other Apple suppliers. Chiang saw his net worth drop by $1 billion between May 2011 and May 2012, but renewed confidence in mobile device sales have sent his shares up 44% from a year ago.

name: Billionaires
bio: Diego Della Valle chairs the luxury Italian shoe- and purse-maker Tod's, which is growing due healthy sales in China and Hong Kong; sales grew nearly 14% in 2011 and were up 7% in the first nine months of 2012, to $990 million (750 million Euros). With his brother Andrea (also a billionaire), Diego owns a 56% stake in Tod's; a rise in the share price has added more than $300 million to Diego's net worth since March 2012. He founded Tod's in 1978. With brother Andrea, he also owns stakes in U.S. retailer Saks and eyewear company Marcolin. Diego has pledged $33 million to fund renovations at Rome's crumbling Coliseum. They were due to start in December 2012 but were delayed because of court challenges to the contract bidding process. In early February a regional administrative court gave the green light for the stalled restorations to begin.

name: Billionaires
bio: As a Gap board member, William Fisher, one of three sons of Gap founders Donald and Doris Fisher, presides over an apparel empire his parents started as a jeans and music store in 1969. A former president of Gap's international division, Bill expanded the company into Canada, Japan and Europe. He founded Manzanita Capital, a London-based private equity firm, in 2001 and serves at its CEO. Like his brothers he attended Princeton as an undergrad before moving on to Stanford for business school. He is a frequent donor to Stanford, where he and his wife, Sakurako, have endowed a professorship; in 2011 the couple gave $1 million to Stanford's Freeman Spogli Institute for International Studies.
title: Director

name: Billionaires
bio: Vladimir Iorich, a Russian-born German citizen, made his original fortune as a large shareholder of Russian mining and steel company Mechel AOA, run by Russian billionaire Igor Zyuzin. In 2007, after a disagreement with Zyuzin, Iorich sold his shares in the company and established Pala Investments, based in Zug, Switzerland. Pala owns chunks of mining outfits in Australia, Canada and Sierra Leone.

name: Billionaires
bio: In March 2012, Irwin Jacobs left the board of Qualcomm, ending his tenure at the wireless chip manufacturer he co-founded in 1985. A former academic, Jacobs attended Cornell seeking a degree in hotel administration before switching over to electrical engineering. He earned his doctorate at MIT where he then spent several years teaching. He moved to California in 1966 and taught computer science at the University of California at San Diego, where the engineering school is now named after him, following a $110 million gift in 2003. His son Paul has run San Diego-based Qualcomm as CEO since 2005. A noted philanthropist and Giving Pledge signatory, Jacobs and his wife, Joan, donated $30 million to MIT in 2007 for fellowships in the electrical engineering and computer science fields. They've also pledged more than $100 million to the San Diego Symphony. In 2010, Jacobs and his wife gave $75 million to the University of California, San Diego health system. Jacobs is also a noted supporter of Democratic causes and gave at least $2.3 million to Democratic super PACs during the last presidential election cycle.
title: Cofounder & Chairman Emeritus

name: Billionaires
bio: Indian pharma tycoon Habil Khorakiwala rejoins the billionaire ranks after four-year hiatus as shares of his generics maker Wockhardt soared nearly four-fold in the past year. The company, which had a near death experience when it defaulted on loans and its market cap plunged to $140 million in 2009 over foreign exchange losses, has staged a dramatic turnaround, largely by selling some businesses to cut down debt. It's now focusing on expanding sales, notably in the US, its biggest market. Daughter Zahabiya, youngest of his three children, is in charge of group's hospital arm.

name: Billionaires
bio: Indian tech pioneer N.R.Narayana Murthy is chairman emeritus of software bellwether Infosys, which he cofounded and ran for 30 years until 2011. Has lately been an outspoken critic of government on issues like corruption and economic reform. Last May, he was selected for the James C. Morgan Global Humanitarian Award sponsored by Applied Materials, whose past recipients include Bill Gates and Al Gore. He stepped down recently from the board of HSBC after a four-year stint.  He also owns venture capital fund Catamaran.  Murthy has been awarded 25 honorary doctorates from universities in India and overseas

name: Billionaires
bio: Blinds baron Ralph Sonnenberg runs the Hunter Douglas Group, a Netherlands company that sells window coverings and architectural products. His father founded the group in 1919 as a machine-tool manufacturer, eventually developing new technology for the production of lightweight aluminum slats for Venetian blinds. The company supplied blinds and ceiling systems to the world's tallest building, the Burj Khalifa tower in Dubai. Sonnenberg is the CEO and owns more than 80% of the firm's stock. His sons, Marko and David, also work for Hunter Douglas.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Hunter Douglas N.V.', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Mining and banking investor Zdenek Bakala has seen the value of his stakes in coal miner New World Resources and iron ore producer Ferrexpo fall this year, down 40% and 13% respectively. Instead he is focusing his energy on sports and politics. As the majority owner of the Omega Pharma Quickstep cycling team, he is revamping the world of professional cycling. Bakala was also active in the ultimately unsuccessful presidential campaign of Karel Schwarzenberg. Through his charity, NDB, Bakala funds study abroad for the Czech Republic's brightest as well as non-profit organizations such as The Aspen Institute in Prague. He is married to the former Miss Czechoslovakia Michaela Malacova, who runs beauty pageants in the Czech Republic.

name: Billionaires
bio: Jean-Michel, 45, along with siblings Marie, 32, and Emmanuel, 42, inherited French dairy giant Lactalis, producers of popular Président brie among hundreds of other cheese, milk and yogurt brands. Between them, they own 100% of the company their grandfather founded in the 1930s. Lactalis' once fairly opaque financials were brought to light when the Besnier family, through another holding company, acquired a majority stake in publicly traded Italian milk manufacturer Parmalat in 2011, rescuing it from bankruptcy after the infamous 2003 collapse that landed its founder in jail.

name: Billionaires
bio: Marie, 32, along with siblings Emmanuel, 42, and Jean-Michel, 45, inherited French dairy giant Lactalis, producers of popular Président brie among hundreds of other cheese, milk and yogurt brands. Between them, they own 100% of the company their grandfather founded in the 1930s. Lactalis' once fairly opaque financials were brought to light when the Besnier family, through another holding company, acquired a majority stake in publicly traded Italian milk manufacturer Parmalat in 2011, rescuing it from bankruptcy after the infamous 2003 collapse that landed its founder in jail.

name: Billionaires
bio: Manoj Bhargava's 5-Hour Energy weathered some negative publicity this past year. In 2012 the Indian-born mogul's ubiquitous energy shots were named by the Food & Drug Administration as having possibly contributed to 13 deaths in four years. Parent company Living Essentials responded that it was "unaware of any deaths proven to be caused by the consumption of 5-Hour Energy." Bhargava joined the Forbes Billionaires list last year, having taken a highly unusual career path. A math whiz, he moved to Philadelphia with his family as a teen, and soon headed to Princeton U,. but dropped out after freshman year. He went back to India, where he lived as a monk in the mountains for 12 years. After returning to the U.S., he forged a successful career in plastics then stumbled upon a formula for energy shots at a health trade fair. His two-ounce caffeine and vitamin elixir, 5-Hour Energy, promises to keep users alert without crashing, and claims a 90%-plus market share in the energy shot sector. The brand gets its own boost from its distinctive red bottles and deliberately corny, low-cost TV ads. Bhargava owns 35% of 5-Hour's parent company; he pledged another 45% to charitable causes in poverty-stricken rural India.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chang Yung-fa is the chairman and founder of Evergreen Marine, one of the world's largest  shipping companies with more than 160 container vessels. Chang and his family also control EVA Airways and Evergreen International Storage and Transport. Evergreen's hotel chain has 1,923 rooms in Taipei, Paris, Bangkok and other cities.   Born in 1927, Chang entered the shipping business at age 14 when he worked in Miname Nippon Steamship's office in the city of Keelung in northern Taiwan while he attended night classes in vocational school in Taipei. Father died in 1944 after U.S. allies sank a Japanese ship he was on.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ciputra founded Ciputra Group 30 years ago, and turned the group into one of the country's leading property developer, with several luxury property projects, hotels, malls, and offices under its belt. Shares of the property arm, Ciputra Development, have been on an uptrend in recent months, registering a one-year gain of about 45%. The trained architect also holds grand aspirations of offering affordable housing projects in Jakarta. Ciputra now is concerned with transforming Indonesia's 6 million overseas migrant workers into entrepreneurs. Through Ciputra Entrepreneurship Foundation, he offers classes for picking up the English language, and computer skills, to migrant workers who have moved to places such as Hong Kong or Singapore to work as domestic helpers. The foundation continues offering classes to these workers when they return home, in hopes that they will be equipped to start their own business.

name: Billionaires
bio: Scott Cook's giant software company, Intuit, makes the well-known programs Quicken and TurboTax.  Cook previously worked at Proctor & Gamble and started Intuit in 1983. He came up with the idea for Quicken in response to his wife's complaints about balancing a checkbook. In the early years the company almost went under twice. He took the company public in 1993 and stepped down as CEO in 1994. He's still a board member and the largest single investor. Intuit was the first company in the software industry to do testing with consumers before launching a product. It developed Fasal, a text messaging service that helps farmers in India get real time agricultural prices and information. It also owns Mint.com, an online budget-tracking software outfit. Cook originally wanted to be an economist but found it boring. While at USC, he turned the university's bankrupt ski club into the largest campus organization in just one year. He gave $14 million to his alma mater, University of Wisconsin-Madison Business School, where he supports the Center for Brand & Product Management. He has also donated $5.3 million to the Myelin Repair Foundation and $2.1 million to the Environmental Defense Fund.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ashwin Dani started working in Asian Paints, cofounded by his father, in 1968. He's now vice chairman of the $1.8 billion (sales) company, Asia's third largest paints manufacturer with  23 factories in 17 countries. Its stock soared 50% in the past year as it reported higher sales and net profits, despite a construction slowdown and rising raw material costs. His son Jalaj overseas international operations. His wife Ina, who sits on board, is a yoga teacher. Asian Paints was named to Forbes list of Fab 50 companies for two years in a row.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mortgage magnate William Erbey leaped into the billionaire ranks in 2012 as his public stocks soared. Erbey is the chairman of Ocwen Financial Corporation, a firm which describes itself as "the industry leader in servicing high-risk loans" and boasts "helping homeowners is what we do!" In 2010 Ocwen launched its Shared Appreciation Modification model, a creative solution for servicing underwater loans. The company keeps homeowners happy by restructuring mortgages so that they have 5% equity in their properties and pay a lower rate. The catch: when the home is eventually sold, the borrower must share 25% of any profits with the investor. A resident of the US Virgin Islands, Erbey is also the chairman of Altisource Porfolio Solutions. He graduated from Allegheny College in 1971 and earned an MBA from Harvard in 1973.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fang Wei chairs Beijing's Fangda International Industrial Investment, best known for buying turnaround situations, especially those in the steel industry. Many of those businesses struggled during China's slowdown last year, however, and Fang's wealth is little changed as a result. During the first nine months of 2012, net profit at Fangda Carbon New Material dropped 28% to $61 million; Fangda Special Steel's net income fell 30% to $51 million, and Fangda Jinhua Chemical Technology's profits plunged 96% to $0.7 million. Looking to new business horizons, Fangda Group last year agreed to buy 10% of Shenzhen-listed Northeast Pharmaceutical Group from its parent company for $44 million. In June 2012, the Fangda Group donated $1.9 million to Renmin University in Beijing, part of $21 million in donations to charity over the years by Fang's holding company.

name: Billionaires
bio: Victor Gradin joined Odebrecht, Brazil's largest construction company, as chief financial officer in 1974. Through a series of purchases he built up a large stake in the company, which has more than 150,000 employees and revenues of $35 billion. Victor's sons, Bernado and Miguel, also worked as Odebrecth executives. Bernardo was president of Braskem, the petrochemical division of the group and Miguel led the Oil & Gas division. Together the Gradin family owns 20.6% of the private conglomerate, second only to the Odebrecht family. In 2010 the Odebrechts exercised an option to buy out all minority investors, most of whom had small stakes of around 1% and who agreed to sell.The Gradin family members refused to hand over the shares, and the case is now being decided in Brazil's courts. Victor's parents were born in Spain. He has no siblings and is fond of literature.

name: Billionaires
bio: Vladimir Gridin, together with his sons, is the largest shareholder in Siberian Business Unit, also known as SDS-Holding, a coal mining, railway transportation, chemicals and machine building concern. The company owns radio stations, too, and in 2011 it bought European Media Group, one of Russia's biggest radio networks, from France's Lagardere for $162 million. In the 1980s Gridin oversaw railway facilities in the Novokuznetz area and forged ties with railway head Aman Tuleev, who is now governor of the Kemerovo region, where SDS-Holding is based. In 2007 he was appointed deputy to the State Duma for Vladimir Putin's party; in 2011 he won a second term as deputy chairman of its transport committee.

name: Billionaires
bio: The son of Lebanese immigrants, Alfredo Harp Helu made his fortune in 2001, when Citigroup bought Mexican bank Banamex. The cousin of Mexico's richest man, Carlos Slim Helu, Harp was kidnapped in 1994 for 106 days and released after a payment of $30 million. Today he is a renowned philanthropist, supporting sports, culture, education and social assistance. He is a baseball fan and owner of the Mexico City Diablos Rojos (Red Devils) team.

name: Billionaires
bio: London resident Xiu Li Hawken is the main shareholder of Chinese real estate investor Renhe Commercial Holdings, which as of mid-2012 operated 22 (mostly underground) malls in 15 cities across the country including up-and-coming  cities such as Yueyang in Hunan Province and Wuxi in Jiangsu Province. Her wealth is down on a decline in Renhe's Hong Kong-listed shares amid concerns about the company's future prospects. Hawken is the sister of the Renhe's chairman and CEO Dai Yongge, whose wife Zhang Xingmei is also on the company's board.  She is married to Tony Hawken, a teacher, and they have a modest home in South Norwood, near Croydon, in the U.K. She also invests in China Shouguang Agricultural, an agricultural market, with Blackstone. Hawken holds a bachelor's degree in Chinese literature from Heilongjiang University.

name: Billionaires
bio: Boston Red Sox owner John Henry saw his baseball team miss the playoffs for the third straight season in 2012, so he blew it up, trading a bunch of underperforming stars and firing the manager. He bought the Red Sox in 2002 after building his fortune through his hedge fund J.W. Henry & Company. He broke the "Curse of the Bambino" by winning World Series championships in 2004 and 2007. His Fenway Sports Group now owns the Liverpool F.C. soccer team, 80% of the New England Sports Network (NESN), and 50% of Roush Fenway Racing. In his free time Henry enjoys playing iRacing, the online racing simulator game he owns. In 2009 he married his second wife on his private yacht (now for sale) and held the reception at Fenway Park in Boston.

name: Billionaires
bio: Hong Ra-Hee is the director of Leeum Samsung Museum and the wife of billionaire Samsung Group Chairman Lee Kun-Hee. Her father Hong Jin-ki was the former chairman of South Korean newspaper JoongAng Ilbo, and her brother Hong Suk-hyeon currently heads the paper, which is one of Korea's largest. Hong Ra-Hee is not involved in Samsung's management but is active in running the museum and in philanthropic work. She is known for being a prolific art buyer.

name: Billionaires
bio: Indianapolis Colts owner Jim Irsay was excited in 2012 as touted rookie Andrew Luck lived up to the hype and led the Colts to the playoffs. Irsay is by far the most active NFL owner on Twitter, and he has lots to talk about. His Colts shed franchise stalwart Peyton Manning (along with coaches and front office staff) to start fresh with Luck, a star quarterback at Stanford. The Colts have one of the best stadium deals in the NFL, and the team's valuation increased in 2012 for the fourth straight year. Irsay's father Robert (d. 1997) bought the then-Baltimore Colts in 1972 for $15 million. As a music fan and collector, he has guitars formerly owned by Jerry Garcia, George Harrison and Elvis Presley. He prefers to keep his charitable donations private and frequently gives to the victims of natural disasters.
title: CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: Lawyer Joe Jamail Jr. built his fortune on personal injury cases, landing $345 million in contingency fees after representing Pennzoil against Texaco in 1987. In 1986 he and his late wife, Lee, established the Lee and Joseph D. Jamail Foundation, which has given more than $200 million to education, medical research and the performing arts. That includes $30 million to the University of Texas, his alma mater, which has used the funds to award scholarships to 4,500 students. The university also named a swim center after the couple. The campus has two statues of Jamail.

name: Billionaires
bio: Jiang Rensheng, chairman of Chongqing Zhifei Biological Products, has enjoyed an increase in wealth owing to good prospects for the company's vaccine business.  The company in September signed a distribution pact with Merck & Co. for a vaccine for cervical cancer. The company's sales rose 9% to $80 million in the first nine months of 2012; net profit grew 11% to $23 million. Jiang was once a health official in Guanxi Province. Chongqing Zhifei Biological Products listed its shares at the Shenzhen Stock Exchange in 2010.

name: Billionaires
bio: Hanni Toosbuy Kasprzak is owner and chairman of $1.3 billion (sales) Danish shoe manufacturer, Ecco, founded by her late father in 1963. The brand, which celebrates its 50th anniversary this year, can be found in more than 1,000 stores in more than 90 countries. Toosbuy joined the family business straight out of school and worked in different departments to learn the ropes; she was a quality controller in India for a time. After a stint in Germany, she returned to Denmark in 1997 and took over as chairman.  Toosbuy is also vice chairman of Sydbank, the fourth largest bank in Denmark. Her husband, Dieter Kasprzak, a chief designer at several leading shoe factories before joining Ecco, was appointed its president upon his father-in-law's 2004 death.
