Her son André is a professional golfer and her daughter Anna is a dressage rider, who recently represented Denmark at the Olympics in London.

name: Billionaires
bio: Vinod Khosla continues to advocate for greener energy sources and has shown his willingness to bet on them. His Khosla Ventures was a big backer of biofuel producers Kior and Gevo, both of which went public in 2011. Khosla made his early money as a co-founder of Sun Microsystems and later as a venture capitalist with Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers. Khosla Ventures-funded server builder SeaMicro was acquired by AMD for $334 million in February 2012. His firm also had a stake in social enterprise software company Yammer, which was purchased by Microsoft in July 2012 for $1.2 billion. He currently sits on the board of Jack Dorsey's mobile payment company, Square. The Indian-born engineer knew he wanted to be a tech entrepreneur from an early age. At 20, he tried and failed to start a soy milk company for people in India who lacked refrigerators. Khosla continues to be involved in numerous confrontations involving public access to Martin's Beach, near San Francisco. He reportedly purchased beachfront property in 2008 and later closed off entrances that members of the public had used for decades to access the coast. He signed Bill Gates' and Warren Buffett's Giving Pledge in 2011.
title: Investor
investments: [{'name': 'Contrail Systems', 'type': 'investment', 'imageExists': False}, {'name': 'Rearden Commerce', 'type': 'investment', 'imageExists': False}, {'name': 'Xsigo Systems, Inc.', 'type': 'investment', 'imageExists': False}]

name: Billionaires
bio: Andrei Kosogov is board chairman of Altimo, the telecom subsidiary of the Alfa Group investment company. He oversaw the cell network operator Vimpelcom before it merged in 2011 with Egyptian billionaire Naguib Sawiris's telecom holdings to form Wind Telecom, becoming the sixth largest telecom company in the world. Last year Alfa Group, together with AAR partners Viktor Vekselberg and Leonard Blavatnik, agreed to sell a 50% stake in TNK-BP to the state-owned Rosneft oil company for $28 billion; that deal will bring Kosogov $750 million in cash. Born in Estonia when it was part of the Soviet Union, he graduated from the Moscow Power Engineering Institute and then served as commercial director at a small firm founded with the institute's help. In 1992 he was hired by Alfa Group to oversee the establishment of a privatization investment fund. Months later he became chief executive of Alfa Capital, the group's fund management company. After expanding Alfa Capital, Kosogov became responsible for all of the bank's investment units.

name: Billionaires
bio: Stephen Lansdown makes his debut on the Forbes Billionaires list as one of the majority stakeholders and co-founder of the the $48 billion (assets under management) U.K. financial services firm Hargreaves Lansdown. He and fellow billionaire Peter Hargreaves started the firm in 1981 out of a bedroom in Bristol. Lansdown's 20% of the firm is now worth approximately $1.3 billion as the company's stock price has shot up in the past year. Landsown is also the majority owner of soccer team Bristol City FC and has a stake in Bristol Rugby. He is from the island of Guernsey and is a citizen of the Channel Islands, which is a British Crown Dependency (and not part of the United Kingdom).

name: Billionaires
bio: The nephew of Samsung chairman Lee Kun-Hee and eldest grandson of Samsung's late founder Lee Byung-Chul, Lee Jay-Hyun inherited the CJ Group, which separated from Samsung in 1997. Founded in 1953 as Cheiljedang, the company began as a sugar mill, boosting sugar production after the Korean War. Now CJ is South Korea's biggest food processer, making products like refined sugar and monosodium glutamate. CJ Group has also moved into pharmaceuticals, home shopping and entertainment, and has been expanding in China, Vietnam and Southeast Asia.

name: Billionaires
bio: As the youngest daughter of late Samsung Group founder Lee Byung Chul, Lee Myung-Hee heads retail giant Shinsegae Group, which was owned by Samsung until the two separated in 1991. Shinsegae is the nation's second-largest retailer after Lotte Group. Her son, billionaire Chung Yong-Jin, resigned as Shinsegae's vice chairman in late Februrary 2013 following investigations by the labor ministry into charges that the group was illegally monitoring employees to prevent them from joining a union.

name: Billionaires
bio: Famed buyout specialist Tom Lee closed four deals in late 2012, including three in December. It took wealth management firm Edelman Financial private in a $260 million transaction. His private equity firm also made investments in Eating Recovery Center, the largest acute care center for patients with severe eating disorders; Paragon, a manufacturer of drill and line pipes for the oil and gas industry, and Captive Resources, said to be the nation's largest manager of captive insurance companies. He is still best known for his Snapple deal. His first firm Thomas H. Lee Partners led a deal to buy the beverage maker for $140 million in 1992 and flipped it two years later to Quaker Oats for $1.7 billion. Lee left that firm in 2006 but still has investments from those times in such companies as Nielsen and Dunkin Donuts. The son of an art dealer, he collects Andy Warhol, Francis Bacon and Mark Rothko, and is a trustee of the Museum of Modern Art in New York, the Whitney Museum of American Art and Lincoln Center.

name: Billionaires
bio: Diamond king Lev Leviev faced down former partner Arkady Gaydamak in a London court in 2012 over charges that he owed Gaydamak $1 billion in commissions and dividends connected with Angolan diamonds; Gaydamak also filed a complaint with Israeli police. Leviev won the case, and now Gaydamak has been ordered to pay Leviev's legal fees. In November, Leviev was named executive chairman of finance company AFI Development. He was born in Uzbekistan; his Lubavitcher Jewish family fled to Israel in 1971. He made his name undercutting the De Beers diamond cartel, striking his own deals with diamond-producing countries like Russia and Angola. He is president of the Federation of Jewish Communities in Russia.

name: Billionaires
bio: Lim Oon Kuin founded Hin Leong Trading, one of Singapore's largest independent oil traders at the age of 20 in 1963 with a single truck. Known as OK, he worked as an apprentice mechanic as a teenager. Has majority stake in Universal Terminal, Asia's largest oil logistics terminal whose higher valuation this year makes him a billionaire. Lim also owns a fleet of 100 tankers via shipping arm Ocean Tankers run by son Evan. To counter shipping glut last year, it formed a tanker pool consortium with Denmark's A.P. Moller-Maersk, Japan's Mitsui O.S.K Lines, Singapore's Samco Shipholding. His two daughters also work with him.

name: Billionaires
bio: Daniel Loeb,the founder and head of hedge fund firm Third Point, had a fabulous year in 2012. His flagship hedge fund beat the U.S. stock market, which most hedge funds failed to do, with a 21.2% net return. His smaller leveraged fund was one of the best-performing hedge funds in 2012. The New York investor has enjoyed big years before, but now he is managing $10 billion. He made money betting on Greek sovereign debt and on a couple of activist positions. Known for firing off harsh letters lambasting corporate executives and board members of companies he is targeting, in 2012 Loeb led a successful effort to dislodge Scott Thompson from the CEO position at Yahoo and replace him with Marissa Mayer. He also joined Yahoo's board of directors. The stock has been a winner for Loeb as has been his activist position in Murphy Oil. Loeb made news in early 2013 by taking a position in Herbalife, the nutritional supplements seller, shortly after another prominent hedge fund manager, William Ackman, called the company a pyramid scheme. He sold part of his stake within weeks. He serves as the chairman of the board of Success Academies Charter Schools in Brooklyn, helps lead Students First New York., and is a trustee of Prep for Prep. Beyond education, he is also a trustee of the US Olympic Foundation, Mt. Sinai Hospital, the Manhattan Institute and the LA MOCA.
title: Investor

name: Billionaires
bio: Robert Miller, the flamboyant cofounder of Duty Free Shoppers, still holds a large minority stake in the firm he started with Chuck Feeney in 1960 in Hong Kong. Miller  divides his time between Hong Kong, London, the U.S. -- where he was born -- and other spots. Last year he sold investment firm, Squadron Capital Advisors, which was part of his Search Investment Group. To some he is best known as father of the three famed "Miller sisters." Two married royalty (though one is divorced). The third, Pia Getty, married a grandson of Getty Oil founder and is a filmmaker who won awards last year for her latest work, Axis of Light.

name: Billionaires
bio: Zelimkhan Mutsoev's family controls the Regions Group, which owns dozens of shopping centers as well as an 8.1% stake in Uralkali, a major fertilizer producer. Mutsoev drove a dump truck on construction sites after he finished school, and in the late 1980s he founded a clothing manufacturer. In the 1990s he became a co-owner of Pervouralsk, a factory that produces pipes and tubes, and in 2004 he sold it to Andrey Komarov's ChTPZ group. He has been elected as a deputy in the Edinaya Rossiya party three times and took a seat in Russia's State Duma in 2012. In February 2013 he and billionaire Gavril Yushvaev  bought billionaire Mikhail Prokhorov's 38% stake in the gold producer Polyus Gold for $3.6 billion.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ezra Nahmad, together with his brother David, is an influential megadealer of modern and impressionist art by the most well-known names, from Monet and Matisse to Renoir and Rothko. The brothers own a vast inventory of between 4,000 and 4,500 works, stored in a duty-free warehouse next to the airport in Geneva, Switzerland. Among those holdings: 300 Picassos, worth some $900 million. The brothers buy and sell most of their works at auction. The collection is worth some $3 billion and the brothers, who are listed separately for the first time, hold the assets jointly, split 50/50.
title: Investor

name: Billionaires
bio: Jonathan Nelson made his fortune buying media and telecom companies and selling them for a profit. The son of a Providence, Rhode Island orthodontist, he studied economics at Brown University and worked in China for chemical company Wellman. In 1989 he founded Providence Equity Partners, which now manages $27 billion. In October 2012 the company opened an office in Beijing; Nelson has said he plans to invest at least 25% of the firm's assets in emerging markets. Also in October Providence sold its 10% stake in online video site Hulu, reportedly for $300 million. Nelson sits on the board of the Newport Festivals Foundation, which puts on the Newport jazz and folk music festivals. He is also a Brown trustee and donated $20 million to fund a new fitness center and back professorships. He supported Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney. In September 2012 he signed the Giving Pledge, promising to donate at least half his wealth to charity. He is an avid sailor and skier.
title: Chief executive officer
employment: {'name': 'Providence Equity Partners', 'title': 'Chief executive officer', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Go Daddy founder Bob Parsons is the man behind some of the most memorable ? and controversial ? ads in Super Bowl history. This year's ad featuring Israeli model Bar Refaeli making out with a nerd was no exception, provoking disgust among many viewers, particularly turned off by the sound effects. Parsons is unapologetic, as befits someone who has made a fortune being daring. A Vietnam vet who received three medals during his tour including the Purple Heart, he graduated magna cum laude with an accounting degree and in 1984 started a software company in his basement, writing the computer programs himself. He sold that company, Parsons Technology, to Intuit for $64 million and used the proceeds to start web hosting provider Go Daddy.  He sold the majority of the company in 2011 to private equity investors KKR, Silver Lake and TCV in a deal that valued the firm at more than $2 billion. Parsons, who received an estimated $930 million in cash, remains the largest individual shareholder and is executive chairman of the firm. He and his wife Renee have used some of the proceeds to create the Parsons Foundation in 2012, which is primarily focused on helping children in greater Phoenix area and in Haiti. He has also made donations to his alma mater, University of Baltimore, and to the Semper Fi Fund, an organization that aids wounded veterans.

name: Billionaires
bio: Gregorio Perez Companc built energy conglomerate Perez Companc and sold it to Brazilian energy giant Petrobas for $1 billion in 2002. In December 2009 he stepped down from active involvement in the business, gifting his entire 75% stake in food giant Molinos Rio de la Plata, a diversified maker of pasta, flour and frozen vegetables, to his seven children. Gregorio Perez had bought 60% of Molinos Rio de la Plata from Bunge & Born in 1999 for $400 million. In the past 10 years he has been more focused on his health, family, philanthropy and passion for cars than on his diverse investments in energy, finance, construction, telecommunications, food and agriculture. At his wife's urging, he launched ice cream parlor chain Munchi's.  He established the Bioparque Temaiken, a nature and wildlife preserve outside of Buenos Aires. He had eight children with his wife Maria del Carmen Sundblad Beccar Varela. He founded the Pérez Companc foundation after Margarita, his eldest daughter, died in a car accident in the '80s.

name: Billionaires
bio: James Pritzker, a retired Army lieutenant colonel, founded the Pritzker Military Library in Chicago in 2003, and through his Tawani Foundation works to preserve American military history. He is CEO of private wealth management firm Tawani Enterprises in Chicago. James is one of 10 billionaire members of the extended Pritzker family, who sold a controlling stake in industrial conglomerate Marmon Holdings to Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway for $4.5 billion. James' grandfather, A.N. Pritzker (d. 1986), with his sons Jay (d. 1999), Robert (d. 2011) and Donald (D. 1972), created Marmon and hotel chain Hyatt.
title: CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: Phillip Ragon, known as Terry, founded Cambridge, Mass-based InterSystems in 1978 and built it into a $443 million (2012 revenues) company, selling databases and other software tools. Customers are mainly in health care, and include Epic Systems, Siemens and General Electric. Ragon remains the sole owner of the company, where his wife Susan is also a high level executive. He is new to the billionaires ranks this year. In 2009, following a trip to South Africa where Ragon witnessed the ravages of AIDS, the couple established the Ragon Institute in partnership with Mass General Hospital, Harvard and MIT, to pursue the development of an HIV vaccine.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of turmeric farmer, K. Anji Reddy' founded $1.9 billion (revenues) generic outfit Dr. Reddy's Laboratories, now run by his son and son-in-law. It formed a partnership in June with Merck Serono, a division of Germany's Merck, to develop cancer drugs. It already has a marketing alliance with GlaxoSmithKline and a joint venture with Fujifilm Corp. to develop and sell generic drugs in Japan. Recently Bristol Myers Squibb sued the company for an alleged patent infringement of a cancer drug. He and other family members transferred the bulk of their stake in the company to a family trust. For the first time, he skipped the company's annual shareholders' meeting last July sparking speculation about his retirement.

name: Billionaires
bio: Desmond Sacco joins the ranks of the world's billionaires for the first time this year, due to the rising share values of his resilient mining company, Assore Group, in the face of terrible violence and unrest within South Africa's mining indusry. Assore Group's shares have nearly doubled since January 2012, while other outfits, like billionaire Patrice Motsepe's African Rainbow Minerals, have struggled to keep turnover numbers above water. Sacco's father, Guido Sacco, first got into mining in 1928 when he established Gloucester Manganese Mines. Guido went on to acquire other mining interests and later formed Assore Group, which listed its shares on the Johannesburg Stock Exchange more than 60 years ago. Desmond, a geologist, joined the Assore Group in 1968, was appointed to the group's board in 1974 and, upon Guido's retirement in 1992, became chairman and managing director. In his younger years, he played cricket and hockey at the University of South Africa.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of mobile phone distributor Hikari Tsushi, Yasumitsu Shigeta, is benefitting from a doubling of the company's stock price after last year's share buyback and strong performance. Shigeta has been diversifing his product line and focusing on mobile phone contracts with large corporations to drive revenue and profit growth. In October, he acquired the remaining portion of advertiser e-machitown he did not already own. The comeback kid,Shigeta founded Hikari Tsushin at 23 and lost almost all his wealth, which peaked at $42 billion, in the dotcom crash.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of a trucking company owner, Brij Bhushan Singal controls Bhushan Steel which supplies steel to Indian auto makers and home appliance manufacturers. Expansion of its plant in eastern India that will take total annual capacity to 5.2 million tons has been delayed for various reasons including a spate of accidents at the site that have reportedly caused the deaths of 90 workers since 2005. Younger son Neeraj is vice chairman and managing director of listed flagship. Older son Sanjay controls his own privately-held outfit after settling decade-long family feud two years ago. He does yoga every day.

name: Billionaires
bio: Katsumi Tada cut ties with Daito Trust Construction, the Japanese property developer he founded, in June 2011. That's when he stepped down as chairman and sold his stake back to the company. The sale netted him $2 billion. These days Tada seems busy "down under." He owns the recently reopened Park Hyatt in Sydney, run by his daughter, which he bought for an estimated $200 million in 2007 and spent $70 million fixing up. In April, he begins construction on a 32-story tower in Brisbane, the first office tower in the city to be started on-spec in almost five years.

name: Billionaires
bio: With her sister-in-law Joan Tisch, Wilma Tisch controls the family fortune built by their late husbands, investors Preston and Laurence Tisch. The brothers started with a small New Jersey hotel in 1946 and acquired Loews Theatres in 1959. Today publicly traded Loews Corp. includes oil drilling (Diamond Offshore), natural gas pipelines (Boardwalk) and insurance (CNA). Joan's son Jonathan heads Loews Hotels. Wilma's son James is the CEO of Loews. Wilma's other son Andrew is co-chairman of the board with Jonathan. In keeping with the charitable legacies of Preston and Laurence, Wilma and her family have given millions to educational and charitable causes throughout New York City. At NYU, the family helped create the Tisch School of the Arts and the Tisch Hospital at Langone Medical Center. She has also given to the Tisch Children's Zoo in Central Park and to Gay Men's Health Crisis, the 92nd Street Y and the UJA-Federation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Albert von Thurn und Taxis first appeared in Forbes' billionaire rankings at age 8 but officially inherited his fortune in 2001 on his 18th birthday. In June 2008, he received an M.A. in economics and theology from the University of Edinburgh in Scotland. His assets include real estate, art and 36,000 hectares of woodland in Germany, one of the largest forest holdings in Europe. His plan to build one of the world's largest solar energy installations in Bavaria, southern Germany, was put on hold after government subsidies were cancelled. He lives in the family castle, Schloss Emmeram. The eligible bachelor is also a race car driver and tours with a German auto-racing league.

name: Billionaires
bio: Vietnam's first billionaire is 44-year old Pham Nhat Vuong, the founder of Vingroup, a conglomerate with interests in real estate, hotels and healthcare. He studied in Moscow, then moved to Ukraine where he started Technocom, a maker of instant noodles. Moved back to Vietnam in 2001 to plunge into real estate, eventually selling his foods company  in 2009 to Nestle. Merged his Vincom and Vinpearl Land last year to create VinGroup, one of the most valuable companies on the Vietnam stock exchange.

name: Billionaires
bio: Jacky Xu leads retailer Trendy International Group, one of the most successful home-grown Chinese businesses to cash in on the country's spending binge on apparel in recent years. The best-known brands among Xu's 2,000 shops include Ochirly and Five Plus. The company will team up with 10 Corso Como this year to open the Italian fashion retailer's first China store in Shanghai. Trendy's investors include LVMH's L Capital.

name: Billionaires
bio: After resigning from Yahoo's board in January 2012,co-founder Jerry Yang has completely removed himself from Silicon Valley business dealings, stepping down from the board of Cisco in November. That move was more ceremonious than his exit from Yahoo, which capped a gradual fall from grace that began with his 2009 replacement as CEO by Carol Bartz. Yahoo is now led by former Googler Marissa Mayer, who praised the Yahoo cofounder for making a $1 billion investment in Chinese e-Commerce platform Alibaba in 2005. In September, Yahoo closed a deal to sell back half of its 40% stake in the company for more than $7 billion. Yang, a trustee at Stanford, and his wife pledged $75 million to the university in 2007 largely to build the Jerry Yang and Akiko Yamazaki Environment and Energy Building, affectionately known on campus as Y2E2. A former Chinese calligraphy student, he has a collection of 250 works of ancient Chinese calligraphers from the Ming and Qing eras.

name: Billionaires
bio: Middle East retail magnate M.A. Yusuff Ali heads the Abu Dhabi-headquartered LuLu Group whose flagship is the $4.25 billion(sales) LuLu retail chain, recently ranked by Deloitte as one of the ten fastest growing retailers in the world. LuLu runs a string of hypermarkets, supermarkets and grocery stores in the Middle East, Africa and will soon launch its first mall in India.  Ali, born and educated in India, migrated to Abu Dhabi in the 1970s to join the family's small trading business. He started importing frozen foods before launching LuLu during the Gulf War, it went on to make its name as a provider of value-for-money goods. His group's other interests include healthcare, software and infrastructure with operations in 21 countries. Ali was an early backer of Cochin airport in his native Kerala state, India's first airport built through a public-private partnership. He also owns two Marriott hotels and a Grand Hyatt in the same city and was recently in the news for his bid to buy a minority stake in Catholic Syrian Bank.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of a mining engineer, Kostyantin Zhevago took over Poltava Iron Ore, the largest exporter of pellets in CIS, at the age of twenty two, and in 2007 he took his mining company Ferrexpo public. The company's stock price is down 10% over the past year as iron ore prices decline. Zhevago's Stakhanov Carriage Building, one of the largest producers of freight wagons in Ukraine, also significantly fell in value, because of a shortage of carriage casting. To get around the shortfall, Zhevago acquired the largest Czech steel-casting plant, CKD Kutna Hora, last year. An avid soccer fan, Zhevago owns FC Vorska football.

name: Billionaires
bio: Zhu Yicai is the chairman of China Yurun Group of Nanjing. He returns to the Forbes Billionaires List this year though his wealth has declined from 2012 because of a 50% drop in the shares of meat processor China Yurun Food, where he departed as chairman last July amid skepticism about the firm's accounting practices. (The firm denied any problems.)  Zhu's other businesses have done better. Shares in his 70%-owned retailer Nanjing Central Emporium have gained on improved profits. In February, the company announced plans to invest nearly $350 million in two new malls. DreamWorks Animation in January of this year forged a strategic cooperation agreement with Zhu's Yurun Holding Group to create dragon-themed arena shows in the country. DreamWorks Animation CEO Jeffrey Katzenberg was on hand for the announcement in Nanjing. Zhu founded the China Yurun Group in 1993.

name: Billionaires
bio: Belmiro de Azevedo chairs Portuguese conglomerate Sonae, which owns Modelo Continente hypermarkets and has partnerships in mobile and fixed telecom services (Sonaecom) and shopping centers. It has operations or investments in 65 countries, including Zippy children's clothing stores in Saudi Arabia, Turkey and Kazakhstan. De Azevedo and his immediate family own just under 53% of Sonae, shares of which have rebounded by more than 50% due to better than expected earnings amid ongoing economic weakness in Portugal. As a result, his net worth is $500 million higher than a year ago. The son of a carpenter, he founded Sonae SGPS in 1959 as a maker of decorative laminates. His son Paulo is the chief executive officer.

name: Billionaires
bio: Huang Yi's wealth had declined from a year ago as shares of the Hong Kong-listed auto distributorship he chairs, Zhongsheng, have been hit by worries about profit margins and inventory levels. Zhongsheng's earnings shrank 34% in the first half of 2012 to $66 million even though it sold 50% more vehicles than a year earlier. Zhongsheng opened its first Toyota and Nissan dealership in 1998 and now distributes Porsche, Lamborghini, Lexus and Toyota brands from 140 dealerships across China. Huang holds a bachelor's degree in economics from Xiamen University. His main partner, Li Guoqiang, was also a member of the 2012 Forbes China Rich List.

name: Billionaires
bio: Lin Li is the chairman of the Shenzhen Liye Group, which he founded in 1995 after working as a banker earlier in his career. After a successful investment in Ping An Insurance, Li has diversified into other financial services investments, including Chinalion Securities, as well as battery manufacturing, real estate, pharmaceuticals and mining. Liye raised 1 billion yuan, or $161 million, in a bond sale last December to fund battery and biological product investments.

name: Billionaires
bio: Property magnate Vikas Oberoi's Bombay Stock Exchange-listed Oberoi Realty, which he listed in 2010, has built 34 projects covering 5 million square feet in suburban Mumbai, and has very little debt. An upcoming midtown project will have a luxury hotel for which he's reportedly negotiating with Ritz Carlton and St Regis after discussions with Mandarin Oriental unravelled. He's also planning to enter the Delhi market, in bid to expand outside his home base. His sister Bindu sits on the company's board. Oberoi flies his own plane.

name: Billionaires
bio: Though Best Buy founder Richard Shulze announced in 2012 that he would try to take the struggling consumer electronics retailer private, he didn't make a bid by the late February 2013 deadline. Reportedly, he raised the needed financing, but the Best Buy board rejected offers that likely included additional shares with special privileges like increased voting power. The company has fared better in 2013 thanks to new CEO Hubert Joly's plan to slash jobs and expenses. Schulze was forced out as chairman and resigned from Best Buy's board in 2012 after a scandal involving his hand-picked CEO, Brian Dunn, and a 29-year-old female employee. The Minnesotan started the company in 1966 as the "Sound of Music Store" in St. Paul. He remains its biggest individual shareholder. His net worth dropped by $500 million in the past year as Best Buy's stock tanked. He first made an offer to take the company private in May 2012, offering $24 to $26 per share, a buyout that valued the company at $8 billion, a 36% premium over its then-market cap. He supports health-related causes including, in 2009 and 2010 alone, $11 million to support cancer treatment at the Mayo Clinic and $13 million for Type 1 Diabetes research at the Minnesota Medical Foundation.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Wei Shaojun debuts on Forbes' Billionaires List thanks to the success of his real estate development company Longjitaihe, of Hebei Province. Longjitaihe's projects include Baigou New City, a commercial real estate center that covers more 740 acres in Hebei, and Zhuozhou Bamboo Culture Villas, south of Beijing. This year it has announced plans to develop 2,700 acres of property in Tangshan, Tianjin and Langfang. The Tianjin project alone will be a $887 million investment. Longjitaihe employs more than 20,000 people. Wei is a member of China's National Party Congress.

name: Billionaires
bio: Xiong Xuqiang is the chairman of real estate developer Ningbo Yinyi Group. The value of his shares is up slightly in recent months as expectations have risen for the Shenzhen-listed company in 2013. Certainly, the first three quarters last year were rough: Yinyi's net profit declined by 37% to $52 million, on sales that plunged by 57% from a year earlier to $234 million. In 2010 Xiong injected his real estate business into listed firm Gansu Languang Science and Technology in 2011, and changed the company's name to Yinyi Real Estate Group. Xiong also holds mining investments in Mexico, Indonesia and the Philippine. The Ningbo native graduated from Zhejiang University.

name: Billionaires
bio: A returnee to the Billionaires list after six yearsCKCK, Farkhad Akhmedov surfaced recently in Russian news when he sold his 49% of Nortgas, an oil and gas company in Siberia, to Novatek, a Gazprom rival. It was a parting shot to a long-running feud with the natural gas giant. It all started in 1993 when Akhmedov?a native of Azerbaijan who first traded Russian sables in London, then started a company that sold equipment to Russian gas producers?became a minority shareholder of Nortgas, which was controlled by Gazprom. Steadily buying up shares, he managed to dilute Gazprom's stake to a mere 0.5%, claiming the state-owned company invested nothing in Nortgas. Gazprom took legal action, and Akhmedov was forced to restore the shares. Today, he still owns AzNar Natural Products, a juice maker in Azerbaijan.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mohamed Al Fayed, owner of the famed Hotel Ritz in Paris, closed it in August 2012 to start construction on what was billed as the biggest redo since it was built in 1898. The much-needed renovation is expected to last a little more than two years and cost $180 million. In 2010 the London-based Egyptian sold Harrods to Qatar Holding for a reported $2.4 billion. He's since shifted his attention to online retail, buying U.K.-based discount fashion website Cocosa in 2011. Also in 2011, he bought a controlling stake in Princess Kate Middleton's favorite designer brand, Issa, for his daughter Camilla. He's the owner of the Fulham football club, a castle in Scotland, and he has a ground lease on 75 Rockefeller Plaza in New York.

name: Billionaires
bio: Saif Al Ghurair is the former chairman of Al Ghurair Group. His brother Abdulla is also a billionaire. They come from an old Dubai merchant family with interests in banking, malls and manufacturing. Six of Saif's sons hold positions within the group; Abdulrahman is chairman and Majid is chief executive. Saif is a major shareholder in Mashreq, a leading Emirati bank run by his nephew, Abdul Aziz Al Ghurair. In November 2011 Saif sold a stake in his steel company to Nippon Steel.

name: Billionaires
bio: Roman Avdeev is the owner of Credit Bank of Moscow. In 2012 the World Bank's International Finance Corporation and the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development bought 15% of the bank for $190 million. It weathered the global financial crisis so successfully that in the last four years its assets more than quadrupled, to $9 billion. Avdeev began his career in the late 1980s producing decoders. Then in the 1990s he bought a bank. He also owns agricultural land and commercial and residential real estate. He has 23 children, 19 of them adopted, and is a yoga aficionado.

name: Billionaires
bio: Elisabeth Badinter is the daughter of Marcel Bleustein-Blanchet, who founded $7.9 billion (sales) French communications firm Publicis in 1926. Badinter's wealth comes from an inherited stake in the company; she owns 19 million shares. Her fortune got a boost of $300 million this year along with a rise in Publicis shares. Badinter has been chair of the board since 1996. A professor at the Ecole Polytechnique in Paris and a noted feminist writer, philosopher, intellectual, and mother of three, Badinter is the author of nearly two dozen books, including the European bestseller, "The Conflict: How Modern Motherhood Undermines the Status of Women," which has caused a stir among readers around the world.

name: Billionaires
bio: Oleg Boyko, armed with a degree in economics, opened Moscow's first stores with credit card readers in the 1990s. His diversified company later imported fruit, traded food and electronics and managed banks. During the 1995 banking crisis most of the group's assets were restructured and sold. He invested in the metallurgy and gambling business, then went into real estate and retail. In 2012 he sold his controlling stake in the Rive Gauche chain, one of the biggest perfume and cosmetics sellers in Russia. His newest investment is in a company called 4finance, which offers micro loans in Eastern Europe and Scandinavia.

name: Billionaires
bio: The bulk of Julio Bozano's fortune comes from the sale in 2000 of Banco Bozano & Simonsen to Spain's Banco Santander. He kept out of the limelight until the beginning of 2013, when Group Bozzano announced it bought 30% of Mercatto Investimentos, one of the 15 largest independent asset management firms in Brazil. Bozano also owns stakes in Brazilian jetmaker Embraer, one of the world's largest aircraft manufacturers, and Azul Linhas Aéreas, a domestic low-cost airline launched by JetBlue founder David Neeleman. A thoroughbred horse owner, Bozano has more than 300 mares at farms around the world. He is also an art collector and owns more than 100 paintings by artists including Picasso and contemporary Brazilian painter Beatriz Milhares. The Brazilian press referred to Bozano's 1996 split with his wife as "the most expensive divorce in Brazil ever." It cost him more than $175 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: John Brown became chairman emeritus of Stryker Corp. in January 2010, after a 32-year career as president and chief executive of the medical equipment maker. He joined Stryker as chief executive after the founder's son, Lee, died in a plane crash in 1976. Brown transformed the company from a $17 million hospital bed maker into one of the world's leading medical technology companies with $8.7 billion in 2012 revenues. The company makes joint replacements, software, surgical cameras. Shares are up almost 20 percent on news of an acquisition in China and other growth prospects. In 2011, he and his wife, Rosemary, pledged $10 million to Auburn University's College of Veterinary Medicine in memory of a college friend and longtime faculty member.

name: Billionaires
bio: Len Buckeridge spent much of 2012 fighting legal battles against government agencies while trying to expand his Buckeridge Group building-materials empire. The government has been blocking his plan to build a private port and to expand his brickworks facility, and has also interfered with his plans to supply gypsum to his plasterboard factory. Trained as an architect, he first built high-rise apartment blocks in Perth, his hometown, and won awards for low-cost housing designs. He became a home builder on an industrial scale, supplying most building products from his own factories. He opposes organized labor and says he prefers private ownership to public investment.

name: Billionaires
bio: Italian-born Paolo Bulgari and his brother Nicola are the great-great-grandsons of Greek silversmith Konstantinos Voulgaris, who started the family jewelry business more than 150 years ago. Today Hollywood beauties flaunt Bulgari's bold, hand-crafted gems on red carpets. The duo sold the company to French luxury conglomerate LVMH in an all-share deal in 2011. In 2012, as LVMH's stock rose, the Bulgaris sold a tiny sliver of their stake, reportedly to take care of taxes and other expenses.The brothers now own just over 2.4% of LVMH between them, enough to land them each a spot on the list for the first time.

name: Billionaires
bio: AOL founder Steve Case's investment company, Revolution, sold its stake in Zipcar for roughly $95 million in January. Revolution also has investments in LivingSocial, a competitor to Groupon; Echo360, a software maker that records college classroom lectures in a digital format for students to watch on their computers and mobile devices; and FedBid, which provides online auctions for sales to government. Case has high hopes for 2013 as a year of regional tech booms beyond Silicon Valley and Boston: "A confluence of developments in public policy, technological innovation, and economic trends have altered the playing field at the regional level in the United States to enable businesses to start, scale, and succeed," he said in January. In 1985 he helped found Quantum Computer Services.; he became CEO in 1991 and changed its name to America Online. AOL purchased Time Warner in 2001 in a $164 billion acquisition that was later deemed one of the most unwise mergers in history. Case lives in Hawaii and owns 40,000-acre Grove Farm on the island of Kaua'i . He attended the prestigious Punahou School, where Barack Obama also went to high school; in 2011 the president appointed him to lead the Startup America Partnership, a nonprofit aimed at spurring the growth of new companies. Case also chairs Accelerate Brain Cancer Cure (ABC2), a nonprofit he founded with his late brother, Dan. His Case Foundation is devoted to employing the Internet to make philanthropy more effective and efficient.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former rice trader Vanich Chaiyawan debuts on list thanks to the rising value of Thai Life, nation's second-biggest life insurer in which he owns 75% stake with family. The privately-held company recently denied a report of a deal to sell a 20% stake to a strategic investor for $500 million. With a 15% market share, it logged a 57% rise in first-year premiums during the first half of 2012. Son Chai is president.  Chaiyawan also owns a 1% stake in Thai Beverage, the Singapore-listed brewer and distiller founded by fellow billionaire Charoen Sirivadhanabhakdi.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chen Tianqiao co-founded Shanda Interactive, one of China's largest online gaming and entertainment companies. Stating his ambition of focusing on long-term strategy, he took the company private and delisted from the Nasdaq a year ago. He has since sold off some of his businesses. Zhejiang Daily of China agreed to pay $492 million for Hangzhou Bianfeng Network Technology, a casual game company, and $49 million for Shanghai Haofang, a developer of online game platforms. Shanda Interactive still has two affiliated companies trading in the U.S.:  Shanda Games and Ku6 Media.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chen Yung-Tai's Aurora Group started out almost 50 years ago in Taiwan selling office clocks, but expanded into office equipment and furniture. Chen went on to duplicate much of Aurora's success in the bigger mainland market. Aurora is also known for its real estate, with a prominent tower along Taipei's prestigious Xinyi Road and another in the heart of Shanghai's Lujiazui financial district. The company in 2012 opened a museum in Shanghai designed by Japanese architect Tadao Ando.

name: Billionaires
bio: The hottest young money manager on the planet, Chase Coleman cooled off a touch in 2012, but his Tiger Global hedge fund, which he co-manages with Feroz Dewan, still beat the U.S. stock market and most other hedge funds out there. Coleman extended his impressive winning streak, finishing a third straight year with a net return in excess of 20%. Among his savvy moves: creating venture capital vehicles, with the help of Lee Fixel and Scott Shleifer, to invest in fast-growing private tech companies like Facebook while they were still privately held. His Tiger Global Management smartly sold a big chunk of its stake in Facebook in the IPO. A "Tiger Cub" who trained at Julian Robertson's famed hedge fund shop, Tiger Management, Coleman has for six years served as co-chair of the Tiger Foundation, which Robertson started to battle poverty in New York City. Coleman is also co-chair of the investment committee for the Hospital for Special Surgery in New York.
title: Investor
employment: {'name': 'Tiger Global Management', 'title': 'Founder & CEO', 'totalEarningEst': True, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Economics PhD Leszek Czarnecki made his first fortune creating Poland's largest leasing company, listing it on the London Stock Exchange in 2000 before selling out to French bank Credit Agricole for $280 million a year later. Since then he's built an Eastern European banking empire with outposts in  Ukraine, Russia, Belarus in addition to Poland.  He's the majority shareholder of financial group Getin Holding and controls Poland's Getin Noble Bank, which merged with his Get Bank in June. He is also starting a new investment fund, Open Finance TFI, to invest in equity, bond, money market and mixed funds. A cave diver since his 20s, he beat a world record in 2009, swimming 10.5 miles in underground corridors over the course of 10 hours.

name: Billionaires
bio: Despite a difficult business environment in Venezuela, Juan Carlos Escotet founded and presides over growing banking empire Banesco, which now has arms in Panama, the Dominican Republic, Puerto Rico, Colombia, and the United States. Escotet began working as a messenger for Banco Union when he was 17 and studying economics at university. In 1986 he founded Casa de Bolsa Escotet Valores, a money management firm. He added banking services in 1991, and over the years expanded to offer insurance. In 2001 he merged his bank with Union, where he'd started his financial career. In December 2012, Banesco paid $66 million for a 70% stake in Banco Etcheverria, a 300-year-old Spanish bank. Escotet enjoys running and aquatic sports. He has four grown sons, who all work with their father at Banesco.

name: Billionaires
bio: Via his MNG Holding, Mehmet Nazif Gunal has built assets in construction, tourism, energy, finance, media, cargo, airline and plane maintenance sectors. Two of his ten hotels in Antalya are exact replicas of the Kremlin and Topkapi Palace in Russia. Media-shy, Gunal keeps a low profile.

name: Billionaires
bio: Douglas Hsu chairs the Far Eastern Group of Taipei, which controls more than 200 businesses involved in everything from cement to banking. Hsu's wealth has increased in the past year in part due to a rise in the share prices of Far EasTone Telecommunications, one of the island's main mobile service providers. Among his numerous institutional affiliations, Hsu is a director of the MasterCard Asia/Pacific Regional Advisory Board and trustee at the University of Notre Dame, from which he holds two degrees. He also has an honorary doctorate degree in management from National Chiao Tung University in Taiwan.

name: Billionaires
bio: Huang Shih Tsai has interests in real estate in Asia and North America through his privately held  property developer Greater China International Investment Group. Flagship properties include the 300-room Hilton Hotel in central Shenzhen. Daughter Huang Wenxi heads Hong Kong-listed Waytung Global Group, a real estate firm.

name: Billionaires
bio: Huang Zelan's wealth is little changed amid slack business at his Chongyi Zhangyuan Tungsten, one of the country's largest tungsten producers. Sales in the first nine months of 2012 at the Shenzhen-listed company dropped by 17.6% from a year earlier to $207 million. That helped to pull down net profit by half to $17.8 million. Huang borrowed money to buy a tungsten mine in 1994. Son Huang Shichun, born in 1981, became CEO of Chongyi Zhangyuan Tungsten after his father retired from the job in April 2012. Huang senior's wife Lai Xiangying is a director of the listed company and CFO of its parent company, Chongyi Zhangyuan Investment Holding. She owns 6% of the parent company, which in turn holds 81.5% of the listed company. Huang Zelan owns the other 94% of the holding company.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ravi Jaipuria founded and controls privately held $1 billion (revenues) RJ Corp which is PepsiCo's biggest bottler by far in India. He also has franchises for Pizza Hut, KFC and Costa Coffee; a beer joint venture with Anheuser-Busch InBev in which he has 51% stake. Has expanded into Africa with interests in bottling, dairy and fast foods. His father got the bottling franchise for Coca Cola in the 1960s. The youngest of three brothers, he studied in the US and shifted to Canada starting a small venture in real estate. Returned home in 1985 when his wife died in a plane crash. After a family division in 1987, in which he got one bottling plant as his share, he switched to Pepsi and has stayed loyal since.  His companies Varun Beverages and Devyani  International are named after his two children. Son Varun who works with him has recently acquired the franchise for Nike.

name: Billionaires
bio: Property tycoon, hotelier Koh Wee Meng debuts on list as shares of his Singapore-listed Fragrance Group surged over the past year. He spun off Fragrance's hotel arm into Global Premium Hotels, listing the budget hotel chain last April and is now also expanding into commercial real estate. He broke off from family's jewelry business to get into property in the 1990s. Vintage car collector, he's sued a Rolls-Royce dealer in Singapore for allegedly selling him a defective Phantom car in 2008.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded his now $12.2 billion hedge fund firm in 1995 with his sister, Sonia Gardner. In the wake of a down year in 2011, Avenue bounced back in 2012, with the firm's European fund producing a net return of 16% and the US fund returning 15%. Lasry claimed a second victory in 2012 when Democrat Barack Obama won a second term in the white house. In June, Lasry hosted a $40,000 per plate fundraiser for the president's campaign at his Upper East Side home. A native of Morocco, Lasry immigrated to the United States with his family as a child. He received his undergraduate degree at Clark University before attending law school at NYU. Lasry later left law to lead bankruptcy operations for Cowen & Co. before working for Texas billionaire Robert Bass.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Liang Yunchao is a new member of the World's Billionaires list thanks to soaring shares of his Guangdong By-Health Biotechnology, a big supplier of vitamins, herbal extracts and other health supplements. Revenue in the first nine months of 2012 climbed by 70% to $130 million, boosting profit by nearly two-thirds to $40 million. The company launched a new brand "Twelve Skeps" last October on China's popular Tmall e-commerce website. It has a growing network of 30,000-plus sales locations around China. Liang's mother-in-law Sun Jinyu owns 2.3% of By-Health. Yao Ming has appeared in By-Health's ads.

name: Billionaires
bio: Liu Gexin is chairman of Shenzhen-listed Sichuan Kelun Pharmaceutical, a maker of antibiotics and traditional Chinese medicines. Liu returns to the billionaire ranks this year after dropping off in 2012, following gains in Kelun's share price and growing sales in China. Revenue in the first nine months of 2012 increased by 19.4% to $700 million, helping to boost net profit by 11% to $123 million. The company said in December is would purchase up to 30% of Hong Kong-listed Lijun International Pharmaceutical for up to $316 million to expand its product line and sales channels. Liu's brother Liu Suihua is deputy general manager at Kelun.

name: Billionaires
bio: Lodha Developers, which Indian property magnate Mangal Prabhat Lodha founded in 1980, has 35 projects under construction covering 40 million square feet, in Mumbai. Showpiece project is the 117-story World One, a luxury high-rise designed by Armani Casa in central Mumbai, touted as the world's tallest residence. Firm made splash last August, when it bought a coveted 17.5-acre mid-town plot in Mumbai from Kushal Pal Singh's DLF for $510 million where it will build an apartment complex called Blue Moon. It received 1,300 applications amounting to $1 billion from prospective customers when it opened for pre-bookings. It is investing over $1 billion in developing New Cuffe Parade, an upcoming township, comprising four 63-story towers in the first phase, on a 23-acre site that it had bought for $765 million, three years ago. Marketing-savvy sons Abhisheck and Abhinandan run company, while Lodha spends half his time on charitable work.

name: Billionaires
bio: Max Michel Suberville is new to the Forbes Billionaires list. He has a large stake in Coca-Cola bottler FEMSA. He is also a member of one of the families that in the 1930s co-founded El Puerto de Liverpool, the first and largest department store chain in Mexico, with nearly 100 stores. He started to work at the chain when he was 22 and is now honorary chairman of the board. His nephew David Michel Max is chairman. In 2010 the company bought 50% of Regal Forest, a regional chain of electronics and furniture stores, and continues to expand in Mexico.

name: Billionaires
bio: Gary Michelson made his first fortune as a surgeon when he invented spinal implants. A member of the National Inventors Hall of Fame, he reached a $1.35 billion settlement with medical device giant Medtronic in 2005 following years of litigation over spinal surgery patents. He is credited with more than 250 U.S. patents on orthopedic instruments, methods and devices. After winning the settlement he made investments in distressed real estate and oil pipelines. He now focuses on philanthropic work in education, animal welfare and medical research. He supports the Twenty Million Minds Foundation, which helps students get free textbooks. He has also spent $10 million to convert municipal animal services from kill facilities to adoption centers and to provide free spaying and neutering services to low-income households. In 2010 he teamed up with actor Pierce Brosnan to pressure the White House to renew a moratorium on whaling. The initiative prevailed.

name: Billionaires
bio: Henry Nicholas III launched semiconductor Broadcom from his spare bedroom in his Redondo Beach, Calif. condominium in 1991. He and his business partner Henry Samueli (also a billionaire) built an electronic manufacturing powerhouse that reached $1 billion in annual revenue faster than any U.S. semiconductor company in history. 2011 revenues were $7.4 billion. A music enthusiast, Nicholas says his inspiration for Broadcom came from Pink Floyd lyrics. He retired from Broadcom in 2003, but still remains one of the company's largest shareholders. Several years ago he faced separate charges of drug distribution and options backdating, but both were dismissed in 2010. Since then Nicholas has focused on philanthropy. His Nicholas Academic Centers have sent more than 230 students to top-ranked universities across the nation. Through his Henry T. Nicholas Foundation, he frequently gives to Episcopal community causes as well as arts and education programs. In 2008, he mobilized California to pass Marsy's Law, a crime victim's bill of rights, named for his murdered sister.
title: Cofounder

name: Billionaires
bio: Neal Patterson's Cerner Corp., which sells health IT systems including electronic health records to doctor's offices and hospitals, has been consistently profitable since he took it public in 1986. Revenues and shares have soared as a result of the 2009 stimulus law, which instituted penalties for health systems that did not make enough progress in going digital. In 2012 the company posted profits of $396 million on sales of $2.67 billion. Patterson started Cerner in 1979 with two colleagues from Arthur Andersen's consulting business. He is now chairman, CEO and president. A co-owner of the Major League Soccer club Sporting Kansas City, he says he is a devoted follower of Ayn Rand and has been known to give copies of Atlas Shrugged to family members

name: Billionaires
bio: Florentino Perez, a civil engineer, has headed Spain's largest construction company, $36.9 billion (2011 sales) Actividades de Construccion y Servicios S.A., since 1993. But he may be best known to many Spaniards for his leadership at the popular Real Madrid soccer club, once the team of stars like David Beckham and Zinédine Zidane. He ran the club from 2000 to Feb. 2006 and was re-elected president in 2009. Now Real Madrid is the leading soccer club worldwide in terms of revenues: $690.6 million for the 2011-2012 season. It certainly is more fun than running his construction business these days. ACS, in which he has a 12.5%, posted a $1.4 billion loss in the first nine months of 2012. Although Spain's financial crisis and the burst of its housing bubble are certainly to blame, ACS's 2011 acquisition of German construction firm Hochtief--with which Perez hoped to boost profits and build the largest construction firm in the western hemisphere profits--certainly made the situation worse. ACS has been sloughing off debt: last year the company dumped a 3.69% stake in Iberdrola, sold 2,800 kilometers of power lines in Brazil, and also announced that it would cancel the February 2013 dividend. This year (2013), ACS plans to sell 6.4 million treasury shares to further reduce debt.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Ross Perot has made his mark as a developer in Texas, creating Hillwood, a massive nationwide real estate firm. Hillwood's biggest project is the 18,000-acre AllianceTexas industrial park near Dallas, which includes homes, offices, a giant rail yard and its own airport. Now he's trying to replicate the concept in Florida and California. In 2012 he also cut a $1 billion deal with Brookfield Property Group to develop commercial property nationwide. It hasn't all gone well. Suffered missteps with Victory Park development in downtown Dallas and lost big in the collapse of Parkcentral hedge fund in 2008. With siblings, donated $50 million in his parents' name in 2008 to create Perot Museum of Nature and Science in Dallas. He served in the Air Force and, in 1982, he and a co-pilot became the first to circumnavigate the globe in a helicopter.

name: Billionaires
bio: Megdet Rahimkulov has been a fastidious investor who until recently ran his own diversified investment portfolio. "I celebrated 65 years and retired," he told Forbes. Now his assets are spread among 20 relatives and managed by his company in Cyprus. In the mid-1990s he became chief executive and 10% owner of a joint venture between gas giant Gazprom and Hungary's oil and gas concern MOL. Gazprom bought a Hungarian bank, Altalanos ErtekForgalmi Bank (AEB), to process payments from its local customers; Rahimkulov headed AEB as well and later bought it from Gazprom. In 2007 he sold the bank and used the proceeds to buy shares in MOL and OTP, Hungary's largest bank. He also owns shares in Gazprom and VTB.

name: Billionaires
bio: Jorge Rodriguez Rodriguez is new to the Forbes Billionaires list. Along with his brother Vito, in 1967 he founded Jose Rodriguez Banda SA, a transport company that provides services for mining companies. They named the company after their father. In 1986 the brothers bought Gloria SA, Peru's largest producer of canned evaporated milk. Nestlé owned 60% of Gloria and the Berckemeyer family of Peru owned 40%. Nestlé sold its shares because Alan García, then-president of Peru, said the company should be transferred to Peruvians. Gloria became a highly profitable company. Since 1991, it has bought a number of other companies. Today the Rodriguez family has stakes in food companies in Argentina, Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador, Puerto Rico and Uruguay. They also have investments in sugar mills in Peru, Ecuador and Argentina.

name: Billionaires
bio: Boris Rotenberg and his older brother Arkady are the billionaire co-owners of SMP Bank and SGM Group, a major supplier of steel pipes and construction services to Russian gas giant Gazprom. The Rotenbergs are childhood friends and former judo sparring partners of president Vladimir Putin. Boris  is a vice-president of Russian Judo Federation, and holds dual citizenship from Russia and Finland. One son Roman is a head of marketing at SKA St. Petersburg ice hockey club, the president of which is Gennady Timchenko. Another son Boris is a soccer player for Cyprus club Olympiacos Nicosia.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chanchai Ruayrungruang leads the privately-held Reignwood Group, which focuses on luxury goods and services for the affluent. The Chinese-Thai businessman is also known by the Chinese name Yan Bin. Reignwood produces Red Bull drinks in China, operates the Pinewood Valley Golf Course in Beijing and is the sales agent for Bell Helicopter in China.

name: Billionaires
bio: Nobutada Saji, the third generation to run the family drinks business, Suntory, founded by his grandfather, returns to the billionaires this year after Forbes pinned down his and his wife's personal stake in the growing guzzler. Suntory plans to IPO the company's non-alcoholic drinks and food business, seeking to potentially raise over $3 billion. Since Saji took control in 1999, he has focused Suntory on overseas acquisitions. Some of his biggest include the 2009 acquisition of France's Orangina Schweppes Group and New Zealand's Frucor Beverages Group. A hoped-for merger with rival Kirin Holdings fell apart in 2010. Saji heads the Advertising Council of Japan. Arts patron runs major Tokyo gallery. Avid swimmer also operates chain of gyms.

name: Billionaires
bio: Egyptian-born Fayez Sarofim, nicknamed "The Sphinx," returns to the Forbes Billionaires list for the first time since 2008 thanks to his stake in energy transportation company Kinder Morgan. He is one of the firm's original shareholders, serving as a director from 2007 until the IPO in February 2011. He maintains his post as a director and holds 3% of the firm's equity. The son of a wealthy Egyptian cotton farmer, he got an MBA from Harvard Business School before starting his own investment firm, Fayez Sarofim & Co., in 1958. He made his fortune as a buy-and-hold investor with stakes in Philip Morris, Coca-Cola and Procter & Gamble.  In 1997 he was inducted into the Texas Business Hall of Fame. Fayez Sarofim & Co. has $27 billion in assets under management. He has donated to numerous causes including hospitals, schools, and the arts.  He sits on the board of the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center and is a director of the Texas Heart Institute.

name: Billionaires
bio: Richard Scaife is an heir to the family fortune that was amassed by his great uncle the industrialist Andrew Mellon. The value of his trusts became public in 2007 when court documents were leaked during his messy second divorce. He owns and is publisher of the Pittsburgh Tribune-Review. He also owns Newsmax, a conservative magazine and website, and Pittsburgh-based KQV radio. In the 2012 election cycle he donated at least $500,000 to conservative causes.

name: Billionaires
bio: As CEO of Toronto-based buyout firm Onex, Gerald Schwartz is one of Canada's highest compensated executives. He earned more than $60 million pre-tax in 2011, according to the company's financial documents. His fortune has risen $400 million from a year ago due to a rise in the price of Onex shares; he owns nearly 20% of the company. Schwartz founded Onex in 1983 after working at Bear Stearns and CanWest. In May 2012, the company was reportedly exploring a deal to launch a new casino. Onex struck an agreement to buy USI Insurance Services from a unit of Goldman Sachs for $2.3 billion in November 2012. An honorary director of the Bank of Nova Scotia, Schwartz also serves as a director of Indigo Books & Music, where his wife, Heather Reisman, is the CEO. Schwartz owns homes in Toronto, Malibu, Nantucket and Palm Beach--where he keeps his 19-foot dinghy, "Know Heather," named after his wife.

name: Billionaires
bio: Bloomberg LP co-founder Thomas Secunda's net worth grew by $100 million this past year thanks to rising revenues at the data giant, where he remains a key figure. Sales for 2012 reached $7.9 billion. He was named vice chairman of the company in 2011, and oversees financial products, research and development. The low-profile SUNY Binghamton grad met Michael Bloomberg at Salomon Brothers, where he was once a researcher. After working as a trader at Morgan Stanley, he and his former colleague set up Innovative Market Systems in 1982. They renamed it Bloomberg LP in 1987. Secunda retains a 4% stake in the company. He and wife Cindy head the Secunda Family Foundation, donating to the arts, education, health and Jewish causes. An avid environmentalist, he sits on the boards of the National Parks Conservation Association, the Westchester County Parks, Recreation and Conservation Board and the Intrepid Museum Foundation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Shao Genhuo returns to the billionaire ranks after dropping off last year due to an increase in share price of the Shenzhen-listed animal feed and seed supplier he chairs, Beijing Dabeinong Technology Group. Sales in the first nine months of 2012 rose by 38% from a year earlier to $1.2 billion, helping to lift net profit by 38% to $70 million following an increase in production capacity. Its shares rose last year despite negative publicity from reports that a company subsidiary had bought waste oil, also known as "gutter oil," for its products. Shao, born in China's entrepreneurial mecca of Zhejiang province, began his career as an educator. He worked as a teacher at a Beijing college for two years after receiving a Ph.D. from China Agricultural University. He left in 1994 to start Dabeinong. A Buddhist, Shao enjoys tea and reading in his spare time.
title: Entrepreneur

name: Billionaires
bio: Tom Steyer, founder of $19 billion hedge fund Farallon Capital Management, retired at the end of 2012 and sold his stake in the hedge fund firm to his partners. Steyer's last year at Farallon was decent enough, with his flagship hedge fund returning 11.42% net, though the performance trailed the U.S. stock market. He has clearly been bitten by the political bug. In early September he spoke at the Democratic National Convention in Charlotte, North Carolina, where he served as a delegate. He was the primary backer of California ballot initiative Prop. 39, which passed in 2012. It closed a corporate tax loophole that lets multistate businesses choose to pay taxes outside of California and use the tax funds for alternative energy projects; he contributed some $22 million to get the measure passed. In 2010, Steyer successfully led the opposition to a California ballot initiative that would have quashed a law limiting greenhouse gas emissions. Steyer continues to back the Advanced Energy Economy business organization, which he cofounded. It is working to help American alternative energy companies succeed. He donated $10 million in 2012 to its affiliated nonprofit Advanced Energy Economy Institute. He and his wife, Kat Taylor, were among the first to sign the Gates-Buffett Giving Pledge in 2010. The couple gave $25 million to Steyer's alma mater, Yale University, in 2011 to establish an energy sciences institute. They also gave $40 million to Stanford University (where Steyer got his MBA) in 2009 to establish the TomKat Center for Sustainable Energy and another $7 million in 2010 to create the Steyer-Taylor Center for Energy Finance and Policy. In 2004, they created a foundation to start a community bank, One Pacific Coast Bank, and have so far spent $50 million to fund it.
title: Founder & Co-Senior Managing Partner
employment: {'name': 'Farallon Capital Management', 'title': 'Founder & Co-Senior Managing Partner', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Sun Piaoyang's wealth has increased sharply from a year earlier on growing sales of anti-cancer drugs at Jiangsu Hengrui Medicine, of which he is chairman. Sales in the first nine months of 2012 rose by 22% from a year earlier to $651.6 million and net profit climbed 20% to $130 million. Hengrui has regulatory approvals to sell drugs in the U.S., the Netherlands and India, among other markets. The company has a research center in New Jersey. Sun's wife Zhong Huijuan chairs Jiangsu Hansoh Pharmaceutical Group, which is reportedly eyeing a Hong Kong IPO.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chef's son Tony Tan Caktiong started Jollibee Foods in 1978 with two Manila ice cream parlors. Now it is the country's largest fast-food company, with nearly a dozen chains, including Jollibee, Chow King, Greenwich Pizza, and more than 2,000 stores in the Philippines and 541 overseas. Also owns the Burger King franchise in the Philippines. Plans to expand to Singapore. Says international outlets, which now account for 20% of sales, will equal domestic sales by 2020. Line of customers greeted June opening of Jollibee in Jersey City, its second outlet in the New York metro area. Joins billionaires for first time on better understanding of ownership of his fortune.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mehmet Sinan Tara is Chairman of the Board of Enka, one of Turkey's largest construction companies; company's stock price is up 17% over the past year. Using family foundation funds to start Enka Schools, one in Istanbul and the other in Adapazari; 2.000 students are enrolled. They also own the Enka Sports Club.

name: Billionaires
bio: Peter Unger founded auto parts and repair outfit Auto-Teile-Unger in 1985 and built it into a well-known chain of stores in Germany. He sold 80% of the company to British investor group Doughty Hanson & Co. in 2002 for a reported $800 million. In 2004, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts bought the entire company, including Unger's remaining 20% stake, for which he received an estimated $360 million. Unger is retired and lives in Bavaria.

name: Billionaires
bio: Wang Muqing's fortune has declined on falling profit margins and share prices in the auto distribution industry. Wang is the founder and a non-executive director of China ZhengTong Auto, which began as a single Nissan dealership and now distributes all kinds of luxury makes including BMW, Audi, Land Rover, Jaguar and Volvo from dozens of locations in central and eastern China. Its shares were first listed on the Hong Kong exchange in 2010. ZhengTong is 10% owned by fund management company Value Partners of Hong Kong. Prior to founding the Group in 1999, Wang held various positions over 18 years at the Hubei Industrial Building Group Installation Engineering, an equipment supplier before setting up on his own in 1996.

name: Billionaires
bio: Wang Wenxue's China Fortune Land Development of Beijing has invested in 17 industrial parks in China. Like fellow Chinese billionaire Xiong Xuqiang, Wang injected his real estate business into another already-listed company and then renamed it. China Fortune Land was previously called Zhejiang King Refrigeration Industry. Sales in the first nine months of 2012 rose by 30% from a year earlier to $1.1 billion; net profit rose 29% to  $240.6 million. Fortune Land signed a strategic cooperation framework agreement with China Aerospace Science and Technology last November to co-develop an Aerospace Technology Industrial Park in Guan in Hebei province. China Aerospace Science & Technology and its associates will also invest in China Fortune Land Development's industrial parks around the country.

name: Billionaires
bio: Bricks have been very good to the WIlks family, but fracking made them billionaires. Father Voy Wilks took up bricklaying to literally build a house for his family and get them out of the goat shed. He then asked his employer at a Cisco, TX factory for a small raise. When his employer refused Voy quit and switched his career to masonry. Following in their father's footsteps Dan and his brother Farris became masons themselves, founding Wilks Masonry together in 1995. In 2002 the brothers branched out into the hydraulic fracturing and oil field services industry with the founding of Frac Tech. In May 2011 the brothers sold their nearly 70% combined interest in Frac Tech to a partnership lead by Singapore's Temasek Holdings for $3.5 billion. The pair recently purchased the 66,000 acre N Bar Ranch in Montana from fellow billionaire Tom Siebel and they are building an airport in Cisco.

name: Billionaires
bio: Bricks have been very good to the WIlks family, but fracking made them billionaires. Father Voy Wilks took up bricklaying to literally build a house for his family and get them out of the goat shed. He then asked his employer at a Cisco, TX factory for a small raise. When his employer refused Voy quit and switched his career to masonry. Following in their father's footsteps Dan and his brother Farris became masons themselves, founding Wilks Masonry together in 1995. In 2002 the brothers branched out into the hydraulic fracturing and oil field services industry with the founding of Frac Tech. In May 2011 the brothers sold their nearly 70% combined interest in Frac Tech to a partnership lead by Singapore's Temasek Holdings for $3.5 billion. The pair recently purchased the 66,000 acre N Bar Ranch in Montana from fellow billionaire Tom Siebel and they are building an airport in Cisco. Farris serves as pastor of the Assembly of Yahweh 7th Day in Cisco, Texas.

name: Billionaires
bio: Gordon Wu returns to the ranks of the world's billionaires thanks to a sharp jump in shares of his Hopewell Holdings, which has interests in property, highways, power and hotels. Its Hong Kong- traded shares vaulted by three-quarters last year on hopes for new real estate business in the city. Son Thomas, a managing director, is heir apparent. Wife, Ivy, also sits on the board. Knighted by Queen Elizabeth in 1997.

name: Billionaires
bio: Albert Yeung's net worth is up $300 million from a year ago thanks to rising shares of his flagship Emperor International Holdings. Yeung controls five listed companies: Emperor International, Emperor Watch and Jewelry, Emperor Entertainment, Emperor Capital and New Media Group. Last year Emperor celebrated the 70th anniversary since its founding by Albert's father, Yeung Shing, with events that included American singer Paul Anka crooning at a gala dinner and Taiwan singer Tsai Chin on hand. The company also supplied blood tests for hepatitis B, free to the public. Started as a watch shop in Kowloon, listed Emperor Watch & Jewellery is now one of the city's largest watch retailers.

name: Billionaires
bio: Zhang Zhixiang is one of China's biggest steel moguls, and is diversifying quickly into other metal-bending interests. The Qingdao shipyard owned by his privately held Jianlong Group in January received orders for 14 ships worth $145 million from China's military. Last June, the company paid $158 million for a 5% stake of Shanghai-listed automaker Beiqi Foton Motor. Beiqi will set up a joint venture company that will make engine parts. The company was ranked no. 13 on a list of China's 500 largest private-sector companies in 2012.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ahmet Nazif Zorlu founded a textile company with his brother Zeki Zorlu, turning it into Turkey's largest exporter. Now his Zorlu holding company is active in consumer electronics and energy industries; owns private-label TV maker and distributor Vestel. This year, his large condominium and shopping mall project will start operating. Zorlu also founded Turkey's first nickel refinery and aims to export 10,000 tons of nickel a year. High school dropout shuttles around Europe in custom-designed helicopter.

name: Billionaires
bio: Wen Yibo is China's first and, for now, only entrepreneur to break into the billionaire ranks thanks to an expertise in treating waste water. His Hong Kong- and Singapore-listed company Sound Global provides water treatment services to several major Chinese cities and manufacturing zones. His Shenzhen-listed Sound Environmental Resources also builds waste processing facilities. Increases in business last year lifted the shares of both, and with it, Wen's wealth. Sound Environmental's sales in first nine months of 2012 rose by 26% to $208 million; it's net profit jumped 42% to $44 million. Sound Global's revenue increased by 12% in the six months ending in June to $191 million. Wen holds a degree in environmental engineering from Langzhou Jiaotong University, where he is a part-time professor. He shares his fortune with his wife.

name: Billionaires
bio: Andrei Bokarev, a new billionaire in 2013, runs Transmashholding, one of Russia's biggest Russian machine building companies, a producer of rolling stock for railways and subway systems. In 1998, two years after graduating from the Moscow Finance Institute, he met Iskander Makhmudov, who invited him to head Krutredag, which ran the export operations of the Kuzbassrazrezugol coal company. Since then he has been a minority partner in most of Makhmudov's projects, including not only Kuzbassrazrezugol but Transmashholding, the freight railway operator Transgroup, and Aeroexpress, which handles passenger railway operations in the Moscow region. An avid skier, he is president of the Russian Ski Sports Association and the Freestyle Federation of Russia.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ana María Brescia Cafferata is new to the Forbes Billionaires list this year. She inherited her fortune from her father, Fortunato Brescia Tassano, who built a real estate company that capitalized on Lima's growth. Fortunato died in 1951. Ana María's assets are managed by her brothers, Pedro and Mario. They control a group of companies know as Grupo Brescia, with interests in agriculture, fish products, cement, paint products, explosives, welding, insurance, banking, mining and real estate. She owns 30% of Grupo Brescia.

name: Billionaires
bio: Rosa Brescia Cafferata is new to the Forbes Billionaires list this year .She inherited her fortune from her father, Fortunato Brescia Tassano, who built a real estate company that capitalized on Lima's growth. Fortunato died in 1951. Her fortune was managed by her husband, Paul Fort, until he died in 2004. Since then her son Alex Fort Brescia has managed her assets. The Brescia family controls a group of companies know as Grupo Brescia, with interests in agriculture, fish products, cement, paint products, explosives, welding, insurance, banking, mining  and real estate. Together with her two sons and three daughters, Rosa own 30% of Grupo Brescia. One of her sons, Bernardo Fort Brescia, is an architect who designed many buildings in the U.S. and Peru, including Lima's tallest building, the Westin Lima Hotel, which is owned by the Grupo Brescia.

name: Billionaires
bio: Andrea Della Valle and his brother Diego Della Valle (also a billionaire) together own 56% of Tod's, the luxury Italian shoe and purse maker that has benefited from strong sales in China and Hong Kong. Revenue rose 7% in the first nine months of 2012 to $990 million (750 million Euros). Andrea is vice-chairman; Diego is chairman. Andrea's net worth is $250 million higher than a year ago due to a jump in the price of Tod's stock. The brothers also own stakes in retailer Saks, Italian luxury eyewear company Marcolin (which sells the Kenneth Cole, Timberland, and Tom Ford brands) and Italian magazine and newspaper publisher RCS MediaGroup.

name: Billionaires
bio: Andrei Filatov co-owns N-Trans Group, a railway and port operator, with his partners and fellow billionaires Konstantin Nikolaev and Nikita Mishin. In the summer of 2011 they took public one of Russia's biggest port operators, Global Ports Investments, for about $500 million, and in October 2012 they sold a 37.5% stake in Global Ports to a subsidiary of the Danish shipping giant A.P. Moller-Maersk, for $863 million. Filatov was born in the Ukraine and earned a degree as a chess teacher and coach from Belarus' Academy of Physical Culture and Sports. He worked at businesses in Murmansk's port before joining up with Nikolaev and Mishin in 1996 to found their first shipping company, Severstaltrans. Billionaire Alexei Mordashov was also an investor in Severstaltrans, but in 2007 the partners bought his stake, and a year later they renamed the company N-Trans. In the fall of 2012 Filatov's partners sold their stakes in the railway operator Transoil, but he kept his 7%. He has financed a memorial in Paris honoring the first Russian world chess champion, Alexander Alekhine, and he sponsored a world title chess match in Moscow in 2012.

name: Billionaires
bio: Shares of Geng Jianming's RiseSun Real Estate Development are up sharply in the past six months, reflecting strong property sales in China's second-tier cities. RiseSun is a residential developer headquartered in inland Hebei Province, and owns five-star hotels in Langfang and Cangzhou in Heibei, and in Liaocheng, Shandong Province. The company's net profit in the first half of the year climbed 37% to $133 million, on sales that rose 39% to $878 million. Geng is a member of the National People's Congress.

name: Billionaires
bio: Following his 1967 wedding to Linda Marie Pace, Christopher ?Kit? Goldsbury started his career cutting vegetables in the production line of her father's Pace salsa factory. In 1977, he was named president of the company and by 1982, he and Linda Marie Pace had bought out her family's remaining interests in the firm. Following the couple's 1987 divorce, Goldsbury purchased Linda's half for just $95 million. Eight years later, he sold the entire outfit to Campbell Soup for $1.1 billion. Goldsbury soon jumped back into the food industry via Silver Ventures, which has a stake in tomato producer NatureSweet. His investments appear to be paying off; Goldsbury sold artisanal bread maker Ecce Panis to Campbell for a reported $65 million in 2009. With a record $35 million donation to the Culinary Institute of America in 2007, Goldsbury recruited the cooking school to open a campus on the site of the former Pearl Brewery in San Antonio, which Goldsbury's private equity firm Silver Ventures purchased in 2001. Goldsbury established a $20 million scholarship fund called El Sueño to subsidize education costs for low-income students attending the culinary school. Pearl Park, home to a music venue that seats 1,000, opened last year, and the area now boasts numerous stores, a spa and upscale restaurants.
