Silver Ventures is apparently expanding the redevelopment zone, having last year purchased the site of the seedy Alamo Lodge motel, which reportedly received 1200 police calls since 2006 and was once declared by city officials a "substantial threat to public life and safety."
title: Chief Executive Officer
employment: {'name': 'Silver Ventures', 'title': 'Chief Executive Officer', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Bangalore resident S. 'Kris' Gopalakrishnan is co-chairman of Infosys, which he cofounded in 1981 and helped grow into India's second largest outsourcer. Its shares have declined on concerns over slowing growth especially in the US, its biggest market. In July, he was appointed to head government panel on cloud computing. Gopalakrishnan, who donates close to $4 million annually to various causes, including funding scholarships for needy college students,has backed Startup Village, a technology incubator in Kerala that aims to create 1,000 new ventures. Family owns a coffee estate and farm in Karnataka state.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ayman Hariri is the son of slain Lebanese Prime Minister Rafik Hariri. He's involved in running Saudi Oger, one of Saudi Arabia's biggest construction companies and the source of the Hariri family fortune. Oger was part of a venture that won a $653 million contract in January 2013 to build a local branch of the Louvre museum in Abu Dhabi, due to open in 2015. His other interests include telecommunications; Oger has a major stake in Turk Telekom. It also owns shares in Middle Eastern banks, such as Jordan's Arab Bank, which hasn't fared so well. Saudi Oger had to take out a $1 billion loan in February 2013 to refinance debt related to its investment in Arab Bank.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fahd Hariri is the youngest son of slain Lebanese Prime Minister Rafik Hariri. He graduated from the Ecole Spéciale d'Architecture de Paris in 2004. While still a student, he ran an interior design studio on the outskirts of the city and sold furniture to clients in Saudi Arabia. While he reportedly hasn't set foot in Beirut since his father's assassination in 2005, he develops residential buildings in there, and credits his father for his love of real estate development.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ingeburg Herz and her sons Michael and Wolfgang own Tchibo GmbH, makers of Germany's best-known coffee brand, which they inherited from Ingeburg's late husband, Max Herz.  Ingeburg and her sons also own 50% of listed skincare company Beiersdorf AG, which makes the Nivea brand. Herz was involved in an effort to push out her son Gunter and her daughter Daniela from the company in 2003 in a drawn-out family feud; the family bought out Gunter and Daniela's shares for $5 billion. Another son, Joachim, died in 2008 after being hit by a boat while swimming in a lake in Georgia in the U.S.

name: Billionaires
bio: Marc Ladreit de Lacharriere is the chief executive and chairman of the board of Fimalac ($740 million sales), the parent of Fitch Ratings, which now operates in more than 50 countries. His firm was criticized for its role in the 2008 sub-prime real estate crisis. When he was 21, Ladreit de Lacharriere started a teen magazine, which he sold a few years later before attending the prestigious Ecole Nationale d'Administration and moving into banking and finance. He eventually landed at L'Oreal, where he worked for 15 years, becoming executive vice president of finance. He then founded Fimalac in 1991 with the goal of becoming an international ratings agency. The firm acquired Fitch Ratings in 1998. He sits on the boards of L'Oreal, Renault, and Casino Guichard-Perrachon. A theater buff, Ladreit de Lacharriere helped renovate the Theater du Rond Point in Paris. He also serves as a director of the Établissement public du Musée du Louvre (which performs administrative and financial duties for the Louvre Museum). In 2009, he was named goodwill ambassador by UNESCO.

name: Billionaires
bio: Nikita Mishin co-owns N-Trans Group, a railway and port operator, with his partners and fellow billionaires Andrei Filatov and Konstantin Nikolaev. In the summer of 2011 they took public one of Russia's biggest port operators, Global Ports Investments, for about $500 million, and in October of 2012 they sold a 37.5% stake in Global Ports to a subsidiary of the Danish shipping giant A.P. Moller-Maersk, for $863 million. Mishin studied philosophy at Moscow State University, and he joined up with Filatov and Nakolaev in 1996 to found their first shipping company, Severstaltrans. Billionaire Alexei Mordashov was also an investor in Severstaltrans, but in 2007 the partners bought his stake, and a year later they renamed the company N-Trans. In the fall of 2012 Mishin and Nikolaev sold their 13% stake in the railway operator Transoil to Gennady Timchenko, who is apparently a close friend of Russian Prime Minister Vladimir Putin.

name: Billionaires
bio: Konstantin Nikolaev co-owns N-Trans Group, a railway and port operator, with his partners and fellow billionaires Andrei Filatov and Nikita Mishin. In the summer of 2011 they took public one of Russia's biggest port operators, Global Ports Investments, for about $500 million, and in October of 2012 they sold a 37.5% stake in Global Ports to a subsidiary of the Danish shipping giant A.P. Moller-Maersk, for $863 million. Nikolaev was born in Ukraine, studied philosophy at Moscow State University, and worked at businesses in Murmansk's port before joining up with Filatov and Mishin in 1996 to found their first shipping company, Severstaltrans. Billionaire Alexei Mordashov was also an investor in Severstaltrans, but in 2007 the partners bought his stake, and a year later they renamed the company N-Trans. Nikolaev is one of the co-founders of Skolkovo, in Moscow, the first business school in Russia. In November 2011 he and MIshin sold their 13% stake in the railway operator Transoil to Gennady Timchenko, a close friend of Russian Prime Minister Vladimir Putin.

name: Billionaires
bio: Before 1993 he headed production company Urayneftegaz, in April of the same year he was appointed president of state-owned oil company Rosneft. After he left Rosneft in 1998 he worked as a special representative of British Petroleum / Amoco in oil company Sidanko. In 2004 he became co-owner of a drilling company founded by Alexander Dzhaparidze, which is now called Eurasia Drilling. After Dzhaparidze suddenly sold 22% stake in the company, Putilov became the biggest shareholder of Eurasia Drilling.

name: Billionaires
bio: Nikolai Sarkisov, the younger brother of billionaire Sergei Sarkisov, started his own business in 1990, trading metals and importing construction equipment, after quitting his job at a Soviet company that exported commodities. Later he joined his brother's successful insurance company, RESO-Garantiya, and was given oversight of its largest clients. Now he manages the RESO group's construction projects. Since 2012 the group has gotten out of construction projects in Russia and invested in European ones. The Sarkisovs own 63% of RESO-Garantiya; the French insurance company AXA owns the remaining 37%.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sergei Sarkisov bought a 25% stake in Russia's sixth-largest insurer, Insurance House VSK, in 2011. He has said that he is planning to buy the seventh-lagest insurer, Soglasie, and merge them. He got his start at the Soviet state insurance firm Ingosstrakh and founded his own firm, RESO-Garantiya, in 1991; today he serves as chairman of the board. In 2007 he sold a 37% stake in RESO-Garantiya to the French insurance giant AXA for $1.2 billion, a record sum for a Russian insurer. AXA had an option to buy a controlling interest but eventually opted out; Sarkisov has retained control of the company and is expanding its business in Russia. He and his brother Nikolai, also a billionaire, are still its largest investors. Sarkisov is fond of auto racing.

name: Billionaires
bio: Shagang Group Chairman Shen Wenrong saw his wealth slip this year as sluggish steel industry sales in China hurt profits. Shagang's Shenzhen-listed steelmaking arm Jiangsu Shagang suffered an up to 95% dive in 2012 net profit from a year earlier, the company said in a provisional statement in January. Shagang is China's biggest privately owned steel maker but is diversifying away from steel by putting money into investment funds such as the government-backed private equity vehicle GP Capital of Shanghai. Shagang Group in January set up a headquarters in Singapore to promote its overseas business. Shen's son Shen Bin is a Shagang Group managing director; his brother Shen Wenming is also a director and deputy general manager.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sit Kwong Lam did not have the best 2012. The founder and chairman of Hong Kong-listed Brightoil Petroleum suffered depressed economic conditions in its oil shipping business and narrowing margins in its fuel storage business. Its CEO resigned in November and the company warned of a loss for the second half of 2012. It has seen several of its top executives and traders leave in recent months. Sit's Brightoil shares, which are nearly all of his net worth, are down 40% from a year ago. Brightoil is one of a growing number of private-sector companies to expand in the energy industry and is diversifying by developing natural gas deposits in Xinjiang, in northwest China.Sit is a member of the China People's Political Consultative Conference, an influential political body.

name: Billionaires
bio: Lia Maria Aguiar is the low-profile adopted daughter of the late Brazilian banker Amador Aguiar, the founder of Bradesco bank, one of Brazil's largest banks. Amador's death in 1991 sparked more than a decade of ugly court fights between his adopted daughters and his second wife, whom he married less than five months before his death. Amador's widow, 40 years his junior, reportedly demanded her husband's body be exhumed for a DNA test to prove paternity and disqualify his three adopted daughters. Amador's  daughters prevailed in court and sisters Lia and Lina Aguiar are billionaires thanks to their stake in Bradesco Bank, while the third daughter, Maria Angela, received fewer shares and does not make the list. Amador left the majority of his fortune to the Bradesco Foundation, which he founded in 1956 to benefit education in Brazil. In 2008 Lia started her own foundation, Fundacao Lia Maria Aguiar, to benefit the city of Campos de Jordao, where she has been living since the early '90s.

name: Billionaires
bio: After a disappointing run that saw him lose money in 2011, Bacon returned $2 billion in assets to investors in 2012 believing it would help him "be more nimble in navigating these markets." The results for the macro investor were not bad, but his Moore Global Investment Fund, which posted a net return of more than 8%, still underperformed the U.S. stock market after charging its investors steep fees. A noted conservationist, he fended off a different kind of intervention when he successfully fought efforts by two power companies to build a power line across his Trinchera Ranch in Colorado. In 2012, he announced his intentions to donate a conservation easement on 90,000 acres of land on Trinchera (bought from Forbes family in 2007) to the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service. Including that land, Bacon has set aside close to 200,000 acres through 10 easements including 424 acres on Robins Island in New York's Peconic Bay, and 3,000 acres on his ancestor's original plantation down south. The easements protect the land in perpetuity; they also have tax benefits. According to Bacon, he has given around $50 million to mostly environmental groups. At age 20, he spent the summer working on the fishing boat of NYSE board member Walter Frank, which later led to a job at Frank's specialist firm. Bacon's stepmother is Julian Robertson's sister.
title: Founder and Chief Executive Officer
employment: {'name': 'Moore Capital Management, LP', 'title': 'Founder and Chief Executive Officer', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Media-shy Mehmet Rustu Basaran inherited the industrial conglomerate, Habas Company, from his father who has started out by working at a flour mill. Today Habas is a well-known producer of industrial and medical gases, heavy machinery and LNG. Basaran, who is known for his love of expensive automobiles, has a large collection comprising McKaren F1, Superamerica, Enzo and a $4.5 million dollar Ferrari FFX. He also owns two villas on the shores of the Bosporus.

name: Billionaires
bio: Italian-born Nicola Bulgari and his brother Paolo are the great-great-grandsons of Greek silversmith Konstantinos Voulgaris, who started the family jewelry business more than 150 years ago. Today Hollywood beauties flaunt Bulgari's bold, hand-crafted gems on red carpets. The duo sold the company to French luxury conglomerate LVMH in an all-share deal in 2011. In 2012, as LVMH's stock rose, the Bulgaris sold a tiny sliver of their stake, reportedly to take care of taxes and other expenses.The brothers now own just over 2.4% of LVMH between them, enough to land them each a spot on the billionaires list for the first time.

name: Billionaires
bio: Gary Burrell was a certified pilot when he teamed up with Min Kao in 1989 to start Garmin, maker of GPS technology. The company's name comes from the founders' first names. Coalition forces during the Gulf War were among the company's first customers, using the products to navigate through the desert. In 1998 Garmin branched into consumer devices and the company went public in 2000. Burrell is chairman emeritus and still owns more than 15% of the company. Garmin is headquartered in Kansas City, where it operates a face-to-face customer service center for people who want more technical support than they can get over the phone. The company continues to face stiff competition from cell phone manufacturers like Apple which offer built-in GPS technology. The stock has slid in the last year.
title: Chairman Emeritus

name: Billionaires
bio: Che Jianxin started out as a furniture maker at the outset of the country's economic reforms in 1986 and has since built up a retail and real estate empire. Che chairs Red Star Macalline, one of China's largest furniture retail chains, with more than 100 locations nationwide. Investors include fellow billionaire Guo Guangchang, whose Fosun International owns a minority stake in the company. Fosun Media is a partner of Forbes Media.

name: Billionaires
bio:
Turgay Ciner owns a diversified portfolio of companies including electric power plants, copper aluminum and soda ash mines, hotels and a media company in Turkey. He is investing $1.35 billion in partnership with the Chinese Tianchen Corporation for a second soda facility, alongside his Eti Soda.  
Ciner is rapidly opening new UCZ (Turkish word for cheap) stores to compete with BIM which belongs to fellow billionaire Mustafa Latif Topbas. Ciner is a soccer fan who owns one of Istanbul's soccer teams, Kasimpasa Spor.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sisley Cosmetics' French founder Hubert d'Ornano makes the list thanks to his skincare company's cult following (and his prices: $475 for a 1.6 ounce pot of their signature Sisleÿa Extra-Rich Cream). He and his family own 100% of Sisley, which he founded in 1976 and which did over $760 million in revenues in 2011. D'Ornano is considered cosmetics industry royalty: his father, Guillaume, co-founded Lancôme in 1935. He's also real royalty, of sorts: a Count, married to a Polish royal, a Radziwill (his wife's uncle was married to Jackie Kennedy Onassis' sister).

name: Billionaires
bio: D. Leopoldo del Pino y Calvo-Sotelo is new to the Forbes Billionaire list this year. In 2010, Leopoldo, the fourth of the del Pino heirs, and his brother, Joaquin, joined the Board of Directors of Ferrovial, with Leopoldo representing Portman Baela SL, a family  holding company. Leopoldo owns slightly less than 10% of Ferrovial S.A.  He also acts as a member of the Audit and Control Committee of the company. He is vice-president of Empark, a car park business, and until recently was a member of the board of Ebro Foods S.A., the leading company in the Spanish food processing sector. At the end of 2012, he sold his shares in Ebro Foods for close to $50 million.
person: {'name': 'D. Leopoldo Del Pino y Calvo-Sotelo', 'uri': 'd-leopoldo-del-pino', 'imageExists': False}
personName: D. Leopoldo Del Pino y Calvo-Sotelo

name: Billionaires
bio: Shares of Divis Laboratories, generics maker that Indian pharma tycoon Murali Divi founded in 1990, gained 42% in past year, giving big boost to his wealth. That rise plus new information on his holdings earn him a spot on list for the first time. Company, which does custom manufacturing of patented drugs for big pharma and derives 90% of its $344 million revenues from exports, benefited from weaker rupee. Yoga fanatic, he spends weekends on his farm.

name: Billionaires
bio: Aydin Dogan is the owner of Turkey's largest media group which was fined a $4.6 billion tax penalty four years ago; the final payment of a reduced fine was paid last year. As a result, Dogan sold many of his media as well as non-media related assets and only in the past several months has he started to reinvest in new projects. His Dogan Energy bought two energy companies belonging to Akdeniz Construction owned by fellow billionaire, Ali Agaoglu, for approximately $500 million. The stock price of his publicly traded holding company is up 54% over the past year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Juan Gallardo Thurlow, new to the Forbes Billionaires list this year, controls 63% of Organizacion Cultiba SAB de C.V., a holding company that along with its subsidiaries, produces cane sugar and molasses, and distributes soft drinks, including bottled water and all Pepsi-brand drinks in Mexico. Organizacion Cultiba's share price has doubled from January 2008 to January 2013, raising the value of Gallardo Thurlow's stake to $1.3 billion. Cultiba is also the largest distributor in the water jugs sector in Mexico, with an estimated 18% market share in 2011. In that same year, Cultiba was the only producer and distributor of beverages in Mexico with nationwide operations and was the country's second-largest beverage company based on combined sales volume of soft drinks and water. Cultiba is one of the largest private sector producers of sugar in Mexico, with three mills and a 49% interest in a fourth mill. As a result of the integration between the sugar and beverage businesses, Cultiba benefits from a natural hedge against fluctuation in sugar prices. In January 2013 Cultiba made a secondary offering of nearly 100 million shares, raising close to $200 million. In the 1990s, Gallardo Thurlow was well known in Washington, D.C., for his role as chief NAFTA negotiator on behalf of Mexico's business sector.

name: Billionaires
bio: Valentin Gapontsev is considered by Russians to be the father of the fiber-optic laser industry. In 1990, at age 51, he founded IPG Photonics, which produces high-power fiber-optic lasers for cutting materials and telecommunications. The company is based in Oxford, Mass., but operates all over the world. He studied laser physics at the Soviet Academy of Science's Institute of Radio Engineering and Electronics. Gapontsev holds Russian and U.S. citizenships and lives in Worcester, Mass.

name: Billionaires
bio: Alan Gerry, a WWII Marine Corps veteran and TV repair shop owner began constructing an upstate New York cable network in 1956 trying to bolster demand for his TV sets. Gerry's original system only had the capability to transmit five channels at a time, despite access to seven networks. As such, Gerry often found himself changing channels for the whole region, sometimes swapping out a news program for the Yankees game and vice versa. By the 1990s his Cablevision Industries had established networks in 18 states from New York to Florida. Gerry sold CVI to Time Warner in 1996 for $2.8 billion, netting himself $900 million in the deal. The self-described "country boy" purchased the site of the 1969 Woodstock festival at the urging of his youngest daughter, opening the Bethel Woods Center for the Arts in 2006.

name: Billionaires
bio: Andreas Halvorsen launched his $18 billion hedge fund, Viking Global Investors, in 1999 after seven successful years with Julian Robertson's famed Tiger Management. Last year his $16.2 billion flagship Viking Global Equities fund was up 12.8% while the $2 billion long fund (which Halvorsen closed to new investors last year) was up an impressive 23%. Among some of his biggest positions last year were News Corp, Visa, and Time Warner. Apple was also among Halvorsen's large positions in 2012 but he sold Viking's entire stake in the fourth quarter.
title: Investor
employment: {'name': 'Viking Global Investors', 'title': 'Founding Partner & Chief Executive Officer', 'totalEarnings': 560.0, 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Dubbed London's "Wizard of Winton", David Harding's main fund was down in 2012 and the firm saw some capital outflows. It now manages about $26 billion. Harding tried to join Wall Street after graduating, but all the American investment banks he applied to turned him down. He took a trainee position at a small broker, then became a futures trader at one of the U.K.'s first futures funds. In 1987 he co-founded a quant-driven firm, AHL, which sold to Man Group. In 1997 he founded his second firm, Winton, his middle name. It is now the world's biggest managed futures firm. He made a record 20 million pound donation to Cambridge's physics department to advance studies in sustainability. Likes punk rock, hiking. Did textual analysis of the bible.
title: Investor
employment: {'name': 'Winton Capital Management', 'title': 'Chairman & Head of Research', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Developer of Bangkok's Skytrain, Keeree Kanjanapas becomes a billionaire for the first time as shares of BTS Group Holdings, the company he founded and chairs, gained 90% in the past year on the back of growing ridership and higher ticket prices. He spun-off VGI Global Media, the company's out-of-home ad operation, in what was one of last year's most successful IPOs in the country. BTS plans a $1.2 billion IPO this year of an infrastructure fund to build new mass transit lines in Thailand and elsewhere in Asia. The Bangkok city government, under control of Thailand's opposition Democrat party, extended the company's operating contract by an additional 30 years in May, but the move is under investigation after being challenged by politicians of the Pheu Thai Party, which controls the national government.  He is the younger brother of Anant, whose Bangkok Land Co. developed Muang Thong Thani, a vast high-rise condo complex that became an emblem of real estate speculation in the 1997 financial crisis.

name: Billionaires
bio: Natural resource investor Thomas Kaplan made nearly $2 billion in 2007 when he sold an East Texas natural gas field. He used some of that money to make bets on gold and silver, acquiring stakes in mining development firms NovaGold Resources and Gabriel Resources. His natural resources group, Electrum, also expanded into silver assets. Kaplan's fortune has slid $500 million in the last year as gold and silver prices have declined. His sister, Ellen, filed a suit against him alleging that she and her family were unlawfully removed as potential beneficiaries of trusts tied to the Texas natural gas payout; Kaplan denies any wrongdoing. Ellen's son Aguiar also sued Kaplan, claiming he deserved proceeds from the sale. Kaplan countersued. In June 2012 Aguiar disappeared off the coast of Ft. Lauderdale.  There has been speculation that Aguiar faked his own death. Kaplan is chairman of the 92nd Street Y in Manhattan. He is also executive chairman of Panthera, a foundation dedicated to the preservation of wild cats. He and his wife have also endowed the Wildlife Conservation Research Unit at Oxford University, Kaplan's alma mater, and founded the Orianne Society, which supports the conservation of longleaf pine forests and their fauna in the southeastern United States.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ali Metin Kazanci owns Kazanci Holding which has interests in generator production, natural gas distribution and electricity plant operation. The holding sold 13.3% of its electricity production company traded on the ISE, Aksa Energy, to Goldman Sachs for $240 million last year. Around the same time, Ali transferred one third of his shares in Kazanci Holding to his youngest son Cemil Kazanci, who joins him on the billionaires list.

name: Billionaires
bio: Koo Bon-Neung is chairman of Heesung Group, Korea's largest maker of LCD backlight units and a supplier to LG Electronics. His younger brother, billionaire Koo Bon-Sik, runs Heesung. Koo Bon-Neung is a shareholder in LG. His billionaire brother Koo Bon-Moo is chairman of giant electronics conglomerate LG Group. After Koo Bon-Moo's only son was killed in an accident, in 2004 Koo Bon-Moo adopted Koo Bon-Sik's son, Koo Kwang-mo, who is expected to take over the LG Group. A one-time baseball player, Koo Bon-Neung became head of the Korea Baseball Organization in August 2011.

name: Billionaires
bio: Timur Kulibaev, son-in-law of Kazakhstan's president, Nursultan Nazarbaev, rejoins the billionaire ranks in 2013 on the rising revenues and profits of his Halyk Bank, whose stock price is up more than 40% in the past year. In 2011 Kulibaev resigned from his chairmanship of the sovereign wealth fund that controls the country's oil industry; he remains head of oil, gas and energy trade association KazEnergy and director of Gazprom, and he has a reported stake in engineering firm KazStroyService. He also leads the National Economic Chamber Atameken Union, a chamber of commerce organization. As the President of the Kazakhstan Boxing Federation, he was instrumental in bringing the 2013 AIBA World Boxing Championships to Astana, Kazakhstan.

name: Billionaires
bio: Dinara Kulibaeva, daughter of Kazakhstan's president, Nursultan Nazarbaev, rejoins billionaire ranks on rising revenues and profits of Halyk Bank, which she owns together with her husband, billionaire Timur Kulibaev. The bank's stock price is up more than 40% in the past year. A graduate of the Institute of Theater Arts, in Moscow, Kulibaeva is head of the Kazakhstan president's education foundation, which provides aid to needy students.

name: Billionaires
bio: Li Shuirong's wealth continues its multiyear slump, and is down $1 billion from a year ago, as lower prices for its plastics-related products hurt his main business, Rongsheng Petrochemical. Its revenue edged up 0.4% in the first nine months of 2012 to $2.9 billion, yet profit tanked 80% to $49 million. Even amid the downturn, the company announced new investments in Dalian and Ningbo. Li invests in real estate through his Ningbo United Group.

name: Billionaires
bio: Jose Llado Fernandez-Urrutia, new to Forbes' billionaire ranks, founded contractor Tecnicas Reunidas in 1960 and built it into a multibillion-dollar company, with revenues estimated at $3.6 billion in 2012. Projects include three petrochemical plants in Saudi Arabia. In February it won the bid to build a refinery for Lukoil in Russia. Llado owns 37% of the company and serves as chairman. Shares rose some 30% over the last year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Kolkata-born resident of Thailand Aloke Lohia grew Indorama Ventures from a small trading outfit to the world's largest polyester company by capacity. It reported revenues of $7.8 billion in 2012,  missing analysts' target of $8 billion, due to overcapacity. As margins took hit, the stock was down more than 10% in the past year. Company announced a12 month moratorium on M&A deals in November. Brother Sri Prakash Lohia is one of Indonesia's richest.

name: Billionaires
bio: Texas legend Red McCombs hosted the inaugural Formula One Grand Prix race last November at the new race track the Circuit of the Americas in Austin. McCombs got his start selling cars--Ford Edsels. At peak he owned 55 dealerships, and still has a handful today. "All other products pale in comparison with the desire to have a car." Over the years has owned and sold Clear Channel Communications and pro-sports teams the Nuggets, Spurs and Vikings. Breeds cattle, drills for oil, builds condos. New autobiography last year "Big Red" gives secrets of business success. "Attitude is absolutely the most critical element in selling anything. You can't fake attitude." Heir apparent, daughter Marsha Shields, getting more involved in the business.

name: Billionaires
bio: Shigenobu Nagamori is chairman and CEO of Nidec, the world's top maker of micromotors for hard disks and optical drives. The company's share price is down 30% over the past year on weak outlook for PCs. Nagamori is countering the decline with investments in industrial technology and motors for things like car steering systems and wind power generators. Nidec also has its own deep pool of patents and invests heavily in R&D, ranking 22nd on Forbes magazine's list of innovative companies in 2012.

name: Billionaires
bio: Infosys cofounder and former CEO, Nandan Nilekani, joined the government four years ago to become head of the Unique Identification Authority of India, which is issuing identity numbers to all Indian residents. "It was a big shift from my comfort zone," he told Forbes recently. It has issued 280 million online IDs so far. The government has started using these identity numbers to provide direct cash transfers of various entitlements. He and his wife, Rohini, are prominent philanthropists; they took part in Azim Premji's philanthropy meeting with Bill Gates in Bangalore last June.

name: Billionaires
bio: Maxim Nogotkov controls the privately held retailer Svyaznoy, now the second-largest cell phone merchant in Russia. Nogotkov got his start selling computer programs while in school and later began selling cordless phones. He dropped out of college to focus on building his business trading cell phones wholesale before moving into retail. He's also founder of online store Enter and owns a chain of jewelry shops under franchise from Danish company Pandora. In 2010 Nogotkov founded Svyaznoy Bank. Last year he committed a reported $6 million to the digital democracy group Yopolis.

name: Billionaires
bio: Casino and pachisuro machine mogul Kazuo Okada is fighting his former partner, US billionaire Steve Wynn, in a series of lawsuits that aim to counter Wynn's redemption of Okada's former 20% stake in Wynn Resorts. Okada, who helped launched Wynn Resorts in 2000 with a $260 million investment, is owed $1.9 billion from the casino. Okada suffered a series of setbacks in February when he resigned his board seat ahead of a shareholder vote to oust him. Wynn Resorts reported that Okada's removal was approved by an near-unanimous vote at a special shareholder meeting. In a statement, Okada's Universal Entertainment claimed the special meeting had no purpose. Okada's removal was approved by 99.6% of the shares voting at the special meeting. Okada faces an investigation in the Phillipines for allegedly giving improper payments to gambling regulators; he is partnered with the property company of Phillipines billionaire John Gokongwei on a Manila casino.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ranjan Pai heads Manipal Education & Medical Group,which operates 6 colleges and 15 hospitals, and has interests also in stem cell therapy and clinical research. His grandfather started the business when he opened India's first privately owned medical school in Manipal, a town in Karnataka, in 1953. His father took charge after an acrimonious family split in 1978. Pai, who also has a medical degree, quit his job in the U.S. at age 28 when he was asked to take over his family's delayed medical school project in Malaysia. He succeeded and has been with the business ever since, turning Manipal into a global brand in education. Pai is buying back stakes that software tycoons Azim Premji and N.R.Narayana Murthy both personally held in Manipal that pegs the valuation of his education firm at $1.2 billion

name: Billionaires
bio: Peter Peterson's fortune comes from alternative investment giant The Blackstone Group, which he  founded with fellow billionaire Stephen Schwarzman in 1985. Peterson served as the chairman of Lehman Brothers  from 1973 to 1984 and as Commerce Secretary under President Richard Nixon. From 2000 to 2004 he headed the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. In 2008 he left Blackstone with a payout of $1.85 billion. He founded the Peter G. Peterson Foundation, which works on raising public awareness about issues related to the country's long-term fiscal sustainability problems, with a focus on the federal deficit and entitlement programs. The son of poor Greek immigrants, he has also spoken out in favor of wealthy people like himself shouldering higher taxes and reduced benefits. He has authored numerous books, including an autobiography, and is married to Joan Ganz Cooney, the creator of Sesame Street.

name: Billionaires
bio: Michael Price manages his wealth through MFP Investors, which currently holds stock such as Bank of America, Ubiquiti Networks and Intel. In 2012 Price spoke out about the value of some big financial institutions, saying certain parts of companies like Goldman Sachs and Citigroup are worth more than the entire banks. He started his career in finance in 1975, as a research assistant at Heine Securities. By 1988 he was the sole owner of the company. An expert value investor, Price increased the value of the mutual funds he managed to more than $17 billion before selling Heine Securities to Franklin Securities for $670 million in 1996. He donated $25 million to Yeshiva University in 2001 for a biomedical research center in his name and $18 million to his alma mater, the University of Oklahoma, to form the Price College of Business in 1997.
title: President

name: Billionaires
bio: Suzan Sabanci Dincer is part of the third generation of the Sabancis to run the family holdings. She is chairman of her family's publicly traded Akbank. The bank's stock price is up roughly 20% over the past year and have helped increase her fortune by $300 million since March 2012. Her husband, Haluk Dincer, is chairman of Sabanci Holding's retail group. Retail electronics store Teknosa, of which she owns 2%, went public last year. Suzan is a dance aficionado.

name: Billionaires
bio: Board member and shareholder of her large family conglomerate, Sabanci Holding, Serra Sabanci returns to the billionaires list this year after dropping off in 2012. With markets soaring, the family's Akbank is benefitting; the stock price is up 21% over the past year. Serra is the niece of fellow billionaire Sevket Sabanci and cousin of billionaire Suzan Sabanci Diner.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sevket Sabanci is one of the original five brothers who built Sabanci Holding. Although he still has shares of the group, in 2000 he started another large Turkish conglomerate, Esas Holding, with his daughter Emine Sabanci Kamisli and his son Ali Sabanci. Esas invests in food, entertainment, health and aviation as well as real estate. Pegasus airlines which is managed by his son Ali Sabanci recently ordered 100 planes from Airbus for 12 billion dollars.

name: Billionaires
bio: Silvio Santos is new to the Forbes Billionaires list this year. He is one of Brazil's most famous entrepreneurs. His Grupo Silvio Santos controls more than 30 companies and reports annual sales of $2 billion. He began his career in the 1940s when he was in his early teens, working as a street vendor in Rio de Janeiro. A radio scout noticed Santos' ability to sell almost anything, including plastic covers for voting IDs. The scout got Santos a job at a local radio station. With the advent of TV in the 1960s Santos became a popular TV personality. He still appears on TV and viewers love him. In 1981 he founded TVS, later rebranded as SBT (Sistema Brasileiro de Televsiao). The company is the third-largest broadcaster in Brazil. He also owns Jequiti Cosmeticos, a fast-growing beauty brand. Coty is reportedly bidding to buy the company. In addition he owns Liderança Capitalizaçao, which sells Tele Sena, a one-time payment bond. He was the controlling shareholder of Banco Panamericano SA, which he sold to fellow billionaire Andre Esteves' Banco BTG Pactual SA in 2011 for $270 million, after the company was involved in an alleged $2 billion accounting fraud scandal. Santos used the proceeds to offset Banco Panamericano's losses, which were assumed by BTG Pactual SA.

name: Billionaires
bio: Moroccan entrepreneur Anas Sefrioui formed real estate developer Groupe Addoha in 1988, but his big break came nearly ten years later when he won a contract to build a chunk of government-subsidized housing under the patronage of Morocco's late King Hassan II. In 2005 he won a $1 billion state contract to build more housing units. Groupe Addoha went public the following year. In 2012 Sefrioui expanded into Ivory Coast, Guinea-Conakry and Cameroon, building cement plants. Shares in Groupe Addoha have fallen in the past year, shaving $300 million off his net worth.

name: Billionaires
bio: Shaul Shani became involved in the founding of technology companies in 1982, with Oshap Technologies, later followed by others including Technomatix and Sapiens. Those three all went public on the Nasdaq and were eventually sold to strategic buyers. Shani was also a lead investor in Precise Software, DSP Group and others. In 1999 he founded Global Village Telecom, in Brazil; it went public in 2007 and was sold to Vivendi in 2009 for $4.5 billion. In 2007 his secretive investment vehicle, Swarth Group, partnered with Ashmore, a U.K.-based investment group with assets under management of $71 billion, to take over Israel-based ECI Telecom for $1.25 billion, delisting that company from the Nasdaq. Swarth, a privately held company, focuses not only on telecoms, software and cyber security but also financial investments involving mezzanine loans, capital markets and algorithmic trading.

name: Billionaires
bio: Evgeny Shvidler, who became an American citizen in 1994, is the best friend of Russian billionaire Roman Abramovich. He lives in London in Belgravia, but also owns a house in Snowmass, Colorado. Among his interests are a stake in Russian steelmaker Evraz, Moscow real estate and cash from the sale of his Sibneft stake to Gazprom in 2005. In June 2012, a pension consultant urged Evraz shareholders to oppose Shvidler's appointment to its first board (along with several other board members), citing "governance concerns," but shareholders ultimately voted Shvidler on. He was also recently appointed onto the board of AFC Energy, which develops alkaline fuel cell technology. Shvidler's vineyard at his Château Thenac in France produces nine grape varieties and his wines are beginning to garner positive reviews from critics; Shvidler's property also has two plum orchards. His 370-foot yacht, Le Grand Bleu, was a gift from Abramovich. He was the primary funder for the rebuilding of a Jewish school in England that is now called Beit Shvidler Primary School.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of hedge fund firm Elliott Management, which oversees $21 billion in assets. Its two main funds returned more than 12% in 2012. Singer's hedge fund has been waging a high-profile battle with Argentina over defaulted bonds, going so far in 2012 as to convince the government of Ghana to at one point take possession of an Argentine naval vessel. Elliott's investments include backing the movie version of Les Miserables and a lawsuit against Walt Disney Co., over Stan Lee's iconic superhero characters. The hedge fund also frequently  takes activist positions, like its recent investment in Hess Corp. A former Wall Street lawyer, Singer has been a big supporter of Republican political causes and gay rights. He played a major role in the passage of marriage equality in New York.
title: Investor

name: Billionaires
bio: Edwin Soeryadjaya's Adara Energy, like other coal producers, suffered a drop in its share price this year, and as a result his wealth modestly declined. His investment firm, Saratoga Capital, also has stakes in Provident Agro, a plantation company, Interra Resources, an oil and gas exploration outfit, and Mandala Airlines, which has been struggling. In December 2012 he was one of several businessmen accused of involvement when an Indonesian couple, Maya Ambarsari and Reza Nazruddin, seized Intrepid Mines' Tujuh Bukit drilling project and ordered Intrepid's workers to leave. The pair claimed they were working with Soeryadjaya and others. His telecom tower company, Tower Bersama, is reported to be a candidate for a merger with the country's biggest telecom firm, Telkomunikasi Indonesia.

name: Billionaires
bio: Helmut Sohmen, an Austrian citizen who lives in Hong Kong, saw his net worth tumble by $ 900 million over the past two years as shares of shipping concern BW Offshore and the value of BW Maritime's very large crude tankers cratered. He chairs BW Group, whose fleet of nearly 100 oil tankers and gas carriers is one of the world's largest maritime groups. Sohmen settled in Hong Kong more than 40 years ago and married the daughter of shipping tycoon Yue-Kong Pao. He is the recipient of China's Friendship Ambassador award for his contributions to China-Austria ties. A Southern Methodist University law school alumnus, he supports a graduate scholarship program for Chinese lawyers studying at SMU's Dedman School of Law. His Oxford and Harvard-educated eldest son, Andreas Sohmen-Pao, is chief executive of BW Maritime and BW Gas. In 1991 he founded the Sohmen-Far-East-Foundation to assist young Austrians in establishing new contacts in Asia.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mark Stevens is a former partner at Silicon Valley venture capital firm Sequoia Capital. After nearly 20 years at the firm he switched his status to special limited partner last year and created his own firm, S-Cubed Capital. Stakes in Google and LinkedIn, both of which were backed by Sequoia, have buoyed his fortune. An electrical engineer, he scored an early investment in 1999 in graphics chipmaker Nvidia, where he is still a board member. He is lecturing part time at Stanford University Graduate School of Business and has invested in some of his students' startups. He has been a generous donor to the University of Southern California, where he is a trustee, and to Santa Clara University, his wife's alma mater.

name: Billionaires
bio: Jon Stryker, one of three heirs to the Stryker medical equipment company, was identified as one of the top five donors to President Obama's reelection campaign. He has given $2 million to the Priorities USA Action super PAC and has given $66,000 in contributions to Obama and the Democratic Party. He has also given millions of dollars to groups supporting gay rights and the conservation of apes. In 2012, he gave $23 million to establish the Arcus Center for Social Justice Leadership at Kalamazoo College, and is funding construction of the center's new $5 million headquarters.

name: Billionaires
bio: Vincent Tan urned over the chairmanship of his conglomerate Berjaya Group to son Robin, who is also chief executive. Berjaya Corp. shares lost ground as uncertainly in an election year bedeviled two of its main industries, property and gaming. In August it opened the first RadioShack store in Kuala Lumpur and plans 1,000 more in Southeast Asia over 10 years. Won approval to list its lottery operator, Sports Toto, in Singapore. Property arm is developing a $3.5 billion resort in South Korea's Jeju Island. Tan got his start working as a bank clerk and insurance salesman but his break came at the age of 29 when he bought his first McDonald's franchise. He caused a stir last summer when he changed the jersey colors of his Cardiff Football Club from blue to red with a new dragon crest. He recently signed the Giving Pledge, committing to donating half his wealth during his lifetime.

name: Billionaires
bio: Tsai Ming-Kai, chairman of Taiwan's Mediatek, returns to the Forbes Billionaires List this year on strong demand for mobile phone handsets that use the company's chipsets. Mediatek is especially poised to benefit from growth in China's smartphone market. Net profit this year is projected to climb to $950 million, a 75% increase from 2012, according to a forecast by SinoPac Securities in Taipei. Customers include Lenovo, Acer and Asus. A merger agreement with MStar Semiconductor of Taiwan is pending.

name: Billionaires
bio: Wang Yong is new to the Forbes Billionaires list. He is the founder and chairman of Xiwang Group, Asia's biggest manufacturer of food sweeteners. Boosted by China's growing sweet tooth, Xiwang expanded its production capacity of starch sugar to one million tons per year in 2012. Founded in 1986, Xiwang Group's core business is manufacturing and processing agricultural products such as cornstarch, glucose, corn oil and feed. It has also expanded into the steel, real estate and thermoelectricity industries over the past decade. It employs 14,000 people and consists of one joint venture and nine major subsidiaries, including Xiwang Sugar Holding, Xiwang Foodstuffs, and Xiwang Special Steel. Wang and his son hold about 66% of the group.

name: Billionaires
bio: Charlotte Colket Weber, the granddaughter of condensed soup inventor and Campbell Soup founder John T. Dorrance, has been on the board of Campbell Soup with her cousins Bennett Dorrance and Mary Alice Dorrance Malone since 1990. A devoted equestrian, Weber owns and manages Live Oak Stud, a 4,500-acre thoroughbred farm and commercial cattle operation in Ocala, Florida. She studied art and design at l'Ecole du Louvre in Paris and is a patron of the arts. She sits on the chairman's council of The Metropolitan Museum of Art and in 1988, donated a collection of Chinese art worth $20 million to the museum. She also supports women's and children's initiatives like the New York Women's Foundation and Work to Ride in Philadelphia through her philanthropic Live Oak Foundation.
title: Director

name: Billionaires
bio: Allan Wong's net worth is up a tick from a year ago. Shares of his VTech Holding, a maker of electronic learning products that also does contract manufacturing and sells mobile phones, have held their value in a tough global economy. Investors rewarded the company for a 3% increase in net profit to $91.2 million in the six months to September. Sales rose by 2.1% to $876 million. Wong is a graduate of the University of Wisconsin-Madison.

name: Billionaires
bio: GoPro founder and CEO Nicholas Woodman rode the wave of the world's fastest growing camera company to become a billionaire. It's been 10 years in the making for Woodman, 37, who started the company in 2002 and built the first camera prototypes in his bedroom with his mom's sewing machine and a drill. According to friends, he would work 18-hour days in his bedroom, only emerging to show off new features and occasionally declare that his product would make him a millionaire.  GoPro came out with its first camera, a 35-millimeter waterproof film version, in 2004. Today, the camera shoots full video in cinema quality HD, allowing anyone from professional surfer Kelly Slater to amatuer snowboarders to capture their adventures. Revenues, which surpassed $500 million in 2012, have nearly doubled every year since the company's creation and Woodman maintains that GoPro has been profitable from day one. In December 2012, Taiwan-based electronics manufacturer Foxconn made a $200 million investment in the company for an 8.88%. At a $2.25 billion valuation, that backing made Woodman, who owns nearly half the company according to sources close to the company, a billionaire.

name: Billionaires
bio: Wu Yiling's Chinese herbal medicine maker Shijiazhuang Yiling Pharmaceutical has had a tough stretch in the past year following worries about the safety of drug capsules. Although his own products weren't cited for problems, Yiling's sales fell by nearly a quarter to $171 million in the first three months of 2012. Net profit during the period plunged 46% to $26 million. That was followed by a 30% swoon in its share price in the fall, cutting into the wealth of its billionaire chairman. The Shenzhen-listed company produces Chinese medicine for heart diseases and the flu. Parent company Hebei Yiling Pharmaceutical Group also owns the Hebei Yiling Hospital in Shijiazhuang city in Hebei Province. Dad's son Wu Xiangjun, who holds degrees in business and Chinese medicine, is a vice president; daughter Wu Rui, who holds a law degree, is a deputy general manager.
title: Entrepreneur

name: Billionaires
bio: Yan Zhi took his Wuhan-based shopping mall operator Zall Development Holding public in Hong Kong in July 2011 and has fared better than many other real estate tycoons, though his company has been battered by tougher times. Zall Development's revenue for the first half of 2012 fell 68% to $84 million, dragging down profit 54% to $62 million. Despite that, Yan's net worth is up $100 million from a year ago. In December Yan bought a 75% stake in Hong Kong-listed port operator CIG Yangtze Ports, also located in Wuhan, now worth about $30 million. Yan is a vice chairman of the Wuhan Federation of Industry & Commerce, and a representative of the Hubei Provincial People's Congress.

name: Billionaires
bio: Beer billionaire Dick Yuengling is the fifth-generation owner of America's oldest operating brewery, D.G. Yuengling & Son, founded in 1829. The company stubbornly remains private, despite steep competition and frequent acquisitions in the beer industry. Sole-owner Yuengling has turned down offers from all the major players and vows never to sell. In a 1996 Forbes story, he scoffed at the idea of adding a partner, noting: "I couldn't even get along with my own father." He bought out his dad in 1985, when revenues were only $6 million and they counted barrels sold by the thousands. The Pottsville, Pennsylvania company now sells more than 2.5 million barrels of beer a year and pulls in hundreds of millions of dollars in revenues. Yuengling favors measured growth - the company is only in 14 states so far - over incurring debt, and he would rather wear jeans and drive an old car than sell out and flaunt his wealth.

name: Billionaires
bio: In 2012 Mikhail Abyzov became a minister in the Russian Federation's cabinet. He started in business in the early 1990s, while a student at Moscow State University, importing food from Bulgaria. Later he assembled a controlling stake in Novosibirskenergo, the biggest of the regional energy companies that have remained independent of state monopoly. He did a stint at the government-owned energy concern RAO UES, resigned in 2005, and then bought several engineering and construction companies, which he combined to form his E4 Group, one of the biggest private construction subcontractors in Russia's energy industry.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fawzi Al Kharafi is the vice chairman of the Kharafi Group, one of the Middle East's biggest holding companies. Until his death of a heart attack in April 2011, his brother Nasser had overseen the family business. The group has major stakes in Kuwaiti companies including National Bank of Kuwait and telecom company Zain. Its Americana division operates several fast-food joints throughout the Middle East including KFC, Hardee's and Krispy Kreme. The Kharafis are among the largest shareholders in the doughnut chain. His brothers Jassim and Mohannad are also billionaires.

name: Billionaires
bio: Jassim Al Kharafi is the eldest brother of Nasser Al Kharafi, who died unexpectedly of a heart attack while on a visit to Cairo two years ago. Jassim, Nasser and six other siblings inherited the Kharafi Group from their father Mohammed. The group is one of the Middle East's biggest holding companies. While Nasser ran the business, Jassim pursued his passion for politics and served for thirteen years, until 2011, as speaker of the National Assembly. His brothers Fawzi and Mohannad are also billionaires.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mohannad Al Kharafi is the younger brother of Nasser Al Kharafi, who passed away in 2011 from a heart attack. Along with brothers Jassim, Nasser, Fawzi and four other siblings, he inherited a stake in the Kharafi Group from father Mohammed. The group is one of the Middle East's biggest holding companies. Nasser ran the business, which has major stakes in Kuwaiti companies, including the National Bank of Kuwait, and telecom company Zain. Its Americana division operates several fast-food joints throughout the Middle East, including KFC, Hardee's, and Krispy Kreme. The Kharafis are one of the doughnut chain's largest shareholders.

name: Billionaires
bio: Venugopal Dhoot who runs Videocon, Indian maker of electronics and appliances, is waiting to cash in on energy investments: an oil find in a deep sea basin in Brazil; he claims that Videocon's 10% stake in a Mozambique oil field is worth over $2 billion. Younger brother Pradip recently moved to Dubai to oversee oil interests. He was mulling a bid for an Indian Premier League cricket team put up for sale by its cash-strapped owner, but later backed out. Instead, his Videocon D2H, a provider of direct-to-home services which he's planning to list, has agreed to be the lead sponsor of Mukesh Ambani's Mumbai Indians cricket team for $6 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: David Einhorn, the founder and head of hedge fund firm Greenlight Capital, has delivered annualized returns north of 19% since inception in 1996, but in 2012 his hedge fund trailed the U.S. stock market as a big bet on Apple soured near the end of the year. He has been actively pushing Apple to return capital to shareholders, going so far as to sue the company over corporate governance matters in February. He did find great success in 2012 at the poker table, finishing 3rd in the $1 million buy-in World Series of Poker's No Limit Hold 'Em event. He donated the $4.35 million in prize money to City Year, a charity focused on increasing high school graduation rates. Einhorn is known for sometimes successfully betting against companies like Allied Capital in 2002 and Lehman Brothers, ahead of its bankruptcy. More recently, he successfully shorted Green Mountain Coffee. Einhorn, whose grandfather had Parkinson's, sits on the board of the Michael J. Fox Foundation; he's also a board member of the Robin Hood Foundation.
title: Founder & President

name: Billionaires
bio: William Clay Ford, 87, is the last-surviving grandchild of Henry Ford. He retired from Ford Motor's board of directors in 2005 and is no longer directly involved in the company. But the Ford family still controls 40% through their Class B shares. Ford's North American recovery is solid, with a strong 10.4% operating margin, but mounting losses in Europe are weighing on the company's stock, which had been rising until early this year. Meanwhile, Ford is spending heavily in China to catch up with other global players. Bill Ford's most valuable holding is the Detroit Lions football team, which he bought in 1963 for $4.5 million, and is now worth $581 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Stock market investor with a cult following, Rakesh Jhunjhunwala recently said that he doesn't like being called India's Warren Buffet. But stocks he buys continue to jump on news of his investment. One fan writes a  blog called The Secret Journal of Rakesh Jhunjunwala. Current top holdings include watchmaker Titan Industries and pharma firm Lupin Laboratories. He was looking to sell his 36% stake in listed IT training firm Aptech but couldn't get price he was asking. He's lately increased his holding in infotech firm Geometric, part of billionaire Adi Godrej's group. A Bollywood fan, he co-produced English Vinglish that was released last October and became a box office hit.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sergei Kislov owns Yug Rusi (vegetable oil production and grain exports) and oil refinery. Yug Rusi has about 200,000 hectares of land (about 500,000 acres). Main vegetable oil brand is Zolotaya Semechka (Golden Seed). Sergei Kislov graduated from Rostov University specializing in physics, started business in 1992. In 2007 became honored consul of France in South of Russia. In the beginning of 1990s Sergey Kislov founded agricultural holding Yug Rusi. The company specializes in vegetable oil production and also grain exports. In 2000s the holding financed construction of oil refinery.

name: Billionaires
bio: The daughter of Samsung Chairman Lee Kun-Hee, Lee Boo-Jin became the first female president of a Samsung company when she was promoted to head up Hotel Shilla and Samsung Everland in December 2010. Samsung Everland has operations in construction, energy conservation services and amusement park. In 2011 she became the first of Lee Kun-Hee's children to sit on a board, when she was appointed to the Hotel Shilla board. She tried to secure a 10-year contract to run the duty free shop at LAX airport, but lost it to DFS Group, the existing operator of the stores. Her husband Im Woo-jae was promoted to vice president of Samsung Electro-Mechanics in 2011.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ni Zhaoxing is a newcomer to the Forbes Billionaires List this year. The chairman of the Zhongrong Group has interests in real estate and energy. The Zhejiang native invested in Shanghai real estate more than a decade ago, and has reaped profits from its subsequent boom, through projects such as Zhongrong Jasper Tower in the Lujiazui financial district. One important project these days is "Chang'an No.1" in Beijing, a development featuring 78 European-style villas set in a mountain landscape. Ni's daughter Alice is heir apparent.

name: Billionaires
bio: Patrick Ryan is the chairman and CEO of Ryan Specialty Group, an insurance brokerage. He got his start selling insurance policies after graduating from Northwestern University and founded Pat Ryan & Associates in 1964. He merged Ryan Specialty Group with Combined International in 1982 and renamed the company Aon, which became the world's largest reinsurance broker. In 2008 he retired to focus on Chicago's failed bid for the 2016 Olympic Games. He launched a wholesale insurance brokerage and holding company, Ryan Specialty, two years later. The company has been rapidly expanding, acquiring two insurance firms in the fall of 2012, Atlantic Star Intermediaries, which specializes in real estate and construction, and U.K. company Direct Group. Ryan also owns a 20% in the NFL's Chicago Bears.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Ryan Specialty Group', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Sun Weijie debuts on this year's billionaire's list after shares of his Yantai Jereh Oilfield Services Group, a provider of oilfield equipment and services, rose by more than half in the past year on the Shenzhen exchange. Sales in first nine months of 2012 increased by 52% to $241 million; net profit rose by 38% too $64 million. The company is based in Yantai in Shandong Province but also has operations in Houston. Sun is a graduate of the Shandong institute of Business and Technology.

name: Billionaires
bio: Graham Weston made his fortune from Rackspace.com, a company that does web-hosting and cloud-computing. Raised on a ranch near San Antonio, he started his first venture in high school, taking photos of livestock shows and selling them to contestants. After college at Texas A&M he went into real estate. In 1998 three college students asked him to invest in their web-hosting startup and Weston joined Rackspace as CEO, stepping down in 2006. He is now chairman and the company's largest shareholder. He supports San Antonio science and education projects including a computer terminal at the public library where students can see the view from a ship exploring the ocean's floor. He supports efforts to expand San Antonio's tech community, and he backs a local initiative that would raise sales taxes to fund pre-kindergarten programs.

name: Billionaires
bio: Bill Ackman seems to thrive on drama. In late 2012 he announced a massive short position in Herbalife, declaring the nutritional supplement company a pyramid scheme. Rival hedge fund titans Daniel Loeb and Carl Icahn challenged him, with Loeb announcing a long position in Herbalife and Icahn questioning Ackman's investment skills in a live showdown on CNBC. The stakes are big for Pershing Square Capital Management, the $12 billion hedge fund firm Ackman founded. His first hedge fund, Gotham Partners, was wound down in 2002 after a big bet on a golf course venture turned sour and investors asked for their money back. An attempt to salvage the investment failed when shareholders won a lawsuit preventing Ackman from merging a real estate company with the bleeding golf course company. Meanwhile, Ackman was making another big bet, this time against bond insurer MBIA, whose triple A rating he questioned in a research report. The report was controversial, of course, but Ackman was eventually proven right as MBIA began to crumble amid the financial crisis.
title: Founder, CEO
employment: {'name': 'Pershing Square Capital Management, L.P.', 'title': 'Founder, CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False, 'employees': 47, 'employeesYear': 2012}

name: Billionaires
bio: Tennessee Titans owner Kenneth "Bud" Adams, Jr., expressed his grave disappointment in his team's 2012 performance, saying that it was one of the worst in his more than 50 year as an owner. One of the original owners in the American Football League, Adams brought pro football to Houston with a $25,000 purchase of the aptly-named Oilers. In 1997, after a stadium dispute, he moved the team to Tennessee and gave them a new name. Adams founded ADA Oil Co. in 1946 after returning from the Navy. He later renamed it Adams Resources & Energy and took it public in 1974. Adams and his wife Nancy were married for 62 years before she passed away in 2009.

name: Billionaires
bio: Bassam Alghanim is no longer involved in the family holding company. The firm, Alghanim Industries, has a major stake in Gulf Bank of Kuwait. Alghanim and his brother Kutayba inherited the group from their father, but have been fighting over division of the assets. Bassam sued his brother in the U.S., alleging that Kutayba and his son Omar hacked into his email. In October 2011 a U.K. judge found two people liable for hacking into Bassam Alghanim's email on what looked like orders from Kutayba and his son. In the U.S. a judge has put the case on hold, pending arbitration in Kuwait.

name: Billionaires
bio: Kutayba Alghanim and his brother Bassam have been fighting over the division of the assets they inherited their father. The assets include Kuwaiti conglomerate Alghanim Industries and a stake in Gulf Bank. The feud intensified when Kutayba's son Omar, a Harvard MBA grad, took over the reigns of the family holding company, which sells General Motors vehicles, among other things. Bassam accused Kutayba and Omar in U.S. courts of hacking into his email to gain the upper hand in negotiations. In October 2011 a U.K. judge ruled that Kutayba and Omar may have orchestrated the hacking. In the U.S. a judge put the case on hold, pending arbitration in Kuwait.

name: Billionaires
bio: Igor Altushkin is the founder and largest shareholder of RMK, Russia's third-largest copper producer, though in spring 2011 he sold a 20% stake to Ruslan Baysarov. After the sale, he bought a giant coal field in Tuva from Sergey Pugachev, a former senator, with plans to invest more than $4 billion in it. Then in 2012 he revealed that he had "suddenly" discovered he had a debt of about $2 billion, whereupon he returned the Tuva field to Pugachev. In the fall of 2009, together with Iskander Makhmudov's UGMK mining company, he bought a controlling stake in the Chelyabinsk Zinc Factory, the largest zinc producer in Russia. He started his career in the early 1990s trading scrap metals. In 1997 he established Uralelectromed-Vtortsvetmet, which became the main supplier of scrap and copper to UGMK. He purchased Madonna's former home in London and is a major supporter of the Russian Orthodox Church and a father of six.

name: Billionaires
bio: Roberto Angelini Rossi heads Chile's Angelini Group, which invests primarily in natural resources. The group's largest holding is publicly-traded Antarchile, which distributes fuel, operates fishing and shipping businesses and invests in energy and forestry. The Angelini Group is the largest owner of forest land in Latin America, with 4 million acres throughout Chile, Argentina, Brazil and Uruguay. In September 2012, Antarchile's forestry subsidiary, Arauco, entered North America with the purchase of Canada's Flakeboard. In 2009, Roberto Angelini struck a deal with Scandinavian paper maker Stora Enso to build a eucalyptus pulp mill in Uruguay. In late 2010, the Angelini Group purchased a 59% stake in Proenergia, a Colombian gas and fuel distributor, for $45 million. The Angelini family is very private, typically eschewing publicity. The family group was previously headed by Roberto's uncle, Anacleto Angelini, who died in 2007.

name: Billionaires
bio: Edmund Ansin's father, Sidney, used proceeds from the family's Boston shoemaking business to purchase Florida real estate in the 1950s. Edmund apparently took a liking to the area, buying Miami TV station WSVN for $3.4 million in 1962. The station, still owned by Edmund's Sunbeam Television and operating as a Fox affiliate, pioneered the "if it bleeds, it leads" style of television journalism by focusing on crime and consumer interest stories. Ansin has also brought this approach to his native Boston market, where he currently operates NBC and CW affiliate stations. In January 2011, a Florida federal judge threw out Sunbeam's suit against ratings company Nielsen alleging anti-trust violations. Ansin also maintains substantial commercial real estate holdings in the southern Florida and Indianapolis areas.
title: President

name: Billionaires
bio: Shares in Kiki Barki's publicly traded coal producer, Harum Energy, fell in value in the past year, driving his wealth down by $500 million. The company is planning to increase production 8% in the next year and to improve its distribution and production, while upgrading its freight port terminal. Kiki's son Lawrence runs the company. Kiki got his engineering degree from Beijing University. He still visits China often and supports  increased trade between China and Indonesia.

name: Billionaires
bio: New Orleans Saints owner Tom Benson snapped up another city sports franchise in April 2012, buying the NBA's Hornets for $338 million. As he did with the Saints, Benson will try to turn the moribund franchise around. He has already changed the team's name to the more regionally-appropriate Pelicans. A loyal New Orleans resident, Benson also offered to buy the Times-Picayune newspaper after its corporate owners decided to cut back the print edition to three issues per week. His other local ventures include auto dealerships, the city's FOX television affiliate and real estate, including the newly renamed Benson Tower. He also owns a 122-foot yacht and a 2,500-acre ranch in Texas. His charitable efforts include the $20-million Tom and Gayle Benson Cancer Center.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ranked No. 1 on the Forbes Midas List of top technology investors in 2012 and 2011, Accel Partners Jim Breyer has been a central figure in several companies in the news lately: One of Facebook's earliest investors, he is also on the boards of Wal-Mart, News Corp. and Dell. His latest bet: with Russian billionaire Yuri Milner, Breyer recently contributed to a $15 million round of Series A funding (through Accel and personal investments) for the social news reading app Prismatic. The program personalizes news content based on the user's social channels. He also serves on the boards of Harvard Business School, the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art and is a minority owner of the Boston Celtics. He's an admitted oenophile, art connoisseur, film buff and music aficionado who loves everything from Bach to Eminem, Fellini to Christopher Nolan.
title: Investor

name: Billionaires
bio: Antonio Jose Carneiro first worked in banking and got into the electricity distribution business seven years ago, buying a stake in Brazilian electricity distributor Cataguazes Leopoldina at a bargain price when U.S. institutional investor Alliant sold its stake at a loss. The majority of his wealth comes from his shares in Energisa, a publicly-traded company that controls 10.5% of the electricity distribution in Brazil's Northeast region. Carneiro also chairs Rio de Janeiro-based real estate construction and sales company Joao Fortes Engenharia. He reportedly loves horses and soccer; he is a passionate fan of Botafogo, one of Brazil's most well known soccer clubs.

name: Billionaires
bio: Before building his fortune, real estate tycoon Leon Charney considered a career as a vocalist. Instead he became an entertainment lawyer. The son of a sewing supply salesman, he worked his way through Brooklyn Law School by singing in synagogues. He represented entertainers including Sammy Davis Jr., and then expanded his practice beyond entertainment, maximizing tax benefits for oil partnerships. He was an adviser to Jimmy Carter and he helped broker the Camp David Accords between Egypt and Israel in 1978. He bought his first building, One Times Square, on the night Jimmy Carter lost the presidential election to Ronald Reagan in 1980. He borrowed money and reinvested his income into 12 surrounding buildings. He now owns three skyscrapers in Times Square, amounting to 1.5 million square feet of commercial space. He has written four books including, most recently, "The Mystery of the Kaddish."

name: Billionaires
bio: The son of an advertising executive, Richard Chilton grew up in New Jersey and studied finance and economics at Alfred University. After graduation, his first job was at Merrill Lynch, where he worked in mergers and acquisitions. In 1985, Chilton began investing for Alliance Capital Management and later worked for fellow billionaire Herbert Allen at Allen & Co. Chilton founded Chilton Investment Co. in 1992 and serves as chairman and CEO of the firm, which now manages approximately $5 billion in assets. Chilton Investments' flagship fund produced a 12% net return in 2012. Chilton sits on the board of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chung Yong-Jin announced his resignation as vice-chairman of the board of retail giant Shinsegae Group in late February 2013, following investigations by the labor ministry into charges that the group was illegally monitoring employees to prevent them from joining a union. The group denied that Chung's resignation was related to the investigations, claiming it was intended to encourage responsibility among members of the management team. Shinsegae owns a string of department stores and the Starbucks chain in South Korea. The scion of one of Korea's most powerful families, Chung is the nephew of Samsung chairman billionaire Lee Kun-Hee. His billionaire mother, Lee Myung-Hee, is Shinsegae's chairman. Chung joined Shinsegae after graduating from Brown University in 1994. He became vice chairman in 2009. Despite the union-busting charges, Chung is known for creating a positive environment for employees, allowing them to wear jeans and t-shirts to work and setting up college funds for the children of retired workers. Most of his fortune comes from his stakes in Samsung Electronics and discount retailer E-mart, which was split off from Shinsegae in 2011.

name: Billionaires
bio: A century ago Christopher Cline's grandfather mined coal with a pickaxe in Beckley, W.V. At age 6 Cline's dad paid him a penny a bag to excavate dirt from under the porch. In 1980 dad scraped together $500,000 to buy out a mining partner and gave a share to Cline, then 21. Cline has since parlayed that start into Foresight Energy, which produces 20 million tons of coal a year and controls a total of more than 4 billion tons, much of it in Illinois. He now has a 150-acre estate in Beckley, a 34,000 square foot ocean front mansion in Florida and a yacht called Mine Game. Carlyle Group is a big investor in Foresight, and he's also sold millions of tons of reserves to Natural Resource Partners to raise cash to build mines. Despite plunging coal prices, Foresight has filed for an IPO, hopefully in 2013.

name: Billionaires
bio: Maria Ines de Lafuente Lacroze, the only child of Amalia Lacroze Fortabat, has been Argentina's richest woman since her mother died at age 90 in early 2012. The bulk of the fortune she inherited comes from the sale of Loma Negra, Argentina's largest cement making company. Her mother, "the cement lady," ran the company for nearly 25 years before selling her stake for a reported $1 billion to conglomerate Camargo Correa of Brazil in 2005. Her fortune included art, properties in Argentina, the USA and Uruguay, and over 90,000 hectares in Argentina's countryside. Maria Ines is well known for preferring philanthropy and family activities over business. With her three children, she supports the Fortabat Foundation, whose main asset is an art collection displayed in a state-of-the-art building in Puerto Madero, a fashionable neighborhood in Buenos Aires.

name: Billionaires
bio: Maria del Pino y Calvo-Sotelo, new to the billionaire ranks this year, is the eldest of Rafael del Pino y Moreno's five heirs. She has been a member of the  Board of Director of Ferrovial, S.A. since 2009. She is Vice President and General Director of Karlovy SL, a family holding company. Maria's main focus in the family business is the Del Pino Foundation. Founded in 1999 by her late father and with working capital of $154 million, the Foundation, which she chairs, focuses on developing future business leaders. It organizes conferences on globalization, grants fellowships to students and professionals with leadership qualities, and supports cultural events. She likes to travel with her husband and play tennis with her friends.

name: Billionaires
bio: Robert Duggan is new to the Forbes Billionaires list, thanks to the surging stock price of biotech firm Pharmacyclics, where he first invested in 2005. He owns 19% of the company and serves as chairman and CEO. Pharmacyclics makes a drug now in clinical trials to treat chronic lymphocytic leukemia. He assumed leadership of the company in 2008, shelving the company's other efforts to focus R&D on the cancer drug. Duggan is considered one of the founders of robotic surgery. He served as chairman of Computer Motion, the world's first robotic surgery company, from 1989, and CEO from 1997, until it was acquired by Intuitive Surgical in 2003. He has also been a private venture investor for more than 30 years and is the founder of Robert W. Duggan & Associates, which invests in medical, biomedical, high technology, information services, billboard, media and communication companies.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former Harvard hockey player made billions shorting subprime, then blew billions on LightSquared, a controversial attempt to convert satellite radio frequencies into a new cellular service. LightSquared filed for bankruptcy and he's been sued by the SEC, but fortune holding up after LightSquared bonds recovered and stock in his publicly-traded Harbinger Group doubled. The youngest of nine kids, Falcone grew up in Chisholm, Minn. Money was tight: His father was a utility superintendent, and his mother worked for 80 cents an hour at a shirt factory. Falcone majored in economics at Harvard and started on the junk bond desk at Kidder, Peabody & Co in 1985. Up until LightSquared, his biggest wipeout was losing his entire investment in troubled plastics maker AAB Manufacturing, an event he credits for having "had a profound impact upon my success as a hedge fund manager." Wife Lisa Maria is on the board of the New York City Ballet.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mikhail Fedyaev, with fellow billionaire Vladimir Gridin, controls the privately held conglomerate Sibirskiy Delovoy Soyuz (or Siberian Business Union), which has operations in coal mining, engineering, chemicals, transportation and  construction. SDS produces more than 20 million tons of coal a year and two years ago bought a fertilizers producer in Kemerovo from Sibur for about $1 billion. Fedyaev after college worked as a mechanic in a car factory. In the 1990s Fedyaev met Vladimir Gridin and, with support from Aman Tuleev, the governor of Kemerovo Oblast, they became co-owners of a coal field. Fedyaev's son Pavel became State Duma deputy for Putin's Edinaya Rossiya party in 2011.

name: Billionaires
bio: Feng Hailiang owns a broad mix of businesses across China. His Hailiang Group in Zhuji in Zhejiang Province owns copper processor Zhejiang Hailiang, which went public on the Shenzhen Stock Exchange in 2008. He also holds a stake in China-listed Sichuan Golden Summit Group, a cement outfit. Feng also has interests in education and real estate. The latter includes development projects in Chongqing, Inner Mongolia, Tibet, Ningxia and Shanghai, among other cities. Feng's sister Feng Yali is chairman of the listed company Zhejiang Hailiang.

name: Billionaires
bio: Soichiro Fukutake is head of Benesse Holdings, one of the world's largest educational services companies, which acquired Berlitz language schools in 2001. The company is branching out beyond prep courses and language instruction into businesses like nursing homes, executive training and translation services. It is also expanding schools and correspondence courses overseas, especially in China, Korea and Taiwan. Last year, Benesse sold seven of its 200 nursing home properties to a REIT in order to fund new homes. Fukutake chairs an electric car motor R&D outfit called Sim-Drive which unveiled its passenger car, the DS3 Electrum, at the Paris Motor Show last year. A resident of New Zealand, last year Fukutake merged three of his charities to form the Fukutake Foundation, which supports art, science and regional Japanese culture, and runs a contemporary art museum on a group of islands in Japan's Inland Sea.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mario Gabelli started buying stocks at the age of 13. By 34 he had founded Gabelli Asset Management, now Gamco Investors. Today, the publicly traded fund manager oversees $36.4 billion in client assets. Gabelli has a unique compensation agreement with his firm. Rather than taking a salary, bonus or stock options, Gabelli enjoys 10% of the company's pretax profit and "variable compensation." In 2011, for instance, he earned a $62 million payday. Pretax, Gabelli has received more than $700 million in compensation from Gamco since the outfit's 1999 IPO. In September 2010 Gabelli gave $25 million to his alma mater, Fordham University. It is the largest single donation in the school's history.

name: Billionaires
bio: More than a century after her grandfather John Nordstrom, who arrived in the U.S. at age 16 with $5, opened his first store in Seattle, Anne Gittinger makes her debut among the world's billionaires.
