The department store's stock is at all-time highs, as it achieved record sales and earnings for the third consecutive year. Indeed the stock is up 9% in the past year and up nearly 700% from his 2008 low.  She and her brother Bruce, who ran the company for 27 years, are the company's biggest individual shareholders. Her nephew Blake now runs the company. She is on the national board of Canine Companions for Independence, which provides people with disabilities with highly trained assistance dogs. Her husband, Wayne, is a Seattle attorney.

name: Billionaires
bio: Andrew Gotianun is founder and chairman emeritus of Filinvest Development Corporation, a conglomerate with interests in property, financial services, sugar, hospitality and utilities. Filinvest shares surged by close to a third in the past year, making him a billionaire. He took banking arm East West Bank last year and has recently entered the hospitality industry with the Crimson Resort and Spa in Mactan, Cebu and Crimson Hotel Filinvest City. The group is also setting up its first power plant and is bidding for the expansion of the Mactan International Airport in Cebu.

name: Billionaires
bio: Konstantin Grigorishin is the biggest shareholder of Energy Standard Group, which owns several electric energy equipment factories in Ukraine, where he was born. He began selling Ukrainian metallurgy products to Russia in the late 1980s, becoming along with his partners a big trader in the former USSR metals market. After their company was privatized it snapped up metallurgy, energy, and machine building assets, and it recently sold some of them to Ukrainian billionaires. Grigorishin was a backer of Ukraine's Orange Revolution. He loves to swim.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mubariz Gurbanoglu owns Palmali Navigation whose 227 ships carried 127 tons of crude oil from the Black Sea. Palmali has long term contracts for transportation with oil companies such as Lukoil and Socar; it also provides services to Lukoil for oil exploration and storage on the Hazar Sea. Gurbanoglu is an avid soccer plan who spends $25 million a year on soccer club Lankeran which he owns in Azerbaijan; he is also an ardent supporter of the Turkish soccer team Besiktas. The former soldier has an antique weapons collection consisting of more than 600 pieces, some of which are displayed in the waiting area of his offices in Istanbul. mp3 downloader

name: Billionaires
bio: During the Soviet era Yuri Gushchin was an underground producer of consumer goods, particularly candy. During perestroika he became one of the first businessmen to legalize their operations. In 1991 he founded Guta-Bank, in Moscow, and in 1993 it began working with Gosincor, a state-owned bank created by President Boris Yeltsin to draw foreign investment and headed by Yeltsin's longtime right-hand man Yuri Petrov. After the 1998 Russian financial crisis Gushchin bought controlling stakes in Moscow's biggest confectionery factories and with them created Obyedinennye Konditery. He leases buildings of the former Krasny Oktyabr candy company to billionaire Mikhail Prokhorov's Snob magazine, Mikhail Abyzov's Digital October educational center, and Alexander Mamut's Strelka Institute for Media, Architecture and Design. In 2008 he bought the Coral Strand Hotel in the Seychelles, which was previously owned by British Airways, and next to it he is building a new luxury hotel, Savoy Resort and Spa, that is to open at the end of 2013.

name: Billionaires
bio: Longtime head of generics maker Cipla and an outspoken champion of affordable medicines, recently retired as managing director though he remains non-executive chairman. He caused a stir last May when he slashed prices for three cancer drugs used to treat kidney and liver cancer by 75%. In November, he cut prices of three more cancer drugs and inked deal to buy a majority stake in Cipla's South African distributor for $220 million. Moves boosted share price by nearly 20% in past year. He claimed in an interview to Forbes Asia that he's done more humanitarian work than Bill Gates and Warren Buffet, and insisted that Cipla, which also makes AIDS, malaria and asthma drugs, is not for sale: "I don't need more money in the bank."

name: Billionaires
bio: Mehmet Hattat is the president of Hattat Holding which has interests in industry, energy, tourism, real estate and construction. He is expanding into thermal electricity, and has begun phase one of his operations, starting production at coal mines in Northern Turkey last summer. Last August he also signed a $250 million investment agreement with the Chinese Harbin Electric Group for the production of electricity plant units. In December 2012, as Istanbul was under a heavy snow storm, a helicopter carrying Mehmet Hattat and his daughter Ipek Hattat back from Amasra risked falling and had to make an emergency landing on the shore of the Bosporus.

name: Billionaires
bio: Hua Bangsong is a newcomer to the Forbes Billionaires List this year thanks to years of growth in China's energy and chemicals industries. The chairman and founder of Wison Engineering in Hong Kong runs the largest non-government controlled engineering and construction firm to China's chemicals and energy-extraction industries. Wison, incorporated in 1997 to make ethylene cracking furnaces, has operations in China, the U.S., Hong Kong and Saudi Arabia. It floated an IPO in December in Hong Kong, raising $154 million selling 600 million shares. Hua and his wife own close to 80% of the company. Its shares are up 35% since late January. One of its divisions is expanding its shipbuilding capacity and its Horton Wison Deepwater division based in Houston delivered an innovative floating rig to be used in the shallower waters off of Peru.

name: Billionaires
bio: Huang Hongyun's wealth has climbed in the past year on increased sales at his Jinke Property Group, as well as investor expectations for even more gains. Jinke, a real estate developer in the central Chinese city of Chongqing, saw its revenue rise by 16% in the nine-months to September to $984 million; net profit gained 17% to $149 million. Jinke appears poised for new business: In January, it won bids for three pieces of land in the Changshou district in Chongqing City worth $186 million. Jinke donated $1 million in January to help 10,000 poor families. Huang in 2012 became chairman of Chongqing's Federation of Industry & Commerce, the city's top business group. Huang in August 2011 injected his real estate business into Shenzhen-listed Chongqing Dongyuan Industry in a backdoor listing. He holds an executive MBA from Chongqing University, and enjoys hiking.

name: Billionaires
bio: Jiang Zhaobai joins the ranks of the world's billionaires in 2013 after a steady climb toward the list. Zhaobai, not yet 50 years old, is chairman of Shanghai Pengxin Group, a holding company that owns real estate and big stakes in Shanghai Synica, a metals and specialty chemicals concern, and SinoLink Securities, a domestic brokerage. Shares of Synica have soared 80% in the past 12 months. Sinolink shares are up 65%. Pengxin also bought a 12% stake in Hong Kong-listed Interchina Holdings last August. Later in 2012, Interchina said it would buy Jiang-owned South American-focused agribusiness firm Pengxin Agricultural for $65 million. It faced local opposition in its reported $200 million-plus bid for a big New Zealand dairy operation. Zhaobai graduated in Nanjing Institute of Architecture and Civil Engineering and was admitted to an Executive Master of Business Administration degree at China Europe International Business School in June 2005.

name: Billionaires
bio: Forbes is adding Canada's "Doughnut King" Ronald Joyce to this year's World Billionaires list after uncovering previously undisclosed assets. Joyce co-founded Tim Horton's doughnut chain with former NHL player Tim Horton, then sold the company to Wendy's for $600 million in 1995. A former policeman, Joyce reportedly met his future business partner in the early 1960s after visiting the Tim Horton Donut Shop while on patrol. By 1967, he had followed his gut and opened up two more restaurants under the same name, becoming a full partner with Horton in the process. When Horton died in a car accident in 1974, Joyce bought his partner's shares and became the sole owner of the chain. After the Wendy's transaction he became the fast food chain's largest shareholder, gaining more than 16 million shares. By 2003 he had sold off all his Wendy's shares, enjoying a considerable pop in the stock in the intervening years. He says he has since diversified his portfolio, picking shares in established Canadian companies and industries that provide considerable dividend income. He owns an aircraft charter company and the Fox Harb'r golf resort on the north shore of Nova Scotia. He serves as chairman emeritus of the Tim Horton Children Foundation.

name: Billionaires
bio: MIT engineer Baba Kalyani joined his family-owned Bharat Forge in 1972 and built it into one of the world's largest makers of auto forgings.  It's the flagship of his $2.5 billion (revenues) Kalyani Group, which has expanded into non-auto forgings to counter a slowdown in the car market. But revenues fell in the last quarter due to declining capital investments in other sectors as well. Other businesses picking up: group's joint venture with Alstom to make power equipment snatched a $297 million order to supply turbines to state-owned National Thermal Power Corporation. Returns to list on new information about his land holdings such as stake in a 4,700-acre special economic zone near Pune city where he lives.

name: Billionaires
bio: More than 40 years ago Sidney Kimmel founded the Jones Group apparel company  and since 2011 he has served as non-executive chairman. The Philadelphia-born retailer now focuses on his movie production company, Sidney Kimmel Entertainment. He had a modest hit in 2011 with the Matthew McConaughey vehicle, "The Lincoln Lawyer." The Jennifer Lopez thriller "Parker" is due out in 2013. He also owns 5% of the Miami Heat basketball team. Kimmel joined the Gates-Buffett Giving Pledge in November 2010, writing in his pledge letter, "My thinking is rather simple: I learned as a young boy that sharing with others is the right thing to do." He created the Sidney Kimmel Foundation in 1993 and since that time the foundation and its subsidiary, the Sidney Kimmel Foundation for Cancer Research, have committed more than $550 million to various philanthropic causes. In 2012, Kimmel donated $25 million to the Entertainment Industry Foundation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mustafa Vehbi Koc is the eldest son of billionaire Mustafa Rahmi Koc and the Chairman of the Board at the family's Koc Holding whose stock price is up 30% over the past year. The conglomerate operates in energy, automotive, durable consumer goods and finance; it is also active in the technology, retail, food, agriculture, tourism and shipyard sectors. Last December, in partnership with fellow billionaire Murat Ulker, he won the privatization bid for the Bogazici and Fatih Sultan Mehmet bridges that connect Istanbul's two shores. His marine construction company RMK Marin also undertook the construction of 6 war ships in early 2013. Koc is a wildlife photographer who also flies model planes and plays golf. In addition to his father, his brothers Yildirim Ali and Mehmet Omer, and his aunts Semahat Arsel and Suna Kirac are also billionaires.

name: Billionaires
bio: Pyotr Kondrashev sold his stake in Silvinit, Russia's second-largest producer of potassium fertilizer in the summer of 2010 to billionaires Anatoly Skurov and Zelimkhan Mutsoev. He's now retired and keeping a low profile in Vienna, Austria. Kondrashev, a graduate of the Magnitogorsk Mining and Metallurgical Institute, worked for 35 years at the Silvinit fertilizer factory, and became the firm's CEO in 1990. He organized the privatization of the company and became one of its largest shareholders.

name: Billionaires
bio: Andrei Kozitsyn heads the Russian copper producer Urals Mining and Metals Company. He grew up in the Urals, in the town of Verkhnaya Pyshma, studied metallurgy, and in 1979 went to work as a mechanic at Uralelectromed, now UMMC's main factory. He was general director there from 1995 to 2002. Beyond mining and metals, UMMC also manages agricultural, construction and telecom companies in the Urals. Kozitsyn is the closest business partner of fellow billionaire Iskander Makhmudov and has helped him build holdings in Urals mining and metallurgy. On January 30, 2012, after large opposition demonstrations in Moscow, more than 1000 UMMC employees demonstrated in Ekaterinburg in support of Vladimir Putin. In May 2012 UMMC beat out Norilsk Nickel to win the right to develop the third biggest copper and nickel field in Russia, in Voronezh oblast. The company plans to spend more than $2 billion building an ore-processing plant there.

name: Billionaires
bio: Solomon Lew's Premier Investments owns several of Australia's largest fashion chains and stakes in other retail groups. In 1964, when he was 18, he took control of his father's small retail business and turned it into an empire. He is a fierce opponent of the sales-tax exemption on Internet purchases, which allows overseas competitors to sell goods to Australians tax free. He and his wife Rosie support Opera Australia.

name: Billionaires
bio: Peter Lewis, chairman of Progressive Insurance, died in November 2013, soon after celebrating his 80th birthday. Lewis was the country's most high-profile billionaire backer of drug law reform. During the November 2012 election, he spent almost $3 million helping secure the passage of marijuana legalization bills in both Washington state and Massachusetts. The National Organization for the Reform of Marijuana Laws estimated that Lewis had spent well over $40 million funding the cause since the 1980s. "Our marijuana laws are outdated, ineffective and stupid," Lewis told Forbes in a 2011 interview.  Lewis also had a personal reason for publicly backing marijuana.  The Ohio native used the drug to combat pain from a partial amputation he had at age 64 on his left leg due to an incurable infection. A Princeton grad, he started out as an underwriter at Progressive, which his father founded, in 1955. He took over 10 years later and remained CEO until 2000. At the time of his death, his net worth was over $1.3 billion, the majority of which was tied up in Progressive's stock.

name: Billionaires
bio: Billionaire list newcomer Liu Zaiwang is chairman and cofounder of Jangho Curtain Wall, a fast-growing designer and manufacturer of building exteriors, including those of many of China's boldest skyscrapers. Revenue during the first nine months of 2012 rose 47% to $913 million; net profit soared 61% to $49 million. Those gains helped to propel Janho's shares up by more than half. The Beijing-based company said in January it is looking to raise cash through a $100 million bond sale, adding to $145 million raised in December. In January, it bought 12.5% of unlisted Gangyuan Architectural Decoration, one of the top ten decoration companies in China. That follows its purchase last year of an 85% stake in contractor Sundart Holdings that does business in Greater China. Liu and his wife in December pledged $8 million to Northeastern University in China to set up the Jangho Curtain Wall College.

name: Billionaires
bio: Businessman Anatoly Lomakin took up lawmaking in August 2012, becoming a Yedinaya Rossiya party deputy in Russia's State Duma. In February 2013, he stepped down from the State Duma, citing health problems. He has longstanding ties to Silvinit, the Russian fertilizer company. In 1992 he started the International Potassium Company (MMK), bringing together Silvinit and two of the other largest post-Soviet producers of fertilizer. Several years later the alliance broke up, over reserve sharing. In 2005, MMK began exporting only Silvinit's production, and after Silvinit merged with Uralkali, in 2011, MMK lost its potash contracts. Now it does consulting.

name: Billionaires
bio: Nikolai Maximov sold his stake in Maxi Group, a developer of steel mini mills, to billionaire Vladimir Lisin's NLMK in 2007. NLMK paid a first installment of $300 million in January 2008, but the second payment became locked in a dispute when NLMK accused former top managers at Maxi of stripping funds from the group and Maximov demanded more money for his shares. In February 2011 he was detained in Moscow on charges of abuse of power and posted bail of $1.8 million. The case drags on. Born in Yekaterinburg, Maximov graduated from a mining institute and then in 1991 founded a family timber and furniture business. Three years later he began trading scrap iron, investing the profits in shares of small metallurgy works in the Urals. He founded Metallurgy Holding in 2004 and later renamed it Maxi Group. He invested wisely during the global recession, buying stock in Sberbank when prices were low and later selling for nearly five times as much.

name: Billionaires
bio: Dean Metropoulos is out to save the Twinkie. Through his private equity firm, Metropoulos & Co, he's teaming up with fellow billionaire Leon Black's private equity firm Apollo to buy bankrupt Hostess's snack cakes line, putting up a baseline offer of $410 million for the brands in January. Metropoulos knows a thing or two about turning around brands. He paid $250 million in June 2011 for blue-collar-turned-hipster-darling Pabst Brewing Co., North America's largest privately-held brewer. In 1996 he and partners formed International Home Foods, then revamped Chef Boyardee pasta products, PAM cooking spray and Bumble Bee seafood. In 2000 he sold IHF to ConAgra for $2.9 billion. Four years later he bought Aurora Foods out of bankruptcy and merged it with Pinnacle Foods (Aunt Jemima, Duncan Hines, Log Cabin). He and fellow investors sold it to Blackstone Group for $2.2 billion in 2007. Metropoulos has also reinvigorated businesses such as U.K.-based Hillsdown Holdings (now public), Premier Foods and Mumm and Perrier-Jouet champagnes. He moved from Greece to Watertown, Mass. with his family at age 10. At age 25, he went to Geneva, Switzerland, to become a financial director for GTE International's (now Verizon) European, Middle Eastern and African operations; he returned to the U.S. as the company's youngest controller.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former real estate broker, Mofatraj Munot is now one of Mumbai's leading property developers. His privately held Kalpataru Constructions has a dozen ongoing projects in Mumbai and Pune, including a 5-million-square-foot township in suburban Mumbai. (The name Kalpataru is derived from Kalpavruksha, a mythological tree of wish fulfillment). He recently concluded a $225 million deal to acquire 108 acres in Mumbai from Bayer's Indian arm. He's building a hostel for poor students in Mumbai. Firm's other interests include property management, power transmission, logistics and telecom infrastructure. Son Parag works with him

name: Billionaires
bio: More than a century after his grandfather John Nordstrom, who arrived in the U.S. at age 16 with $5, opened his first store in Seattle, Bruce Nordstrom makes his debut among the world's billionaires. The stock of the department store, which he ran for 27 years and is now headed by his son Blake, is at all-time highs, as it achieved record sales and earnings for the third consecutive year. The shares of the department store chain are up 9% in the past year and up nearly 700% from its 2008 low. Nordstrom began his career working the stockroom and sales floor of Nordstrom's downtown Seattle store for 25 cents an hour when he was nine years old.  He and his sister Anne Gittinger are the company's biggest individual shareholders.

name: Billionaires
bio: Gains from Sjamsul Nursalim's stake in his retail empire have been somewhat offset by the poor performance of shares of his tire production group. His net worth has been hit by the fall in the share price of tiremaker Gajah Tunggal, which is planning a $500 million bond sale to retire bonds issued earlier, and for working capital. Gajah Tunggal, or "supreme elephant" in Bahasa Indonesia, is reportedly looking to sell its full 26.3% stake in Polychem Indonesia, a producer of a raw material known as ethylene glycol. On the other hand, his retail arm Mitra Adiperkasa, which has licenses to Burger King, Starbucks and Zara, is thriving. Shares of the retailer, which now has 1,209 stores, about 200 more than a year ago, have shot up by about 20% in past year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former minister of trade under Marcos regime, Roberto Ongpin has investments in property, gaming, mining, telecommunications. Top Frontier, investment company he heads, has a controlling interest in San Miguel Corporation. In December, Manila court ordered the freezing of bank accounts tied to Ongpin as part of an investigation about possible preferential treatment he got for loans from state-owned Development Bank of the Philippines.  Ongpin has reportedly said he was being unfairly targeted. He's a certified public accountant, Harvard Business School grad.

name: Billionaires
bio: Nihat Ozdemir heads the conglomerate Limak Holding, which he co-founded with billionaire Sezai Bacaksiz; they split the company equally. Total revenue across a diverse array of business lines from energy to tourism to cement grew 24%. In June 2012, they won the tender for the Kosova Electricity Company's electricity distribution and procurement business with fellow billionaire, Ahmet Calik. In December 2012 they bought BEDAS in concert with Cengiz and Kolin Construction for nearly $2 billon; BEDAS distributes electricity to Istanbul's European shore and has 10 million subscribers. With this tender, the Limak, Cengiz, Kolin partnership covers 30% of all electricity subscribers in Turkey. Ozdemir was the vice-president of the Fenerbahce Sports Club but resigned at the end of 2012. His daughter Ebru Ozdemir works at Limak in business development and finance and his son Batuhan Ozdemir works in energy production and distribution.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ahsen Ozokur is one of the major shareholders of Yildiz Holding, one of Turkey's largest food producers, but she is not involved in the management of the company. Her sons Ali Ulker and Ahmet Ozokur are on the Holding's board of directors; her brother billionaire Murat Ulker runs the business. The conglomerate makes everything from biscuits, chocolate, milk to baby food and packaging. Ulker Biscuit, which is the Group's largest publicly traded company streamlined operations this year, leading to a 100% increase in the companies stock price.The founder of the company, her father Sabri Ulker died on June 2012.

name: Billionaires
bio: Nelson Peltz made his name on Wall Street doing LBOs fueled by Michael Milken's junk bonds back in the 1980s, and he's still doing deals today. In February, he chalked up a win when Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway and 3G Capital announced a takeover of H.J. Heinz, valuing the company at $2.3 billion. Peltz's $5 billion Trian Partners hedge fund held 5.4% of Heinz. More recently Trian has been investing in financial companies including Legg Mason where it took a 10% stake in October 2011. Peltz has been pushing for changes at the firm--and getting his way. Legg Mason named a new CEO in February after shares suffered a 60% drop under the tenure of its previous leader. Trian launched a new fund late last year that it expects will reach some $2 billion in capital.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Former race car driver Roger Penkse is one of the richest people in racing. He owns his own NASCAR and IndyCar team, Penske Racing. The billionaire founded his eponymous company in 1969, distributing diesel engines for GM. Today, Penske Auto Group operates more than 300 car dealerships, both in the United States and abroad. While the recession briefly knocked Penske's net worth below a billion dollars in the middle of 2011, Penske is back up. In 2009, Penkse abandoned his attempt to buy car-maker Saturn from GM and turn it into an independent company. An alumnus of Lehigh University, Penske is a director of GE and the Universal Technical Institute, Inc.

name: Billionaires
bio: Thanks to a resurgence in Florida real estate values, condo king Jorge Perez is back on the billionaires list for the first time since 2008. Capitalizing on South Florida's nascent housing rebound, Perez has more than a dozen new apartment buildings underway, including one of Miami's first new post-bubble condo projects. Born in Argentina to Cuban parents, Perez started out as an urban planner and then moved into low-income housing development and later high-end housing with Related Companies' Stephen Ross. Perez sparked controversy in 2011 when the Miami Art Museum agreed to rename itself the Jorge M. Perez Art Museum of Miami-Dade County after he pledged $35 million in cash and artwork over ten years. Perez recently signed on to the Gates-Buffett Giving Pledge.

name: Billionaires
bio: Best known as a corporate raider for his runs at Gulf Oil, Unocal, Pioneer and others in the 1980s, in recent years T. Boone Pickens has focused on managing Dallas-based hedge funds and pushing his Pickens Plan to boost adoption of wind, solar, and especially natural gas. Plunging natural gas prices shelved a plan to build the world's largest wind farm in Texas. Instead he's pushing for a future of natural gas-powered vehicles. He got his start at Phillips Petroleum, then founded Mesa Petroleum in 1956. He led the Swift Boat attacks against John Kerry in 2004. In 2006 he donated $165 million to athletics program at alma mater Oklahoma State University. In 2008 he donated $100 million more to OSU academics. Divorcing from fourth wife Madeleine, but pre-nup will protect his assets.

name: Billionaires
bio: Revenues for Under Armour, the sports apparel juggernaut Kevin Plank founded in his grandmother's basement in 1996, reached $1.8 billion in 2012, a 25% increase over the prior year. Quarterback Tom Brady is an endorser and owns stock in the company. The company's big product release this year? A workout monitor. Nearly all of his fortune is tied up in Under Armour stock, up 63% in the past year. His one other notable holding is 530-acre Sagamore Farm in Glyndon, Md., which he bought in 2007 to revive Maryland horseracing--and hopefully win the Triple Crown. Plank donates 10% of his own stock sales to the Cupid Foundation, which focuses on Maryland charities.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Under Armour, Inc.', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Lately fertilizer tycoon Alexander Rovt has been plowing cash into real estate. He owns more than 30 investment properties, mostly apartment buildings in New York City. In April 2012 he paid $303 million in cash for a majority stake of the 1 million-square foot office building at 14 Wall Street in Manhattan. In 2011 he sold two Eastern European fertilizer factories to Russia's Gazprom entities for upwards of $500 million. His IBE Trade is still one of the world's largest traders of ammonium-based fertilizer. Rovt grew up poor in Carpathia, a contested Soviet territory, and attended the prestigious Lvov State University of Trade and Economics in the Ukraine. He holds a Ph.D in international economics. He managed a high-end Hungarian resort in the U.S.S.R. before migrating to New York, where he first ran a deli and then sold jewelry. He has never invested money in a stock or bond, preferring hard assets like housing. In 2011 Rovt, who lives ib Brooklyn, plucked Manhattan's storied Sloane Mansion out of foreclosure an hour before auction for $34 million, with plans to renovate and eventually live there. He also owns an ornate townhouse on Manhattan's Upper East Side that he has been trying to offload.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cigdem Sabanci Bilen returns to the billionaires list as her family's holding group thrives. Her stake in Akbank is up 21% over the past year. She is the sister of billionaire Suzan Sabanci Dincer and granddaughter of Sabanci Group founder Haci Omer Sabanci. Her husband Faruk Bilen joined the Sabanci Group in 1996 and has been chief financial officer of Sabanci Holding since 1977. He is also a board member of various Sabanci Group companies.

name: Billionaires
bio: Lily Safra inherited her fortune from her late husband Edmond Safra, a billionaire banker who died in a fire in his Monaco apartment in 1999. Safra is known as a socialite and philanthropist, and splits her time between London and New York. She also has homes in Geneva and Monaco. In January 2013, she donated $2 million to the Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research and pledged an additional $4.5 million over two years from the Edmond J. Safra Foundation. She has donated nearly $20 million to the Michael J. Fox Foundation since 2001.  In May 2012, Safra auctioned off 70 items in her jewelry collection in a "Jewels For Hope" event at Christie's in Geneva that raised nearly $38 million, which she donated to 32 charities. She counts among her friends Prince Charles of the U.K. and his wife, Camilla.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sandell's flagship hedge fund, Castlerigg Master Investments, returned 15.5% net of fees in 2012. The market-beating performance was accompanied by net capital inflows, pushing assets under management back up to the $1 billion mark. A former Swedish badminton prodigy, Sandell attended college outside Stockholm before spending two years in Paris covering European equities for Atlantic Finance. He then earned an MBA at Columbia and joined Bear Stearns in 1988, where he was a colleague of famed investment banker Ace Greenberg. While at Bear Stearns, Sandell worked on billionaire Kirk Kerkorian's bid for Chrysler before departing to found fund manager Sandell Asset Management in 1998.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: B. Francis Saul II is chairman and CEO of publicly traded Saul Centers, which operates a real estate portfolio of 9.5 million square feet, primarily shopping centers in metropolitan Washington, D.C. and Baltimore. He got his start with Chevy Chase Bank, which he founded in 1969 and operated out of a trailer on Connecticut Avenue. He sold the bank to Capital One in 2009 for $476 million but kept Chevy Chase Trust, which services high-net-worth clients. He also owns BF Saul Hotels, a private company, with more than 3,400 rooms in 19 hotels. The most well known is the luxury Hay-Adams Hotel, across the street from the White House, which he bought in 2006.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Saul Centers Inc.', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Seo Jung-Jin is new to the Forbes Billionaires list. He is the CEO and cofounder of biotech firm Celltrion, which specializes in biosimilars, affordable generic versions of biological products that replicate natural substances in the human body such as antibodies. Biosimilars are used to treat chronic and severe illnesses like cancer. Example: Remsima, meant to have the same effect as the rheumatoid-arthritis drug Remicade. For now Remsima is only sold in South Korea. Celltrion expects the drug to be approved in emerging markets like India this year. The company's shares have made strong gains in the past year, propelling Seo to billionaire status. It has attracted foreign investors including Temasek Holdings, an investment firm owned by the government of Singapore. Seo founded Celltrion in 2002 after losing his job at Daewoo Motor in 1999 shortly before the company went bankrupt.

name: Billionaires
bio: Bacaksiz Sezai is the vice-chairman of Limak Holding, which has businesses in the construction, energy, tourism and cement sectors. Bacaksiz, a mechanical engineer by training, owns half of Limak; fellow billionaire Nihat Ozdemir owns the other half. Bacaksiz is responsible for airport and tourism business lines while Ozdemir is responsible for the cement and energy sectors. In November 2011 the Limak Construction - GMR joint venture won the tender for the renovation of the Cairo Airport with an offer of $387 million; in 2012 they took over the Iskenderun Port. Last summer, the company won the tender for the Kosova Electricity Company's electricity distribution and procurement business with fellow billionaire, Ahmet Calik. In December 2012 they bought BEDAS in concert with Cengiz and Kolin Construction for nearly $2 billon; BEDAS distributes electricity to Istanbul's European shore and has 10 million subscribers. The Limak, Cengiz, Kolin partnership covers 30% of all electricity subscribers in Turkey.

name: Billionaires
bio: Canadian media magnate Allan Slaight got his start in radio in 1948 with CHAB in Moose Jaw, Saskatchewan. From the rank of on-air reporter Slaight rose rapidly through the industry, becoming General Manager of CHUM radio in Toronto in 1965. Five years later, Slaight made the jump to ownership, purchasing stations in Toronto and Montreal, then merging with IWC Communications and later buying Standard Broadcasting Corporation in 1985. In 2007 Slaight sold 53 radio and two television stations, effectively all of Standard's broadcasting assets, to Astral Media for CAD 880 million and 4.75 million Astral shares. In late January 2012 Slaight and his wife Emmanuelle Gattuso announced a CAD 50 million pledge to the Princess Margaret Cancer Foundation, raising their total commitment to that organization to CAD 72 million.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Norwegian hotel baron Petter Stordalen is the owner and CEO of Nordic Choice Hotels, which has more than 170 hotels in Scandinavia. In 2012 the environmentalist and former Ironman racer opened seven new hotels and led a group of investors to take over Norway's second-largest shopping center chain. Stordalen also received an unexpected $80 million tax bill from the Swedish government for prior business sales, but said he was happy to pay it. He chained himself to U.K. nuclear treatment plant Sellafield in protest for nine hours in 2002. More recently he rebuilt his sports car to be the world's first biofueled Ferrari. He proposed to his supermodel-turned-physician wife Gunhild on top of a mountain on New Year's Eve 2008, then spent $5 million for the most expensive wedding in Scandinavian history.

name: Billionaires
bio: After divesting himself of almost all equity in Magna International, company founder Frank Stronach has turned his attention to European politics. In September 2012, the Austrian-born Stronach announced his plans to form his own political party and run for chancellor in his birth country. By advocating that Austria depart the Eurozone, his party, dubbed "Team Stronach," has gained some traction and now has five seats in parliament as of November 2012. Raised in Austria during Nazi-rule he apprenticed at a tool-and-die maker, before emigrating to Canada and founding the precursor for Magna in 1957. Today the company is one of the largest automotive part suppliers in the world, with nearly $30 billion in sales. Among many of Stronach's passions is horse racing. He is the owner of several racetracks (including Santa Anita near Los Angeles) and a successful horse breeder.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Sun Hongbin, the chairman of property developer Sunac China Holdings, debuts on the Forbes Billionaires list this year. Shares in Sunac more than doubled in value in the past year amid hopes for recovery in China's real estate market. Headquartered in Tianjin, the company took advantage of the stock rally to raise cash through a January 2013 stock sale that led Sun's stake in the company to fall to 47.1% from 51.8%. Sun is a U.S. citizen.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former partner of Highbridge Capital Management co-founder Glenn Dubin, Swieca parted ways with his longtime pal (they grew up together in Washington Heights) and the firm they built together in 2009, launching a new fund management company in early 2011. Called Talpion Fund Management, derived from the term "Talpiot," which refers to a castle's turrets and signifies the "pinnacle of achievement," the venture didn't last long: Swieca returned outside investors' capital during the fall of 2011. As such, Talpion now effectively serves as Swieca's family office. Recent beneficiaries of his Swieca Family Foundation include The Frisch School and the American Israel Education Foundation.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: New information on the holdings of long-time Ukrainian politician, Serhiy Tihipko, put him on the billionaires list this year. Tihipko began working in banking in the 1990s, and was one of the early founders of PrivatBank now owned by fellow billionaires Ihor Kolomoyskyy and Henadiy Boholyubov. He sold off another banking asset, TAS-Kommerzbank, to a Swedish investor at the height of the market in 2007 for $735 million and invested funds in his election campains as well as in various businesses from real estate to machinery. Now Tihipko is focused on growing agricultural interests. The former vice-Prime Minister is in parliament as a member of President Victor Yanukovich's Party of Regions.

name: Billionaires
bio: Kenny Troutt made his money in telecom but now focuses on horse racing. He owns Winstar Farm, in Versailles, Ky. A bartender's son, he paid for his tuition at Southern Illinois University by selling life insurance. He founded a long-distance phone company, Excel Communications, in 1988 and took it public in 1996. He merged it two years after that with Teleglobe, in a $3.5 billion deal, and reinvested the profits in stocks, bonds and horses. He sponsors his two sons' nationally competitive youth basketball teams, which integrate disadvantaged families with middle- and upper-class ones. He was an active donor to Republican candidates in the November 2012 election, giving to Rick Perry and Tim Pawlenty in the GOP primaries and Mitt Romney in the general election, as well as $500,000 to Karl Rove's American Crossroads SuperPAC. He ranks 25th on the Center for Responsive Politics' list of top individual political contributors.

name: Billionaires
bio: Tu Jianhua chairs Loncin Holding, one of the largest real estate developers in the central Chinese city of Chongqing. He invests in financial services through a stake in Hong Kong-listed Chongqing Rural Commercial Bank and also owns about half of Loncin Motor, one of China's largest  motorcycle makers and exporters. In December, Loncin acquired 24% of domestically listed Shanghai Fengwa Group for $89 million, triggering speculation that Tu would inject his real estate asset into the listed company.

name: Billionaires
bio: Dot-com pioneer Todd Wagner profited from selling his web startup at the height of the bubble. He and Mark Cuban sold audio and video portal Broadcast.com to Yahoo for $5.7 billion in 1999, making both instant billionaires, and their 300 employees millionaires. He avoided the impending crash by shrewdly protecting his shares with put options, then entered into new entertainment ventures with Cuban, like Magnolia Pictures, Landmark Theatres, and AXS TV. Wagner also created a charitable foundation in 2000 to help underprivileged children.

name: Billionaires
bio: Langley Walker is new to the Forbes World's Billionaires list. He sold the bulk of his property development company, Walker Corp., in 2006, just before the global financial crisis. Since then the Sydney resident has quickly rebuilt an empire spanning residential master-plan developments, industrial property and a large commercial project in Melbourne.

name: Billionaires
bio: Transportation and logistics entrepreneur Wang Wei keeps such a low profile that when a prominent Chinese magazine ran a feature article on him last year, it didn't have a photo of him (it ran an artist's conception of him instead). Wang made his debut as a billionaire on Forbes' 2012 list of China's 100 richest people. His unlisted company, SF Express, is the closest business in China to a U.S.-style Fedex, providing express delivery around much of the country. It is expanding into southeast region. Last year's revenue figures are not available but should be up strongly from its 2011 revenue of $1.5 billion thanks to booming demand from online commerce.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: In February 2013 Gavril Yushvaev and billionaire Zelimkhan Mutsoev bought billionaire Mikhail Prokhorov's stake (38%) in Polyus Gold, a gold producer, for $3.6 billion. Three years before, Pepsico bought Yushvaev's 19.6% stake in the dairy and juice company Wimm-Bill-Dann for about $1.1 billion, as part of the beverage maker's acquisition of all the Russian company's shares; Wimm-Bill-Dann was delisted after that. Back when that company went public, in 2002, the prospectus revealed that Yushvaev had served nine years in a Soviet prison camp after being found guilty of a "violent crime" in 1980. Yushvayev had been released in 1989, and investors weren't scared off. He was also a founder of Trinity, which owns car dealerships, Cherry Casino, one of Russia's first gambling clubs, and Metelitsa, a Moscow dance club that was popular in the early '90s.

name: Billionaires
bio: Bouchard joins the billionaire ranks this year on the strength of his Alimentation Couche-Tard, which he has grown into a $23 billion (2012 revenue) convenvience store giant via acquisition and moxie. The company's stock price has risen 64% over the past year. The Canadian purveyor, whose company name means night owl in French, made a big play last April when it paid $2.8 billion for Norwegian oil giant Statoil ASA's retail business, giving him a large European footprint. In the U.S., he operates more than 3,300 Circle K branded stores. Bouchard has been rejiggering convenience stores since he stocked his first shelf at 19 at his brother's franchised Perrette store in Bois-des-Filion, Quebec. He spent five years laying out new stores as the chain expanded. Then he tried his hand as a franchisee for another Quebec operator, Provi-Soir, but chafed at the corporate mandates. With three partners he began what would become Couche-Tard. Over the years, it has quickly expanded and now has 12,000 stores including licensees. Bouchard plans to pass the company he is building to his children; his son, who has cerebral palsy, and who Bouchard says keeps him grounded; and his daughter may take his place at the helm one day.
organization: Alimentation Couche Tard Inc. Cl A
title: Entrepreneur
employment: {'name': 'Alimentation Couche Tard Inc. Cl A', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Auto glass maker Cho Tak Wong's wealth is little changed from a year ago amid slow auto demand in China and a sluggish global economy. Cho chairs Shanghai-listed Fuyao Glass Industry Group, whose customer list includes GM, Ford and Nissan. Net profit in the first nine months of 2012 declined by 0.9% to $186.6 million, even though sales rose by 6.3% to $1.2 billion  The company in November announced plans for a new $110 million floating-glass plant in Cho's home Fujian Province.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ana Lucia de Mattos Barretto Villela belongs to one of Brazil's oldest and most distinguished banking families. She is one of the largest individual shareholders of Sao Paulo-based Investimentos Itau S.A, a holding company known as Itausa. The company controls Unibanco Holding S.A., one of Brazil's largest banks. It also controls  wood panel producer Duratex, banking and consumer electronics company Itautec and chemical producer Elekeiroz. She also directly owns a minor stake at Duratex. Ana Lucia's fortune has dropped by more than $2 billion in the past year because of detailed new information unearthed by Forbes about the value of her holdings. She is the president of Alana Institute, a non-profit organization she co-founded with her brother Alfredo in 1994 to promote social work, education and culture. She is a fellow at Ashoka, an international organization that supports social entrepreneurs. She has also given $5 million to Vox Capital, a Brazilian venture fund that invests in companies that do business with low-income people.
person: {'name': 'Ana Lucia de Mattos Barretto Villela', 'uri': 'ana-lucia-de-mattos-barretto-villela', 'imageExists': False, 'squareImage': '//specials-images.forbesimg.com/imageserve/5e7422c310380d0006bdac2a/416x416.jpg?background=000000&cropX1=176&cropX2=2832&cropY1=268&cropY2=2925'}
personName: Ana Lucia de Mattos Barretto Villela

name: Billionaires
bio: Alfredo Egydio Villela Filho is a low-profile member of one of Brazil's oldest banking families. He was chosen to lead the family business after his great uncle Olavo Setubal died in 2008. That year the family's Banco Itau merged with Unibanco and Alfredo became CEO and General Director of Itausa, a holding company that controls Unibanco Holding S.A., one of Brazil's largest banks. Itausa also controls wood panel producer Duratex, banking and consumer electronics company Itautec and chemical producer Elekeiroz. Alfredo directly owns a minor stake at Duratex. Alfredo's fortune dropped by more than $2 billion in the past year because of detailed new information unearthed by Forbes about the value of his holdings.  With his sister, Ana Lucia, he supports Alana Institute, a non-profit organization created in 1994 to support social work, education and culture.

name: Billionaires
bio: Gabriel Escarrer opened his first hotel, the Altair, in Palma de Majorca more than 50 years ago when he was just 21 years old. His Melia Hotels International now has more than 350 hotels and resorts in 35 countries and $1.8 billion in revenues. It is one of the world's largest hotel chains and the largest in Spain, and has ambitious plans to open 500 more hotels by 2015. The latest in the chain is ME by Melia, a contemporary luxury brand similar to Starwood's W line, that recently opened in London and is slated for Dubai and Doha. Also in 2012, Melia signed a deal with Microsoft to develop technology for hotel rooms of the future. Escarrer still runs the show with help from his two sons and is a major figure in the development of the Spanish hotel industry. He's received numerous awards, including the United Nations World Tourism Organization inaugural Lifetime Achievement in December 2012. He's also an avid golfer.

name: Billionaires
bio: George Joseph founded auto insurer Mercury General Corp. in 1962. He still chairs the company at age 91 and goes to the office five days a week. He also plays tennis several times a week. A former World War II B-17 bomber pilot, he was working as a door-to-door insurance salesman when he realized that auto insurance companies were not adequately screening customers. That led him to start Mercury General, which is publicly traded. The insurance magnate is currently backing a California ballot measure that would give drivers a "good driver discount." Critics say it would drive up prices for people who haven't been able to afford insurance in the past. The pragmatic tycoon seems not to care. "They can call me as many names as they want. And that's fine with me as long as we get this thing done," Joseph told Best's Insurance News in April 2012.

name: Billionaires
bio: Billionaires list newcomer Lam Kong chairs pharmaceutical distributor China Medical Systems. Its Hong Kong-traded shares have more than doubled since June on optimism about the demand for health-related products at a time of improving economic growth in the mainland. China Medical distributes imported and locally produced pharmaceuticals including anti-depressants. Lam received a bachelor's degree in medicine from Zhanjiang Medical College in 1992; the school is now called Guangdong Medical College.

name: Billionaires
bio: Jeffrey Lorberbaum debuts on the Forbes Billionaires list thanks to a surging stock price in Calhoun, Georgia-based Mohawk Industries, the world's largest flooring maker. He owns a 14% stake in the company, which has a big share of both the carpet and hard surface markets. In 1975 his father Alan founded Aladdin Mills, which originally made bath mats. Jeffrey joined Aladdin in 1976. He was president and CEO until 1994, when his family sold Aladdin to Mohawk. Since taking charge of Mohawk in 2001, he has built it into a $5.7 billion (revenues) giant, partly through acquisitions.

name: Billionaires
bio: Rosa Evangelina Marcondes Penido Dalla Vecchia and her sister Ana Maria Marcondes Penido Sant'Anna join the Forbes Billionaires list thanks to their father, Pelerson Soares Penido, who died in 2012 at the age of 93 and left them shares in CCR Group, Brazil's largest toll-road company by market value. In the 1950s Pelerson played an important role in the construction of the country's capital, Brasilia. Later he exchanged his toll-road operation for a stake in CCR, which has been listed since 2002 and holds 38% of STP, which operates the Brazilian versions of electronic payment systems similar to E-Z Pass. Rosa Evangelina studied psychology and lives in Sao Paulo, Brazil's main financial city.
person: {'name': 'Rosa Evangelina Marcondes Penido Dalla Vecchia', 'uri': 'rosa-evangelina-marcondes-penido-dalla-vecchia', 'imageExists': False}
personName: Rosa Evangelina Marcondes Penido Dalla Vecchia

name: Billionaires
bio: Los Angeles Angels owner Arturo Moreno splurged in the 2012 offseason on Albert Pujols and other stars, but his team only finished third in the American League West. He added slugger Josh Hamilton this year, hoping to do better. The Angels have benefited from a $2.5 billion local television deal (over 17 years). He bought the Anaheim Angels from Disney in 2003, and re-named them in 2005 to capture the larger L.A. market. A Vietnam veteran, he took billboard advertising company Outdoor Systems public in 1996, then sold it to Infinity Broadcasting for $8.7 billion in stock in 1999.

name: Billionaires
bio: Qi Jinxing, the chairman of Hangzhou Binjiang Real Estate Group, returns to the Forbes Billionaires List after dropping off in 2012 following a broad run-up in real estate stocks in China and healthy sales of its own new projects. Hangzhou Binjiang Real Estate Group's net profit in the first nine months of 2012 soared by 187% to $59.5 million, on sales that nearly doubled to $308 million. The company signaled its intention to build up its business close to home in Hangzhou by purchasing two pieces of land in the tourist haven in November worth $267 million. Hangzhou Binjiang Investment Holding, Qi's main holding company, is also an investor in cancer-treatment firm Ascletis, which last year formed a partnership with Nasdaq-listed Alnylam Pharmaceuticals to develop drugs to fight liver cancer.

name: Billionaires
bio: Albert Shigaboutdinov is new to the Forbes Billionaires list. He co-owns and chairs the boad of the TAIF Group, a large regional holding company with assets in the Republic of Tatarstan. The company includes oil refineries, a gas station chain, chemical factories, power plants and construction companies. TAIF became a shareholder in most of its companies during Russia's privatization in the mid-' 90s.

name: Billionaires
bio: Leonid Simanovsky is a co-founder of the gas company Novatek. He had a 6% stake in it at the time of its initial public offering, in 2005, but has since sold shares and now now holds just under 2%. He met fellow billionaire Leonid Mikhelson, his partner in Novatek, in the late 1980s, when he worked as a deputy of Mikhelson's in a construction company. Today the two control First United Bank. Simanovsky recently won election to a third term in Russia's State Duma, representing Vladimir Putin's Edinaya Rossiya (United Russia) party. He is a deputy chairman of the Duma's budget and tax committee.

name: Billionaires
bio: Peter Sperling owes his fortune to the troubled Apollo Group, which runs the for-profit University of Phoenix. Apollo announced in October 2012 that it would be cutting about 800 jobs and shutting down 115 campuses in an effort to cut its costs by $300 million by fiscal year 2014. Its stock is down more than 60% in the past year. Sperling's father, John Sperling, left a humanities professorship at San Jose State in 1976 to start the University of Phoenix. Peter joined in 1983. Both of them still run Apollo, which has 400,000 students taking classes both on- and offline, but only Peter is a billionaire, having?wisely it seems?cashed out over the years. These days only $75 million of his fortune is in Apollo stock; most of the rest is in cash. He is active in renewable energy politics and helped establish a California law requiring renewable energy goals and standards for the state's electric utilities.

name: Billionaires
bio: Rustem Sulteev is new to the Forbes Billionaires list. He co-owns the TAIF Group, a large regional holding company with assets in the Republic of Tatarstan. The company includes oil refineries, a gas station chain, chemical factories, power plants and construction companies. TAIF became a shareholder in most of its companies during Russias privatization in the mid-90s. He has worked as deputy toTAIF board chairman Albert Shigaboutdinov since the early '90s. Sulteev's son Timur sits on the board.

name: Billionaires
bio: Garibaldi Thohir is CEO of Adaro Energy, the world's fourth-largest coal producer. He owns one sixth of the company. Thohir or "Boy," as he is nicknamed, has plans for Adaro to produce 80 million metric tons by 2014. Meantime he has improved productivity and is on the hunt for acquisitions. He also heads Surya Esa Perkasa, Indonesia's second-largest private liquefied petroleum gas refinery company, which recently went public. His first name comes from the famous Italian war hero, General Garibaldi. His father, Mochamad Teddy Thohir, was the highest-ranking Indonesian in Union Carbide's country office and then one of the founders of Astra International, which grew into the nation's largest car dealer. International, which grew into the nation's largest car dealer.

name: Billionaires
bio: Arkady Volozh is a principal founder and largest individual shareholder of search engine Yandex, Russia's Google. Yandex has 60% of the Russian search market, Google ? about 26%. Yandex is an acronym for the phrase "Yet Another iNDEXer". In spring 2011 Yandex and shareholders raised more $1.3 billion in IPO on NASDAQ. Volozh studied applied mathematics at Gubkin University of Oil and Gas. He started working on search in 1989. Volozh also co-founded CompTek, one of the largest distributors of network and telecom equipment in Russia.

name: Billionaires
bio: Wong Kwong Yu, the founder and main shareholder of Gome Electrical Appliances, is serving a 14-year jail sentence received in 2010 for insider trading and other economic crimes. Meanwhile, shares of his giant chain of retail stores have rallied a bit from their lows but remain well off their highs from 2011 as Chinese shoppers have been turning in droves to e-commerce and away from traditional retailers. Gome reported a loss of $123 million in the first nine months of 2013 compared with a profit of $370 million a year earlier. Bain Capital holds 11% of Gome.

name: Billionaires
bio: Marcel Adams is one of the largest landlords in Quebec. He owns and manages 8 million square feet over more than 100 properties "consisting principally of retail shopping centers but also including significant office, industrial, and residential assets." He was born in Romania in 1920. After surviving labor camps during World War II,  Adams immigrated to Canada where he worked in the leather industry in Quebec. By the mid-1950s Adams was investing his savings in local real estate, forming Iberville Developments in 1958 to manage his holdings.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Len Ainsworth is new to the Forbes World's Billionaires list. He hit the jackpot after getting a foothold in Las Vegas for his small betting-machine company, Ainsworth Game Technology, and seeing its stock quadruple. He had been patiently steering his outfit toward the U.S. market for most of a decade. He also owns a large stake in rival gambling-machine company Aristocrat Leisure, which he founded in 1953, stepping down in 2001 after getting cancer. Once he beat the disease his children refused to let him go back to his former job.

name: Billionaires
bio: Nezih Barut joins the billionaires ranks on the strength of Abdi Ibrahim Pharmaceuticals which he owns with his sister, Nesrin Esirtgen. Barut is also one of Turkey's foremost art collectors, owning paintings of Turkish contemporary painters such as Erol Akyavas and Selma Gurbuz, as well as classic painters such as Sevket Dag and Halil Pasa. He lives in the 120-year-old Yedisekiz Hasa Pasha Villa by the Bosporus.

name: Billionaires
bio: Elena Baturina remains Russia's wealthiest woman, although she has not been living in the country for the last two years. After selling her main assets, a construction company called Inteko, and the Verkhnebakansk cement factory, she decided to invest outside Russia. She will work through two real estate funds. One will invest in European properties, and the other, in U.S. real estate. She started out as a factory worker, then studied at the Moscow Institute of Management. In 2012 she bought the Morrison, a four-star hotel in Dublin, for $29 million. She also owns hotels in Russia, Austria and the Czech Republic. She met her ex-husband, former Moscow mayor Yuri Luzhkov, in 1987, when they were both serving on the Mosgorispolcom, a Soviet-era municipal commission. In 1991 she started Inteko, which produced furniture and crockery before expanding into construction and construction materials.

name: Billionaires
bio: Silicon Valley real estate titan Carl Berg offloaded the assets in his publicly traded Mission West in December 2012 to realty developer Divco West. That deal, worth about $1.3 billion in cash, stock and debt considerations, allowed Berg to move out of the spotlight shined on public companies. He still maintains a private real estate portfolio through his firm, Berg and Berg.  A former vending machine repairman who worked night shifts to pay his way through the University of New Mexico, Berg bought real estate investment trust Mission West in 1997.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cheung Yan chairs Nine Dragons Paper, one of Asia's largest producers of paper products. Her husband Liu Ming Chung, a Brazilian national, is also a member of this year's Forbes Billionaires List.After starting out as a supplier of box packaging for manufacturers in southern China's export hub, Nine Dragon has been turning toward China's expanding consumer economy for new sales. The company expects to increase its manufacturing capacity by 21% by June 2014 compared with two years earlier. Sales in the 12 months to June (the latest fiscal year available) rose by 11% to $4.4 billion; net profit nevertheless fell by about a quarter to $226 million on higher financing costs. Its shares are up about a tenth from a year ago, helping to lift Cheung's wealth.  Nine Dragons has more than 18,000 full-time staff.

name: Billionaires
bio: As the man who cofounded Netscape, Jim Clark is a billionaire because of timely investments he's made in modern technology and internet companies. His investment strategy favors a big stake in Apple as well as early bets on social media companies like Facebook and Twitter. The former Stanford professor is now retired and lives with his wife Kristy Hinze, a former Victoria's Secret and Sports Illustrated model, and his young daughter. Clark says he leads a relatively comfortable life collecting art--with several pieces from Picasso, Monet, Matisse and van Gogh--and wine. He calls his 40,000-bottle Burgundy wine collection his "liquid asset." A former ocean lover, he got sea legs and gave up sailing, listing his two yachts, Hanuman and Athena, for a collective $100 million. He was the major financial backer for Japanese dolphin hunting documentary, The Cove, as well as the namesake behind the James H. Clark Bio-X Center at Stanford University. He also gives yearly to the Perlman Music Program in New York.

name: Billionaires
bio: Jack Dorsey, one of Silicon Valley's youngest tech executives, makes the Forbes Billionaires list for the first time because of his stake in mobile payment startup Square. While Dorsey made a name for himself as a cofounder and leader of 140-character microblogging company Twitter, most of his fortune is derived from his roughly 25% stake in Square, which is attempting to revolutionize how money is exchanged from person to person and was recently valued by a Blackrock purchase on the secondary market at north of $9 billion. Dorsey serves as Square's CEO and Twitter's executive chairman. The New York University dropout spun off Twitter from audio blogging startup Odeo in 2007 and turned it into a worldwide social networking phenomenon. Dorsey cofounded Square in 2009. A certified masseur, he is known for his eclectic interests, which include punk music and clothes.
title: CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: John Edson started building sailboats in his Seattle garage and founded Bayliner Marine Corp. in 1955, focusing on affordable plywood motorboats. He sold the enterprise to the Brunswick Corporation for $425 million in 1986. In 2005, he donated $5.4 million to an Arizona State University entrepreneurship program. Edson is a longtime supporter of Seattle's Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center and enjoys flying and spending time on his 164-ft yacht, Evviva (Italian for "long live"). He retains a small stake in Bayliner and also has an equity stake in Westport Shipyard.

name: Billionaires
bio: Oilman Paul Foster returns to the World Billionaires List for the first time since 2008 because of the surging stock price of his company, Western Refining. As of February, the company's shares are up more than 90%. Western Refining operates two refineries with a combined capacity of 155,000 barrels of crude oil per day and owns approximately 225 convenience stores in the Southwestern U.S. A graduate of Baylor, he became a certified public account before running finances for oil refineries across the Southwest. He founded Western Refining in 1997 and took it public in 2006. He spent his childhood finding ways to make money from manning fireworks stands to bagging groceries. As a teenager he spent his summers in the New Mexico oil fields welding pipes, digging ditches, cleaning tanks. He called that labor "the single biggest motivation to get an education."
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Fu Guangming supplies chicken to KFC in China through his Fujian Sunner Development. Fu's net worth is down slightly in the past year due to the company's slipping shares. Sales in the first six months of 2012 soared by nearly half, but its net profit rose only 1% to $20 million. Earnings have been hurt by lower chicken prices and higher raw material costs. A tough year hasn't dampened Fu's ambitions. In August Fujian Sunner announced plans to triple annual production of chickens from 250 million to 750 million birds in the next five years.

name: Billionaires
bio: Suat Gunsel is the owner of the largest educational facility in Northern Cyprus, the Near East University, whose education business is booming. He also owns interests in a hospital, bank, gas station, plastics and cable companies. However, the main bulk of his wealth is tied to the land he owns in Northern Cyprus and Turkey. His daughter Cemre got married in a lavish cermony last year. Suat likes to spend his time jogging, riding horses and playing tennis. He also collects stamps and antique cars.

name: Billionaires
bio: Dan Harrison III leased his 100,000 ranch in south Texas to Shell Oil for $1 billion in cash plus royalties on future oil and gas production from the prolific Eagle Ford shale. The 2010 deal appears to be the biggest ever for a family with deep roots in Texas oil. His grandfather, the first Dan Harrison, was a legendary Texas oilman, teaming up with J.S. Abercrombie to discover gushers like the Old Ocean field in Brazoria County. He built up and oil and ranching empire across Texas. Father Dan Jr. ran the ranchland and was a master breeder of quarterhorses. To this day Dan III maintains a quarterhorse operation on a ranch in Fulshear. For a time, Dan III shared the empire with brother Bruce (d. 2004), and back in 1990 they sold a 43,000-acre west Texas ranch for about $70 million. Very private.

name: Billionaires
bio: Huang Zhenda is a newcomer to the Forbes Billionaires List this year. The founder of the diversified Guangdong Liantai Group worked early in his life as a construction laborer in Shantou in Guangdong province in 1965, before setting up the Shantou Dahao Infrastructure Co. in 1984 and Guangdong Liantai Group in May 2008. Liantai's businesses include toll roads, contracting, real estate and waste-water treatment. The privately held company raised $241 million in a bond sale last March to invest in a highway in Hunan. His son, Jianxun, is currently the chairman.

name: Billionaires
bio: Huo Qinghua is a newcomer to the Forbes Billionaires List this year. Huo is chairman of China Kingho Energy Group, one of the country's largest privately held mining and energy companies, with operations in China, Africa and Mongolia. Huo's daughter Huo Rui, 30, is a company supervisor. Kingho, which was founded in 1996, in October signed a memorandum of understanding to work with Australian mining consultancy Runge as it expands globally.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mohammed Ibrahim, known as ?Mo,? founded Celtel, a mobile phone company that now serves 23 countries in Africa and the Middle East. He sold it in 2005 for $3.4 billion and pocketed $1.4 billion. He now lives in London and spends his time on philanthropy and investing in Africa. In 2000 before becoming CEO of Celtel, he sold off the company's former parent company, MSI, for more than $600 million. In 2006 he created the Mo Ibrahim Foundation to improve governance and leadership in Africa. It gives a lifetime award of $5 million over 10 years to retired African heads of state who have left their countries materially better off and more transparent. The foundation is headed by Ibrahim's daughter, Hadeel, and for the last three years has not given out the yearly prize, citing a lack of "visionary leadership" necessary to facilitate change. The foundation also publishes a 300-page index of conditions in 53 developing countries covering 88 factors such as health, press freedom, and infrastructure, often thought of as the most thorough compilation of quantitative information on Africa.  Future projects will include information on agricultural development and climate change.
title: Founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Daisy Igel is Brazilian billionaire, new to the list this year, who tries hard to stay out of the limelight. Her fortune lies in a nearly 8% stake she inherited of Ultrapar, a Brazilian company engaged in fuel distribution and petrochemical production, with more than 9,000 employees. Shares of the company rose more than 20% over the past year. Igel is the daughter of Ultrapar's founder, Ernesto Igel, and sister of Pery Igel, who ran the company until he died in 1998. In April 2012, Oxiteno, one of Ultrapar's subsidiaries, acquired a specialty chemicals plant located in Pasadena, Texas. Igel is an architect and lives in Rio de Janeiro.

name: Billionaires
bio: Robert Ingham, who is new to the Forbes Billionaires list, put poultry group Inghams Enterprises up for sale in July 2012 and has gotten interest from food groups throughout Asia. The company is also reportedly exploring an IPO. Bob Ingham's grandfather Walter started the business in 1918 with a rooster and six hens. Robert and his brother Jack inherited the unlisted company from their father more than 50 years ago. Ingham says the company generates annual sales of $2.1 billion. He used to own one of Australia's biggest thoroughbred racing and breeding operations, but sold it in 2008 to Sheikh Mohammed bin Rashid al-Maktoum, ruler of Dubai, for a reported $473 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Melville, N.Y.-based MSC Industrial Direct, provider of office and industrial equipment worldwide. Founded in 1941 by his father Sidney Jacobson, the firm thrived for several years as a traditional distributor. However, Jacobson was concerned that two customers made up nearly 90 percent of his business, and looked to catalog sales to supplement his customer base. The rest is history. Today, the company has sales of $2.4 billion. Mitchell, Sidney's only son, entered the family business in 1976, became president in 1982 and was CEO from 1995 through 2005 and is currently the company's largest shareholder.

name: Billionaires
bio: Bent Jensen is new to the Forbes Billionaires list. He is the owner and CEO of Linak, a Danish firm that makes linear actuators, devices that convert power into linear motion. They are used in industrial equipment, furniture, and healthcare equipment such as hospital beds. The company was founded in 1907 by Jensen's grandfather and it originally manufactured pulleys, grinding mills and forges. Jensen, who has a degree in mechanical engineering, joined the firm in 1976 with an idea for a new product. That product became the linear actuator which Linak started selling in 1979.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ryoichi Jinnai retired from consumer lender Promise in 2001, the same year his only child, son Hideki, died. Jinnai now raises cattle and grows mangos and bananas in greenhouses on Japan's northern island of Hokkaido, known for its frigid winters. As for Promise, the company he founded, it was acquired by Sumitomo in a stock swap in December 2011.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ke Xiping chairs the Xiamen Hengxing Group, which has investments in real estate, mining, auto parts, trade, electronics, transportation and dairy. His wealth has declined from a year ago in part because of a fall in the share price of Zijin Mining Group. Ke was elected last year as chairman of the Xiamen Association of Industry and Commerce. Ke has donated more than $32 million to charity over the years, and Ke with his wife ranked No.41 on the Forbes China 2012 philanthropy list with 32 million yuan ($5 million) of giving.

name: Billionaires
bio: Kim Jun-Ki is new to the Forbes Billionaires list. His fortune comes from the Dongbu Group, a huge conglomerate he founded in 1968 when he was 24 years old. The group started out as Miryung Construction, which translates to ?a beautiful rising.? It now provides services in the steel, chemicals, and financial industries.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mehmet Omer Koc is a third generation member of the Koc Family and deputy Chairman of the Board of Koc Holding, whose stock price is up 30% over the past year. He is also Chairman of the Board of Tupras which is Turkey's only oil refinery. Mehmet is one of Turkey's most noted art collectors with a large collection of orientalist paintings, drawings, books and an etching collection as well as a large contemporary painting collection. His brothers Mustafa Vehbi and Yildirim Ali Koc, his aunts Suna Kirac and Semahat Arsel and his father Mustafa Rahmi Koc are also billionaires.

name: Billionaires
bio: Dmitry Korzhev and his partner Dmitry Troitsky took the Russian supermarket chain O'Key Group public on the London Stock Exchange in the fall of 2010. Its market capitalization as of early 2013 is $3 billion. They began collaborating as students, selling automobiles and in 1993 founding Mega-Auto, which is now one of the biggest car dealers in St. Petersburg. In 1995 they founded Multon, a juice producer, and after 10 years they sold it to Coca-Cola for $500 million. They launched O'Key in 2001, and since 2007 they have owned Neva Rus, an Armenian metallurgy business. In November 2011 they opened a new ore dressing enterprise, Sagamar, investing $94 million in it.

name: Billionaires
bio: Throughout the 1990s Yuri Kovalchuck was a good friend of Vladimir Putin, who was then deputy mayor of St. Petersburg. They both had country houses in the Ozero dacha cooperative, and when Putin became president of Russia, many of the cooperative's members' careers improved. Kovalchuck is now the largest shareholder of Rossiya Bank, which controls Sogas, one of Russia's largest insurance companies. Sogas' main client is the gas behemoth Gazprom. In 2011 Sogas lost control of the asset management company Leader, which owns a 41% stake in Gazprombank, one of Russia's biggest banks (Gazprom and VTB bank became Leader's main shareholders). At the same time, though, he increased his bank's stake in the company that owns 25.2% of CTC Media, one of Russia's leading media companies.

name: Billionaires
bio: Michael Krasny started selling used computers after receiving a huge response to his first $3, 3-line ad in the Chicago Tribune for his old IBM. An auto-dealer's son, Krasny founded Computer Discount Warehouse in 1984, took it public in 1993, then retired from leadership in 2001. He's been out of the news since selling his company to private equity firm Madison Dearborn Partners for $7.3 billion in 2007. Krasny donated more than $350 million in shares to charity. He is now listed as president of Sawdust Investment Management Corporation in Illinois.
title: Investor
employment: {'name': 'Sawdust Investment Management Corp.', 'title': 'President', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Lee Man Tat is a third-generation leader of family business Lee Kum Kee, one of the world's largest suppliers of oyster sauce, soy sauce and more than other 200 Chinese sauces and condiments. It also sells Chinese health food. The company traces its roots back to 1888, when the founder Lee Kum Sheng invented oyster sauce.

name: Billionaires
bio: Eric Lefkofsky is an investor and cofounder of Groupon, the Chicago-based online coupon machine, whose stock price fell nearly 70% over the past year. As a result, Lefkofsky lost more than half of his fortune and cofounder and Groupon CEO Andrew Mason was ousted. Groupon, which was once labeled the fastest-growing company ever, started when Mason called Lefkofksy in December 2006 with an idea to launch a company that "used the power of tipping points and the Internet to solve collective action problems." Lefkofsky offered $1 million if Mason would drop out of school and start that business. The pair made a fortune with Groupon's IPO in November 2011, the biggest by a U.S. Web company since Google. Lefkofsky also operates a venture fund, Light Bank. He grew up in the Detroit suburbs and got his start selling carpets during his freshman year at University of Michigan after being dumped by a girl.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: A former emergency room doctor, James Leininger started healthcare company Kinetic Concepts in a one-bedroom apartment in 1976. KCI first sold specialized hospital beds. Now its major business is wound care products. In November 2012 a consortium of private equity firms led by Apax Partners closed on a $6.3 billion acquisition of KCI. "Dr. Jim" was the largest individual shareholder and sold his stake in the company when Apax took it private. Leininger backs conservative causes and donated to Rick Perry's failed bid for the Republican presidential nomination in 2012. He also contributed $5,000 between July  and September 2012 to Donna Campbell, the Tea-Party-backed Texas state senator. He supports school choice and home schooling. He and his wife have given at least $100 million to improve education and provide scholarships. He enjoys fishing, bow hunting, scuba diving and hiking.

name: Billionaires
bio: Li Li chairs Shenzhen Hepalink Pharmaceutical, a maker of the blood thinner heparin. His wealth is down $800 million since October after a fall in the company's profits during the first three quarters of last year, which fueled a slide in its stock price. One notable foreign investor in Hepalink, GS Direct Pharma -- part of Goldman Sachs -- lowered its stake to 6% last year from 11% previously. The company is 72% owned by Li and his wife, Li Tan. Hepalink in January said it paid $10 million for a 10% stake in Toronto-traded ProMetic Life Sciences. Li, a former worker in a meat company, holds a chemistry degree from Sichuan University.

name: Billionaires
bio: Lim Hariyanto Wijaya Sarwono is making his debut on the Forbes Billionaires list after taking his palm oil plantation company, Bumitama Agri, public in Singapore. He controls roughly half of the company together with his son, Lim Gunawan Hariyanto. Lim's father, a Chinese immigrant, set up a small grocery shop in Indonesia nearly a century ago. Lim transformed the business by expanding into mining and timber. His plywood-product manufacturing firm, Tirta Mahakam, has been listed in Jakarta since 1999. Lim also has plans to take his nickel mining business public.

name: Billionaires
bio: Liu Chung Ming is the deputy chairman and CEO of Nine Dragon Paper, one of Asia's largest producers of paper products. After starting out mainly as a supplier of packaging used to make boxes for manufacturers in southern China's export hub, Nine Dragons has been turning toward China's domestic market. The company is looking to increase its manufacturing capacity by 21% by June 2014 compared with two years earlier. Sales in the six months to December rose by 17% rose from a year earlier to $2.4 billion. Liu's wealth and the company's shares have gained on hopes for business recovery this year. Liu's wife Cheung Yan is also a member of this year's Billionaires List.

name: Billionaires
bio: Alexander Lutsenko, former Soviet army officer, in 1994 together with his spouse Natalia founded Sodrugestvo Group. Sodrugestvo specializes on fodder production, importing raw products from Brazil. The group has own terminals in Kaliningrad (Baltic Sea), railcar stock and processing plants in Russia, Brazil and Denmark. In 2012 Japanese trader Mitsui & Co bought 10% in the group.

name: Billionaires
bio: William Macaulay founded energy-focused private equity giant First Reserve, which now holds 41 portfolio companies with $200 billion in revenues. Two years ago First Reserve made a 50% return on a $2 billion investment in convertible bonds of newly public commodities trader Glencore. Also bought 80% of copper company Mettalum Holdings for $960 million. Owns coal in China, gas in Pennsylvania, oil offshore west Africa and a bunch of solar plants. Macaulay is an avid bird watcher; with his wife Linda, he has traveled the world recording bird sounds. Donated to Cornell University, which named its renowned library of natural sounds after the Macaulays. "I like bird watching. It's quiet."

name: Billionaires
bio: Edir Macedo is new to the Forbes Billionaires list. He is one of the world's richest religious leaders and a prominent media baron in Brazil. Raised as a Catholic, he converted to evangelical Christianity in the early 1970s. In 1977 he founded his own denomination in Rio de Janeiro, the Universal Church of the Kingdom of God, which grew into one of the biggest and most controversial religions in Brazil. The sect follows "prosperity theology," which holds that faith and commitment to a church are rewarded with wealth.
