The bulk of Macedo's fortune comes from his ownership of Rede Record, Brazil's second-largest broadcaster, which he acquired in 1990 from fellow billionaire Silvio Santos. It's not clear where he got the money to buy the company. Brazil's Public Ministry has been probing the question for more than 10 years. Reports have suggested he used church funds. Macedo won't comment. He also owns W67CI, an Atlanta-based Telemundo affiliate. His 2012 biography, "Nothing to Lose," chronicles the 11 days he spent in jail in 1992 on accusations of charlatanism (he was cleared of the charges). The book surpassed sales of Steve Jobs' biography in Brazil and topped the country's best-seller list for six consecutive weeks.

name: Billionaires
bio: Tech investor Yuri Milner broke onto the Billionaires List in 2011 thanks to his savvy timing on social media. His investment vehicle DST scooped up sizable pieces of Facebook, Zynga and Groupon well before those firms went public. DST's $200 million investment in Facebook in 2009 is up an estimated five-fold. He's since bought stakes in Twitter, Spotify, Airbnb and Chinese online retailers 360buy.com and Alibaba Group. In 2010, Milner divided his DST  into two parts, taking its Russian Web portal Mail.Ru public (Milner has since sold off most of his Mail.ru stake), to focus on international investments at DST. Milner plans to invest in every startup that comes out of Silicon Valley incubator Y Combinator without reading the business plan. The former particle physicist last year gave $3 million in prizes to nine theoretical physicists and later announced two "special" $3 million prizes: one to Stephen Hawking and one split between a number of people who played important roles in this year's Higgs boson discovery at the LHC.
title: Investor

name: Billionaires
bio: Manuel "Matty" Moroun controls Detroit's Ambassador Bridge, the busiest border crossing between the U.S. and Canada. But the trucking and logistics magnate is desperately trying to fend off competition from a proposed public bridge two miles downriver. His bridge, which handles 8,000 trucks a day and $100 billion in trade every year, takes in about $60 million a year in tolls and another $15 million annually in gas and duty-free sales. He and his son, Matthew, own other transportation-related assets, including Universal Truckload Services and other trucking firms, logistics support, air freight and insurance.

name: Billionaires
bio: Charles Munger, Warren Buffett's right-hand man, continues to gift away his valuable Berkshire Hathaway Class A shares to his favorite universities and philanthropic causes. He has not given enough, however, to fall under the 10-figure mark, especially with Berkshire's shares performing so well (they're up more than 20% year-over-year as of February). His two children, Molly and Charles, Jr. became the focus of the recent state election in California as they battled on opposite sides of several education propositions, spending more than a combined $80 million to support their initiatives. The Omaha native dropped out of the University of Michigan to serve as a meteorologist in the U.S. Army Air Corps. He later attended Harvard Law. The pragmatic investor met friend and business partner Buffett at a dinner party in 1959.
title: Vice Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Gabe Newell is one of the most respected figures in the video game business. Valve Corporation continued its growth despite a lack of major 2012 hits. The Bellevue, Wash. software firm scored in 2011 both as game developer (Portal 2 was a monster hit) and game distributor -- digital distribution platform Steam doubled sales for the seventh straight year, and has over 40 million users. Newell owns more than 50% of privately-held Valve, which he co-founded in 1996 after cashing in stock options earned over a decade producing software for Microsoft.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ioan Niculae returns to the Forbes Billionaires list with soaring sales at Interagro, the agricultural and fertilizer conglomerate he founded. Over the past year, he invested nearly $50 million in a cogeneration plant, part of his long-term strategy to reduce energy costs and begin to resell excess capacity. Niculae also owns a private plane operator. He got his start at a state-owned agricultural company, then branched out on his own. Niculae is an avid hunter, who prefers home to travel.

name: Billionaires
bio: Guilherme Paulus joins the Forbes billionaires list as a result of Brazil's booming tourism sector. Paulus co-founded tour operator CVC Brasil Operadora e Agencia de Viagens S.A. in 1972 at age 24. His partner was a Brazilian politician, who left the venture four years later. Under Paulus' leadership CVC has grown to become Latin America's largest tour operator. In late 2009, global private equity firm Carlyle group bought 63.6% stake in CVC a price estimated at $420 million. The company is expected to list its shares this year. In 2005, Paulus founded GJP Hotels and Resorts, which controls over 15 hotels and resorts in Brazil and is bidding to build and maintain hotels near airports in Brazil. The country expects a huge influx of visitors for the 2014 World Soccer Cup and 2016 Summer Olympics. Paulus worked for IBM as an intern before he was 20.

name: Billionaires
bio: Nicholas Pritzker is a nephew of A.N. Pritzker (d. 1986), who, with his sons Jay (d. 1999) and Robert (d. 2011) created industrial conglomerate Marmon Holdings and the Hyatt hotel chain. Back in 2007, the family sold Marmon to Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway and the extended Pritzker family has been selling assets it owns jointly for the past decade. Nick was for many years the head of Hyatt's new hotel development efforts. He retired in 2009. Pritzker teamed up with Netflix CEO Reed Hastings and former billionaire Chuck Feeney to bring an end to the death penalty in California in the 2012 election. Both he and Feeney threw $1 million at the repeal, but voters chose to keep the controversial law.

name: Billionaires
bio: Que Wenbin is the biggest shareholder of Shenzhen-listed Gansu Duyiwei Biological Pharmaceutical. His stake in the Tibetan herbal medicine producer accounts for the largest share of his personal fortune. Sales last year rose by 10% to $54 million, though profit increased by a slower 3.3% amid easing economic growth in China. Que also controls Sichuan Western Resources Holding, a mining company, and Sichuan Hengkang Capital Management, an investment business.

name: Billionaires
bio: Infrastructure tycoon G.M.Rao whose fortune shrank as shares of his flagship GMR Infrastructure tumbled in the past year partly on concerns over its ballooning debt, which stands at $6.6 billion. The recent cancellation of its airport contract by the government of Maldives ballooned into controversy with company claiming $800 million as compensation. In January, GMR terminated what was country's biggest highways contract worth $1.4 billion, citing delays in getting approvals.  Earlier, airlines had protested its move to hike charges at Delhi airport by over 350%. A federal auditor criticized the government for, among much else, giving GMR prime land on lease near Delhi airport at throwaway price. Company denied allegations.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former engineer James Ratcliffe is the chairman of $43 billion (sales) chemical powerhouse Ineos Group. Over the years, Ineos has grown through a series of acquisitions and partnerships, including the purchase of Belgium-based Tessenderlo's European chlor-vinyls business for $110 million, a $1 billion sale of a 50% stake in Ineos's European refinery operations to Petrochina, and a joint venture with Germany's BASF, making it one of the world's biggest producers of styrene monomer and polystyrene. In 2012, the firm formed a joint venture with Accsys Technologies to produce and distribute Tricoya, a water-resistant wood-based construction material.  The company's biggest acquisition came in 2005, an $8.7 billion deal to buy BP Group's Innovene business. In 2010, Ineos moved its headquarters from the U.K. to Switzerland. The firm has expressed interest in pursuing joint ventures in the Middle East.

name: Billionaires
bio: Alberto Roemmers is new to the Forbes Billionaires list. He heads Laboratorios Roemmers, Argentina's largest pharmaceutical group, founded by his father in 1921. He also has an investment in a real estate project in Uruguay, he produces olive oil in three different provinces in Argentina, and he owns a stake in Gador, an Argentine pharmaceutical company. Roemmers is of German descent. He collects the works of Fernando Fader, a French- born Argentine impressionist painter. He is married to Hebe Colman and together they had four sons: Alberto Junior, Alejandro, Pablo and Christian, who died in a 1998 accident while participating in a paragliding competition in Mendoza, a region of foothills and high plains on the eastern side of the Andes.

name: Billionaires
bio: Lord David Sainsbury of Turville inherited a stake in $38 billion (sales) Sainsbury's, one of the U.K.'s largest supermarket chains. He served as chairman and CEO but withdrew in 1998 when he was appointed to the government. He spent eight years as Minister of Science and Innovation and resigned in 2006. He has been loyal to the Labour Party, donating more than $15 million since 2000. But his support of the party has reportedly waned since Ed Miliband took the helm in 2010. Sainsbury supports Ed's brother, David Miliband. In 1987, he established the Sainsbury Management Fellowship Society to prepare engineers from the U.K. to become effective C-level executives and corporate leaders. The program provides $472,000 in MBA scholarships to young, qualified engineers in the U.K.

name: Billionaires
bio: Vladimir Scherbakov had a brilliant career at the end of the Soviet era: In 1990, when he was 40, he was appointed first deputy prime minister of the USSR and head of its economic planning agency, Gosplan. Then in 1991, after the collapse of the Soviet state, he founded the International Investment and Privatization Fund, to help to privatize companies in Russia and other former republics. Five years later he founded Avtotor Holding, which assembles foreign cars in Kaliningrad oblast while enjoying the tax benefits of a special economic zone. In 2012 Avtotor built 265,000 automobiles and became the second biggest car maker in Russia, after AvtoVAZ.

name: Billionaires
bio: Airat Shaimiev is new to the Forbes Billionaires list. He co-owns the TAIF Group, a large regional holding company with assets in the Republic of Tatarstan. The company includes oil refineries, two gas station chains, chemical factories, power plants and construction companies. TAIF became a shareholder in most of its companies during Russia's privatization in the mid-90s. Shaimiev is CEO of Tatautodor, which does road construction and repair in Tatarstan. Airat's father, Mintimer Shaimiev, was Tatarstan's first president and his brother, Radik Shaimiev, is a fellow billionaire. An avid race car driver, he won a European competition called Autocross in 2002, 2004 and 2005.

name: Billionaires
bio: Radik Shaimiev is new to the Forbes Billionaires list. He co-owns the TAIF Group, a large regional holding company with assets in the Republic of Tatarstan. The company includes oil refineries, two gas station chains, chemical factories, power plants and construction companies. TAIF became a shareholder in most of its companies during Russia's privatization in the mid-90s. Radik's father, Mintimer Shaimiev, was Tatarstan's first president and his brother, Airat Shaimiev, is a fellow billionaire. An avid race car driver, he won a European competition called Autocross in 2003.

name: Billionaires
bio: Billionaires list newcomer Sheng Baijiao is the CEO of Belle Holding, China's biggest retailer of women's footwear with more 12,000 outlets. Belle also sells sportswear at 5,400 stores. China's sportswear industry was dogged last year by high inventories, but investors have pushed up Belle's shares on expectations of improved business in 2013.

name: Billionaires
bio: New billionaire Edward Stack made his fortune from the publicly traded Dick's Sporting Goods chain. The roots of the business date back to 1948, the year his father opened a fishing bait shop in Binghamton, New York, with $300 of his mother's savings. In 1984 Stack bought the two stores his father owned and expanded the business. He took the company public in 2002. He is still CEO of the retailer, which now has 500 locations in 44 states. He is also its biggest individual shareholder with a 15% stake; his ex-wife also has some shares. Dick's is one of the biggest gun retailers in the country and after the December 2012 mass school shooting in Newtown, Conn., the stores suspended the sale of high-powered rifles.
title: Entrepreneur
employment: {'name': "Dick's Sporting Goods", 'uri': 'companies/dicks-sporting-goods', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Former McDonald's executive Woods Staton has been busy spreading the Golden Arches across Latin America. In 2007, his Arcos Dorados company (which means "Golden Arches" in Spanish) paid McDonald's $700 million for 1,560 restaurants and the rights to operate McDonald's in Latin America and the Caribbean. It now owns 1,880 outlets in 20 countries and territories. Revenue in 2011 hit $3.7 billion. The burger king should feel at home in any of his restaurants; he speaks English, Spanish, and Portuguese. (He was born in Colombia to a Brazilian father and a Czech mother.) His net worth has fallen by $500 million since a year ago as Arcos Dorados shares wilted amid slower than expected growth and a depreciation of Brazil's currency against the dollar. Its McDonald's restaurants cater to the local crowd: in addition to the standard Big Mac, they offer arepas in Venezuela, chicken with hogao in Colombia, and Mexican food in Mexico. Staton, whose grandfather Albert Staton founded Coca-Cola bottler Panamerican Beverages, became a billionaire in April 2011, when Arcos Dorados debuted on the New York Stock Exchange.

name: Billionaires
bio: Widow Dorothea Steinbruch gets most of her wealth from her stake in one of Brazil's largest steelmakers, Companhia Siderurgica Nacional (CSN ). The company used to be owned by the state. It was founded in 1941 by Brazil's then-President  Getúlio Vargas. It was privatized in 1993 when the Brazilian government sold its 91% interest in the Company. This is the first year Dorothea is on the Forbes Billionaires list on her own, without her family members. Forbes is counting only her holdings, which is why her net worth appears to have dropped by $3.4 billion. Dorothea is not involved in running the business. Her son Benjamin serves as chairman and chief executive of CSN. Through Vicunha Group, Dorothea also owns stakes in Vicunha Textil, one of the largest textile manufacturers in the world and Banco Fibra, founded in 1987 and positioned as one of the largest Brazilian controlled private sector banks in assets. Dorothea's son Ricardo is chairman of the board of Banco Fibra.

name: Billionaires
bio: Benny Subianto returns to the Forbes World's Billionaires list after dropping off in 2012. He is one of five major shareholders in Indonesian coal miner Adaro Energy. Falling coal prices have driven down the value of his Adaro shares but his net worth is up thanks to his private holdings, including palm oil producer Triputra Agro Persada and rubber manufacturer Kirana Megatara. Triputra Agro Persada plans to go public in three to five years' time and is reportedly planning to increase its planted area by about two-thirds by 2015. He is the former vice chairman of carmaker Astra International and the former president director of United Tractor.

name: Billionaires
bio: Tang Xiuguo is one of four executives from equipment manufacturer Sany Group to make the 2013 World's Billionaires list, along with Liang Wengen, Mao Zhongwu and Xiang Wenbo. His wealth is down from a year ago amid a drop in the stock prices of domestically traded flagship Sany Heavy Industry and Hong Kong-listed coal equipment maker Sany Heavy Equipment International. The company suffered a setback in September when the U.S. rejected a Sany-backed application to build a wind farm next to a U.S. military base in Oregon. Trade barriers in the U.S. were not to be found in Germany, where Sany successfully teamed up with CITIC Private Equity Advisors of China to purchase Putzmeister, one of the world's largest concrete pump manufacturers, in a deal worth $475 million last year. Sany in December moved its headquarters from Changsha to Beijing in a step to facilitate its international growth. Tang, along with Liang, is a graduate of Central South University in China.

name: Billionaires
bio: Lawyer turned investor Wichai Thongthan represented deposed Thai prime minister Thaksin Shinawatra in an asset concealment case in 2001. He started investing when clients couldn't afford fees and instead paid him with real estate. Sits on boards of various listed companies including listed hospital company outfit Bangkok Dusit Medical, in which he and his wife own 12%; its shares have climbed 50% since Thongtha debuted on Thailand's list in September, making him a billionaire for the first time. Cable Thai Holdings, which he owns 25% of, spent $170 million last year to upgrade viewers to digital cable; it beat out bigger competitors in bid for broadcast rights for English Premier League football in Thailand, Cambodia and Laos through 2016.

name: Billionaires
bio: Dmitry Troitsky with his partner Dmitry Korzhev took the Russian supermarket chain O'Key Group public on the London Stock Exchange in the fall of 2010. Its market capitalization as of early 2013 is $3 billion. They began collaborating as students, selling automobiles and in 1993 founding Mega-Auto, which is now one of the biggest car dealers in St. Petersburg. In 1995 they founded Multon, a juice producer, and after 10 years they sold it to Coca-Cola for $500 million. They launched O'Key in 2001, and since 2007 they have owned Neva Rus, an Armenian metallurgy business. In November 2011 they opened a new ore dressing enterprise, Sagamar, investing $94 million in it.

name: Billionaires
bio: Hamdi Ulukaya, who is new to the Forbes Billionaires list, is the founder, president and CEO of Chobani Inc, formerly Agro Farma, the maker of Chobani Greek yogurt. Born in Turkey, he came to the United States to study business in 1997. In 2001 he started Euphrates, a feta cheese company, in central New York. While running Euphrates he saw a for-sale ad for a Kraft Foods yogurt plant in a neighboring town. He bought the plant in 2005 and started perfecting the recipe for Greek-style yogurt. The first order was shipped in October 2007. Since then the company's sales have grown to nearly $1 billion annually. In December 2012 he opened a new yogurt plant in Twin Falls, Idaho. He is facing a reported $1.5 billion lawsuit brought by his ex-wife, Dr. Alyse Giray. She sued him in August 2012, claiming that she gave him money to start and expand his original business in exchange for a 53% stake. She claims that he used some of the funds to buy the yogurt factory that became Agro-Farma. Ulukaya has said the suit has no merit.
title: Entrepreneur

name: Billionaires
bio: Ye Cheng, a newcomer to the Forbes Billionaires List, chairs the Shandong Landbridge Group, which has business interests that include port logistics, petrochemicals, timber trading and real estate. The company also holds a stake in Rizhao Bank, located in Shandong. Landbridge's business partners include Chinese government-controlled giants Cnooc and China National Petroleum. Ye is the vice president of the Rizhao City Charity Federation and is a director at Rizhao Bank.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ye Yuanxi chairs Shenzhen Grandland Decoration Group, one of the largest interior decoration and construction companies in China. He returns to the Forbes Billionaires List after dropping off in 2012. In November 2012 the company invested in window and curtain wall maker Shenzheng Fangte Decoration Engineering and Shenzhen Base Point, a designer of intelligent building systems. Ye serves as chairman of the Shenzhen Promotion Association for Small and Medium Enterprises and vice chairman of the China Building Decoration Association. Ye's brother Ye Yuandong is a director and deputy general manager of the listed company.

name: Billionaires
bio: San Francisco 49ers owner Denise DeBartolo York watched her team go all the way to the Super Bowl in 2013, only to lose to the Baltimore Ravens. The 49ers have been on a tear since they hired coach Jim Harbaugh in January 2011, and broke ground on a new 68,500-seat stadium in Santa Clara in April 2012. The franchise has seen its value go up every year for the last decade, and that's before the revenue from the new stadium kicks in. Daughter of real estate magnate Edward DeBartolo Sr., York and her brother Edward Jr. are both billionaires. She took control of the 49ers franchise in 2000 after Edward Jr. pled guilty to a federal charge related to the corruption case of Louisiana Governor Edwin Edwards. Her son Jed is the 49ers' president and CEO.
title: Co-Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Chinese real estate tycoon Zhang Guiping saw a slight jump in his net worth thanks to rising shares of his Suning Universal on hopes for a rebound in the country's real estate market. Suning Universal's profit last year was, however, underwhelming: revenue declined by 7% in the first nine months of last year to $435 million, contributing to a 29% drop in net profit to $88 million. Zhang owns commercial real estate in the eastern Chinese city of Nanjing, and has been diversifying into hotels. Zhang Guiping's brother Zhang Jindong is also a member of this year's Forbes Billionaires List.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mori Arkin is an investor in the pharma company Perrigo and Israel's largest bank, Hapoalim. He got his start in business in 1972 helping his father run a small Israeli pharmaceutical distribution company. The two saw the writing on the wall as big pharma companies began creating their own distribution arms, leaving no room for regional businesses, and Arkin oversaw the company's transformation into a generics manufacturer. In 1983 he incorporated it as Agis Industries.He ran it under that name for two decades before selling it to Perrigo, which was willing to pay a 21% premium above its roughly $700 million market capitalization. Now Arkin has $100 million invested in about 15 medical startup companies, many of them under the umbrella of Arkin Holdings. He cites the 1997 publication of an essay he wrote, "One of the Marys . . . : An Interdisciplinary Analysis of Michelangelo's Florentine Pietà," in The Art Bulletin, as one of his proudest accomplishments.

name: Billionaires
bio: Iraqi immigrant to Israel worked his way up the chain at First International Bank of Israel, eventually serving as its CEO from 1978 to 1986. He bought the company two decades later. Now the bulk of his fortune comes from Paz Oil, which became the first Israeli company to vertically integrate the oil supply chain in 2006, when it won the Israeli government's tender for the sale of the Ashdod Oil Refinery. It also runs a series of convenience stores throughout Israel. Bino is famous for working fast, quietly and for paying in cash.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cui Zhixiang is a first-time member of the Forbes Billionaires List this year. The former banker at the People's Bank of China took the plunge as an entrepreneur in 1998 when he co-founded Dongying Fangyuan Nonferrous Metals. The privately held company, based in Shandong province, is one of China's largest producers of copper cathodes.

name: Billionaires
bio: Best known in Europe for his EasyJet discount airline (modeled on Herb Kelleher's Southwest Airlines), the Greek-born entrepreneur Stelios returns to the billionaire ranks this year after a 6 year hiatus thanks to a strong year at the airline. EasyJet's passenger numbers were up 7% to around 60 million, contributing to a 6% increase in revenues and helping push its shares up more than 50% in the past year. Stelios also heads up EasyGroup, the parent company to the Easy brand, which includes EasyGym, EasyBus, EasyCar and EasyHotel. He was also the founder of Stelmar Tankers, a shipping company that listed on the New York Stock Exchange and later sold to OSG shipping group in 2005. Stelios, who prefers to go by his first name only, was knighted in 2006 for his services to entrepreneurship.

name: Billionaires
bio: A value investor known for avoiding leverage and holding cash. Seth Klarman's Boston-based Baupost Group has seen assets under management balloon to $26 billion as new money flowed in. Klarman, 55, tries keep a low-profile. His out-of-print book Margin of Safety (which sells for $2,500 on Amazon.com) has become a new bible of value investing. His performance trailed 7.6% net range the U.S. stock market in 2012. "While our return for the year was not scintillating, we regard it as acceptable considering the limited risk incurred to achieve it," Klarman told investors in January. Baupost did do well with its big position in distressed debt of Lehman Brothers. He set up his Klarman Family Foundation, which has $255 million in assets, to back scientific research, promote access to music learning and support causes in Israel.
title: Investor

name: Billionaires
bio: Liu Baolin chairs pharmaceuticals and medical instruments marketer Jointown Pharmaceutical Group. Its sales have been rising in part on the strength of its national distribution network. Among other brands, Jointown distributes Church & Dwight electric toothbrushes and Trojan condoms. Its net profit in the first nine months of last year rose by 17.8% to $30.5 million, on sales that increased a fifth to $3.6 billion. Liu's brothers Shulin and Zhaonian are vice chairmen.

name: Billionaires
bio: Tougher times at German publishing house Holtzbrinck Group - owner of publishers Farrar, Straus & Giroux, St. Martin's Press and Henry Holt, as well as several German newspapers - mean a lower net worth for part owner Monika Schoeller. Net income at Holtzbrinck Group fell 40% in 2011 to $90 million (70 million Euros) while revenue dipped 4% to $2.86 billion (2.14 billion Euros), contributing to the $1 billion decline in her fortune. Schoeller, her brother Dieter von Holtzbrinck and her half-brother Stefan von Holtzbrinck inherited the publishing house from their father George, who founded it as a book club in 1948. In 2006, Schoeller and Stefan bought out Dieter's one-third share. In 2009 they sold German financial paper Handelsblatt, 51% of weekly paper Die Zeit and other assets to Dieter. Schoeller heads book publisher S. Fischer Verlag, which dates back to 1886. The group was the original publisher of Thomas Mann, Franz Kafka and Hermann Hesse.

name: Billionaires
bio: Leaner times at publishing house Holtzbrinck Group have shrunk the fortune of Stefan von Holtzbrinck. Net income for the group fell 40% in 2011 to $90 million (70 million Euros) while revenue dipped 4% to $2.86 billion (2.14 billion Euros), contributing to the $1 billion decline in his net worth since last year. Stefan has run the company--which he inherited along with his two siblings and includes book publishers Farrar Straus & Giroux, St. Martin's and Henry Holt - since 2001.  In 2006, Stefan and half-sister Monika Schoeller (also a billionaire) bought out Dieter's one-third share. Stefan and Schoeller later sold Dieter the financial newspaper Handelsbatt, 51% of weekly paper Die Zeit and other assets. A lawyer, Stefan apprenticed at Bloomsbury Publishing in London before joining the Holtzbrinck company in 1994. The group's HV Holtzbrinck Ventures is active in digital media and known to invest early in Internet businesses. In late 2012 Holtzbrinck sold its shares of daily deal website Groupon.

name: Billionaires
bio: Wang Jinshu makes his first appearance on the 2013 Billionaires List. He chairs Shandong Yuhuang Chemical, a major producer of isoprene, which is used to make synthetic rubber. Its isoprene is sold to the U.S., Italy, Brazil and elsewhere, according to the company's website. The privately held company has more than 4,400 employees. Wang is a member of the National People's Congress.

name: Billionaires
bio: Wang Junmin is the chairman of Xizang Haisco Pharmaceutical Group in Tibet. He debuts on this year's Billionaires List after the company's shares more than doubled since they began trading on the Shenzhen exchange in January 2012. Sales last year climbed 32% to $129 million; net profit rose by 42% to $71.5 million. Wang holds a bachelor's degree from Shenyang Pharmaceutical University. He founded his first business in 2000 with Fan Xiulian and Zheng Wei, who are both shareholders of Xizang Haisco. The company said in February it would invest up to $48 million in the city of Meishan in Sichuan Province to expand production.

name: Billionaires
bio: Soegiarto Adikoesoemo is new to the Forbes Billionaires list. He founded AKR Corporindo, a distributor of high speed diesel, marine fuel oil and industrial diesel oil to companies in the mining, power generation and bunker industries. In the early days AKR traded basic chemicals in Surabaya, East Java. It went public in 1994. Because of the declining price of coal, AKR recently got out of the coal business and started investing in business parks.  An art lover, Adikoesoemo gives away 2% of AKR's profits to local artists, mostly painters.

name: Billionaires
bio: Straight after high school, Joy Alukkas headed to the Gulf in 1987 to open his family's first overseas jewelry store. He later went off on his own, creating Joyalukkas, a jewelry retail chain that has $1.2 billion in sales from 85 stores in India and the Gulf. Its 58,000 square foot store in Chennai city is billed as the world's biggest jewelry store. He's set to open the Mall Of Joy, a one-stop shop for weddings in several Indian cities. Other interests include a luxury air charter service, money exchange and a chain of stores selling Indian wedding and trousseau wear.

name: Billionaires
bio: Patricia Angelini Rossi makes the billionaires list for the first time thanks to her stake in natural resources conglomerate Angelini Group, which she inherited from her late uncle Anacleto, who died in 2007. The group's largest holding is publicly-traded Antarchile, which distributes fuel, operates fishing and shipping businesses, and invests in energy and forestry. The group is the largest owner of forest land in Latin America, with 4 million acres throughout Chile, Argentina, Brazil and Uruguay. In September 2012 Antarchile's forestry subsidiary, Arauco, entered North America with the purchase of Canadian laminated product maker Flakeboard. In 2009 Patricia's brother Roberto Angelini, who heads up the Angelini Group's operations, struck a deal with Scandinavian paper maker Stora Enso to build a eucalyptus pulp mill in Uruguay. In late 2010 the Angelini Group purchased a 59% stake in Proenergia, a Colombian gas and fuel distributor, for $45 million. The Angelini family eschews publicity.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former owner of steelmaker Arcelor, Jose Maria Aristrain de la Cruz backed Indian billionaire Lakshmi Mittal in his successful 2006 bid to merge steel groups Arcelor and Mittal Steel. Aristrain got a sizable stake in ArcelorMittal, the world's largest steel company whose shares tumbled in 2011 and have not yet recovered, and in fact have fallen further still. Very press shy, Aristrain reportedly never travels in public without a bodyguard for fear of kidnapping and assassination attempts by Basque separatists. He owns a cattle ranch, Ganaderias Aguadulce, in the south of Spain, where he raises bulls for bullfighting.

name: Billionaires
bio: Lord Michael Anthony Ashcroft, a serial entrepreneur, has started numerous companies only to sell them before their bottoms fell out. His most significant acquisition was camping equipment manufacturer Hawley-Goodall, which he transformed into one of the security industry's leading firms after buying U.S. security firm ADT Security Services. Ashcroft's wealth comes from selling ADT to Tyco in a multi-billion-dollar reverse merger, landing him a windfall in Tyco shares, which he later sold. His fortune has grown over the years as he sold companies and shares. He once served as the deputy chairman of Britain's Conservative Party and remains a loyal supporter. Ashcroft owns British Caribbean Bank, and according to reports in the British press, he also secretly controlled Oxford Ventures, a company in theTurks and Caicos islands that the bank owed money to and that collapsed in 2010. Ashcroft denies the connection to Oxford Ventures. In 2009 he sued the U.K.'s Independent newspaper for libel. The trial concluded in 2012 with a personal apology to Aschcroft in court and an admission that no evidence of corruption had been found. Ashcroft has published five books and numerous articles detailing his dealings with the government and the media. He blogs regularly.

name: Billionaires
bio: Thomas Bailey's fortune comes from mutual fund giant Janus, which he founded in Denver in 1969. The firm had exceptional returns during the bull markets of the 1980s and 1990s. Losses mounted in 2000 and he resigned as CEO in 2002. Two years later he stepped down as chairman. He also sold his stake in the firm. Now he breeds horses at his Iron Rose Ranch in Carbondale, Colorado. He is a Michigan State graduate who worked on Wall Street before moving to Denver, where Janus is based.

name: Billionaires
bio: Enrique Banuelos is staking his fortune on two major projects: Barcelona World, a tourist and casino destination he is marketing as the next Monaco, and Formula E racing, an effort to create a Formula 1-style international racing championship with electric cars. He founded real estate firm Astroc Mediterraneo S.A., which debuted on the Spanish stock exchange in 2006, launching him on the Forbes Billionaires List in 2007 with a net worth of $7.7 billion. He lost $6.4 billion within a year amid rumors of inflated earnings and a cooling property market in Spain, and became a scapegoat figure in the nation's crisis. But in 2011, Spain's highest court cleared Bañuelos of any malfeasance having to do with his company's fall. His real estate company, which he renamed Quabit Inmobiliaria S.A.., still trades on the Spanish stock exchange, but he has been reinventing himself in Brazil. In May 2011 he merged Brazilian real estate group Agre Empreendimentos Imobiliarios S.A. with PDG Realty, one of Brazil's largest builders; he also merged his Brazilian agribusinesses to form Vanguarda Agro. Banuelos has since exited both companies.

name: Billionaires
bio: Returning to the list this year after dropping off in 2009, Carol Jenkins Barnett, the daughter of grocery magnate George Jenkins (d.1996), is chairman of Publix Super Markets and puts her time and money towards children's programs in her native Florida. Since 1991, she's served as president of Publix Super Markets Charities, which donates $25 million each year to nonprofit organizations supporting youth education and the homeless. She and her husband, Barney Barnett, have also donated generously to local childhood literacy programs and high school learning centers.
title: Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Contrarian real estate investor Thomas Barrack founded Colony Capital in 1991 to buy bad real estate loans from busted S&Ls. The firm now manages $34 billion in assets, including $18 billion in 16 commercial real estate and distressed debt-focused funds. The grandson of Lebanese immigrants to Los Angeles, he has built his fortune through buying out-of-favor assets, including some $200 million in Middle East real estate and $534 million in non-performing German real estate loans. Quirkier investments include Michael Jackson's Neverland Ranch and a $24 million loan to photographer Annie Leibowitz.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sara Blakely became the youngest self-made female billionaire in the world in 2012 thanks to the success of Spanx, her reinvention of the girdle. In November 2012 she started rolling out the shapewear brand's first standalone retail stores at upmarket malls on the east coast. She's come a long way since age 29, when she invested her entire life savings, $5,000, trying to come up with something flattering to wear under her white slacks. Six months later the one-time Disney World ride greeter and door-to-door fax machine salesperson found her new line of shaping underwear named one of Oprah Winfrey's Favorite Things. Since then Blakely has taken Spanx from a one-product wonder sold out of her Atlanta apartment to a powerhouse with $250 million in annual revenues and net profit margins estimated at 20%. She owns 100% of the private company, has never advertised and never taken outside investment.

name: Billionaires
bio: A disciple of value investing guru Benjamin Graham, Charles Brandes founded Brandes Investment Partners in 1974. Today the firm manages $27.2 billion, down from $120 billion in March of 2007. Despite the outflows, Brandes' funds continue to perform well, with both the Global Equity fund and the International Equity fund producing double digit returns over the last twelve months. He's a fan of Elton John, who performed at his 2006 wedding to wife Tanya. Through his Tanya & Charles Brandes Foundation, Brandes supports the San Diego Symphony and Elton John's Aids Foundation.
title: Founder & Chairman
employment: {'name': 'Brandes Investment Partners, L.P.', 'title': 'Founder & Chairman', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: As fashion mogul Tory Burch makes her rich list debut, so does her ex-husband, once co-chair of her luxe-bohemian womenswear company. Veteran retailer Chris Burch sold most of his 28.3% stake in Tory Burch LLC (2012 revenues: $800 million) to two new investors in December, putting to rest months of lawsuits and counterclaims that once threatened to detail a future IPO. The trouble between the one-time couple began in 2011 when Chris launched C. Wonder, a preppy clothing chain bearing a striking resemblance to Tory's multi-billion dollar brand, but at a far cheaper price. Chris Burch left the board in 2012, but retained almost a third of the company's shares until his December sale, which values Tory Burch LLC at well over $3 billion. In 2013, Chris sold 10% of C. Wonder to Fidelity Investments for $35 million; the value of his majority stake pushes him over the billionaire mark. His other business interests include investments in phone gadget manufacturer Aliph, which owns popular Bluetooth handset Jawbone; pricey Norwegian artesian bottled water brand Voss and wireless charging outfit Powermat.

name: Billionaires
bio: Queen of the $200 ballet flat Tory Burch joins this year's Forbes Billionaires list thanks to the incredible growth of her preppy-bohemian womenswear brand, which brought in $800 million in revenues in 2012. Burch is the second youngest self-made female billionaire in America (only Spanx inventor Sara Blakely is younger). In December one-time company co-chair Chris Burch, her ex-husband, sold part of his 28.3% stake in Tory Burch LLC, valuing the entire company at well over $3 billion. Now all eyes are on the designer herself, who owns a 28.3% stake and counts Warner Music billionaire Len Blavatnik as one of a handful of high-powered minority investors. A public offering would make her even richer if recent fashion offerings, like Michael Kors', are any indication.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cao Kejian is the chairman of Zhejiang Kaishan Compressor, China's biggest manufacturer of air compressors, including an innovative screw expander that generates electricity from the hot water by-product from mines and chemical refineries. Cao holds a 52% stake in Kaishan, which exports its goods to the U.S., Germany and Japan. Kaishan went public in 2011; its shares have gained more than a third in the past year and are back at their historic highs. Cao is a graduate of the Zhejiang University of Technology.

name: Billionaires
bio: Christopher Chandler founded Dubai-based Legatum Capital after splitting off from his brother, Richard, in 2006 to invest on his own. Legatum is a private, multibillion-dollar investment firm that puts money into companies in developing countries as well as the world's capital markets. The son of a beekeeper from North Island, New Zealand, Chandler and his brother first started taking proceeds from the sale of their parents' department store and investing in Hong Kong real estate. The siblings then formed investment firm Sovereign Global in Monaco to focus on transitioning industries in Russia, Latin America and Eastern Europe. In April 2012, Legatum acquired its own building in the Dubai International Finance Centre.

name: Billionaires
bio: Binod Chaudhary is Nepal's first billionaire but built most of his fortune overseas. His Cinnovation/Chaudhary Group, owns among much else, popular instant noodle brand Wai Wai, a controlling stake in Nepal's Nabil Bank and a string of luxury hotels with India's Taj hotel chain. His grandfather, a textile trader, migrated from Rajasthan and started supplying goods to the erstwhile rulers. His father opened country's first department store. Binod skipped college to join the family trade at age 18. Singapore arm Cinnovation  and other overseas interests are managed by sons Rahul and Varun, both non-residents. Eldest son Nirvana, overseas domestic businesses. A fitness fanatic, Chaudhary goes trekking in the Himalayas every year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chen Jinshi chairs Shenzhen-listed builder and commercial real estate developer Jiangsu Zhongnan Construction Group. Sales in first nine months of 2012 increased 3.6% to $1.3 billion; net profit rose by 11% to $114 million, but its Shenzhen-traded shares have climbed in the past year on hopes for better gains in 2013. Chen's daughter Chen Yuhan chairs Zhongnan's hotel management subsidiary. Chen started his business with 28 workers and $806 in 1988. Today, Zhongnan employs 40,000 people. Chen last year was elected as a member of the National People's Congress.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chen Lip Keong founded gaming company NagaCorp, which has a monopoly on gambling in Phnom Penh. NagaWorld, largest casino in Cambodia, listed in Hong Kong in 2006; controls more than half of the company. Stock price doubled since last year, propelling the former medical doctor to the billionaire ranks for the first time. Last November, he broke ground on Naga2 expansion, to be completed by 2015, which will include two new hotels, restaurants, entertainment complex and shopping area. Also controls Karambunai, a Malaysia-listed property developer and tourism company.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chen Miaolin, a newcomer this year to the Billionaires List, chairs the privately held New Century Hotel Group of Hangzhou, one of China's largest private-sector hotel operators with locations in more than two dozen cities including Beijing, Shanghai and Ningbo. U.S. designer WATG + Wimberly Interiors has worked on some of Chen's projects.

name: Billionaires
bio: Pollyanna Chu says she didn't know very much about stocks and foreign exchange when she returned home to Hong Kong in 1992 after attending college in California and working in the U.S. real estate business.  Yet everything worked out:  She debuts on Forbes Billionaires List this year in part on the value of her shares in Kingston Financial, one of Hong Kong's largest home-grown brokerages, which she runs as CEO with her chairman husband Nicholas.   What's behind her success?  Timing is crucial when seizing an opportunity, as well as networking she recently told Forbes.  To that end, Chu's active in a long list of industry groups in Hong Kong.  She put her instincts about timing on the line last year when she bought a Hong Kong-listed luxury watch distributor Sincere Watch.  Son Kingston is running the business. Time will tell, literally, how that one works out.

name: Billionaires
bio: Alberto Cortina is ex-husband of billionaire heiress Alicia Koplowitz. He and his first cousin, Alberto Alcocer, who married Alicia's sister Esther, ran Construcciones y Contratas (now called FCC), the large industrial company their wives inherited, together from the early 1970s until both marriages ended in 1989. Los Albertos, as they were dubbed by the press, then moved into banking, running Banco Zaragozano. They sold their combined 40% stake to Barclays in 2004. The cousins now hold their wealth in investment arm Alcor Holding, which has stakes in eucalyptus pulp producer Grupo Empresarial ENCE, and construction firm Actividades de Construccion y Servicios. He also has an investment in mines in Africa. Cortina is said to enjoy boating, collecting art, and hunting.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman and CEO of commodities giant Trafigura Beheer BV, Claude Dauphin, joins the billionaire ranks with an estimated net worth of at least $1 billion, as his firm's sales hit $120 billion in 2012, a sixty five per cent increase over the past five years. Dauphin got his start working at Marc Rich AG, now Glencore AG. He left to cofound Trafigura in 1993. Two decades later, Amsterdam headquartered Trafigura remains privately owned by French citizen, Dauphin and over 700 senior managers. The firm, which concentrates on trading oil, metals, ores and bulk commodities, may in the future consider floating Puma Energy, its rapidly expanding fuel station business. After years of allegations about it having mishandled waste on board the Probo Koala within the port of Amsterdam, and subsequent alleged dumping in the Ivory Coast, Trafigura agreed to settle with the Dutch Prosecution Service in November 2012. Neither Trafigura nor its executives accepted any conviction, nor made any admission of liability or guilt as part of this settlement. Through the Trafigura Foundation, Dauphin supports development programs in over 30 countries.
title: Investor

name: Billionaires
bio: A former Arkansas farm boy whose family often didn't have a dollar to spare for movies, Darwin Deason left his small town the day after he graduated high school, with $50 borrowed from his dad and a 1949 Pontiac. He headed for the "bright lights, big city" of Tulsa, Oklahoma and got a job at Gulf Oil.   He eventually joined Dallas data-processing firm MTech and later took it over after all but his division failed. Deason became CEO at age 29, sold MTech in 1988 and within days started Affiliated Computer Services to handle computer and other business process services for clients such as E-ZPass. He eventually took ACS public and then sold it to Xerox for $6.4 billion in 2010. Deason, who is his fifth wife, Katerina, 27 years his junior, is personally now worth $1 billion.

name: Billionaires
bio: Gary Fegel attained billionaire status in May 2011 in the wake of Glencore's IPO. After earning his MBA from the University of St. Gallen, Fegel joined the alumina and aluminum department at the commodities titan in 2001. In 2006 the Swiss national was appointed director of the department, where he now oversees buying, marketing, logistics, hedging and risk management for Glencore's aluminum business. Glencore announced plans to merge with mining outfit Xstrata in February 2012. The proposed all-stock "merger of equals" is currently awaiting regulatory approval in China.

name: Billionaires
bio: David Grainger is the largest individual stockholder of W.W. Grainger, the industrial supply company founded by his father William W. Grainger in Chicago in 1927. David joined the company in 1952 and became a director of it the next year. He served in that capacity until 2007. After he left, a former sales manager accused the company of overbilling the US government in supply contracts. The company settled with the government out of court for $6 million, and admitted no wrongdoing. In February 2013, W.W. Grainger was reported, alongside General Mills, to be a possible buy-up target for Warren Buffet's cash-rich Berkshire Hathaway. The company's stock was recession-proof leading up to and during the financial crisis -- and the value of W.W. Grainger stock  has nearly tripled in the past five years.

name: Billionaires
bio: Vladimir Gruzdev is a businessman-turned-politician. After retiring from the military 20 years ago, Gruzdev began managing several shops for fellow billionaire Oleg Boyko, and later founded supermarkets chain Sedmoi Kontinent.  Gruzdev sold his stake in the company in 2007, before the crisis, to his partner Alexander Zanadvorov. Gruzdev's family continues to control retail network Fashion Continent, owns land near Moscow, and also holds a stake in RGI International, a luxury real estate developer in Moscow. Gruzdev entered politics in 2001 when he was elected to the Moscow City Duma. Two years later he was elected to the State Duma, representing the Chertanovo region of Moscow. He was reelected in 2007 and last year was appointed interim governor of  Tula Oblast, 200 kilometers south of Moscow. According to his tax declaration for 2012, Gruzdev had the biggest income among government officials: his family's annual income was about $130m. While in the Army, he served as an interpreter (he speaks English, Portuguese and Spanish) and in military intelligence. In August 2007 he was part of the crew of the Mir 1 deep-sea diving vessel, which travelled 4261 meters below the North Pole, leaving behind a Russian flag and a time capsule.

name: Billionaires
bio: Donald Hall is chairman of  Hallmark Cards, a company founded by his father Joyce C. Hall (d. 1982) in 1910. Donald took over in 1966 and expanded into Crayons (Crayola), real estate (Crown Center shopping complex) and media (Crown Media Holdings, parent of Hallmark Donald Channel). Son Donald Hall Jr. is president and CEO of Hallmark and son David is president of Hallmark's North American business. The Crayola brand makes 3 billion crayons every year, including 1 billion made using solar power. The Hall Family Foundations gives to Kansas City-area organizations focused on arts and education.

name: Billionaires
bio: Handojo Santosa inherited Ometraco Group from his father, and turned its animal food firm Japfa Comfeed into the second-largest poultry feed producer in the country.  The company's roots date back to a 1871 joint venture in the feed business with a Dutch company. He is the son-in-law of Gustimego, who used to own the tiremaker Gajah Tunggal group. Santosa spends one month a year in Britain, and is based in Singapore. He also supports national chess players through Japfa Chess Club.

name: Billionaires
bio: On again, off again billionaire Gerry Harvey is yet again back in the ranks of the world's richest, thanks to a recent pop of shares of his electronics retailer Harvey Norman. The closest thing to Australia's king of retail, Harvey is a consummate salesman. With partner Ian Norman, he started electrical goods retailer Norman Ross. When that business was taken over, both men quit, later opening Harvey Norman in 1982. Remains chairman of the now publicly traded retail group. Harvey's other passion is horses: he owns part of Magic Millions Thoroughbred auction house and personally owns some 900 horses.

name: Billionaires
bio: Co-founder of erstwhile Royal Brothers, Asok Kumar Hiranandani separated from older sibling Raj Kumar in 2011 after dividing their family property empire in Singapore. The settlement involved properties worth an estimated $1.4 billion. His assets are now housed in privately owned Royal Group Holdings which has built a new corporate headquarters and a 135- room Sofitel So Hotel designed by Karl Lagerfeld, due to open later this year. He recently bought the 144-room Stamford Double Bay Hotel in Sydney for $58 million and is also expanding into Indonesia. The new projects are overseen by son Bobby, whom he's grooming to be his successor.
title: Artist

name: Billionaires
bio: Huang Bingwen, a newcomer to the Billionaires List, is the founder of Shantou Dongfeng Printing, a manufacturer of paper packaging for the tobacco and other industries. Shantou Dongfeng went public on the Shanghai exchange a year ago. Huang stepped down as chairman in 2010. Today, his son Huang Jiaer chairs Dongfeng, while dad serves as a director. Sales in the first nine months of last year rose by 17% to $167 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Huang Maoru chairs Maoye International, one of China's largest retailers with 37 department stores in 18 cities. Maoye has been adding new stores in Shenyang and Nanjing, and its shares are climbing back from their lows in the fall of 2012. The company holds a majority stake in China-listed Bohai Logistics and last year acquired a minority stake in domestically listed retailer Dashang. Huang is a Belize national. Maoye is headquartered in Shenzhen, located just across from the Hong Kong border.

name: Billionaires
bio: Morris Kahn made his fortune as an original investor in Amdocs, a customer-relationship management-and-billing software firm for large telecom outfits. Since Amdocs went public in 1998, he has cashed out nearly $1 billion worth of shares. Kahn now focuses on venture capital and philanthropy in Israel. As principal of Aurum Ventures, he has invested in a dozen emerging life-science and tech companies like Atlantium, which specializes in water disinfection, and N-Trig, which makes a multitouch screen for computers. The firm also invests in other telecom, automotive and renewable energy outfits. Kahn lives on Israel's Mediterranean coast and spends most of his time on a 100-foot yacht. He is a cofounder of Coral World International, a string of aquariums in locations such as the Bahamas and Australia. His son Benjamin is a marine biologist and president of the company.  He helps fund a camp for children with terminal diseases as well as a therapeutic riding camp for the disabled. He further funds cataract surgery in Ethiopia.

name: Billionaires
bio: T.S. Kalyanaraman, founded and chairs Kalyan Jewellers, a 45-store gold jewelry chain in south India. Kalyan earned its name for its range of wedding jewelry and for allowing customers to test the gold they were buying. Hailing from a family of Hindu temple priests, his grandfather opted out of the priesthood to set up a textile mill that was later nationalised. Kalyanaraman started working at the age of 12 in the family's textiles store before setting up his jewelry retailer in 1993 which today has top Bollywood icons as its brand ambassadors.  He's lately diversified into property development.

name: Billionaires
bio: Dmitry Kamenshchik, together with business partner Valery Kogan, owns Domodedovo Airport, the largest in Russia, used by 28 million passengers last year. In spring 2011 the airport's managing company, DME Limited, filed for an IPO in London, but later abandoned the plan. Rumors have been flying that the airport is up for sale. As a Moscow State University philosophy student, Kamenshchik started his business in 1992 by chartering a plane, which flew goods from China to Moscow. Business grew; Kamenshchik built a cargo terminal in Moscow's Domodedovo airport and later took control of the entire airport. After reconstruction in 1999-2000, Domodedovo gained popularity among airlines and became the largest airport in Russia.

name: Billionaires
bio: Kavanaugh joins our list for the first time this year thanks to fellow billionaire Ron Burkle's investment in the 38-year-old's movie studio, Relativity. While most studios focus on huge superhero movies and teen franchises, Kavanaugh is making money by hitting singles and doubles like the recent Safe Haven which cost $25 million to make and has grossed more than $50 million at the box office. Relativity now also has a TV division, sports management and a music department. Up next for Kavanaugh: a big bet on China as the next growth market for his movies.

name: Billionaires
bio: Saban Cemil Kazanci joins his father Ali Metin Kazanci on the billionaires list after his father transferred one third of his shares in Kazanci Holding to him last summer. Kazanci Holding has interests in generator production, natural gas distribution and electricity plant operation. Last year, the group sold 13.3% of its electricity production company traded on the ISE, Aksa Energy, to Goldman Sachs for $240 million. mp3 downloader free download youtube downloader

name: Billionaires
bio: Nasser Khalili is an Iranian-born academic and former art dealer who owns one of the world's largest private collections of Islamic art, with more than 20,000 pieces spanning 1,400 years. Nicknamed the secret sultan, Khalili left Iran before the 1979 revolution and now lives in London as a dual U.S.-British citizen. His collection includes rare Koranic manuscripts, paintings, ceramics, glass, and textiles. When he was a teenager he made his first purchase, of a 19th century Qajar lacquer pen box. Khalili became known as a collector in the '80s. He denied rumors that he was buying on behalf of the Sultan of Brunei. In 2012, Arabian royals in Qatar and Kuwait and private buyers from Europe and Asia supported the top end of the Islamic art market, boosting Khalili's fortune. He also collects Japanese art from the Meiji period, Indian and Swedish textiles, and Spanish metal works. The Khalili Family Trust holds all of his collections. Khalili owns commercial and retail properties in and around London, including in tony Mayfair. He is reportedly building an energy-efficient office block dubbed "The Wave." Khalili is co-founder and chairman of the Maimonides Foundation, a charity that promotes interfaith peace and understanding.

name: Billionaires
bio: The foundation of Victor Kharitonin's wealth is 38% stake in pharmaceutical company Pharmstandard, which today has a market capitalization of more than $3b. Kharitonin began building up this company in 2003, when he together with billionaires Roman Abramovich and Evgeny Shvidler bought from US ICN Pharmaceuticals Russian plants that became the base for Pharmstandard. They spent $55m to buy the plants. In spring of 2007 during IPO in London investors estimated the company at $2.2b. Pharmstandard produces well-known medicine in Russia against the flu - Arbidol. Kharitonin started the business in Novosibirsk where in 1993 he opened intermediary trading company Creditinform. Later in Moscow he founded investment company Profit-House, which worked in the interest of Sibneft shareholders (in particular, it bought pharmaceutical plants for Abramovich and Shvidler). Kharitonin is building a network of private clinics in Russia.

name: Billionaires
bio: Yildirim Ali is the youngest third generation member of the Koc family that has 6 billionaire members. He returns to the billionaires list as the stock price of Koc Holding has risen 30% over the past year. In 2012, he stepped in as Chairman of the Board at Ford Otosan,replacing his father Mustafa who had been at the helm for 40 years. As a result, he gave up the vice presidency of the Fenerbahce Sports Club. His father Mustafa Rahmi Koc, aunts Semahat Arsel and Suna Kirac and brothers Mustafa Vehbi and Mustafa Omer are also billionaires.

name: Billionaires
bio: New Czech billionaire Karel Komarek joins the billionaires list after he cashed out of his family's conglomerate in 2010, and took over the group's oil and gas assets (his father and sister took the machinery division). He got his start in the family trading business in the early 1990s; during the Czech Republic's privatization period, the family bought up shares in oil and gas and machinery companies, uniting them into KKCG group. Now Komarek has taken over Moravske Naftove Doly, the Czech Republic's largest crude oil and gas company and plans to built a new gas tank in cooperation with Russia's Gazprom. Last year, Komarek also purchased the remaining 50% stake of Czech betting company Sazka from former partner and Czech's wealthiest man Petr Kellner for over $300 million. Komarek spends most of his time in Palm Beach, near a mansion owned by Celine Dion.

name: Billionaires
bio: Kong Jian Min is the chairman of KWG Property Holding, a property developer based in Guangzhou. The company's Hong Kong-listed shares have gained on expectations of a recovery in mainland real estate prices this year. KWG said in December it ended the year on a strong note, with pre-sold property transactions of 87,104 square meters, an increase from 35,000 square meters a year earlier. KWG raised $300 million in a bond sale in January. Kong served as a credit officer at the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China in Guangzhou before taking the plunge into entrepreneurship. He holds a degree in computer science from Jinan University in China.

name: Billionaires
bio: The youngest brother of billionaire Koo Bon-Moo, the head of electronics conglomerate LG Corporation, Koo Bon-Sik makes his debut on the Forbes Billionaires list, thanks to strong valuations for Heesung Electronics, where he is president. Heesung is Korea's largest maker of LCD backlight units and a supplier to LG Electronics. Koo Bon-Sik's other brother, Koo Bon-Neung, also a billionaire, is chairman of Heesung.

name: Billionaires
bio: Esther Koplowitz inherited Spanish construction company Fomento de Construcciones y Contratas (FCC) from her late father, Ernesto. Koplowitz serves as vice president of the company, which has undergone a major restructuring since its revenues and stock began a steady and steep decline in 2007 amid the global financial crisis and Spain's economic woes. Esther and her sister Alicia, a billionaire, ran FCC operations jointly from 1989 until 1997 when Esther bought her sister's stake for $800 million. Carlos Slim bought a 25% stake in the company in 2014; Esther now holds 22%, down from 48%. Her daughter, Alicia Alcocer Koplowitz, was appointed chairwoman of subsidiary Cementos Portland Valderrivas in May 2015. Her other daughter Esther Alcocer Koplowitz, is chairwoman of FCC Group. Esther has a private art collection that includes works by Francisco Goya and Camille Pissarro. In 2012 Koplowitz was decorated with a Legion of Honor award from France for her philanthropic and business activities. She now spends most of her time on philanthropic pursuits.

name: Billionaires
bio: Lee Joong-Keun is new to the Forbes Billionaires list. He built his construction company, Booyoung Group, at a time when government policies favored rentals. After he declared bankruptcy in 1979, he put Booyoung shares in his relatives? names so that he could do deals. Starting in 2004 he served a three-year jail term and paid $11.5 million in fines after being convicted for embezzling company funds. Following his release in 2007 he began putting Booyoung shares in his name. Those shares have moved him into the billionaire ranks. Since 2003 he has supported education in Vietnam, Cambodia, Laos and 11 other countries, granting scholarships and providing school supplies. The group bought Muju Resort and Anchor Hotel in Jeju island and recently announced that it will launch a pro baseball team.

name: Billionaires
bio: Lee Seo-Hyun joined the Forbes Billionaires list in 2012, thanks to her inherited stake in Samsung Everland, a company with operations in construction, energy conservation services, and amusement parks. She is the youngest daughter of Samsung Chairman Lee Kun-Hee. A graduate of the Parsons School of Design, she is vice president of the luxury goods and fashion division of Cheil Industries (part of the Samsung Group), as well as a vice president at Cheil Worldwide, Korea's largest advertising firm. Samsung Everland announced this year that it would help to reconstruct the old houses of poor families as part of its corporate social responsibility efforts. Lee's husband is Kim Jae-Youl, president of Samsung Engineering and the younger son of the Donga Newspaper's chairman.

name: Billionaires
bio: Li Zhenjiang is the chairman of China Shineway, one of the country's largest producers of Chinese medicine, mainly for cardiovascular disease and antiviral uses. Sales were $161 million in the first six months of last year. Li guides the company's R&D as well as its overall management. He holds an EMBA degree from the Yangtze Commercial Institute and is the vice-chairman of the PRC's Chinese Medicine Association. The Li family's stake is held in a trust Li Zhenjiang founded.

name: Billionaires
bio: Liang Xinjun returns to the Forbes Billionaires list this year. Born in the city of Taizhou in Zhejiang province on China's east coast, he co-founded Fosun International in 1992 with three other Shanghai-based Fudan University graduates, including fellow billionaire Guo Guangchang. Liang serves as vice chairman and CEO of Fosun, one of China's largest conglomerates, with interests in pharmaceuticals, real estate, steel, mining, retailing and publishing. The Hong Kong-listed company had 42 publicly traded companies worldwide as of December 2012. In October 2012 Fosun's generic drug unit, Fosun Pharmaceutical, listed shares in Hong Kong and raised $512 million. Hainan Ming Co., an iron ore miner and Fosun subsidiary, is planning an IPO on the Shanghai Stock Exchange.

name: Billionaires
bio: Liu Xuejing is the chairman of unlisted GMK Holdings, whose main businesses are chicken processing and copper smelting. GMK supplies chicken to KFC and McDonald's in China and Southeast Asia. Liu is vice president of the China Nonferrous Metals Industry Association. Son Liu Zhiguang, a Cambridge graduate, is GMK's CEO.

name: Billionaires
bio: Monique Louis-Dreyfus is new to the Forbes Billionaires list. Her fortune comes from her reported 12% stake in commodities giant Louis Dreyfus Holdings. Her brother, Robert Louis-Dreyfus, ran the firm until his death in 2009 from leukemia. Her sister-in-law, Margarita, chairs the firm. Relations between Margarita and Robert's two sisters have reportedly been icy since Robert's death. Both Monique and Robert's elder sister, Marie-Jeanne Meyer, have not commented on their plans for their stakes, which Margarita is said to want to buy.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mao Zhongwu's wealth dipped slightly from a year ago amid a drop in the stock prices of flagship Sany Heavy Industry and coal equipment maker Sany Heavy Equipment International. Still, Mao is one of four executives from equipment manufacturer Sany Group to make the 2013 Forbes Billionaires list. The others are along Liang Wengen, Tang Xiuguo and Xiang Wenbo. Mao in October stepped down as chairman of the coal mining equipment manufacturer but is a member of the board. Sany in December moved its headquarters to Beijing in a shift to help speed its overseas expansion; most of its operations will remain in its original home in Changsha. Sany Group suffered a setback in September when the U.S. rejected a Sany-backed application to build a wind farm next to a U.S. military base in Oregon. The U.S. bad press contrasts with Sany's successful teaming up with CITIC Private Equity Advisors of China to purchase Putzmeister of Germany, one of the world's largest concrete pump manufacturers, in a deal worth $475 million earlier last year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Marie-Jeanne Meyer is new to the Forbes Billionaires list. Her fortune comes from her reported 12% stake in commodities giant Louis Dreyfus Holdings. Her brother, Robert Louis-Dreyfus, ran the firm until his death in 2009 from leukemia. Her sister-in-law, Margarita, chairs the firm. Relations between Margarita and Robert's two sisters have reportedly been icy. Both Marie-Jeanne and Robert's younger sister, Monique Louis-Dreyfus, have not commented on their plans for their stakes, which Margarita is said to want to buy. Meyer also has a private equity firm, Florac. Together with LVMH's private equity arm, Florac owns a controlling stake in Groupe SMCP. The firm owns Parisian fashion brands including Maje and Claudie Pierlot.
title: President of PE firm Florac
