name: Billionaires
bio: Third generation diamantaire and jeweller Nirav Modi, aspires to be the Laurence Graffe of India. He made a splash in 2010 when his Lotus necklace with a rare Golconda diamond was auctioned by Christie's for $3 million. His salon in Mumbai, decorated with artworks from his private collection, attracts a super-rich clientele. Modi grew up in Belgium, dropped out of Wharton and moved to India in 1990 to work with his uncle in the diamond trade. In 1999, he struck out on his own to set up Firestar International Group, which today has revenues of $900 million and manufacturing units in India, Russia, Armenia and South Africa. It owns American bridal jewellery retailer A.Jaffe and sells to the American armed forces.

name: Billionaires
bio: Marcos Antonio Molina dos Santos is new to the Forbes Billionaires list. He has been working in the beef sector since the age of 16, when he opened his first business. He is now chairman of the board of directors of Marfrig, the company he founded. After many acquisitions it has become one of Brazil's three largest food company. The company operates 183 processing plants, distribution centers, feedlots and offices in 17 countries worldwide. In 2012, as China surpassed the U.S. as Brazil's main commercial partner, Marfig became the first Brazilian company authorized to export pork products to China .

name: Billionaires
bio: Oil and gas wildcatter William "Tex" Moncrief Jr. made perhaps the biggest find of his life in January 2010 with the offshore field "Davy Jones," which holds up to 6 trillion cubic feet of gas. Moncrief Offshore LLC owns 10% of the platform and exploration. Production was originally expected to begin in early 2012, but as of fall 2012 production testing was still in the works. Now 92, Moncrief got his start when he was 10, when his father, W. A. "Monty" Moncrief Sr. (d. 1986), discovered a 6-billion-barrel East Texas oilfield. In 1939 Tex wanted to quit school and become a pro golfer, but his father talked him out of it. He is a football fan and benefactor of both the University of Texas and Texas Christian University.

name: Billionaires
bio: Despite continuing to give away Cisco shares to family foundations, former Cisco CEO John Morgridge still maintains a 10-figure fortune. After falling off the Forbes 400 in 2012, Morgridge makes our 2013 billionaire list thanks to a rally in Cisco shares, which are up nearly 10% from August to mid-February. A former Honeywell executive, Morgridge became chief of networking firm Cisco in 1988. He took Cisco public in 1990, stepped down in 1995 and became a billionaire the next year as the company's stock continued to climb. He now serves as Cisco's chairman emeritus. An avid philanthropist with his wife, Tasha, he's given numerous gifts to his alma maters the University of Wisconsin, where he went for undergrad, and Stanford University, where he received his M.B.A.
title: Chairman Emeritus

name: Billionaires
bio: Yoshiko Mori is the wife of Minoru Mori, who passed away last year; she inherited part of Minoru's estate. Minoru, with his brother, Akira, had inherited his initial fortune from their father but then each brother went his own way to pursue his preferred strategy. Minoru was the one known for his grandiose projects: he built Tokyo's swank Roppongi Hills as well as China's tallest building, the Shanghai World Financial Center. Company benefiting from uptick in real estate. Yoshiko chairs the Mori Art Museum.

name: Billionaires
bio: Israeli Marius Nacht co-founded cybersecurity firm Check Point Software with former Forbes cover boy Gil Shwed. As the story goes he both programmed code and fetched the soda. Media-shy Nacht still serves on the executive board. Nacht is a veteran of Talpiot, an elite division of Israeli army. He has degrees Physics and Mathematics from the Hebrew University of Jerusalem and in Electrical Engineering and Communication Systems from Tel Aviv University in 1987.

name: Billionaires
bio: Akio Nitori is the founder and president of Nitori, the biggest discount home furnishings retailer in Japan with 270 large furniture stores. The company's share price is down 4% over the past year as the weak yen drove up product costs and hurt the bottom line. To spur sales, Nitori announced price cuts of 10% to 40% on hundreds of items last November; the company also launched a handful of small Deco Home shops to reach new customers.

name: Billionaires
bio: Park Hyeon-Joo is new to the Forbes Billionaire list but may not hold onto his spot for long. His insurance firm, Mirae Asset Life, could face sanctions by South Korean regulators over breaches in accounting standards. The country's Financial Supervisory Service is reportedly expected to slap fines on several firms, including his, for artificially boosting dividend payouts to shareholders. There are also rumors of internal turmoil at Mirae after Koo Jae-sang, one of Park's trusted staff, quit as CEO of Mirae Global Investments in November 2012. Nicknamed ?Finance Founder,? Park got his start working at a finance firm before founding South Korea's first funds management company. In March 2012 he got approval to set up an asset management company in China. That same month he merged his Mirae Asset Management and Mirae Asset Maps Management.

name: Billionaires
bio: Stephen Saad, who is new to the Forbes Billionaires list, co-founded Aspen Pharmacare in 1997 and proceeded to turn it into the largest publicly-traded drug manufacturer on the Johannesburg Stock Exchange. In early 2012, Aspen's revenues took a hit as new generic drug manufacturers entered the market. But Aspen shares have soared in the past year, turning Saad into a billionaire as his company formed relationships with global pharma innovators, which often see generic companies as rivals. Now GlaxoSmithKline is Aspen's largest shareholder. Saad became a millionaire at age 29 after he sold his share in the drug business Covan Zurich for $3 million. In 2011 Aspen purchased the global rights to manufacture some of GSK's smaller brands. Saad spends his free time at Exeter, his private game reserve at Sabi Sands, which is adjacent to Kruger National Park, the largest national park in South Africa.

name: Billionaires
bio: Dilek Sabanci, a newcomer to the Forbes billionaires list, is an heir to the Sabanci family fortune. She chairs Vista Tourism and Travel, which she founded in 1989, and serves as a board member of the Sabanci Foundation. Her sister, Sevil Sabanci Sabanci, is a board member of the family's Sabanci Holding, whose value has skyrocketed over the past year. The group's stake in Akbank increased more than 20% in the 12 months since February 2012. Dilek is handicapped and devotes her time to various causes working with mentally impaired children; she chairs the board of the Turkish Special Olympics and also helped sponsor the Dilek Sabanci Sports School.

name: Billionaires
bio: Newcomer to the list, Sevil Sabanci Sabanci, is a board member of the family's Sabanci Holding whose value has skyrocketed this year. The group's stake in Akbank is worth 21% more over the past twelve months. The trained equestrian owns stables in Istabul. She is joined by her sister, and new billionaire, Dilek Sabanci, on the billionaires list this year, along with other members of the family.

name: Billionaires
bio: Washington Redskins owner Dan Snyder rode rookie sensation Robert Griffin III to his team's first winning season and playoff appearance in five years. His Redskins are the NFL's third-most-valuable team. Red Zone Capital, Snyder's private equity firm, agreed to sell its stake in Dick Clark Productions to Guggenheim Partners for $370 million in September 2012. A University of Maryland dropout, he made his first million at age 20 by selling advertising at colleges. He built his wealth with his marketing company, Snyder Communications, which he sold off in 2000.

name: Billionaires
bio: San Diego Chargers owner Alexander Spanos fired his longtime coach and general manager this year after the team missed the playoffs for the third straight season. He founded a catering company in 1951 with an $800 loan after working at his parents' bakery. Spanos funneled profits into real estate, building A.G. Spanos companies into one of the country's largest apartment developers. He bought a controlling stake in the Chargers in 1984. His son Dean is now the team's chairman and president. In 2013 Spanos will celebrate 65 years of marriage to his wife Faye.
title: CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: Harjo Sutanto is new to the Forbes Billionaires list. His fortune comes from his 40% stake in Wings Group, the consumer goods company that he co-founded with fellow billionaire Eddy Katuari's late father, Ferdinand. While Katuari runs Wings, Sutanto's children work in the group in various capacities. In December 2012 the company agreed to work with Japanese snackmaker Calbee Inc and Itochu Corporation, a Japanese conglomerate that owns LeSportsac and part of Dean & Deluca, to manufacture snacks in Indonesia. The joint venture will include a production plant slated to begin operations in March 2014.

name: Billionaires
bio: Alain Taravella is the founder of $3.5 billion (property portfolio value) Altarea Cogedim, France's third-largest retail property firm. He is currently the group's Chairman and CEO. In 1994, he started Altarea SA, a real estate firm focused on developing shopping centers. He took his firm public in 2004, acquired Cogedim three years later, and formed Altarea Cogedim Group, with interests in residential, commercial and enterprise property development markets. The company operates primarily in France and Italy.

name: Billionaires
bio: Alexander Tedja is known as the king of Surabaya's property and shopping malls. His three-decade-old Pakuwon Group owns the largest retail mall in East Java and big residential projects in both East and West Surabaya. The group has expanded into Jakarta with two projects in the capital. It also owns the largest integrated mixed-use development in South Jakarta, Superblock Gandaria City. Known for good relations with tenants, the company has high occupancy rates in its malls. It expects 2013 revenues to increase 70% over 2012 and is planning three new projects in Surabaya. Tedja's daughter Irene is married to the son of billionaire Murdaya Poo.

name: Billionaires
bio: Jim Thompson started out in the moving business in Japan but then switched to Hong Kong. His Crown Worldwide is now a global logistics company with expected 2012 revenue of $850 million. Crown does business in 55 countries. One target for expansion last year: Ulaanbaatar in Mongolia. Through a European acquisition in 2011, Crown is also expanding in the art and collectibles business. He makes his return to the Billionaires List after last appearing among the ranks in 2008.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sergei Tsikalyuk is the largest shareholder in VSK, one of Russia's biggest commercial insurers. In 2011 he sold a 25% stake in VSK to RESO, the group owned by billionaire brothers Nikolay and Sergey Sarkisov, for $220 million. Last year it became known that the deal may include insurance company Soglasiye, owned by Mikhail Prokhorov. The merged company may become the biggest player in the insurance market in Russia. Tsikalyuk graduated from military school and served 16 years in the Army; he retired in 1992 at the rank of colonel. That same year he founded Military Insurance Company (VSK), which initially provided health and life insurance for army personnel. In 2002 AIG announced interest in buying VSK, but the army was against the deal. Tsikalyuk then broadened his company into a general insurance firm; today half its portfolio comes from car insurance deals.

name: Billionaires
bio: Max Turnauer, new to Forbes' billionaire ranks this year, is the son of entrepreneur Herbert Turnauer, who founded Constantia Industries in Vienna, Austria in 1969. Constantia owns four companies, including FunderMax, which specializes in timber products and decorative laminates, and Isosport, which makes plastic composite materials for the ski and snowboard industries. Revenues for the group were more than $1.1 billion in 2011 (868 million Euros)  The holding company previously traded on the Vienna exchange but was taken private in 2004. Max Turnauer is no longer involved in the management; he is ambassador of the Order of Malta in Liechtenstein. His son, Stanislaus, is CEO of Constantia Industries. Isovoltaic, which makes the backing for solar modules and is also owned by Turnauer, was slated to go public in 2011 but failed to do so due to lack of investor interest.

name: Billionaires
bio: John Van Lieshout is new to the Forbes World's Billionaires list. Based in Brisbane, he made his fortune selling his Super A-Mart discount furniture chain in 2006 while keeping the stores' buildings. Those properties provide the steady rental income he is using to invest in real estate development, especially in residential property. On the hunt for new investments, he's targeting undervalued Queensland houseware stores. A Dutch native, he arrived in Australia at age 14.

name: Billionaires
bio: Murat Vargi is the founder of Turkey's largest cell phone operator, Turkcell, whose stock price is up 12% over the past year. He also established MV Holding, which makes investments in the energy and tourism sectors and owns a stake in KVK, the biggest mobile phone retail network in Turkey. His Dost Enerji entered the renewable energy market in 2007; it now has a 10% share of Turkey's wind power market.

name: Billionaires
bio: Andrey Verevskiy started trading in grain when he was 19; founded Kernel Holding a decade later growing it into Ukraine's largest sunflower oil producer. He took the company public in 2007, netting $300 million; the company's stock price is down 7% over the past year. Verevskiy is turning to Russia for growth, acquiring  two oil extracting factories and a port terminal with plans to start grain export from Russia. Last year, Verevskiy was elected to Ukraine's Parliament as a delegate from the Party of Regions which supports Ukraine's current president Viktor Yanukovich.

name: Billionaires
bio: Indian property magnate Jitendra Virwani debuts on list after snatching some of the biggest private equity deals in real estate for his Bangalore-headquarted Embassy Property Developments. Last July, private equity firm Blackstone bought 49% stake in its commercial property portfolio for $200 million. Recently, Blackstone, Embassy and HDFC Bank's property fund invested a third each in a business park in the city for $360 million. Virwani, who got a start in his father's construction business as a teenager, set up Dynasty Developers in 1993 with $50,000 borrowed from friends. He later renamed the firm as Embassy, a brand now synonymous with Bangalore's sprawling tech and business parks housing multinationals like IBM, Nokia and Yahoo. A horse lover, he owns one of the country's largest private riding academies.

name: Billionaires
bio: Tech entrepreneur Wang Jianyi is new to the Forbes Billionaires list. He is the founder and chairman of Zhejiang-based Futong Group, one of China's largest manufacturers of fiber optic cable products and a major supplier of cable to the country's biggest telecoms, including China Mobile, China Unicom, and China Telecom. Company revenue climbed 45% in 2011 to $1.4 billion (8.73 billion yuan). In the first half of 2012, revenue increased by 13.2% to $690 million (4.3 billion yuan). Net income in the same period also grew 30.5% to $37.5 million (2.33 billion yuan). Wang owns 80% of the private company. Its strong performance in 2012 made him a billionaire. He founded Futong Telecommunication Materials Co. in 1987 and began manufacturing fiber optic cables in 1993. Today it employs more than 5,000 people and generates $1.4 billion a year in sales. Wang is a member of Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference.
title: Entrepreneur

name: Billionaires
bio: Wang Yiting is a newcomer to the Billionaires List this year. Wang is the chairman of privately held Inner Mongolia Taixi Coal Group, one of the largest coal mining companies in China, with sales of more than $1 billion in the first nine months of 2012. He rose through the ranks of a business that eventually became Taixi in the 1980s and 1990s, holding both management and Communist Party representative jobs. Today, he owns half of Taixi.

name: Billionaires
bio: Wen Jianping is a newcomer to the Billionaires List this year. Wen is chairman of Beijing Origin Water Technology, a sewage and wastewater treatment company he cofounded with other Chinese students after graduating in 2001 with a doctorate from Australia's University of New South Wales. The company, 25% owned by Wen, listed on the Shenzhen exchange in 2010. Net profit last year rose as much as 80% from $55.6 million in 2011, according to a preliminary company estimate.

name: Billionaires
bio: Wu Chong-yi makes it back onto the Forbes Billionaires List for a second year in a row. His current post is chairman of Fine Blanking, a Taiwan manufacturer of auto and motorcycle parts, yet his main source of wealth comes from Hong Kong-listed beverage maker Tingyi, whose four founding Wei brothers are also all members of our list this year. Wu attended the University of California in Los Angeles.

name: Billionaires
bio: Xiang Wenbo is frequently the public voice among the quartet of billionaires who run equipment manufacturer Sany Group. Like the others--Liang Wengen, Mao Zhongqu and Tang Xiuguo--his wealth is down from a year ago amid a drop in the share prices of domestically traded flagship Sany Heavy Industry and Hong Kong-listed mining equipment maker Sany Heavy Equipment International. Sany suffered a setback in September when the U.S. rejected a Sany-backed application to build a wind farm next to a U.S. military base in Oregon. The U.S. bad press contrasts with Sany's successful teaming up with CITIC Private Equity Advisors of China to purchase Putzmeister of Germany, one of the world's largest concrete pump manufacturers, in a deal worth $475 million earlier last year. Sany in December moved its headquarters from Changsha to Beijing in a step to facilitate its international growth. Xiang, who is frequently the public voice of Sany, is a graduate of Dalian University of Technology with a master's degree in molding.

name: Billionaires
bio: Takao Yasuda founded discount retailer Don Quijote in 1980, remains chairmand and CEO leading the company's global expansion. The stock price is up 38% over the past year on strong sales and profits. In February, Yasuda sold 3 million shares to improve the company's liquidity as he readies to invest in China and North America. The former amateur boxer claims to have spent much of his time at Keio University playing mah-jongg.

name: Billionaires
bio: Larry Yung's wealth stems largely from his minority stake in CITIC Pacific, an offshoot of government-controlled China International Investment and Trust Corp. Yung hails from one of China's most colorful clans. His grandfather Rong Desheng was one of Shanghai's most successful businesspeople before the Communist revolution. His father Rong Yiren stayed behind afterward, while much of the family went abroad, and rose to become a guiding hand of economic reform after Deng Xiaoping consolidated power in the 1980s. Larry went to Hong Kong to develop CITIC Pacific. Yung resigned as chairman in 2009 amid a financial crisis.

name: Billionaires
bio: Zan Shengda has seen his wealth slip over the past year due to poor results at his Shanghai-listed Jiangsu Zongyi. Revenue plunged by 41% to $92.5 million in the first three quarters of last year; net profit fell an even steeper 64% to $18 million on falling prices for its photovoltaic products. Looking for new business, Jiangsu Zongyi announced it would take a minority stake in China International Futures, China's biggest futures company. Zan, who holds an EMBA degree from Tsinghua University, also invests in spirits, dairy and software.

name: Billionaires
bio: Charles Zegar rejoins the Forbes Billionaires list after a three-year absence thanks to rising revenues at Bloomberg LP. Sales of $7.9 billion in 2012 put Zegar back alongside fellow billionaires and co-founders of the financial data giant, Michael Bloomberg and Thomas Secunda. Zegar earned his master's degree in computer science at NYU, then built the first software for Bloomberg's famous terminals. The low-profile son of a subway conductor was widowed young but remarried in 2001; he and second wife Merryl Snow Zegar are signatories of the Gates / Buffett Giving Pledge. They donate to Jewish causes and inner city education, among other interests, via their Zegar Family Foundation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Jailed Chinese businessman Zhang Keqiang returns to billionaire status this year thanks to a surge in shares of Poly Real Estate, China's second biggest property developer by market capitalization. A cofounder of Poly Real Estate Group, Zhang owns more than 200 million shares in the company, which is the main source of his wealth. He also owns valuable stakes in other listed companies, including Qinghai Salt Lake Industry Group, China's leading potash producer. That successful investment has also brought him some misery. In January 2011, Zhang was arrested by local police on charges of defrauding the state when he bought stakes in Qinghai Salt Lake. After two years in jail, Zhang is still awaiting judgment for his case in trial court.
